*Scroll Eleven of the Records of Mount Mao begins: A Record of the Succeeding Patriarchs, composed by Liu Dabin.*

**Scroll Eleven: A Record of the Succeeding Patriarchs**

**The Eleventh Patriarch:**
The Venerable Master of the Upper Records, Inspector of Immortals, Tang State Preceptor, Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, posthumously titled Master Tixuan, bore the surname Pan, the personal name Shizheng, and the courtesy name Zizhen. He hailed from Zongcheng in Bei Prefecture.

His father, Pan Zhen, served as Prefect of Tong Prefecture during the Sui, while his mother, née Lu, was skilled in eloquent discourse on renowned principles. She fed him the *Dao De Jing* from her own mouth. After her death, he built a hut by her grave and was renowned for his filial piety.

During the Daye era, a Daoist named Liu Aidao saw him and marveled, saying: *"A steed of three aspirations—who but you could ride it?"* At the time, the Dharma Master Wang was held in high esteem by Emperor Yang, often entering the palace to personally offer pine resin and spring water for blessings. Aidao said: *"I deeply wish for you to follow me, yet to accomplish the work of the Dao, none but the Dharma Master will suffice."* Thus, he became a disciple of the Dharma Master and returned with him to Mount Mao.

One day, the Dharma Master said to him: *"Songyang is the place for your cultivation of the True—you must hasten there without doubt."* The Master then entered the valley between the twin springs of Zhong Ridge, dwelling there for over a decade before venturing deeper into Xiaoyao Valley, where he became utterly secluded from the world.

In the third year of the Shangyuan era, Emperor Gaozong visited the eastern capital and paid homage at Mount Song. He summoned the Master and requested talismanic writings, but the Master declined, claiming no knowledge of them. The Emperor then asked what he needed in the mountains. The Master replied: *"Lush pines and pure springs are all I require—these are not lacking here."* The Emperor was struck with admiration.

At the beginning of the Tiaolu era, when the Emperor again performed sacrifices at Mount Song, he visited Xiaoyao Valley. There, he saw a rattan couch overgrown with creeping figs, nearly rotted away, with no utensils for fire or grain—only two gourds holding green-tinged congee. Moved, he ordered the immediate construction of Chongtang Abbey on the spot.

The following spring, he had the Master conveyed by palanquin to the western palace in Luoyang and urgently renamed Songyang Abbey as Fengtian Palace. Whenever the Emperor composed music, he would present the names of the Master’s disciples for consultation, and from then on, the imperial carriage frequently traversed the mountain passes. While in Luoyang, the Emperor summoned the Master again for an audience. When the Master requested to return, the Emperor composed a poem to see him off.

The Master once told his disciples: *"Truly, I have no use for meeting emperors, for it disturbs the sacred mountains. If you study the Dao without wearying of its profound mysteries, you will be free of encumbrances."*

On the fourteenth day of the sixth month in the first year of the Yongchun era, he asked for a bath. Writing a green talisman, he placed it in the water, saying: *"This will remain cold for a lifetime."* At the time, a stone chamber was being built beneath the northern cliff, nearly complete.

On the sixteenth day, he suddenly declared: *"I depart, I depart."*

The disciple Han Wenli asked where he was going, and he replied: *"To Mount Tai to inspect merits and virtues."* With these words, clouds of qi enveloped the courtyard, and in an instant, he shed his mortal form at the age of ninety-eight.

In an imperial edict, the Empress Dowager proclaimed: *"Last winter’s late season saw the carriage of the Xuanyuan Emperor unsummoned. This autumn’s early days find the abode of Guangcheng once more empty."*

In the second year of the Shengli era, a stele was erected on Mount Song.

**Eulogy:**
A talent beyond the world,
All yearned to befriend him.
The path of immortality is fixed—
Who would dare abandon it for private ends?
Lush p

A phoenix-like crow once descended upon his incense table, its talon marks forming the characters: *"Perfected One of the Upper Records of the Eastern Flower."* Thereafter, his conduct grew ever more numinous. Emperor Xuanzong, struck by wonder, dispatched envoys to summon him, compelling him to reside in the Yang Terrace Abbey built upon Mount Wangwu. One day, moved by the Celestial Emperor’s call, he came to the mountain to pay homage at the Hua Yang Grotto-Heaven. There he composed the *Stele of Purity and Simplicity*, secretly inscribing upon it that Wangwu’s Lesser Existence Heaven was the central precinct of the Assembly of Perfected Ones: *"Its vital qi is secluded and reverent, its spirits gather in splendor. If our Dao is to flourish, what could be impossible? Soaring and alighting at will, I resolve to make this my final abode."*

Later, at the abbey’s northern ridge, where the heights reached their utmost and the boundaries grew most remote, he discovered the Central Rock Terrace—directly aligned with the Heavenly Altar above, encircled by long mounds below, embraced by colossal trees, with murmuring streams flowing through its midst. Here, for days uncounted, he nurtured dragons in the great valleys, kept cranes upon the central peaks, burned myriad incenses in the Golden Grotto, and inhaled the pure qi from the Stone Window. He composed the *Discourse on Sitting in Forgetfulness* and compiled the *Twelve Secret Essentials of Cultivating Perfection*, which became the companion text to the *Secrets of the Reclusive Perfected*. Yet fearing the emperor’s favor might endure too long, he relocated to Jade Cloud Peak on Mount Tiantai, there to await his ascension.

The court then compelled the construction of Tongwu Abbey, where the master inscribed the *Dao De Jing* in full with his five limbs. On the eighteenth day of the sixth month in the *yihai* year of the Kaiyuan era, he suddenly told his attendants: *"I have received an appointment in the Mystic Capital and may no longer remain."* He then arranged his seals and fastenings as if preparing for a distant journey. By dusk, a crimson cloud swirled down to earth, bearing the clear strains of celestial pipes. All who witnessed this were awestruck, certain he would ascend. Rushing to his chamber, they found only his discarded form.

Emperor Xuanzong’s imperial stele stands atop the Tongwu summit.

**Eulogy:**
Utterly numinous, merging with the Void,
Responding to all things without bound.
Forcibly named *Sitting in Forgetfulness*—
It dissolves the dust of mortal form.
Lofty winds in the Flowery Grove,
Dawn’s light on the Cinnabar Terrace.
No teacher beyond Penglai’s seas—
Returning, he sought Mount Tiantai.

**Thirteenth Patriarch:**
Perfected One of the Upper Records, Tang State Preceptor, Grand Master for Proper Consultation, Master of Mystic Serenity—his surname was Li, personal name Han’guang, a native of Jiangdu in Guangling. His original surname was Hong, changed to avoid the taboo of Empress Wu Zetian. His family had long followed the Confucian path. His father, Xiaowei, was styled Master of Purity and Reclusion and was deeply versed in the arts of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi.

At the beginning of the Shenlong era, the Master was ordained as a Daoist on account of his aspiration and conduct, residing at Longxing Abbey. In the seventeenth year of the Kaiyuan reign, he followed Master Sima to Mount Wangwu. At first sight, Sima declared, “A true guest of jade-like aspiration!” He dwelt in Songyang for over twenty years. When Sima Zhen traveled, Emperor Xuanzong summoned the Master to court for an audience. Sighing, the emperor said, “In seeing Han’guang, I know that Perfected One Sima yet remains in the world.” One day, the emperor inquired about the golden crucible. The Master replied, “The Dao and virtue are public; light ascent is but a private matter within the public. If one neglects the Dao and virtue to pursue life and indulge desires, it is like striking the wind.” Xuanzong was deeply moved and marveled at this. He issued an edict for the Master to reside at Yangtai Abbey. After more than a year, the Master claimed illness and begged to return to Mount Juqu to compile scriptures and methods. In the twelfth month of the fourth year of the Tianbao reign, the emperor dispatched an imperial envoy bearing a jade-sealed edict to summon him. Upon arrival, the Master was lodged within the palace precincts. Whenever the emperor wished to consult him, he would first purify himself through fasting and bathing. When the emperor requested transmission of the Daoist methods, the Master declined on account of illness, and the emperor did not press him further. He again sought to return to the mountains. Thereupon, the emperor specially bestowed the former residence of Yang and Xu—Ziyang Abbey—for his dwelling. The emperor composed a poem to see him off, and further prohibited hunting, fishing, and the gathering of plants within the mountain, while those who consumed meat or blood were barred from entry. At the time, many authentic scriptures and sacred traces had already scattered and been lost. The Master, in accordance with imperial decree, searched and collected them, presenting the recovered treasures to the throne. The emperor further ordered the mountain recluse Wang Ai to request the Master’s standard script for thirteen pages of the *Upper Scripture*, to supplement what was missing. On the eighteenth day of the third month in the seventh year, Xuanzong received the catalog of the Three Caverns’ scriptures in the Datong Hall, paying distant reverence to the Master as his preceptor. He bestowed upon him the title *Master of Mystic Serenity* and a set of ritual robes, fulfilling the rites of master and disciple. An edict was issued to carve a stele at Huayang Grotto Abbey to commemorate the event. The emperor twice summoned the Master to court, but each time he requested retirement and returned. When he performed rituals for the state, auspicious signs such as sweet dew and sacred fungi repeatedly appeared.

On the fourteenth day of the eleventh month in the fourth year of the Dali reign (769), the year *jiyou*, he shed his mortal form at the Ziyang Retreat, aged eighty-seven. He was posthumously enfeoffed as *Grand Master of the Left Mystic* and conferred the title *Grand Master for Proper Consultation*.

**Eulogy:**
The distinction between public and private,
The words and names of the Supreme Dao—
Though spoken, none heeded;
Repeatedly, the sovereign’s grace was bestowed.
Thirteen pages of the *Upper Scripture*,
Exquisitely mending what was lost.
Inscribed in stele and record,
His merit stands peerless.

**Fourteenth Patriarch of the Lineage:**
The *Master of the Upper Realm, Immortal Lord, and Perfected One of the Great Cavern in the Zhengyuan Era*, surnamed Wei, personal name Jingzhao, was a native of Yanling in Danyang and a sixteenth-generation descendant of Wu, the Minister of Works Shen. Though he mastered Confucian learning, he refused to pursue official rank, instead devoting himself to the study of immortals and transcendents. In his early years, he was ordained at the Xunzhen Abbey in Yanling, taking Master Bao Shirong as his teacher. Shirong’s master was Bao Fazheng of Chongxuan Abbey; Fazheng’s master was Bao Fangguang; Fangguang’s master was Wang Gui; and Gui’s master was Wang Fazhu, the *Master of Ascending Perfection*. He specialized in the scriptures and methods of the *Lingbao* tradition and later resided at the Suming Abbey in Chang’an. During the Tianbao era, he was ordered to attend Master Xuanjing and returned to Mount Mao. After the upheaval, he established the Ziyang Abbey and took up residence there. At the beginning of the Dali reign, he received the orthodox transmission of the *Xuanjing* scriptures and talismans. From the reigns of Suzong and Daizong onward, as the realm fell into chaos, he alone took the Dao as his duty. In the first year of the Zhenyuan era (785), on the day *guimao* of the eleventh month, he summoned his disciples and said: *"Yesterday, I saw an immortal official bearing a summons, appointing me* Master of the Upper Realm*. I shall no longer remain in this world. Why rejoice at coming? Why grieve at going? You must embody this truth—do not mourn."*

At the age of ninety-two, he passed away.

**Eulogy:**
The spirit rides the void and is born,
The utmost numinous is its treasure.
As worldly dust swirls in chaos,
He alone preserved stillness.
When the time came to return to emptiness,
I knew where his归宿 lay.
No joy in coming,
No sorrow in going.

**The Fifteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Cavernous Truth, surnamed Huang, personal name Dongyuan, was a native of Mount Nanyue. In his early years, he traveled to Huayang, where he became a fellow student and friend of Master Xuanjing. He once received the method of ingesting the solar essence of the Central Yellow while wearing yellow robes. Later, he entered Wuling and resided at the Peach Blossom Abbey. There was a youth named Xiang Ting from Chenxi who came to serve him with great reverence. One day, after wandering alone, the youth returned and told the master: *"Within the Peach Blossom Spring, there is a watery cavern where flowers and trees exude fragrance. The cavern chambers wind around the stream, and many five-colored stones lie within. I found one shaped like a tortoise—when I pulled its head, its tail moved in response."* The master stored it in his scripture case, but after ten days, it vanished. Another day, they agreed to go together, but the waters had risen, and the stream and cavern were lost, their whereabouts unknown.

In the summer of the eighth year of the Dali era (773), on the last day of the fifth month, the youth took leave of the master, saying: *"We shall meet again at Juqu."* The following year, the master moved to Purple Cloud Peak on Mount Lu, where he dwelt for ten years. He then returned to the mountain and resided at the Lower Ji Palace, reciting the *Scripture of the Great Cavern* daily. He inherited the teachings of Patriarch Wei and spent another eight years there. One day, the youth Xiang Ting arrived, but the master had just gone out with his staff. Xiang Ting did not wait. When the master returned and heard his name, he was greatly startled. He changed his robes, lit incense, and prostrated toward the void. After standing motionless for a long while, he passed away—only his empty garments remained. Emperor Dezong marveled at this and posthumously bestowed a title upon the master. He lived to ninety-five.

**Eulogy:**
Gazing at the sun, he attained the Dao,
His knowledge was most true.
With Xiang Ting’s arrival,
The Peach Blossom Spring began its spring.
The five-colored stone tortoise,
Head moving, tail responding—
Suddenly it vanished,
A wondrous sign of the profound mystery.

**The Sixteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Luminous Mystery, surnamed Sun, personal name Zhizhi, was of unknown origin. In infancy, he recoiled at the scent of meat and fish. When he grew older, he accepted only wine. He left his family and entered the mountains, becoming a disciple of Master of Cavernous Truth.

In the sixth year of the Dahe era, he served as the master of ceremonies for the mountain monastery. In the seventh year, he memorialized the throne to strictly prohibit the hunting and fishing of creatures in all four seasons and to abolish the use of sacrificial animals in rituals, presenting apocryphal scriptures and erecting stone steles. The Duke of Weiguo at Ziyang Abbey, Li Deyu, revered the master and once composed a poem in his honor.

In the first year of the Huichang era under Emperor Wuzong, he was summoned to conduct the *Shengshen* Fast, where he constructed a nine-tiered precious altar to perform the Daoist rites, and was consequently bestowed a title. At the time of his liberation, the assembly witnessed amidst wind and rain a great fish with golden scales and jade mane; the master mounted it and ascended beyond the Great Peak, though the exact date remains unknown.

**Eulogy:**
To consume flavors is to nourish the form,
To consume qi is to nourish the spirit.
The cauldron and chopping block harm life,
Enduring this injures benevolence.
I esteem the Mother of Nourishment,
No need to borrow from without.
Gazing upon his demeanor, who felt it—
Could they grasp its meeting?

**The Seventeenth Patriarch:**
National Master of Tang, Master of Rare Subtlety, surnamed Hao, personal name Fatong, was a native of Danyang in Runzhou. Possessing literary talent, he sat for the imperial examinations but met with no success, and so came to the mountain. Master of Luminous Mystery ordained him as a Daoist and transmitted to him all the scriptures and methods.

In his youth, when Luminous Mystery transformed amidst wind and rain, the master attained profound enlightenment. In the second year of Qianfu during the reign of Emperor Xizong, he was dispatched as an emissary to receive the Great Cavern Register, and was honored from afar with the title of "Initiating Master," bestowed with the honorific "Master." In the fourth year of Tianyou, at the age of eighty-three, foreseeing the turmoil of the world, he concealed himself in a mountain cavern and vanished without a trace.

**Eulogy:**
When the world teeters on peril,
The wise depart from it.
Yet that Perfected One,
Moved to profound sorrow,
Dwelt deep in the cavern,
His influence flowing a thousand *li*.
All things, moving and still, flourished,
And timely rains arrived.

**The Eighteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Cavernous Subtlety and Primordial Stillness, surnamed Liu, personal name Dechang, was a native of Jinling. At seventeen, he composed the *Song of the Great Dao* and presented it to Patriarch Hao. Observing his bearing and essence—ethereal, transcending the mundane—the master remarked, "A worthy one who drinks the springs of Maoshan will, in a month, be tenfold wiser than today; in a year, radiate luminous wisdom; and in a decade, hear the Dao of immortals." Thereupon, the disciple composed the *Chant of Tinkling Springs*. The master further said, "I possess the esoteric essence of the Jade Canon. If you refine your blossoms into fruit, you may harmonize heaven and humanity, transcending emotion and reason." Thus, bowing twice, he took the disciple’s vow and received the Dao. He dwelt at Ziyang Abbey for twenty years, never stepping beyond its gates. One evening at Huaniang Mountain, a youth sang: *"The sacred fungi grow long, the golden blade rings."* The mountain’s inhabitants, hearing it repeatedly, feared an army’s approach. That year, yellow *zhi* mushrooms flourished, yet withered within a month—just as the master attained true liberation.

**Eulogy:**
Dragon-script and phoenix-writ,
Can temper the kalpa’s fate.
To conceal them, value emptiness;
To preserve them, value stillness.
The whole body is the vessel—
Who clings to its form?
To fathom its destination,
Even disciples lose the Way.

**The Nineteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Purity, surnamed Wang, personal name Qixia, also named Jingzhen, styled Xuanyin, was born in Qi and raised in Lu. At seven, he passed the child prodigy examination, his immortal talent and numinous *qi* discerned as innate. In the *dingmao* year of Tianyou, fleeing chaos, he crossed south to Shouchun, where he received the Dao and its methods from Master Wen Zheng of Asking Governance.

Upon arriving at Huayang, he further received the *Dadong Jingjue* from Master Deng Qi of Dignified Conduct. When the Founding Emperor of Southern Tang was still a guest at court, the emperor came to assume his post, summoning the master to Jinling and lodging him at Xuanzhen Abbey. During the sacred reign of restoration, imperial favor and ritual esteem were exceptionally profound, and he was bestowed a golden seal with purple sash, styled Grand Master of Mystic Erudition. He submitted a memorial requesting return to the mountains, but the edict did not permit it. He was further honored as Master of Purity, posthumously granted the title Master of Recondite Stillness in the Grotto-Mysteries.

In the first year of Baoda, the *renzi* year, on the *jiayin* day of the fourth lunar month, he concealed his transformation at Xuanzhen. Having lived sixty-two springs and autumns, he was presented with two hundred thousand coins for funeral expenses, and his cap and sword were returned for burial at Leiping Mountain. Xu Xuan composed the stele inscription, with this eulogy:

Before the rising sun,
The stars gleam bright.
In the southern capital,
They lean on our immortal ruins.
Golden seal and purple sash—
What are these to me?
Those who deem them noble
Come and accept them in due course.

**The Twentieth Patriarch:**
Master of Purple Yang and Lofty Emptiness, surnamed Cheng, personal name Yanzhao, styled Huaiyu, was a native of Jintan in Runzhou. His *qi* was pure and unsullied, unstained by worldly dust. He first journeyed to Purple Yang Abbey, where he prostrated himself before Master Wang and became his disciple.

「In the eighth year of Song’s *Kāibǎo* era (975 CE), after the pacification of the Southern Jiangnan, **Yang Kelan**, a *Lingzhong* of the Ministry of Punishments and magistrate of Shengzhou, invited the Master to serve as the **Weyi** of Maoshan and the Daoist preceptor of Shengzhou. Not long after, he declined and returned to his former abode at Purple Yang.

His disciples were numerous. In the first year of the *Chunhua* era (990 CE), on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, he passed away peacefully. He was seventy-nine years old.

The eulogy reads:
   The vastness of the realm,
   Only the King and the Dao.
   I, with my empty spirit,
   He, with his honored station.
   The teachings of Huayang,
   Their scriptures are vast indeed.
   To aid the age’s work,
   He harmonized the *yin* and *yang*.

**The Twenty-First Patriarch:**
□ **Dongxu Master**, surnamed Jiang, given name Yuangji, styled Jipu, with the sobriquet **Bixu Zi**, was from Yixing in Changzhou. His grandfather was **Lin**, and his father, **Qizhi**, sold medicine without ever marking up its price, being a refined scholar revered in his village.

The Master’s bearing was lofty and untouched by the mundane; he scorned worldly affairs and labor, excelling particularly in poetry. Often, he would summon cranes in broad daylight, drifting with an air of celestial ascent. He followed **Chongxu Master** in response to imperial summons, residing in the capital for some time before returning to Purple Yang together. There, they engaged in profound discussions on the lofty studies of the Dao, and the Master said: *"The Three Caverns’ jade scriptures—none but you can entrust them to me for transmission."*

The Master replied: *"I transmit the scriptures, not the secrets. I have no expectations from you, Master."*

**Chongxu** said: *"I transmit the person, not the scriptures. My hope rests solely with you."*

After receiving transmission, people remarked: *"The Jiang clan’s virtuous lineage is now rewarded!"*
He upheld and propagated the great teachings, and wondrous omens appeared time and again.

In the third year of the *Xianping* era (1000 CE), on the fifteenth day of the third month, he passed the Daoist canon to his disciple **Wan Baochong**, and then ascended to the Dao.

The eulogy reads:
   Morning soars through the jade groves,
   Evening rests beside the moonlit pool.

The faint sighs of the **Dao** stir, and the resonant breath of **Zhuangxu** rises like frost and mist.
A sage from the **Xuanpu** grove, his plumage pure and bright.
I soar to the **Taizhi** heights, and lend you my flight and grace.

The twenty-second generation Patriarch:
**Chongxu Master**, surname **Wan**, given name **Baochong**, courtesy name **Yongxuan**, of Changzhou Wujin.
As a child, he served as an apprentice to his elder brother, who nurtured and guided him.
When he grew older, he reflected upon his **business teacher** and said:
*"Had I not my elder brother, I would not have this day.
The division of my **craft’s lineage** was not what I wished to inherit—
To dwell near the **yellow crown** is enough for me."*

Thus, he went to **Tengxian Guan** and took the **out-family** path,
Later paying respects at **Dongxu Cave** beneath the **Dongxu** master.

In the first year of the *Xianping* era (998 CE),
He began transmitting the **Upper Dao**, excelling in the methods of gathering and refining the **celestial radiance**.

By the age of ninety-two, his **spiritual transformation** complete,
His visage remained youthful as a child’s.

During the *Jingde* era (1004–1007 CE),
He received imperial summons and was granted the **seal of office**,
Retiring thereafter to **Heihu Valley** in seclusion.

The eulogy reads:
   **Hesyang** radiates its brilliance,
   **Chishui** leaps with sacred light.
   Drawn by the **Divine Tripod**,
   Immersed in the **Numinous Elixir**.
   A thousand days of Dao’s fulfillment,
   The **Dragon’s Gate** surges with boundless freedom.
   Lingering as a **jade boy**,
   In **white robes and black sashes**.

The twenty-third patriarch: **Master Guànmiào of Sòng**, surnamed Zhū, given name **Zìyīng**, courtesy name **Yǐnzhī**, a native of **Jùqū’s Zhūyáng Village**. Born in the first year of **Tàipíng Xīngguó** (976 CE).

At eight or nine, he followed a shepherd boy, **Guō Qiāncūn**, who could summon cranes by playing the flute. His parents deemed this ominous and abandoned him.

He then joined **Zhū Yuánjí**, donning Daoist robes at age twelve—at the start of the **Duānróng** era (984 CE). Later, he studied under **Míngzhēn Zhāng**, the Alchemical Master, atop **Jījīn Mountain**, testing the method of abstaining from grain. People began to gather around him, and he sought distant travels.

Arriving in **Xiàngyáng**, he met the eccentric **Chén Tiějiǎo**, who took him to **Qīngchéng Mountain**. He then passed through **Jīxiàng**, where he examined ancient scriptures in the **Gǔcáng** of **Wěidà Zhìguān**. There, he encountered the **Water Star Boy**, **Wǔ Bàoyī**, who wandered through **Hézhōng Prefecture**, his movements divine and inexplicable.

In the first year of **Jìngdé** (1004 CE), he succeeded the **Second Teaching** at age twenty-nine. In the fourth year, Emperor **Zhēnzōng** sent envoys to pray for an heir, and the next year, **Rénzōng** was born—details recorded in the *Sòng Shǐ*.

By imperial decree, he presided over **Yùzhì Zhāoyìng Gōng**. Within the mountains, he constructed **Jièyàn** and **Qián Yuán Tiānshèng** halls, receiving the title **Guóshī**. The **Empress Dowager Míngsù** transmitted the **Great Cavern’s Complete Method**, and he was further honored as **Guànmiào Zhēnsheng**.

Returning to the mountains, he received a letter from **Wǔ Bàoyī** sent from **Shǔ**, reproaching him for revealing his name and fame, exposing celestial secrets. The Master wept, tears streaming, leaving his disciples bewildered.

On the eleventh month of the seventh year of **Tiānshèng** (1029 CE), he ascended in seated meditation, holding the **auspicious jade *rúyì*** bestowed by the **Confucius Temple**, his body drenched in sweat, a pearl-like bead forming on his brow. His **corporeal dissolution** was a supreme attainment—his lifespan, fifty-three years.

Eulogy:
   **Red child’s pristine innocence**,
   **Innate wisdom, darkly realized.**

The **Master of the Void and Clarity** was born when the **Dao** resounded above the clouds and left no trace upon the waters.
At his **auspicious dawn**, warmth spread like the heart of spring.
He wielded the jade and struck the golden bell—
a **temporal sage** for the age.

The **Twenty-fourth Patriarch of the **Way of Transcendence and Illumination**: **Master Máo Fèngróu**, of the **Máo** clan, born **Fèngróu**,
a man from **Jiànkāng’s Jùróng** district.
Once, while attending his father at the **Celestial Market Altar** in **Máo Shān**,
he encountered a **black tiger**—his father saw nothing,
but the Master gazed intently, and the tiger bowed before him.

**Master Guànmiào Zhēnsheng** heard of this and marveled,
telling his father: *"The **Dao** of **Huáyáng** rests in your son."*

Thus, he remained in the mountains,
studying under **Master Guànmiào Zhēnsheng**.
Modest and upright, with the bearing of a sage,
he built his hermitage at **Jīyín Shān**,
admiring the **hidden, pure, and tranquil** lands of **Dàozhēng**,
and devoted himself to **effortless ascension**.

In the twelfth month of **Jiāyòu**’s eighth year (1063 CE),
amid a great snowfall, the **wood jasmine** bloomed suddenly before his abode—
the Master found this strange.
After a short while,
a **Daoist** named **Liú Hùnkāng** arrived from **Tāihé Guān** in **Chángzhōu**,
his sincerity moving the Master,
and the auspicious sign confirming his **virtue/power**—
thus, he imparted the **scriptures and methods** in that moment.

Not long after, he attained **corporeal dissolution**.
In **Chóngníng**’s first year (1102 CE),
he was posthumously honored with a title.

The **eulogy** proclaims:
At the shadowed peak of **Jīyín Shān**, its spirit’s might is profound.
The **Portals of the Numinous** respond with sacred signs—
opening the **Daoist gate** to the immortal way.
Two doors swing wide, and the **Celestial Image** takes form.
**Cinnabar light** glows in the forest—
mortals recognize the **Cauldron’s** lingering essence.

**The Twenty-Fifth Generation Master:**
**Bo-Zhen Guan-Miao Chong-He Master**, **Grand Secretary of the Middle Court**,
**Suffused with Stillness, One**—
Surname **Liú**, given name **Hùnkāng**, also called **Zhìtōng**,
of **Jìnlíng** lineage. Born on the **twelfth day of the twelfth month, Yǐhài**, in **Jǐngyòu’s second year** (1055 CE).

At **thirteen**, he studied under **Tāng Hánxiàng** at **Tāihé Guān**.
In **Jiāyòu’s fifth year** (1060 CE), he passed the **scriptural examination** and became a **Daoist**.
One night, a **divine figure** appeared in his dream and said:
*"If you seek the **Way of the Immortals**, choose a sacred mountain."*

Often lamenting the lack of a true teacher,
he would, in quiet nights, ascend the **altar**,
loose his hair, burn incense,
and take the **Heavenly Dao** as his master.

Later, hearing of **Huàyáng Máo Zōngshī’s** virtue,
he went to serve under him.

Residing in **Jīyín Shān’s** hermitage,
he often saw **five-colored clouds** forming palaces—
mortals marveled at this.
One day, **three羽士** arrived at his dwelling,
pointing to the **eastern corner of his hut** and saying:
*"Dwell here, embrace the **Spirit**, and guard the **Center**—
your **virtue/power** will bless others,
and you shall have no cause to shame your predecessors."*

They then gazed at his brow and asked:
*"This is a place of **non-doing**—
the **Dao** holds it sacred.
No blemish may remain."*
With their hands, they touched the mark—
and by morning, the scar vanished.

In **Yuán’yòu’s first year** (1086 CE),
Empress **Mèng** of the **Philosopher’s Son** (Zhèzōng) accidentally swallowed a needle,
and physicians could not remove it.
The officials, hearing of his **high virtue/power**, summoned him.
The Master administered a **talisman**—
she vomited up the needle, and the **inscription** appeared on the paper.

The court marveled at this, bestowing the title
**"Dòngyuán Tōngmiào Fashi" (Master of Penetrating Originality and Mysterious Perfection)**
and appointing him **Head of the Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace**.

In **Shàoshèng’s fourth year** (1097 CE),
the **Jiāngníng Prefecture** was renamed **Yuánsú Guān**,
with his **Qiánshén Ān** as its center.
He also established **Sān Máo Shān** in **Jùróng Xiàn**,
**Jīngpēng Zōngtán** in **Xìnzhōu’s Lónghǔ Shān**,
and **Hézào Shān** in **Línjiāng Jūn**—
**three peaks standing firm**, aiding the **imperial transformation**.

The **Huizōng Emperor** further honored him with:
the title **"Yuánsú Wànníng Gōng" (Palace of Originality and Universal Peace)**,
the **jade seal "Jiǔlǎo Xiāndū Jūn"** (Lord of the Nine Elders of the Immortal Realm),
the **jewel-encrusted "Jǐngzhèn Yángjù Dāo"** (Sword of Resounding Thunder),
and imperial **poetry, calligraphy, and paintings**.

Though he repeatedly submitted petitions on calamities,
the emperor, though moved, did not act upon them.
He was summoned to the capital repeatedly.

In **Dàguān’s second year** (1108 CE),
when called to court, he managed the **Lùzhē Dao** (Deer-Barrier Road).
The Master explained its meaning—
a deer struck the carriage and died at the road’s side.
Before this, his **tamed crane**, hearing the summons, flew away.
He said:
*"The crane departs, the deer dies—
I have no return."*

In the **fourth month**, he arrived in the capital,
where the **Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace** had newly built the **Yuánsú** branch temple.
That night, he dreamed of the **Celestial Sovereign’s** summons.

At dawn, the emperor visited the **Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace** to see him,
and the Master presented the **ten volumes of the *Dàdòng Jīng*** he had recited.
On the **seventh day**, at noon,
he **ascended in transformation**, aged **seventy-two**.

The court dispatched officials to escort his remains back to the mountain,
where he was buried at **Diéyù Fēng**.
By imperial decree, the **Cángzhēn Guān** was built as his shrine.

The **eulogy** proclaims:
**Jade blossoms** drift on the void,
**golden flowers** scatter fragrant qi.
The **host of immortals** opens the **Celestial Gate**—
receiving the **Purple Sovereign’s** sacred contract.

In the **divine realm’s domain**, the **Way** is perfected.
**Inheriting truth**, **transmitting the Dao**—
**Heaven and Earth grow old together**.

**The Twenty-Sixth Generation Master:**
**Níngshén Diànshì Chéngjìng Chong-Hé Master**,
**Suffused with Concealment**—
Surname **Zhú**, given name **Mózhī**, also called **Zhìyuǎn**,
of **Jīnlíng** lineage.
His father, **Déyī**, loved the **Dao** and guarded its teachings,
and the villagers called him **"Dáfáng"** (the **Vessel of the Way**).

There was a **Du Daoist** from **Yúháng**,
who concealed his name,
and once studied under him.

The **Sixth Year of Xīníng**, the Master was about to be born, when his father dreamed that the **Du Daoist** from **Yúháng** came to their home, and he took note of this wonder.

As a child, the Master often played with the Daoist’s young attendant, and whenever they did, he would draw patterns on the ground depicting **Daoist figures**. His father then took him to the mountain, where **Sīliú Mr.** saw him and marveled, saying: *"This child will one day become a **Human-Heaven Master**."* The Master leapt with joy, vowing never to return home again, and his father rejoiced as well. He followed the Daoist.

During the **Yuán-Yòu** period, the Master and his teacher together entered the imperial court, where **Mr.** was granted an edict to oversee the **Upper Residence of Auspicious Retention** (*Shàngzhǐ Chúxiáng Gōng*), and the Master was sent back to his home, to manage the affairs of the **Upper Residence of Original Symbols** (*Yuánfú Gōng*).

In the **Fourth Year of Chóngníng**, the Master was bestowed with the title of **Law Master**, and he was also entrusted with the **Chóngxì Guān**. For all matters of imperial favor—whether the construction of earthen and wooden structures or petitions for the **mountain gate’s** affairs—he diligently attended to them. He composed and gathered **ritual texts and procedures**, rescued the needy and impoverished, and especially devoted himself to such deeds.

On the **Third Day of the Seventh Month in the Third Year of Zhènghé**, he summoned his disciples and said: *"I am now forty-six years old. In the past, **Mr.** had instructed me that my lifespan would not exceed this age, and yet by the grace of the court, I have been granted such longevity. Thus, I have reached my limit."* He then took up his brush to write a farewell memorial, bathed and changed into fresh robes, and passed away peacefully.

When the memorial was heard, the **Son of Heaven** sighed and mourned, bestowing the title of **Suffused Concealment** (*Chónghé*) **Mr.** upon him, and conferring rank upon his parents. The Master was buried in the **mountain of the Concealed Truth** (*Cángzhēn Guān*).

His disciples included **Yú Xīyǐn** and **Xú Xīhé**. **Xú Xīhé**, upon receiving the imperial decree, succeeded him in holding the **seal and sword**. **Yú Xīyǐn** entered **Qīngchéng Mountain**, and today in **Shǔ** there are those who speak of the **Cavern Method** (*Dòngfǎ*) ascending the **Way**, for it is the **public transformation** (*xínghuà*) of **Yú Mr.**

The Master had a fine beard and a tall, sturdy frame, with a robust and uncommonly graceful build. Whenever he entered to pay his respects, the **Sovereign** would bestow special favors upon him.

「Praise thus:

The autumn sky clears, dust gone;
The spring pool’s ice, vast and deep.
Ah, noble the Daoist bearing,
Brightly praised by all.

Yet praise alone his bearing,
Without delving into his Way.
The final words he spoke—
The essence of imperial rule.

**The Twenty-Seventh Generation Master of the Tradition:**
**Revered Master of Mysterious Perfection and Concentrated Essence, the Honorable *Xiū Xīhé* (Surname Xu, given name Xīhé), courtesy name Zhònghé**, a native of Lìshuǐ, Jīnlíng (modern-day Nanjing). He held the title *Tàizhōng Dàfū* (Grand Minister of the Central Palace) and served as an attendant in the *Níngshén Diàn* (Hall of Concentrated Essence), nurturing the Celestial and refining the Marvelous.

His grandfather, *Lèshī Yǔ*, was a whip-bearer to a nobleman whom Master Xu held in profound reverence. Once, he accompanied his grandfather to court, where the emperor admired his Daoist talent and virtue. The emperor then granted him the title of *Dàoshì* (Daoist Immortal) and, upon his request, bestowed the *Zōngtán* (Altar of the Tradition) succession. In the fourth year of *Zhènghé* (1114), he was summoned to the capital but returned to the mountains in autumn, receiving the honorific *Dāntái Láng* (Officer of the Celestial Terrace) and promotion to *Tàisù Dàfū* (Grand Minister of Supreme Purity), overseeing the *Níngshén Diàn* registers.

In the third year of *Xuānhé* (1121), he was again summoned to the inner palace, where a separate residence was established for him. In the fourth year (1122), he was reinstated in his former rank and requested permission to return to his mountain retreat, where officials escorted him with ceremonial honors. On the eighteenth day of the third month of the fifth year (1123), the emperor bestowed a sacred seal upon him as he ascended the mountain, accompanied by the omen of a white crane and celestial lanterns.

Often, while seated in profound stillness, he would receive descending immortals. Attendants who spied upon him heard only his voice. The Master, foreseeing the world’s fate, often seemed burdened with hidden sorrow. At the onset of *Jìngkāng* (1126), he sealed himself in seclusion, refusing food. One day, he gathered his disciples and declared:
*"My term among the immortals is near—I shall not witness the Sage’s governance of the world."*

On the twenty-fifth day of the seventh month of the first year of *Jiàn’án* (1127), he departed in the state of *zuòwàng* (sitting-forgetfulness), ascending beyond.

**Eulogy:**
Ancient sages and true immortals,
Refine essence, return to origin.
Coming and going without bounds,
Gathering and dispersing without form.
My spirit is most true—
Thus I met with them.
Who stands at the outer gate?
Desires to hear their words.

The Twenty-Eighth Patriarch: Master Yuanguān, surnamed Jiang with the given name Jǐngchè, styled Tōnglǎo, of Jùróng in Jīnníng.

His brow and eyes were strikingly refined, his face marked with a celestial pattern. At eleven, he served Master Chōngyǐn Gōng. When he heard that Master Yú of the Three Caverns had entered Shu, he journeyed to see him at Éméi Mountain. Master Yú admired his devotion and deepened his teachings.

At parting, he told the Master: *"At the thirty-fifth generation, I shall return to the peaks of Fùjí Mountain and succeed as the grand master of the Dao."*

When the *Jiàn’án* rebellions arose, the *Yuánfú* Palace was destroyed, yet the Master alone preserved the sacred scrolls, the ritual seal, and the sword. Left Street Grand Coordinator Fú Xīliè reported this to the court, and Emperor Gāozōng granted gold to rebuild the temple. The Master then traveled north to the capital.

The night before his arrival, Prince Wáng Yáng Chúnzhōng and his wife, Lady Zhào, dreamed of the Celestial Worthy descending to their home. The next day, the Master visited the prince’s gate, who held him in great reverence and faith. The present temple’s mountain gate was built by the prince.

The Master often sighed: *"Because of my involvement in mundane construction, I have diminished my Daoist merit and cannot ascend in broad daylight."*

He possessed a secret white jade statue of the Celestial Worthy, which vanished at the moment of his dissolution. This occurred on the twenty-ninth day of the fourth month of the sixteenth year of *Shàoxīng* (1146).

**Eulogy:**

The grandeur of earthen and wooden structures rises and falls with the times.
My practice is effortless, yet his dreams foretold a divine omen.

Lofty as the Celestial Sovereign, pure as the essence of heaven—
At dissolution, all returned together: who could hold their pact?
On the twenty-ninth day, the Master of the *Daizōng* lineage:
Revered Virtue Master, surname **Lǐ**, given name **Jǐnghé**,
courtesy name **Língyùn**, native of **Jùróng**.

As a youth, he studied under Master Yuánguān,
mastering the scriptures with thorough precision.
After the Southern Migration, ritual platforms and ceremonial norms had decayed—
His refinements restored them.

One day, wandering **Léipíng Shān**, he found an ancient sword,
which he presented to Master Yuánguān.
Yuánguān replied: *"This is from the tomb of Taoist Lord Dàotóng.
Divine artifacts must not be revealed—return it to its original place."*
He indeed found the hidden tomb and placed the sword upright upon it.

A moment later, thunder and lightning struck with fierce winds, obscuring the sky.
The next day, he went to inspect—
the sword had vanished, and instead, two emerald-green **Lǐ** fruits appeared on the tomb.
Yuánguān heard of this and said: *"The sword departs, the fruits emerge—
I ought to step aside from the platform."*

He immediately honored the Master, who ascended the altar.
That day, tigers roared, deer howled,
and cranes and phoenix-like birds gathered in harmony.
The Master delighted in dispensing medicine—
whenever a person’s illness was eased,
he would cast a single coin into the **Yàojiàn Píng**.
The coins accumulated, filling the well,
and people named it the **Medicine-Money Well**.
The number of lives he saved can be inferred.

On the fifteenth day of the ninth month of the **Shàoxīng** era (1150),
he passed away without illness,
and was buried in **Guīzhēn Shān**.
**Eulogy:**

The sacred **Lǐ** fruits returned, accompanied by thunder and lightning.
Where did the green **Lǐ** come from?
They emerged as a sign of the Master’s divine resting place.

He dispensed medicine to ease suffering,
and the waters flowed, filling the groves.
With boundless generosity, he awaited those still in need.

Thirty generations of his disciples:
**Jìngzhēn** Master, surname **Jǐng**, given name **Yǐng**, courtesy name **Línghuī**,
younger brother of the **Chóngdé** Master.
He lost his father young, and with filial devotion served his mother.
At forty, he did not marry; when his mother passed,
he donned the yellow **guān** with his elder brother.

The **Chóngdé** Master said:
*"In days past, I found two **Lǐ** fruits beneath Master Táo’s tomb—
now you have come to verify them."*

Thus, he built the **Two Lǐ Fruits Pavilion** by Bái Lǐ Stream.
The Master possessed a pure and tranquil nature,
cherishing **virtue** and frugality.
Once he entered **Great Stillness (Dàjìng)**,
he remained secluded for a month without emerging.

The **Emperor Gāozōng** repeatedly summoned him,
but he declined due to illness and never appeared.
The Emperor then bestowed upon him the title **Jìngzhēn Master** from his mountain retreat.

In the summer of the **Lóngxīng** era (1163), a drought struck,
and the **Lǐshǒu** (regional governor) visited the Master to pray for rain—
which fell abundantly, as the Master had foretold.
The **Lǐshǒu** heard of this and rejoiced.

Imperial envoys came twice more,
but the Master, feigning illness with utmost sincerity,
still refused to leave.

The following year, upon receiving a petition from **Qín** Lady **Wáng**,
he discerned that **Qín** (Qin Gui) had struck **Dèng Dū** (Deng Zhi).
In the first month of the **Lóngxīng** era (1164),
he told his attendants:
*"I shall soon witness the transformation."*

He sat in quiet repose, taking no food,
until the sixth day at noon, when he **observed the Dao (guānhuà)**.
**Eulogy:**
The **Tàiyī** (Great Unity) loves life,
and the **dharma** (fā) of supplication and sacrifice
is fulfilled in its essence.

「Yet in bestowing blessings and calamities,
he dared not act in private favor.

When a nation strayed, he deemed it worthy of punishment—
still, he hoped for a hidden retribution.

The **Mysterious Prison’s** warning
also upheld the **orthodox teachings**.

**The 31st Patriarch of the Dao:** Master **Chōng Miào of Bǎoníng**,
surname **Xú**, given name **Shǒu Jīng**,
a native of **Lìshuǐ**, **Jīnlíng**.

His mother dreamed of a **meteor** descending into her chamber,
and thus he was born.
At ten years old, he could not speak,
until a **Daoist adept** said he had come from **Máoshān**,
and after taking his **elixir (dān)**,
he could speak at once.

His mother then sent him into the mountains
to study under **Master Jìngzhēn**.
He held fast to the **Dao/Way**,
not seeking human recognition.

In the **Lóngxīng** era (1164),
when the **new master** (of the **altars**) passed away,
the court repeatedly summoned him,
but he adhered to **Master Jìngzhēn’s** teachings,
resolutely refusing to rise.

Whenever **Qín** (Qin Gui) was exorcised,
he dispatched officials to the mountain
to perform rituals on his behalf—
and they invariably received favorable responses.

Then, upon meeting **Master Xīng of Jiāngyīn**,
he entrusted him with the **seal and sword**,
retiring to conceal them in secrecy.

On the **ninth day of the third month of the Qìngyuán era** (1195),
he bade farewell to his disciples and departed.

**Eulogy:**
The **meteor’s** radiance, descending to become a man.
Concentrating his essence, holding its brilliance—
silent, untouched by dust.
The **elixir’s** arrival, the **Dao/Way** not given lightly.
Responding to things with tranquil ease—
this is the **virtue/power** of the **Mysterious Prison’s** guardian.

**The 32nd Patriarch of the Dao:** Master **Míngjiào**,
surname **Qín**, given name **Rǔ Dá**,
courtesy name **Tōngyuǎn**,
a native of **Jiāngyīn**.

His family was poor, yet he endured hardship in his studies,
often gathering discarded paper and strayed brushes
to learn calligraphy, his memory surpassing others.

He sought the **Dao/Way** in the famous mountains of the east and south.
The **Patriarch of Bǎoníng** opened the **western cave** for him,
and sent him a letter.

When the Master arrived,
they spoke throughout the night.
The next day, he presented the **seal and sword**
to the Master as he ascended the **altar**,
and the assembly saw the Master’s **brow and eye** as divine—
all marveled at the **Patriarch of Bǎoníng’s** discernment of talent
and his clarity of insight.

In the **Shàoxī** era (1191),
the court dispatched officials to offer **incense and wine**,
and to establish the **Golden Records Hall (Jīn Lù Zhāi)**,
where **white cranes and colored clouds** appeared as omens—
the court then bestowed a title upon the Master.

On the **ninth day of the tenth month of the Qìngyuán era** (1195),
**Book Shén of Gōngchéng** came to pay respects.
When they parted,
at the **mountain bridge**,
he heard the **temple bell**,
and someone said: *"The **Daoist Patriarch Qín** has ascended."*

**Shén** was greatly startled,
and turned to gaze upon the Master—
his **body** still sat upright, his **form** yet warm,
whereupon he sighed:
*"We met when the tea was already over,
and with a single laugh, he ascended."*

His **inner-chamber disciple, Xíng Rǔ Jiā**,
was then in the capital,
serving as **Left Street Daoist Instructor** of **Tàiyī Palace**.
That very day, he returned to the mountain,
and **transmitted the teachings** to his successor.

**Eulogy:**
The **Daoist adept’s** learning surpasses mortal skill—
not something sought through books.

「What harm in my coarse and humble attire?
Why cast me aside?
My slight movement stirred by a whisper—
I felt it with empty **virtue/power**.
They say I foresaw it—
Who could probe the mysteries of the **Dao**?

The **Patriarch of the Thirty-Third Generation**:
**True Response Master**, surname **Xíng**, given name **Rǔ Jiā**, courtesy name **Zǐ Jiā**,
a native of **Lìshuǐ**, **Jiànkāng** (present-day Nanjing).
At seven years old, he could compose verses,
and excel in discussing **names and principles**,
his stature seven *chǐ* tall,
his hands reaching past his knees.

The **Emperor Xiàozōng** summoned him as **Imperial Daoist Instructor**,
but the Master was already bald in his youth,
unable to bear a cap,
so he was specially granted a **headcloth** to wrap his head
and ascend the hall,
while the Emperor composed a poem:
*"I myself command the weaving of the Huáyáng headcloth,
to bestow upon the **Daoist adept** of Máo Mountain.
Wearing this, he need not fear the **imperial court’s** lofty steps,
no longer must the Five Peaks endure dust and grime."*

In the tenth month of the **Qìngyuán era** (1195),
he received a letter from the **Daoist Patriarch Qín**:
*"I have recently attained the **True Mandates**,
and soon shall return to the **Celestial Chariot**—
the matter of **religious transmission** is most urgent,
you may swiftly request **True Response Master**,
return to receive the **seal and sword**,
and meet me on the ninth day."*

Upon reaching the mountain and delivering the message,
the Emperor was deeply astonished.
**True Response Master** was sent back to the mountain,
and became the **Patriarch’s successor**.

In the **Jiādìng era** (1208–1224),
when the **hidden chamber** was rebuilt,
he received **gold and silk** worth tens of thousands.
He told his disciples:
*"I do not covet this.
Next year, there will be a great famine."*

On the twenty-second day of the third month of the **Jiādìng era** (1210),
he passed away without illness.
That year, the autumn harvest was poor,
and the people relied on his provisions to survive.
Those he aided beyond their need—
the number of lives saved was incalculable.
Such was his **compassionate heart**.」

At the **Huángfù Líng** [1], he personally upheld filial principles.
Thus he cherished the **Way of Quietude**, seeking counsel from the **True Masters**.
With his own hands, he fashioned the **flowered silk headband** [2],
to bestow upon **Nà** the **dust-covering crown** [3].

In his generation, he alone fulfilled this noble calling,
his lofty virtue standing like jade—tall and unyielding.

The **Thirty-Fourth Generation Patriarch**:
**Master Chōng Xuán Míngyī** [4], surname **Sà** [5], given name **Rǔjī** [6], courtesy name **Défū** [7],
a native of **Jìnlíng, Chángzhōu** [8].

By nature, he was frugal and unassuming,
studying the *Zhōuyì* [9] and *Lǎozhāng* [10],
his **Dao/Way** resonating deeply with **True Response Master** [11].
For over twenty years, the **True Response Master**—as a **High Sage**—held the **Altar of the Supreme** [12],
yet their exchanges remained unrecorded.
Later, they became **Teacher and Friend** [13],
transmitting the **Dao lineage** [14].

In the **Jiādìng era**, year **six (1213)**, on the **Làrì** [15] of **gēyǒu** [16],
Empress Yáng of **Níngzōng** [17] followed the precedent of **Empress Míngsù** [18]
and ordered **Left Street Jianyi** [19] **Guān Déqīn** [20]
to offer incense and gifts to **Great Cavern** [21] **Graduate Bìfǎ** [22],
to perform the **Remote Ritual** for **Master Chōng** as **Dao Teacher**,
and to conduct the **Luótiān Jiào** [23].

**Sweet Dew** descended, **Spirit Kei** grew,
white cranes soared amid **auspicious clouds**—
these were but a few of the **joyous omens** [24].
**High Sage** Liú Xiānjué composed the *"Chronicle of Transmission"*.

In year **seven (1214)**, on the **eighteenth day of the twelfth month**,
he attained **True Perfection** [25].

Initially, his name was **Kèzhāo** [26], courtesy name **Míngfū** [27].
Upon transmitting the **Huáyáng teachings** [28],
he reverted to his former name,
to mark the origin of his **worldly virtue** [29].

**Praise:**

*"Unveiling the scriptures, illuminating the Dao,*
*entrusting the *Yì* [30] to clarify the mysteries.
*Rising with the sun, setting with the moon,*
*his Way stands upright, never tipping.
*Sweet Dew descends in secret, Spirit Kei flourishes on its own—*
*white cranes take flight, ascending beyond the **High Peak** [31].*"

**Thirty-Fifth Patriarch of the Lineage: Master Tónglíng Zhìdào,**
surname **Rén**, given name **Yuánfù**, courtesy name **Shānfǔ**,
a native of **Lìshuǐ**.

From youth, he bore an extraordinary nature,
discerning profound principles with penetrating insight,
his divine bearing transcending the mundane,
his bearing exuding an aura of the immortal.

**Master Xué**, the Patriarch, dreamed of a boy
raising his seat and declaring:
*"Master Yú is coming—you must yield your place."*
Yú was none other than **Yuán Guān**, the **Jiāng Lord of Éméi Mountain**,
who had spoken of the thirty-fifth Patriarch as **Rùfù**.
This was a prophecy from **Shǔ**, where the immortal had departed decades prior,
and **Xué** had once heard such words.

When the Master entered the mountains,
**Xué** remarked:
*"A guest of Huáyáng has returned."*

He was then granted the **Jade Scriptures**,
and disciples flocked to him in succession.

In the **sixteenth year of Jiādìng (1223)**,

The Master directed the floodwaters to the **Kūn corner**,
facing the **Gèn door** with measured steps,
as if warding off malevolent forces.
The Emperor had also foreseen in a dream
that this place harbored hidden malevolence,
unknown to others.

The following year, when summoned again to **stop the rains**,
he was further honored with the title **Zhìdào**,
granted the **xiàngjiǎn crown and cloak**,
and **Empress Xiànzōng** presented him with a **ceremonial fan**,

All other gifts he distributed to the indigent,

**Cāxiān Three Year, Third Month, Eighteenth Day**, after the fast was completed, he addressed the assembly: *"I shall now assist the Lord of Fate, fulfilling the duties of loyalty and filial piety—this is a matter to be held in highest regard."* Then, with a serene expression, he departed, having lived to sixty-four.

Who says the Daoist Sage

**Thirty-sixth Generation Patriarch: Mingwēi Master**, surname Bào, given name Zhìzhēn, courtesy name Chúnfū, of Lìshuǐ.
His family practiced Confucian learning but lived in poverty. His father found abandoned gold and, upon questioning, returned it to a weeping official. **Eulogy:**
One in a thousand preserves pure virtue,
One in ten billion reaches its utmost.
Pure to the extreme—he ascends as an immortal,
Humanity transformed—his passage complete.
His father did not take what was lost—

That very night, the rain fell. The Emperor rejoiced greatly, and the people raised their hands in praise, calling him *"Tang the Daoist who summoned the rain."* He was summoned to reside in **Tàiyī Palace**, but he firmly declined, insisting on returning to the mountains. The Emperor granted him a generous parting gift.

In the **Eleventh Year**, he submitted a petition to resign.

In **Bǎoyòu Six Year**, on the **third day of the first month**, he said to his disciples: *"Laughing into the boundless void—one*—thus I depart from the world with a single laugh."*

The disciples praised him:

*"The cap, sash, and robes—
these are the adornments of the outer self.
I measure my life by wandering,
returning to my true nature is no strange thing.
The worries of the **Sānglín** life
are cast aside with sweet simplicity.
Yet I do not deify myself—
the rain that nourishes is Heaven’s gift."*

The **40th Generation Patriarch, Yuánjìng Master**,

surname **Zhái**, given name **Zhìyǐng**, courtesy name **Tóngshū**,

**Hua yang’s cave** boasts walls of dark jade.

Humans bear fire’s legacy,

In the **year twenty-eight of the Yuan era**,

They praised him:

The **lineage of Shangzhi**’s **Master**,
the world receives as **worthy**.

The **era of Jingyun** began anew,

With **breaths of harmony and precision**,

His hidden virtue reached the **Highest Sovereign**, who commanded Yuanzhi to receive transformation in the **Southern Palace** and ascend to the Metropolis. In her youth, Yuanzhi also cultivated the Dao, consuming **reed rhizome** for thirty years before encountering **Stone Longevity**, who taught her the **Method of Transformation and Evasion**—a form of **upper body ascension**. The *Hidden Residences* notes that Chang was Zhou Jia’s younger cousin, serving as **River South Administrator** during Emperor Chao’s reign and later as **Grand Officer of Light**. **Zhang Taozhi** was the mother of **Zhu Yu**, the **Secretary of the Capital Region** in Han. Zhu’s mother practiced hidden virtue, and though long rumored to have ascended, she was later appointed as an attendant. The *Hidden Residences* states that Zhu, from **Pei**, was among the **Eight Virtuous Ones** of the **Huan-Ling era**.

**Xia Fu**, styled **Zizhi**, of **Chenliu**, in his youth cultivated the Dao, consuming **wood-based elixirs** and mixing **mica**. Later, he entered **Hao Mountain**, where he studied the **Soul-Refining Method** under **Red-Bearded Master**, and later received the **Yellow Water Cloud Nectar Method** from **Tongxiang True Person**, attaining the Dao and ascending to the Metropolis. In his youth, Fu was summoned by a government office but departed by inscribing his resignation on a wall and hanging it from a mulberry tree—his lofty ambition thus displayed. The *Hidden Residences* and *Records of Later Han and High Virtue* state that Fu was a **Yù official** of **Chenliu**, recommended for his **upright speech** during Emperor Huan’s reign but declining the post. The *True Revelations* states that such attendants were selected based on **equanimity, rectitude, hidden virtue, and clarity of spirit**, without gender restriction. The remaining individuals cannot be enumerated here.

The **Preservation of Life Bureau** also had its **Forbidden Prohibitions Overseer**.

Zhang Xuanbin, a native of Dingyi in Shanyang. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei, he was recommended as a **Teacher of Virtue** (茂才). Returning to his hometown, he became a disciple of Ji Gong of Xīhé, learning to take **wooden decoctions** (服木饵) and practicing the **Dao of the Primordial Void** (洞房元白) within the **Cavern of the Mysterious** (元白之事).

Later, he encountered the **True Person** Fan Ziming at Shàoshì Mountain and was taught the **Dao of Evasion and Transformation** (遁变隐景之道). Once he resided at Tiānzhù Mountain, then moved to Huáyáng’s inner chambers, becoming the **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** (理禁伯).

The **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** was the official in charge of **meteorological rites** (主雨水官), also serving as the **Supervisor of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命之监国). Xuanbin excelled in discussing **emptiness and non-existence** (空无), being a **Daoist adept** (谈士), often expounding:

*"Non-existence* (无) *is the dwelling of the Great Existence* (大有), *and the lesser existence* (小有) *is where it arises. By accumulating lesser existence to nourish lesser non-existence* (积小有以养小无), *one perceives the Great Existence as the root of the Great Non-existence* (见大有以本大无). *Existence is also non-existence, and non-existence is also existence* (有有亦无焉，无无亦有焉). *Thus, my eyes see nothing, yet nothing hides from me. Non-existence depends on existence to achieve non-existence* (无寄有以成无), *and depends on non-existence to attain non-existence* (寄无以得无). *In this way, non-existence has no dwelling* (於是无则无宅也), *yet the Absolute Void also dwells in non-existence* (太空亦宅无矣).

*Before my birth, the world knew no non-existence* (我未生时，天下皆无无也). *I once visited* **Left Lord of Penglai**, **Song Chengsheng** (蓬莱左公宋晨生), *and discussed non-existence with him. His understanding surpassed others, and even the* **True Persons of Tongwu** (桐梧诸真) *could not refute him. Beyond this, I have yet to grasp the root of existence* (过此以去，尚未能本有)， *how could I grasp non-existence?* (安能本无耶) *Such was his lofty* **qi** (高气) *and profound Daoist principles* (秉理如此).

The **Deputy of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命府丞).

Zhào Wēibó, a native of Shù Commandery, in his youth studied under Master Zhāng of Nàzōu. He carried the luminosity of the sun and moon and wore the radiant petals of the Nine Spirits’ Mirror. Later, at Zhōngyuè, he received the *Yùpèi Jīndāng Jīng* from Fàn Qiūlín. Qiūlín was the wife of Wèi Xíngdào, the Han *Lóuchuán* General. The *Hétú* states: *"Hàochǔ has many who have glimpsed the Great Peace."* He often told others: *"These words are not false—this proof will soon manifest."* The luminous mirror he preserved was not of the ordinary world’s craft. After attaining the Dao, he dwelled within Huáyáng, serving as Deputy of the Preservation of Life.

The Preservation of Life Bureau has four deputies: Zhào oversees the *xiānjiè* (仙籍, celestial registers) and violent storms, commanding the Five Sacred Herbs of gold and jade. Those seeking torrential rains may present petitions to him.

One deputy is Lè Chángzhì of Xiányáng, a native of Dōngqīng, where the Lord of *Sìmìng* resides. He was recommended by the *Máoxiǎo* Lady and appointed as Imperial Secretary during Emperor Huán’s reign. Later, he studied the *Bùqī Yuānfǎ* from Master Lǐ of Zhōngyuè and ascended as an immortal. Chángzhì oversees calamities.

Another deputy is Zhèng Zhìzhèng, a disciple of the Inner Chamber of Master Méng. Méng recommended him, and he oversees examinations and registries.

The fourth deputy is Master Táng of Xīshān, a native of Fáng Shǔ. He served Lǐ Bābó. Táng oversees life and death.

The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: Huáng Yuánpíng, of Dōnghǎi, was about thirty years old, dressed in white linen robes. Yuánpíng carried a black tablet, which he presented to Deputy Zhào of the Preservation of Life, though he held no official rank. Lǐ Zhěng of Héjiǔ once received the *Shǒuyī Fǎ*, practiced in a cavernous chamber, and attained the Dao. Initially at Yángluò Shān, he later entered Huáyáng, where he also oversaw examinations and rituals for the people. Zhěng had once served as a tutor for the Lord of Chángdào, receiving the Dao and entering the mountains at age sixty. The *Yǐnjū* states: *"Zhěng resided at Sìpíng Shān and Dàmáo’s eastern peak, where he gathered victory stones, consuming them to attain the Dao. The gathering site remains."*

Zhōu Zǐliáng, styled Yuánsù, with the inner taboo *Tàixuān* and the style *Xūlíng*, was a native of Yǒngjiā. As a hidden recluse, he was a disciple of Gāojì. On the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month in the fourteenth year of Liáng Tiānjiàn (515 CE), he underwent *báirì shījiě* (白日尸解, daytime dissolution of the corpse) at age twenty. The recluse compiled his daily records of true transformations, categorizing them into four volumes, which he presented to Emperor Wǔ of the Liang—this became the *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì*. The text records two officials appointed as deputies of the Preservation Bureau, a position newly established to assist in managing celestial registers. Though their duties were minor, their virtue and purity were esteemed. Later, they would ascend to *Bǎochén Sī* (保晨司), overseeing the Daoist practices of immortals across the world and the methods of instruction.

The ghostly marshals of the Preservation of Life Bureau—Wáng Yán, Fù Huǎng, Fàn Qiáng, and Xú Wèi—were originally Daoist *sàijiào* (祭酒, ritual toasts). Having mastered the *xiàjiě fǎ* (下解法, method of descending dissolution), they were appointed as ghostly marshals.

**Huáyáng’s Celestial Child of Jade**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: In the heavens of Huáyáng, the Marshal of Dawn, Jade Child, surnames Jǐng, named Shàngqī.

**The Recluse of Xiāoxián Palace**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: The Daoist official Zhāng Zǐ’ān of Xiāoxián, wearing a *fúróng guān* (芙蓉冠, hibiscus crown) and crimson embroidered robes, with three attendants. Zǐ’ān’s given name was Xiào, a native of Jiàjǐng in Róngyáng.

**Initial Marshal of the Bureau, Liú Wénráo**—Liú Kuān of Hóngnóng.

At seventy-three, one day he encountered Master Qīnggǔ in his chamber, who taught him the *zhàngjiě fǎ* (杖解法, staff dissolution method) and, as he prepared to depart for Huàshān, instructed him in the *jiǔxī fúqì* (九息服气, nine-breaths qi cultivation). He was also given the elixir furnace-fire formula. Having perfected his Dao, he later returned to the grotto, where he oversaw those who first sought the Way.

Kuān served the Han, rising to the rank of *Sītú Tàiyuè* (司徒太尉, Grand Tutor and Grand Marshal). He delighted in practicing *yīndé* (阴德, hidden virtue), rescuing the cold and destitute, and the common people rejoiced and clung to him as to parents. His biography appears in the *Hànshū*.

**Superintendent of the Bureau, Fàn Yòuchōng**—A native of Liáoxī.

He received the *Tàisù tāihuà yìxíng* (太素胎化易形, Supreme Primordial Embryonic Transformation and Metamorphosis) Dao. Daily, he would preserve the three *qì*—green, white, and red—each as a boat, drawing them from the *shùfāng* (束方, bound direction) as the sun descended, guiding them straight into his mouth. He would then embrace them ninety times before stopping once sated. Practicing this for ten years, he attained the Dao.

His method was concise, and its efficacy was proven—a secret transmission of the Supreme Primordial Dao. The "Superintendent Fàn" refers to this man, who once served as Superintendent of the Bureau and now resides in Huáyáng.

**Daoists of the Bureau:**
The Bureau of Jǔngchū includes Wáng Shàodào, Fàn Shūshèng, and Lǐ Bóshān—all its foremost figures.

**Wáng Shàodào**—A man of the Han era, surnamed Wáng, originally named Zhú’ér (逐儿). **Yùn**—a Han-era governor of Shānyáng.

**Fàn Shūshèng**—A native of Běidì, who served as *Huángmén Làng* (黄门郎, Imperial Attendant) under Wèi Wéndì.

**Lǐ Bóshān**—Father of Lǐ Chōng, who, in the Han, held the office of *Báimǎ Lìng* (白马令, White Horse Prefect). Chōng practiced *yīndé*, and it is said that either through accumulated merit over generations or innate virtue, his benevolence was profound. These Daoists all advanced step by step, gaining entry to this Bureau—not necessarily having come directly here.

**Grand Justiciar of the Three Officials:**
Fàn Shuài said: The Three Officials have a judicial officer, not called *Tíngwèi* (廷尉, Censorate), but *Dàlǐ* (大理, Grand Justiciar). Lǐ Fēng now serves as the *Shǒuhuò* (守缺, acting) Grand Justiciar of Dūyú, having been compared to Wáng Fùzǐ (王附子) but not to Xǔ Hǔ (许虎).

*The Hidden Residence* records: Lǐ Fēng, courtesy name Ānguó (安国), later changed to Xuānguó (宣国), was from Féngyàn. Lǐ Yì’s adopted son, originally of humble birth, possessed talent and ambition, and thus entered service under Wèi as *Shàngshū Fúshè* (尚书仆射, Minister of War).

The Grand Justiciar is the ancient judicial officer; during the Former Han and Wèi, the *Tíngwèi* was also called *Dàlǐ*. This is a Daoist office. Wáng Fùzǐ was the childhood name of Wáng Huò, and Xǔ Hǔ refers to *Hǔyá* (虎牙, Tiger Claw).

**Earthly Overseer:**
Bào Shuō, courtesy name Tàixuān (太玄), a native of Chénliú.

He served the Jìn, repeatedly summoned to the post of *Huángmén Shìlàng* (黄门侍郎, Imperial Attendant), later appointed Governor of Nánhǎi. Proficient in the mysteries of the grotto and well-versed in the *jīngwéi* (经纬, classics and divination), none could fathom his depth.

Bào Shuō’s master, **Zǔ Yuànfàng**, transmitted to him the *Zhōngbù Fǎ* (中部法, Central Sect Teachings) and the *Sān Huáng Nèi Wén* (三皇内文, Inner Scriptures of the Three Sovereigns), enabling him to command and subdue spirits and demons, and to seal mountains and pacify malevolent forces. Later, upon **Jiǎngshān**, he encountered the True Person **Yīn Chángshēng**, who instructed him in the *Dāojiě* (刀解, Blade-Severance) technique for protection.

According to the *Zhēnxù* (《真诰》), both Bào Shuō and his sister were descendants of a seventh-generation ancestor who had accumulated profound *yīndé* (阴德, hidden virtue), thus granting their lineage enduring blessings—hence their roles as **Earthly Overseers**. Within the grotto palaces, Bào Shuō’s studies were initially shallow and his nature unrefined, so he did not attain greater mastery.

The *Yǐnjū* (《隐居》) states: Bào Shuō employed the *Tàiqīng Shījiě* (泰清尸解, Embalmed Dissolution of the Mortal Frame) technique, suggesting that his rank among the Overseers was not the highest.

Bào Shuō’s daughter, **Bào Gū**, became the wife of **Gě Hóng**, the *Sànqí Chángshì* (散骑常侍, Standing Attendant of the Scattered Cavalry). Both Bào Gū and **Zhìchuān** (稚川) ascended to immortality in succession. There is also a separate account of **Bào Gū’s** use of *ài* (艾, mugwort) and *zhú* (灼, cauterization) to subdue a dragon maiden.

**Yì Qiān’s Immortal of the Transferred Palace**
The *Yìqiān Guǎn* (易迁馆) and the *Hántián Tái* (含真台) are both official titles. Within the *Yìqiān Zhōngdū* (易迁中都), there were eighty-three immortals.

The lady was **Huáng Jǐnghuá** (黄景华), daughter of the Han *Sīkōng* (司空, Grand Tutor) **Huáng Jūn**. She studied under **Hán Zhōng**, who taught her the *Mínshān Dān* (岷山丹, Mineral Elixir of Mount Mín). Upon ingesting it, she attained immortality.

**Liú Chūnlóng** was the daughter of **Liú Fèngxiān** (刘奉先), the Han *Zōngzhèng* (宗正, Minister of Ceremonial Rites).

**Hánzhēntái’s** *Xiānrén* (仙人, Immortal)

The **Hánzhēntái** (含真台), where these women who have attained the Dao/Way reside, is under the jurisdiction of the **Tàiyuán Shùgōng** (太元束宫, Celestial Bureau of Grand Unity), housing nearly two hundred individuals.

Within it, two **Nǚzhēn** (女真, True Women) oversee the affairs: One is **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子), the daughter of **Zhāng Qìng** (张庆), the Han *Zhāngdì* (昭帝, Emperor)’s *Jiāngzuò Dàjiàng* (将作大匠, Grand Master of Construction). **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子) was devoted to the Dao/Way, attaining the *Shījiěfǎ* (尸解法, Method of Corporeal Dissolution), and habitually ingested *Wùqì* (雾气, Mist Qi), receiving her teachings from **Shùhǎi Shùhuá Yùfēi Chúnwénqī** (束海束华玉妃淳文期), the younger sister of **Qīngtóng** (青童, Azure Boy).

The *Wùqì* (雾气) refers to the refined essences of mountains, marshes, rivers, lakes, and the five elements—metal and stone *Yíngqì* (盈气, Qi of Abundance). By consuming it, one can disperse one’s corporeal form into the void and merge with clouds and mist.

The other is **Chuányǐ Hé** (传礼和), the daughter of **Fù Jiàn** (傅建), the *Shìzhōng* (侍中, Attendant-in-Ordinary) and distant cousin of the Han *Huándì* (桓帝, Emperor). 「The *Dìnglù* (定录) recorded the words of **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展上公): **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展先生) once studied the Dao/Way under **Fùlóng** (伏龙, Master Fu Long), where the mountain was planted with peach trees, filling every corner of his dwelling.

**Jiāngshūmǎo** (姜叔茂), the **Bālíng** (巴陵) Marquis of **Qín** (秦), attained the Dao/Way at **Jùqū Shān** (句曲山). He cultivated the Five Fruits and Five Pungent Herbs, selling them in exchange for cinnabar.
