**The Lóuguān Sect’s Scriptures**

The **Yuánsì Wànníng Gōng** [Palace of Primordial Peace and Universal Tranquility], located at **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain], was originally the site of **Táo Yǐnjū** [Master Tao of Seclusion], whose Daoist name was **Dàozhēng**. Above this foundation, **Liú Míngshēng** [Master Liu], with the Daoist name **Hùnkāng**, established his residence.

When the master encountered **Zhézōng** [Emperor Philosopher], he was granted favor, and his dwelling was named **Yuánsì Guān** [Primordial Peace Hall]. Its construction was completed in the **Chóngníng** [Venerable Peace] 5th year [1106]. **Huízōng** [Emperor Gaozong] personally inscribed the plaque, which read: **"Yuánsì Wànníng Gōng"** [Palace of Primordial Peace and Universal Tranquility]. Additionally, a **Yuánsì Bié Guān** [Separate Hall of Primordial Peace] was built beside the **Shùqīng Chǔxiáng Guān** [Palace of Upper Clarity’s Auspicious Treasures], serving as the master’s residence when he entered the imperial court and took up duties.

Today, the palace retains its original layout: The first ascent to the mountain is marked by the **Tōngxiān Qiáo** [Bridge of Ascending Perfection], which leads directly to the gate of the **Yuánsì Wànníng Guān**. To the left is the **Guān Tīng** [Palace Hall], and to the right, the **Yùshì** [Bathing Chamber]. The second gate is called the **Yùhuá Mén** [Gate of Jade Flower].

The main hall enshrines the **Sānmáo Zhēnjūn** [Three Teachings of Perfection, i.e., the Three Pure Ones], named **Tiānníng Wànfú Diàn** [Hall of Heavenly Tranquility and Universal Blessings]. To its left is the **Yùcè Diàn** [Hall of Jade Registers], and to its right, the **Jiǔshì Diàn** [Hall of the Nine Auspicious Offerings]. Behind the **Jǐngfú Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery and Longevity] is the **Mǎjīngfú Wànnián Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery and Longevity, named "Sage’s Everlasting Auspiciousness"]. To the west is the **Yìngfēitiān Fǎshū Diàn** [Hall of the Responsive Celestial Law Transmission], flanked by a **Zhōnglóu** [Bell Tower] to the left and a **Jīnggé** [Scripture Pavilion] to the right.

Behind the **Tiānníng Diàn** [Hall of Heavenly Tranquility] lies the **Dàyǒu Táng** [Hall of Great Possession], followed by the **Bùkù Táng** [Hall of the Treasury] and the **Xīyún Táng** [Hall of Western Clouds]. Beyond the **Xīyún Táng** is the **Bǎolù Diàn** [Hall of Precious Records].

Behind the **Jǐngfú Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery] is the **Yún Chú** [Cloud Kitchen], and behind the **Dàyǒu Táng** is the **Zhòngmiào Táng** [Hall of Supreme Marvels]. To the left of the **Zhī Guān Wèi** [Office of the Palace Administrator] is the **Sān Sù Táng** [Hall of the Three Unadorned Ones], and to the right, the **Fùzhī Guān Wèi** [Office of the Deputy Palace Administrator] is the **Jiǔzhēn Táng** [Hall of the Nine Perfect Ones].

The **Běijí Gé** [Pavilion of the Northern Pole] stands behind the **Bǎolù Diàn** [Hall of Precious Records], while the **Zhònglíng Táng** [Hall of Trembling Spirits] is located behind the **Zhòngmiào Táng** [Hall of Supreme Marvels]. There is also the **Gǎngshén Ān** [Hermitage of the Harbor Spirit], situated behind the halls, which was burned by bandits in the **Jiàn’ān** [Rebuilding and Peace] 4th year [1130]. In the **Shàoxīng** [Glory to the Song] year **Wùyín** [1138], **Gāozōng** [Emperor Xiaozong] granted gold for its reconstruction and personally inscribed the palace plaque.

During **Lǐzōng**’s reign [1224–1264], the halls underwent repairs, and the emperor inscribed two plaques: **"Shùqīng Zōngtán"** [Altar of the Upper Clarity Sect] and **"Shèngdé Rényòu Diàn"** [Hall of Sacred Virtue and Benevolent Assistance].

The **Chóngxǐ Wànshòu Gōng** [Palace of Venerable Longevity and Universal Auspiciousness], located at the **Dīnggōng Shān** [Dinggong Mountain]’s forefront, was originally the site of **Yǐnjū Huáyáng Xiàwǎn** [Master Tao’s Secluded Dwelling in Mount Hua’s Lower Reaches]. In the **Táng Zhēnguān** [Tang Zhenguan] 9th year [635], **Emperor Taizong** [of Tang] built it for **Wáng Fǎzhǔ** [Master Wang, the Law Sovereign], naming it **Tàipíng Guān** [Hall of Great Peace]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Emperor Xuánzong** [of Tang] forcibly took it from **Lǐ Xuánjìng** [Master Li of Mysterious Tranquility], relocating a hundred households of commoners nearby, exempting them from rent, taxes, and corvée labor, and perpetually assigning them to maintain the hall’s upkeep and cleanliness. During the **Zhōnghé** [Intermediate Harmony] period [881–885], bandits set it ablaze.

「During the **Tiānyòu** [Heavenly Assistance] period, **Dèng Qǐxiá** [Master Deng] rebuilt it. In the **Song** [Song Dynasty], it was renamed **Chóngxǐ Guān** [Hall of Venerable Auspiciousness], but was again destroyed by fire in the **Jiàn’án** [Rebuilt Peace] era.

**Qín Xī** [Master Qin] reconstructed it once more, and **Emperor Ningzong** [of Song] bestowed upon it the names **Gāoshì Yìrú Gāngzhǐ Táng** [Hall of the High Virtue of Just Repose, named after Master Yang] and **Fāngzhàng** [Square Measure], both inscribed by imperial decree. **Emperor Lizong** [of Song] later inscribed the characters **Yùqì Níngrùn** [Jade Qi Congealing] and **Hèqíng Chāoliáo** [Crane Emotion Ascending the Liao], and also bestowed the **Bǎozhū Lín** [Jewel Bamboo Grove] inscription upon **Sìtú Shī Tǎn** [Master Shi Tan of the Temple].

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] [Mongol] period:
In the **Yányòu** [延佑] 6th year [1319], it was decreed to change its name to an official title.

**Yùchén Guān** [Jade Dawn Hall], located north of **Léipíng Shān** [Leiping Mountain], was where **Zhǎnshàng Gōng** [Lord of the Upper Court], **Zhōu Yǒu** [Master Zhou], **Guō Sì** [Master Guo of the Four Dynasties], **Jiāng Shūmào** [Lord Jiang, Master Maie of the Chángshāo River], **Yáng Zhēnrén** [Master Yang], **Xǔ Zhǎngshǐ** [Master Xu, the Chief Clerk] and his son attained the **Dao** [Way]. During the **Song Tàishǐ** [Song Taishi] period, the Daoist **Wáng Jǔ** [Master Wang] was highly regarded by **Jǐngwáng Yǎ** [Prince Jing of Chángshā, the Wise], and thus established the **Chángshāo** [Long Shao] retreat in the residence of the Chief Clerk.

In the **Liáng Tiānjiàn** [Liang Tianjian] 13th year [514], it was decreed to move it to **Júyáng** [Juyang] and name it **Júyáng** [Juyang] retreat, where **Táo Zhēnrén** [Master Tao] resided. A **Zhāozhēn Tái** [Platform of Illustrious Virtue] was erected to enshrine the true traces, scriptures, and edicts of **Yáng, Xǔ** [Masters Yang and Xu], and the three **Zhēnrén** [True Persons].

In the **Táng** [Tang Dynasty], **Emperor Taizong** [of Tang] built the **Huáyáng Guān** [Hua yang Hall] for **Tóngwú Xiansheng** [Master Mr. Tong of the Willow Grove]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Emperor Xuánzong** [of Tang] decreed to change it into **Zǐyáng Guān** [Purple Yang Hall] for **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Mr. Xuán of Mysterious Tranquility]. It was then decreed to take two hundred households of nearby commoners, exempting them from rent and corvée labor, and permanently assigning them to maintain the hall’s upkeep and protection. **Wáng Zhēnshù** [Master Wang of the Pure and Substantial] of **Nán Táng** [Southern Tang] later resided there.

In the **Song Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Song Dazhong Xiangfu] 1st year [1008], it was renamed **Yùchén Guān** [Jade Dawn Hall]. **Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord Dinglu] said: "This is the land marked for a tranquil retreat, the very site where the **Xuánjìng** [Mysterious Tranquility] retreat once stood. If it were not for the **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Xu of Mysterious Tranquility] and his son, how could this place have been preserved?" He added, "Future generations will have virtuous descendants who will reside here—this is indeed a blessed land." He further declared, "This is the very auspicious land of **Jīnlíng** [Jinling]."

**Chóngshòu Guān** [Hall of Venerable Longevity], located beneath **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], south of **Huáyáng Dòng** [Hua yang Cave], and before the **Biànmén** [Convenient Gate], was the former residence of **Jìn Zhēnrén Rén Dūn** [Master Ren Dun of the Jin Dynasty]. In the **Song Yuánjiā** [Song Yuanjia] 11th year [434], **Lù Tàihòu** [Lady Lu] began constructing the hall. During the **Tàishǐ** [Taishi] period, **Kǒng Suìzhī** [Master Kong of the Lu country], the governor of **Lúlíng** [Luling], rebuilt it, and provided sustenance for the Daoist **Huà Wénxián** [Master Hua of the Wen clan, the Virtuous and Exalted] from **Qǔ’ē** [Master Qu of the E clan].

In the **Qí Jiànyuán** [Qi Jianyuan] 2nd year [478], it was decreed to establish the **Chóngyuán** [Venerable Source] retreat, with the **Tàizǐ** [Crown Prince] and **Emperor Wǔdì** [of Qi] visiting in person. **Wáng Wénqīng** [Master Wang of the Pure and Clear], the host, arranged the halls and chambers, which were most fitting and harmonious.

In the early years of the **Táng** [Tang Dynasty], **Zhēnguān** [Zhenguan], it was renamed **Chóngyuán Guān** [Hall of Venerable Source]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Xuán of Mysterious Tranquility] urged its reconstruction, and again took one hundred households of nearby commoners, exempting them from rent and corvée labor, and permanently assigning them to maintain and protect the hall. In the **Song Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Song Dazhong Xiangfu] 7th year [1014], it was decreed to bestow its current name.

**Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord Dinglu] said: "Even beneath **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], there is a spring, and beneath it, one may establish a tranquil retreat. Near the spring’s mouth is where one should reside." **Yǐnjū** [Master Tao] noted, "In the present age, there are those who reside near the southern entrance of **Dàdòng** [Great Cave], where the water flows well but is rocky. The terrain quickly becomes level, and this has been the case for generations."

In the early years of the **Qí** [Qi Dynasty], **Wáng Wénqīng** [Master Wang of the Pure and Clear], a man from **Jùróng** [Master Ju of the Rong clan], established a retreat here, naming it **Chóngyuán** [Venerable Source], which is this very hall. There is a stele from the **Táng Tàijí** [Tang Taiji] 1st year [617], inscribed by **Zhuōyú Sūn Chǔxuán** [Mr. Sun of the Zhuo clan, the Left Censor], with **Yáng Yōu** [Master Yang] writing the **Jīng** [Scripture] and the remaining characters indistinct and unrecognizable. In the **Yuán Táidìng** [Yuan Taiding] 1st year [1324], **Yùjí** [Master Yu], the director of the **Guózǐ** [National Students], rewrote the inscription, which was carved in regular script on the reverse side of the **Tàijí** [Taiji] stele.

**Xiàpō Guōng** [Retreat of the Lower Bank], located west of **Zhōng Máocāng** [Middle Teased Mountain], was where **Dà Sīmìng Jūn** [Lord of the Great Command] ascended from **Xiànyáng** [Xianyang] during the **Hàn Dì Jiē** [Han Di Jie] 3rd year [230] to meet his two younger brothers, **Chǔ** [Master Chu] and **Yǔ** [Master Yu]. **Yǐnjū** [Master Tao] noted, "The elders of the region passed down the tale that in the northwest level ground of **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], among the **tánglǐ** [Tangli] trees, there was a place named **Xiàpō Chù** [Lower Bank Dwelling], which was said to be the former residence of the **Sīmìng Jūn** [Lord of the Command]."

In the **Táng Zhēnguān** [Tang Zhenguan] 11th year [637], a stele was rebuilt there, inscribed by **Huáng Xiansheng** [Master Huang] of **Táoyuán** [Peach Grove] and calligraphied by **Lú Shǐjūn** [Master Lu, the Official] of **Hézhōu** [Hezhou]. The current inscription is not the original; it was written by **Wáng Gōng Wěi** [Master Wang, the Duke], who once served as the **Táng Yùshì Dàfū** [Tang Grand Master of the Palace], and this is the record of his work.»

The **Huáyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace] stands on the western slope of **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain]. The **Yǐnjū Shàngguǎn** [Secluded Upper Hall] was where, in the seventh month of the **Tiānbǎo** [Sky Treasure] 7th year [748], Emperor Xuánzōng received the *Shàngqīng Jīnglù* [Upper Clarity Scripture Record] from Master Xuánjìng and encouraged Daoist priests to burn incense in devotion. The hall was later destroyed by war. During the **Sòng Zhènghé** [Song Zhenghe] era, Daoist **Zhuāngshènzhì** [Solemn and Reverent] rebuilt it. The **Yǐnjū Dānjǐng** [Secluded Dan Well] and **lóujī** [pavilion foundations] remain there.

The **Quányuán Guàn** [Complete Record Hall] bears this inscription from **Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord of the Record], who said: Beneath **Dàhéng Shān** [Great Horizontal Mountain] lies a spring. Long ago, **Lǐ Míng** [Master Li] refined immortal elixir here and ascended to **Xuánzhōu** [Mysterious Isle]. In the **Tiānjiàn** [Heavenly Governance] 14th year [423], the recluse **Bìyù Gāng** [Obsidian Jade Ridge] built a retreat to follow the traces of Xuánzhou. During the **Tiānbǎo** era, Master Xuánjìng resided there, erecting the **Qízhen Táng** [Abiding-in-Truth Hall] and five pavilions: **Huìzhēn** [Gathering Truth], **Hòuxiān** [Awaiting Immortality], **Dàodé** [Dao Virtue], **Yíng’ēn** [Receiving Grace], and **Bàibiǎo** [Kneeling in Reverence]. In the **Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Great Harmony Auspicious] 2nd year [1014], Master Guànmiào constructed a nine-tiered platform for Dao practice. In the **Tiānsèng** [Heavenly Veneration] 3rd year [1025], it was renamed **Jíxū’ān** [Gathering Void Hermitage], later restored to its current name.

The **Yàn Dòng Gōng** [Swallow Cave Palace] is at **Yànkǒu Dòng** [Swallow Mouth Cave]. A female immortal, **Qián Miàozhēn** [Money Miao True], vanished here, and a shrine was erected in her honor. A stele by **Liáng Shàolíng Wáng** [Liang Prince of Shaoling] no longer exists. In **Tiānbǎo** 7th year [748], the palace was granted its name, and three female Daoists were ordained to tend the incense. In **Yuányòu Jiǎchén** [Elemental Revival, Year of the Dragon] [1084], it was burned by wildfires and relocated to **Jùróng Xiàn** [Jurong County]. In **Shàoxīng** [Sovereign Peace] 20th year [1150], it was rebuilt on its original site in the west of **Zhōngmáo** [Central Teased], adjacent to the **Hèmiào** [Crane Temple].

In **Tiānbǎo** 7th year [748], a **jìngshè** [pure dwelling] was established beneath the temple, where Daoists were ordained and incense burned in honor of the **Sānmáo Jūn** [Three Teased Lords] and the Daoist patriarchs. A stele by **Túntián Yuànwàiláng Liù Shí** [Grain Field Outer Official Liu Shi] is now lost.

The **Huáyáng Guàn** [Huayang Hall] was the former residence of the **Liáng Zhāomíng Tàizǐ** [Liang Prince of Illuminating Clarity], once called **Hóngxǐ Yuàn** [Auspicious Felicity Hall] and **Fúxiāng Guǎn** [Felicity Village Lodge], located west of **Chóngshòu Guàn** [Longevity Nurturing Hall]. In the **Bǎolì** [Treasure History] 2nd year [826], it was granted imperial patronage and renamed **Bǎolì Chóngyuán Shèngzǔ Yuàn** [Treasure History Nurturing Origin Sacred Ancestor Hall]. At the time, **Zànhuáng Lǐ Déyù** [Li Deyu of Zhanhuang] enshrined statues of **Lǎozǐ** [Old Master], **Kǒngzǐ** [Confucius], and **Yín Zhēnrén** [Immortal Yin], and venerated **Tàixuān Zhōu Shī** [Master Zhou of Supreme Mystery] here. During the **Zhìpíng** [Political Peace] era, it was renamed **Hóngxǐ Guàn** [Auspicious Felicity Hall]. In **Xuānhé** [Extended Harmony], it received its current name.

The **Tiānsèng Guàn** [Heavenly Veneration Hall] is atop **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain]. In the early **Tiānjiàn** [Heavenly Governance] era, the recluse **Bì** [Obsidian] cultivated at **Xiǎozhǎo** [Small Marsh], nurturing a dragon child in the **Léipíng Chí** [Thunder Calm Pool]. During the **Zhēnguān** [Zhenguan] era, **Wáng Fǎzhǔ** [Master Wang, the Law Holder] resided here and encountered the immortal **Fǎběn Xiānrén** [Master Faben]. In the **Sùzōng Zhìdé** [Suzong Rectified Virtue] era, it was granted the name **Huǒyuàn Gōng** [Fire Hall Palace]. By the end of the Tang, it fell into ruin. In **Jìngdé** [Jingde] 3rd year [1006], Master **Míngzhēn Zhāng Shàoyīng** [Illuminating Truth Zhang Shaoying] rebuilt it. Mingzhen, along with **Zhū Guànmiào** [Master Zhu of Illuminating Mystery], were the two transmitters of the **Míngsù Tàihòu** [Illuminating Lineage Grand Empress]. In the 9th month of **Tiānsèng** 3rd year [1025], his residence was granted the name **Yánzhēn’ān** [Extending Truth Hermitage], and in the 5th year [1027], it was renamed **Qízhen Guàn** [Abiding-in-Truth Hall], located west of **Huáyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace].

The **Yǐnjū Zhōngguǎn** [Secluded Middle Hall] was the residence of **Huáyuán Huáng Zūnshī** [Revered Master Huang of Peach Grove], with a stele inscribed by **Hézhōu Lú Shìmóu** [Lu Simou of Hezhou], now lost. During the **Xuānhé** era, it was granted its name.

The **Wǔyún Guàn** [Five Clouds Hall] is beneath **Wǔyún Fēng** [Five Cloud Peak]. Built during the **Tiānsèng** era, it was later granted its name after **Chéngxiàng Wáng Gōng Qǐnrú** [Chancellor Wang Qinru] passed away. **Xǔ Guó Fūrén** [Lady Xu of the State] petitioned the court to establish it as his resting place, and **Yàn Yuánxiàn Gōng** [Yan Yuanxian, Duke of Yuan] inscribed the stele.

The **Qīngzhēn Guàn** [Pure Truth Hall] is at **Dàluó Yuán** [Great Luo Spring]. During the **Zhènghé** era, the Daoist **Hàodé Qīng** [Virtuous Virtue Qing] built a hermitage to welcome wandering Daoists. Emperor **Huízōng** granted it the name **Guàn** [Hall]. Every year on the 18th day of the 3rd month, Daoists from afar gather to pay homage to the **Máo Jūn** [Teased Lord]. During the rituals, white cranes often soar overhead, giving rise to the legend of the **Hèhuì** [Crane Assembly].

The **Bái’yún Chóngfú Guàn** [White Cloud Nurturing Virtue Hall] is beneath **Bái’yún Fēng** [White Cloud Peak]. **Bìyáng Gōng Zhīgōng Wáng Jǐngwēn** [Palace Official Wang Jingwen of Biyang] retired here. Jingwen gained renown at the **Déshòu Gōng** [Longevity Nurturing Palace], and the hall was granted its name. He was later promoted through Daoist ranks, serving four successive courts. During the reign of **Níngzōng’s** [Ningzong] grandson, he received ordination and, upon ascending the throne, was granted the title **Xūjìng Zhēnrén** [Void Stillness Immortal]. **Dài Xī Xuéshì** [Scholar Dai of Dai Stream] composed the hall’s record.

The **Níngshén’ān** [Concentrated Spirit Hermitage] is in **Hēihǔ Gǔ** [Black Tiger Valley]. In **Shàoxīng Gēngwǔ** [Sovereign Peace, Year of the Monkey] [1140], the shrine and Daoist priests were rebuilt by **Zhāng Zhànglíng** [Zhang Zhangling], formerly named **Féngdào** [Encountering Dao]. Emperor **Gāozōng** annually sent envoys to offer incense in the mountains. In the **Yǐhài** year [1149], Zhang’s Daoist name reached the emperor, and he was repeatedly summoned to the **Déshòu Diàn** [Longevity Nurturing Hall], receiving gifts of a **móxiù bèi** [embroidered robe], **shuǐjīng huán** [jade ring], **zǐshí chá** [purple stone mortar], imperial calligraphy of the **Yīnfú** [Dark Secret] and **Qīngjìng** [Pure Stillness] scriptures, and an order to have his likeness painted in the **Shénxiān Gé** [Immortal Gallery].

The **Shēngyuán Guàn** [Ascending Source Hall], formerly the **Báiè Miào** [White Crane Temple], is a dedicated shrine to **Sīmìng Zhēnjūn** [True Lord of Command], located west of **Zhōngmáo** [Central Teased]. During the **Tiānbǎo** era, its halls were repaired, Daoists were ordained, and incense burned in accordance with the **Qǐdiǎn** [Sacrificial Rites]. In **Zhènghé** 8th year [1118], the governor of **Jiànkāng** [Jiankang], **Yú Zhuō** [Yu Zhuo], petitioned for its current name. In **Jiànyán** 3rd year [1129], it was burned by bandits. In **Shàoxīng** 14th year [1144], the Daoist **Máo Zōngbái** [Mao Zongbai] rebuilt it south of its original site.

「Liu Zhìxiào [Liu Zhi Xiao] three times encountered the spirit peach tree at its place, the events recorded in the *Cǎizhēn Yóu* [Adventures of the Transcendent Sage]. The **Bàoyuán Guàn** [Embracing the Source Hall], located above the **Liǔjì Quán** [Willow Rescue Spring], was in the **Zhènghé** 8th year [1118] when **Chén Xīwēi** [Chen Xiwei] of **Gūsū** [Gusu] followed **Liu Xiānsheng** [Master Liu] in Daoist practice and resided there. Later, the **Liǔgǔ Àn** [Willow Valley Hermitage] urged its transformation into a hall.

The **Yuányáng Guàn** [Primordial Sun Hall], an ancient hall, appears in **Gù Kuàng** [Gu Kuang]'s poetry:
*"For ten years I’ve wandered this hall,
For a thousand miles I’ve lodged in this room.
Returning to the old window below,
I take your verse again to read."*

The current hall stands above **Máo Dòng** [Mao Cave]. At the beginning of the **Lóngxīng** era [1163], the Daoist **Hàoxīng Dàorén** [Shen Shen of Bright Dawn], **Shěn Shànzhì** [Shen Shanzhi], dwelled in a cave, calling himself the **Dòngzhǔ** [Cave Master]. He met **Xīn Wáng** [Fire King] **Hán Fūrén** [Lady Han], who commissioned him to construct the hall’s buildings. Initially named **Chōngxū Àn** [Piercing the Void Hermitage], its name was later changed to **Guàn** [Hall] during the **Qìngyuán** era [1195–1200].

The **Cángzhēn Guàn** [Treasure of the True Hall], a serene shrine to **Jìngyī Liú Zōngshī** [Master Liu of Pure Unity], is located at **Diéyù Fēng** [Stacked Jade Peak]. In the **Dàguān** [Great Hall] era, its construction was completed.

The **Zǐyáng Guàn** [Purple Yang Hall], formerly known as **Dòngyún Àn** [Cave Cloud Hermitage], was during the **Jiànyán** era [1127–1130] when a Daoist from **Bó Zhōu** [Bo Prefecture] in **Héběi** [Northern Rivers], **Wáng Ruòníng** [Wang Ruoning], came to the mountains and lived alone beneath the **Dīnggōng Shān** [Ding Gong Mountain] **Shùyán** [Bundle Rock]. One night, he dreamed of a divine person pointing to a cave and saying: *"This is the place where the spirits of Dengzhou [a netherworldly region] interrogate the dead. You may dwell here, a hundred paces from the cave."* Upon **Qín Qiè** [Qin Qie]'s demise, **Fūrén Wáng Shì** [Lady Wang], a woman of pure virtue, visited **Jìngzhēn** [Settled Sage] **Liú Zōngshī** [Master Liu] and begged for a written petition, learning that **Qín Qiè** was imprisoned within **Dēngshān** [Deng Mountain]. **Wáng** [Wang] then ordered his son to build a **Tàiyǐ Diàn** [Great Unity Hall] at the cave’s entrance to seek a posthumous pardon. The **mò** [incense burner] and **shí** [stone tablet] he offered remain preserved there.

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] **Tìyuán** era [1264–1294], specifically the **Gǔwǔ** year [1273], an imperial decree established it as a **Guàn** [Hall], retaining its ancient name.»

「The **Chóngyuán Guàn** [Hall of Exalted Benevolence], at the end of the **Shàoxīng** era [1131–1162], was founded by **Shí Xiānsheng** [Master Shi] of **Tóngchuān** [Tongchuan], named **Yuánpǔ** [Original Simplicity], who studied the **Dao** from **Yáng Yíjiǎ** [Yang Yijia]. He resided at the **Chángníng** [Constant Peace] **Yǎn** [Hermitage] on the southern slope of **Nánzhèn** [Southern Garrison], practicing medicine to benefit others. Daily, he would recognize one **cǎo lǚ** [straw sandal] and ten coins from passersby, hanging them on a tree outside his door so that travelers might take them freely, regardless of season. He lived to eighty-eight years old and departed without illness.

**Liú Zhài** [Master Liu] of **Màntáng** [Mantang] composed a eulogy for him.

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] **Yuanfù** era [1294–1307], specifically the **Bīngzǐ** year [1306], an imperial decree granted the hall its ancient name, and his disciples thereafter maintained the **yàoshì** [pharmacy hall].

The **Shèngyòu Guàn** [Hall of Sacred Benevolence] stands atop **Dàmáo Shān** [Great Mao Mountain]. In the **Yányòu** era [1201–1208], particularly the **Sānnián** [Third Year, 1205], an imperial edict bestowed its name and elevated its seal to **Dàjūn Zhēnyìng Zhēnjūn** [Great Lord, Manifest Response, True Lord].

The **Déyòu Guàn** [Hall of Virtuous Benevolence] is atop **Zhōngmáo Shān** [Middle Mao Mountain]. As above, an imperial edict granted its name and elevated its seal to **Zhōngjūn Miàoyìng Zhēnjūn** [Middle Lord, Marvelous Response, True Lord].

The **Rényòu Guàn** [Hall of Benevolent Grace] is atop **Xiǎomáo Shān** [Lesser Mao Mountain]. As above, an imperial edict granted its name and elevated its seal to **Xiǎojūn Shényìng Zhēnjūn** [Lesser Lord, Divine Response, True Lord].

The *Tàiyuān Nèichuán* [Inner Transmission of the Great Yuan] records that in the **Yǒngmíng** era [58–75] of the **Hàn** [Han] **Míngdì** [Emperor Ming], the **Jìng** [Effort] **Jùn** [District] **Xiàn** [County] constructed a temple for the **Jūqū** [Jucur] **Zhēnrén** [True Person] of **Dānyáng** [Danyang]. *Yǐnjū* [Hidden Residence] states: "This temple still exists today." The villages of **Shūmóu** [Shumou] and **Liúxī** [Liuxi], along with others, each built their own temples. The **Hàoxū** [Hao Xu] Temple was located on the western side of **Dàmáo** [Great Mao], and the **Shùxū** [Shu Xu] Temple stood below the rear mountain of **Zhōngmáo** [Middle Mao]; both are now abandoned.

Only the **Shēngyuán Guàn** [Hall of Ascended Benevolence], originally named **Hèmiào** [Crane Temple], resides above the **cíyǔ** [ancestral hall], at **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] **Wèn** [Question], when it was rebuilt by imperial decree. A radiant **Dān** [Dan] light appeared at its foundation.

The **Dàoshì** [Daoist] **Lǚ Yún** [Lu Yun] inscribed its records, though they are now lost.

The **Guǎngjì** [Broad Benevolence] Temple, also known as **Tiānshèng Guàn** [Hall of Heavenly Saint] and **Lóngcí** [Dragon Shrine], was renamed in the **Shàoxīng** era [1131–1162] with the titles **Chúnxī** [Pure Heir] and **Chúnyòu** [Pure Benevolence], and three times elevated the **Shénlóng** [Divine Dragon] to **Fūzé Guǎngyìng Lìjì Zhēnjūn** [Benevolent Sower, Broad Response, Graceful Aid, True Lord].

The **Yuánfú** [Yuanfu] Temple and **Yuánfú Gōng** [Yuanfu Palace] were established in the **Yuánfú** era [1098–1100], with the **Shén** [Divine] **Yuánfú** [Yuanfu] enshrined as **Hùshèng Zhēnjūn** [True Lord, Protective Benevolence], and the **Yuánfú Gōng** [Yuanfu Palace] **Èrshǐzhě** [Two Envoys] enshrined as **Língyòu Línghù Zhēnjūn** [True Lord, Spiritual Aid, Soul Protector]. The records are detailed in the *Sòngshǐ* [History of Song].

The **Máo Shìtú Mìào** [Temple of Mao, the Grand Marshal] is located within the **Qiányuán Guàn** [Hall of Primordial Benevolence]. It faces the **Jiāngbā Lù** [Jiangba Road] to the south. In ancient times, a man suffering from illness lay at the roadside. In the dead of night, a guide arrived on horseback, demanding his name. The man confessed his ailment, and the horseman gave him a pill, saying: "I am **Máo Shìtú** [Mao, the Grand Marshal]." By dawn, his illness was cured, and he built a temple at the site. The account is found in *Qǐshén Lù* [Records of Divine Inquiry].

There is also a shrine one *lǐ* [li] outside the **Shūmén** [Shumen] gate of **Jiànkāng** [Jiankang, modern Nanjing].

The *Máoshān Zhì* [Gazetteer of Maoshan], **Juàn** [Volume] **Shíqī** [Seventeenth], concludes with the note: "The previous text has 『Féng』 [Encounter] instead of 『Dá』 [Reach]."

The *Máoshān Zhì*, **Juàn** [Volume] **Shíbā** [Eighteenth], records the **Shòuqīng** [Successive Sage] **Zhēnjūnshī** [Master of the True Lord] **Liú Dàbīn** [Liu Dabin] constructing the **Shàngqīng** [Upper Clarity] Temple.»

The **Lóuguān** [Louguan] section—**Mountain Lodges and Hermitages**

The **Xù Chángshǐ** [Xu Changshi’s] residence, now **Yùchén Guān** [Yuchen Observatory]. The *Yǐnjū* [Hidden Residence] states: *"After Xu Changshi’s residence fell into ruin, no one knew its location."* During the reign of **Jìngwáng** [King Jing] of **Chángshā** [Changsha], **Tántàifēi** [Tan Taifei, the dowager] sponsored the Daoist **Chén** [Chen], who established a response at **Léipíng** [Leiping]’s northwest—this was also where **Běichá** [North察] was located. Later, **Wénqīng** [Wenqing] **Wáng** [Wang] of **Jùróng** [Jurong] became the patron of those afflicted with **xiàn** [癣, ringworm], as recorded in his biography. It was known that Xu Changshi had settled here, and through inquiries among the elders, by the **Dàmíng** [Daming] era of the seventh year (1423), an old villager named **Xúǒu** [Xu Ou] recalled that his ancestors had served Xu Changshi and knew of this residence. I have also seen the **Chángshǐ jǐng** [Changshi’s well] within.

The **Língbǎo Yuàn** [Lingbao Abbey], located at the former site of **Yǐnjū Zhāozhēn Tái** [Hidden Residence’s Zhaozhen Terrace] beneath **Yùchén Guān** [Yuchen Observatory]. During the **Táng** [Tang], the masters **Sūn Zhìqīng** [Sun Zhiqing] and **Wáng Qíxiá** [Wang Qixia] rebuilt it, enshrining the image of the **Língbǎo Tiānzūn** [Lingbao Heavenly Venerable]. The plaque reads *"Língbǎo"* [Lingbao]. Within, there is also an ancient **Lǎojūn** [Laojun, Laozi] image of divine auspice. Originally erected by **Xuánjìng Xiānshēng** [Xuanjing Master], during the **Gāozǔ** [High Ancestor, Emperor Taizong of Song]’s reign, **Lǎojūn** [Laojun] repeatedly descended upon **Yángjiǎo Shān** [Yangjiao Mountain] in **Jìnzhōu** [Jinzhou]. A request was made to enshrine his image, and in the **Dàguān** [Daguan] era, fourth month of the third year (1109), **Liáng Wùzhēn** [Liang Wuzhen], a Daoist of **Yùchén** [Yuchen], drew water from the **Zhōuzhēn rén chí** [Zhouzhen Person’s Pond] before the hall—this was the **Zhōu Zhēnrén** [Zhou Zhenren’s] pond. Suddenly, a **zǐyīn** [紫姻, purple mist] enveloped him, and within it, he saw **Lǎojūn** [Laojun] riding a white horse, bestowing upon him the *Tiāndóng Jīng* [Tiantong Scripture]. Liang, though simple and unlearned, thereafter neither ate nor recited scriptures, and his words on others’ fortunes and misfortunes proved accurate. The *Tiāndóng Jīng* [Tiantong Scripture] was later inscribed on stone and transmitted.

The **Ruòshān Àn** [Ruoshan Hermitage], located east of **Guō Gāntáng** [Guo Gantang]. **Ruòshān** [Ruoshan] was, during the **Kāiyuán** [Kaiyuan] era of the **Táng** [Tang], the **Rùnzhōu** [Runzhou] prefect, who abandoned office and came to the mountain, later residing at **Tàihú Bāoshān** [Taihu Baoshan]. Today, a ruined stele remains in the forest.

The **Yóuzūn Shī Àn** [Youzun Master’s Hermitage], located south of **Bāguà Tái** [Bagua Terrace], a few dozen steps away. The master’s name is unknown, nor is it known when he resided here. Layered tiles formed its walls, and a stone mortar was carved from rock—its space barely exceeding a *zhàng* [丈, ~3 meters] in length and width. The remnants of his **áo** [鳌, turtle] still linger, long obscured by overgrowth. During the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era of **Chén Shàngshū** [Chen Shangshu], the hermitage was rebuilt, revealing it once more.

**Gù Zhùzuò Shānfáng** [Gu Zuzuo’s Mountain Lodge], situated atop **Jǔpú Tán** [Jupu Pond]’s **Shímò Chí** [Stone Ink Pool]. **Gù Qiào** [Gu Qiao], who styled himself **Huàyáng Zhēnyì** [Huayang True Hermit], was the author of the *Jiāoshān Zuòhè Míng* [Seat Crane Inscription of Jiaoshan]. Qiao served as **Kànqiú Guān** [Kanqiu Official] under **Hán Qiào** [Han Qiao], later holding posts as **Jiāngnán Jùnshèng** [Jiangnan Circuit Inspector], **Jiàoshū Láng** [Jiaoshu Clerk], and **Zhuózùo Láng** [Zhuozuo Clerk]. After years of neglect, he abandoned worldly affairs and built a dwelling in the mountains. His son, **Fēixióng** [Feixiong], passed the **Jìnshì** [Jinshi, advanced scholar] examination and successively served in various prefectural offices. During the **Dàzhōng** [Dazhong] era, he held the post of **Yùyí Bùmù** [Yuyi Bureau Clerk].

The **Qín Xì Shānfáng** [Qin Xi’s Mountain Lodge], located beside **Shímò Chí** [Stone Ink Pool]. According to the *Yúdì Xún* [Yudi Seeking], **Qín Xì** [Qin Xi], a **Táng** [Tang] scholar, carved a **yàn** [研, inkstone] from stone to annotate the *Dàodé Jīng* [Dao De Jing]. The *Yǐnyì Zhuàn* [Hidden Retirees’ Biography] also records him as a native of **Kuàijī** [Kuaiji, modern Shaoxing], skilled in poetry. **Quán Déyǔ** [Quan Deyu] remarked: *"Liú Zhǎngqīng* [Liu Zhangqing] called himself the ‘long wall of *wǔyán* [五言, quintain verse],’ and I, with my inferior forces, though aged, still press onward."* During the **Sòng** [Song], **Qíqiū Shānfáng** [Qiqiu Mountain Lodge] was built atop **Hǎiyǎn Quán** [Haiyan Spring]. The lodges of **Zhèng Shàngshū** [Zheng Shangshu], **Péi Tàishī** [Pei Taishi], and **Yáng Shàngshū** [Yang Shangshu] were also near **Hǎiyǎn Quán** [Haiyan Spring]. The lodges of **Zhào Shūjì** [Zhao Shuji], **Yáng Shìláng** [Yang Shilang], and **Zhōu Shìláng** [Zhou Shilang] were all in the southwest of **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao]. The lodges of **Lǐ Shìláng** [Li Shilang] and **Gāo Jiàoshū** [Gao Jiaoshu] were at **Wúzhī Lǒng** [Wuzhi Ridge]. The lodges of **Liú Shìláng** [Liu Shilang] and **Péi Shìláng** [Pei Shilang] were before **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao]. The lodges of **Léi Lángzhōng** [Lei Langzhong], **Zhāng Shíyú** [Zhang Shiyu], and **Hé Xiānshēng** [He Xiansheng] were on **Lóngwěi Shān** [Longwei Mountain]. The lodges of **Cuī Zhēngjūn** [Cui Zhengjun], **Yuàn Liànshī** [Yuan Lianshi], and **Wáng Liànshī** [Wang Lianshi] were on **Léipíng Shān** [Leiping Mountain]. **Cuī Dìngyán** [Cui Dingyan] composed emotional verse. The lodges of **Dòu Liànshī** [Dou Lianshi], **Hóu Xiāngū** [Hou Xiangu], **Yán Liànshī** [Yan Lianshi], **Táng Liànshī** [Tang Lianshi], and **Jīnshān Rén** [Jinshan Person] were in **Nán Dòng** [Nan Dong].

The **Sòng Zhāng Wénjiǎn Gōng Shānfáng** [Zhang Wenjian Gong’s Mountain Lodge], located in the **Shēnxiù Xuān** [Shenxiu Pavilion] of **Huàyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace]. The master’s name was **Gāng** [Gang], who served as **Cánzhī Zhèngshì** [Chanzhi Chancellor] during the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era. He read in the mountains and compiled the *Huàyáng Lǎorén Jí* [Huayang Laoren Collection] in forty volumes.

The **Qíyún Àn** [Qiyun Hermitage], located in **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao], west of **Xiǎo Máo** [Xiao Mao] and above **Yùshā Quán** [Yusha Spring], was the residence of **Liú Shāyī Xiānshēng** [Liu Shayi Master].

The **Tiānxìn Àn** [Tianxin Hermitage], located beneath **Sōulún Fēng** [Soulun Peak], was the residence of **Yáng Zhíjiǎ Xiānshēng** [Yang Zhiya Master].

The **Dòngyáng Guàn** [Dongyang Pavilion], located west of **Huàyáng Guān** [Huayang Observatory] in **Nán Dòng** [Nan Dong]. During the **Zhènghé** [Zhenghe] era, it was rebuilt by **Yánkāng Dàxiànshì Wáng Gōng Hàn** [Yankang Grand Academy Master Wang Gong Han], who sponsored the recluse **Shěn Zǐzhōu** [Shen Zizhou] and refined elixirs there.

The **Yuánxǐ Àn** [Yuanxi Hermitage], established during the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era by the **Pílíng** [Piling] Daoist **Yú Huìcōng** [Yu Huicong]. Huicong practiced **péngtóu kǔxíng** [蓬头苦行, ascetic austerity], first dwelling at **Dàluó Yuán** [Daluo Spring], weaving two **cǎoxié** [草屦, straw sandals] daily to exchange for grain. Each evening, he knelt in prayer to the **Dòu** [斗, Big Dipper].

A certain night, he was moved by a black tiger lying at his side. Emperor Gaozong, hearing of his fame, summoned him to the De Shou Palace, bestowing upon him abstinence rice and saying, *"This rustic has no use—let him remain for military provisions."* The emperor smiled and released him back to the mountains, whereupon he relocated to the front of Longwei Mountain.

**East Tianning Temple**, located in Danyang County, Zhenjiang.
**West Tianning Temple**, located in Jurong County, Jiankang—both part of the Yuanfu Estate, granted the name by imperial decree in the fifth year of Chongning.

**Qi Bai An**, built by the scholar-official Qin Qiao of Huawen Ge, overseen by Zhang Dongyuan during the Yuanfu era, situated on Dinggong Mountain, where the cliffs are exquisitely steep.

**Xuanzhou Jing She**, atop Hetai Ravine. In the Zhiyuan era of the Great Yuan, established by Master Jiang Zongshi of Yuhai. The hall still stands on Yugang Ridge, an ancient name.

In the **Rénshù** year of **Zhìzhèng** (1323), Master Liu Zongshi requested permission to establish a retreat and built **Wàijìng** at the site where the Purple Pavilion Immortal’s fire was extinguished.

**Huayang Dao Yuan**, on the bundle of Jijin Mountain. Built by Master Wang Zongshi of Mu Chai during the Dade era. To its west stood a strange rock, upon which Chancellor Yuan Mingshan inscribed a stele.

**Sanmao Dao Yuan**, established by the Yuanfu Daoist Jiang Dagui during the Dade era.

**Sūzhōng of Shàngqīng** (Master Lǐu Dàbīn) constructed the **Língzhí Jiǎnpiān** (a concise record of sacred roots) and **Shénzhī Qíyào** (wondrous herbs of the Daoist Immortal).

According to *Tàiyuán Nèichuán* (Inner Transmission of the Supreme Primordial), **Jùqū Shān** (Sentient Curve Mountain) has five divine herbs. The two lords (二君) once saw a Daoist who had achieved union with the immortals (合仙者), and they also gave these herbs to him.

The method for obtaining the herbs requires ascending the mountain on the **opening days** (开日) of the **third** or **ninth month**, carrying **two golden rings** (金环), and offering them with a solemn oath. The two lords did this three times as a pledge of sincerity, casting the rings onto the stones and not looking back. The immortals value **green rings** (青环) as tokens of trust.

The **first herb, Lóngxiān Zhī** (Dragon Immortal Herb), resembles the intertwined form of two dragons, with its leaves as scales and its roots coiled like a dragon.

The **second herb, Cānhéng Zhī** (Dragon’s Back Herb), is vermilion in color, with a radiant luster. When struck, its trunk and leaves emit a sound like metal or stone, and if broken, it can be rejoined seamlessly.

The **third herb, Yàntāi Zhī** (Swallow’s Egg Herb), resembles **kǎi leaves** (葵叶) but is purple, with a swallow-like shape poised as if ready to take flight. It shines brightly and penetrates with clarity.

The **fourth herb, Yèguāng Dòngcǎo** (Moonlight Piercing Grass), is green in color, with leaves resembling **xiàngshí** (a type of grass), and its fruit is white like a **plum** (李), standing three to four feet tall. Its fruit emits moonlight-like radiance at night, illuminating a room like a lantern. A single stalk bears nine fruits, which, upon falling to the ground, quickly expand to the size of a seven-inch diameter **mirror** (镜盘), pressing into the earth one to two inches deep. When viewed at night, the fruit’s glow resembles the **eyes of a cow** (牛目) gazing and blinking.

The **fifth herb, Báijiāng Kǔguò Qièyù Zhī** (White Jiang Bitter-Exceeding Cut Jade Herb), surpasses even the **Yùzhī** (Jade Herb) in bitterness.

The **Yínghuǒ Zhī** (Glowing Fire Herb), as *Zhēnkuò* (True Edicts) states: On **Liángcháng Shān** (Good Constant Mountain), there exists a herb resembling a **glowing firefly** (荧火), whose fruit appears grass-like but is not. Its **purple flowers** (紫华) are as large as beans, and when viewed at night, they emit light. Consuming this herb clarifies the mind (心孔明), enabling one to read by moonlight.

The **Jiǔjīng Zǐgē Zhī** (Nine-Stem Purple Mushroom), **Dānzhū** (Crimson Pearl), and **Yùjiāng** (Jade Nectar), along with the **Lánggě Zhī** (Lánggě Herb), are all recorded in *Zhōushì Xuántōng Jì* (Master Zhou’s Secret Transmission of Daoist Penetration).

The **Dānzhī** (Crimson Herb) mentioned above, according to Daoist transmissions, is not something ordinary mortals can easily obtain.

**Shí Nǎo** (Stone Brain) is recorded by the lords as coming from the northern cave of **Fāngshān** (Square Mountain). **Máo Yangzi Jiāng Bózhēn** (Master Máo of the Sentient Sun, Jiang Bózhēn) once took and consumed it. There is also this substance in the center of **Běikūn** (Northern Kun).

**Shí Shèng** (Stone Victory) resembles stone but is smaller, spotted, and softer. It is found everywhere.

Consuming this causes one to feel **warmth** (身热) intermittently and also prevents **thirst** (不渴). According to *Zhēnzhǐ* (True Edicts), it cures **wind-related numbness and paralysis** (疗风痹).

**Shí Zhōng Rǔ** (Stone Bell Milk) is recorded in the *Běncǎo* (Classic of Herbs) as follows: In **Máoshān** (Mao Mountain), the soil and stones are mixed, and the milk-like substance is slightly black and smooth. It is called **Máoshān Rǔ** (Mao Mountain Milk), with a **slightly cold nature** (微寒).

**Yǔyú Liáng** (Yǔyú Grain), as the *Běncǎo* states: **Máoshān** has excellent specimens, resembling **niúhuáng** (ox gallstone), with layered, armored scales. The finest parts are purple, resembling **miǎn** (a type of cloth), and when blown upon, they leave no residue. However, it should be finely ground and then decocted with water to extract the juice, which must be clarified—**no sand or soil should remain** (勿令有沙土也). As *Yǐnjū* (Hidden Dwelling) notes: This substance is obtained by digging into the earth of **Máoshān**, and the finest specimens bear **purple flowers** (紫华). It is **delicate and refined** (靡靡), suitable for consumption and medicinal use.

**Nánzhù** (Southern Candle), according to *Qīngxū Zhēnrén Nèichuán* (Inner Transmission of the Pure Void Immortal), is a plant whose **trunk resembles wood** (木本), but its **leaves resemble grass** (似草), hence its name **Nánzhù Cǎo** (Southern Candle Grass). It is also known as **Hóushú Cǎo** (Hóushú Grass), **Nánxù** (Southern Continuation), and **Wéinà Mù** (King of the Wéinà Trees).

**Xiǎoxǔ Zhēnrén** (Master Xiao of the Tiny Allowance) states: **Fāngshān** (Square Mountain) has an exceptional variety of **Hóushú Cǎo**, with large leaves. The **Hàoyuè** (Broad Valley) region also calls it **Rǎnshú** (Stained Grass).

As *Dēngzhēn Yǐnjiào* (Hidden Precepts of Ascending the Dao) records: The **Sān Máo** (Three Mao Mountains) and **Sì Píng** (Four Flat Mountains) have fewer of these plants, but their trunks are large. Their **fruits resemble tea berries** (茱萸), ripening in the **eighth** or **ninth month**, with a **sour yet sweet taste** (酸美可食). The leaves do not grow opposite each other, resembling **míng leaves** (茗) but rounded. Their flavor is **heavy and intoxicating** (厚味小醉), and they remain evergreen in both **winter and summer** (冬夏常青). Their **branches and stems are slightly purple** (枝茎微紫), and the large trees reach heights of four to five **zhang** (丈), though they are **brittle** (甚脆) and easily broken.

The **good prescription** (良方) attributed to **Shěn Cúnzhōng** (Shěn the Hidden Middle) is not the **Nántiān Zhù** (Southern Heaven Candle), as previously stated.

**Mùběncǎo** (Wood-Born Grass), as *Yǐnjū* states: The finest specimens come from **Báishān** (White Mountain), **Jiāngshān** (Jiāng Mountain), and **Máoshān**. According to *Zhēnkuò*, the **Zǐwēi Fūrén Mù** (Wood of the Purple Darkness Lady) is praised for its benefits, and several prescriptions for its consumption are transmitted.

**Páoyào** (Peony), as *Yǐnjū* states: The finest specimens come from **Báishān**, **Jiāngshān**, and **Máoshān**, being **white and large** (白而长大). Other regions have it, but it is often **red** (赤). There are also three varieties recorded in the **Páoyào Cōng** (Peony Canon): **Máoshān Guànzǐ** (Mao Mountain Crown), **Zǐlóuzǐ** (Purple Tower), and **Máoshān Hóng** (Mao Mountain Red).

**Huángjīng**, when **nine-steamed and nine-baked** (九蒸九曝), preserves youthful appearance (驻颜). As *Yǐnjū* states: It is highly regarded in Daoist scriptures, and its **roots, leaves, flowers, and fruits** (根叶华实) can all be consumed or used in medicines. It is best taken in **alcohol dispersions** (酒散随宜), and the **Máoshān** variety is the finest.

**Hé Shǒuwū**, as the *Běncǎo* states: It was transmitted by **Zǔnéng Sū** (the Sage who inherited the Ancestor’s ability). Consuming it is beneficial. In **Táng Yùnhé** (Tang Yuanhe, 812 CE), **Monk Wénxiàng** (文象) encountered an **old man of Máoshān** (茅山老人), who then passed down its cultivation. **Lǐ Yì** (李翱) later recorded this in his **Fānglù** (Square Records).

**Fùzǐ**, known in the mountains as **Máofù** (Mao Attachment), is smaller than the **Shǔ** (Sichuan) variety but has **weaker efficacy** (气劣) and **stronger ability to dispel dampness** (大去湿).

**Wūtóu** (Monk’s Head) has the same properties as **Fùzǐ**.

**Jǔpú** (Galingale), sourced from **Jǔpú Tán** (Galingale Pond), grows to one **inch** (寸) with twelve **nodes** (节).

**Suìlíng** (Dried Poria), **Báishú** (White Atractylodes), **Gǒuqǐ** (Lycium Fruit), **Zéxiè** (Alisma), **Huánglián** (Coptis), **Juémíng** (Spiegel’s Ironweed), **Máosháo** (Mao Peony), **Jiégēng** (Platycodon), **Xìxīn** (Asarum), **Qiánhú** (Peucedanum), **Jùmǔ** (Curculigo), **Fángfēng** (Ligusticum), **Yīngsù** (Poppy), **Xuán Húsǔo** (Black Cohosh), **Tiānnánxīng** (Arisaema), **Huángdú** (Solomon’s Seal), **Shānyào** (Dioscorea), **Yùjùn** (Jade Fungus), **Zǐyú** (Purple Colocasia), and **Jīn Yīngzǐ** (Golden Poppy Seed) are all refined into **medicinal pastes** (炼为膏) or **decocted as alcohol tinctures** (煎酒和服), with a taste like **honey** (饴).

These are **remarkable trees and rare plants** (名木异卉).

The **Left-Nu Cypress** was planted by the hand of **Xù Chángshǐ** of **Jìn**, standing in **Yùchén Guān**. The **Crane-Top Pine**, also called the **Nine-Branched Pine**, is found atop the **Crane Temple**; it is said that when **Máo Jūn** governed **Yìchéng**, he ascended here, and its twin trunks suggest it may not be the original tree. The **Nine-Sun Pine** stands on the northern slope of **Jīnjūn Shān**, its rainbow-hued branches arching to the earth, its ancient majesty unmatched.

The **Recluse’s Pine** grows atop the **Fāngtán** of **Xuánzhōu’s** hermitage. The **Coiled-Dragon Pine** is beside **Qīngzhēn Guān**. The **Scripture Platform Pine** was planted before the **Tàiyuán Hall** of **Chóngshòu Guān**—in the late **Sòng**, a Daoist from **Xiányáng’s** **Lǎojūn Scripture Platform** transplanted its roots here; its fragrant wood, verdant and rare, surpasses common trees.

The **Loquat-Plum Tree** stood in the **Xiàbó Palace**; when **Dà Sīmìng Jūn** first entered the mountains, he dwelled beneath it, building a hut to await his two younger brothers. The **Residual Vermilion Well** remains, though the tree is now gone. The **discarded drum** hidden in **Xiàbó** was carved from a single block of wood, over three *chǐ* in diameter—it is said to have been made from an ancient tree’s trunk.

The **Ancient Trees of Fúxiāng** were planted by **Liáng Zhāomíng Tàizǐ** above the **Fúxiāng Well**; though half its heartwood has rotted, its vitality thrives anew. The **Wild Peach** and **Slanting-Li Tree** are recorded in **Wèi Gōng’s** *Píngquán Records of Plants*, both native to **Máoshān**. The **White Li Tree** bears seeds left by **Zhǎn Xiānrén**. The **Fúxiāng Nai** resembles a **Lì bird** but is smaller, said to dispel pestilence.

The **Mandarin Duck Tree** in **Gǔniú Cáo** has two trunks fused at their crowns, with no visible joints. The **Stream Reeds**—recorded as *fāngsuì* in **Píngquán’s** *Fragrant Reeds*—grow in **Máoshān’s** eastern streams; the *Yǐnjū* calls them *suìhuā*, purple-blossomed and thriving in shallow waters, said to have been planted by the **female immortal** **Qián Miàozhēn**.

The **Jade Orchid’s** buds exhale a subtle essence—another variant of the **Zhīyīng** (mushroom). The **Orchid**, **Osmanthus**, **Tea**, and **Lucky Fragrance** complete the account.

(*Máoshān Zhì*, Volume 19 concludes.)

**Volume 20 of the *Records of Máoshān***, compiled by the **Succeeding Master of the Upper Clarity Daoist Lineage**, **Liù Dàbīn**, records the **Gold and Stone** section.

The **Inscription of the Nine Sacrificial Offerings to the True Person of the Three Teáos**—its **Jade Tablet Text of the Nine Sacrificial Offerings** appears in the **Decree and Supplementary Ink** section.

In the **third year of the Common Era** (under the **Liáng** dynasty), the year **Rén Yín**, on the **first day of the fifth month**, **Rén Chén**, and the **fifteenth day**, **Bǐng Wǔ**, the **disciple of the Three Caverns**, **Zhènghào** of **Zhāng Jùn’s** district, and the **Daoist of Máoshān**, **Sūn Wéntāo**, inscribed it, while **Yuàn Dàoshù** engraved the characters.

The **True Person of Great Origin, Sīmìng Jūn**, whose given name was **Yíng**, with the courtesy name **Shūshēn**, hailed from **Nán Guān** of **Xiànyáng**. He was born in the **fifth year of the Middle Element** (under the **Hàn** dynasty), the year **Bǐng Shēn**, when the **Great Year** (太歲) coincided with the **Hàn Scène Emperor’s** reign. At **eighteen**, he abandoned his family to study the **Dao**, entering **Héngshān** for six years. By then, he was **twenty-five**.

Moved by the **Dao’s** divine penetration, he then followed **Wáng Jūn** of **Xīchéng** for **seventeen years**. The **True Lord of Fixed Records**, whose given name was **Gù**, with the courtesy name **Jìwěi**, was the second brother of **Taiyuan Lord**. He was born in the year **Gēngzǐ** of *Hòuyuán*’s third year. From his youth, he was renowned for his **moral integrity and upright conduct**, earning high praise for his **virtuous and refined character**. Due to his **superior learning and fitness for office**, in the second year of **Xuāndì’s** *Dìjié*, he was appointed as **Magistrate of Wéiyáng**, later transferred to **Western City Military Commander**. In the fourth year, fourth month, he was appointed **Governor of Shàngjùn** and **Grandee of the Five Departments**, departing on the same day as **Dìnglù Lord**. On the day of his **meeting with the Lord of Fate and the Guest**, he was **ninety-eight years old**.

In the fifth year of **Yuándì’s** *Yǒngyuán*, during the year **Rénwǔ**, they crossed the river to seek their elder brother. At that time, the **Middle Lord** was **one hundred and fifty years old**, and the **Younger Lord** was **one hundred and thirty years old**. Your station compared to that of a **Worldly Attendant**. Your elder brother, **Kuì**, with the worldly name **Zhèn**, and your second brother, **Hǔfāng**, with the worldly name **Lián**, also attained the Dao. **Kuì** now has a **Celestial Descendant**, **Língzhēn**, in the mountains, urging the establishment of a **Hall for True Succession** to honor the distant ancestors.

**Inscription for Master Táo of Zhúyáng’s Precious Retreat**
Composed by **Emperor of Liang**

In the **Tàihé** era, there was **Xǔ Yuǎn**, a wandering traveler, who was a **cherished friend of Yúnxiāo** and a **refined guest of Tàixū**. The Master’s conduct was as precise as a square and round, his footsteps truly followed the **Dao/Way** of the noble. Before the foundations were laid, he had already raised the structure. Towering heights defied measure, allowing one to gaze upon the **Flying Star** through the windows; lofty arches soared, leaning upon the balustrades to behold the **rising sun**. The cascading waters formed a boundary along the **Dao/Way**, like the **Celestial River**’s horizontal waves; striking the rocks, they rose as clouds, as if **odd peaks** emerged from their **recesses**. The inscription reads:

> *He began in profound silence,*
> *Yet transformed into harmony and praise.*
> *Though his body was entrusted to the outer realm,*
> *His heart aligned with the **Dao/Way** of chaos.*
> *He adhered to the **Dao/Way** and followed **virtue/power**,*
> *Thus accumulating sincere devotion.*
> *He looked back to Fénshè,*
> *And inquired through distant seals.*
> *The retreat of Zhúyáng flourished,*
> *The pavilions of **virtue/power** rose in splendor.*
> *The quiet terrace crowned the moon,*
> *The light **#2** pavilion welcomed the wind.*
> *Gazing at the dawn’s lofty branches,*
> *Lost in misty heights, his elegance refined.*
> *His vision spanned the mountains and rivers,*
> *Surveying the **imperial capital** and lands beyond.*
> *Emerald ridges stretched a thousand peaks,*
> *Clear streams flowed through ten thousand valleys.*
> *Shadows fell upon layered cliffs,*
> *Grace blossomed in hidden recesses.*

**Inscription for the Longshà Retreat of Máo Mountain**
Composed by **Táo Yǐnjū of Huáyáng**

The myriad phenomena of the cosmos, though vast and intricate, do not exceed the realm of **Yīn** and **Yáng**. The hundred teachings, though diverse, do not surpass the boundaries of the **Three Teachings**. Those who adorn their **Dao/Way** with rituals and propriety confine themselves to the **inner chambers** of the court; those of upright character abandon their **flags and banners** in the **mountainous wilderness**. The inscription reads:

> *Great is the **Primordial Dao/Way** of Heaven,*
> *All things derive their origin from it.*
> *When the **Sovereign Kings** receive their mandate,*
> *The **Three Powers** are thereby harmonized.*
> *Only the **sage** perceives the **spirit**,*
> *Only the **spirit** bestows blessings.*
> *His **virtue/power** shines in songs and bells,*
> *His name is recorded in **maps and histories**.*
> *He cherished his brothers as friends,*
> *With reverence for **Xī Xuān**.**
> *His words followed the **flourishing deeds** of the past,*
> *His actions honored the **legacy of his ancestors**.*
> *He dared to follow ancient customs,*
> *Yet innovated among the **mixed teachings**.*
> *Engraved on stone, it shall not decay,*

**Inscription for the Qǔlín Retreat of Máo Mountain**
Composed by **Táo Yǐnjū of Huáyáng**

Layered ridges stood outside,
Deep halls reflected within,
Slanted caves connected nearby,
Coiling springs mirrored afar.
He aspired to **virtue/power** and leaned on **ren**,
Praying for life and **virtue/power**’s command,
Between **Heaven** and **Earth**,
Like the **ordinary** and the **sage**.
Roofs aligned with lofty branches,
Each declared their understanding of the **Dao/Way**.
Ascending the **ancient paths** of **Jīngwèi**,
Climbing the rocks, his words refined.
Who could rival **Qǔlín**?
Only it stood as the **most robust and splendid**.
Concealing his nearness, he **refined his skill**,
Guarding this place until his **end of life**.
The **true handwriting** of **Huáyáng’s recluse** remains.

**Note on the Original Handwriting of Emperor Yuǎndì:**
When **Emperor Yuǎndì** was still a **feudal prince**, he sent the inscription to the mountain, which still remains in the **Zhúyáng’s retreat**.

Additionally, there was the **Longyuǎn retreat** constructed by **Nánpíng Wáng Xiāo Wěi**, where **Hóngjǐng’s** disciple **Xuān Qīngyuǎn** resided. **Xuān** was the **Master of the Dao/Way** named **Fǎxián**, the **missing two characters** being his teacher. When the **Master of Xuān** first entered the mountain, he composed a poem:

> *In the cold valley as morning approaches,*
> *I seek both the **scenic beauty** and the **true Dao**.*
> *The square altar is shaded by dense leaves,*
> *The water reveals the **scarlet scales** of fish.**
> *Though the **peach grove** may shelter beasts,*
> *The **mushroom fields** await the **worthy**.*
> *Once the **elixir** is refined, the **stones** will transform,*
> *When the **furnace** changes, the **silver** will melt.*
> *Know that this **victorious place** is distant,*
> *Here, one is **free from worldly dust**.*

**Emperor Zhāo Líng Wáng** once entered **Máo Mountain** to seek **Xuān Qīngyuǎn**, and inscribed a poem on the wall:

> *The **Jīngmén** hills and valleys are many,*
> *The **wine jar**’s window lets in **wind and clouds**.*
> *Unless one harbors the **recluse’s spirit**,*
> *Who can endure the **dew and frost**?’

In the **west of Zhúyáng’s retreat**, there was also the **Longshà retreat** constructed by **Longshà’s Succeeded King**, whose foundations still remain. **Liáng Chāng Hóu** also erected a **stone stele**, with **Hóngjǐng** composing the inscription, now also found in **Zhúyáng’s retreat**.

Two miles north, there is the residence of the **recluse Zhōu Hóngràng**. On **Léipíng Mountain**, there is a spring named **Liǔgǔ Jì**, also called **Tián Gōng Quán**. According to the *Máo Transmission*, it states: *On the left of the mountain, the spring is named Liǔgǔ; on the west of the ridge, it is called Yánggǔ.* In the past, **Tián Shū** resided here and drew water, thus naming it. This spring is the **Yùjīn Shā** water, which benefits one’s health. Today, its water is so pure that **clothes washed in it do not require ash**.

**Hóngjǐng’s stone ode reads:**

> *To the left, the **Liǔgǔ** spring flows,*
> *To the right, the **Yánggǔ** spring rises.*
> *The earth cradles the **north’s dark hues**,
> *The well yields the **wind’s gate spring**.*

There was also the **Guō Yú** pool. In the past, the **Yān brothers**—**Guō Cháo** and his three siblings—all claimed to have **attained the Dao**, and they also held **official positions in the cavern**. **Guō Cháo** was the eldest, and when he first arrived at the mountain, he cultivated here, naming the pool **Yú** as an omen of this **auspicious sign**.

A **stone carving** of **Táo Yǐnjū’s** earlier **small portrait** was initially hidden in the **house of Jiàn’ān Xú Hóng**. In the **Xuánhé Year 12 (1120 CE)** of the **Song Dynasty**, the **Daoist** **Fāng Nánhúá** copied and engraved it, passing it down through generations.

**Inscription for Master Zhenbai’s Retreat at Tao’s Hidden Dwelling**
Composed by **Prince Xiao Yun of Shaoling**
**Master Zhenbai’s** name was **Hongjing**, with the courtesy name **Tongming**, originally from **Pingyang in Ji Province**.

His ancestors descended from **Emperor Yao’s** **Tao-Tang lineage**,
For Yao ruled **Ji Province’s** **Pingyang**,
And thus they settled there.
When the **dragon horse** beheld the **Five-Colored Auspicious Symbols**,
And the **reverent and bright** displayed the **Eight Auspicious Patterns**,
Their **radiance** spread across the **lands**,
Their **virtue** extended to all **officials**.
Their **grand lineage** stretched far and wide,
Their **ties** unbroken and long.
When the **Han Dynasty** arose,
He served as **Emperor Gaozu’s** **Right General of the Palace**.
His son, **Qingzhi**, rose to the rank of **Chancellor**.
In the late **Eastern Han**, after migrating south,
They first resided in **Danyang**.
His seventh-generation ancestor, **Jun**, served under **Emperor Wu of Jin** as **General Pacifying the South** and **Magistrate of Xing Prefecture**.
His grandfather, **Long**, was a **Military Advisor to the Southern Commander** in the **Song Dynasty**.
His father, **Zhenbao**, held the posts of **Secretary of State** and **Attendant to the Prince of Jian’an**.
All bore **clean and upright conduct**,
And were **well-versed in literature and history**.

Master **Hongjing** possessed the **harmonious breath of primordial essence**,
And bore the **elegant bearing of the lofty winds**.
He encompassed the **Seven Virtues**,
And cultivated the **Nine Powers**.
He walked the **Dao of Benevolence** and trod the **Path of Righteousness**,
Like a **mountain standing firm** and a **pool abiding deep**,
Whose **height** cannot be measured,
Whose **depth** cannot be fathomed.
His **Dao** soared as high as the **Milky Way**,
His **noble spirit** extended as far as the **celestial clouds**.

At **six years old**, he already understood **writing**,
And could compose **prose**.
By **seven**, he had read **thousands of words** from the *Scripture on Filial Piety*, the *Analects*, and the *Mao Commentary on the Odes*.
From a young age, he **delighted in** the **classics**,
And as a boy, he **recited** **poetry and prose**.
Compared to the **ancients**, they would have **much to be ashamed of**,
Thus he **doubted his own worth** and **praised others**.
Because of this, he **withdrew from public life** and **composed odes**.

There was a **villager** who obtained **Ge Hong’s** *Transmission of the Immortals*,
And read of the **Eight Worthies of Huainan** and other **sages’** deeds,
Then sighed, saying: *"Reading this book gives one **the spirit of soaring above the clouds**."*
From then on, he **studied it night and day**,
Without pause from **dawn to dusk**.

At **twenty-seven**, he became **Attendant Scholar to the Prince of Yi**,
And **supervised the Palace Archives**.

The Prince sought worthy men, and the imperial gardens summoned scholars—
the court found no fault in its selection, for all who came were men of worth.
Obscured though Oblique’s literary skill might be, it could not rival the balance of a scribe,
Nor could Sun Chu’s eloquence suffice to bear the weight of his reputation.
In the Qi dynasty, there was a fondness for grand palaces—
now the Prince was restoring the old gardens of Qingxi, rebuilding and expanding them,
and submitting a petition with a commemorative ode.
The work was splendid and refined—
his poem of joyful service matched the brilliance of the *Jingfu* edicts.

The Emperor read it for a long time and deemed it excellent,
then granted him the title of *Deliberative Attendant at Court*.
He took up his post with solemn duty,
ever vigilant from dawn to dusk,
attending the spring and autumn audiences—
this was the way of the unadorned and sincere.

The Master had never sought honor,
yet often wished to resign.
He wrote to his kin and friends:
*"In my earlier years, I never wished to be asked by others."*
At forty, he fulfilled his ambition in the mountains and forests.
Now thirty-six, time would not wait—
how divine was his foresight!
Why should he torment himself further?

The following year, he submitted his resignation,
bundling his hairpins and departing beyond the city gates,
untying his official sash at the northern slopes of the mountains,
joining the recluses of Jiqiu, emulating Liu Bang’s refusal of grain,
and preparing his boat for departure.
The court sent inquiries, and scholars saw him off with two *cushion essays* and four *hidden verses*—
his departure was as effortless as that of the ancients, though from a different age.

He set out with staff in hand, wandering through famous peaks,
until he reached Jurong and ascended Maoling—
this place was the abode of immortals, a sacred refuge of marvels.
Once entered, none returned.
He settled there and made it his home.

The Master said:
*"The Master said: ‘Retire to seek one’s purpose, act with virtue to fulfill the Way.’
I have heard these words but never seen such a man.
Now my virtue is fulfilled—
there is no need for further retreat.
I ask only to join those who seek their purpose,
thus I call myself a recluse,
following Zhi Chan’s *Embrace of Simplicity* and Shi An’s *Mystic Tranquility*."

Leaning against cliffs, dwelling in shadows,
nesting among trees, hiding at the forest’s edge,
weaving branches into a dwelling, carving a path as his gate,
facing cascades from sheer precipices, gazing upon mist-laden woods,
deep gorges and steep peaks—
the mists entwined like silken threads,
his pillow a stone, his cup the stream.
Mountain birds did not disturb him,
and as he gathered herbs, wild beasts did not dare approach.
He wandered freely, unbound by the world,
his spirit untouched, as if severed from mortal cares.

When the Qi dynasty declined and the Mandate of Heaven faltered,
the land of water trembled in Jiachen—
the Master, pondering omens, foresaw the signs.
Thus, he cut off all correspondence, near and far.
*"I have heard of Xia Fu in the past,
but now I see it in you, Master."*

The great fortune of Dai Liang was at hand,
the Mandate of Heaven clear—
the Three Stars shone bright, the Four Seas at peace.
The Master submitted a petition in celebration,
and his letters were once more answered.

Since the *Tianjian* era, he was repeatedly summoned with imperial edicts,
supplied with medicines and provisions without end,
and showered with seasonal favors unmatched by any other.
For seven years, he briefly visited Nan Yue.

This mountain—
the pivot of the *Biwei* winds, the celestial support of Kunlun,
overlooking the Eight Directions, between the Nine Regions—
its trees bore fangs of jade, its grasses sprouted chariots.
Detached from the world, he lingered, forgetting to return.

In the eleventh year, an imperial envoy, the Left Secretary of State Huiming,
was sent to summon the Master back to Maoshan,
granting him a residence to dwell in.
*"Like Xuān Zhong descending to serve the Heavenly Old Man,
or the Han Emperor honoring the River Master—
how could I refuse such an honor today?"*

Nurturing his purpose amid mountains and rivers,
he spent many years refining his life,
his vitality preserved, divine omens descending—
no fierce beast dared approach, no demons or spirits encountered him.
Thorns did not grow in his courtyard,
his neighbors were as distant as the *Que* enclave,
his steps emitted divine springs,
and distant cedars swayed in response.
Thus, feathered immortals lingered,
celestial guests ascended and descended,
cranes and phoenixes gathered,
and the *zhi* and *ying* mushrooms flourished in abundance.

In the second year of *Dà Tóng* (429 CE),
in the year *Bingchen*, on the first day of the third month,
the twelfth day, *Gengchou*,
he bade farewell and departed—
aged eighty-one.

Ah, how the distinctions of right and wrong may be reconciled! The self and the world are one, and life and death may be forgotten—awake and dreaming are as one.

In the winter of the tenth month, on the fourteenth day of the *Jiǎyǒu* year of the *Dàlì* era (775 CE), the Master departed in seclusion at the separate retreat of Zìyáng (紫阳). He was eighty-seven years of age.

Thus, he wandered freely in the Dao, esteemed as a sage by kings, honored with the privilege of riding in a palanquin, and summoned by imperial decree—once as the teacher of the Yellow Emperor, now as the guide of the Emperor Xuánzōng.
