chunks.original_text: 奉旨左右中书，复稍有能者，惟周喜赞。 夫以含心之黄，实伺夹锺吐气。 今既自上体妙，为下理用成工。 每惟申锺王论於天下，进艺方兴。 所恨臣沉朽不能钻仰高深，自怀欺慕。 前奉神笔三纸，并今为五。 非但字字注目，乃画画抽心。 日觉劲媚，转不可说。 以酬昔岁，不复相类。 正此即为楷，何复多寻锺王。 臣心本自敬重，今者弥增爱服。 俯仰悦豫，不能不以启适。 伏蒙二卷，伏览标帖。 皆如圣旨，既不显垂允少留，不能久停。 已就摹索者，一段未毕。 不赴今信，纸巷先已经有。 兼多他杂，无所复取。 亦请伺俱了，日奉送。 兼此诸书，是篇章体。 臣今不辫，复得修习。 惟愿细书，如《乐毅论》、《太师箴》例。 依仿以写，经传永存。 冥题中精要而已。 再答后启 又省别疏云：故当宜微以着，赏此既胜事，口风训非嫌，云云。 然非所习，聊试略言。 夫运笔邪，则无芒角。 执手宽，则书缓弱。 点画短，则法臃肿。 点撇长，则法离撕。 画促，则字横。 画疏，则形慢。 拘则之势，放又少，则纯骨无媚，纯肉无力。 少墨，浮涩。 多墨，笨钝。 比并皆然任之所之，自然之理也。 若抑扬得所，趣舍无违。 值笔连断，触势峰郁，扬波折节，中规合矩。 分问下注，浓纤有方。 肥瘦相和，骨力相称。 婉婉暧暧，视之不足。 棱棱凛凛，常有生气。 适眼合心，便为甲科。 众家可识，亦当复贯串耳。 六文#5可工，亦当由习耳#6。 一闻能持，一见能记。 且古且今，不无其人。 大抵为论终归是习，程邈所以能变书体，为．之旧也。 张芝所以能善书工，学之积也。 既旧既积，方可以肆其谭。 吾少来乃至不尝口画甲子，无论於篇纸。 老而言之，亦复何谓，正足见嗤於当今，贻笑於后代。 遂有独冠之言，览之背热。 隐真於是乎，累真矣。 此直一艺之精，非吾所谓胜事。 此道心之尘，非吾所谓无欲也。 《乐毅论》，愚心近甚疑是摹，而不敢轻言。 今旨以为非真，窃自信颇涉有悟。 箴赞过为沦弱，许静素段遂蒙永给。 仰铭矜奖，益无以喻。 如此书虽不在法例，而致用理均，背问细楷兼复两玩，先於都遇得飞白一卷，云是逸少好迹。 臣不尝别见，无以能辨。 唯觉势力惊绝，谨以上．圣。 於臣非用，脱可充阁，愿仍以奉上，臣昔於马澄处见逸少《正书目录》一巷，澄云：右军劝进《洛神赋》诸书十余首，皆作今体。 唯急就章二篇，古法紧细近脱。 忆此语，当是零落已不复存。 澄又云：帖注出装者，皆拟安诸王及朝士。 臣近见三巷。 首帖亦谓已久，分本不敢识。 此正复希，於三卷中一二条，更得预出装之例耳。 天旨遂复，顿给先卷，下情益用悚息。 近初见巷，题云二十三四已。 欣其多，今者赐书第至二百七十。 惋讶无已，天府如海，非一饼所汲。 良用息心，前后都已蒙见大小五卷於野拙之分，实以过幸。 若非殊恩岂可鴂望。 愚固本博涉而不能精，昔息书不可看，乃愿作主书史。 晚爱隶法，又羡典掌之人。 尝言人生，数纪之内。 识解不能周流。 天壤区区，唯充恣五欲，实可愧耻。 每以为得作才鬼，亦当胜於顽仙，至今犹然。 始欲翻之，自无射以后国政方股。 山心歉默，不敢复以虚闲尘触。 馑於此题事，遂成烦黩。 伏愿圣慈，照录诚嫌。
chunks.translated_text:
**Memorial of Yinju to Emperor Wu on Calligraphy (Continued)**

By Your Majesty’s decree, I have reviewed the works held by the Central Secretariat, and among those with some ability, only Zhou Xizan stands out. For the yellow of the heart’s core truly awaits the exhalation of *jiazhong*’s qi. Now that Your Majesty’s own calligraphy embodies the sublime, it perfects both principle and application below. Whenever I reflect on Your Majesty’s discussions of Zhong [You] and Wang [Xizhi] as models for the realm, the advancement of this art is only just beginning. What grieves me is my own dullness—I cannot fathom such heights, and my admiration verges on self-deception.

Previously, I received three sheets of Your Majesty’s divine brushwork, and with these, the total now reaches five. Not only does each character command my gaze, but every stroke pierces my heart. Day by day, their vigor and charm grow beyond description. Compared to those of past years, they are no longer of the same order. If these alone serve as models, why seek further among Zhong and Wang?

My reverence has always been profound, but now my admiration deepens still. Joy and delight fill me, and I cannot but report this. I prostrate myself in gratitude for the two scrolls, having examined their inscribed slips. All accords with Your Majesty’s decree. Though I dared not presume to retain them long, I could not bear to part with them at once. The tracing I had begun remains unfinished. Since the courier must depart now, and the paper lanes are already prepared, and as there are many other miscellaneous texts without further use, I shall await their completion and return them all together.

These writings are of the *pianzhang* style. Though I have not yet distinguished their forms, I may yet study and practice them. I only wish for finely written texts, such as the *Yue Yi Lun* or *Tai Shi Zhen*, to copy and preserve for posterity—recording only their essentials.

**Further Response to Your Majesty’s Edict**
I have also reviewed Your Majesty’s separate note, which states that such matters should be subtly recorded, for this appreciation is a noble pursuit, and oral instruction is not to be dismissed. Though this is not my usual practice, I venture a brief attempt.

When the brush is held askew, the strokes lack sharpness. When the grip is too loose, the writing becomes weak. Short dots and strokes produce a bloated form; long ones, a torn and scattered effect. If horizontal strokes are too compressed, the character tilts; if too sparse, the shape slackens. Constraint yields stiffness, while excess freedom lacks structure—pure bone without charm, pure flesh without strength. Too little ink makes the brush float and hesitate; too much, the strokes grow dull and sluggish. All these arise naturally from the hand’s movement.

Yet when modulation is apt and intent unerring, when the brush connects and severs with purpose, when it surges like waves and bends like joints, conforming to compass and square—when strokes descend in measured weight, their thickness and thinness balanced, their plumpness and leanness harmonized, their strength proportioned—then the writing appears gentle yet radiant, endlessly pleasing to the eye. Its edges sharp and its presence imposing, it seems alive. When it delights both eye and heart, it ranks among the finest. Even if one recognizes the styles of many masters, one must still grasp their underlying principles.

The Six Scripts may be mastered, but this too comes only through practice. Some can retain what they hear once; others, what they see once. Such people exist in every age. In the end, all discussion returns to practice. Cheng Miao reformed the script through long use; Zhang Zhi perfected his calligraphy through accumulated study. Only after long use and deep study can one discourse freely.

In my youth, I never even traced the *tian gan di zhi* on my palm, let alone on paper. To speak of it now is meaningless—it only invites ridicule from my contemporaries and mockery from future generations. Yet I have made bold claims, and reading them now makes my back burn with shame. In this, I have truly piled falsehood upon falsehood. This is but mastery of a single art, not what I would call a noble pursuit. It is but dust upon the heart’s Dao, not what I would call desirelessness.

Regarding the *Yue Yi Lun*, I have long suspected it to be a copy, though I dared not speak lightly. Now that Your Majesty deems it inauthentic, I trust my own judgment has gained some insight. The *Zhen Zan* is overly delicate and weak. That Xu Jingsu’s works were granted permanent provision fills me with awe at Your Majesty’s gracious praise, beyond words.

Though these writings do not follow standard models, their practical application and principle are sound. The fine regular script on the reverse invites repeated admiration. Earlier, in the capital, I obtained a scroll of *feibai* calligraphy, said to be Wang Xizhi’s prized work. Having never seen other examples, I could not verify it, but its power and force struck me as extraordinary. I humbly present it to Your Majesty. Though it serves no use to me, if it might grace Your Majesty’s collection, I would gladly offer it.

Once, at Ma Cheng’s residence, I saw a volume of Wang Xizhi’s *Zhengshu Catalogue*. Ma said that Wang had transcribed over ten works, including the *Luoshen Fu*, all in the modern style, except for two *Jijiu Zhang* pieces, which retained the tight, fine, and nearly archaic ancient method. Recalling this, I fear they have long since scattered and no longer survive. Ma also said that the inscribed slips from his traveling library were all imitations for the imperial princes and court officials. Recently, I saw three volumes. The first slip was said to be quite old, but I dared not presume to identify it. Such rarities are scarce. If even one or two slips from these three volumes could be included among the traveling library’s examples, it would be most fortunate.

Your Majesty’s decree has now granted the earlier volumes, filling me with awe and trepidation. When I first saw the volumes, they were numbered twenty-three or twenty-four. Delighted by their abundance, I now find the gifted texts have reached two hundred seventy. My astonishment knows no end. The imperial treasury is vast as the sea, not to be drawn by a single ladle. I can only still my heart in gratitude. Altogether, I have now received five volumes, large and small, far beyond what my crude talents deserve. Without Your Majesty’s extraordinary favor, how could I dare hope for such bounty?

By nature, I am broadly learned but lack precision. Once, I found my own calligraphy unworthy of viewing and aspired to become a scribe or historian. Later, I grew fond of clerical script and envied those who held official posts. I have often said that in the span of a human life, one’s understanding cannot encompass all things. The world is vast, yet we indulge only the five desires—this is truly shameful. I would rather become a talented ghost than a dull immortal, and this remains my conviction.

At first, I wished to abandon such pursuits, but since the *wuyi* year, state affairs have pressed heavily. My mountain heart grows weary and silent, and I dare not trouble Your Majesty with idle matters. Yet this topic has led me to importune Your Majesty excessively. I prostrate myself, praying that Your Majesty’s sagely compassion will forgive my presumption.
chunks.overlap_context:
require more finely written texts, I shall provide them. For instance, in the style of *lun* and *zhen*, Wang Xizhi’s calligraphy is not excessively fine. His *Yue Yi Lun* is somewhat robust, but I suspect it is not an authentic work. The *Tai Shi Zhen* is slightly more refined and charming, yet the brushwork is too delicate, and the style deviates—both have already been examined by the keenest eyes. Beyond these, there is nothing else to send.

**Memorial of Yinju to Emperor Wu on Calligraphy**

chunks.original_text: 省区别诸书，良有精赏。 所异同所未可知，悉可否耳。 给事黄门二纸。 为任静书。 观所送静书诸字，相附近二纸，静书体解杂，便当非静书。 复当以点画波撇，论极诸家之致。 此亦非可仓卒运於豪楮，且保拙守中也。 许任二迹并摹者并付反。 第一#7卷中有杂迹，谨疏注如#8别。 恐未允，愚衷并窃所摹者，亦以上呈。 近十余日精虑悚悸，无宁涉事。 遂至淹替不宜，复待填毕，余条并非用，唯《叔夜》《威笔》二篇是经书体式。 追以单部为恨，伏按卷上第数，甚为不少。 前旨唯有四卷，此似是宋元嘉中撰集。 当由自后多玫散失，逸少有名之迸不过数首。 《黄庭》《劝进》《像赞》《洛神》此等，不审令犹得存者。 第二十三巷今见有十二条在别纸，按此卷是右军书，惟有八条前《乐毅论》书，乃极劲利而非甚用意，故颇有坏字。 《太师箴》《大雅吟》用意甚至，而更成小拘束，乃是书扇头屏风好体，其余五片无的可称。 臣涛言一纸，此书项不惠而非右军，又不识谁边，又似是摹。 给事黄门二纸，治康沥一纸，是子敬书，亦似摹边。 后又治沥狸骨方一纸。 是子敬书亦是摹边。 右四条非右军书 第二十四卷今见有二十一条在按此卷是右军书者； 唯有十一条。 皆非甚合，进兼多漫，抹於华起，难复委曲。 前黄初二年一纸，是后人学右军谬袭告墓文一纸，是许先生书抱怀幽痛一纸，是张澄书五月十一日一纸，是摹王泯书被油尚想黄绮一纸，遂结滞一纸，凡一篇并复人所学，甚拙恩。 不复展一纸，是子敬书便复改月一纸是张翼书五月十五日孙白一纸，亦是王泯书治钦方一纸。 是谢安书 右十条非右军书。 伏恐未垂许以区别，今馑上许先生任静书，如别比方。 即可知王泯张澄张翼谢安书，公家应有。 锺王乃有一卷，传以为真。 意谓悉是摹学，多不足论。 有两三行许，似摹微得锺体。 逸少学锺的，可知近有二十许首。 此外字细画短，多是锺法。 今欲令人帖装，未便得付。 来月有竟者，当遣送也。 启伏览书，前意虽止二六。 而规矩爻周，后书不出二百亦褒贬大备，一言以蔽便书情极。 顿使元常老骨更蒙荣造，子敬懦肌不况泉夜。 唯逸少得进退其问，则玉科显然可观。 若非圣证品析，恐爱附近习之风永遂沦迷矣。 伯英既称草圣，元常亦自隶绝论。 旨所谓殆同一机，神宝旷世莫继。 斯理既明，诸画虎之徒，当日就辍笔。 反古归真，方弘盛世。 愚管见预闻，喜佩#9无届比，世皆尚子敬。 元常#10继以齐代，名实脱略海内。 非唯不复知有元常，於逸少亦然。 非排弃所可黜，涅而不淄，不过数族。 今奉此论自舞自跳，未足逞泄。 愿以所摹，窃示洪远思旷。 此二人皆是均思者，铃当赞仰踊跃，有盈半之益。 臣与洪远虽不相识，从子栩以学，往来因之有会。 但既在阁，恐或已应闻。 知摹者所装字大小不堪，均调郭看乃尚可，恐笔意大殊。 此篇方传千载，故宜令迹随矣。 所奉三纸，伏循字迹，大觉劲密。 窃恐既以言发意，意则应言，而心随意运#11手与笔会。 故益得谐。 称下情欢。

Having reviewed and distinguished the various manuscripts, I find your discernment truly refined. Whether they differ or align remains uncertain—all hinges on their merits. Two sheets are to be given to the *jishizhong* and *huangmen*: one for Ren Jing’s calligraphy.

Examining the characters sent under Jing’s name, they closely resemble the two sheets in question, yet Jing’s style is eclectic and fluid—this cannot be his work. One must further assess the nuances of brushstrokes, waves, and flourishes to grasp the essence of each master’s art. Such judgment cannot be rushed in the handling of brush and paper; for now, I shall guard my clumsiness and adhere to moderation. Both the copies of Xu Ren’s and Ren Jing’s works, along with the traced versions, are hereby returned. The first scroll (#7) contains miscellaneous pieces, which I have meticulously annotated in a separate note (#8). Fearing my assessment may not be just, I also submit the copies I privately made for Your Majesty’s review.

For over ten days, my thoughts have been fraught with anxiety, leaving no peace for other matters. Thus, this delay is unseemly, and I await the completion of the remaining tasks. The other entries are of no use, save for the two pieces, *Shuye* and *Weibi*, which adhere to the standard script style. I regret that they are presented as single volumes. Upon examining the scroll numbers, I find them far from few. Your earlier decree mentioned only four volumes, yet this collection appears to have been compiled during the *Yuanjia* era of the Liu-Song. Likely, many were later gathered and lost. Of Wang Xizhi’s renowned works, scarcely a handful survive—*Huangting*, *Exhortation to Advance*, *Portrait Eulogies*, and *The Goddess of the Luo River*—I cannot confirm whether these remain extant.

The twenty-third fascicle now contains twelve entries on a separate sheet. Of these, only eight are attributed to Wang Xizhi’s hand. The first, *Yue Yi Lun*, is executed with exceptional vigor yet lacks deliberate intent, resulting in several flawed characters. *The Grand Preceptor’s Admonition* and *The Great Odes* are painstakingly rendered but overly constrained, making them suitable only for fans or screens. The remaining five pieces offer little of note.

One sheet bears Minister Tao’s inscription, but this work is neither graceful nor by Wang Xizhi’s hand. Its provenance is unknown, and it appears to be a tracing. The two sheets for the *jishizhong* and *huangmen*, along with one sheet of *Zhikang Li*, are in Wang Xianzhi’s hand, though they too seem traced. Another sheet, *Ligu Fang*, is also by Wang Xianzhi and likewise a tracing. These four entries are not by Wang Xizhi.

The twenty-fourth fascicle now contains twenty-one entries, of which only eleven are attributed to Wang Xizhi. None are particularly fitting: many are careless, their strokes lacking refinement, and their elegance diminished, making detailed critique difficult. The first, from the second year of *Huangchu*, is a later imitation of Wang Xizhi’s style. One sheet, *Epitaph for a Tomb*, is by Master Xu; another, *Embracing Hidden Sorrow*, by Zhang Cheng; one dated the eleventh of the fifth month by a traced copy of Wang Min’s work; another, *Still Yearning for the Yellow and Qi*, also traced; one sheet of *Stagnation*; and a full piece, all imitations by others, clumsily executed. One sheet, undated, is by Wang Xianzhi but with altered months; another, dated the fifteenth of the fifth month, by Sun Bai; one sheet of *Zhiqin Fang* by Wang Min; and one by Xie An. These ten entries are not by Wang Xizhi.

Fearing Your Majesty may not yet deign to distinguish them, I now submit the calligraphy of Master Xu and Ren Jing for comparison, as outlined separately. From this, one may discern the hands of Wang Min, Zhang Cheng, Zhang Yi, and Xie An—works Your Majesty’s court should possess. Of the Zhong [Yao] and Wang [Xizhi] scrolls, one volume is traditionally deemed authentic, but I suspect all are traced copies, most unworthy of discussion. Only two or three lines faintly capture Zhong’s style. Wang Xizhi’s study of Zhong is evident in nearly twenty pieces. The rest, with their fine strokes and short lines, largely follow Zhong’s method.

I wish to have them mounted, but it is not yet convenient to deliver them. By next month, when the task is complete, I shall send them. Upon reviewing Your Majesty’s instructions, though the initial intent was limited to twelve pieces, the standards and judgments are comprehensive. Even if later works do not exceed two hundred, their praise and censure are fully encompassed—a single word suffices to capture the essence of calligraphy. This would instantly bestow new honor upon the aged bones of Zhong [Yao], while Wang Xianzhi’s delicate flesh would pale beside the night’s darkness. Only Wang Xizhi’s work allows for measured critique, revealing the jade-like purity of his art. Without Your Majesty’s sagely discernment in appraisal, the trend of favoring recent imitations may lead to eternal confusion.

Zhang Zhi is hailed as the sage of cursive script, and Zhong [Yao] himself is unmatched in clerical script. As the saying goes, their art shares a single mechanism—a divine treasure unmatched across ages. With this principle clarified, those who merely mimic the tiger should lay down their brushes at once. Returning to antiquity and restoring authenticity will truly herald a flourishing era.

My humble insights, though presumptuous, have been shared with joy and admiration beyond measure. The world now esteems Wang Xianzhi, while Zhong [Yao]’s legacy, though equal in the Qi and Liang dynasties, has faded in reputation. Not only is Zhong no longer recognized, but Wang Xizhi’s standing has also suffered. This is not a matter of rejection or dismissal but of being stained without purification—scarcely a few lineages remain. Now, upon receiving this discourse, I leap and dance with excitement, though it scarcely vents my fervor. I wish to privately show the traced copies to Hong Yuan and Si Kuang. These two are men of balanced judgment; they would surely leap with admiration, gaining more than half the benefit.

Though I do not know Hong Yuan personally, through my nephew Xu, we have corresponded and met. However, as he serves in the palace, he may have already heard of this. The size of the characters in the traced copies is unsuitable, but if Guo Jun were to adjust them, they might still suffice—though the brushwork’s intent may differ greatly. This work will be transmitted for a thousand generations, so the traces should follow accordingly.

Of the three sheets I present, upon examining the brushwork, I find them remarkably vigorous and precise. I fear that once words express intent, intent must align with words, and the heart must guide the hand and brush in harmony—only then can true accord be achieved. I humbly rejoice in this.

chunks.original_text: 仰宝奉愈，至世论咸云，江东无复锺迹。 常以欺息，皆片望中原廓清太丘之碑，可就摹探。 今论旨云，真迹虽少，可得而推。 是犹有存者，不审可复几字。 既无出见，理冒愿得工人摹填数行，脱蒙见赐，实为过幸。 又逸少学锺，势巧形密，胜於自运。 不审此例，复有几纸。 垂旨以黄庭像赞等诸文，可更有出给。 理自运之迹，今不复希。 请学锺妙，仰惟殊恩。 又启 逸少合吴兴以前，诸书犹未称。 凡原好进，皆是向会稽时永和十许年中者。 从失郡告灵不仕，以后略不复自书，皆使此一人，世中不能别见，其缓异呼？ 为末年书，逸少亡后，子敬年十七八。 全仿此人书，故遂成与之相似。 今圣旨标显，足使众识顿悟於逸少无。 末年之讥阮研，近闻有一人学研书，遂不复可别。 臣比郭摹所得，虽粗写字形，而无复其用笔迹势。 不审前后诸卷一两条，谨密者可得在出装之例。 复蒙垂给至年末问，否此泽自天，直以启审，非敢铃觊。 武帝答进玄通记手诏 省疏并见周氏遗迹真言，显然符验前诰二三，明白益为奇特。 四卷今留之，见渊文并具一二，唯增赞#12叹十二月二十日。 隐居进周氏玄通记启 某启去十月将末，忽有周氏事。 既在斋禁，无由即得启闻。 今谨撰事迹，凡四卷。 如别上呈，但某覆邺疑网，不早信悟。 追自咎悼，分贻刻责渊文，口具陈述。 伏愿宥以合惰，馑启。 茅山志卷之一竟 #1举（触）：笪本作『卑』。 #2标：笪本作『标』。 #3记：笪本作『寄』。 #4校：笪本作『核』。 #5文：笪本作『义』。 #6亦当由羽耳：笪本作『亦当复由习耳』。 #7『第』原本作『一』，据笪本改。 #8如：笪本作『一』。 #9佩：笪本作『备』。 #10常：原本作『末』，据笪本改。 #11运：笪本作『连』。 #12赞：原本作『降』，据笪本改。 茅山志序 皇庆改元，制赐茅山四十五代宗师刘大彬洞观微妙玄应真人。 后五年，褒封三茅真君，徽号各加二字：日真应，日妙应，日神应。 仍劫三峰为观，曰圣佑，日德佑，日仁佑。 明年，传坛之玉印久湮，至□是复出。 有司上其事，奉旨嘉升本山。 於是涣渥杳臻，灵芝挺瑞，神人以和。 凡经录楝宇，百废之宜饬治缮完者，宗师得以悉其心力焉。 又病，夫山志前约而后阙也，乃嘱诸入室弟子采集成书，来征予序，阅其所载，诏诰之隆，仙真之异，洞府之邃，坛录之传，人物之伟，楼观之盛，山水之清，草木之秀，碑刻之纪，题咏之工，莫不妒分类析，集然大备。 按茅山本句曲山，第八华阳洞天，第一地肺福地，汉茅君昆季栖遁登晨于此，山因氏茅。 迨晋魏，元君大畅厥绪，真风灵迹绵绵延延，郁为寰宇之名山，神灵之区奥也。 皇元治尚清静，自版图归职方氏，主坛席者，征至阙下，优降玺书金汤。 其教至宗师始显，被恩数度，越前躅。 於戏懿哉，盖山川之气，发舒於休息。 既久，亦宗师之道行，升闻。 寂通之妙，其在斯乎。 顾山志不可不辑，而丕既不可无述也。 昔唐玄宗问理化於李玄静，玄静对日：《道德经》，君王之师也。 汉文帝行其言，仁寿天下力又谘以金鼎，日：道德公也。 轻举公中之私耳。 后之人盍体玄静之格言，踵宗师之诚感。

Admiration for the treasured gifts grows ever deeper. As the world universally declares, the traces of Zhong [You] no longer exist in Jiangdong. I have long regretted this, cherishing only the distant hope that when the Central Plains are pacified, the stele of Taiqiu might be traced and studied. Now, however, the imperial decree states that though authentic traces are few, they may yet be inferred. This suggests some still remain—though I know not how many characters survive. Since I cannot view them in person, I dare presume to request that skilled artisans trace and fill several lines. Should I be so fortunate as to receive them, it would be an undeserved blessing.

Moreover, when [Wang] Yishao studied under Zhong [You], his technique—subtle in movement, dense in form—surpassed his own spontaneous brushwork. I wonder how many sheets of such examples remain. The decree further mentions that works like the *Huangting Xiang Zan* may yet be provided. As for his spontaneous brushwork, I no longer dare hope. I only beg to study Zhong’s marvels, humbly awaiting this singular grace.

Additionally, before Yishao assumed office in Wuxing, his calligraphy had yet to earn acclaim. All his finest works—those he cherished and advanced—date to his time in Kuaiji, roughly the decade of Yonghe. After resigning his post and withdrawing from service upon the death of his elder, he scarcely wrote again himself, entrusting all to a single scribe. Yet the world could not distinguish their hands—how strange! In his later years, after Yishao’s death, his son Zijing, then seventeen or eighteen, imitated this scribe’s style so perfectly that their scripts became indistinguishable. Now, by the imperial decree’s illumination, all may suddenly recognize Yishao’s late work.

As for the criticism of Ruan Yan’s calligraphy in his later years, I recently heard of someone who studied Yan’s script so closely that their hands could no longer be told apart. Among the works I obtained through Guo’s tracing, though the character forms are roughly rendered, the brushwork’s intent and momentum are lost. I wonder if among the previous scrolls, one or two meticulously executed examples might be included in the set to be mounted.

Again, I am deeply moved by the imperial grace extended to the end of the year. This favor descends from heaven; I merely report what I have ascertained, without presumption or desire. *Emperor Wu’s Rescript in Reply to the Presentation of the* Xuantong Ji:

Having reviewed the memorial and examined the authentic words of Zhou’s relics, their evident verification of earlier prophecies is all the more wondrous. The four scrolls are now retained. The profound texts are fully recorded in part, with only added praise and admiration. Twentieth day of the twelfth month.

*Memorial Presenting Zhou’s* Xuantong Ji *by the Recluse:*

Your servant respectfully reports: In the final days of the tenth month, Zhou’s affair suddenly arose. As I was then observing purification rites, I could not immediately memorialize it. Now, I have meticulously compiled the events into four scrolls, which I present separately. Yet I, having lingered in doubt like a fish in a net, failed to believe and awaken sooner. In remorse and sorrow, I deserve severe censure. The profound texts are orally recounted in full. I humbly pray for leniency toward my negligence. I prostrate myself in submission.

*End of the First Scroll of the* Maoshan Annals.

---

*Preface to the* Maoshan Annals:

In the first year of Huangqing, an imperial edict bestowed upon Liu Dabin, the forty-fifth patriarch of Maoshan, the title *True Man of Subtle and Mysterious Responses in the Grotto’s Observation*. Five years later, the Three Mao Lords were honored with additional two-character epithets: *True Response*, *Marvelous Response*, and *Divine Response*. The three peaks were consecrated as abbeys: *Sacred Protection*, *Virtue’s Protection*, and *Benevolent Protection*. The following year, the jade seal of the altar, long lost, resurfaced. The authorities reported the matter, and an imperial decree elevated the mountain’s status.

Thereupon, imperial favor deepened, auspicious omens flourished, and harmony prevailed between gods and men. All recorded structures—every dilapidated hall or pavilion in need of repair—were entrusted to the patriarch’s care. Yet I lamented that the mountain’s annals, though begun, remained unfinished. Thus, I charged my disciples to gather materials and compile a complete record, later inviting me to compose a preface. Reviewing its contents, I find the imperial decrees’ grandeur, the immortals’ marvels, the grottoes’ profundity, the altar records’ transmission, the figures’ greatness, the towers’ splendor, the mountains and waters’ purity, the flora’s elegance, the steles’ inscriptions, and the verses’ artistry—all meticulously categorized and fully presented.

Maoshan, originally called Juqu Mountain, is the eighth of the *Cave Heavens of Huayang* and the foremost of the *Earthly Blessings’ Lungs*. The Mao brothers of Han retired here to cultivate the Dao, and the mountain took their name. By the Jin and Wei dynasties, the Yuan Lady greatly expanded its legacy. The immortal winds and numinous traces flowed unbroken, making it a renowned mountain and sacred realm under heaven.

The imperial Yuan dynasty esteems clarity and stillness. Since the land was submitted to the Bureau of Geography, the masters of its altars have been summoned to court, honored with imperial rescripts and golden charters. The teachings flourished under the patriarch, who received grace surpassing all predecessors. Ah, how splendid! For the mountain’s *qi* unfolds in times of peace, and after long ages, the patriarch’s Dao likewise ascends to imperial notice. Herein lies the marvel of silent communion.

Thus, the mountain’s annals must be compiled, and this work cannot lack a preface. Formerly, Emperor Xuanzong of Tang inquired of Li Xuanjing about governance and transformation. Xuanjing replied: *The* Daodejing *is the sovereign’s teacher.* Emperor Wen of Han practiced its teachings, bringing benevolence and longevity to the realm. He later consulted on the golden tripod, saying: *The* Daode *is public; light ascension is private.* May later generations embody Xuanjing’s noble words and follow the patriarch’s sincere devotion.

chunks.original_text: 则庶几休应，是又可续志与兹山为无穷也。 泰定甲子日南至集贤大学士，光绿大夫西秦赵世延序。 钦惟皇元之有天下也，首崇清静之道以开泰平之基。 是以方外祠臣特蒙简注，恩辉炫悼，表章山林，若不着为成书，后世何以考，见顾余斯语名山实闻。 至大庚戌，予以祀事至茅山。 因阅其山之旧志，遗阙甚多，尝以语之四十四代宗师牧斋王真人，未几真人传真，山志无所闻。 后五年复祀其山，又以语之嗣宗师刘真人，十又三年为泰定丙寅。 天子用故事醮其山，予实代礼，始获睹其成书。 凡十有五卷，自汉晋而下及齐梁唐宋之书，搜括无遗。 噫，何其详哉。 其首篇日诰副墨，则国朝所封三真君制词，三峰观赐额劫书具在，皆予所奏请者。 其末篇曰杂着，则有仁皇用先开府张公所奏还赐玉章始末。 呜呼，是书前后凡二十年始成，仙灵诚有所待耶。 不然，国朝褒封锡额、还赐玉章诸异恩，又将补阙拾遗於成书之后，作者不无憾焉。 平章赵公既为之序，予嘉是书之传有益斯道，而予言之勉成者不徒然也，故为之书。 泰定丁卯春正月特进上卿玄教大宗师昊全节序。 茅山志叙录 句曲有记尚矣。
chunks.translated_text:
May this then bring forth auspicious responses, and thus the annals may be perpetuated alongside this mountain for endless ages.

Composed on the Winter Solstice of the *jiazi* year in the Taiding era by Grand Academician of the Jixian Institute and Grand Master for Glorious Happiness Zhao Shiyan of Western Qin.

When the august Yuan first took the realm, it first honored the Dao of clarity and quiescence to lay the foundation of great peace. Thus, those beyond the world—court servants of the sacred altars—were specially favored with imperial appointment, their grace and radiance illuminating the mountains and forests. If these were not recorded in a completed work, how could later generations examine and witness them? Reflecting on my own words, I realize this famous mountain truly deserves to be heard.

In the *gengxu* year of the Zhida era, I came to Mount Mao for sacrificial rites. There, I perused the mountain’s old annals and found many omissions and gaps. I once mentioned this to the forty-fourth-generation patriarch, Master Wang of Muchen, but before long, the master transmitted his truth, and the mountain’s annals remained unheard. Five years later, I returned to the mountain for rites and again spoke of this to the succeeding patriarch, Master Liu. Thirteen years passed, and in the *bingyin* year of the Taiding era, the Son of Heaven, following ancient precedent, performed a jiao ritual for the mountain. I was appointed to officiate the rites and at last beheld the completed work. In fifteen scrolls, it gathered writings from the Han and Jin down through the Qi, Liang, Tang, and Song without omission. Ah, how thorough it is!

Its first chapter, "Edicts and Inscriptions," contains the imperial decrees conferring titles upon the Three Perfected Lords of our dynasty, along with the calligraphic plaques bestowed upon Three Peaks Abbey—all documents I had memorialized and requested. Its final chapter, "Miscellaneous Writings," records the full account of Benevolent Emperor Renzong’s restoration of the jade seal, as originally memorialized by the late Grand Master Zhang. Alas! This work took twenty years to complete—did the immortals truly await something? If not, then the dynasty’s extraordinary favors—bestowals of titles, plaques, and the return of the jade seal—would have been left to fill gaps after the work’s completion, and its authors would have no regrets.

Minister Zhao having already composed a preface, I commend this work for its transmission’s benefit to the Dao. My words, which urged its completion, were not in vain, and so I write this afterword.

Composed in the first month of spring in the *dingmao* year of the Taiding era by Grand Master of the Mysterious Teachings and Supreme Minister Wu Quanjie.

**Preface to the Annals of Mount Mao**

The records of Mount Gouqu are ancient indeed.

chunks.original_text: 宋绍兴二十年，南丰曾徇孚仲昭台道士傅霄子昂修山记四卷，所书山水祠宇，粗录名号而已，考古述事则犹略焉。 大彬登坛一纪，始克修证传宗经录，又五载而成。 是书凡十二篇十五卷，题日：《茅山志》，载惟兹山察灵，异於开辟之初，应帝王於虚无之表。 夏禹巡幸，秦始登崇。 汉元寿二年太帝九锡茅君白日神仙，其名益大显于天下。 及晋宋经道之兴，梁唐尊尚之笃，真人道士代为帝者师，龙文凤札，积如云霞。 慨乎年世旷邈，玺书罕存。 追录见闻百余一二，暨我皇元混一区宇，世祖圣德神功，文武皇帝首降明韶。 召嗣宗师蒋君宗瑛诣阙，县是累朝大护其教，乃延佑三载，加号三君，改观三峰，光掩前古，圣人以神道设教有自来矣。 作《诰副墨》第一加封明诏若日：兹山之灵，以氏为号。 茅君真冑，盍先传焉。 按《登真隐诀真传》例，列圣道君称纪，余真称传。 夫以三茅秦汉道君，今日下士仰述圣迹，何得称传？ 作《三神纪》第二。 金坛华阳洞天，金陵地肺福地，桐相真人所谓养真之福境，成神之灵墟，虽百世可知也，集诸山水洞穴，作《括神区》第三。 观方平海中扬尘之谕，令威华表去家之语，是知仙圣按行民问，亦尝咄咄古今之异，玄踪所在，不与陵谷迁变者几希。 作《稽古迹》第四。 上清经法下教出世，始晋兴宁二年，紫虚魏元君降喂琅琊王公府舍人杨君，作隶字写出，以传护军长史许君父子。 其图录秘，非盟跪不传。 今疏篇目，使学真之子略见晓焉。 书论附名其左。 作《道山册》第五。 初元始七传而至紫虚，自紫虚积于今四十五代。 苟非其人，道不虚行，河东柳识故云：道门华阳，亦儒门沬泗。 作《上清品》第六。 刘向云：天有神司，仙人充之。

In the twentieth year of the Shaoxing era of the Song, Zeng Xun of Nanfeng, styled Zhongzhao, and the Daoist Fu Xiaozian of Taidao Abbey compiled a four-fascicle *Record of Mount Mao*. Their work merely listed the names of mountains, waters, temples, and shrines, with scant attention to historical inquiry or narrative. Only after a full twelve-year cycle since Dabin’s ascent to the altar did he finally complete the compilation and verification of the lineage’s scriptures and records, taking another five years to bring the work to fruition.

This book, titled *Annals of Mount Mao*, comprises twelve sections in fifteen fascicles. It chronicles the numinous efficacy of this mountain, which from the dawn of creation has stood apart, responding to emperors from beyond the void. Yu the Great of Xia once visited; the First Emperor of Qin ascended its heights. In the second year of Yuanshou of the Han, the Supreme Thearch bestowed the Nine Gifts upon Lord Mao, who ascended as an immortal in broad daylight—his name thus resounded throughout the realm. By the Jin and Song dynasties, the flourishing of the Dao saw the Liang and Tang courts hold it in profound reverence. Perfected Ones and Daoists generation after generation served as teachers to emperors, their dragon-script and phoenix-characters accumulating like clouds and mist. Yet alas, the ages have grown distant, and imperial seals are rarely preserved. What remains is but a fraction of what was once seen and heard.

Under our August Yuan, the realm was unified. Through the sagely virtue and divine merit of Emperor Shizu, the Martial Emperor first issued the *Mingzhao* edict. He summoned the lineage’s successor, Master Jiang Zongying, to the court. Thus, successive dynasties have greatly protected this teaching. In the third year of the Yanyou era, the Three Lords were granted honorific titles, and the Three Peaks were renamed, their glory outshining all antiquity. That the sage employs the divine Dao to establish teaching has ever been thus.

The first section, *Decrees and Inscriptions*, records the imperial edicts of investiture, which proclaim: “The numen of this mountain takes its name from its surname. The true heirs of the Mao Lords—let their transmission be recorded first.” Following the example of *The Hidden Instructions on Ascending to Perfection and the True Transmission*, the sagely Dao Lords are titled “Records,” while other Perfected Ones are titled “Transmissions.” How could the Three Mao Lords of Qin and Han, whose sagely traces are revered by scholars today, be merely called “Transmissions”? Thus, the second section is titled *Records of the Three Divinities*.

Jintan’s Huayang Grotto-Heaven, the Earthly Lung of Jinling, and the Blessed Land of Tongxiang—these are the “blessed realms for nurturing perfection” and “numinous ruins for attaining divinity” spoken of by the Perfected One of Tongxiang. Their legacy endures for a hundred generations. Collecting the mountains, waters, and grottoes, the third section is titled *Compendium of the Numinous Realm*.

From Lord Wang’s admonition about “dust rising from the sea” to Lord Hua’s words on “the marker post leaving home,” we know that immortals and sages traversing the mortal world have often marveled at the changes between ancient and modern. Yet the traces of the mysterious Dao, unlike the shifting hills and valleys, are few indeed. Thus, the fourth section is titled *Traces of Antiquity Verified*.

The teachings of the Shangqing scriptures were first transmitted to the world in the second year of Xingning of the Jin, when the Purple Void’s Lady Wei descended to the residence of Yang Jun, a clerk in the household of Wang Fangzhi of Langye. She transcribed them in clerical script and passed them to Xu Jun, the Chief Clerk of the Protectorate, and his son. Their charts and records were secret, transmitted only after oaths and prostration. Here, their chapter titles are outlined so that students of the true may glimpse their essence. Treatises and discussions are appended to the left. Thus, the fifth section is titled *Register of the Daoist Mountain*.

From the Primordial Beginning, seven transmissions reached the Purple Void. From the Purple Void to the present spans forty-five generations. If the recipient is unworthy, the Dao does not flow in vain. As Liu Zhi of Hedong once said: “The Huayang of the Daoist gate is like the Ruist streams of the Yi and Si.” Thus, the sixth section is titled *Lineages of the Shangqing*.

Liu Xiang said: “Heaven has its divine overseers; immortals fill its ranks.”

chunks.original_text: 洞宫官僚，自《真诰》、《玄通记》传出。 时运变易，应有迁补。 譬如周礼汉仪，不复相同。 神道幽远，非世所知。 作《仙曹署》第七。 山源曲而有容，高尚求志之士栖遁其问，不可婵纪，所采古今卓行之着明者。 若夫深晦无为，潜升晨景，则曷得而名作《采真游》第八。 魏晋六朝绾宇，散居林麓。 唐宋始劫改官观之盛，奉祠祝厘，此其地也。 作《楼观部》第九。 丹砂宝气，金玉华津，人服之而引年易质。 其渍润积久，发於芝英草木，神异而灵长信，物理之固然。 作《灵植检》第十。 碑铭书刻，载道之舟车也。 真人手泽，犹得模楷。 而立德立功立言者，文亦在兹乎？ 作《录金石》第十一。 古人采诗，盖有关名教，山中赋咏，散逸既多，此皆绝妙好辞，足丽於飞空谣歌之末。 作《金蓬编》第十二。 终焉。 是志之作，不问今昔，一行一言，录其至善。 其或传事调谬，撰辞芜恶如指桓，记之属一无所取，非脱遗也。 於戏，太史公称天下名山，南华称博大真人。 若句曲兼二者，盖千数百年纂懿流光，未有若斯之盛者也。 后之学士无狭其所居，无厌其所生，无小无大。 台是皆以清静为本，尚有征於斯文哉。 大元天历元年岁在戊辰十二月二日，嗣上清经录四十五代宗师洞观微妙玄应真人刘大彬序。 茅山志卷之二 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造

The celestial bureaucracy of the Grotto Palaces derives from the *True Reports* and *Records of Mystic Communication*. As the cycles of time shift, appointments and promotions must follow. Like the rites of Zhou and the institutions of Han, they no longer remain the same. The divine Dao is profound and distant, beyond the ken of the worldly. Thus, the seventh section is titled *Register of the Immortal Offices*.

The mountain’s sources wind deep and hold space; reclusive scholars of lofty aspiration dwell in their recesses, their traces too scattered to chronicle. Here are gathered the most luminous exemplars of transcendent conduct from antiquity and the present. As for those who vanish in stillness, ascending unseen with the dawn’s light—how could their names be recorded? Thus, the eighth section is titled *Wanderings in the Harvest of Truth*.

From the Wei and Jin through the Six Dynasties, they wove the realm’s fabric, dwelling dispersed among forests and foothills. Only in the Tang and Song did the flourishing of temples and monasteries begin, where rites of offering and blessing were observed—this is their ground. Thus, the ninth section is titled *Records of the Louguan Lineage*.

Cinnabar and treasured qi, gold and jade’s radiant essence: those who ingest them extend their years and transform their substance. Their nurturing moisture, accumulated over time, emerges in mushrooms, herbs, and trees—wondrous, numinous, and enduring in truth, for such is the inherent principle of things. Thus, the tenth section is titled *Catalogue of Numinous Flora*.

Steles, inscriptions, and carved texts are the vessels and chariots of the Dao. The brushstrokes of perfected beings remain as models for emulation. For those who establish virtue, merit, or words, is not their legacy preserved herein? Thus, the eleventh section is titled *Record of Metal and Stone*.

The ancients collected poems to uphold the teachings of names and propriety. Verses composed in the mountains, though scattered and lost in great number, are all exquisite and fine phrases, worthy to adorn the end of soaring celestial hymns. Thus, the twelfth section is titled *Golden Lotus Anthology*.

Here ends the compilation. In crafting this record, no distinction is made between past and present; every deed and every word is included for its utmost excellence. If accounts are distorted or compositions coarse and flawed—like the finger pointing at Huan—such entries are entirely omitted, not by oversight.

Alas! The Grand Historian extolled the famous mountains of the world; the *Nanhua* lauded the vast and true perfected ones. Yet Mount Gouqu combines both virtues, its illustrious radiance compiled over a thousand and hundreds of years—never has there been such splendor. May later scholars not disparage their dwelling, nor weary of their origins, whether great or small. Let all take purity and stillness as their foundation; surely this text bears witness to such principles.

In the first year of the Tianli era of the Great Yuan, the year *wuchen* of the sexagenary cycle, the second day of the twelfth month. By the forty-fifth generational lineage-holder of the *Shangqing* scriptural transmission, the Perfected of Subtle Mystery and Wondrous Response of the Grotto Vision, Liu Dabin.

chunks.original_text: 诰副墨 唐韶诰 太宗赐王法主诏 先生操履夷简，德业冲粹。 屏弃尘杂，栖志虚玄。 吐故纳新，食芝饵木。 会众妙於三清之表，返华发於百龄之外。 道迈前烈，声高自古。 非夫得秘诀於金坛，受幽文於玉岌者，其孰能与此乎？ 朕昔在藩朝，早获闻道，眷言夙范，无忘寤寐。 近览来奏请归故山，已有别敕，不违高志。 并许置观甩表，宿心未知。 先生早晚以届，江外所营楝宇。 何当就功？ 伫闻，委曲，副兹引领。 近已令太史令荫颐往宣朕意。 贞观九年，事见旧唐书本传。 高宗赠王法主诰 门下故玉清观道士王远知，性含几迹，迹徇幽玄。 体兹县解，见称先觉。 自缔构之初，迄光华之旦。

Tang Emperor Shao’s Decree to Master of the Dharma Wang
Master, your conduct is unadorned and simple, your virtue and practice pure and profound. You have cast aside worldly distractions, dwelling your mind in emptiness and mystery. Exhaling the old and inhaling the new, you feed on fungi and herbs. You gather the myriad wonders beyond the Three Clarities, restoring youthful radiance beyond a hundred years. Your Dao surpasses the achievements of the ancients, your renown resounds through the ages. Had you not received secret instructions upon the Golden Altar and received hidden texts upon the Jade Summit, how could you have attained such heights?

When I was still a prince, I early heard of your Way, and your long-held model has never faded from my waking or dreaming thoughts. Recently, upon reading your memorial requesting return to your native mountains, I have issued a separate edict honoring your lofty aspirations. I have also granted permission to establish an abbey and erect a stele, though your long-cherished wish remains unfulfilled. When, Master, will you arrive? The buildings you have commissioned beyond the Yangzi—when will they be completed? I await word in eager anticipation, longing to hear the details that will fulfill this yearning. I have already dispatched the Grand Astrologer Yin Yi to convey my intentions.

chunks.original_text: 绸缪恩遇，事昭纶脖。 仙化不追，英灵浸远。 眷言留乌，宜有褒崇。 可赠太中大夫，谧日：升真先生。 主者施行。 调露二年二月七日。 劝旨润州太平观道士宜准七寺等例，度满七七人。 如后有缺，随即简度讫申。 调露二年二月一十五日。 武后加赠王法主诰 门下子乔羽化，或留连於故祠。 康成道存尚延，伫於旧邑。 蚓夫迹膺仙录，名偶圣朝，追想遗尘，载殷远念。 故玉清观道士赠太中大夫升真先生。 王远知性与道合，神从化游，初穷帝解之微，自得天倪之理。 时历三代，报秘术以韬光； 年逾十纪，属睿图之启运。 藏往知来，察幽鉴远。 亟符先渥缅，惟赠恤之恩。 聿申后命，宜峻褒崇之礼，可赠金紫光禄大夫升玄先生。 余如故主者施行。 嗣圣兀年正月二十八日 玄宗赐李玄静先生敕书凡二十四通 敕丹阳郡太守林洋，及道俗父老百姓等。 朕远遵玄妙，载想灵仙。 眷兹茅山，是为天洞。 瑶坛旧观，余址尚存。 道要真经，散落将尽。 永言法宝，良用怃然。 今为黎元，大崇道本。 故令清修之士，建立真仪，访迩灵山，以新观宇。 庶使玄宗再阐，瞻奉知归。 降福寰瀛，致之仁寿也。 又比年以来，每遵清静官吏，有修良之美，农桑属丰稔之期。 百姓之间，庶无乏绝也。 微寒卿及道俗、父老百姓等，并平安好。 遣书指不多及。 劝江束道采访处置使，晋陵郡太守董瑰：山岳上疏分野，下镇方隅。 降福佑於人，施云雨之惠。 且茅山神秀，华阳洞天，法教之所源，草仙之所宅。 固望秩之礼，虽有典常而崇敬之，心宜增精洁。 自今以后，茅山中，令断采捕及渔猎，四远百姓有吃荤血者，不须令入。 如有事式申祈祷，当以香药珍镒，亦不得以牲牢等物。 卿与所由存心，检校渐寒，卿得平安好。 敕广陵李炼师，上清品人也。 抗志云霞和光，代俗为予修福，灵边将赴金坛。 故赋诗宠行，以美其志。 紫府烟霞士，玄宗道德师。 心将万籁合，志与九仙期。 绝俗遗尘境，同人喜济时。 访经游玉洞，敷教入瑶墀。 茅岭追余边，金坛赴远思。 阴宫看旧记，阳观饬新祠。 缅想埋双壁，长怀采五芝。 真灵若可遇，惊鹤伫来兹。 尊师抱一守中，探微昭远。 能回贞洁，发挥道门，遂与太和。 先生启是仙宗，起予虔奉，崇饬灵边，广求真经。 则诗以宠行，物将厚意。 永慰岐路，以彰礼贤也。 所谢知。 劝炼师李含光，道高紫府，学总黄庭，贵然来思，式敷至妙。 既而属念茅岭，言访真经。 近出咸秦，远游方外。 朕载怀仙境，延伫勤修。 将使九有之人，同归玄教。 三清之众，俯鉴遵行。 岂徒梦寐华胥，驰诚碧落而已。 想尊师建立真仪，所修坛宇，初至经构，殊用劳心。 甚寒，得平安好，遣书指不多及。 敕炼师李含光：昨程元暹，至得所进，图具规矩矣。 然崇饰仙观，祈望真游，若不幽邃清闲，岂降霓裳羽盖，且在科仪，犹有差降。 至於仙真道众，故亦不可同居所置紫阳观大院内，更不须着人居止。 但作虚廊四合，清洁殿堂，以修香火，用候云驾。 其道众等别院安置。 今具作图，往应所添加，亦入支料矣。 尊师体真远识，含和内融，必能上合灵仙之心，下副钦崇之意也。 甚寒，得平安好，遣书，指不多及。 敕炼师李含光：尊师，远访名山，精求至教，建立坛宇，载写真经。

The gracious favor bestowed was resplendent in imperial decrees. Though his immortal transformation cannot be recalled, his radiant spirit grows ever more distant. In cherishing memory of the departed crow, fitting honors must be conferred. Let him be posthumously appointed Grand Master for Splendid Happiness, with the posthumous title "Master Ascended to Perfection." Let the relevant authorities carry this out.

On the seventh day of the second month in the second year of the Tiaolu era.

By imperial edict, the Daoist priests of Taiping Abbey in Runzhou shall follow the precedent of the Seven Temples, with a full ordination quota of forty-nine. Should vacancies arise thereafter, they shall be promptly filled through selection and reported accordingly.

On the fifteenth day of the second month in the second year of the Tiaolu era.

Decree from Empress Wu on the Posthumous Honors for Master of the Dharma Wang

Alas! When Wang Qiao ascended as an immortal, he lingered at his old shrine; when Zheng Kangcheng’s Dao endured, it still extended within his former abode. How much more so for one whose traces were recorded in the immortal registers, whose name graced the sagely court—when we recall his departed dust, our distant longing deepens.

The late Daoist of Jade Purity Abbey, posthumously appointed Grand Master for Splendid Happiness and Master Ascended to Perfection, Wang Yuanzhi, was by nature in harmony with the Dao, his spirit roaming through transformations. From the outset, he plumbed the subtleties of the imperial apocrypha, attaining the principle of Heaven’s spontaneity. Across three reigns, he concealed his esoteric arts to conceal his brilliance; surpassing a century, he witnessed the unfolding of the sagely enterprise. Concealing the past and knowing the future, he discerned the obscure and perceived the distant. Repeatedly, he received the profound grace of former emperors, and the favor of posthumous honors. Now, to extend the mandate of later generations, it is fitting to elevate the rites of commemoration. Let him be posthumously appointed Grand Master of the Palace with Gold and Purple, with the posthumous title "Master Ascended to Mystery." All else remains as before. Let the relevant authorities carry this out.

On the twenty-eighth day of the first month in the first year of the Sisheng era.

Twenty-four Edicts from Emperor Xuanzong to Master Li Xuanjing

Edict to Lin Yang, Governor of Danyang Commandery, and to the Daoist and lay elders and common people:

We have long revered the profound and wondrous, ever contemplating the numinous immortals. In cherishing this Mount Mao, we recognize it as a celestial cavern. The jade altars of its ancient abbeys remain in vestige, yet the essential scriptures of the Dao lie scattered, nearly lost. Reflecting on these sacred treasures, We are deeply moved. Now, for the sake of the people, We greatly exalt the root of the Dao. Thus, We have commanded the pure and cultivated to establish true rites, to seek the nearby numinous mountain, and to renew the abbey’s halls. May this allow the profound teachings to flourish anew, that all may know where to turn in reverence. May blessings descend upon the realm, bringing benevolence and longevity.

Moreover, in recent years, We have consistently appointed officials of purity and tranquility, who have governed with excellence, while agriculture and sericulture have coincided with seasons of abundance. Among the people, none have suffered want.

We trust that you, the governor, along with the Daoist and lay elders and common people, are all in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of Our thoughts.

Edict to Dong Gui, Inspector of Jiangdong Circuit and Governor of Jinling Commandery:

The mountains and peaks above divide the heavens, while below they stabilize the regions. They bestow blessings upon the people and dispense the grace of clouds and rain. Moreover, Mount Mao, with its divine splendor, is the Huayang Grotto-Heaven, the source of the Dharma’s teachings and the dwelling of perfected immortals. Though the rites of reverence are established, the heart of devotion should ever deepen in purity. Henceforth, within Mount Mao, let all logging, hunting, and fishing be prohibited. Let those from afar who consume meat and blood not be permitted entry. Should there be occasions for rituals, petitions, or prayers, let them be conducted with incense, herbs, and precious offerings—never with sacrificial animals. You and your subordinates must attend to this with care.

We trust you are in good health.

Edict to the Perfected of Guangling, Li the Master of Refinement:

You are a person of the Upper Clarity rank, your aspirations soaring with the clouds and mist, harmonizing with the world while transcending it. For Our sake, you cultivate blessings, soon to ascend the Golden Altar. Thus, We compose a poem to honor your journey and praise your resolve:

A scholar of the Purple Palace’s mist and haze,
A master of the Dao’s profound Way.
Your heart unites with the myriad sounds,
Your will aligns with the Nine Immortals’ vow.
Beyond the world, you leave the dust behind,
With kindred spirits, you delight in aiding the age.
Seeking scriptures, you wander jade grottoes,
Expounding teachings, you enter the jeweled steps.
At Mao Ridge, you follow the traces of the ancients,
At the Golden Altar, you fulfill distant thoughts.
In the Yin Palace, you peruse old records,
In the Yang Abbey, you adorn the new shrine.
From afar, We recall the buried twin jades,
Ever cherishing the gathering of the five sacred herbs.
If the true immortals may be encountered,
We await the startling crane’s arrival here.

Honored Master, you embrace the One and guard the center, exploring the subtle and illuminating the distant. Your purity and integrity have unfolded the gates of the Dao, uniting with the Great Harmony. As a patriarch of the immortal lineage, you have inspired Our reverence, adorning the numinous precincts and broadly seeking the true scriptures. Thus, We compose this poem to honor your journey, conveying Our profound regard. May it console you on the road and manifest Our esteem for the worthy.

You are aware of Our intent.

Edict to Master of Refinement Li Hanguang:

Your Dao is lofty as the Purple Palace, your learning encompasses the Yellow Court. Nobly, you have come at Our summons, unfolding the most wondrous teachings. Now, you turn your thoughts to Mao Ridge, seeking the true scriptures. Recently, you journeyed from the capital of Qin, venturing far beyond the world. We have long cherished the immortal realms, eagerly awaiting your diligent cultivation. May this allow the people of the Nine Provinces to together return to the profound teachings, and the hosts of the Three Clarities to look down and witness their observance. This is not merely dreaming of the land of Huaxu or directing Our sincerity toward the azure heavens. We imagine you, Honored Master, establishing the true rites, constructing the altar halls—from your first arrival to the completion of the structures—expending great effort. We trust you are in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of Our thoughts.

Edict to Master of Refinement Li Hanguang:

Yesterday, Cheng Yuanxian arrived and presented the plans you submitted, which clearly outline the regulations. However, in adorning the immortal abbey and invoking the presence of the perfected, if the site is not secluded and tranquil, how could the rainbow robes and feathered canopies descend? Moreover, in the rituals, there are distinctions in rank. As for the perfected immortals and Daoist assembly, they must not reside together within the same precincts as the Purple Yang Abbey’s grand courtyard. No one should be permitted to dwell there. Instead, construct an open colonnade enclosing a purified hall to maintain the incense offerings and await the cloud-borne chariots. The Daoist assembly shall be accommodated in separate quarters.

We have now provided a detailed diagram, which should guide any necessary additions, and the requisite materials have been allocated. Honored Master, your embodiment of the true and your far-reaching insight, your harmonious nature inwardly refined, must surely align with the hearts of the numinous immortals above and fulfill the reverent intentions below. We trust you are in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of Our thoughts.

Edict to Master of Refinement Li Hanguang:

Honored Master, you have traveled far to renowned mountains, diligently seeking the supreme teachings. You have established altars and halls, transcribing the true scriptures.

May your diligent efforts in all matters bring you weariness indeed. My aspiration to seek the essentials of the Dao and my distant longing for the true immortals shall rely upon your pure sincerity to cultivate the profound and wondrous. On the eighteenth day of this month, I shall purify myself in fasting and sanctify the altar to receive the scriptural decrees, praying for the descent of the numinous immortals’ blessings and their attestation.

I now send the prayer texts and incense offerings with this letter. Honored Master, you must proclaim the ritual observances, present the prayers, and offer thanks, that they may ascend to the immortal palaces above and bring forth manifest responses below. The weather grows warm. I trust you are in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

Admonition to Refiner Li:
The Dao is the origin of all existence, and the Dharma is the covenant of the Nine Perfected. The Great Sage bequeathed these teachings to later disciples, that those who cultivate themselves might advance. I have long wished to reverently receive the scriptural Dharma but have not yet fully grasped its solemn mysteries. Moreover, many of the true scriptures have scattered and fallen into error. Recently, I sought out the vestiges left by the Heavenly Perfected, and in their rituals and observances, nothing was lacking. I have had them transcribed in strict accordance with the precepts. My long-held aspiration is now fulfilled, and I am grateful for the descent of the true numinous ones’ grace.

On the eighteenth day of this month, I shall reverently invoke the Three Pure Ones, the Grand Master, the Mystic Master, and the True Master, purifying myself in fasting to receive the sacred texts. Bearing the true scriptures, I shall reverently unfold the phoenix-script, directing my heart toward the realm of the Great Void to nurture the longevity of the Valley Spirit. The fragrant offerings have been prepared in full accordance with the scriptural traditions. I now enclose the prayer texts and seal them for dispatch. Honored Master, your mastery of the Dao’s essentials and your harmonious radiance, your purity and effortless virtue, align with my own aspirations. I entreat you, as my master, to present these prayer texts and fragrant offerings at the Golden Altar of the Numinous Treasury in the Huayang Grotto-Heaven of Mount Mao, as a token of sincerity to attest to my diligent devotion.

Those of virtue are honored with noble titles. Thus, Ge Hong bore the appellation "Master of Embracing Simplicity," and Tao Hongjing was known as "Master of Integrity and Purity." The deeds of those who came before are not distant. Henceforth, I bestow upon you the title "Master of Mystic Stillness," to illuminate your illustrious virtue and exalt your lofty conduct. I now dispatch an emissary for this purpose. The weather grows warm. I trust you are in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

Honored Master, your harmonious virtue and your exploration of its essentials have led you to personally safeguard the fragrant offerings and invoke the true numinous ones. Moreover, the bestowal of this title serves to honor your diligent cultivation. The robes are a means to express reverence and devotion, a form to manifest veneration and to praise the beauty of the immortal ranks. I am grateful for your understanding.

The lingzhi you presented is indeed an auspicious sign. Like multicolored clouds spreading abundantly, its fragrance rivals that of orchids, flourishing in the blessed land of Ziyang. It is a propitious omen of the ascent of cinnabar sincerity, distantly resonating with the great jade lingzhi of Datong, forming a harmonious correspondence. The true immortals above have bestowed this felicitous sign in response to your pure sincerity. I am deeply gratified.

I now command that prayer texts and incense be offered at the Heavenly Grotto, entrusting your lofty virtue to convey my devout heart. The lingzhi arises from harmonious qi and is overseen by the true immortals. In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor’s attainment of the Dao was marked by the repeated blossoming of the Three Wonders. I have long pondered these auspicious omens. Today, the golden radiance and vermilion hues of eighty-one stalks, their colors resonant with the golden square and their number aligned with the yang auspices, some with conjoined stems and paired calyxes, others with twin roots sharing a single branch, emerge from the Heavenly Grotto to flourish, adorning the medicinal altar with their splendor. This is a rare and wondrous occurrence, evoking profound gratitude for such extraordinary auspices.

Honored Master, having presented your prayers and conveyed your sincerity, you have sent these true gifts from afar. I receive them with reverence. May great fortune attend, and may I partake of them. The weather is hot. I trust you are well.

Edict:
Longing for antiquity, I reflect upon the immortal precincts adjoining the grotto-palaces, the ancient abodes of the blue altars, and the numinous borders. The new halls of the Purple Terrace now gleam, revealing the true lineage. To manifest my reverent devotion, I have established households for repair and maintenance. Honored Masters, you have fulfilled my intentions with your pure and precious observances.

Edict:
The weight of your virtue, Honored Master, is esteemed by the immortal perfected. Thus, the purification rites must be met with profound sincerity. Moreover, this mountain is the lung of the earth, where the blessings of the Controller of Destinies converge. Its courtyard altars lie near the heavenly palaces, the former abodes of the true persons. I, your disciple, am diligent in my aspirations to extend the realm of longevity to all living beings. Gazing eastward from afar, I yearn for you day and night. With the arrival of spring, I await the return of your wind-borne chariot to ease my longing for your wisdom and to receive the profound teachings of the Dao.

The autumn heat lingers. I trust you are in good health. This letter conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

Edict:
The alchemical furnace opens the immortal elixir, transmitted by the Nine Perfected. The courtyard yields lingzhi, overseen by the Three Maos. Such omens, recorded in the mysterious annals, have never before been heard. Only Wei Boyang foretold them in the past. Now, Li Yue has brought them to fruition here. I shall purify my heart and await the arrival of a special emissary to welcome you, that we may together receive the Dao’s blessings. I am grateful for your understanding.

Edict:
I have always revered purity and truth, personally seeking those of the Dao. My sincere request is difficult to refuse, so I have allowed you to fulfill your wishes and seek medical treatment. Now that your recovery is well underway, you should return soon.

*Poem to Send Off Master of Mystic Stillness on His Temporary Return to Guangling, with Preface*

Master of Mystic Stillness embodies harmonious purity and delights in the Dao’s emptiness. Recently, he came to the capital, bringing blessings to all. Now, he yearns for the forests and springs, to cleanse his heart of worldly dust. I admire and esteem him, and to fulfill his wishes, I compose this poem to honor his departure, reflecting on his journey:

Yang and Xu opened the true records,
While you, sir, secretly transmitted the covenant.
Nine stars linked beneath the purple canopy,
Twin radiance merged in the cinnabar field.
Holding the jade tablet, you serve at the Tortoise Terrace,
A golden altar immortal of the grotto-palace.
I still await the ease of riding the wind,
Morning and evening, to welcome your cool return.

Respectfully inquiring of Master of Mystic Stillness:
Master, you uphold the purity of unsullied integrity and possess the inner harmony that penetrates all principles. Your learning encompasses the nine schools, yet you transcend them in profound silence. Your heart roams the Eight Effulgences, ever blending with the light of the world. Your secret conduct and lofty virtue are truly admirable. Yet you have humbled your solitary resolve to broadly propagate the Way of salvation. Following the true blessings, you have deeply nurtured the pure source. I am aware that your past and present meritorious deeds have all evoked responses. Gazing southeast, my heart races toward you day and night.

I now send offerings and fragrant jujubes. Honored Master, I entreat you to perform the ninefold meritorious rites.

chunks.original_text: 庶使苍生承日用之福，外化有归顺之心。 天下和平，惟道所庇。 修功德了，当暂迂风驭。 一至京来，甚寒。 尊师比清畅唐师回，遣书指不多及。 斋醮之仪，顾有模楷。 将致诚恳，必仗精修。 故屈尊师敬申，妙旨，知己事毕，良多愧也。 所谢知。 尊师思虑就精，虔心斋洁。 致福利物，其功实多。 况择高流，同勤至道。 精修不息，嘉尚弥深。 香信之资，用昭诚意也。 尊师以至道妙用，精诚感真。 荐福朕躬，居宁寰宇。 俯及长至，来庆休祥。 履端之吉，是与同也。 迟至来春当＃２，共尊师相见。 敬问玄静先生，昨弟子唐若倩至。 具知去月十一日，功德事毕。 夫以至诚之心，精修之感。 坛在仙境，宜按冲科。 下庇苍生，上资宗社。 永求福应，玄感昭然。 及知天地至和，人神胥庆。 以降甘露，以表休符。 则视履考祥，其旋元吉。 今岁律云：暮璇玑运行不愧，再劳事绿万姓。 今附香信往，至年下且请尊师，於所居修功德以助履新。 至来载春和复请尊师，於茅山上为宗社，下为黎元修河图大斋。 应缘功德之物，触新再造。 无以多劳，所利者广。

May the world know peace, sheltered only by the Dao. Once the meritorious rites are completed, you shall momentarily ascend upon the wind’s chariot. I have learned that upon your arrival in the capital, the cold was severe. Since Master Qingchang’s return from Master Tang, I have sent letters, though they have not conveyed much.

The rituals of fasting and offering possess established models; to ensure sincerest devotion, they must rely on meticulous practice. You have extended blessings to my person, bringing tranquility to the realm. As the winter solstice approaches, may auspicious omens arrive. The felicity of the new year’s beginning shall be shared by all.

I have also learned that heaven and earth are in perfect harmony, and gods and humans alike rejoice. Sweet dew descended, marking the auspicious sign. Thus, in observing the omens of your steps, all returns to primordial felicity.

This year’s celestial cycles proclaim: *"The turning of the jade celestial sphere proceeds without flaw; twice have the people been wearied by affairs."* I now send fragrant offerings and request that, by year’s end, Your Reverence perform meritorious rites at your residence to assist in welcoming the new year. When spring returns next year, I shall again invite Your Reverence to Mount Mao to conduct the grand *Hetu* fast for the ancestral temples above and the common people below. Moreover, as the Dao and virtue draw close, our qi and dispositions align in perfect resonance. The sacred traces across these mountains abound with transcendent beings. Should any seek to visit them, Your Reverence must summon them for your disciples.

The cold is severe; may Your Reverence’s Dao-body remain peaceful and harmonious. When Tang Ruoqian returns, I send this letter with but brief words.

Your Reverence upholds the true cultivation of the Highest Clarity above and propagates the teachings of immortality below, securing blessings for me and sheltering the common people. The esoteric scriptures of the Three Sovereigns have already borne auspicious responses. The inner records of the *Hetu* entreat the prolongation of fortune and felicity. **Poem Presented to Master Xuanjing upon His Return to Guangling, with Preface**

The Master’s qi traverses rivers and mountains; his spirit is pure and serene.
His Dao soars to the Eight Effulgences, his learning encompasses the Nine Streams.
Whenever he expounds the Mystic Origin or enlightens the registers of immortality,
He extends the jade august mandate for me and preserves me until the golden elixir’s fruition.
Such reverence, such weight!
Deeply do I regret our parting; thus, I compose this poem to bid him farewell:

Silently receiving the Dao of Wang Ni,
Deeper than the teachings of Yin Xi.
Rejoicing in the assembly of the Eight Effulgences,
Yet sighing for the time of the Nine Elixirs.
Phoenixes and cranes drift through misty realms;
Rivers and mountains stretch with parting thoughts.
When you ascend to your grotto-palace,
Do not forget the days in the imperial capital.

Your Reverence, with the pivot of the Dao, brings salvation; with the true origin, you enlighten. Coming to convey the profound and wondrous, departing to return to cloud-wreathed mountains—this poem expresses my sentiments and marks our sorrowful farewell.

With gratitude for your understanding.

**Emperor Suzong’s Letter of Encouragement to Master Xuanjing**

Decree to Master Li Hanguang:
Long have you grasped the essentials of the true, deeply penetrated the subtleties of the Mystic. Roaming the boundless realms, you have attained the Dao of luminous clarity. In the days of the Supreme Emperor, you were known by his favor.

Now, refining your being in the famous mountains, I hold you in profound admiration. Moreover, the grottoes of the Mao Lords, as the scriptures proclaim, are places of numinous transformations and secret divine medicines. You must peruse the esoteric formulas of the Golden Registers and cultivate purity in the Dark Palace. Verify the methods for dispelling calamities and demonstrate the arts of longevity—it is especially fitting that you redouble your efforts and manifest the merits of fasting.

The summer heat is intense; may you remain in peace and good health. This letter conveys but a few words.

**Decree to Master Li Hanguang**

Master, you have deeply penetrated the wonders of the Dao and long been renowned. The mountains of the Mao Lords of old are now the profound mysteries of the Grotto Realms. Given your virtue and conduct, I hold you in deep admiration.

Recently, I have quelled the weapons of war and swept away the lurking evils, preserving the myriad people and securing the two capitals. The Supreme Emperor’s sacred carriage has been welcomed back to the palace. In this act of filial piety, joy and comfort descend from heaven. I look up in gratitude for the protection of the Mystic Origin, which has twice established the enterprise of the ancestral temples. Your precise cultivation and vows have also assisted in this.

You must devote greater care to the altar precincts, purify the incense and flames, and broadly extend the Supreme Emperor’s fortune and longevity, ensuring the well-being of all under heaven. The rectification of the Daoist gate rests with you.

With gratitude for your understanding.

**Decree for the Construction of Ziyang Abbey**

To the Right Minister, the Merit-Offering Commissioner, Master Xuanjing Li Hanguang, and the Palace Attendant Supervisor Cheng Yuanxian, et al., jointly inspecting the construction of Ziyang Abbey on Mount Mao:

The aforementioned abbey has been completed, and the ritual offerings of thanksgiving to the above have concluded.

On the twenty-second day of the ninth month last year, upon submission of the report, it was decreed that the relevant authorities proceed with the construction of the abbey. A remainder of 104 strings and 285 cash was returned. Beyond the construction, this remainder exists.

As the abbey’s construction is now complete, upon submission of the report, it was decreed that the remainder be granted to the abbey’s household as permanent property. The local authorities have already allocated this sum to the Three Principles.

I have consulted with the abbey’s director, Daoist Liu Xingju, and others, proposing that a nearby county establish a repository for pledges. Each month, the interest shall be collected to sustain the permanent property, with the principal remaining intact.

I humbly hope that the abbey’s name be preserved, and that the land previously allotted to its disciples—measured in *qing* and *mu*—be made sufficient. This year’s grain tax shall be allocated, and next year’s provisions shall also be supplied to the abbey.

Previously, there were four slaves, six oxen (one small), and one carriage, all presently accounted for.

I have now questioned the local county officials and the Three Principles regarding the abbey’s prior properties. Upon verification, the quantities are consistent. The grain provisions are already sufficient for annual use. Next spring, I request that cultivation of the abbey’s furnishings, the Five Phases, and other necessities be undertaken.

The abbey’s household was formerly impoverished, with few furnishings. During the recent merit-offering, Commissioner Cheng Yuanxian, by decree, supplied the Yellow Thread Fast. Beyond this, a remainder of one hundred taels of silver was returned. I have instructed that this be distributed to the abbey’s disciples to purchase the lacking furnishings, ensuring all are made complete.

Regarding the abbey’s pines, bamboos, fruit trees, and other flora:
I humbly note that the abbey lies on Mount Mao, where immortals gather. Though its halls are splendid, pines and bamboos are scarce. As the season is inopportune, planting has not been possible. I request that, come spring, planting be undertaken with care. Additionally, lotuses shall be sown in the southern pond, that the grounds may be fully adorned.

Respectfully submitted as above.
Lin Yang, Governor of Danyang Commandery, presents this secondary report.

**Memorandum from the Chancellery:**
The Danyang Commandery’s memorandum, in accordance with the decree, is approved. The memorandum is hereby issued in compliance with the decree.

On the eighth day of the first month, the eighth year of Tianbao (749), by the Left Chancellor, Minister of War, Chen Xilie, and the Left Vice Director, concurrently Right Chancellor, Lin Fu.

**Memorial from Master Xuanjing et al. appended.**

chunks.translated_text:
The Daoist minister Han Guang respectfully states: On the eighteenth day of this month, the official Wang Youxian conveyed an oral decree, bestowing upon your minister six sets of ritual robes. Furthermore, today, General Gao Lishi announced an imperial edict, presenting your minister with a poem composed by His Majesty, two hundred bolts of fine silk, and an incense burner among other items. Though your minister dwells among the Daoist clergy, possessing no profound insight, I have encountered this sagely era and remain laden with the state’s grace. The rainbow-hued feathered robes issue from the celestial treasury, while the divine brush’s luminous verses suddenly alight upon this humble frame. That your minister—□—should receive such bounty truly exceeds all bounds of propriety. For over a decade, your minister has been afflicted with a wind-borne malady, body enfeebled and strength depleted, rendering all endeavors neglected. I can but pray that the incense burner may bring blessings, repaying in some small measure the sagely person of His Majesty. For the remainder of my days, I shall harbor no other aspiration, overwhelmed as I am by awe and trepidation.

On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month, the sixth year of Tianbao (747).

The Daoist minister Han Guang further states: On the twenty-fourth day of this month, the palace messenger Dan Tingyao, along with the Daoist Tang Ruoqian, delivered fragile items and an imperial rescript to the mountain. On the twenty-fifth day, I, together with Tingyao and Ruoqian, burned incense and recited the rescript at the gate of Huayang Grotto, thereafter interring the fragile missive. Overcome with boundless joy, I humbly dispatch Yang Shenshe to first present this memorial. Once the detailed depiction of the *zhi*’s forms is complete, I shall separately send an emissary to report. The twentieth day of the fifth month, the seventh year of Tianbao (748).

Today, in accordance with the Dao, we gathered the *zhi* grass—eighty-one stalks in all, their luxuriance arrayed like dragons. chunks.original_text: 但臣无功，每蒙赐及，伏增战栗，今供拟已办。 馑遣弟子唐若倩随中使齐令说，奉表以闻。 天宝十一载六月十九日。 臣含光言：晷度环周，日长南至，伏惟陛下膺纳乾佑，庆无不宜。 臣等今於茅山为国焚修斋醮，无任欣悦之至。 馑遣中使啖庭瑶起居，谨奉表以闻。 天宝十一载十月二十五日。 臣含光言：前所奏请紫阳观东郁冈山右奉修斋醮，自六月二十七日起首，行道至今月七日冬至日初出时，绿是斋人及中使齐令说等，咸见斋坛四远松树悉有甘露，其色白，其气香，其味甘，其松去坛渐远者而露亦渐少。 计今几降甘露松树，都有二百三十株。 谨按《道德经》称，天地相合以降甘露，人莫之令而自均焉。 玄圣着经，以为嘉瑞。 斋醮遇此，又为吉祥。 敢不以闻，谨遣弟子唐若倩随中使齐令说，奉表供进甘露二合。 臣含光言：孟春犹寒，伏惟圣躬起居万福。 去载十二月二十五日，中使啖庭瑶及臣弟子唐若倩等至，伏奉恩敕劳问，臣蒙赐绢百疋，行道道士赐绢二百疋，又奉圣旨以本命紫纹七十疋、五方纹缯各二十疋、银五百两，令臣依《河图内篇》奉修齐谢并余功德。 臣爰以去载十二月晦及今载元正之日，先於广陵郡大唐广业大龙兴观馑修岁节吉斋，以助履新之庆。 今又於茅山紫阳观中铨举同法有戒行者，共营斋具讲习之仪，务令合法，然后施用。 至夏斋毕，随事上闻。 但臣自顾非材，谬参道法，不以庸浅频荷国恩，虽竭愚诚，岂酬万一？ 无任悚惧之至。 天宝＋三载正月二十五日。 臣含光言：仲夏炎热，伏惟圣躬起居万福。 臣先奉圣旨，令於茅山修奉河图斋谢，频属霖雨，遂阙施行，至今月八日夜始就宿启次，九日、十日夜依法正斋，并伸礼献次，十二日江中投璧，以望日设斋饭贤。 自始及终，颇为周悉。 但臣等学非师授，材愧聪明，虽馑按成规而所疑未洗，不胜惶惧之至。
chunks.translated_text:

I have dispatched my disciple Tang Ruoqian to accompany the imperial messenger Qi Lingshuo, bearing this memorial to Your Majesty.

On the nineteenth day of the sixth month, the eleventh year of Tianbao:
Your humble servant Han Guang respectfully submits: As the sun’s arc completes its circuit and daylight reaches its southernmost extent, I reverently pray that Your Majesty, who receives the celestial mandate and embraces the blessings of Heaven, may know boundless prosperity. At present, we are conducting rites of fasting and offerings at Maoshan for the welfare of the state, and our joy is beyond measure. I have sent the imperial messenger Dan Tingyao to inquire after Your Majesty’s well-being and now humbly present this memorial.

---

On the twenty-fifth day of the tenth month, the eleventh year of Tianbao:
Your humble servant Han Guang respectfully submits: Regarding the rites of fasting and offerings previously petitioned for at the eastern slope of Yugang Mountain, to the right of the Ziyang Abbey, we commenced on the twenty-seventh day of the sixth month and have continued the Daoist observances until the seventh day of this month, at the first light of the winter solstice. On that occasion, both the participants in the fast and the imperial messenger Qi Lingshuo witnessed sweet dew descending upon the pine trees in all directions around the altar. The dew was white in color, fragrant in scent, sweet in taste, and its abundance diminished with the distance of the pines from the altar. To date, we estimate that sweet dew has descended upon two hundred and thirty pine trees. As the *Daodejing* states, “When Heaven and Earth unite, sweet dew descends—no one commands it, yet it falls evenly.” The sages of old recorded this in their scriptures as an auspicious omen. That our rites of fasting and offerings should coincide with such a sign is most propitious. How could I dare withhold this news? I have dispatched my disciple Tang Ruoqian to accompany the imperial messenger Qi Lingshuo, bearing this memorial and presenting two measures of the sweet dew.

---

On the twenty-fifth day of the first month, the twelfth year of Tianbao:
Your humble servant Han Guang respectfully submits: Though the first month of spring still brings chill, I reverently pray that Your Majesty’s well-being may be ever blessed. On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month of the previous year, the imperial messenger Dan Tingyao and my disciples, including Tang Ruoqian, arrived, bearing Your Majesty’s gracious decree of inquiry and consolation. I have received one hundred bolts of silk, while the Daoist practitioners conducting the rites were bestowed two hundred bolts. Furthermore, I was honored by Your Majesty’s command to perform rites of purification, thanksgiving, and additional meritorious observances in accordance with the *He Tu Nei Pian*, for which I received seventy bolts of purple-woven silk for my life-cord, twenty bolts each of five-directional patterned silk, and five hundred taels of silver. Accordingly, on the last day of the twelfth month of the previous year and the first day of the new year, I first conducted the auspicious New Year’s fast at the Great Dragon Prosperity Abbey of the Great Tang in Guangling Prefecture, to enhance the blessings of the season’s renewal. Now, at the Ziyang Abbey on Maoshan, I have assembled fellow practitioners of the Dao who uphold the precepts, jointly preparing the ritual implements and rehearsing the ceremonies to ensure strict adherence to the proper forms before their use. Once the summer fast concludes, I shall report the proceedings in full. Yet I, who am of no talent, have been mistakenly entrusted with the Daoist teachings and, despite my unworthiness, have repeatedly received the state’s favor. Though I strive with utmost sincerity, how could I ever repay even a fraction? My awe and trepidation are beyond measure.

---

On the twenty-fifth day of the fifth month, the twelfth year of Tianbao:
Your humble servant Han Guang respectfully submits: As the heat of midsummer intensifies, I reverently pray that Your Majesty’s well-being may be ever blessed. Previously, I received Your Majesty’s decree commanding the performance of the *He Tu* rites of purification and thanksgiving at Maoshan. Due to incessant rains, the observances were delayed, and it was not until the night of the eighth day of this month that we established the fasting quarters. On the nights of the ninth and tenth days, we conducted the formal fast in accordance with the proper forms, proceeding through the rites of obeisance and offerings. On the twelfth day, we cast jade into the river, and on the full moon, we prepared a fast to honor the worthy. From beginning to end, the proceedings were carried out with meticulous care. Yet my learning has not been transmitted by a master, and my abilities fall short of wisdom. Though I have followed the established regulations, my doubts remain unresolved, and my apprehension is beyond measure.

Your servant Han Guang respectfully reports: On the tenth day of this month, the imperial envoy Meng Youxian arrived at Maoshan with a sacred edict to conduct meritorious deeds at the ritual site. Overwhelmed by the imperial grace, I am filled with awe and trepidation. Previously, on this mountain, I and those Daoist priests of strict discipline have together maintained the duties of incense and lamp offerings, humbly seeking to aid the state, uphold the teachings, dispel calamities, and invoke blessings. **Imperial Edict on the Prohibited Mountains of Maoshan, Runzhou**

**Damao Mountain:** To the west, within three *li* of level ground, lies Taiping Abbey. To the south, within three *li* of level ground, stands Chongyuan Abbey and the Daoist Ancestral Hall at the southern gate of Huayang Grotto. To the east, within four *li*, and to the northeast, along the unbroken ridge of Lǜ Ridge, the boundary follows the level path. To the north, it connects to Jijin Ridge, encompassing the western gate of Huayang Grotto and its shrines.

**Zhongmao Mountain:** To the west, within three *li* of level ground, lie Sanmao Temple and its shrines. To the east, within three *li* of level ground, to the south, adjoining Jijin Ridge, and to the north, connected to Xiaomao Mountain.

**Xiaomao Mountain:** To the west, within three *li* of level ground, extending northwest to the Dragon Pond at Leiping, Master Guo’s Pond, and Ziyang Abbey. To the south, it adjoins Zhongmao Mountain; to the east, within three *li* of level ground; and to the north, it connects to Daheng Mountain, encompassing Yankou Grotto and its shrines, as well as Liandan Abbey, three *li* northward.

The above account is submitted by Sun Zhiqing and other ceremonial Daoist priests of the Three Abbeys of Maoshan. The sacred precincts of the Perfected Ones of Huayang Grotto-Heaven, having previously received the imperial decree prohibiting hunting, logging, and the burning of vegetation in autumn and winter, as well as the cessation of all sacrificial offerings involving animals, have since endured hardship. The original edict has been lost, and the people, disregarding the former command, have increasingly encroached upon these lands, recklessly felling the mountain forests and falsely claiming long-standing rights.
