chunks.translated_text:
Deputy Copyist of Imperial Edicts, Song Shao, *Edict Prohibiting Logging in the Mountains*

It has come to our attention that within the boundaries of Maoshan, near the temples, abbeys, and oratories, many disregard the regulations of cultivation and arbitrarily engage in logging or set wildfires to burn the mountain forests. This matter requires deliberation and specific directives.

The state now extends its blessings to nurture the people. These renowned mountains, recorded in the local gazetteers, are either governed by benevolence or serve as the abode of perfected beings. They are places where blessings descend and are rightfully deemed sanctuaries for the spirit. How, then, can axes and hatchets compete to fell them, or firewood-gathering proceed without restraint, causing the finest growth to wither and the numinous traces to fade from view? Thus, we issue this prohibition to manifest our reverence and solemnity.

Hereby, we command Runzhou and Shengzhou that, upon receipt of this imperial proclamation, they shall demarcate the boundaries on all four sides of Maoshan. Strict orders shall be enforced to sever all such activities. Henceforth, no person—including the officials, abbots, and custodians of the mountain’s temples, abbeys, and oratories—shall be permitted to engage in logging, felling, or setting wildfires to burn the forests.

Local patrol officers, officials, elders, and strongmen shall be charged with surveillance and inspection. Should any violations occur, the offenders shall be immediately apprehended and sent to the relevant prefectures and counties for interrogation. After a public display of fifteen days, they shall be released. If the scale of logging is extensive and the circumstances unforgivable, the offenders shall be detained and a report submitted for further instructions, after which they shall be sentenced and exiled accordingly.

For areas outside the temples, abbeys, and oratories where firewood is needed and the trees are not part of ancient sites or long-preserved growth, the county officials and the custodians of the abbeys shall jointly demarcate the boundaries and erect clear markers before any logging may proceed. Where trees have already been felled or burned, leaving gaps in the rows, the local prefectures and counties shall mandate the replanting of trees in those areas to ensure no barren spaces remain. No disturbances shall be tolerated.

This imperial proclamation shall be inscribed on stone and displayed at the gates of the abbeys and along major thoroughfares for all to know.

The 2nd year of the Dazhong Xiangfu era, by imperial decree as above.

The August Empress Liu bestows upon Master Zhu of the Dao a red imperial letter, along with a gold water vessel weighing thirty taels in total. This vessel was used by the Emperor in his youth and is now granted to the Daoist to purchase land for the sustenance of the Daoist community, providing for their daily meals and rituals. These rituals shall be conducted daily to pray for the Emperor’s longevity, perpetual peace, and eternal freedom from calamity. The recipient shall consult with the local prefect to acquire fertile land and fine estates. Ren Wenqing and the prefect shall jointly oversee the purchase, and upon completion, a map shall be drawn and submitted.

*Imperial Edict Conferring Additional Titles upon the Three Lords of Maoshan*

The Chancellery is hereby decreed: Within the Grotto-Heaven of Juqu, there dwell perfected beings whose transformations are boundless and whose numinous wonders are unfathomable. Since the Qin and Han dynasties, over a thousand years have passed, during which their blessings have manifested and their grace extended to the people. Yet their exalted names and titles remain incomplete, which does not suffice to express the utmost sincerity of our veneration.

The Great Lord of Maoshan, currently titled *Taiyuan Zhenren, Eastern Marchmount Supreme Minister, and Director of Destinies*, shall henceforth be advanced to *Taiyuan Miaodao Zhenren, Eastern Marchmount Supreme Minister, and Director of Destinies*.

The Middle Lord of Maoshan, currently titled *Dinglu Right Prohibitions Zhenren*, shall henceforth be advanced to *Dinglu Right Prohibitions Chongjing Zhenren*.

The Lesser Lord of Maoshan, currently titled *Sanguan Baoming Zhenren*, shall henceforth be advanced to *Sanguan Baoming Chonghui Zhenren*.

May this harmonize the qi, elicit auspicious responses, and assist our state in securing boundless peace and prosperity.

Thus is this edict decreed.

chunks.original_text: 所乞立木事，已降指挥修建本观所，要疾速选定日期兴工。 如逐旋有阙，一一奏来。 春气渐和，自加调适，谨奉天时，以滋妙道。 崇宁二年正月九日。 敕刘混康：尔自别京师，倏改岁华。 完修祠殿，备悉勤劳。 近览奏章，具知安裕。 所云殿名，以天宁万福可也。 其清静经，并依所奏。 尔肃恭祀事，达于上境，所见灾祥，何不具奏？ 此者，牟麦发生之际，惟藉膏泽之力。 乃自春首以来，颇愆时雨，未济四郊之农，甚惨千箱之望。 朕心忧惧，夙夜匪遑。 尔当悉心体予至怀，用斯恳切之诚，精加祈梼之意。 以名非高道，岂达清都？ 余宜将爱，愈探妙理。 山林幽静，更保真常。 崇宁二年三月二十一日。 劝刘混康：尔自别京师，屡经岁时。 抚宣之意，惟常累遣。 逮于仲夏，畏日永长。 想尔山居清冻高爽，道妙之余，动止臻常否？ 修严秘宇构茸，必已成就。 崇奉至真，付委加于有德。 事更有阙典，可缕缕敷陈。 如所见灾祥，须一一具奏。 时正暑炎，宜自保炼，余勤道业，体予至怀。 崇宁二年五月二十三日。 敕刘混康：卿昔寓处都阙，延对禁廷，每陈忠道之诚，开益朕躬之志。 虚心采纳，岂泯嘉言？ 赐号越常，用昭褒显，所有诰一轴，今递付卿，至可领也。 秋气爽肃，燕居练养之余，宜加保护。 持赐葆真观妙先生诰。 敕江宁府句容县茅山道士洞元通妙大师刘混康：朕执古之道以御今之有，嘉与希夷守一之士，以正浇漓之习，惟尔专气致柔，敦其若朴，虽道尊德贵，莫之能爵，而名实称谓，其可已乎？ 宜申锡於命书，庶激扬於后学，尚推尔素以辅善民，可特赐号葆真观妙先生。 崇宁二年七月二十五日中书舍人白时中行。 朕以卿道备德隆，陈诚助国，特颁异号，故显高仁。 若以恤物济功未婵嘉称，址阁命宜当祇受，勿复固辞，想宜知悉。 敕刘混康，自建京国，屡改岁华。 所思一德之可嘉，在我三秋而不忘。 近收来奏，喜知宁谧，章继先猷缉熙，秘宇殿成，宝录庆　　以臻严阁耸崇，宁仰上真之来格。 卿素守虚无，超然高尚，斋持秘宇，能顺育於炎冻静乐，茅峰自安怡於泉石。 来奏具悉，已降指挥差御药、苏珪提举管勾应合，须索，一一申禀，自可奏裁，应副不致有阙也。 霜秋届候，气律初寒，更臻道妙，言不多及。 如见有何灾异，一一奏来。 前者祈求事，至今未得感应，今次如何也？ 崇宁三年九月十五日。 劝刘混康：自别京畿，屡更岁钥。 栖三茅而浩志，洁一已以全真，寓边山居，潜心物外，缅想道妙冲静，植性清夷，顺穹壤以养高，脱尘寰而悟理。 兹览来奏，良载悉所怀。 涉冬而来，动止安否：知中春诣阙，已差使臣张栩津置其行，备委官司一切应副。 或尚有阙，详具奏来，可期观尔，预积欣棕。 方届隆冬，将迎朔易更，在博施真教，协济草生余，加保练之功，用体眷勤之意。 姑此书谕，指不多及。 崇宁三年十一月二十三日。 敕刘混康：省览来奏，备悉恳诚。 隆寒岁暮，喜获安常。 茸构葆真，尚阙绘用，已降指挥，应干官吏责以近限，并力就功。 上梁等事，各有司存，何必告成？ 乃离渊室，及漕运经画，一一去讫。 首春气暖，当先诣阙，勿为稍稽，以多高虑，坤听舟楫，来赴闽阁。 已差诸司官沿路管勾。
chunks.translated_text:
The request to erect timber has been approved, and an order issued for the construction of the abbey. Select an auspicious date to commence work with haste. Should any deficiencies arise in the course of progress, memorialize each in turn.

As the spring qi gradually harmonizes, attend well to your own regulation, reverently aligning with the celestial seasons to nurture the wondrous Dao.

*Issued on the ninth day of the first month in the second year of Chongning.*

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
Since your departure from the capital, the seasons have swiftly turned. The completion and repair of the shrine halls bespeak your diligent toil. Upon reviewing your recent memorial, I am pleased to learn of your peace and prosperity.

As for the name of the hall, *Heavenly Tranquility and Myriad Blessings* shall suffice. The *Scripture of Purity and Stillness* shall proceed as memorialized.

You, in solemn reverence, conduct the rites, reaching the celestial realms. Why have you not memorialized in full the portents and omens you have witnessed?

At this time of barley and wheat sprouting, we rely solely on the grace of timely rains. Yet since the onset of spring, the seasonal rains have been wanting, leaving the fields of the four directions unwatered and the hopes of a thousand granaries in dire straits. My heart is heavy with concern, and day and night I find no respite.

You must wholeheartedly grasp my deepest sentiments. With this earnest sincerity, redouble your prayers with utmost devotion. Though my title is not that of a lofty Daoist, how could I fail to reach the Pure Capital? The rest may be cherished as before; delve ever deeper into the wondrous principles.

In the seclusion of the mountains and forests, guard well your true constancy.

*Issued on the twenty-first day of the third month in the second year of Chongning.*

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
Since your departure from the capital, many seasons have passed. My thoughts of comfort and inquiry have been repeatedly conveyed.

Now in midsummer, the scorching sun lingers long. I imagine your mountain dwelling, cool and lofty, where in the tranquility of Daoist practice, your movements and repose remain in harmony. The renovation of the sacred halls must surely be complete.

In reverent devotion to the Supreme Perfection, entrust the task to one of virtue. Should any rites or matters be lacking, memorialize them in detail. As for any portents or omens you witness, report each without omission.

The season is now one of intense heat; attend well to your cultivation and refinement, and in your diligence in the Dao, embody my deepest care.

*Issued on the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the second year of Chongning.*

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
When you once resided near the capital and were summoned to the imperial court, you frequently expressed your sincere devotion to the Dao, broadening my own aspirations. With an open heart, I embraced your counsel—how could such fine words be forgotten?

To honor and make manifest your distinction, I bestowed upon you the title *Transcending the Common*. The accompanying decree, now dispatched to you, is to be received accordingly.

As the autumn air turns crisp and solemn, in the leisure of your refined cultivation, take care to preserve your well-being.

Hold the bestowed decree of *Mysterious Master of the Abbey of Preserving the True*.

Decree to Liu Hun Kang, Daoist Master of Penetrating Mystery and Great Perfection of Mao Mountain in Jurong County, Jiangning Prefecture:
I govern the present with the Dao of antiquity, esteeming those who, like you, embrace the obscure and guard the One, rectifying the decadent customs of the age. You concentrate your qi to attain suppleness and nurture simplicity. Though the Dao is exalted and virtue esteemed, beyond the reach of rank, how can the correspondence of name and reality be set aside?

Thus, I renew the bestowal of this decree, that it may inspire later scholars. Continue to extend your innate goodness to aid the people. You are hereby specially granted the title *Mysterious Master of the Abbey of Preserving the True*.

*Issued on the twenty-fifth day of the seventh month in the second year of Chongning, by Secretary of the Secretariat Bai Shizhong.*

I, considering your profound Dao and towering virtue, your sincere devotion to the state, have specially conferred this exceptional title to manifest your lofty benevolence. If you feel your merits in aiding the world fall short of such a distinguished appellation, the imperial command must still be reverently accepted. Do not persist in refusal; you should understand this well.

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
Since the founding of the capital, the years have turned many times. I have cherished the singular virtue you possess, and through three autumns, I have not forgotten.

Upon receiving your recent memorial, I rejoice to learn of your tranquility. Your chapters continue the former plans, the sacred halls are completed, and the precious records bring blessings—all now adorn the towering pavilions, awaiting the descent of the Supreme Perfection.

You have long guarded emptiness and transcendence, your loftiness surpassing the common. In maintaining the sacred halls, you harmonize the extremes of heat and cold with serene joy. On Mao Peak, you find contentment among the springs and rocks.

Your memorial has been reviewed in full. An order has been issued to dispatch the Imperial Physician Su Gui to oversee and manage all necessary provisions. Memorialize whatever you require, and it shall be granted without deficiency.

As autumn’s frost arrives and the seasonal qi turns cold, may you further attain the wondrous Dao. Words are not needed to convey more.

Should you witness any further calamities or omens, memorialize each in turn. As for the prayers previously offered, to this day no response has been received. What is to be done this time?

*Issued on the fifteenth day of the ninth month in the third year of Chongning.*

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
Since your departure from the capital region, many years have passed. Dwelling on the Three Mao Peaks, your aspirations remain vast; purifying yourself, you preserve your true nature. Residing in the border mountains, your heart dwells beyond the mundane.

I recall your wondrous Dao, serene and tranquil, your nature planted in purity and peace. You align with heaven and earth to nurture your loftiness, shedding the dust of the world to awaken to principle.

Upon reviewing your recent memorial, I am pleased to learn of your thoughts.

As winter approaches, how do your movements and repose fare? I understand that in mid-spring you will journey to the capital. An emissary, Zhang Xu, has been dispatched to arrange your travel, and all relevant officials have been instructed to provide for your needs. Should anything still be lacking, memorialize in detail, that I may anticipate your arrival with joy.

Now in the depths of winter, as the year draws to a close, in your broad dissemination of the true teachings and your aid to the sprouting grasses, redouble your efforts in cultivation to embody my deepest care.

This letter conveys my intent; further words are unnecessary.

*Issued on the twenty-third day of the eleventh month in the third year of Chongning.*

Decree to Liu Hun Kang:
Your memorial has been reviewed in full, and your earnest sincerity is understood. As the year ends in bitter cold, I rejoice in your well-being.

The construction of the Abbey of Preserving the True still lacks decorative painting. An order has been issued to the relevant officials to enforce a strict deadline and complete the work with all haste. The matters of raising the ridgepole and the like are the responsibility of the respective offices—why must you report their completion?

The arrangements for your departure from the deep chamber and the planning of the canal transport have all been carried out.

As the early spring air warms, you should first journey to the capital without delay. Do not allow even slight hesitation, lest it cause me further concern. Prepare your boat and oars, and hasten to the imperial court.

Officials from the various bureaus have been dispatched to oversee your journey along the way.

chunks.original_text: 在理，当然难为寝罢，体予眷待宜悉至怀。 崇宁四年正月十二日。 敕刘混康：荐览来奏，备悉恳情。 春首峭寒，喜知宁谧。 尔心志通博，绝尘虑以保真常，识达精微，养灵台而臻妙道。 自建三茅，萦尔一心。 兹者，修完之役已，至丹臜之工，委付有司，必早周备。 冲静是守，毋劳神用。 乃眷尔益，欲宣趋对之怀，厥意惟坚，宜遂告成之请。 可依所奏，才候工毕日，速赴阙下。 其张斓已降指挥专一催督、应办去讫，并本命神像迁入法堂，权行奉安。 如更有阙，一一奏来。 春寒届候，宜加保毓，用昭优渥，体予至怀。 崇宁四年正月二十四日。 劝刘混康：览卿来奏，备悉恳怀。 欣富涉春，益闻保福，中前赴色之书，继有告成之约。 以谓君子不可以力致，方士不可以拘萦，载详尔意，宜遂厥求。 俾从达者之逍遥，式副高人之所请。 固非少拒，勿致深疑。 况卿洞鉴真元，默垂道荫； 植性衍冲渊之意，禀材多介恪之仁！ ，神符有济，顺天地之生成，法力无穷，赞阴阳之化育； 清高可尚，尘俗难羁； 浩然守志於林泉，洁素以安於寿考。 宫宇修完，应办可集。 已令促役，必无缓时。 才有毕工之奏，速期赴阙之行。 未即对问，更希加爱，故兹语示，想宜知悉。 崇宁四年闰二月三日。 劝刘混康：卿宅心道妙，显迩神功，顺四序以凝和，寓一身而永福，灵符法水，久推济物之仁，保气存神，自得养生之主。 涉#4此畏景，想集殊禧。 比询入觐之期，力有告成之请。

In principle, it is indeed difficult to rest easy, and you should fully understand my deep regard for you.

On the twelfth day of the first month, the fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang: Having reviewed your memorial, I have fully grasped your sincere sentiments. Though early spring brings biting cold, I am pleased to learn of your peace and tranquility. Your mind is vast and penetrating, transcending worldly concerns to preserve your true and constant nature; your understanding reaches the subtlest depths, nurturing the spirit-terrace to attain the wondrous Dao. Since the founding of the Three Mao Abbey, it has wholly occupied your heart. Now that the work of repair and completion is done, the task of applying cinnabar and pigments has been entrusted to the relevant offices, and they will surely see it finished without delay. Maintain your serenity and stillness, and do not overtax your spirit.

My regard for you has only grown, and I wish to summon you for an audience to express my thoughts. Your resolve is firm, and your request for completion should be granted. You may proceed as memorialized: as soon as the work is finished, hasten to the imperial court.

Zhang Lan has already been issued orders to supervise the project exclusively and ensure all preparations are made. The sacred images commissioned for you are to be moved into the Dharma Hall and provisionally enshrined. If anything remains lacking, report it to me at once. As spring’s cold lingers, take care to preserve your health, that my profound favor may be made manifest. You should fully understand my deepest concerns.

On the twenty-fourth day of the first month, the fourth year of Chongning.

An exhortation to Liu Hun Kang: Having reviewed your memorial, I have fully grasped your sincere sentiments. As spring deepens, I am gladdened to hear of your continued well-being. Your earlier letter expressing readiness to journey here has been followed by a pledge of completion. I have considered that a gentleman cannot be compelled by force, nor can a master of the Dao be bound by constraints. Having carefully weighed your intentions, I shall grant your request, allowing you to follow the carefree path of the enlightened and fulfilling the wishes of one of lofty virtue. This is no slight refusal, so do not entertain deep doubts.

Moreover, your insight penetrates the true origin, silently bestowing the blessings of the Dao. Your nature is rooted in profound and abyssal tranquility, and your endowment abounds with steadfast benevolence. Your spiritual efficacy brings aid, aligning with the creative and sustaining forces of Heaven and Earth; your dharmic power is boundless, aiding the transformative nurturance of yin and yang. Your purity and nobility are to be esteemed, and worldly ties cannot restrain you. With unwavering resolve, you dwell in forests and springs, maintaining purity to ensure longevity. The abbey’s halls are repaired, and all preparations should be complete. I have ordered the work to be expedited, and there must be no delay. As soon as you memorialize the completion of the project, make haste to the imperial court. Though I have not yet met with you in person, I urge you to take even greater care. Let these words serve as instruction, and I trust you will understand.

On the third day of the intercalary second month, the fourth year of Chongning.

An exhortation to Liu Hun Kang: Your heart abides in the wondrous Dao, and your spiritual efficacy is renowned near and far. You harmonize with the four seasons to cultivate harmony, dwelling in your body to ensure lasting fortune. Your sacred talismans and dharma-water have long been praised for their benevolence in aiding others; preserving qi and nurturing spirit, you naturally attain mastery of life’s cultivation. As this season of scorching heat approaches, I trust extraordinary blessings will gather upon you. I have inquired about your scheduled audience, and you have earnestly requested completion of the work.

chunks.original_text: 毕工在迩，重诺难渝。 宜促行装，正风帆可乘之便，早登画鹊，当江水善利之时。 暑炎在候，更切保颐。 故兹书示，言不多及。 崇宁四年五月二十九日。 敕刘混康：省观来奏，备悉所怀。 涉夏之中，提身益福。 历知工筑仅及於告成，将伺舟维届临於近甸。 其如服勤职事，干集善能顾惟激励之风，当允诚忱之请。 指期良观，促日戒行。 敷善利於草生，享微名於大道。 副兹至礼，体我眷怀。 夏热，卿比平安好。 遣书，指不多及。 崇宁四年六月十七日。 敕刘混康：卿法大道之自然，稽真诠之典则。 顺时乐性，正一己之贞心，阐教济人，保千龄之上寿。 睽阔滋久，怀想#5良多。 累召待来，逮今改岁。 尚有力难之奏，犹压固避之言。 况予迭命有司，当遂责成，董集其工，但勿贻虑，余者完缮，悉付规模，渐可庆全，夫何多逊？ 宜速登舟之备，伫聆飞橹之音。 仙#6帆风静，秋水波平，乘兹清景，勿辞来对。 荐颁诏谕，示我眷隆，将遂观言。 遣书，指不多及。

The completion of the work is near, and solemn promises must not be broken. You should hasten your preparations, for now is the time when favorable winds fill the sails, and the painted magpie may soon ascend—when the river’s waters flow smooth and swift. The scorching heat is upon us; take even greater care to preserve your well-being. Thus I write to inform you, and shall say no more.

On the twenty-ninth day of the fifth month, the fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang: Having reviewed your recent memorial, I fully comprehend your sentiments. Through the height of summer, you have maintained your person and increased your fortune. I have learned that the construction is nearly complete, and you will soon arrive by boat in the capital’s vicinity. In serving diligently at your post, you have gathered merit and demonstrated your ability, embodying the spirit of encouragement. Your sincere request shall be granted. Set a date for your audience and hasten your departure. Spread good fortune like sprouting grass, and enjoy modest renown along the great Dao. Fulfill this utmost courtesy and honor my deep regard.

The summer heat is intense; I trust you remain well. This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

On the seventeenth day of the sixth month, the fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang: You embody the naturalness of the great Dao, studying the canonical principles of true doctrine. Accord with the seasons and delight in your nature, rectifying the steadfast heart within yourself. Expound the teachings to aid others, preserving a lifespan of a thousand years. Our separation has grown long, and my thoughts of you are many. Though I have repeatedly summoned you, the year has turned anew. There remains your memorial of hardship, and your words of persistent avoidance. Moreover, I have repeatedly ordered the officials to ensure completion, supervising the work’s assembly. Do not harbor further concerns; the rest of the repairs shall follow the established plan. Gradual progress will bring full success—why offer excessive modesty? Prepare swiftly for your voyage, and I shall await the sound of your oars. With the immortal’s sail stilled by gentle winds and autumn waters calm, seize this clear season and do not decline to come for an audience. I issue this edict to demonstrate my profound regard, and shall soon witness your words in person.

chunks.original_text: 崇宁四年七月十八日。 敕刘混康：自远皇都，屡周星岁。 居名山而崇秘殿，竭丹恳以奉高真； 阐扬大道之源，昭答上灵之既； 茸兴观宇，广集休祥； 壮一伐之弘规，衍万年之景祚； 凡所陈述，皆尽公忠。 显须来对，从便船居。 其如退材，已行处分。 毕役云初，庆成就绪，当斯秋景，促棹安流。 天高云静，蘸晴光千里之平波； 水翠烟淇，荡素色一帆之轻吹。 尚测气力，自养清高。 故此诏示，宜悉眷怀。 非晚观言，兹惟简及。 崇宁四年八月二十日。 敕刘混康：省所奏修造已就绪，欲於九月中乘船赴阙朝谢者。 欣聆画鹊容与秦淮，显伺仙亮翱翔魏阙，伫听希夷之妙诲，钦敷慈俭之淳风。 治念烹鲜，动趋正道。 霜秋届候，涉履良勤。 爰命使华，往加抚劳。 体兹眷异，益固冲和。 宜速进舟，慰予跤望。 秋玲，卿比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 崇宁四年九月十二日 敕刘混康：心存道要，夙契真元，久处逍遥之场，自得冲和之旨。 昨迂芝盖来叩枫宸，遂款秘奥之名。 言乞还茅峰之旧隐，志坚意切，勉从所陈。 违远以来，倏尔经月，每一思念，寤寐不忘。 扁舟高卧。 谅及淮楚之畿，三秀栖真，获出尘寰之表。 高风遐举，良景慕之。 时当拌暑，卿比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 先生自离阙下，倏忽阅月。 想以道妙动止冲和，每一南望，愈增恋慕。 向者所托奏章之事，伺有天意，可速奏来。 及求伤风符子数十道，附递封进。 时方炎暑，清虚自重，想已到宫，所修如何？ 潜神庵了与未，一一奏来崇宁五年五月十三日。 劝刘混康：所奏拜章事，具知。 夫至诚必通，精修有感，事具存於真典，仪昭着於真科。 卿虔心请祷，斋洁驰神，默契高真，获通秘旨。 非夫公忠之内充，何得精诚而上达？ 邮音忽至，嘉叹良深。 昨恳辞上京，丐还旧里。 三茅胜盘，允资高尚之居； 列圣所栖，克时潜神之志。 更宜保练，以副虚怀。 畏暑在序，卿比平安好。 遣书，指不多及。 崇宁五年六月二＋日 先生离阙下来，又复累月，比日炎暑，想以道妙清胜。 所奏祥章，不胜嘉叹，自非先生高道洞达，何以臻此？ 如更有所见，附黄希叟来奏，得无隐幸也。 本宫所阙，亦可一一缕细开陈。 潜神之役，未见告功，不知所修可意否。 同前。 劝刘混康：徒弟傅希列资到表章，具知刻意虚无，宅心清静，得无为之妙理，通大道之渊源。 自抵万宁，蚓多余裕。 三茅紫府，列圣福庭，真仙所栖，灵答如响。 卿宝金录而练气，秘玉简以清修。 想得优游，必资香火，上祈宗社之谧宁，下济黎元於仁寿。 所驰至意，宜亮悉之徒众。 忽临封章来上，深嘉远恳，益表勤诚，骤尔睽违，但渴名理。 褥暑尚炽，善卫是宜，卿比平安好。 遣书指不多及。 傅希列等资到表章，知卿已至元符万宁宫。 及知拜章事，蒙上天慈恤。 敷锡嘉祥。 卿道慕三茅，行遵二许，暂来魏阙，还驻故山，鹤驭难留。 每深引向，近烦慈念，通拜宝章，祇荷苍昱，俯垂渊鉴，丁宁天训，警悟不忘，夙夜钦崇以酬昭既。 炎暑方隆，保爱是宜，余具诏意。 所奏事，逐一降指挥讫。 如更有所阙，但一一见示。

On the eighteenth day of the seventh month, fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang:
Since your departure from the imperial capital, many months and years have passed. Dwelling upon the renowned mountains and revering the sacred halls, you have devoted your utmost sincerity to serve the exalted immortals. You have expounded the origins of the Great Dao, illuminating the responses of the celestial spirits above. You have restored and expanded the temple precincts, gathering auspicious omens, magnifying the grand design of this single endeavor, and extending the radiant blessings of ten thousand years. All that you have presented has been marked by utmost loyalty. I eagerly await your audience; you may travel by boat at your convenience. As for your modest reluctance, I have already issued instructions accordingly. Now that the initial phase of the work is complete and the project nears its joyous conclusion, seize this autumn season and hasten your oars upon the tranquil currents. With the heavens high and clouds stilled, the clear light bathes a thousand miles of calm waves; waters emerald and mists verdant, a single sail billows in the gentle breeze. Still, I gauge your strength and encourage you to nurture your purity and loftiness.

This edict is issued to demonstrate my profound regard; may you fully grasp its intent. I shall soon witness your words in person.

This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

---

On the twentieth day of the eighth month, fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang:
I have reviewed your memorial reporting the completion of the repairs and your intention to embark by boat in the ninth month to attend court and offer thanks. I rejoice at the prospect of your leisurely journey along the Qinhuai, your luminous presence soaring like an immortal toward the imperial gates. I await the profound teachings of your subtle wisdom and revere the pure winds of your compassionate frugality. Your thoughts are ever fixed on governance and the preparation of fresh offerings, ever tending toward the true Dao. As autumn’s frost approaches, your travels must have been arduous. I have dispatched an emissary to convey my comfort and esteem. May this exceptional regard further strengthen your serenity. Prepare swiftly for your voyage to ease my longing. Autumn lingers—how fare you of late?

This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

---

On the twelfth day of the ninth month, fourth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang:
Your heart holds fast to the essence of the Dao, long attuned to the true origin. For years, you have dwelled in the realm of carefree ease, mastering the subtleties of harmony. Recently, your cloud-borne canopy arrived at the vermilion gates, and you graciously revealed the secrets of your renowned teachings. You petitioned to return to your former retreat on Maofeng, your resolve steadfast and earnest. I have reluctantly acceded to your request. Since your departure, a month has swiftly passed, and with each thought of you, I remain wakeful and forgetful of sleep. Though you recline in your secluded boat, I trust you have reached the borders of Huaichu, where the threefold auspicious herbs nurture your true nature beyond the dust of the world. Your lofty winds and distant ascent are truly admirable.

As the season battles the lingering heat, how fare you of late?

This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

---

Since your departure from the capital, a month has quickly elapsed. I imagine your movements and stillness remain attuned to the Dao’s subtleties. With each glance southward, my longing and admiration only deepen. Regarding the matters you entrusted in your memorial, await the celestial will and present them swiftly. Additionally, I request several dozen talismans for wind ailments to be sealed and forwarded. As the season remains oppressively hot, tend to your clarity and emptiness. I trust you have arrived at the palace—how fare the repairs? Have you completed the work on the meditation hermitage? Report each detail in your memorial.

On the thirteenth day of the fifth month, fifth year of Chongning.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang:
I have reviewed your memorial regarding the presentation of the sacred writ. Truly, utmost sincerity must reach the heavens, and diligent cultivation will evoke response. The details are preserved in the true canons, and the rites are clearly set forth in the sacred codes. Your reverent heart has prayed with purity, your spirit soaring in devotion, silently communing with the exalted immortals to receive their secret decrees. Were it not for the fullness of your public loyalty, how could your sincerity ascend so purely? Your swift arrival brings profound admiration.

Recently, you earnestly sought to decline the journey to the capital and petitioned to return to your former abode. The three peaks of Maoshan are indeed a fitting retreat for one of your loftiness, a sanctuary where past sages have dwelled, fulfilling your aspiration to withdraw and cultivate the spirit. You must further refine yourself to match my earnest hopes. As the season turns to scorching heat, how fare you of late?

This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

---

Since your departure from the capital, months have again passed. With the days growing hotter, I imagine your mastery of the Dao keeps you serene. Your memorial of auspicious omens fills me with admiration—were it not for your profound understanding of the lofty Dao, how could such blessings be attained? If you have further insights, send them with Huang Xisou; do not conceal anything. Also, itemize any deficiencies in the palace and report them in detail. The work on the meditation hermitage has yet to be announced as complete—are the repairs to your satisfaction?

As before.

An edict to Liu Hun Kang:
Your disciple Fu Xilie has presented a memorial, from which I understand your dedication to emptiness and your dwelling in purity, attaining the wondrous principles of non-action and plumbing the depths of the Great Dao. Since arriving at Wanning Palace, you have enjoyed abundant leisure. The three peaks of Maoshan and the Purple Mansion, the blessed courts of past sages, the abodes of true immortals—all respond to your presence like an echo. You treasure the Golden Registers to refine your qi and guard the Jade Tablets in your pure cultivation. I trust you find ease and leisure, sustaining the incense and flames to pray for the tranquility of the imperial house above and the well-being of the people below. Your earnest devotion is duly noted.

Your sealed memorial has arrived, deeply moving me with its distant sincerity and further demonstrating your diligence. Though our separation has been brief, I thirst for your wisdom. As the scorching heat persists, take care to protect yourself.

How fare you of late?

This letter conveys my message, and I shall say no more.

---

Fu Xilie and others have presented a memorial, informing me of your arrival at Yuanfu Wanning Palace and your successful presentation of the sacred writ, for which you have received the compassionate favor of Heaven and the bestowal of auspicious signs. Your Dao emulates the three peaks of Maoshan, your conduct follows the two masters Xu, briefly visiting the imperial court before returning to your native mountains—how could the crane-borne chariot be detained? Though I deeply cherish our bond, your recent kindness has weighed heavily on my thoughts. Your presentation of the sacred writ has borne the august gaze of Heaven, and I humbly receive its profound instructions, ever mindful of its warnings, day and night revering and striving to fulfill its radiant decrees.

As the scorching heat intensifies, take care to preserve your well-being. The rest is as conveyed in the edict. All matters in your memorial have been addressed accordingly. If further needs arise, report them in detail.

The eternal resting place of Yongsheng shall permit the assembly of devotees for rites of incense and prayer; the officials of the Hidden Spirit Abbey shall be rewarded according to their ranks and grades. The decree has already been issued—you may rest assured.

I revere and honor the Great Dao, gazing with admiration upon the sacred traces of the immortals. To manifest my aspirations and glorify their merits, I have opened the mountains and erected halls. Now that the construction is complete and the work presented, my joy and gratitude overflow as hoped. May the true wind be widely proclaimed, bestowing abundant blessings upon the people; may the refined cultivation of the dharma records forever harmonize with and support the grand foundation. Though my earnest instructions remain distant, guard well your pure heart.

The autumn chill approaches—how fares your health of late? This letter conveys but a few words.

**Edict to Liu Hun Kang:**
I have reviewed your memorial requesting the appointment of an official to compose the record of the abbey. All details are understood.

Mao Ridge, a secluded retreat, stands upon an ancient site of golden repute. Mindful of its sacred proximity, adjoining the cavern palaces, I have expanded the new sanctuary of jade towers to grandly inaugurate the flourishing of the true wind. With the abbey’s completion, the monumental stele awaits its inscription. I have commanded a learned scholar to compose the text and personally inscribed the stele’s title. This is not merely a splendid occasion of the present but also a means to extol the virtuous renown of those who came before. You must carefully select eminent Daoist masters to diligently cultivate the supreme Way with unwavering devotion. Such is the aspiration I hold for you, ever mindful of its essence, and ever recalling your exemplary conduct.

Given the long and arduous journey, I imagine our meeting remains distant. The stele’s title I have personally inscribed, along with the record composed and written by Cai Bian, are now dispatched under the escort of an imperial envoy—you may receive them accordingly.

The autumn chill approaches—how fares your health of late? This letter conveys but a few words.

You have long dwelled in purity upon Golden Mount, your name recorded in the Purple Bureau. Since your departure by immortal boat, I have daily pondered and missed you. Now that the autumn air has suddenly turned crisp, I reflect from afar upon the harmony of your Daoist body. Though our meeting remains beyond reach, my longing for your Way is profound. Preserve your hidden spirit in cultivation, fulfilling my earnest gaze.

The stele’s title and other items have now been completed and are sent to you. Any further matters you wish to convey are fully set forth in the memorial.

**Edict to Liu Hun Kang:**
You have long resided in the truth, unwavering in your adherence to the Dao. Your merits and conduct grow ever more illustrious, your reputation long established. Dwelling in the peace of Wanning, you serve the Great Record with diligence; your broad salvation of the living draws all toward virtuous transformation. Expanding the wonders of your effortless mastery, you bring forth the auspicious signs I may attain. For fame is made manifest by reality, and rites are measured by virtue—thus, it is fitting to bestow honors of praise and esteem, extending far-reaching blessings. The elevation of your dharma title is most fitting. Receive this with reverence and do not decline.

The edict of appointment is now dispatched to you—you may receive it accordingly.

The season of white autumn is upon us—how fares your health of late? This letter conveys but a few words.

I reflect upon your dwelling in truth upon Sentence Mountain, nurturing purity and concealing your spirit. Your healing waters have brought relief near and far; you have summoned crane chariots to discourse upon the Dao and proclaim harmony, guiding with effortless wisdom to aid the people’s tranquil governance. I revere your subtle mysteries, ever mindful of them waking and sleeping. Recently, with the completion of the abbey, I have added the title "Master of Serene Harmony" to your name. The edict has already been sent to you—may you appreciate this favor.

Though your tribute of wise counsel has arrived, your audience remains beyond reach. Take especial care of yourself.

Regarding the memorial from Master Yi on matters of the abbey gates, walls, and other structures, requesting repairs—I have ordered the relevant authorities to act with utmost urgency. Materials, timber, and the like shall be procured within a strict deadline, swiftly assembled without delay or negligence. If you have any further needs, submit them without reservation.

I also request several dozen talismans for dispelling wind afflictions and calming the heart against fright—this would be most welcome.

chunks.original_text: 敕江宁府茅山元符万宁官葆真观妙先生刘混康：三茅灵境，仙圣所栖。 比建新宫，用伸崇奉。 以尔心游澹漠，道合元微，俾宅其问，阐扬至化，宜加美号，以示眷怀。 可特授葆真观妙冲和先生。 崇宁五年八月二十三日，中书舍人李图南行。 敕刘混康：卿#8奉教玄元，宅心清静，造洞真之奥，隐茅峰之颠，，乃卷旧居，缅然灵异，构崇新宇，大壮宗风。 丹台鲜丽，演崆峒之道枢； 紫府鼎新，追汗漫之高躅。 按图显敞，皇称真游。 益彰崇奉之勤，用庆落成之美。 益增欣沃，当形咏歌。 御制庆成颂一轴，今入递赐，至可领也。 高秋气肃，比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 御制元符万宁宫庆成颂 茅山之麓，元符中，即隐者刘混康所庐建观，号元符观。 经始於元年秋，至崇宁五年秋宫成。 大书其榜，更号元符万宁宫。 盖以协成哲宗之志，以安妥明灵，钦崇妙道，昭示后世，乃为之颂日： 句曲之山，有居其颠，谁氏之子，象帝之先。 启迪后人，淑修其身。 守静而笃，是为葆真。 在昔元符，作室其下。 经始勿亟，以遗来者。 我应受之，嗣绍厥绪。 我仪图之，缮此楝宇。 考彼官宇，因心而友，不日成之。 克相其后，乃益其名，日维万宁，书以揭之，用妥明灵。 道大无方，体用有常。 以德则帝，以业而王，坐进此道，与道无极。 神之听之，洽此万国。 崇宁丙戌岁宣和殿书。 初夏之别，几半载矣。 坐阻颜角，乃情惰想，每引领之动，思阻修途而兴叹。 还山以来，景仰何啻：有诗写怀，今同附递到，并检领。 极思晤语，邈未有期。 金风向 敕，天和善保。 符子已收，更求佩带符数道。 推恩事已施行，希知之。 葆真观妙冲和先生归山以诗送之 当年问道属高人，曾揽霞衣到紫宸。 身是三山云外倡，心无一点世问尘。 征鸿望极幽栖远，贺燕归飞洞府新。 多谢为传心法妙，此真真外更无真。 崇宁五年九月一日，御制并书。 劝刘混康省：累上表，具悉。 卿道高二许，德贯三茅，为教法之宗师，扩真风而济物，恳辞辇毂，裕处名山，阔清标之晤会，思绮褥之奥言。 每觊贡章，良嘉勤意。 所陈乞事，皆已施行。 徒弟师名，锡凝和之美号。 丰碑刊勒，许漕幕之总提。 今者，方外父宁，雨旸时若，荷上帝之降康，亦焚修之有助。 霜秋届候，良晤未期，勉加保颐，用慰倾想。 笞一序之 敕，今同递附，至可领也。 卿比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 崇宁五年十月十二日。 睽阻以来，复见穷秋。 引领南顾，徒切坐驰。 每得邮音，大慰倾渴。 山林虚静，想神游冲漠，以适安耳。 所赐还山诗、庆成颂，并许刊模、自余手诏等，不可上石乍玲，保持法录外，倍万珍啬。 敕刘混康：省#9所进天宁节功德疏，具悉。 卿养浩山樊，栖真方外，忠惟体国，志在爱君。 属厥月之诞，弥被清场而荐祉，疏言来上，嘉叹良深，故兹诏示，想宜知悉，冬寒。 卿比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 崇宁五年十月二十四 日o
chunks.translated_text:
**Edict to Liu Hun Kang, Mysterious Master of the Baozhen Abbey at Yuanfu Wanning Palace, Mount Mao, Jiangning Prefecture:**

The sacred realm of the Three Maos is where immortals and sages dwell. Now that the new abbey has been built to honor and revere them, and as your heart wanders in serene detachment, your Dao harmonizes with the primordial and subtle, you are entrusted with its governance to propagate the supreme transformation. It is fitting to bestow upon you a noble title to express my esteem. You are hereby specially appointed **Mysterious Master of Serene Harmony of the Baozhen Abbey**.

**Twenty-third day of the eighth month, fifth year of Chongning.**
*Executed by Li Tunan, Vice Director of the Secretariat.*

---

**Edict to Liu Hun Kang:**

You, sir, have devoted yourself to the teachings of the Mysterious Origin, your heart dwelling in purity and stillness. You have delved into the profound mysteries of the Cavern of Truth and concealed yourself upon the peaks of Mount Mao. Now, you have returned to your former abode, where wondrous marvels abound, and erected a grand new sanctuary, greatly magnifying the ancestral tradition. The cinnabar terraces gleam resplendent, expounding the pivotal Dao of Mount Kongtong; the purple palaces are renewed, emulating the lofty footsteps of the vast and boundless. As the illustrated plans reveal its splendor, the emperor’s true journey is proclaimed. Your diligence in reverence is thus further manifested, and the beauty of its completion is celebrated. My joy overflows, and it should inspire songs of praise.

A scroll of the **Imperially Composed Ode on the Abbey’s Completion** is now sent to you by courier—you should receive it with gratitude.

As the high autumn air turns crisp, I trust you remain in good health. This missive conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

---

**Imperially Composed Ode on the Completion of Yuanfu Wanning Abbey**

At the foot of Mount Mao, during the Yuanfu era, an abbey was built upon the hermitage of Liu Hun Kang, named the Yuanfu Abbey. Construction began in the autumn of the first year and was completed in the autumn of the fifth year of Chongning. Its plaque was inscribed in grand script, and it was renamed **Yuanfu Wanning Abbey**, to fulfill the will of Emperor Zhezong, pacify the luminous spirits, revere the wondrous Dao, and enlighten posterity. Thus, I compose this ode:

Upon the peaks of Mount Juqu,
There stands a dwelling.
Who is this man?
He embodies the primordial before the Emperor.
He enlightens those who come after,
Refining his person.
Abiding in stillness with sincerity,
He preserves the true.

In the Yuanfu era of old,
A chamber was built beneath.
Its construction was unhurried,
Left for those to come.
I have received this legacy,
Continuing its thread.
I have followed its design,
Restoring these halls.
Surveying this abbey,
It befriends the heart,
Completed without delay.
To aid those who follow,
I augment its name,
Calling it **Wanning**,
Inscribing it upon the plaque,
To pacify the luminous spirits.

The Dao is vast and without bounds,
Its essence and function constant.
In virtue, it is imperial;
In deeds, it is kingly.
Advancing in this Dao,
One becomes one with it without end.
May the spirits heed this,
And bring harmony to all under heaven.

*Written in the bingxu year of Chongning, inscribed in the Xuanhe Hall.*

---

Since our parting in early summer, nearly half a year has passed. Though separated by distance, my longing for your presence weighs heavily upon me. Each time I raise my gaze, I am moved to sigh at the length of the journey. Since your return to the mountain, my admiration has only deepened. I have composed a poem to express my sentiments, which is now sent to you along with this missive—please acknowledge its receipt.

I yearn for our conversation, yet the time for meeting remains distant. As the golden winds approach, may the harmony of heaven preserve your well-being. The talismans have been received; I now request several more for wearing.

The bestowal of grace has already been enacted—may you be aware of this.

---

**Imperially Composed and Inscribed Poem on the Return of Mysterious Master of Serene Harmony to the Mountain**

In those years, you sought the Dao from a lofty master,
Once donning the rosy clouds to reach the purple court.
Your body is a minstrel beyond the three mountains,
Your heart untouched by a speck of worldly dust.
The migrating geese gaze into the distance, your secluded dwelling far,
The swallows of congratulation return to the newly built grotto abode.
I thank you for transmitting the wonders of the heart’s method—
Beyond this truth, there is no other truth.

*First day of the ninth month, fifth year of Chongning. Composed and inscribed by imperial hand.*

---

**Edict to Liu Hun Kang:**

Your repeated memorials have been received in full. Your Dao is as lofty as the two Xus, your virtue spans the three Maos. As the patriarch of the teachings and a master who propagates the true wind to aid all beings, you humbly decline the imperial carriage and dwell in the renowned mountains. Though our meetings are rare, I long for the profound words of your pure and refined character.

Each time you present your memorials, your earnest devotion is deeply appreciated. All the matters you have requested have been enacted. Your disciples have been bestowed the fine title of **Ninghe**. The grand stele has been permitted for carving, with the transport bureau overseeing its completion.

Now, in the realm beyond the world, all is at peace; wind and rain arrive in due season. The grace bestowed by the August Emperor brings well-being, aided by your devout cultivation. As the frosty autumn arrives, though our meeting remains distant, I urge you to take care of yourself to ease my longing.

The **Preface to the Edict** is now sent to you by courier—please receive it with gratitude.

I trust you remain in good health. This missive conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

*Twelfth day of the tenth month, fifth year of Chongning.*

---

Since our separation, autumn has deepened. I crane my neck toward the south, my thoughts racing. Each time I receive your letters, my longing is greatly soothed. In the emptiness and stillness of the mountains and forests, I imagine your spirit roaming in serene detachment, finding peace.

The **Poem on Your Return to the Mountain**, the **Ode on the Abbey’s Completion**, and permission to carve them, along with other imperial decrees, are beyond precious. Beyond preserving them in the abbey’s records, guard them as if they were ten thousand times more valuable.

---

**Edict to Liu Hun Kang:**

Your memorial on the merits and virtues for the **Tianning Festival** has been received in full. You nurture your vastness in the mountains and forests, dwelling in truth beyond the world, yet your loyalty is devoted to the state, your aspiration to cherish the sovereign. As the month of his birth approached, you widely partook in the pure rites to offer blessings. Your memorial was presented, and my admiration runs deep. Thus, this edict is issued to inform you. As winter’s chill sets in, I trust you remain in good health. This missive conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

*Twenty-fourth day of the tenth month, fifth year of Chongning.*

Your memorial presenting your petition has been received in full. You dwell in profound stillness, your cultivation of the Dao pure and complete. As winter’s rhythm unfolds, you preserve the harmony of Heaven’s principle. Upon reviewing the tribute and offerings you presented, I have fully understood your earnest pleas.

That the completion of these meritorious works has not yet received due imperial recognition is a matter for which your detailed account is fitting. Your deliberations are measured and just, and thus your petition is approved in its entirety and shall be put into effect. The **Xuan Yi** agricultural fields are hereby granted as you requested: the **Danyang** embankments and dams shall not be seized or withheld by other offices. All affairs are to be conducted with impartiality, nothing reserved for private gain. Your diligence and devotion move me deeply, and I commend your loyalty.

May you delight in the constancy of truth and expand the practice of the **Upper Clarity** teachings, that you may extend your blessings to me and forever shelter the realm. This depends on the sincerity of your heart—understand my intent.

The early cold has set in; I trust you remain in good health. This missive conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

Since we parted, time has flown like the swift passage of days and months—how could my longing ever be satisfied? Amid the towering white clouds, I imagine you find much that is fine. You recently requested that the poems and eulogies bestowed upon you be inscribed in stone, along with the carved models and the distributed authentic copies—all are to be kept by you personally. If you have further petitions, submit them through the postal relay.

Our next meeting remains uncertain, and my yearning only grows deeper. As winter’s season deepens, guard your health in the Way.

Your heart roams Penglai Isle, and in seated reverence you greet Kongtong; you guard the mysteries of cultivating truth and embracing the One, penetrating to the root and returning to the source of life—thus, at the auspicious Qingcheng retreat, immortal lamps appeared as auspicious signs. This arises from the ascent of pure devotion, filled within by utmost sincerity, and thus felicitous omens gather while the numinous responds in kind. All living beings share in this blessing, and its splendid benefit is beyond words. Since reading your memorial, I have been deeply moved and full of praise.

I have also learned that on a chosen day in mid-winter, you personally journeyed to Yongsheng to perform the burning of yellow talismans. The season is bitterly cold, and the labor cannot have been light. I imagine the crane-borne carriage has now returned you to the mountains, where you draw near to welcome the *Scripture of Longevity* and its virtuous protection.

I have heard that at the abbey, sacred lamps appeared upon Sou Lun Peak—truly a marvel. Had it not been for your profound sincerity moving the unseen, how could such a thing have come to pass? Putting brush to paper only deepens my admiration, though our reunion remains uncertain. My yearning only grows, and I urge you to care for yourself, truly fulfilling my hopes.

I hear that in past years, when you performed the burning of yellow talismans, the cold was severe. Guard your health upon the road. On the day you return to your hermitage, seek out several dozen more [talismans/rites]. As before.

Dwelling in mountain caves, you wander freely; revering the dharma records, you abide in tranquility. Given your profound virtue, it is fitting that you receive praise and honor. Already I have bestowed poems in proclamation, and further expressed my admiration in eulogies. You have submitted a memorial requesting their inscription in stone, and I approve. Your cinnabar sincerity, diligent in jade-like refinement, has moved me to command that the imperial barge convey them to your abbey’s walls. chunks.original_text: 腊残春及，气易序迁，更勤保练之功，频示冲虚之诀。 已差使臣专一管押刻石前去，至可领也。 凝寒，卿比平安好，遣书，指不多及。 大观1 兀年正月二＋七日。 敕刘混康：卿秉心无妄，执道不回，总持法源，旱生所赖，功庸昭着，揭如日星，使上清之教益隆而弗替者，皇有力焉。 比以道释混淆，理宜区别，断自朕心，重订调谬。 至如三清混居於水陆，元命反祠于梵宫，绘塑无伦，不可盘举。 朕方图叔彝伦，讲明教法，稽考后先之理，推原积习之端，申饬有司分别崇奉，庶蒙休祉，溥佑含生。 谅在渊冲，必惟允议。 更新岁律，尚冀保绥，故兹示谕，想宜知悉。 寒冱，卿比平安好，遣书指不多及。 大观元年二月九日 敕刘混康：卿提身冲粹，有#10道渊深，秉志不回，推心笃善。 省观奏牍，备悉至怀。 仍闻新岁以来，法履泰定。 所进木煎灵方，夙授仙饵，今存虽神鼎金丹之妙，无以加诸长生之理。 兹其大致乎披绎，勤志听惬于中。 妙术恭持，必无畔戾。 时传邮命，副以好音。 春序云初，天和善护。 睽异晤言，俄经新律。 渴想仪刑，朝夕弗替。 近降 敕书，所谕道释混淆，已付外施行。 事恐未详尽，今录元降全文，付卿一看。 卿教门纲领，人所视效，其诸传授，保执持之，无吝忽也。 所修石桥道路事，已委发运使曾孝蕴专一应副施行。 益远会见，千万加慎。 镇心神符子，告求数十道。

Your meritorious deeds shine resplendent as the sun and stars, and it is through your efforts that the teachings of Supreme Clarity flourish without decline. Herein lies the throne’s contribution.

Consider how the Three Clarities now share space with water-and-land rites, or how the *Yuanming* scriptures are venerated within Buddhist halls—such chaotic depictions and carvings defy enumeration. I am now ordering the restoration of proper ritual norms and the clarification of teachings. By examining the principles of past and present, tracing the origins of entrenched customs, and instructing officials to enforce distinctions in reverence, may all beings receive boundless blessings and protection.

I trust your profound equanimity will align with this judgment. As the new year begins, I hope you remain secure and serene. Let this decree inform you accordingly.

As a leader of your teaching, you are observed and emulated by all. In all transmissions you oversee, preserve and uphold them without negligence.

chunks.original_text: 恐有所见灾福，告先生示及。 直师，初春可令至。 昨降物往彼道场，已到否： 有天下者尊事上帝，敕命惟几，敢有弗虔？ 而释氏之徒修营佛事，妄以天帝次於鬼神之列。 渎神瑜分，莫此之甚。 其能克享上帝之心乎？ 可令有司检会削除，以称朕严恭寅畏之意。 大观元年二月十五日。 敕刘混康：朕祗奉三元，钦崇至道。 每念灵承之重，庶臻可致之祥。 凡在幅员，率兴观宇，卷三茅之名封，集殊方之胜盘。 倚毗师法，以召蕃厘。 卿夙资渊妙之功，屡获嘉休之应，累迂鹤驭来叩枫宸，款名理之至言，询心法之要妙，保神清静，阐闱厌闻，旅寓储祥，殆非宜称。 已令董治鸠工构宇，即上清之束隅建万宁之别观。 庶专静绾，延处云耕，可预择徒弟来此住持，故兹示谕，想宜知悉。 领所奏道教未便洎陈乞事。 卿道门宗师，教法纲领，凡所陈请，皆合朕志，睽违高论，日驰南顾，遐想香火之余，高栖云表，保神练气，所得多矣。 竺师争之候黄冕到山，可同赴阙。 春序将暄，为道加慎。 大观元年二月＋九日。 敕刘混康：省所奏辞免赴阙事，具悉。 朕钦奉真元，夙崇高道。 眷彼栖真之倡，常形梦寐之思。 伫瞻每渴於仪刑，睽阔倏更於岁钥。 再款话言，庶资妙理。 是用载驰使传，敦趣造朝。 忽露封章，引疾恳避。 夫岂不怀，义非可强。 当止召命，更伺岁年，尚慎寝瓮，以副眷渥。 春和，卿比平安好，遣书指不多及。 相别周岁，引领尤勤。 两披奏牍，以疾力辞赴阙，已具别敕，可其所请，宜亮悉之。 安处潜神，以保寿康，想绰有余裕也。 道场事，前已报知。 笞一师陈请，皆契勘施行，候指挥到，止，可令竺师赴阙会晤，尚赊对时自卫。 治百病伤风符子，告求数十道。 夜分灯下，发虑先生，意不安故也。 大观元年四月七日o 敕刘混康：省览累奏，具悉卿槟弃人事，远去尘寰。 既婵恳迫之诚，勉徇便安之请。 遐想迩来怡神昭旷，持法崇高，处寂以绝营，葆光而不曜，临风束望，一及绪益，不无倾渴之勤也。 竺争之便，可发来赴阙。 或有奏陈，详具无隐。 初夏渐热，卿比平安好，遣书指不多及。 大观元年五月二＋七日。 别来一周，星律倾渴，话言未尝替也。 志趣高尚，厌绝嚣纷，得以澄神静虑，为冲漠之游。 良多慰洗，愈远高论，徒深引向。 首夏清和，为道保育。 月末忽目青，连发疏以书问笞一师，可令速至。 有经数卷，伺笞一师到，令附去，皆亲书。 茅山志卷之三竟 #1址：原作『止』，据笪本改。 #2址：原作『止』。 坚：原作『紧』，据笪本改。 #3到树行疏处：笪本作『到树行稀疏处』。 #4涉：笪本作『际』。 #5想：笪本作『思』。 #6仙：笪本作『山』。 #7灵：原本作『露』，据笪本改。 #8卿：原缺，据笪本增。 下同。 #9省：原缺，据笪本增。 #10有：笪本作『育』。 茅山志卷之四 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造
chunks.translated_text:
Should you observe any omens of fortune or calamity, report them to Master without delay.

Direct Master Zhi to arrive at the beginning of spring.

Have the supplies previously sent to that Daoist sanctuary arrived?

He who rules all under heaven honors and serves the Supreme Emperor. My decrees are issued with utmost reverence—how dare any treat them with irreverence? Yet the followers of Śākya construct Buddhist rituals, recklessly ranking the Heavenly Emperor among ghosts and spirits. Such blasphemy against the divine order is unparalleled. How can this reflect due reverence for the Supreme Emperor? Command the relevant authorities to investigate and expunge such errors, that it may accord with my solemn awe and veneration.

*Dated the fifteenth day of the second month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

**Decree to Liu Hun Kang:**

I reverently serve the Three Primordials and honor the Supreme Dao. Ever mindful of the weight of spiritual inheritance, I strive to attain auspicious blessings. Throughout the realm, Daoist temples flourish, gathering eminent masters from distant lands beneath the banner of the Three Mao Peaks. Relying on your teachings, we summon prosperity and rectify disorder.

You, long steeped in profound and wondrous practice, have repeatedly received felicitous responses. Though the crane-borne carriage has twice conveyed you to my court, your profound discourse on the Dao and inquiry into the essentials of the heart-mind have preserved your spirit in purity and tranquility. Yet your sojourn as a guest, storing up auspiciousness, is hardly fitting. I have already ordered the supervision of artisans to construct a sanctuary at the eastern edge of the Supreme Clarity precincts, establishing a separate retreat named "Myriad Peace." Here, you may dwell in secluded quietude, extending your cloud-plowing cultivation. Select disciples in advance to reside here and take charge. This is hereby decreed; I trust you will take note.

Regarding the matters you memorialized concerning the inconveniences in Daoist teachings and your petitions, as the patriarch of your tradition and the leader of its teachings, all your proposals align with my intentions. Though parted from your lofty counsel, my thoughts turn southward daily. I imagine you amidst incense and flame, dwelling high above the clouds, preserving your spirit and refining your qi—your attainments are surely abundant.

When Master Zhu arrives to await the arrival of Huang Mian at the mountain, have them proceed together to the court.

As spring warms, take care in your Daoist practice.

*Dated the twenty-ninth day of the second month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

**Decree to Liu Hun Kang:**

I have reviewed your memorial declining the summons to court and understand your circumstances.

I revere the True Primordial and have long honored the Supreme Dao. My regard for those who dwell in truth is ever present, even in dreams. I yearn for your exemplary presence, yet our separation has swiftly passed another year’s end. To converse again would surely yield profound insights. Thus, I dispatched envoys with all haste to urge your arrival. Yet your sealed memorial suddenly arrived, pleading illness and seeking to decline. How could I not be moved? Yet propriety cannot be compelled. For now, I shall suspend the summons and await a more auspicious time. Take care in your rest and recovery, that it may reflect my deep regard.

The season warms—how is your health of late? This letter conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

A year has passed since we parted, and my longing has only grown. Having reviewed your two memorials, in which you pleaded illness to decline the summons, I have issued a separate decree granting your request. You should understand this clearly. Remain in seclusion, nurturing your spirit, to preserve your longevity and well-being—your reserves are surely abundant.

Regarding the Daoist sanctuary, I have already responded. Master Chi Yi’s petitions have all been reviewed and implemented. Once further instructions arrive, suspend them, and have Master Zhu proceed to court for an audience. Take care in your travels.

For the talismans to cure all ailments and ward off wind, request several dozen more.

In the quiet of night, by lamplight, my thoughts turn to you, Master, and my heart is uneasy.

*Dated the seventh day of the fourth month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

**Decree to Liu Hun Kang:**

Having reviewed your repeated memorials, I understand your resolve to abandon worldly affairs and retreat far from the dusty realm. Given your earnest and pressing sincerity, I reluctantly accede to your request for convenience and ease.

I imagine of late your spirit is serene and expansive, your practice lofty and exalted. Dwelling in stillness, you shun worldly distractions; preserving your inner light, you do not display it. Gazing toward you in the wind, I am filled with longing—my yearning is unceasing.

Master Zhu may set out to proceed to court. If you have any memorials to submit, present them in full without concealment.

Early summer grows warm—how is your health of late? This letter conveys but a fraction of my thoughts.

*Dated the twenty-seventh day of the fifth month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

A year has passed since we parted, and my longing has only deepened. Our conversations have never ceased.

Your aspirations are noble, and you shun the clamor of the world, allowing your spirit to settle and your thoughts to quiet, wandering in the vast emptiness. This brings me great comfort, though the distance from your lofty counsel only deepens my admiration.

Early summer is mild and harmonious—take care in nurturing your Dao.

At the end of the month, my eyes suddenly grew dim. I promptly sent a letter to Master Chi Yi, ordering him to arrive swiftly. There are several scrolls of scriptures to be sent with him upon his arrival—all written in my own hand.

*End of Scroll Three of the Maoshan Annals*

---

*Scroll Four of the Maoshan Annals*
*Composed by Liu Dabin, Successor of the Supreme Clarity Tradition*

chunks.translated_text:
Deputy Scribal Edict to Song Shao’s Edict, Imperial Decree to Liu Hun Kang:

Our separation has grown long, and the summer’s glare weighs heavy—yet my thoughts of you have only deepened. I imagine you reclining among the towering clouds and mountains, nurturing your lofty spirit beyond the mundane, moving with ease through the realm of self-attainment. My admiration for you knows no bounds.

If there are matters you wish to convey, do not hesitate to speak them aloud. Await the swift arrival of my messenger from the west, that I may hear your full intent in person. Whatever you have witnessed there, spare no detail, however trivial, and send it by post. Let no suffering of the people in that region remain unknown to me—this is my earnest hope.

The summer’s heat rages fiercely; guard well your inner harmony.

Master Huang has arrived and reported all matters as you instructed. With reverent purification, I have written a sealed memorial and entrusted it to you, Master, to present upon your audience. This would be most fortunate. Once the Celestial Response is received, hasten to report it in full.

I have also instructed Master Chi Yi to deliver to you the memorial from the Noble Consort, which shall accompany him on his return to the mountain.

I send two scrolls of imperial brush paintings—one of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy, the other of the Most High Dao Lord—along with last year’s painting of the Most High Lord Lao, to form a triad of the Three Pure Ones for your silent veneration. Five volumes of the *Scriptures of the Northern Dipper*, twenty folding fans, ten kinds of fruit, and offerings of incense, flowers, dragon-brain incense, tea, and candles—all have been counted and entrusted to Master Chi Yi. Additionally, fifty blank ordination certificates from the Bureau of Sacrifices, and thirty purple robes. Should you require ordination for disciples, those under Master Chi Yi’s guidance shall be granted purple robes and the title of Master.

Fifteen attendants accompanying you shall all receive ordination and gifts of silk, each according to rank.

*Dated the twenty-ninth day of the seventh month, first year of the Daguan era.*

The talismans you have repeatedly bestowed upon me, I dare not keep for myself. If anyone falls ill, I shall administer them, that I may fulfill your intent to heal and save.

I request several dozen more talismans to be sent by post.

---

Imperial Decree to Liu Hun Kang:

I have reviewed your memorial and its appended records, and all is clear to me. I am further informed that your memorial of prayer has reached the celestial realm, and that you have received the profound and secret responses. My admiration runs deep.

Had you not awakened to the wondrous subtleties of the inner vision, aligning with the Dao to nurture the true, and devoted your thoughts to the welfare of the people with such sincere and silent devotion, how could such attainment have been possible? My joy is beyond measure.

As summer turns to autumn, your blessings only grow. In the intervals between my myriad duties, I often turn to the essentials of the Dao, and my longing to hear your words is as urgent as thirst for sweet water.

Spring is not far off; I expect your arrival from the west. Do not let modesty keep you from fulfilling my deepest wishes.

The autumn air is crisp and solemn. I trust you are well. My words here are few, but my thoughts of you are constant.

Long have I been deprived of your virtuous presence; I can only strive to draw nearer to it.

Your recent memorials, received by post, speak of your serene and abundant cultivation in seclusion. All matters you have reported through Master Jing shall be examined and acted upon.

Next spring, you shall come to court. Further instructions will be sent; I shall not elaborate here.

When spring waters rise, take a small boat west. Do not resist my will.

As autumn wanes and frost descends, guard your health above all else.

*Dated the fifth day of the ninth month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

Imperial Decree to Liu Hun Kang:

I have reviewed your memorial offering prayers for the Celestial Tranquility Festival. All is understood.

As the early winter season approaches the imperial birthday, you shall conduct solemn rites upon the jade altar, invoking boundless blessings for the empire. That one beyond the world should not forget his devotion to the throne is a loyalty most commendable. My admiration only grows.

Thus, I issue this decree, that you may know my thoughts.

Early winter finds you well, I trust. My words here are few.

*Dated the fourteenth day of the tenth month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

Our separation has been long, and my longing for you is constant. I rejoice to hear that your Dao is pure and your conduct untroubled.

Regarding your memorial declining the summons to court at the year’s beginning, I have not yet granted your request. I truly wish to see you again, to receive your guidance. Our parting has been too long, and your repeated refusals, though earnest, seem almost a rejection. Yet the waters flow gently—what hardship would there be in coming?

After the New Year, another decree shall be issued. For now, tend well to your celestial harmony.

Next spring, I shall send an envoy to summon you. Do not refuse or resist my command.

---

Imperial Decree to Liu Hun Kang:

I have reviewed your recent memorials. All is understood.

You dwell in the seclusion of Mount Mao, nurturing the true beyond the mundane, moving with ease and contentment. Your every action is blessed. Your offerings and words have reached me, and my admiration for your devotion is profound.

Though the subtleties of your discourse remain distant, my thoughts ever turn to you.

I have repeatedly issued edicts summoning you to court next spring. Yet you delay, reluctant to engage with worldly affairs, preferring to nurture your lofty spirit. I urge you to set aside your resolve and grace me with your presence, rather than persist in defiance of my wishes.

Consider well my regard for you, and do not disregard my words.

As winter begins, guard your inner harmony.

The cold has set in; I trust you are well. My words here are few.

*Dated the ninth day of the tenth month, first year of the Daguan era.*

---

Your memorial regarding the elevation of the titles of the Three Mao Lords has been reviewed and approved according to ritual precedent. You shall be informed of the details.

At the year’s beginning, you must come to court. Do not refuse my command.

What I seek is only your intimate and profound presence.

As winter’s severity grows, take utmost care of yourself.

I request several dozen more talismans; your kindness would be deeply felt.

The affairs of the palace gates are ever on my mind—how could I not be concerned?

---

Imperial Decree to Liu Hun Kang:

Your keen insight into the true mechanism of the Dao shines with the radiance of the highest Way. Every memorial you submit resonates deeply with my heart.

Your earnest petition for the ennoblement of the Three Mao Lords, in reverence for the Dao, is most fitting. I shall instruct the relevant offices to bestow upon them the most illustrious titles.

You are hereby granted these honors; receive them accordingly.

*[Missing character] month: may you preserve your well-being.*

How I long for the day when the rivers swell and your journey is unhindered! My thoughts of you are unceasing.

As spring approaches, I eagerly await your arrival. Travel by boat without hesitation.

When the season of growth arrives, refine your spirit with utmost clarity.

The winter is cold; I trust you are well. My words here are few.

Since we parted, how have your days been? When your divine canopy travels east, I think of you often, and cannot help but sigh.

When next spring comes and you sail westward by boat, our profound discourse may at last be realized. The talismans requested by the Noble Consort shall be provided. Until then, tend well to your health.

chunks.original_text: 朕惟至德之世，无为而万物化渊，静而百姓定。 爰率是道，纳民泰和。 诚意感通，异人杳至。 眷遇之礼，曲尽始终。 葆真观妙冲和先生刘混康； 虚一守真，纯白自得，前知休咎，能警群迷，或托呎符，克愈众疾，虽身栖林谷而名振京师。 朕用嘉叹，召对闲宴，屡闻至论，深契予心。 比复造廷，燕居琳馆，了然委化，不约而同。 静思所存，宜加悯饰，太中之秩，视谏大夫。 兹为异恩，尚期饮享，特赠太中大夫。 谧静一诰 敕：朕惟曲水之穴，北距岱宗，南接罗浮。 证法册於河图，得嘉名於地肺。 抱道秘境，惟昔高人。 真风未忘，前辙具在。 赠太中大夫刘混康，出尘累之表，以虚静为宗，观妙勾金之坛，葆光埋璧之地。 慕真风於南岳，窥奥义於西城。 众方有求，忽若委蜕，其颁美谧。 式昭正一之功，庶几异时益振冲虚之教，可特赐谧静一。 敕赐元符万宁宫 尚书省牒：江宁府茅山元符万宁宫茅山元符观牒，奉敕宜改赐元符万宁宫为额，牒至准敕，故牒崇宁五年正月日牒，中大夫守右丞邓、太中大夫守左丞何、司空右仆射。 建元符万宁官提举等官推恩劝命 敕：相观福地，肇建祠官，为彼旱黎导迎景既。 龙图阁直学士左朝议大夫胡师文等，克共乃事，逮兹落成？ 嘉汝之勤，叔进宫品，若时休命，亦既乃心。 可特授左中散大夫，依前职差遣。 宣义郎江东运判乔，可特授宣德郎，差遣如故。 承事郎知句容县事鲍慎辞，特授宣义郎，差遣如故。 右侍禁监江宁府排岸高士迁，特授左侍禁。 西头供奉官高公鼎，特授束头供奉官。 借职张和，特授奉职。 差使叶承，特授借职。 三班差使孟忠，特授三斑。 借职知县事鲍慎，辞免三年磨勘。 又别敕 江宁府茅山元符万宁宫修盖潜神庵宇等，安排御书牌了毕，事体非轻，下项管勾，催促部役官等，可特依此推恩发运。 副使刘何与转一官江宁府通判范希逸，与臧三年磨勘。 候今任满日，特令再任其部役巡检，内殿崇班孙 明翼，转一官。 敕赐藏真观 尚书省牒，江宁府藏真观故刘混康葬所见修道院牒，奉敕宜特赐藏真观为额。 牒至，准敕故牒。 大观二年＋一月　日牒，中大夫守左丞余太师左仆射。 宣和封陆简寂真人诰 朕惟前古高蹈之士名边不泯，而称号未称者，所以追显之。 简寂先生陆修静，真精内得，遗经垂范，而脱然超世。 庐阜故隐有祠，至今考实，定名礼以真人之号。 非特用褒往躅，亦俾后之闻风者知道之所在而勉焉。 可特封丹元真人。 宣和封杨郭许陶五真人诰 敕：朕存婴霄府，盼景龙台，瞻三秀之神乡，企九华之妙诲。 钦厥列仙之躅，昭兹阐化之功。 束华上佐司命杨真人，积学洞微，研心合漠，得中黄之隐诀，受南真之秘传，董司昊越之疆，关总神灵之要，方翎扬於至道，宜褒极於隆名。 庶期冲鉴之临，永侈蕃棋之锡。 可特封洞灵显化真人。 敕：三黑隐灵，固非名言之测，万神凝化，莫容议拟之求。 凡褒叔於上真，实恢张於至道。 玉台侍郎郭真人，功参十极，位列九宫。 含景玉当，已飞行於太极； 扶华晨盖，爰总侍於虚皇。 方丕阐於元纲，宜致隆於显号。 尚期仲格，永佑昌图。 可特封太微葆光真人。 敕：朕降总真之玉境，陆耀景之龙台。 爰校历於元肩，以济生于下土。

In Our consideration of the age of utmost virtue, the myriad things transform in the profound without action, and the hundred clans are settled in stillness. Following this Dao, We guide the people into great harmony. Sincere intent moves in resonance, and extraordinary persons arrive from afar. The rites of Our regard have been extended to their fullest from beginning to end.

To Master Liu Hun Kang of Baozhen Abbey, Observer of the Subtle and Preserver of Primal Harmony: you embrace the One and guard the Real, pure and unblemished in self-attainment. Foreseeing fortune and misfortune, you awaken the deluded masses; at times manifesting in talismanic breath, you cure the multitudes of their ailments. Though your body dwells in the forests and valleys, your name resounds in the capital. We have admired and marveled at you, summoning you to court for leisurely audiences, where We have repeatedly heard your profound discourses, deeply resonating with Our heart. Recently, you again came to court, residing in the Jade Pavilion, where you effortlessly submitted to transformation, in unspoken accord with Us. Reflecting on your steadfast devotion, it is fitting to bestow honor upon you. Thus, We confer the rank of Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, equivalent to that of a Remonstrating Censor. This exceptional grace is granted in anticipation of further offerings. We posthumously confer upon you the title of Grand Master for Thorough Counsel.

**Epithet "Jingyi" (Tranquil Unity) Decree:**
We reflect upon the cavern by the winding stream, which lies north of Mount Tai and south of Mount Luofu. It bears witness to the scriptural registers of the River Chart and is renowned as the "Lung of the Earth." Embracing the Dao within its sacred precincts, it was once the refuge of lofty recluses. The true wind has not been forgotten, and the traces of the past remain evident.

To the late Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, Liu Hun Kang: you stood beyond the dust of worldly entanglements, taking emptiness and stillness as your foundation. You observed the subtle upon the altar of metal and jade, preserving your radiance in the earth where jade is buried. You admired the true wind of the Southern Marchmount and glimpsed the profound mysteries of the Western City. Though the multitudes sought you, you departed as if shedding a cicada’s husk. We now bestow a laudable epithet to honor your memory.

May this serve to illuminate the merit of the Orthodox Unity, and may it inspire the flourishing of the teachings of Primal Emptiness in times to come. We hereby posthumously bestow the epithet "Jingyi" (Tranquil Unity).

---

**Decree Granting the Name "Yuanfu Wanning Abbey":**
**Memorandum from the Ministry of Rites:**
To the Maoshan Yuanfu Abbey of Jiangning Prefecture and the Maoshan Yuanfu Temple: By imperial decree, you are to be renamed "Yuanfu Wanning Abbey." Upon receipt of this memorandum, comply with the decree accordingly.

Memorandum issued on the __ day of the first month of the fifth year of the Chongning era.
*Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, Acting Minister of the Right, Deng; Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, Acting Minister of the Left, He; Minister of Works, Right Grand Councilor.*

---

**Decree for Rewards to Officials Overseeing the Construction of Yuanfu Wanning Abbey:**
Observing the blessed lands, We have established this abbey to guide the people in welcoming the radiant essence. The Hanlin Academician and Left Court Gentleman for Discussion, Hu Shiwen, and others have diligently fulfilled their duties, bringing this project to completion. In recognition of your meritorious efforts, We promote you in rank. As a timely reward, We hereby appoint you as Grand Master for Palace Leisure, retaining your current post and duties.

To Jiangdong Circuit Transport Commissioner, Gentleman for Announcement of Righteousness, Qiao: you are hereby promoted to Gentleman for Propagation of Virtue, retaining your current post and duties.

To Gentleman for Service, Magistrate of Jurong County, Bao Shen Ci: you are hereby promoted to Gentleman for Announcement of Righteousness, retaining your current post and duties.

To Right Attendant-in-Ordinary, Supervisor of Jiangning Prefecture’s Embankments, Gao Shi Qian: you are hereby promoted to Left Attendant-in-Ordinary.

To West Head Attendant-in-Ordinary, Gao Gong Ding: you are hereby promoted to East Head Attendant-in-Ordinary.

To Probationary Official, Zhang He: you are hereby promoted to Attendant-in-Ordinary.

To Commissioner, Ye Cheng: you are hereby promoted to Probationary Official.

To Three Divisions Commissioner, Meng Zhong: you are hereby promoted within the Three Divisions.

To Probationary Official and Magistrate, Bao Shen: you are exempted from the triennial evaluation for three years.

---

**Additional Decree:**
The construction of the Hidden Spirit Hermitage and other structures at the Yuanfu Wanning Abbey of Jiangning Prefecture’s Maoshan, as well as the installation of the imperial calligraphy plaques, are matters of no small importance. The following officials overseeing the project are to be rewarded accordingly:

Vice Commissioner Liu He: promoted one rank.
Jiangning Prefecture Administrator Fan Xi Yi: granted exemption from the triennial evaluation for three years. Upon completion of your current term, you are to be reappointed.

Among the project supervisors, Palace Attendant of the Inner Chambers, Sun Ming Yi: promoted one rank.

**Decree Granting the Name "Zangzhen Abbey":**
**Memorandum from the Ministry of Rites:**
To the Jiangning Prefecture Zangzhen Abbey, the former residence and burial site of the late Liu Hun Kang, now a Daoist abbey: By imperial decree, you are hereby granted the name "Zangzhen Abbey." Upon receipt of this memorandum, comply with the decree accordingly.

Memorandum issued on the __ day of the __ month of the second year of the Daguan era.
*Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, Acting Minister of the Left, Yu; Grand Preceptor, Left Grand Councilor.*

---

**Decree for the Posthumous Enfeoffment of Lu Xiujing as "True Man":**
We reflect upon the lofty recluses of antiquity, whose names have not faded, yet whose titles were not commensurate with their virtue. It is fitting to posthumously honor them.

The Master of Simplicity, Lu Xiujing, attained true essence within and bequeathed scriptures as a model for posterity, transcending the world with effortless grace. His former hermitage on Mount Lu remains, and upon verification, We now bestow upon him the title of "True Man." This is not merely to honor his past footsteps but also to inspire those who hear of him to recognize the path of the Dao and strive accordingly.

We hereby posthumously enfeoff him as "True Man of Cinnabar Prime."

---

**Decrees for the Enfeoffment of Five True Men:**
**Decree:**
We reside in the celestial palace, gazing upon the Terrace of the Azure Dragon, beholding the divine realm of the Three Blossoms and aspiring to the wondrous teachings of the Nine Flowers. Revering the footsteps of the assembled immortals, We illuminate their transformative merit.

To Yang, True Man and Upper Assistant of the Eastern Flower and Director of Destinies: you have delved deeply into learning, exploring the subtle, and aligning your heart with the vast. You have received the hidden instructions of the Central Yellow and the secret transmissions of the Southern Perfected. Governing the lands of Wu and Yue, you oversee the essentials of the divine spirits. As you propagate the supreme Dao, it is fitting to bestow upon you a lofty title. May this reflect Our profound regard and perpetuate the blessings of Our favor.

We hereby enfeoff you as "True Man of Penetrating Spirit and Manifest Transformation."

**Decree:**
The Three Blacks conceal the numinous, defying the measure of names and words; the myriad spirits coalesce in transformation, beyond the reach of analogy. In bestowing honors upon the perfected, We indeed expand the supreme Dao.

To Guo, True Man and Attendant Gentleman of the Jade Terrace: your merit spans the Ten Poles, and your rank resides among the Nine Palaces. Holding the Jade Token of Radiance, you soar through the Great Ultimate; supporting the Morning Canopy of the Eastern Flower, you attend the August Emperor of the Void. As you greatly propagate the fundamental principles, it is fitting to confer upon you a distinguished title. May this reflect Our profound regard and eternally protect Our flourishing enterprise.

We hereby enfeoff you as "True Man of the Great Tenuity and Preserved Radiance."

**Decree:**
We descend to the Jade Realm of the Assembled Perfected, ascending the Dragon Terrace of the Azure Radiance. Here, We examine the records of the primordial shoulder and aid the living in the mortal realm.

The Shangqing True Man and Senior Archivist Xu: outwardly refined and pure, inwardly attaining numinous clarity. As he spreads the Net of Brahmā across the Great Vastness, it is fitting to exalt him with a title of virtue and power. A petition to enfeoff the Five True Ones:
Your servant, in all humility, lays bare his earnest plea, though it may offend the august dignity of the throne. Upon reflection, I recognize my own lowly inadequacy, yet willingly submit to the court’s statutes.

I venture to observe that since antiquity, those who attained the Dao and ascended to True Being have succeeded one another as objects of the age’s reverence, each taking the support of the world and the establishment of the Teaching as their personal duty. After the Three Mao True Lords ascended in flight, there followed Yang, Guo, and the Two Xus. All these Perfected Ones cultivated the Supreme Dao in concentrated refinement at Juqu, where the Heavenly Perfected descended to bestow their regard and personally transmit secret instructions, and the teachings of the Shangqing scriptures gradually spread among humankind. By the time of the Liang and Song dynasties, the True Wind had grown faint and sluggish, yet the sagely Dao remained unbroken, like a sash. Only Master Tao the Recluse strove to uphold the Teaching with subtle words, elucidating the profound purport of the Dao’s essentials, to the fortune of all under heaven in later ages. Yet while the Three Mao brothers were recently honored and ennobled by the court with sacred titles, the remaining Perfected Ones have not, to my knowledge, received any such distinction.

In my foolishness, I humbly beseech Your Sagely Compassion to confer upon the Perfected Ones Yang, Guo, Xu, and Tao—following the precedent of the Three Mao True Lords—augmented and exalted titles in their present immortal offices. A separate memorial will set forth the ranks of the various immortals for Your Majesty’s consideration. Should this petition meet with Your gracious assent, I beg that a sagely edict be issued, directing the relevant authorities to carry it out.

I presumptuously trespass upon Your Celestial Majesty’s awe-inspiring dignity; I await Your command.

chunks.original_text: 宣和六年七月　日，碧落郎凝神殿校藉同知右衔道录院事管辖江宁府玉晨观臣丁安行剖子。 宁宗赐号王景温 王景温履道清尚，操行高洁，眷宠三朝，朕亦礼遇，可赐号虚静真人。 宝庆易如刚先生敕牒 尚书省牒：左右街都道录主管教门公事太一宫都监兼高士易如刚奏，么微野人顷在茅山，於庆元改元，蒙恩召充太一宫高士并都监住持，专任祈梼。 每藉君相，为国爱民，靡不昭格，越今三十余年，褊除道阶。 昨於嘉定六年，蒙恩特赐通妙先生。 续於嘉定十四年，得旨降香设醮茅山。 讫事回奏，乞老还山。 恭奉御笔：高士易如刚祈梼有功，未应告老，宜加显锡以重眷留，特赐通妙葆真先生。 今缴连宁宗皇帝御书二轴，伏望尚书省特颁敕命，旌表名山，以重祈梼。 伏候指挥。 宝庆元年七月十四日，奉圣旨，特令尚＇书省出给敕牒。 奉敕，宜赐通妙葆真先生，牒，至准敕故牒宝庆1 兀年七月日牒。 理宗金录投龙玉简词 维嘉熙元年，岁次丁酉，九月己酉朔，二十六日甲戌，嗣天子臣昀，伏为保延国祚，恭祈嗣续，敬资香信，祇建冲科。 命道士二十一员於建康府元符万宁宫启建灵宝道场一昼二夜，满散设醮三百六十分位，告盟天地，诞集嘉祥。 谨依旧式，诣上清宗坛华阳洞天投送金龙玉简。 伏望至圣至真鉴兹丹捆，乞为誊奏，上闻九天。 臣昀伏以元储虚位，未开态梦之祥，边阐分屯，尚调虎符之戍。 内欲隆於国本，外思靖於兵氛，仰惟祖宗积累之难，探切朝夕继承之惧，是用肆类上帝，褊梼名山。 愿垂覆焘之仁，弘赐扶持之力，得男而应震索，茂延百世之期，偃武而致太平，坐底四方之治，保基图於巩固，措民物於敉宁。 祇近灵休，永依大造。 臣昀无任恳梼之至。 谨言。 加封广济庙龙神诰 敕敷泽广应侯：惟龙质无体而神无方，蚓茅山至人所居，彼其吐吞。 夫丹宠之日月，犹足依凭而为灵乎？ 有司上功，雨旸日时，其御苗也。 实应祭义，申衍侯号，用侈褒章。 金陵，予陪都，其职而幽，以服而侯甸之职，可特封敷泽广应利济侯。 奉敕如右，牒到奉行。 淳佑四年　月　日。
