In the sixth year of the Xuanhe reign, on the ___ day of the seventh month, Ding Anxing, Registrar of the Azure Firmament Bureau, Concurrent Supervisor of the Right Section of the Daoist Registry, and Administrator of the Jade Dawn Abbey in Jiangning Prefecture, respectfully submits this memorial.

**Imperial Grant of Honorific Title to Wang Jingsi**
Wang Jingsi has trodden the Dao with purity and reverence, his conduct lofty and unsullied. Favored across three reigns, We too have extended him due courtesy. Let him be granted the title *True Man of Empty Serenity*.

**Imperial Edict for Master Yi Rugang**
*Memorial from the Ministry of Rites:*
Yi Rugang, Left and Right Street Supervisor of the Daoist Registry, Director of Religious Affairs, Superintendent of the Supreme Unity Palace, and Senior Master, petitions as follows: This humble rustic, once dwelling on Mount Mao, was graciously summoned in the first year of the Qingyuan reign to serve as Senior Master and Superintendent of the Supreme Unity Palace, charged with leading prayers. Through the intercession of lords and ministers, his petitions for state and people have never failed to move the divine, spanning over thirty years—yet his Daoist rank remains unadvanced. In the sixth year of the Jiading reign, he was specially granted the title *Master of Penetrating Mystery*. Later, in the fourteenth year of the same reign, he received an imperial mandate to offer incense and conduct rites on Mount Mao. Upon completion, he memorialized to retire and return to the mountain. We issued an imperial rescript: "Senior Master Yi Rugang has rendered meritorious service in prayer; he shall not retire yet. To honor his devotion, let him be granted the augmented title *Master of Penetrating Mystery and Preserving the True*." Now, he respectfully presents two scrolls of imperial calligraphy bestowed by Emperor Ningzong, beseeching the Ministry of Rites to issue an edict in recognition, thereby ennobling the sacred mountain and enhancing its role in prayer. Awaiting your decree.

On the fourteenth day of the seventh month in the first year of the Baoqing reign, by imperial command, the Ministry of Rites is ordered to issue the edict.
*Edict:* Let Yi Rugang be granted the title *Master of Penetrating Mystery and Preserving the True*. Memorial received and approved. Edict hereby issued on the ___ day of the seventh month in the first year of the Baoqing reign.

**Jade Tablet Inscription for the Golden Register Dragon Offering**
In the first year of the Jiaxi reign, cyclical year *dingyou*, on the twenty-sixth day of the ninth month (the first day being *jiyou*), the filial imperial heir, Your subject Yun, humbly prays for the perpetuation of the state’s destiny and the blessing of an heir. With reverent devotion, he presents incense and conducts the *Chongke* rites. Twenty-one Daoist masters are commanded to perform the *Lingbao* Daoist ritual at the Yuanfu Wanning Abbey in Jiankang Prefecture for one day and two nights, concluding with a grand offering to the Three Hundred and Sixty Divine Positions. Thereby, he petitions Heaven and Earth, invoking auspicious omens. Following ancient precedent, he respectfully deposits a golden dragon and jade tablet at the Hua Yang Grotto-Heaven of the Supreme Clarity Altar. May the Most Sacred and True perceive this sincere offering and deign to transmit it to the Nine Heavens.

Your subject Yun, reflecting that the crown prince’s position remains vacant, with no propitious dream yet manifest, and that border defenses are strained, troops still deployed—within, he seeks to strengthen the state’s foundation; without, he yearns to pacify the scourge of war. Mindful of the arduous accumulation of our ancestral legacy and the pressing fear of succession, he now offers this grand sacrifice to the Supreme Emperor and beseeches the sacred mountains. May they bestow their encompassing benevolence and mighty sustaining power: grant a son to fulfill the *Zhen* and *Suo* omens, extending the dynasty’s line for a hundred generations; still the weapons of war to achieve great peace, securing governance in all four quarters; fortify the foundations of the state and bring tranquility to the people. May we forever draw near to this divine favor and rely upon the great creation.

Your subject Yun, with utmost sincerity, prostrates himself in prayer.

**Edict for the Ennoblement of the Dragon Spirit of the Guangji Temple**
*Edict to the Marquis of Broad Blessings and Responsive Aid:*
The dragon’s essence is formless, its spirit boundless—yet even the humble earthworms of Mount Mao, dwelling place of perfected beings, possess the power to inhale and exhale. How much more, then, should one who has basked in the sun and moon of cinnabar favor become a vessel of numinous efficacy? The authorities have attested to its merits: timely rains and sunshine, the nurturing of crops. Truly, it fulfills the principles of sacrifice. Let its title be expanded and ennobled to enhance its glory. As Jinling is Our auxiliary capital, its duties are profound, its service extending to the domains of the marquis and the royal domain. Let it be specially enfeoffed as the *Marquis of Broad Blessings, Responsive Aid, and Beneficent Salvation*.

By edict as above. Upon receipt, comply accordingly.

chunks.original_text: 无为日道，必刻意缮性而始成； 修身乃真，非积行累功而莫就。 大茅君束岳上卿司命太元妙道冲虚圣佑真君，奇操娇俗，精思集虚，一德斋心，受龟台西华之秘旨，万灵授职，开金陵句曲之宗坛； 丹光千载以如#8新，宝气三峰而弥固，发祥肇祉，民到于今称之，逆雨宁风，天之所助顺也。 直惟作圣，允合佑神； 孔盖翠旌祀，莫严於司命，琼文药简礼，爰举於秩宗。 假兹聪明，佐予平治。 可赐茅山一峰圣佑观，特加封大茅君束岳上卿太元妙道冲虚圣佑真应真君主者施行。 上天眷命，皇帝圣旨：合人心，理万物，礼宜顺於鬼神，建皇极，锡庶民，征有稽於旸雨。 大江以束之地，句曲为望之宗，土乐升平，岁称稔足。 二茅君，定录右禁至道冲静德佑真君，中峰司命，西华炼形； 作牧审烦扰之非，修身得恬担之要； 縿鸾导从，填帘俨奏於云中，化鹤来归，城郭时看於华表。 朕方推仁以济众灵，宜妙物以佑民。 学道受之以神，端有宗於李耳； 望杞不祈其福，诚深慕於汉文。 嘉与含生，诞敷景命。 可赐茅山二峰德佑观，特加封二茅君定录右禁至道冲静德佑妙应真君。 主者施行。 上天眷命，皇帝圣旨：气化为神，握阴阳而执要； 物来能应，遇水旱以成功。 兹山之灵，以氏为号。 三茅君三官保命微妙冲惠仁佑真君，不导引而寿体，纯素为真； 密从苍龙，承左右而无问，时乘白鹊，侍伯仲以远游； 荷天之休，为民请命。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao of non-action is not achieved without deliberate cultivation of one’s nature; true self-cultivation is not attained without the accumulation of deeds and the piling of merits. The Great Lord of Mount Mao, Supreme Minister of the Eastern Marchmount, Director of Destinies, and Perfected Lord of the Wondrous Dao of Primordial Emptiness and Divine Protection—his extraordinary conduct transcended the mundane, his concentrated thought gathered the void, and with undivided virtue he purified his heart. Receiving the secret decree from the Western Flower of the Tortoise Terrace, he was invested by the myriad spirits and established the ancestral altar of Golden Mound at Jurong. His cinnabar radiance has remained ever-new for a thousand years, the precious qi of the Three Peaks ever-firm. Auspicious omens arose, and the people to this day extol him; he summoned rain and calmed winds, for Heaven aids those who act in accord with the Dao. Truly, his sagely virtue aligns with divine protection. No rites are more solemn than those for the Director of Destinies, where jade texts and medicinal writs are offered in due order. Granting him this wisdom, may he assist me in governance.

By imperial decree, let one peak of Mount Mao be bestowed as the Abbey of Sagely Protection, and let the Great Lord of Mount Mao, Supreme Minister of the Eastern Marchmount, be specially enfeoffed as the Perfected Lord of the Wondrous Dao of Primordial Emptiness, Divine Protection, and Sagely Response. Let the responsible officials carry this out.

By the Emperor’s sacred edict, in accordance with Heaven’s cherished mandate: harmonizing the hearts of the people and ordering the myriad things, rites must accord with the spirits; establishing the imperial standard and bestowing blessings upon the common folk, we seek confirmation in timely rains. East of the Great River, Jurong stands as the ancestral seat of reverence. The land rejoices in peace, and the years are marked by abundance.

The Second Lord of Mount Mao, Perfected Lord of the Right Register of Destinies, the Wondrous Dao of Emptiness and Tranquility, and Divine Protection—overseeing the Central Peak as Director of Destinies and refining his form at the Western Flower—discerned the falsity of worldly cares and grasped the essence of serenity in self-cultivation. His feathered banners and simurgh-drawn retinue ascend in solemn procession through the clouds; his transformed crane returns, and the city walls often behold him upon the ornate pillars. As I extend benevolence to aid all spirits, so too should wondrous beings protect the people. Those who study the Dao receive it through the numinous, and none have surpassed Laozi as their ancestral master. Though the Han Emperor Wen did not seek blessings through sacrifices, his sincere reverence was profound. Now, in praise and for the benefit of all living things, I bestow this grand mandate.

By imperial decree, let the second peak of Mount Mao be bestowed as the Abbey of Virtue and Protection, and let the Second Lord of Mount Mao be specially enfeoffed as the Perfected Lord of the Wondrous Dao of Emptiness, Tranquility, Virtue, and Sagely Response. Let the responsible officials carry this out.

By the Emperor’s sacred edict, in accordance with Heaven’s cherished mandate: qi transforms into spirits, grasping the essentials of yin and yang; things respond as they arise, achieving success in times of flood and drought. The numen of this mountain takes its name from its lineage. The Third Lord of Mount Mao, Perfected Lord of the Three Offices, Protector of Life, the Subtle and Wondrous Dao of Primordial Emptiness, and Benevolent Protection—without guiding and pulling, his body attained longevity, for purity alone is true. Secretly following the Azure Dragon, he attends left and right without question; at times he rides the White Magpie, accompanying his elder and younger brothers on distant journeys. Bearing Heaven’s favor, he pleads for the lives of the people.

chunks.original_text: 茅山志卷之四竟 #1省； 原缺，据笪本补。 #2杪：原本作『秒』，据笪本改。 #3乡：原缺，据笪本补。 #4左：原本作『在』，据笪本改。 #5和：原本作『如』，据笪本改。 #6乞封三茅君奏剖：原缺，据笪本补。 #7分：原本作『介』，据笪本改。 #8如：笪本作『维』。 #9第：原作『弟』，据笪本改。 茅山志卷之五 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 三神纪 茅君真冑 大司命君姓茅，讳盈，字叔申，咸阳南关人也。 姬冑分根氏族於茅，积德累仁，祚流百氏。 高祖讳蒙，字初成，一字本初，深识玄远，察览兴亡，知周之衰，不仕诸侯，乃师於北郭北阿鬼谷先生，长往华山，道成以秦始皇三十年九月庚子，乘龙白日升天。 时邑童谣歌日：神仙得者茅初成，驾龙上升入太清。 时下玄洲戏赤城，继世而往在我盈。 帝若学之腊嘉平。 始皇闻之，询诸父老，具封日：此仙人之谣，劝帝求长生之卫。 於是始皇听然有寻仙之志，因改腊日嘉平。 曾祖偃，字泰能，蒙之第四子，仕秦昭王，为舍人，迁车骑校尉长平恭侯。 祖讳宪，字世伦，仕庄襄王，为广信侯。 始皇即位，以为德信侯。 生六子，并知名於时。 其第六子讳祚，字彦英，不仕不学，志慕农桑，生三子，长即大司命君也，次子讳固，字季伟，第三子讳衷，字思和。 司命君生于汉景帝中元五年丙申岁，二弟於戊戌。 庚子岁。 三君少禀异操，天才颖悟，娇志萧抗，独味清虚。 尝谓二弟日：世务纷错，履冰脸职，当慕高祖之逸举，唯愿肥遁之利贞耳。 年十八，弃家辞亲入恒山中，读《道德经》《周易传》，采木服饵，潜景绝崖，积六年。 精思诚感，梦见太玄玉女把玉札而携之日：西城有王君，得真道，可为师，君子奚不往寻而受教乎？ 明晨觉悟，径造西城，心斋三月，沐浴向新，卒见王君驾神虎之饼，控辔神岭，翱翔绣岩。 於是投躯越阻，归命道真，不觉而至君所，王君默使卫官见摄，将还玉宫洞台之中。 良久引进，叩头顿首，求乞长生，匐匍肘行，重陈无已。 王君顾谓左右日：形景空苦，似有志矣。 乃得接引诱问，戒以勿息，遂留洞宫。 执巾履之役者十七年，王君见君谨密，稍使主领衣书图录。 复三年，命驾，造白玉龟山，因担君同诣王母於青琳宫。 母曰：总真挟肉人以登灵台，不亦劳乎？ 王君笑而不答，目君再拜，请乞奇要，乃叩头自陈日：盈小丑贱，生枯骨之余，敢以不肖之躯慕龙凤之年．’朝菌之质求积朔之期，虽仰远流，莫之能济。 常恐一旦死於钻访之难，取笑於世俗之夫。 遭遇王君，一反盈丹苦，粗受冶身之术，岂图今日一睹圣姿？ 恍惚大象，如沦神梦，救生护死，归之乞丐，愿赐长生之要，暂悟行尸之身。 母日：子心至到哉。 吾昔师元始天王搏桑大帝，君遗我要言，所谓玉佩金当之道、太极玄真之经，实天人之殊珍，上帝之奇秘。 汝今日愿闻之耶？ 言毕，劫王君解释玄真之经，自敷玉佩金当之文。 复向说元始天王大帝君，言是太霄二景隐书又有阴阳二景，内真符与本文相随。 太上法，惟令受诸司命。 子玉札玄挺，素书上清，当为上卿之君、司命之任，此道后当别付於子也。 然不先闻明堂玄真之道，亦未由得太霄隐书。 玄真之道，是食日月之法，炼五神之卫耳，非总真弟子，不教司命之挺，不传受命。

**Volume Five of the Mao Shan Gazetteer**
*Composed by Liu Dabin, Hereditary Master of the Supreme Clarity Tradition*

**Records of the Three Divine Ones**
**The True Lineage of the Mao Lords**

The Great Lord of the Controller of Destinies bore the surname Mao, personal name Ying, and style Shushen. He was a native of Nanguan in Xianyang.

The Mao clan traced its roots to the Ji lineage, its virtue and benevolence accumulating across generations, its blessings flowing through a hundred families. His great-grandfather, named Meng, styled Chucheng and also Benchu, possessed profound insight into the mysterious and distant. Discerning the rise and fall of dynasties, he foresaw the decline of Zhou and refused office under the feudal lords. Instead, he became a disciple of Master Guigu of Beiguo and Bei’e, retiring to Mount Hua. There, he attained the Dao and ascended to heaven in broad daylight, riding a dragon, in the thirtieth year of the First Emperor of Qin, on the gengzi day of the ninth month.

At the time, a children’s rhyme in the village sang:
*"The immortal attained is Mao Chucheng,*
*Riding a dragon to ascend into the Great Clarity.*
*Now on the Dark Continent, he sports in Crimson City,*
*And in succession, one after me, shall be Ying.*
*Should the Emperor learn this, let the twelfth month be renamed Jiaoping."*

Upon hearing this, the First Emperor inquired of the village elders, who explained: "This is the song of immortals, exhorting the Emperor to seek the safeguard of longevity." Thereupon, the First Emperor, stirred to action, resolved to seek immortals and renamed the twelfth month *Jiaoping*.

His great-grandfather, Yan, styled Taineng, was the fourth son of Meng. He served King Zhao of Qin as a retainer and was later promoted to Colonel of Chariots and Cavalry, enfeoffed as the Reverent Marquis of Changping. His grandfather, named Xian, styled Shilun, served King Zhuangxiang of Qin as the Marquis of Guangxin. When the First Emperor ascended the throne, he was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Dexin. He fathered six sons, all renowned in their time. His sixth son, named Zuo, styled Yanying, neither served in office nor pursued scholarship, but aspired to farming and sericulture. He had three sons: the eldest was the Great Lord of the Controller of Destinies; the second, named Gu, styled Jiwei; and the third, named Zhong, styled Sihe.

The Lord of the Controller of Destinies was born in the fifth year of the *zhongyuan* era of Emperor Jing of Han, a *bingshen* year, while his two younger brothers were born in *wuxu* and *gengzi* years, respectively. From youth, the three brothers were endowed with extraordinary conduct, their natural talents keen and perceptive. They held themselves aloof from worldly affairs, delighting solely in purity and emptiness. Once, the Lord of the Controller of Destinies said to his brothers: "Worldly affairs are tangled and perilous, like treading on thin ice. We should emulate the lofty retreat of the High Ancestor, aspiring only to the steadfast integrity of reclusion."

At the age of eighteen, he left home and bid farewell to his parents, entering the mountains of Heng. There, he studied the *Dao De Jing* and the *Commentaries on the Zhouyi*, gathered herbs, and consumed elixirs. He concealed his radiance in the cliffs, practicing for six years. His concentrated devotion moved the divine, and in a dream, he saw the Jade Maiden of the Great Mystery holding a jade tablet, leading him and saying: "In the Western City dwells Lord Wang, who has attained the true Dao. Why not seek him out and receive his teachings?"

Awakening at dawn, he journeyed directly to the Western City. After three months of fasting and purification, he suddenly beheld Lord Wang, riding a divine tiger and guiding its reins along the sacred ridge, soaring above the embroidered crags. Thereupon, he cast himself over obstacles, surrendering his life to the true Dao. Unaware, he arrived at Lord Wang’s abode. Lord Wang silently dispatched his attendants to escort him, bringing him to the Jade Terrace within the Tower of Flowing Efflorescence. After a long while, he was led forward. Kneeling and knocking his head to the ground, he begged for the gift of longevity, prostrating himself and repeating his entreaties without cease.

Lord Wang glanced at his attendants and said: "His form and spirit have endured hardship; it seems he is truly resolved." Thereupon, he was guided and instructed, warned never to slacken, and was retained in the Grotto Palace. For seventeen years, he served as an attendant, handling robes and sandals. Seeing his diligence and discretion, Lord Wang gradually entrusted him with managing the records of garments and scriptures. After another three years, Lord Wang commanded his carriage and traveled to White Jade Turtle Mountain, taking the Lord of the Controller of Destinies with him to visit the Queen Mother in the Azure Forest Palace.

The Queen Mother said: "To bring a mortal clad in flesh to the Numinous Terrace—is this not laborious?" Lord Wang smiled but did not answer. The Queen Mother turned to the Lord of the Controller of Destinies, who bowed twice and begged for esoteric essentials. Knocking his head to the ground, he pleaded: "I, Ying, am a lowly and base creature, born of withered bones. How dare I, with this unworthy body, aspire to the years of dragons and phoenixes? With the substance of a morning mushroom, I seek the span of accumulated moons. Though I gaze toward the distant stream, none can aid me. I constantly fear that one day I shall perish in the trials of seeking, becoming a laughingstock to the vulgar. Having encountered Lord Wang, my bitter cinnabar has been transformed, and I have roughly received the arts of refining the body. Who could have imagined that today I would behold your sacred countenance? In a daze, I see the great image, as if submerged in a divine dream. To save the living and protect the dead, I come as a beggar, beseeching the gift of the essentials of longevity, to briefly awaken this walking corpse."

The Queen Mother said: "Your heart is truly sincere. Long ago, I studied under the Celestial King of Primordial Beginning and the Great Emperor of Fusang. He bequeathed to me essential teachings: the *Dao of Jade Pendants and Golden Perfection*, the *Scripture of the Supreme Mystery and the Dark Truth*—truly the rare treasures of heaven and humanity, the wondrous secrets of the Celestial Thearch. Do you wish to hear them today?"

Having spoken, she urged Lord Wang to expound the *Scripture of the Dark Truth* and personally recited the *Text of Jade Pendants and Golden Perfection*. Then, she spoke of the Celestial King of Primordial Beginning and the Great Emperor Lord, saying: "This is the *Hidden Book of the Two Radiant Ones of the Grand Empyrean*. There are also the *Two Radiant Ones of Yin and Yang*, the *Inner True Talismans*, and the original texts that accompany them. By the law of the Most High, only those appointed as Controllers of Destinies may receive them. You, with your jade tablet and dark potency, inscribed with the script of the Supreme Clarity, are destined to become a Lord of the Upper Ministers and assume the office of Controller of Destinies. This Dao shall later be separately transmitted to you. However, without first learning the *Dao of the Dark Truth of the Hall of Light*, you cannot obtain the *Hidden Book of the Grand Empyrean*. The *Dao of the Dark Truth* is the method of consuming the sun and moon, the safeguard of refining the five spirits. It is not taught to disciples of the Total Perfection, nor is the potency of the Controller of Destinies transmitted to those without a mandate."

chunks.original_text: 言讫，王君与君还西城，依承真诀，按而行之。 三年，目有神光，面生玉泽。 王君赐九转还丹一剂、神方一首，立坛结誓，不许宣泄，乃使君归，仍告之曰：子道已成，后百年求我於南岳，授子仙任於昊越矣。 君既辞师，带索混迩，不娇於世，自说入怛山北谷学儒俗之业。 时年四十九，君父母尚存，父见怒曰：为子不孝，不亲供养，游走四方，吾当喻汝为不生之子。 欲杖罚之，君长跪谢日：盈受命，应当得道，道法遁世。 事不两济，虽违远供养，无旦夕之益，能使家门平安，父母老寿。 盈已受圣师符录见营助者，天丁之兵不可打击，恐三官考察，非小故也。 父意未释，亦欲验君情状，示众不惑，於是举杖向君，杖即摧折，段段飞扬，穿柱陷壁。 父悟不凡，乃止君日：所启正虑如此，邂逅中人即有所伤耳。 父又日：子言得道，能起死人否？ 封日：人有天禄终及，积恶罪重者不可更生，其横受夭折，则可令起。 君乃召社公，父闻，在中庭问社公日：此村中已死者，谁可召还？ 社公答云：某甲李乙。 君日：速约敕所关，由使发遣之，须事了诣来白状。 至日入后，社公来白事，某甲李乙事已决了，便可发出。 遂告死者家人掘地发棺，死人气息但不能语，举而出之，三日能坐语言，了了如是。 发数人冢，皆遂生活，更数十岁乃复死耳，远近咸称为神明之君。 后日，贵盛诸侯互有所请，君拥闭神关，塞妙杜验，告之曰：我昔学道，精思深山，山灵附我，因协以驱使之耳，非己自达其神，能死生於万物也。 或迫之不已，君亦佯自笃病，以至於始矣。 渊池括囊，变适无沦。 时人虽奇其有道，亦不能测其有为也。 后十余年，君父母寿考而终，居丧尽礼，停家凡五十三年。
chunks.translated_text:
Having spoken thus, the Perfected King and the Master returned to the Western City, where they followed the true instructions and practiced accordingly. After three years, the Master’s eyes gleamed with divine radiance, and his face took on the luster of jade. The Perfected King then bestowed upon him a dose of the Nine-Turned Returning Elixir and a sacred formula, setting up an altar to swear an oath of secrecy. Forbidding any disclosure, he sent the Master away, saying: "Your Dao is now accomplished. A hundred years hence, seek me at the Southern Marchmount, where I shall confer upon you an immortal office in the realm of Haoyue."

After taking leave of his teacher, the Master wandered the world in humble guise, unadorned by worldly pretensions. He claimed to have entered the northern valley of Mount Da to study the arts of the Confucian and common schools. At the time, he was forty-nine years old, and his parents were still living. His father, enraged upon seeing him, said: "As a son, you are unfilial—abandoning your duty to care for us while roaming far and wide. I shall disown you as if you were never born." He sought to punish him with a staff, but the Master knelt and pleaded: "I have received a mandate to attain the Dao, and the Dao’s way is to withdraw from the world. One cannot serve both paths at once. Though I am far from your daily care, I bring peace to our household and longevity to my parents. I have already received the talismans and registers of a sacred teacher, and the soldiers of the Heavenly Cadets cannot strike me. Should you harm me, the Three Offices will investigate—this is no trifling matter."

His father’s anger remained unappeased, and he wished to test the Master’s claims before others to dispel doubt. Raising his staff to strike, the staff shattered into fragments, which flew about, piercing pillars and embedding in walls. His father, realizing the Master was no ordinary man, ceased and said: "What you say is true, but if you had struck an ordinary person, they would have been injured." He then asked: "If you have attained the Dao, can you revive the dead?" The Master replied: "Those whose heavenly allotment is exhausted or whose sins are grave cannot be restored. Only those who died untimely may be revived."

The Master then summoned the Earth God. His father, standing in the central courtyard, asked the Earth God: "Among the dead in this village, who can be called back?" The Earth God replied: "So-and-so Li Yi." The Master said: "Hasten to command the relevant authorities to dispatch him. Once the matter is settled, report back." After sunset, the Earth God returned and announced: "The matter of So-and-so Li Yi has been resolved; he may now be released." The Master then instructed the deceased’s family to dig up the grave and open the coffin. The dead man showed signs of breath but could not speak. Lifted from the coffin, he sat up and spoke clearly after three days. Several graves were opened, and all the dead revived, living for decades more before dying again. Near and far, people hailed the Master as a divine sage.

Later, powerful nobles and feudal lords sought his favors, but the Master sealed his spiritual gates and blocked his wondrous powers, telling them: "When I first studied the Dao, I meditated deeply in the mountains, and the mountain spirits aided me, enabling me to command them. It is not that I myself have attained such divine mastery as to control life and death over all things." When pressed relentlessly, he feigned severe illness, even to the point of near-death.

He concealed his depths, adapting to circumstances without constraint. Though people marveled at his attainment of the Dao, none could fathom his true actions. More than ten years later, his parents lived to a ripe old age before passing away. The Master observed mourning rites in full, remaining at home for fifty-three years in all.

chunks.original_text: 仲弟即定录君，汉景帝时察孝廉，元朔元年举贤良，拜五官郎，正和二年转太子太傅，元凤元年，拜破胡校尉武威太守。 季弟即保命君，少以节行着名，隐华阴山，武帝建元三年举方正不就，徙梁国，为孝王上宾，宣帝地节二年，迁洛阳令，转拜西城校尉上郡太守。 元帝即位，拜五更大夫，转西河太守，仲弟时为执金吾，并当之官，乡里父老少长祖送者数百人。 君亦在坐对宾日：吾虽不作二千石卿相，亦当有神灵之职。 天帝见选补束岳上卿震林司命君，总统昊越死生之籍，领拔学道，试校旱仙，此亦上真宗师神宫之要位也。 来年四月三日，当升举。 诸君能来顾如今日否？ 若见省者，亦不须有所损费，吾自当有以相供待也。 众宾皆相然。 至期，君门前数顷地忽自平，治青缣帐屋，屋下铺白毡数重，容数百人坐。 远近相语，此家得道当去。 小大并集，来者塞道，客乃数倍於送弟时。 但见金盘玉杯、奇肴珍果自至人前，光景翕赫，不可名状。 丝竹金石，声动天地、芳香之气，达于数里。 饮食随益，六百余人莫不醉饱。 明日，迎官来至，君乃与家辞，次语宗族子弟日：夫真仙道隐，贵在边翳，不应表光曲饰、动耀视听。 吾所以不得默遁藏景、潜举空同者，盖欲以此道诱劝二弟之追慕也，亦何但固、衷之反迷耶？ 天下有心者，尽当注向神仙之冀获耳。 季伟、思和虽见事，晚必能自悔，释官委禄来寻於我。 我今此去，权停江水之束、句曲之山，此山内有灵府，众洞相通，穴岫长连，真洞仙馆也。 昔与圣师期，宜先於此以自清励，恭伺天命，然后镇彼大霍，居于赤城矣。 言毕周辞，即登羽车，参驾龙虎，浮空而去。 东行十余里，忽然不见。
chunks.translated_text:
The second brother was known as the Lord of Fixed Record. During the reign of Emperor Jing of Han, he was recommended as a Filial and Incorrupt candidate, and in the first year of the Yuanshuo era, he was nominated as a Worthy and Good man. He was appointed Gentleman of the Five Offices, and in the second year of the Zhenghe era, he was promoted to Grand Tutor to the Crown Prince. In the first year of the Yuanfeng era, he was appointed Commandant Breaker of the Hu and Governor of Wuwei.

The youngest brother was known as the Lord of Preserving Life. From youth, he was renowned for his integrity and conduct. He withdrew to Mount Huayin, and in the third year of the Jianyuan era of Emperor Wu, he was recommended as a Square and Upright candidate but declined. He moved to Liang State and became an honored guest of the Filial King. In the second year of the Dijie era of Emperor Xuan, he was appointed Magistrate of Luoyang, then promoted to Commandant of the Western Regions and Governor of Shangjun.

When Emperor Yuan ascended the throne, the youngest brother was appointed Grand Master of the Five Elders and later transferred to serve as Governor of Xihe. At that time, the second brother was serving as Commandant of the Capital. As they both prepared to assume their posts, elders and youths from their hometown—several hundred in all—gathered to see them off. The Master was also present, addressing the guests: "Though I have not served as a high minister with a salary of two thousand *shi*, I shall hold a divine office. The Heavenly Emperor has chosen me to fill the position of Supreme Minister of the Eastern Peak, Lord of the Forest of Thunder, and Controller of Life and Death, overseeing the registers of life and death in the realms of Wu and Yue. I shall also supervise the selection of those who study the Dao, testing and verifying those who attain early transcendence. This is indeed a key position among the highest immortals and the divine palace’s ancestral masters."

"On the third day of the fourth month next year, I shall ascend. Will any of you be able to visit me as you do today? If you come, there will be no need for any expense—I shall provide for you myself." The guests all agreed.

When the appointed day arrived, several *qing* of land before the Master’s gate suddenly leveled themselves. A canopy of green silk was erected, beneath which layers of white felt were spread, enough to seat hundreds. Word spread far and near that this family’s master had attained the Dao and was about to depart. Young and old gathered in throngs, filling the roads, their numbers far exceeding those who had come to see off his brothers. Golden platters and jade cups, rare delicacies and precious fruits appeared before the guests of their own accord. The radiance was dazzling, beyond description. Strings and winds, bells and chimes resounded through heaven and earth, while fragrant aromas carried for miles. As the feast flowed on, all six hundred guests drank and ate their fill.

The next day, when the welcoming officials arrived, the Master bid farewell to his family, then addressed his clansmen and disciples: "The true path of immortality is hidden, prizing obscurity over ostentation. One should not seek to display brilliance or adorn oneself with false embellishments to dazzle the eyes and ears. The reason I could not silently withdraw, conceal my light, and ascend unseen from the empty peaks was to use this path to inspire and encourage my brothers’ pursuit of the Dao. How could I alone have been so deluded as to turn back? All under heaven with a seeking heart should turn their gaze toward the hope of attaining divine transcendence. Though Jiwei and Sihe have seen this, they will surely repent in time, resign their offices, abandon their salaries, and come to seek me."

"For now, I shall pause at the eastern banks of the Jiang River, on Mount Juqu. Within this mountain lies a numinous abode, where countless caverns interconnect, their grottoes stretching endlessly—a true immortal’s sanctuary. Long ago, I made a vow with my sacred teacher to first purify and discipline myself here, reverently awaiting heaven’s decree. Only afterward shall I ascend to the great Huo Peak and dwell upon the Red City."

Having spoken, he bid farewell to all, then mounted a feathered carriage, drawn by dragons and tigers. Rising into the void, he departed. After traveling eastward for over ten *li*, he suddenly vanished from sight.

chunks.original_text: 时元帝初元五年丁丑，君年一百二岁矣。 遂过江暂治句曲，内游洞官、推拔真仙外，立茅舍於山之北，即今下泊官是。 领统地官属籍，关决生死。 黑虎驯卫，白鹄交往，灵着江左，道惠百邑，昊越之境竞为臣仆，邦人因改名此山为茅君山。 二弟在官，闻兄白日神仙着於民口，始信仙化可学，神灵可致，然后明松乔不虚，鼎湖有实耳。 於是各弃官还家，以日仄之年修糟粕遗事，未有补益，乃相谓日：家兄得道，非他人也，何不往从，亲禀口诀而乃按云云，方书以规度世乎？ 纵往而不达终，不使吾等死於非所。 遂以元帝永元五年壬午三月六日度江，求兄於束山相见，悲听流涕。 君告二弟日：悟何晚矣？ 二弟谢日：固衷顽下，不达道德，流湎风尘，希世臭味，垂缨汉朝。 阖门完全，位至守相，享年寿考，皆兄神佑覆护之恩。 蒙荫以来，日用不觉，一旦失兄，若无天地。 人非金石，命当有尽，年已朽仄，常虑奄忽，呼吸寄生，不朝则夕。 昔日归家，修兄遗事，不受真诀，未获其效。 越江来侍，规禀训诲，愿赐长生，济弟无死。 君日：卿已老矣，难可补复。 纵得真诀，适可成地上仙耳。 上清升霄大术，非老夫所学於是教。 二弟服青芽始生咽气液之道，亦停年不死之法也。 后语季伟日：卿宜服黄帝四扇散，我昔受之於高丘先生，今以相传耳。 又语思和日：卿宜服王母回童散，思和体中损少於季伟，故宜服此，以填精补脑耳。 夫此二方，皆妙法也。 二弟具受教劝，乃服药咽气，勤精静思，又施行诸为生生之戒慎者，如是十八年，色如处子。 君曰：药已行矣。 乃受以上道，使存明堂玄真之气，以摄运生精，理和魂神。 三年之中，神光始现。 君又各赐九转还丹一剂，神方一首，仙道成矣。 君乃启王君，自陈二弟蒙天恩济度，得为地仙。 仙法，要当佩录受策，带真极之符，然后书署处官，掌领所司，乞愿推恩，平其覆盖。 王君日：子少学道德，勤心不懈。 吾悯汝至志，是以相成，坚心关奏，为子保举之主，太上垂许，赐命神仙。 二弟赖卿荫佑，享年富贵，骄淫败气，止存视息，年出一百，非复学道时也。 得神散、灵方，变化久视足矣，诅宜便受职署，为地上之仙位乎？ 且旷古以来，兄弟俱仙亦为少矣。 然子高祖得道，仁加万物，积德所及，乃锺子身。 慈心仁和，每修阴功，诚可愍也。 子屡请乞二弟仙官之职，今重赐玄水玉液丹，可使长斋而服之。 慎他宣示，别宜关启太帝，而保效之信，子当自将以来。 于时二弟虽内通神灵，外摄六丁，至於天真大神，如王君之俦，犹未肯降见，明高卑不伦矣。 君使二弟清斋服药食芝毕，复相与心斋三月。 诣青童方诸宫，书名金简，次诣西城洞官，朝见总真上宰，南诣衡山朱台，谒太虚赤真人，归方诸，请地仙三真之策，造赤城，受真变神符，又之罗霍，求华旌绣幡，乃上登九宫诣金阙，受圣君之书，顿首於阙下者三月。 圣君乃命九微太真上相王大司命，高晨师青童君，使上诣太上大道君、协晨宫中请朱官使者，下拜固、衷於金阙下。 须臾，使者二人及侍从数千人俱。 使者手授紫素之书，以付固、衷。 紫素策文，二见诰副墨篇。 受书讫，君劫二弟辞，还所治，是以季伟有地真上仙定录神君之号，思和有司三官保命仙君之位焉。
chunks.translated_text:
In the fifth year of Emperor Yuan’s *Chuyuan* reign, the *ding-chou* year, the Master was one hundred and two years of age. He crossed the Jiang River and temporarily settled on Mount Juqu, where he explored the grotto-palaces within, selecting true immortals for advancement. On the mountain’s northern slope, he built a thatched hut—now known as the Lower Lodge. There, he took charge of the earthly registers, determining life and death. Black tigers served as his guardians, white cranes came and went, and his numinous presence shone across the lands east of the Jiang. His Dao and virtue spread through a hundred towns, and the people of Wu and Yue vied to become his servants. Thus, the mountain was renamed Mount Maojun in his honor.

His two younger brothers, still in office, heard the people speak of their elder brother ascending to immortality in broad daylight. Only then did they believe that transcendence could be learned and the divine attained, realizing that the legends of Master Red Pine and Wang Qiao were no empty tales, and that the cauldron at Mount Dinghu held truth. They resigned their posts, returned home, and in their twilight years, sought to follow the Master’s abandoned practices—but to no avail. They said to one another: "Our elder brother has attained the Dao; he is no stranger. Why not seek him out, receive his oral instructions in person, and follow the methods in the esoteric texts to guide the world? Even if we fail to reach the end, at least we will not die in vain."

In the fifth year of Emperor Yuan’s *Yongyuan* reign, the *ren-wu* year, on the sixth day of the third month, they crossed the Jiang River to find their brother on the eastern mountain. Overcome with sorrow, they wept as they listened. The Master said to them: "Why have you awakened so late?" His brothers replied: "We were foolish and dull, blind to the Dao and virtue, lost in the dust of the world, chasing its fleeting pleasures, and serving the Han court. Our families remained intact, our ranks reached governor and minister, and our long lives were all due to your divine protection. Sheltered under your grace, we lived without awareness—until you left, and it was as if heaven and earth had vanished. We are not made of metal or stone; our lives must end. Now, in our decaying years, we fear death may come at any moment, our breath lingering but a morning or evening away. When we returned home, we tried to follow your abandoned practices but received no true instructions and saw no results. Now we have crossed the river to serve you, hoping to receive your teachings. Grant us long life and deliver us from death."

The Master said: "You are already old; it will be difficult to restore you. Even if you receive the true instructions, you may only become earthbound immortals. The great arts of ascending to the Upper Clarity and soaring through the heavens are not what I have studied." Thus, he taught them the Way of swallowing the first sprouts of green herbs and the fluid of *qi*—a method to prolong life without death. Later, he told Jiwei: "You should take the *Four-Fan Powder of the Yellow Emperor*, which I once received from Master Gaoqiu and now pass on to you." To Sihe, he said: "You should take the *Queen Mother’s Rejuvenation Powder*. Your constitution is less depleted than Jiwei’s, so this will replenish your essence and nourish your brain." Both formulas were wondrous methods.

The two brothers diligently followed his teachings, taking the medicines, swallowing *qi*, and cultivating stillness and concentration. They also practiced all the precepts for preserving life. After eighteen years, their complexions became like those of youths. The Master said: "The medicines have taken effect." He then transmitted the higher Dao, teaching them to visualize the *qi* of the Mysterious True within the Hall of Light, to refine and circulate their generative essence, and to harmonize their souls and spirits. After three years, their divine radiance began to manifest. The Master then bestowed upon each a dose of *Ninefold Cyclically Transformed Elixir* and a sacred formula. Thus, their immortal Way was accomplished.

The Master then petitioned Lord Wang, stating that his two brothers had received heavenly grace and deliverance, becoming earthbound immortals. According to immortal law, they were to receive registers, talismans, and official appointments, taking charge of their respective domains. He requested that their protection be extended. Lord Wang replied: "You have studied the Dao from a young age and never wavered in diligence. I pity your steadfast resolve and have thus aided you. Having firmly submitted your petition, I will serve as your guarantor before the Supreme. The Most High has granted permission, bestowing upon them the mandate of divine immortals. Your brothers, sheltered under your grace, enjoyed wealth and nobility, but their indulgence and dissipation depleted their *qi*. They linger only in breath, now over a hundred years old—no longer the time to learn the Dao. Receiving divine powders and sacred formulas, they may transform and prolong their lives; is this not enough? Should they not simply accept their positions as earthbound immortals? Moreover, since ancient times, brothers attaining immortality together has been rare. Yet your great-grandfather attained the Dao, his benevolence extending to all things. The virtue he accumulated has now manifested in you. Your compassion and kindness, your constant practice of hidden merits—these are truly pitiable. You have repeatedly petitioned for your brothers’ immortal offices. Now, I bestow upon them the *Elixir of Jade Fluid from Mystic Water*. Let them fast and take it. Be cautious not to reveal it to others. You must separately petition the Supreme Emperor and vouch for their efficacy. You shall bring them yourself."

At that time, though the two brothers had inwardly connected with the divine and outwardly commanded the Six *Ding* spirits, they had not yet been deemed worthy of an audience with the great celestial perfected, such as Lord Wang, for their status was unequal. The Master instructed his brothers to purify themselves, take the elixir, and consume the sacred fungus, then together perform a three-month fast of the heart. They journeyed to the Palace of the Azure Lad and the Square Cauldron, inscribing their names on golden tablets. Next, they went to the Grotto-Palace of the Western City to pay homage to the Prime Minister of the Assembly of Perfected. Traveling south to the Vermilion Terrace on Mount Heng, they visited the Perfected of the Great Void and the Red One, then returned to the Palace of the Square Cauldron to request the registers of the Three Perfected of Earthly Immortality. They proceeded to the Red City to receive the talismans of true transformation and spirit, then to Mount Luohuo to seek embroidered banners. Finally, they ascended to the Nine Palaces, journeyed to the Golden Portal, and received the scriptures of the Sacred Lord, prostrating themselves at the portal for three months.

The Sacred Lord then commanded the Supreme Minister of the Nine Radiant Perfected, Lord Wang the Grand Director of Destinies, and the Azure Lad, Master of the Lofty Dawn, to ascend to the Palace of the Great Dao of the Supreme and the Hall of Harmonious Dawn. There, they petitioned the Vermilion Palace Envoys to descend and bow before the Golden Portal, presenting their petitions. In an instant, two envoys arrived with thousands of attendants. The envoys handed over the purple silk scriptures to Gu and Zhong. The purple silk registers contained two imperial edicts and supplementary documents. After receiving the scriptures, the Master urged his brothers to take their leave and return to their domains. Thus, Jiwei was granted the title *Perfected of the Earthly True and Divine Lord of the Register of Destinies*, while Sihe was appointed *Immortal Lord of the Three Offices, Preserver of Life*.

erconnect, their grottoes stretching endlessly—a true immortal’s sanctuary. Long ago, I made a vow with my sacred teacher to first purify and discipline myself here, reverently awaiting heaven’s decree. Only afterward shall I ascend to the great Huo Peak and dwell upon the Red City."

Having spoken, he bid farewell to all, then mounted a feathered carriage, drawn by dragons and tigers. Rising into the void, he departed. After traveling eastward for over ten *li*, he suddenly vanished from sight.

chunks.original_text: 各依紫素之命封莅所治，神宫上府亦随事而资给於二君矣。 大司命君住句曲四十三年，至哀帝元寿二年庚申岁，年一百四十有五。 是岁八月十八日己酉，南岳赤真人、西城王君、龟山王母、方诸青童君同造君于山中。 时天皇大帝遣逸域宫绣衣使者，授君以神玺，玉章。 太微天帝君遣三天左宫直御，赐八龙锦舆、紫羽华衣。 太上大道君遣协晨大夫，赐金虎真符、流金之铃。 金阙圣君命太极真人使正一上玄玉郎，赐以四节、燕胎、流明神芝，长曜灵飞夜光洞草，使拜而食之。 佩玺服衣、正冠北首、带符握铃毕，使者告君日，食太极四节隐芝者，位为真卿。 食金阙燕胎玉芝者，位为司命。 食束官流明金英，则有司录之任。 食长曜灵飞夜光洞草，则当为真伯，兼主总左右御史之任。 子今日尽食之矣，寿同天地，位为司命上真东岳卿君，都统昊越之神灵，总帅江左之山元也。 言毕，使者各去。 须臾，五帝君各乘方面色车，从官来下，衔大帝之命，授君九锡册文，九锡文见诰副墨篇位为司命束卿上真君，文以紫玉为版，黄金刻之。 君伏受书署，再拜毕，灵官上真五帝各去。 唯师王君、西王母留后，为君大设天厨，王母命诸侍女作乐，复歌玄云之曲曰：大象虽云寥，我把九天户。 披云泛八景，鲦忽适下土。 空同口玄音，至灵不容冷。 大帝□□□，□悟风尘苦，颐神三元中，纳精玉阙下。 遂乘万龙桩，落凤盼九野。 又曰玄圃遏北台，五城焕嵯峨。 启彼无涯津，泛此织女河。 仰上升绛庭，下游日窟阿。 顾盼八落外，指点九空遐。 忽已不觉劳，岂悟少与多。 抚墩命众女，空遐忽已和。 妙畅自然同，是为玄云歌。 灵韶肆天韵，真音辞无邪。 歌讫良久，俱诣二君之宫。 二君顿首奉迎，北面称小臣之敬。 王母告之日：汝道虽成，所闻未足。 我当为汝二人有所要以受汝於此矣。 须臾，遣侍女郭密香与上元夫人相闻，二君亦不知上元夫人是何神也。 云：西龟九灵太真王夫人。 敬谢，但不相见，已千余年，天事劳我，致以愆面。 茅固、衷道成，适来视之。 久不向人问，主客对坐，邑邑不乐。 夫人能暂来否？ 答能屈驾，当停相须，侍女既去，少顷而返。 上元夫人亦遣侍女答相闻云：阿环再拜，上问起居，远隔绛河，扰以官事，仰恋光润，情系无遗。 密香至承降尊茅固、衷处，闻命之际，登当整驾，先被太帝君劫，使诣希林，枝定三元录，正尔暂往，如是当还，遂便束带，愿暂小留。 二君因问王母不审上元夫人为何真也？ 王母日：三天真皇之母，上元之高真，统领十方玉女之名录也。 当二时许，上元夫人生来时，闻云空之中箫鼓之音，龙马之呜也。 既至，从官数千人，皆女子，年齐十六七许，形容明逸，多服青绫纹衣，光采耀目。 夫人年可十八九，灵仪绝整，服赤霜之袍，披青毛锦裘，头作三角髻，散余发至腰，载九晨耀日之冠，带六出火玉之佩，腰凤文琳华之绶，佩流黄辉精之剑。 入室，向王母拜，王母止之，呼与同坐。 北向上元夫人设厨，乃不异王母所设。 王君劫二君再拜，自陈日：固、衷受性顽鄙，生长浊乱，面墙不启，无闻道真。 然贪生畏死，宗奉师元。 今日成拔，此乃天愿，唯垂衷告。

Each proceeded to their domains in accordance with the commands inscribed on the purple silk. The divine palaces and upper bureaus also allocated resources to the two lords as required.

The Director of Destinies resided on Mount Gouqu for forty-three years. In the second year of Emperor Ai’s *Yuanshou* reign, the *gengshen* year, he reached the age of one hundred and forty-five. On the eighteenth day of the eighth month of that year, the *jiyou* day, the Vermilion Perfected of the Southern Marchmount, the Lord of Western City, the Queen Mother of Mount Gui, and the Azure Lad of Fangzhu together visited him in the mountains.

At that time, the Celestial August Emperor dispatched envoys from the Brocade Garment Court of the Unbounded Realm to bestow upon him a divine seal and jade tablets. The Lord Emperor of the Grand Tenuous Heaven sent the Left Palace Attendants of the Three Heavens to present him with an eight-dragon brocade palanquin and a robe of purple feathers adorned with floral patterns. The Supreme Lord of the Great Dao sent the Grand Master of Harmonious Dawn to confer upon him the True Talisman of the Golden Tiger and a bell of flowing gold. The Sage Lord of the Golden Portal commanded the Perfected of the Grand Ultimate to dispatch the Jade Gentleman of the Supreme Mystery of the Orthodox Unity, gifting him the Four Nodes, Swallow’s Embryo, Luminous Flowing Gold Essence, the Radiant Divine Mushroom of Everlasting Brilliance, and the Night-Glowing Cave Herb. He was instructed to bow and consume them.

After fastening the seal, donning the robe, straightening his cap to face north, and securing the talisman and bell, the envoys addressed him, saying: "He who consumes the Four Nodes and the Hidden Mushroom of the Grand Ultimate shall be ranked as a True Minister. He who consumes the Jade Mushroom of the Swallow’s Embryo from the Golden Portal shall be ranked as a Director of Destinies. He who consumes the Luminous Golden Essence of the Eastern Palace shall hold the office of Registrar. He who consumes the Night-Glowing Cave Herb of Everlasting Brilliance shall become a True Earl, concurrently assuming the duties of Chief Inspector of the Left and Right."

"You have today consumed all of these. Your lifespan shall be as enduring as heaven and earth, and your rank shall be that of *Supreme Perfected of the Eastern Marchmount, Director of Destinies, and Minister of the East*, overseeing the divine spirits of Wu and Yue and commanding the mountain origins of the lands east of the Jiang."

Upon concluding their words, the envoys departed. In an instant, the Lords of the Five Thearchs each arrived in chariots of directional hues, accompanied by their retinues, bearing the mandate of the Great Emperor to present him with the Nine Bestowments and their supplementary documents. The Nine Bestowments were inscribed on tablets of purple jade, engraved with yellow gold, appointing him as *Supreme Perfected of the Eastern Minister, Director of Destinies*. He prostrated himself to receive the documents, bowed twice, and the divine officials and Perfected of the Five Thearchs departed. Only the Master Lord Wang and the Queen Mother of the West remained to host a grand celestial banquet for him. The Queen Mother commanded her attendants to perform music and sing the *Song of the Mystic Clouds*:

*"Though the Great Image seems vast and void,
I grasp the gates of the Nine Heavens.
Parting the clouds, I drift through the Eight Sceneries,
Swiftly descending to the lower earth.
The hollow echo of the Mystic Sound,
The Supreme Spirit brooks no chill.
The Great Emperor...*
*...awakens to the toils of wind and dust,
Nurturing the spirit within the Three Origins,
Absorbing essence beneath the Jade Portal.
Then riding the myriad-dragon post,
Descending with the phoenix’s gaze upon the Nine Wilds."*

Another verse followed:
*"The Mystic Garden bars the Northern Terrace,
Five Cities gleam in towering splendor.
Unlocking the boundless ford,
Floating upon the Weaving Maid’s River.
Above, ascending the Crimson Court,
Below, roaming the sun’s hidden vale.
Gazing beyond the Eight Desolations,
Pointing toward the Nine Voids afar.
Suddenly, weariness is unfelt,
How could one know little or much?
Summoning the maidens with a touch,
The distant voids harmonize in an instant.
Exquisitely attuned to nature’s accord,
This is the Song of the Mystic Clouds.
The divine melody unfolds in celestial rhythm,
The true sound, free of all deviation."*

After the song concluded for some time, they all proceeded to the palaces of the two lords. The two lords prostrated themselves in welcome, facing north and declaring their reverence as humble servants. The Queen Mother addressed them, saying: "Though your Dao is accomplished, your knowledge remains insufficient. I shall arrange for you both to receive something here."

Presently, she dispatched her attendant Guo Mixiang to convey a message to the Supreme Primordial Lady. The two lords did not know who the Supreme Primordial Lady was. The message read: "The True King of the Nine Numinous Powers of the Western Tortoise Mountain." They respectfully acknowledged her but had not met her for over a thousand years, as celestial duties had kept her occupied, preventing their reunion. "Teaogu and Zhong have attained the Dao and have come to visit. Long have I refrained from inquiring after mortals. As host and guests sit facing each other, melancholy lingers. Could you grace us with your presence, even briefly?"

She replied that she would deign to come and would await them. The attendant departed and soon returned. The Supreme Primordial Lady also sent an attendant to convey her response: "Ahuan bows twice and inquires after your well-being. Though separated by the Crimson River and burdened by official duties, my longing for your radiance remains undiminished. Upon Mixiang’s arrival and your summons, I shall prepare my carriage. However, the Celestial August Emperor has just commanded me to attend to the records of the Three Origins in the Grove of Rarities. I shall go briefly and return promptly. I shall don my sash and hope you will tarry a while."

The two lords then asked the Queen Mother who the Supreme Primordial Lady truly was. The Queen Mother replied: "She is the mother of the True August Ones of the Three Heavens, the Supreme Perfected of the Upper Primordial, and the registrar of the names of the jade maidens of the ten directions."

After about two hours, the Supreme Primordial Lady arrived, heralded by the sounds of flutes and drums and the neighing of dragon-horses in the empty sky. Upon her arrival, she was accompanied by thousands of attendants, all women, around sixteen or seventeen years of age, their forms and countenances luminous and graceful. Many wore robes of green damask, their brilliance dazzling the eye. The Lady appeared to be eighteen or nineteen, her divine bearing impeccable. She wore a robe of crimson frost, draped with a fur-lined brocade cloak of azure feathers. Her hair was styled in a triple chignon, the rest cascading to her waist. She wore a crown of the Nine Dawns’ Radiant Sun, a girdle of six-faceted fire-jade pendants, a sash of phoenix-patterned lin-hua jade, and a sword of flowing yellow luminous essence.

She entered the chamber and bowed to the Queen Mother, who stopped her and invited her to sit beside her. A banquet was prepared for the Supreme Primordial Lady, facing north, no different from that of the Queen Mother. Lord Wang urged the two lords to bow twice and declare: "Gu and Zhong, of dull and base nature, were born and raised in the turbid and chaotic world. Like those who face a wall, we have never glimpsed the true Dao. Yet, fearing death and cherishing life, we have followed our master’s guidance. Today, our deliverance is by heaven’s grace. We humbly beseech your instruction."

chunks.original_text: 夫人愍二君之向真，惟灵妙之未启，乃敕侍女宋辟非出《三元流珠丹景》、《道精》、《隐地》、《八术太极绿景》，凡四经，以传于二君。 王母复敕侍女李方明出《玉佩金铛》、《太霄隐书》、《洞飞二景内符传》。 司命君上元夫人有言於王母日：阿母，隐书之妙，上真内经，封之，金台，佩入太微，乃径输而前卫； 文大武却，伏抱关出，登上清则振身瑶房； 左遨希林，长招仙公； 右栖白山，下盼太空； 泛彼天津，则乘云骑龙游此名山，则真人诣房； 万神奉卫，山精司迎； 动有八景玉舆，静则宴寝金堂。 此文妙矣，所谓玉佩金当也。 环有《三元流珠丹景》、《道精》《隐地》、《八术太极绿景经》，能返老还少，却白回婴，摧折千魔，驱策百灵，致明月之黄华，得白日之赤精，藏躯翳景，万物化生，出水入火，叱叱幽冥，收束虎豹，呼召六丁，隐沦八地，颠倒五星，久视在身，与天相倾耳。 安及太霄隐书，八会之奇文乎？ 用之眇邈，可以登玉京之宫，纷纷飘飘入流霞之堂，臣五岳之主，坐司命之床，抱凤腴之醴，漱药丹之觞，驾八龙以凌空，御虚落紫云而高浮远翔。 於是上元夫人下席起立，左手执四部经，右手执受书盟，仰天向二君祝日：九天浩洞，太上曜灵，神照玄微，清虚朗明。 登希者妙，守气者生。 至心道臻，寂感真成。
chunks.translated_text:
The Lady, moved by the two lords’ yearning for the true Dao and seeing that their numinous subtleties remained unopened, commanded her attendant Song Bifei to bring forth *The Three Primordials’ Flowing Pearl and Cinnabar Scenery*, *The Essence of the Dao*, *The Hidden Earth*, and *The Eight Arts of the Great Ultimate and Green Radiance*—four scriptures in all—to transmit to the two lords. The Queen Mother then commanded her attendant Li Fangming to present *The Jade Girdle and Golden Chime*, *The Concealed Writ of the Grand Empyrean*, and *The Transmission of the Two Internal Talismans of Cavernous Flight and Luminous Scenery*.

The Director of Destinies, the Supreme Primordial Lady, addressed the Queen Mother, saying: "O Mother, the wonders of the concealed writs—the inner scriptures of the Supreme Perfected—are sealed within golden terraces. When worn, they enter the Grand Tenuity, advancing directly to the fore of the guards. With civil might, they repel the martial; prostrate, they embrace the gatekeepers’ posts. Ascending the Upper Clarity, they shake their forms in the jasper chambers. To the left, they roam the Grove of Rare Delights, ever summoning the Lords of Immortals; to the right, they nest upon White Mountain, gazing down upon the Grand Void. Crossing the Celestial Ford, they ride clouds and mount dragons; wandering these sacred peaks, perfected beings attend their chambers. Ten thousand spirits offer protection; mountain sprites oversee their welcome. In motion, they possess the eight-scenery jade chariot; in stillness, they repose in the golden hall. This writ is wondrous indeed—what is called the *Jade Girdle and Golden Chime*.

Surrounding it are *The Three Primordials’ Flowing Pearl and Cinnabar Scenery*, *The Essence of the Dao*, *The Hidden Earth*, and *The Eight Arts of the Great Ultimate and Green Radiance*. These can reverse aging and restore youth, turn white hair back to infancy, shatter a thousand demons, and command a hundred spirits. They summon the yellow essence of the bright moon and obtain the crimson radiance of the white sun. Concealing the body and veiling its light, they transform the myriad things. Emerging from water and entering fire, they rebuke the dark netherworld. They bind tigers and leopards, summon the Six Dings, conceal themselves in the eight earths, and invert the five stars. With prolonged vision abiding in the body, they incline the ear to heaven.

How much more so with *The Concealed Writ of the Grand Empyrean*—the marvelous script of the Eight Assemblies? Its use is subtle and boundless; one may ascend the palaces of Jade Capital, drifting and floating into the halls of streaming rosy clouds. One becomes lord of the Five Peaks, sits upon the Director of Destinies’ couch, embraces the rich wine of phoenix marrow, and rinses the goblet of elixir and cinnabar. Mounting eight dragons to soar through the void, one rides the purple clouds of the empty vastness, soaring high and far.

Thereupon, the Supreme Primordial Lady rose from her seat, in her left hand holding the four scriptures, and in her right the covenant of transmission. Facing heaven, she intoned a blessing to the two lords: 'The vastness of the Nine Heavens, the radiance of the Supreme Luminary, the divine illumination of the mysterious and subtle, the clarity and emptiness of pure brightness—those who ascend the rare attain the wondrous; those who guard their qi live. With utmost sincerity, the Dao is attained; in stillness, the true is perfected.'"

chunks.original_text: 役神形辱，安精年荣。 石精金光，藏景录形。 左右招神，天元策灵。 可以步虚，可以沦形。 长生久视，与天同明。 违盟泄漏，祸必族倾。 各宜慎祸，敢告茅生。 祝毕，二君拜受灵书，抱之肘腋焉。 王母亦下座，手执太霄隐书，复命侍女张灵子把交信之盟，对司命君启手授书，向天而祝日：天高地卑，五岳镇形。 元精激气，沧泽玄清。 天回九道，六和长平。 太霄隐书，玉佩金当，玉景八会，宝洞上章。 登行太极，上清瑶房。 泄则受考，身获天殃。 受者慎之，敢告茅盈。 君伏受隐书，宴集受事粗毕，西王母、上元夫人各去，唯王君复留。 於是君与二弟央别，而与王君俱之赤城玉洞之府也。 道次诸山川有司迎启引者将以千万矣。 临去，告二弟日：吾今去，便有局任，不得数相往来，日一夕相见。 要当一年，再过来於此山。 三月十八日、十二月二日期要吾师及南岳太虚赤真人游盼於二弟之处也。 将可记识之有好道者，待我於是日，吾自当料理之，有以相教训於未悟。 於是二君留治此山，洞内立官，结构於外，将道着万物，流润苍生，德加乌兽，各获其情，神验祸福，罪恶必明。 内法既融，外教坦平。 尔乃风雨以时，五禾熟成，疾疠不起，暴害不行，境无灾青，邑无贼兵。 时父老认歌日：茅山连金陵，江湖据下流。 三神乘白鹄，各治一山头。 召雨灌旱稻，陆田亦复柔。 妻子咸保室，使我百无忧。 白鹄翔青天，何时复来游？ 三君往，曾各乘白鹄集山之三处，时人互有见者，是以发於歌咏矣。 乃复因鹄集之处，分句曲之山为大茅君、中茅君、小茅君三山焉。 统而言之，尽是句曲之一山耳，无异名也。 父老虽外承茅君仙真之灵佑，而实未睹温颜於膝下。 茅君亦港闲洞宫，颐神葆真，忽臭味之交驰，远凡俗以静身，故不复外接众庶耳。 唯好道骨挺之子，时得抽引相见。 至於泽溉万物，德加兆民，已阴为用也。 时人惟此灵德之洋溢，同於天地大神，亦显圣道之无心，因民情而为感矣。 遂乃相率，扶老携幼，挈粮壶浆，共起坛积基，立庙观于山中。 穷工肆巧，结构连阿。 图三君之像於丹青之膀，书神灵之德於能宣之笔。 播殖百果，竹梧成林。 决利清流於毗陵之元。 虎豹卫灾，巨狩备关，素鸿玄乌，翰飞戾天。 勇者慑其武，仁者怀其文。 农夫感敬於洪泽，万物宗庇於灵信。 垂死者必获其生，学道者栖慕于墙岸矣。 明帝永平二年，韶劫郡县，修灵山大泽能兴云雨有益百姓者庙，如陈国老子庙、会稽夏禹庙、丹阳句曲茅真人之庙，长沙湘水黄陵二妃、屈原之庙，有是此之比者，皆德遗黎民，道匠万物。 或标圣母之高轨，或范圣贤之灵迹。 是故象以铭器，庙以期神，皆当因而营护，使守而修之。 时邑人通呼此庙为白鹄庙，而实不知司命君早已东之赤城也。 昔人有至心好道入庙请命者，或闻二君在帐中与人言语，或见白鹊在帐中。 白鹄者，是服九转还丹使能分形之变化也，亦可化作数十白鹄，或可乘之以飞行，而本形故在所止也。 二君性好音乐，其有所持念人每入庙者，二君常从方诸官及西城请天妓。 天妓来时，皆闻虚空之中有音乐之声来下稍近。 既到，管弦歌音，非人世所闻，清一及激洞而不可名。 终日乃遣妓，妓去亦复并作，并去渐远，良久乃不闻。
chunks.translated_text:
To command the spirit and humiliate the form is to pacify the essence and flourish the years. The stone’s essence and golden radiance conceal the luminous and record the form. Summoning spirits to left and right, one wields the celestial tally to activate the numinous. Thus may one pace the void or dissolve the form. To live long and endure, one’s brightness equals heaven’s. To violate the covenant or leak its secrets invites calamity that topples the clan. Each must guard against disaster—I dare admonish you, Master Mao.

With the blessing complete, the two lords bowed to receive the sacred scriptures, clasping them beneath their arms. The Queen Mother of the West also rose from her seat, holding the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean* in hand. She commanded the attendant maiden Zhang Lingzi to present the covenant of mutual trust. Facing the Director of Destinies, she extended her hands to deliver the book and intoned toward heaven: “Heaven is high, earth is low; the Five Peaks anchor the form. The primordial essence stirs the qi, and the vast expanse is darkly pure. Heaven revolves through the nine paths; the six harmonies endure in peace. The *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean*, jade pendants and golden seals, the *Jade Luminance* and the *Eight Assemblies*—treasured scriptures of the highest chapters. Ascend and traverse the Grand Ultimate; enter the Jade Chamber of the Supreme Clarity. To leak it is to invite trial; the body incurs heavenly misfortune. He who receives it must be vigilant—I dare admonish you, Mao Ying.”

The lord prostrated himself to receive the hidden writ. Once the feast and transmission were roughly concluded, the Queen Mother of the West and the Supreme Primordial Lady departed, leaving only Lord Wang behind. Thereupon, the lord took leave of his two younger brothers and accompanied Lord Wang to the Jade Cavern Estate of Red City. Along the way, the administrators of mountains and rivers who came forth to welcome and guide them numbered in the thousands. As they prepared to depart, he addressed his two brothers: “Now that I go, I shall have fixed duties and cannot visit often—no longer will we meet day and night. Yet I shall return to this mountain once a year. On the eighteenth day of the third month and the second day of the twelfth month, my master and the Supreme Void Red Perfected of the Southern Peak will visit you here. Take note of those who are devoted to the Dao; await me on these days, and I shall attend to them, offering instruction to those yet unenlightened.”

Thus, the two lords remained to govern the mountain. Within the cavern, they established offices; without, they built structures. They expounded the Dao to all things, nourishing the multitude with its flow. Their virtue extended to birds and beasts, each attaining its nature. Divine portents revealed fortune and misfortune; transgressions were made manifest. With inner teachings harmonized and outer doctrines made level, wind and rain came in season, the five grains ripened, pestilence did not arise, and violence did not spread. The land knew no disasters; the villages knew no bandits. The elders of the time sang:

*Maoshan joins Jinling,
The rivers and lakes lie below.
Three divinities ride white cranes,
Each governing a mountain’s brow.
They summon rain to drench parched rice,
And dry fields too grow soft and nice.
Wives and children dwell secure,
A hundred cares I need not endure.
White cranes soar in azure skies—
When will they return to grace our eyes?*

When the three lords departed, each rode a white crane to alight upon one of the mountain’s three peaks. Many witnessed this, inspiring the song. Thereafter, the peaks of Juqu Mountain were divided into the mountains of the Great Lord Mao, the Middle Lord Mao, and the Lesser Lord Mao. Taken as a whole, they remained a single mountain—Juqu—without other names.

Though the elders outwardly received the divine protection of the Mao Lords’ perfected spirits, they had never beheld their gracious presence in person. The Mao Lords, dwelling in leisure within their cavern palace, nurtured their spirits and preserved their truth. Disdaining the clamor of worldly exchanges, they distanced themselves from the vulgar to maintain stillness. Thus, they no longer met with the common folk, save for those of exceptional destiny and devotion to the Dao, whom they occasionally summoned to see.

Yet in nourishing the myriad things and extending virtue to the multitudes, they worked unseen. The people, sensing the overflow of their numinous power—equal to that of heaven and earth’s great spirits—perceived the effortless manifestation of the sacred Dao, moved by the people’s devotion. Thus, they came in throngs, supporting the old and carrying the young, bearing provisions and libations. Together, they raised altars and laid foundations, erecting temples and halls upon the mountain. Craftsmen exhausted their skill to construct towering edifices. They painted the likenesses of the three lords in vermilion and azure, inscribing their divine virtues with eloquent brushstrokes. They planted a hundred fruits; bamboo and parasol trees grew into forests. They channeled the clear currents of Piling’s source. Tigers and leopards warded off calamity; great beasts guarded the passes. White swans and dark crows soared to the heavens. The brave were awed by their might; the benevolent cherished their culture. Farmers revered their boundless grace; all things sought refuge in their divine trust. The dying were restored to life; seekers of the Dao yearned for their guidance.

Emperor Ming of the Han, in the second year of the *Yongping* era, decreed that counties and commanderies repair the temples of sacred mountains, great marshes, and sites capable of summoning clouds and rain for the people’s benefit—such as the temple of Laozi in Chen, the temple of Yu the Great in Kuaiji, the temple of the Mao Perfected in Juqu of Danyang, the temple of the Two Consorts of the Xiang River and Qu Yuan in Changsha, and others of their kind. All had bequeathed virtue to the people and crafted the Dao for the myriad things. Some marked the lofty path of the Holy Mother; others modeled the divine traces of sages and worthies. Thus, images were cast in bronze to commemorate them; temples were built to invoke their spirits. All were to be maintained and protected, their guardians charged with their upkeep.

The villagers commonly called this temple the White Crane Temple, unaware that the Director of Destinies had long since departed eastward for Red City. In the past, those who entered the temple with sincere devotion to the Dao and prayed for guidance sometimes heard the two lords conversing within the curtains or saw white cranes perched there. These white cranes were transformations wrought by the elixir of ninefold cyclical refinement, enabling them to divide their forms. They could become dozens of white cranes or be ridden in flight, while their original forms remained where they had alighted.

The two lords delighted in music. Whenever devotees entered the temple with earnest intent, the lords would summon celestial courtesans from the Palace of Square Vessels and the Western City. As the courtesans descended, music sounded from the empty sky, drawing nearer. Upon arrival, their pipes, strings, and songs produced melodies beyond mortal hearing—pure, resonant, and indescribably profound. At day’s end, the courtesans were sent away. Their departure was marked by a chorus of music that gradually faded into the distance, until at last it could no longer be heard.

chunks.original_text: 夫此之神者，是能变化假景因百姓之心，以顺其情耳。 本真定形，故自燕逸洞台，颐光潜辉乎定录。 君日：句曲自是司命之别宫，吾人亦不得为洞台之正主也。 东卿司命监泰山之众真，总括昊越之万神，可谓道渊德高，折冲旱灵者也。 贾玄道、李叔升、言城生、傅道流，并受司命君之要也。 玄道，河东人，周威王之末年生。 叔升，涿郡人，汉元帝时生。 道流，北地人，汉灵帝殿中将军也。 城生，昊人，后汉刘圣公时为武当郡尉也。 受学至勤，并得真道，后入泰山友子小白阳山中，此所谓地真者也。 李翼，字仲甫者，京兆人也。 与司命君俱事西城王君，仲甫为入室弟子，司命君为北牖弟子，但仲甫所受业异，恒服水玉，有效，能步斗隐形，昼夜行三纲六纪之法，又作白虎七变，百余岁，转更少壮，与司命君同受还丹一剂，服而归家。 仲甫相识人相去五百里，常以张罗为业，当晨张罗获一大乌，视察之，乃是仲甫。 语毕别去，言已，复是日还家，在民问二百五十年。 汉灵帝时，入西岳去，亦有迎官如司，命君初发时也，受书为西岳副司命，每自叹云：吾受业，少不如茅叔申，此亦吾之命也。 仲甫曾以七变神法传左元放，元放修之亦变化万端矣。 茅山志卷之五竟 茅山志卷之六
chunks.translated_text:
These divine beings possess the power to transform and manifest illusory scenes in accordance with the hearts of the common folk, thereby aligning with their emotions. Yet their true essence remains fixed in form, dwelling in leisure upon the Terrace of Repose, their radiant virtue concealed and their luminous power hidden within the Registers of Stability.

The Lord remarked: "Mount Gouqu is but a detached palace of the Director of Destinies. We are not the rightful masters of the Terrace of Repose. The Eastern Minister, the Director of Destinies, oversees the multitude of perfected beings on Mount Tai, governing the myriad spirits of the Wu and Yue regions. Truly, he may be called one whose Dao runs deep and whose virtue stands lofty, whose authority subdues even the earliest of spirits."

Jia Xuandao, Li Shusheng, Yan Chengsheng, and Fu Daoliu all received the essential teachings of the Lord Director of Destinies. Xuandao, a native of Hedong, was born in the final years of King Weilie of Zhou. Shusheng, from Zhuo Commandery, was born during the reign of Emperor Yuan of Han. Daoliu, from Beidi, served as a palace general under Emperor Ling of Han. Chengsheng, a man of Wu, was the commandant of Wudang Commandery during the reign of Emperor Gengshi of Later Han. Through diligent study, all attained the true Dao and later entered the Friend-of-the-Young Cave on Mount Xiaobaiyang in Tai, known as the Earthly Perfected.

Li Yi, styled Zhongfu, was a native of Jingzhao. He and the Lord Director of Destinies both studied under the Western City Lord Wang. Zhongfu was an inner-chamber disciple, while the Director of Destinies was a northern-window disciple. However, Zhongfu’s received teachings differed: he constantly ingested *shuiyu* (water jade) and achieved efficacy, enabling him to pace the Dipper and conceal his form. By day and night, he practiced the methods of the Three Principles and Six Regulations, and performed the Seven Transformations of the White Tiger. After over a hundred years, he grew ever more youthful and vigorous. Together with the Lord Director of Destinies, he received a dose of the cyclically refined elixir, consumed it, and returned home. Zhongfu could recognize acquaintances from five hundred *li* away. He often made his living by setting nets. One morning, as he spread his nets, he caught a great crow. Upon inspection, it was Zhongfu himself. After speaking, they parted, and on that very day, he returned home, having lived among the people for two hundred and fifty years. During the reign of Emperor Ling of Han, he entered the Western Marchmount and was received with the same ceremonial honors as when the Lord Director of Destinies first departed. He was appointed Vice-Director of Destinies of the Western Marchmount. He often lamented: "In my studies, I fell short of Mao Shushen—this too is my destiny."

Zhongfu once transmitted the Sevenfold Divine Transformation method to Zuo Yuanfang. After cultivating it, Yuanfang too achieved myriad transformations.

chunks.original_text: 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 括神区篇 句曲山《太元真人内传》日：江水之东，金陵之左右，问有小泽，泽东有句曲之山。 此山洞虚内观内有灵府，洞庭四开，穴岫长连，古人谓为金坛之虚台，天后之便阙，清虚之东窗，林屋之隔杳。 众洞相通，阴路所适，七涂九源，四方交达，真洞仙馆也。 山形似已字，故以句曲为号焉，隐居六小泽，即今赤山湖，从江来，直对望此山。 又日句曲山。 源曲而有所容，故号为句容里。 周时名其源泽为曲水之穴，秦时名为句金之坛，以洞天内有金坛百丈，因以致名也。 外又有积金山，亦因积金为坛号矣。 汉有三茅君来治其上，时父老又转名茅君之山。 三君往，乘白鹄，各集山之三处。 时人互有见者，是以发於歌谣，乃复因鹄集之处分为大茅君、中茅君小茅君三山焉。 统而言之，尽是句曲之一山耳。 《隐居》云：句曲从山岭分界，西及北属句容，东及南属延陵。 山去石头江水步道一百五六十里。 句容，延陵，唐并属润州，宋分句容属江宁府，熙宁中废。 延陵山东及南今属钱江金坛县。 华阳洞天《太元内传》日：大天之内，有地中之洞天三十六所，其第八是句曲山之洞。 周回一百五十里，名日金坛华阳之天，洞虚四郭，上下皆石也。 上平处在土下，正当十三四里而出地上耳。 东西四十五里，南北三十五里，正方平，其内空虚之处一百七十丈，下境犹有原阜拢偃，上盖正平也。 其内有阴晖夜光日精之根照此，空内明并日月矣，阴晖主夜，日精主昼，形如日月之圆，飞在空玄之中。 句曲之洞宫有五门，虚空之内皆有石阶曲出以承门口仙人卒行出入者，即若外之道路也。 日月之光既自不异，草木水泽又与外无别。 飞乌交横风云蓊郁，亦不知所以疑之矣。 所谓洞天神宫，灵妙无方，不可得而□议，不可得而罔也。 句曲洞天，东通林屋，北通岱宗，西通峨媚，南通罗浮。 其有小径杂路、阡陌抄会，非一处也。 汉建元史左元放既得道，闻此神山，遂来山勤心礼拜，五年许，乃得其门，入洞虚，造阴宫。 三君授以神芝三种，元放周旋洞官之内经年？ 官室结构，方圆整肃，甚惋具也。 叹日：不图天下复有如此之异，神灵往来，推校生死，如地上之官府矣。 金陵地肺福地，按《洞天福地记》，福地有七十二，地肺福地为第一，即金陵之地是也。 金陵之地出於内传，其地水至即浮，故又比之於肺《抱朴内篇》别有地肺山，乃玉溜屿。 又商山亦名地肺，今以内传为正保命君受言金陵者，洞虚之膏腴，句曲之地肺也。 履之者万万，知之者无一。 人又日：金陵者，兵水不能加，灾厉所不犯。 《河图中要元篇》第四十四卷云：句金之坛，其问有陵，丘病不往，洪波不登，正此之福地也。 《太元内传》曰：句曲山，其问有金陵之地，地方三十七八顷，是金陵之地肺也。 土良而井水甘美，居其地必得度世。 《河图要元篇》亦曰：乃有地肺，土良水清。 句曲之山，金坛之陵，可以度世上升。 曲城定录君受言，金陵之土似北郁。 及北谷关，土坚实，而宜禾谷，掘其问作井，正似长安凤门外井水味，是清源幽澜洞泉远沾耳。 水色白，都不学道，居其土，饮其水，亦令人寿考也。 《内传》又日：金陵之左右有决谷溪，源陵之左有山，右有源沃，名柳谷，陵之西有源济，名阳谷。

The *Comprehensive Record of Divine Realms*, compiled by Liu Dabin, Successor Master of the Supreme Clarity lineage, states:

The *Inner Transmission of the Perfected of Great Primordiality* of Mount Juru records: East of the Yangtze, near Jinling, there lies a small marsh. To its east rises Mount Juru. This mountain’s cavernous interior harbors a numinous precinct, its grotto-heavens opening on all four sides, its caves and peaks stretching endlessly. Ancient texts call it the "Vacuous Terrace of the Golden Altar," the "Convenient Postern of the Heavenly Empress," the "Eastern Window of Clarity and Emptiness," and the "Secluded Screen of the Forest Chamber." Its myriad caverns interconnect, forming hidden paths that lead to seven thoroughfares and nine springs, with routes extending in all directions—truly a divine grotto and immortal sanctuary.

The mountain’s shape resembles the character *ju* (句), hence its name, Juru. It lies concealed among six small marshes, the present-day Chishan Lake, which faces the mountain directly as one arrives from the Yangtze. It is also called Mount Juru. Its winding sources cradle hidden depths, thus the surrounding settlement is named Jurongli. In the Zhou dynasty, its marshy springs were called the "Caverns of Winding Waters"; in the Qin, they were named the "Altar of Jujin," after the hundred-zhang Golden Altar within its grotto-heaven, from which it derived its name. Nearby stands Mount Jijin, likewise named for its accumulated golden altars.

During the Han, the Three Mao Lords came to govern this mountain. Local elders then renamed it the "Mountain of the Mao Lords." The Three Lords departed riding white cranes, each alighting upon one of the mountain’s three peaks. Witnesses at the time gave rise to folk songs, and the crane-alighting sites were later distinguished as the mountains of the Great, Middle, and Lesser Mao Lords. Yet in their entirety, they remain but a single mountain, Mount Juru.

The *Record of the Recluse* states: Mount Juru’s ridges demarcate its boundaries—west and north belonging to Jurong, east and south to Yanling. The mountain lies one hundred fifty to sixty *li* by foot from the Yangtze at Stone Citadel. Jurong and Yanling were both under Runzhou during the Tang; in the Song, Jurong was assigned to Jiangning Prefecture before being abolished during the Xining reign. The eastern and southern portions of Yanling now belong to Jintan County in Qianjiang.

The *Inner Transmission of Great Primordiality* in the *Grotto-Heavens of Flourishing Yang* records: Within the great heavens lie thirty-six earthly grotto-heavens, of which the eighth is the cavern of Mount Juru. Spanning one hundred fifty *li* in circumference, it is called the "Grotto-Heaven of the Golden Altar of Flourishing Yang." Its four walls are hollow, their upper and lower reaches entirely of stone. The level ground lies beneath the earth, emerging only after thirteen or fourteen *li*. It measures forty-five *li* east to west and thirty-five *li* north to south, perfectly square and flat. Its hollow interior extends one hundred seventy *zhang*, its lower reaches still bearing hills and mounds, while its upper vault is perfectly level.

Within, the "Yin Radiance" and "Root of Solar Essence" illuminate the void, their brilliance rivaling sun and moon. The Yin Radiance governs night, the Solar Essence day; both are round like sun and moon, floating in the boundless dark. The grotto-palace of Juru has five gates, each approached by winding stone steps within the void, serving as thoroughfares for immortals and adepts. The light of sun and moon differs not from the world outside, nor do its grasses, trees, waters, or marshes. Birds soar through the air, winds and clouds gather thickly—yet none can fathom its mysteries.

Such is the divine grotto-palace, its numinous wonders beyond measure, beyond conjecture, beyond deception. The grotto-heaven of Juru connects eastward to the Forest Chamber, northward to Mount Tai, westward to Mount Emei, and southward to Mount Luofu. Its lesser paths and intersecting trails are too numerous to count.

During the Jianyuan era of the Han, Zuo Yuanfang, having attained the Dao, heard of this sacred mountain and came to dwell upon it, devoting himself to reverent practice. After five years, he found its gate and entered the hollow grotto, reaching the Yin Palace. The Three Lords bestowed upon him three kinds of divine mushrooms. Yuanfang wandered the grotto-palace for a year, marveling at its chambers and halls, their structures square and round, meticulously ordered, and fully furnished. He sighed: "I never imagined the world held such marvels—where spirits come and go, adjudicating life and death as if it were an earthly court!"

Jinling is the "Earthly Lung" among the blessed lands. According to the *Record of Grotto-Heavens and Blessed Lands*, there are seventy-two blessed lands, of which the Earthly Lung ranks first—this is the land of Jinling. As the *Inner Transmission* notes, its earth floats upon water, hence the comparison to a lung. The *Inner Chapters of Embracing Simplicity* mentions another "Earthly Lung Mountain," Jade Flow Isle, while Mount Shang is also called the Earthly Lung. Here, we follow the *Inner Transmission* as authoritative.

The Lord of Life-Preservation received the teaching that Jinling is the fertile marrow of the hollow grotto, the Earthly Lung of Juru. Countless tread its soil, yet none comprehend it. It is also said of Jinling: "Neither war nor flood may assail it; no calamity or plague shall befall it."

The forty-fourth scroll of the *River Chart’s Essential Primordiality* states: "Within the Altar of Jujin lies a mound. The sick do not go there; floodwaters do not rise there—truly a blessed land." The *Inner Transmission of Great Primordiality* adds: "Within Mount Juru lies the land of Jinling, spanning thirty-seven or thirty-eight *qing*. This is the Earthly Lung of Jinling. Its soil is rich, its well water sweet and fine; those who dwell here are destined for transcendence."

The *Essential Primordiality* also says: "There is an Earthly Lung, where soil is fertile and water clear. The mountains of Juru and the mounds of the Golden Altar enable transcendence and ascension." The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that Jinling’s earth resembles that of Beiyu and the Northern Valley Pass—firm and solid, ideal for growing grains. Digging a well there yields water akin to that outside Feng Gate in Chang’an, its pure source a distant subterranean spring. The water is white, and even those who do not cultivate the Dao will live long lives if they dwell upon this land and drink its waters.

The *Inner Transmission* further states: To the left of Jinling’s ridges lies the Valley of Decision, while to the left of its marshy springs rises a mountain, with fertile sources to its right, called Willow Valley. To the west of the ridges lies the Source of Relief, called Yang Valley.

chunks.original_text: 又《名山内经福地志》日：伏龙之地，在柳谷之西，金坛之右可以高栖。 《孔子福地记》日：冈山之问，有伏龙之乡，可以避水、辟病长生，本所以名冈者，亦金陵之质也。 是以百代百易，非复本名，良可叹也。 右弼王真人受言，越桐梧之金庭、昊句曲之金陵，养真之福境，成神之灵墟也。 五倍尧水东海倾，人尽病死武安兵。 其如矛何由我带，近洞台之幽门，恃此而仿佯耳。 山 大茅山，在元符官南，独高处是司命君白鹄所集处。 定录君受言，大茅山有玄帝时铜鼎，鼎可容四五斛许，偃刻甚精好，在山独高处，入土八尺许，上有盘石掩鼎上，玄帝时命东海神埋藏於此。 又言，玄帝者，昔轩辕子昌意聚蜀山之女，生高阳，德号颛项，父居若水之乡，项身陶七河之津，是为玄帝也。 山顶常现神光，谓之丹光，一日天灯。 旧有石坛、石屋、今为殿宇，祀三茅君古石像。 岁以三月十八日、十二月二日为司命游盼之会，四方之人来山礼觐，盛作灵宝斋事，今古弗渝也。 中茅山，在积金山北，长岭独高处。 定录君受言，中茅玄岭上，司命君埋西胡玉门丹砂於此，深二丈许，堵上四面有盘石镇其上。 其山左右当泉水下流，皆小赤色，饮之益人。 山下左右有小平处，可堪静舍。

The *Inner Classic of Sacred Mountains and Blessed Lands* further states: The land of Hidden Dragons lies west of Willow Valley and to the right of the Golden Altar, where one may dwell in lofty seclusion.

The *Record of Blessed Lands by Confucius* says: Between the ridges of Gang Mountain lies the homeland of Hidden Dragons, where one may evade floods, avert illness, and attain longevity. The very name "Gang" derives from the essence of Jinling itself. Yet over a hundred generations and countless changes, its original name has been lost—how lamentable!

The Perfected Right Assistant Wang received the teaching that beyond the Golden Court of Tongwu and the Golden Mound of Wujuru lies a blessed realm for nurturing the true and a numinous dwelling for attaining transcendence:

*"Five times the waters of Yao would pour eastward into the sea,
All men would sicken and die beneath the weapons of Wu’an.
What use are spears when I bear them not?
Near the secluded gates of the Terrace of Immortals, I wander at ease."*

The Great Mount Mao lies south of Yuanfu Abbey, its solitary peak the gathering place of the Lord of Destiny, the White Crane. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that atop Great Mount Mao rests a bronze tripod from the era of the Dark Emperor, large enough to hold four or five *hu* of grain. Its casting is exquisitely refined, buried eight *chi* deep in the earth at the mountain’s highest point, sealed beneath a slab of stone. The Dark Emperor commanded the Spirit of the Eastern Sea to conceal it there.

It is further said that the Dark Emperor was Gaoyang, son of Changyi, who was in turn the son of the Yellow Emperor’s son, Xuanxiao. Born to a woman of Mount Shu, Gaoyang was titled Zhuanxu. His father dwelled in the land of Ruo Waters, while Zhuanxu himself molded the banks of the Seven Rivers—thus was he called the Dark Emperor.

At the mountain’s summit, divine radiance often appears, known as the Cinnabar Light or the Heavenly Lamp. In ancient times, there stood a stone altar and stone chamber; today, halls and pavilions have been erected, where the ancient stone statues of the Three Mao Lords are venerated. Each year on the eighteenth day of the third month and the second day of the twelfth month, the Lord of Destiny holds his wandering assembly, and people from all directions come to the mountain to pay homage. Grand *Lingbao* purification rites are conducted, a tradition unbroken from antiquity to the present.

Central Mount Mao lies north of Mount Jijin, its solitary ridge towering above all. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that atop the Dark Ridge of Central Mao, the Lord of Destiny buried cinnabar from the Jade Gate of the Western Hu, buried two *zhang* deep and sealed on all four sides by slabs of stone. The streams flowing down the mountain’s flanks are tinged a faint red, and those who drink from them are strengthened. On either side of the mountain’s base lie small level areas, well-suited for quiet retreats.

chunks.original_text: 今三阳百姓问得长寿者，谓朱阳、太阳、北阳三村也。 小茅山，在中茅北。 《太元内传》日：王莽地皇三年七月戊申，遣使者章邕斋黄金、白玉、铜锺五枚赠於句曲三仙君。 光武建武七年三月丁巳，遣使者昊伦斋黄金玉帛献三仙君。 积金山，元符宫之阴，定录君受言，大茅后、中茅前相连长阿，中有连石，古时名积金山。 其处宜人住，可索有水处为屋室静舍，乃佳快。 可合丹以修上道，隐居日此即隐居，今所住处，东面一横垄纯是石，石形甚瓖奇，多穿穴。 西南有大石壁耸而坼开，内有洞，入数丈渐狭小，不复容人，乃飕飕而有风。 金菌山，积金东凹独小山，是定录君喂言句曲支山，有名菌山。 此山至佳，隐居日：今人不复知有菌山者，此山形当如菌孤立，亦或是仓困之困，形如困也。 按大茅后长阿、积金东，凹地有一山子独秀，如博山炉，又近积金，正此是矣。 ＇ 华姥山，在崇禧宫南。 昔女仙人孙寒华修道於此，有庙久废。 此山夜中多见光景，或以为丹芝灵气，居人常望见之。 丁公山，崇禧宫之阴。 相传汉初丁令威仙举其上，不知辽东，何得远来此山？ 岂道成分身，任意之所至也？ 丁山在拱辰峪东。 虎爪山在丁山西。 雷平山，在雷平池上，定录君受言。 许长史今所营屋宅，对东面有小山名雷平山，周时有雷氏养龙来此。 郁冈山，在小茅东北，一名大横山。 林木蔽翳，望之郁然，故名。 定录君受言，雷平山之东俗人呼为大横山，其实名为郁冈山也。 《名山记》所谓冈山是矣。 昔李明於此合神丹而升玄。 洲水边，今犹有处所，其地古名炼丹院。 方隅山《真诰》云，雷平山之东北，良常山之东南，其问有燕口三小山相隅，名方隅山。 古人曾合九鼎丹於此，幽人在世时心尝乐居焉，今常游此。 《隐居》日：前云，李明合丹，即此是矣。 幽人者，许缘去世后，不欲显名，故自称幽人耳。 三公山，在燕口洞东南。 青山，在郁冈东，其西一山名西青山。 麻姑山，在郁冈西。 衔珠山，在雷平南。 《玉匮记》云，俗呼独女山。 独公山，在小茅北。 小竹山，在小茅东。 良常山，《太元内传》日：茅山北垂洞口一山，名良常山，亦句曲相连，都一名耳。 始皇三十七年十月癸丑出游，十一月行至云梦，祠虞舜於九疑，浮江下观，籍柯度梅渚，过丹阳，至钱塘、临浙江，水波恶，乃至西百二十里，从狭中度上会稽，祭夏禹，望于南海，而立石刻颂秦德于会稽山。 李斯请书，乃还诸山川，遂登句曲北垂山，埋白璧一双，於是会旱臣，飨从官。 始皇叹日：巡狩之乐，莫过山海。 自今以往，良为常也。 尔乃草臣并称寿，唤日良为常矣。 又呜大鼓，击大锺，万声齐唱，洞骇山泽，赞乐告兆，大小咸善，乃改句典北垂日良常之山，良常之意从此而名。 又日：良常山西南垂有可住处，是司命君往时别宅处也，亦可合丹。 又日：良常东南，又有可住处，其问当累石如宠形，问或有寄生树，树形如曲盖形，此处正好，但恨浅耳，虽尔自足，洞口西北有一地，小危不安，要自足立外舍也。 泰望山，在丁角路良常东北，小尖，山上下俱路者是也。 始皇亦驻此山，顾望丘阜。 龙尾山，大茅一岭直至山东金坛界，宛如外龙。 三角山，在华盖峰北。
