chunks.original_text: 人问如帑，久留何为？ 委形虚坛，合莫太始。 遗经不忘，保之有子。 五代宗师：上清仙卿保真先生，姓马讳朗，一名温公，字子明，浙束刻县束关人。 家素饶财，履信行义，为乡里所宗。 闻茅山杨、许得道，盛传南真上清经法，以其居接金庭天台，咫尺仙府，弥加崇慕。 元兴三年，许丞黄民载经避乱，君躬迎道左，延止其家，礼敬供养。 元嘉六年，许丞还钱唐，封其先世真经一橱子，留君静室之中，且云此经并是仙灵之迹，唯须我自来取，O纵有书疏，慎勿与之。 唯分十数卷自随，至钱唐感疾，虑不即酸，遣人取经，君既得书，坚执先旨，谓亲受教劫，岂敢轻付，遂不还经，许亦旋没。 君同弟罕敬事经宝有过君父。 恒使有#6心奴子二人，一名白首？ 一名平头，侍直香火，洒扫拂拭。 每有神光灵气见於室宇，君妻颇能通见。 云：数有青衣、玉女空中去来，状如飞乌。 君家遂益富盛，资产巨万，累世寿考而终。 赞曰： 天不爱道，地不爱宝，而彼钞薄，莫之能保。 韦真手遗，玉佩金当，知之者希，见之者昌。 六代宗师：上清仙卿辅正先生，讳罕，字子言，保真之堂弟也，同兄敬奉经宝。 居士娄惠明者，先以在刻，意甚贪乐经法，而肩镭严固，观览无方。 景和元年，乃出都，令嘉兴受秀真启宋主劝，就马家取经，比经至都，受呈景和於华林，暂开，劝以付后堂道士。 即陆先生。 《灵验记》日：二马有保经之功，没世之日，上帝命灵官持玉版召入金庭洞天，俱授仙卿之任。 赞日： 维昔茅君，兄升弟及。 继兹令踪，共保灵茨。 玉书所在，万神卫持。 道以时兴，匪人得私。
chunks.translated_text:
Why linger as in a treasury, long abiding in vain?
Yielding form to the empty altar, merging with the Great Beginning.
The legacy of scriptures not forgotten, preserved by a worthy son.

**Fifth-Generation Lineage Master:**
The Perfected Lord of Preserving the True of the Highest Clarity, surnamed Ma, personal name Lang, also called Wengong, styled Ziming, was a native of Dongguan in Kexian, eastern Zhe. His family had long been wealthy, walking in trust and practicing righteousness, revered by his village. Hearing of Yang and Xu of Mount Mao who had attained the Dao, and the widespread transmission of the Southern Perfected’s Highest Clarity scriptures and methods, he grew ever more devoted in admiration, for his dwelling lay near the Golden Court and Heavenly Terrace, a mere handspan from the immortal realms.

In the third year of Yuanxing, when Vice Minister Huang Min of Agriculture carried the scriptures to escape the chaos, Lord Ma personally welcomed him at the roadside, inviting him to stay in his home, where he honored and supported him with reverence. In the sixth year of Yuangjia, when Vice Minister Huang returned to Qiantang, he sealed a chest of his ancestral Perfected scriptures and left it in Lord Ma’s quiet chamber, saying, “These scriptures are all traces of the divine immortals. Only I may retrieve them. Even if there are written instructions, do not give them to anyone.” He took only a dozen or so scrolls with him. Upon reaching Qiantang, he fell ill and, fearing he might not recover, sent someone to fetch the scriptures. Lord Ma, having received the books, firmly upheld the original injunction, thinking, “How could I dare lightly hand them over, having personally received this teaching?” Thus, he did not return the scriptures, and Xu soon passed away.

Lord Ma and his younger brother Han revered the scriptural treasures even more than their own father. They always kept two servant boys—one named Whitehead, the other Flathead—to tend the incense and fire, sweep, and dust. Often, divine radiance and numinous qi manifested in their chambers. Lord Ma’s wife could also perceive them, saying, “There are often azure-clad maidens and jade women coming and going in the air, swift as flying birds.” Thereafter, the Ma family grew ever more prosperous, their wealth vast, and they enjoyed long lives across generations.

**Eulogy:**
Heaven does not begrudge the Dao,
Earth does not begrudge its treasures.
Yet those who transcribe carelessly
cannot preserve them.
Handed down by the Perfected of Wei,
jade pendants and golden tablets—
few know them,
those who see them flourish.

**Sixth-Generation Lineage Master:**
The Perfected Lord of Assisting the True of the Highest Clarity, personal name Han, styled Ziyan, was the younger cousin of Lord Preserving the True. Together with his elder brother, he revered and upheld the scriptural treasures. A layman named Lou Huiming, who had earlier resided in Ke, was deeply enamored of the scriptures and methods, but his karmic obstacles were severe, and he had no means to study them. In the first year of Jinghe, he went to the capital and, at the urging of the Perfected of Pure Brilliance, sought an audience with the Song sovereign to request the scriptures from the Ma family. By the time the scriptures reached the capital and were presented to Jinghe in the Hua Forest, they were briefly opened, and he urged that they be entrusted to the Daoist of the Rear Hall—Master Lu.

*The Record of Numinous Verifications* states: For their merit in preserving the scriptures, upon their passing, the Celestial Thearch commanded divine officials to summon them with jade tablets into the Grotto-Heaven of Golden Court, where both were appointed as Perfected Lords.

**Eulogy:**
Of old, the Lords of Mao—
elder ascended, younger followed.
Continuing this noble path,
together they preserved the numinous garden.
Where the jade scriptures reside,
ten thousand spirits guard and uphold.
The Dao flourishes in its time—
it is not for men to claim as private.

chunks.original_text: 七代宗师：上清监仙大夫九天掌籍宋国师，谧简寂先生，丹元真人，姓陆讳修静，字简寂，昊兴东迁人。 父琳，九征不起，谧高道处士。 真人踱有重输，足有双踝，掌有大字，背有斗文，笃#7好文籍，旁究象纬。 及长，好方外游，南诣衡湘、九疑。 访南真之遗迹，西至峨眉、西城，寻清虚之高躅。 宋元嘉末，因市药京邑，文帝召不往，乃友陶渊明、僧慧远於庐山。 明帝泰始三年，诏江州刺史王景宗礼聘来朝，劫住后堂； 真人不乐，乃授馆于外。 又劫会于华林延贤之馆，王公毕集。
chunks.translated_text:
The Seven Generations of Patriarchs: The Grand Master of the Upper Clarity, Supervisor of Immortals, Celestial Custodian of Registers, and National Preceptor of Song—Master Lu, posthumously styled the Serene Master, the Perfected of Cinnabar Prime. His surname was Lu, personal name Xiujing, courtesy name Jianji, a native of Wu Xing who had relocated eastward. His father, Lin, declined nine imperial summonses and was posthumously styled the Reclusive Master of Lofty Dao.

The Perfected bore extraordinary marks: his eyebrows were thickly layered, his feet had double ankles, his palms bore large characters, and his back displayed the pattern of the Dipper. From youth, he was deeply devoted to texts and broadly studied astronomy and cosmology. In adulthood, he delighted in wandering beyond the mundane world, journeying south to Mount Heng, the Xiang River, and the Nine Doubts to seek the vestiges of the Southern Perfected. He traveled west to Mount Emei and Western Citadel, tracing the lofty footsteps of the Pure and Void.

At the close of the Yuanjia era of the Song, while purchasing medicine in the capital, Emperor Wen summoned him, but he did not go. Instead, he befriended Tao Yuanming and the monk Huiyuan on Mount Lu. In the third year of Taishi of Emperor Ming, the emperor ordered Wang Jingzong, the governor of Jiangzhou, to extend a ceremonial invitation to court. He was forcibly lodged in the Rear Hall, but the Perfected found no joy in it and was granted quarters outside. Later, he was compelled to attend an assembly at the Hall of Extended Worth in Hua Lin, where all the princes and nobles gathered.

chunks.original_text: 真人鹿巾谒帝而升，帝肃然加敬，遂以受季真取到上清经法劝付真人，总括三洞，为世宗师，仍劫北郊天印山立崇虚馆，建传经宗坛。 教法大备矣。 明年，帝疾，即其馆修金 志一夕，有黄气如宝盖状弥覆坛宇，帝复感异於梦，疾乃有廖。 所着斋法仪范百余卷。 元徽五年正月，忽若趣装，将还旧山，弟子皆讶之，乃三月二日鲦然解化。 时庐山诸徒属共见霓旌蔼然下临静室，闻空中有言曰：上清监仙大夫降。 俄而劲送冠履还山，诏所居为简寂观。 赞日： 缅游灵岳，结友匡庐。 采秀黄华，濯清素叶。 手握奇文，足履轮辐。 萧馆虚林，想见遗躅。
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfected One, donning a deer-hide cap, approached the emperor and ascended the hall. The emperor rose in solemn reverence, whereupon he entrusted the Perfected with the *Shangqing* scriptures and methods received from Ji Zhen, appointing him the master of the Three Caverns and the preceptor of the age. He was then compelled to establish the Hall of Revered Emptiness on Mount Tianyin north of the capital and to erect an altar for transmitting the scriptures. Thus, the teachings reached their full perfection.

The following year, the emperor fell ill. The Perfected performed the *Golden Register* rites in his hall for a single night, whereupon a yellow qi, like a jeweled canopy, enveloped the altar and halls. The emperor, moved by a strange vision in his dreams, found his illness somewhat alleviated.

He composed over a hundred scrolls on the rituals and protocols of the fasts. In the fifth year of the Yuanhui era, on the first day of the first month, he suddenly prepared his belongings as if to return to his old mountain. His disciples were astonished, and on the second day of the third month, he serenely shed his mortal form.

At that time, the disciples on Mount Lu all witnessed a rainbow banner descending gently over his quiet chamber. From the void came these words: "The Grand Overseer of the *Shangqing* Immortals descends." Soon after, his cap and shoes were sent back to the mountain by imperial decree, and his dwelling was named the Abbey of Simplicity and Tranquility.

In praise it is said:
Far roaming the sacred peaks,
befriending souls on Mount Lu.
Gathering the essence of golden blossoms,
bathing the pure white leaves.
In hand, wondrous texts;
his feet trod the wheel’s spokes.
Amid the empty halls and silent groves,
his lofty footsteps linger still.
chunks.overlap_context: Wen summoned him, but he did not go. Instead, he befriended Tao Yuanming and the monk Huiyuan on Mount Lu. In the third year of Taishi of Emperor Ming, the emperor ordered Wang Jingzong, the governor of Jiangzhou, to extend a ceremonial invitation to court. He was forcibly lodged in the Rear Hall, but the Perfected found no joy in it and was granted quarters outside. Later, he was compelled to attend an assembly at the Hall of Extended Worth in Hua Lin, where all the princes and nobles gathered.

chunks.original_text: 八代宗师：紫微仙卿兴世明德先生，姓孙讳游岳，字颖J达，束阳人。 性禀渊淳，博学经传，拜简寂於仙都山，服#8谷精丸。 居仙都四十七年，不与世接。 后来茅山，简寂见而喜日：迟君来，吾高枕庐山矣。 授以杨、许真法。 未几，简寂化，诏先生主兴世馆，为嗣宗师。 一时名士沈□陆景真，陈宝识等咸学焉。 弟子百余人。 先生尝梦茅君日：青华小童复降句曲，汝弟子中善护持之。 永明问，陶弘景入山，先生异其丰神超迈，且闻身有斗文，因省所梦，曰：青华小童，岂非斗中真人耶？ 即尽哑其法，累表乞还山，诏不允。 永明七年五月十五日，沐浴迁神，年九十一。
chunks.translated_text:
The Eight Generations’ Patriarch: The Perfected Lord of the Purple Tenuity, Master Xingshi Mingde, surnamed Sun with the personal name Youyue and courtesy name Ying[J]da, was a native of Shuyang. His nature was profound and pure, and he was broadly learned in the classics and their commentaries. He paid homage to the Abbey of Simplicity and Tranquility on Mount Xiandu, where he ingested the Elixir of Millet Essence. Dwelling on Mount Xiandu for forty-seven years, he had no contact with the world. Later, he came to Mount Mao, where the Abbot of Simplicity and Tranquility, upon seeing him, rejoiced and said: “I have long awaited your arrival; now I may rest easy on Mount Lu.” He transmitted to him the true methods of Yang and Xu.

Before long, the Abbot of Simplicity and Tranquility passed away, and an imperial decree appointed Master Sun to preside over the Abbey of Ascendant Generation, succeeding him as the patriarch. At that time, renowned scholars such as Shen [□], Lu Jingzhen, and Chen Baoshi all studied under him. His disciples numbered over a hundred.

The Master once dreamed that Lord Mao said: “The Lesser Lad of Azure Splendor will descend again upon Mount Juqu; among your disciples, one will be skilled in safeguarding him.” During the Yongming era, when Tao Hongjing entered the mountains, the Master, struck by his extraordinary bearing and transcendent spirit—and hearing that his body bore the pattern of the Dipper—recalled his dream and said: “The Lesser Lad of Azure Splendor—could this not be the Perfected One within the Dipper?” He then fully transmitted his teachings to him. Repeatedly submitting memorials, he begged to return to the mountains, but the imperial decree did not permit it. On the fifteenth day of the fifth month in the seventh year of Yongming, he bathed and relinquished his spirit, aged ninety-one.

chunks.original_text: 赞曰： 百谷之精，结英中庭。 人以腹实，我以虚宁。 金真玉光，神文在世。 青童复来，吾得攸寄。 九代宗师：金阙右卿司命蓬莱都水监梁国师中散大夫，镒贞白先生，宗元斓教真人，姓陶讳弘景，字通明，昊荆牧浚七世孙，丹阳秣陵人也，生宋孝建三年丙申四月三十日甲戌。 十岁见淮南八公事，便嗜养生之说。 既冠而不肯婚，以资营未立，薄游下位，仕齐，历诸王侍读。 年二十余，从兴世馆孙先生咨禀经法#9，获前真杨，许手书。 於是启假束游，诣娄惠明於大洪山，遇杜京产於太平山，寻锺义山於窕山，谒朱僧标於天台，又获真人手迹十余卷。 还都，以振武将军除奉朝请。 永明十一年，乃拜表辞职，时年三十七，遂来山，自称华阳隐居，岭西立华阳三馆，上馆建层楼，身居其上，弟子居中，接宾於下。 梁武即位，弥加钦重，时人谓为山中宰相。 天监四年，出居岭束，有事于炉燧。 七年，以为林岩浅近，复思远游，乃改名氏日王整，官称外兵，夜半出山，至永嘉楠江青幛山。 梦佛哑记，名胜力菩萨，住大若岩，修所着《真诰》。 复泛海，诣霍山，经年还木溜屿。 武帝有劝，迎还旧山，因诣郑县，礼阿育王塔，自誓受五大摄戒。 既归，入住束涧。 明年冬，徙朱阳馆，又移郁冈斋室。 先生山世所着书二百余卷，弟子受经法者三千余人。 大同二年三月十二日，作《告逝篇》示桓法阐等，即日尸解，年八十一，屋中香气积日不散。 劲遣舍人主书监护丧事，十四日穷虚柩于雷平山。 先生神仪明秀，盼睐有光，形细长项，耳问娇娇，显然异众矣。 尝言心中恒如明镜，触形遇物不觉滞碍。 紫阳王君日：陶公久入下仙之上，乃范幼冲等也。 赵丞日：蓬莱都水监高光坐治水事被责，以陶代之，既且停召，当更选耳。 按此乃乙未年中事，见《周氏玄通记》，后二十一年先生始去世，仙位当更升也。 赞日： 高外白云，晨飧绛霞。
chunks.translated_text:
A Eulogy:

The essence of a hundred grains,
congeals as blossoms in the central court.
Others fill their bellies with substance;
I find tranquility in emptiness.
Golden perfection, jade radiance—
divine patterns manifest in the world.
The Azure Lad returns once more,
and I find my entrusted charge.
Ninth-generation Master of the Lineage:
Golden Portal’s Right Minister of Destiny,
Director of the Penglai Waters,
State Preceptor of Liang,
Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary,
Lord Yiyin of Unyielding Purity,
Perfected One Zong Yuanlan of the Teaching—
by family name Tao, personal name Hongjing, style Tongming,
seventh-generation descendant of Tao Jun, Prefect of Wu and Jing,
a native of Danyang Moling.

Born on the thirtieth day of the fourth month, the day *jiaxu*, in the third year of Xiaojian of the Song, the year *bingshen*.
At ten, he read of the Eight Lords of Huainan and became enamored of the teachings of nurturing life.
Upon reaching capping age, he refused marriage, and as his family’s resources were not yet established, he briefly served in a minor post.
He entered officialdom under the Qi, serving as attendant reader to various princes.
At twenty-some years, he studied scriptures and methods under Master Sun of Xingshi Hall, receiving the handwritten texts of the former Perfected Yang Xu.
Thereupon, he requested leave to travel, visiting Lou Huiming at Mount Dahong, encountering Du Jingchan at Mount Taiping, seeking Zhong Yishan at Mount Yaoshan, and paying homage to Monk Zhu Biao at Tiantai.
He obtained over ten volumes of Perfected Ones’ handwritten works.
Returning to the capital, he was appointed Gentleman Consultant with the title General of Vibrant Might.

In the eleventh year of Yongming, he submitted a memorial to resign his post at the age of thirty-seven and came to the mountains, styling himself the Recluse of Huayang.
West of the ridge, he established the Three Halls of Huayang: the upper hall with a storied pavilion where he himself resided, the middle for his disciples, and the lower for receiving guests.
When Emperor Wu of Liang ascended the throne, his esteem grew even greater, and contemporaries called him the Prime Minister of the Mountains.
In the fourth year of Tianjian, he moved to the east of the ridge to tend to his furnace and crucible.
In the seventh year, deeming Linyan too shallow and proximate, he longed to wander afar.
He changed his name to Wang Zheng, assuming the title Outer Arms Officer, and departed the mountains at midnight, arriving at Mount Qingzhang in Nanjiang, Yongjia.
He dreamed the Buddha conferred a prophecy, naming him the Bodhisattva Shengli, and dwelled at Dayuruo Rock, where he compiled his *Declarations of the Perfected*.
He then sailed across the sea to Mount Huo, returning after a year to Muliu Islet.
Emperor Wu urged him to return to his former mountain, whereupon he journeyed to Zheng County to pay homage at the stupa of King Ashoka, vowing to receive the Five Great Precepts.
Upon his return, he took residence in the Eastern Gorge.
The following winter, he moved to Zhuyang Hall, then to the studio at Yugang.
During his life in the mountains, he authored over two hundred volumes, and over three thousand disciples received his teachings in scriptures and methods.

On the twelfth day of the third month in the second year of Datong, he composed his *Farewell Verses* for Huang Fachan and others, and on that very day, his body dissolved in transcendence at the age of eighty-one.
The fragrance in his chamber lingered for days without dissipating.
The court dispatched a chamberlain and scribe to oversee the funeral rites, and on the fourteenth day, his empty coffin was interred at Mount Leiping.
The Master’s spirit and bearing were luminous and refined, his gaze bright with light.
His form was slender, his neck long, and his ears finely shaped—clearly distinct from the common crowd.
He once said his mind was ever like a bright mirror, encountering forms and objects without the slightest obstruction.

The Perfected Lord of Purple Yang said: “Lord Tao has long dwelled among the upper ranks of the lower immortals—he is of the same rank as Fan Youchong.”
Zhao Cheng said: “When Gao Guang, Director of the Penglai Waters, was reprimanded for his handling of waterworks, Tao was appointed in his stead. Yet the appointment was soon suspended, and another was to be selected.”
This occurred in the year *yiwei*, as recorded in *Zhou’s Records of Mystic Communication*. Twenty-one years later, the Master passed away—his immortal rank must have since ascended.

A Eulogy:
Lofty beyond the white clouds,
at dawn he feasts on crimson auroras.

chunks.original_text: 弟子如林，着书满家。 濯神九清，腾耀三景，与天为徒，如日之炯。 十代宗师：上清少室仙伯唐国师金紫光禄大夫，谧升玄先生，姓王讳远知，字德广，琅琊临沂人。 父昙，选陈扬州刺史，母丁梦凤乌集其身。 僧宝志谓其父日：生子当为神仙。 宗伯以梁大通二年生。 弱冠，师宗道先生，臧矜进而宗修隐居经法，陈主召入重阳殿，特加礼敬，送归茅山，居于洞西北岭。 隋，晋王广镇扬州，具礼迎请。 既至，忽须发变白，王惧而归之。 大业七年，炀帝幸涿郡，召见临朔宫，扈驾洛阳，奉劫诣中岳修斋，复诏京师，建玉清玄坛以处之。 唐高祖龙潜时，先生密告以符命。 武德中，太宗为秦王，平王世充因与房玄龄微服谒先生，先生迎谓日：此中有圣人。 秦王乃审其实，先生日：方作太平天子，愿自爱。 已而请还山。 贞观九年，劫建太平观，赐田度道士七七人为侍者。 八月十四日，适因睡寤，喜形於色，谓弟子日：吾向暂游洞宫，仙官见报，欲以疲朽补仙伯，名位已定，行在不久。 十六日，沐浴，入室，焚香，顾问侍者日时早晚？ 对日：辰时。 日：好。 即正衣冠就寝而化，年一百二十有六。 高宗调露二年，赠太中大夫，谧升真先生，天后嗣圣加赠前号，时称玉法主云。 赞日： 翩翩凤仪，览德不迟。
chunks.translated_text:
Disciples thronged like a forest, his writings filled the household.
He cleansed his spirit in the Ninefold Purity, soared in radiance through the Three Luminaries, companion to Heaven, resplendent as the sun.
Tenth-generation patriarch of the lineage:
Master of the Upper Clarity, Immortal Lord of Shaoshi, Tang Court Preceptor, Grand Master for Glorious Happiness with Gold and Purple, posthumously titled Master Shengxuan—his surname was Wang, personal name Yuanzhi, style Deguang, a native of Linyi in Langye.
His father, Tan, was appointed Prefect of Yangzhou under the Chen; his mother, née Ding, dreamed of a phoenix alighting upon her body.
The monk Baozhi told his father: “The child you bear shall become a divine immortal.”
The Patriarch was born in the second year of *Datong* under the Liang.
In his youth, he took as teacher Master Zongdao; Zang Jin further instructed him in the scriptures and methods of the Reclusive Cultivation tradition. The Chen sovereign summoned him to Chongyang Hall, bestowing special honors, and sent him back to Mount Mao, where he dwelled on the northwest ridge.
Under the Sui, Prince Guang of Jin, garrisoning Yangzhou, extended a formal invitation. Upon arrival, the Master’s hair and beard suddenly turned white; the prince, alarmed, sent him home.
In the seventh year of *Daye*, Emperor Yang visited Zhuo Commandery and summoned him to the Linduo Palace. Escorting the imperial carriage to Luoyang, he was pressed into service to perform purification rites at Mount Song; later, he was recalled to the capital, where the Jade Clarity Mystic Altar was built to house him.
When the Tang founder was still in obscurity, the Master secretly revealed to him the talismanic mandate.
During *Wude*, when the future Taizong was Prince of Qin, he subdued Wang Shichong. Together with Fang Xuanling, he came in humble guise to visit the Master, who greeted them, saying: “A sage is among you.”
The Prince of Qin then examined the matter closely. The Master said: “You shall become the Heavenly Sovereign of Great Peace—take care for yourself.”
Thereafter, he requested leave to return to the mountains.
In the ninth year of *Zhenguan*, he was pressed into service to build the Great Peace Abbey; lands were granted, and forty-nine Daoist priests were ordained as his attendants.
On the fourteenth day of the eighth month, he awoke from sleep with a joyful countenance and told his disciples: “I have just made a brief journey to the Grotto Palace. The immortal officials have informed me that this worn-out frame is to be appointed Immortal Lord—my rank and title are now fixed, and my departure is near.”
On the sixteenth, he bathed, entered his chamber, and burned incense. Turning to his attendants, he asked the hour.
They replied: “The hour of *chen*.”
He said: “Good.”
Straightening his robes and cap, he lay down and passed away, aged one hundred and twenty-six.
In the second year of *Diaolu*, Gaozong posthumously granted him the title Grand Master of the Palace; his posthumous name was Master Shengzhen. Empress Wu, in *Sisheng*, added to his former titles. At the time, he was known as the Jade Dharma Lord.

A Eulogy:
Graceful as the soaring phoenix,
his virtue perceived without delay.

chunks.original_text: 上志品 十一代宗师：上志检校仙公唐国师太中大夫，谧体玄先生，姓潘，讳师正，字子真，贝州宗城人。 父真隋通州刺史，母鲁氏善言名理，口喂以《道德经》。 母卒，庐墓以孝闻。 大业中，有道士刘爱道者，见而奇之日：三 志之骥，非尔谁乘之。 时王法主为炀帝所尊礼，每入禁中躬荐松水以祈福。 爱道日：吾甚欲子相从，然成就功道，非法主不可。 由是师事法主，同还茅山。 一．日，谓先生日：嵩阳乃汝修真之地，当亟往无疑。 先生遂入双泉中岭间，居十许年，复深入逍遥谷，邈与世绝。 上元三年，高宗幸束都，礼嵩岳，召见先生，请作符书，辞不解。 又问山中所须，答日：茂松 志泉，臣之所须，此中不乏。 帝异之。 调露初，再杞嵩，帝乃幸逍遥谷，见薜荔绳床将朽败，余无火粒之具，唯两瓢贮青谜饭耳，因即其地劲建崇唐观。 明年春，又以步辇致先生於洛城西官，仍劫改嵩阳观为奉天宫。 每手韶，具弟子姓名咨白，自是乘舆屡险山阿。 帝在洛阳，复召对，及请还，御制诗以送先生。 尝谓弟子日：吾实无用接见帝王，惊扰灵岳。 汝等学道不厌探眇，则无累矣。 永淳元年六月十四日，索沐浴，书青符置汤中日：终身冷也。 时造石室於北岩下，将成。 十六日，遽云：去去。
chunks.translated_text:
**Scroll Eleven: A Record of the Succeeding Patriarchs**

**The Eleventh Patriarch:**
The Venerable Master of the Upper Records, Inspector of Immortals, Tang State Preceptor, Grand Master for Thorough Counsel, posthumously titled Master Tixuan, bore the surname Pan, the personal name Shizheng, and the courtesy name Zizhen. He hailed from Zongcheng in Bei Prefecture.

His father, Pan Zhen, served as Prefect of Tong Prefecture during the Sui, while his mother, née Lu, was skilled in eloquent discourse on renowned principles. She fed him the *Dao De Jing* from her own mouth. After her death, he built a hut by her grave and was renowned for his filial piety.

During the Daye era, a Daoist named Liu Aidao saw him and marveled, saying: *"A steed of three aspirations—who but you could ride it?"* At the time, the Dharma Master Wang was held in high esteem by Emperor Yang, often entering the palace to personally offer pine resin and spring water for blessings. Aidao said: *"I deeply wish for you to follow me, yet to accomplish the work of the Dao, none but the Dharma Master will suffice."* Thus, he became a disciple of the Dharma Master and returned with him to Mount Mao.

One day, the Dharma Master said to him: *"Songyang is the place for your cultivation of the True—you must hasten there without doubt."* The Master then entered the valley between the twin springs of Zhong Ridge, dwelling there for over a decade before venturing deeper into Xiaoyao Valley, where he became utterly secluded from the world.

In the third year of the Shangyuan era, Emperor Gaozong visited the eastern capital and paid homage at Mount Song. He summoned the Master and requested talismanic writings, but the Master declined, claiming no knowledge of them. The Emperor then asked what he needed in the mountains. The Master replied: *"Lush pines and pure springs are all I require—these are not lacking here."* The Emperor was struck with admiration.

At the beginning of the Tiaolu era, when the Emperor again performed sacrifices at Mount Song, he visited Xiaoyao Valley. There, he saw a rattan couch overgrown with creeping figs, nearly rotted away, with no utensils for fire or grain—only two gourds holding green-tinged congee. Moved, he ordered the immediate construction of Chongtang Abbey on the spot.

The following spring, he had the Master conveyed by palanquin to the western palace in Luoyang and urgently renamed Songyang Abbey as Fengtian Palace. Whenever the Emperor composed music, he would present the names of the Master’s disciples for consultation, and from then on, the imperial carriage frequently traversed the mountain passes. While in Luoyang, the Emperor summoned the Master again for an audience. When the Master requested to return, the Emperor composed a poem to see him off.

The Master once told his disciples: *"Truly, I have no use for meeting emperors, for it disturbs the sacred mountains. If you study the Dao without wearying of its profound mysteries, you will be free of encumbrances."*

On the fourteenth day of the sixth month in the first year of the Yongchun era, he asked for a bath. Writing a green talisman, he placed it in the water, saying: *"This will remain cold for a lifetime."* At the time, a stone chamber was being built beneath the northern cliff, nearly complete.

On the sixteenth day, he suddenly declared: *"I depart, I depart."*

A phoenix-like crow once descended upon his incense table, its talon marks forming the characters: *"Perfected One of the Upper Records of the Eastern Flower."* Thereafter, his conduct grew ever more numinous. One day, moved by the Celestial Emperor’s call, he came to the mountain to pay homage at the Hua Yang Grotto-Heaven. There he composed the *Stele of Purity and Simplicity*, secretly inscribing upon it that Wangwu’s Lesser Existence Heaven was the central precinct of the Assembly of Perfected Ones: *"Its vital qi is secluded and reverent, its spirits gather in splendor. If our Dao is to flourish, what could be impossible? Soaring and alighting at will, I resolve to make this my final abode."*

Later, at the abbey’s northern ridge, where the heights reached their utmost and the boundaries grew most remote, he discovered the Central Rock Terrace—directly aligned with the Heavenly Altar above, encircled by long mounds below, embraced by colossal trees, with murmuring streams flowing through its midst. Here, for days uncounted, he nurtured dragons in the great valleys, kept cranes upon the central peaks, burned myriad incenses in the Golden Grotto, and inhaled the pure qi from the Stone Window. By dusk, a crimson cloud swirled down to earth, bearing the clear strains of celestial pipes. All who witnessed this were awestruck, certain he would ascend. Rushing to his chamber, they found only his discarded form.

Emperor Xuanzong’s imperial stele stands atop the Tongwu summit.

Utterly numinous, merging with the Void,
Responding to all things without bound.
Forcibly named *Sitting in Forgetfulness*—
It dissolves the dust of mortal form.
Lofty winds in the Flowery Grove,
Dawn’s light on the Cinnabar Terrace.
No teacher beyond Penglai’s seas—
Returning, he sought Mount Tiantai.

chunks.original_text: 神龙初，师以 志行度为道士，居龙兴观。 开元十七年，从可马先生於王屋山。 一见，目之日：真玉志之客也。 居嵩阳二十余年。 司马传游，玄宗召诣阙与语，叹日：吾见含光，知司马真人犹然在世。 一日，问及金鼎，对日：道德，公也，轻举，公中之私耳。 若忽道德而求生徇欲，则以击风。 玄宗深感异之，诏居阳台观，岁余称疾，乞还句曲纂修经法。 天宝四年十二月，命中使资玺书征之，既至，馆於禁中。 每欲咨禀，必先斋沐。 请传道法，辞以疾，不能强而止，再求还山。 乃特劫杨许故宅紫阳观以居之。 御制诗饯别，又禁山中采捕渔猎，食荤血者不得入。 时经诰真迹已多散逸，师奉韶搜访，备得宝书进上之。 又诏山人王哎请师楷书上经十三纸，以补遗阙。 七年三月十八日，玄宗受三洞经录于大同殿，遥礼先生为度师#1，赐号玄静先生法衣一袭，以伸师资之礼，韶刻石华阳洞宫以志之。 继两征诣阙，旋皆请老而还。 为国修斋，数感甘露灵芝之瑞。
chunks.translated_text: At the beginning of the Shenlong era, the Master was ordained as a Daoist on account of his aspiration and conduct, residing at Longxing Abbey. In the seventeenth year of the Kaiyuan reign, he followed Master Sima to Mount Wangwu. At first sight, Sima declared, “A true guest of jade-like aspiration!” He dwelt in Songyang for over twenty years. When Sima Zhen traveled, Emperor Xuanzong summoned the Master to court for an audience. Sighing, the emperor said, “In seeing Han’guang, I know that Perfected One Sima yet remains in the world.” One day, the emperor inquired about the golden crucible. The Master replied, “The Dao and virtue are public; light ascent is but a private matter within the public. If one neglects the Dao and virtue to pursue life and indulge desires, it is like striking the wind.” Xuanzong was deeply moved and marveled at this. He issued an edict for the Master to reside at Yangtai Abbey. After more than a year, the Master claimed illness and begged to return to Mount Juqu to compile scriptures and methods. In the twelfth month of the fourth year of the Tianbao reign, the emperor dispatched an imperial envoy bearing a jade-sealed edict to summon him. Upon arrival, the Master was lodged within the palace precincts. Whenever the emperor wished to consult him, he would first purify himself through fasting and bathing. When the emperor requested transmission of the Daoist methods, the Master declined on account of illness, and the emperor did not press him further. He again sought to return to the mountains. Thereupon, the emperor specially bestowed the former residence of Yang and Xu—Ziyang Abbey—for his dwelling. The emperor composed a poem to see him off, and further prohibited hunting, fishing, and the gathering of plants within the mountain, while those who consumed meat or blood were barred from entry. At the time, many authentic scriptures and sacred traces had already scattered and been lost. The Master, in accordance with imperial decree, searched and collected them, presenting the recovered treasures to the throne. The emperor further ordered the mountain recluse Wang Ai to request the Master’s standard script for thirteen pages of the *Upper Scripture*, to supplement what was missing. On the eighteenth day of the third month in the seventh year, Xuanzong received the catalog of the Three Caverns’ scriptures in the Datong Hall, paying distant reverence to the Master as his preceptor. He bestowed upon him the title *Master of Mystic Serenity* and a set of ritual robes, fulfilling the rites of master and disciple. An edict was issued to carve a stele at Huayang Grotto Abbey to commemorate the event. The emperor twice summoned the Master to court, but each time he requested retirement and returned. When he performed rituals for the state, auspicious signs such as sweet dew and sacred fungi repeatedly appeared.

chunks.original_text: 大历四年己酉十一月十四日，解蜕于紫阳之别院，年八十有七，以左玄大夫赠正议大夫。 赞日： 公私之辫，至道名言。 徒说弗从，频烦主恩。 上经十三，妙补遗阙。 参着刻铭，无愧称绝。 十四代宗师：上志仙伯大洞贞元先生，姓韦讳景昭，丹阳延陵人，昊司空慎十六代孙。 精究儒术而不肯取科名，独慕神仙之学．o初度于延陵之寻真观，师事包士荣。 士荣师崇玄观包法整，法整师包方广，方广师王轨，轨之师，升真王法主也。 惟习灵宝经法，后居长安肃明观。 至天宝中，奉韶侍玄静先生，归茅山。 劫建紫阳观居焉。 大历初，受玄静经筹正传。 肃代以来，天下丧乱，师独以道为己任。 贞元元年十一月癸卯，召门弟子日：吾昨见仙官持劫书，召任上 志仙伯，不复住世矣。 来何为喜，去何为悲？ 汝等体之，毋或哀泣。

The spirit rides the void and is born,

**The Fifteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Cavernous Truth, surnamed Huang, personal name Dongyuan, was a native of Mount Nanyue. In his early years, he traveled to Huayang, where he became a fellow student and friend of Master Xuanjing. He once received the method of ingesting the solar essence of the Central Yellow while wearing yellow robes. Later, he entered Wuling and resided at the Peach Blossom Abbey. There was a youth named Xiang Ting from Chenxi who came to serve him with great reverence. One day, after wandering alone, the youth returned and told the master: *"Within the Peach Blossom Spring, there is a watery cavern where flowers and trees exude fragrance. The cavern chambers wind around the stream, and many five-colored stones lie within. I found one shaped like a tortoise—when I pulled its head, its tail moved in response."* The master stored it in his scripture case, but after ten days, it vanished. Another day, they agreed to go together, but the waters had risen, and the stream and cavern were lost, their whereabouts unknown.

In the summer of the eighth year of the Dali era (773), on the last day of the fifth month, the youth took leave of the master, saying: *"We shall meet again at Juqu."* The following year, the master moved to Purple Cloud Peak on Mount Lu, where he dwelt for ten years. He then returned to the mountain and resided at the Lower Ji Palace, reciting the *Scripture of the Great Cavern* daily. He inherited the teachings of Patriarch Wei and spent another eight years there. One day, the youth Xiang Ting arrived, but the master had just gone out with his staff. Xiang Ting did not wait. When the master returned and heard his name, he was greatly startled. He changed his robes, lit incense, and prostrated toward the void. After standing motionless for a long while, he passed away—only his empty garments remained. Emperor Dezong marveled at this and posthumously bestowed a title upon the master. He lived to ninety-five.

**Eulogy:**
Gazing at the sun, he attained the Dao,
His knowledge was most true.
With Xiang Ting’s arrival,
The Peach Blossom Spring began its spring.
The five-colored stone tortoise,
Head moving, tail responding—
Suddenly it vanished,
A wondrous sign of the profound mystery.

chunks.original_text: 瑜年，明玄化形风雨中，师大悟解。 僖宗乾符二年，遣使受大洞镰，遥尊称为度师，赐先生号。 天佑四载，年八十三，预知世行有变，潜入岩洞，不知所往。 赞日： 世之将危，智者去之。 而彼真人，慨然兴悲。 深处岩洞，流润千里。 动植遂生，夙雨时至。 十八代宗师； 洞微元静先生，姓刘讳得常，金陵人。 十七岁作大道歌见昊宗师，观其气骨，飘然出尘，日：贤者能饮茅山泉，一月当十倍今日聪明，一年特生光慧，十年闻仙道矣。 师乃作玲泉吟。 又日：吾有玉经妙旨，子若敛华归实，可以混合天人、离情理识。 由是再拜，执弟子礼，得其道，居紫阳观二十年，不瑜户闽。 华姥山一夕有童子歌日：灵菌长，金刀响。 山中人数闻之，虑有兵。 是年盛产黄芝，经月枯悴，师亦解真。 赞日： 龙章凤书，可制劫运，藏之贵虚，保之贵定。 全体皆用，谁执其方，欲穷所之，弟子亡羊。 十九代宗师：贞素先生，姓王讳栖霞，一名敬真，字玄隐，生於齐而长於鲁。 七岁神童及第，而仙才灵气察於自然。 天佑丁卯岁，避乱南渡，至于寿春，从问政聂先生传道法。
chunks.translated_text:
In his youth, when Luminous Mystery transformed amidst wind and rain, the master attained profound enlightenment. In the second year of Qianfu during the reign of Emperor Xizong, he was dispatched as an emissary to receive the Great Cavern Register, and was honored from afar with the title of "Initiating Master," bestowed with the honorific "Master." In the fourth year of Tianyou, at the age of eighty-three, foreseeing the turmoil of the world, he concealed himself in a mountain cavern and vanished without a trace.

**Eulogy:**
When the world teeters on peril,
The wise depart from it.
Yet that Perfected One,
Moved to profound sorrow,
Dwelt deep in the cavern,
His influence flowing a thousand *li*.
All things, moving and still, flourished,
And timely rains arrived.

**The Eighteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Cavernous Subtlety and Primordial Stillness, surnamed Liu, personal name Dechang, was a native of Jinling. At seventeen, he composed the *Song of the Great Dao* and presented it to Patriarch Hao. Observing his bearing and essence—ethereal, transcending the mundane—the master remarked, "A worthy one who drinks the springs of Maoshan will, in a month, be tenfold wiser than today; in a year, radiate luminous wisdom; and in a decade, hear the Dao of immortals." Thereupon, the disciple composed the *Chant of Tinkling Springs*. The master further said, "I possess the esoteric essence of the Jade Canon. If you refine your blossoms into fruit, you may harmonize heaven and humanity, transcending emotion and reason." Thus, bowing twice, he took the disciple’s vow and received the Dao. He dwelt at Ziyang Abbey for twenty years, never stepping beyond its gates. One evening at Huaniang Mountain, a youth sang: *"The sacred fungi grow long, the golden blade rings."* The mountain’s inhabitants, hearing it repeatedly, feared an army’s approach. That year, yellow *zhi* mushrooms flourished, yet withered within a month—just as the master attained true liberation.

**Eulogy:**
Dragon-script and phoenix-writ,
Can temper the kalpa’s fate.
To conceal them, value emptiness;
To preserve them, value stillness.
The whole body is the vessel—
Who clings to its form?
To fathom its destination,
Even disciples lose the Way.

**The Nineteenth Patriarch:**
Master of Purity, surnamed Wang, personal name Qixia, also named Jingzhen, styled Xuanyin, was born in Qi and raised in Lu. At seven, he passed the child prodigy examination, his immortal talent and numinous *qi* discerned as innate. In the *dingmao* year of Tianyou, fleeing chaos, he crossed south to Shouchun, where he received the Dao and its methods from Master Wen Zheng of Asking Governance.

National Master of Tang, Master of Rare Subtlety, surnamed Hao, personal name Fatong, was a native of Danyang in Runzhou. Possessing literary talent, he sat for the imperial examinations but met with no success, and so came to the mountain. Master of Luminous Mystery ordained him as a Daoist and transmitted to him all the scriptures and methods.

Having lived sixty-two springs and autumns, he was presented with two hundred thousand coins for funeral expenses, and his cap and sword were returned for burial at Leiping Mountain. Before the rising sun,
The stars gleam bright.
In the southern capital,
They lean on our immortal ruins.
Golden seal and purple sash—
What are these to me?
Those who deem them noble
Come and accept them in due course.

chunks.original_text: 宋开宝八年，平江南后刑部郎中知升州杨克让，请师为茅山威仪兼升州道正。 未几，辞还紫阳旧居。 门人受学甚众。 淳化元年四月十四日，无疾从容观化。 年七十九。 赞曰： 域中之大，唯王与道。 我以虚神，彼以位宝。 华阳之传，其书孔多。 以佐时功，阴阳大和。 二十一代宗师．□ 洞虚先生，姓蒋讳元吉，字吉甫，号碧虚子，常州义兴人。 祖麟，父器之，货药不二价，为乡里醇儒。 先生丰标绝尘，厌事生产作业，读书尤长於诗，常白日致鹤，飘飘有霄举之气，从冲虚先生应诏，居京师久之，同还紫阳，极论上 志之学，日：三洞玉书，非子不足付度。 师日：度文不度诀，吾无望於师焉。 冲虚曰：度人不度文，吾所望者，子耳。 师既受度，人日：蒋氏世德之报哉。 奉扬大教，屡有祯祥。 咸平改元三月，以经录授弟子万保冲，十五日仙去。 赞日： 朝游宝林，暮宿玉池。

「In the eighth year of Song’s *Kāibǎo* era (975 CE), after the pacification of the Southern Jiangnan, **Yang Kelan**, a *Lingzhong* of the Ministry of Punishments and magistrate of Shengzhou, invited the Master to serve as the **Weyi** of Maoshan and the Daoist preceptor of Shengzhou. Not long after, he declined and returned to his former abode at Purple Yang.

His disciples were numerous. In the first year of the *Chunhua* era (990 CE), on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, he passed away peacefully. He was seventy-nine years old.

□ **Dongxu Master**, surnamed Jiang, given name Yuangji, styled Jipu, with the sobriquet **Bixu Zi**, was from Yixing in Changzhou. His grandfather was **Lin**, and his father, **Qizhi**, sold medicine without ever marking up its price, being a refined scholar revered in his village.

The Master’s bearing was lofty and untouched by the mundane; he scorned worldly affairs and labor, excelling particularly in poetry. Often, he would summon cranes in broad daylight, drifting with an air of celestial ascent. He followed **Chongxu Master** in response to imperial summons, residing in the capital for some time before returning to Purple Yang together. There, they engaged in profound discussions on the lofty studies of the Dao, and the Master said: *"The Three Caverns’ jade scriptures—none but you can entrust them to me for transmission."*

The Master replied: *"I transmit the scriptures, not the secrets. I have no expectations from you, Master."*

**Chongxu** said: *"I transmit the person, not the scriptures. My hope rests solely with you."*

After receiving transmission, people remarked: *"The Jiang clan’s virtuous lineage is now rewarded!"*
He upheld and propagated the great teachings, and wondrous omens appeared time and again.

In the third year of the *Xianping* era (1000 CE), on the fifteenth day of the third month, he passed the Daoist canon to his disciple **Wan Baochong**, and then ascended to the Dao.

The eulogy reads:
   Morning soars through the jade groves,
   Evening rests beside the moonlit pool.

chunks.original_text: 二十三代宗师：宋国师观妙先生，姓朱讳自英，字隐芝，句曲朱阳里人，生於太平兴国元年。 八九岁从牧儿郭千村，能吹笛致鹤，父母以为不祥，弃之。 乃从朱元吉着道士服，时年十二，端拱之初也。 、继与明真张炼师居积金山顶，试辟谷术，人稍趋之，遂思远游。 至襄阳，遇异人陈铁脚挟往青城山，复过激乡，校伟太 志官古藏经。 遇水星童子武抱一，游河中府，行止神变。 景德元年嗣教二年二十九。 四年，真宗遣使祈胤，明年，仁宗生，事具宋史。 奉旨住持玉志昭应宫，山中劫建乾元天圣两观，赐号国师。 明肃太后传大洞毕法，复赐号观妙先生。 还山，得武抱一蜀中所寄书，意警责姓名显耀，暴露天机，先生对之，泣数行下，弟子莫测也。 天圣七年十一月坐化，手执祥符所赐玉如意，流汗浃体，额有凝珠，尸解之上法者，世寿五十又三。 赞日： 赤子童真，宿智冥得。

The twenty-third patriarch: **Master Guànmiào of Sòng**, surnamed Zhū, given name **Zìyīng**, courtesy name **Yǐnzhī**, a native of **Jùqū’s Zhūyáng Village**. Born in the first year of **Tàipíng Xīngguó** (976 CE).

At eight or nine, he followed a shepherd boy, **Guō Qiāncūn**, who could summon cranes by playing the flute. His parents deemed this ominous and abandoned him.

He then joined **Zhū Yuánjí**, donning Daoist robes at age twelve—at the start of the **Duānróng** era (984 CE). Later, he studied under **Míngzhēn Zhāng**, the Alchemical Master, atop **Jījīn Mountain**, testing the method of abstaining from grain. People began to gather around him, and he sought distant travels.

Arriving in **Xiàngyáng**, he met the eccentric **Chén Tiějiǎo**, who took him to **Qīngchéng Mountain**. He then passed through **Jīxiàng**, where he examined ancient scriptures in the **Gǔcáng** of **Wěidà Zhìguān**. There, he encountered the **Water Star Boy**, **Wǔ Bàoyī**, who wandered through **Hézhōng Prefecture**, his movements divine and inexplicable.

In the first year of **Jìngdé** (1004 CE), he succeeded the **Second Teaching** at age twenty-nine. In the fourth year, Emperor **Zhēnzōng** sent envoys to pray for an heir, and the next year, **Rénzōng** was born—details recorded in the *Sòng Shǐ*.

By imperial decree, he presided over **Yùzhì Zhāoyìng Gōng**. Within the mountains, he constructed **Jièyàn** and **Qián Yuán Tiānshèng** halls, receiving the title **Guóshī**. The **Empress Dowager Míngsù** transmitted the **Great Cavern’s Complete Method**, and he was further honored as **Guànmiào Zhēnsheng**.

Returning to the mountains, he received a letter from **Wǔ Bàoyī** sent from **Shǔ**, reproaching him for revealing his name and fame, exposing celestial secrets. The Master wept, tears streaming, leaving his disciples bewildered.

On the eleventh month of the seventh year of **Tiānshèng** (1029 CE), he ascended in seated meditation, holding the **auspicious jade *rúyì*** bestowed by the **Confucius Temple**, his body drenched in sweat, a pearl-like bead forming on his brow. His **corporeal dissolution** was a supreme attainment—his lifespan, fifty-three years.

Eulogy:
   **Red child’s pristine innocence**,
   **Innate wisdom, darkly realized.**

chunks.original_text: 赞日： 积金之阴，其神孔威。 港灵感符，启我仙扉。 两扉阖开，神生悬景。 丹光在林，人识余鼎。 二十五代宗师：葆真观妙冲和先生太中大夫，缢静一，姓刘讳混康，字混康，一字志通，晋陵人，景佑二年乙亥十二月二日生。 十三岁，从泰和观汤含象。 嘉佑五年，试经为道士，一夕梦神人告曰：汝欲学仙，当择名山。 尝患世无良师，每静夜登坛，散发焚香，以天为宗。 已而闻华阳毛宗师有道，往依焉。 庵居积金山，常有五色云雾结为楼殿，人异之。 一日，有三羽士造其庐，指庵之东隅，谓师日：汝即此居，抱神守中，德惠及人，当无愧前人也。 又顾师眉问日：此无作之地，道之所尚，不可有疵。 手为扪之，明日，瘢灭。 元佑元年，哲宗后孟氏误吞针喉中，医莫能出，有司以高道闻，召见，师进服符，呕出针，刺符上。 宫中神其事，赐号洞元通妙法师，住持上 志储祥宫。 绍圣四年，劫江宁府，即所居潜神庵为元符观，别劫江宁府句容县三茅山经篷宗坛与信州龙虎山、临江军合皂山。 三山鼎峙，辅化皇图。 徽宗加号元符万宁宫，赐九老仙都君玉印、景震玉杨具剑、御制诗颂书画。 赐予不能悉记，师累表灾变，上虽加叹而不能用其言，屡召至阙。 大观二年，赴召出山，掌鹿遮道，师以意喻之，一鹿触车而毙座之道左，先是，所畜鹤闻召飞去，师日：鹤去鹿毙，吾无还期。 四月至京，绾于储祥宫新作元符之别观，夜梦天帝召。 诂朝驾幸储祥，就见，因进上所诵《大洞经》十#4七日临午，鲦然解蜕，年七十二。 劫遣使护柩还山，葬迭玉峰，特诏建藏真观为祠室云。 赞日： 玉华荡空，金英散香。 群仙启关，受契紫皇。 神明之区，有相成道。 袭真绍传，天地同老。 二十六代宗师：凝神殿侍宸守静凝和法师冲隐先生，姓竺讳摩之，字志远，金陵人。 父得一，好道卫，乡里号达舫。 余杭有杜道士者，自匿其名，尝从翁游。

The **eulogy** proclaims:
At the shadowed peak of **Jīyín Shān**, its spirit’s might is profound.
The **Portals of the Numinous** respond with sacred signs—
opening the **Daoist gate** to the immortal way.
Two doors swing wide, and the **Celestial Image** takes form.
**Cinnabar light** glows in the forest—
mortals recognize the **Cauldron’s** lingering essence.

---
**The Twenty-Fifth Generation Master:**
**Bo-Zhen Guan-Miao Chong-He Master**, **Grand Secretary of the Middle Court**,
**Suffused with Stillness, One**—
Surname **Liú**, given name **Hùnkāng**, also called **Zhìtōng**,
of **Jìnlíng** lineage. Born on the **twelfth day of the twelfth month, Yǐhài**, in **Jǐngyòu’s second year** (1055 CE).

At **thirteen**, he studied under **Tāng Hánxiàng** at **Tāihé Guān**.
In **Jiāyòu’s fifth year** (1060 CE), he passed the **scriptural examination** and became a **Daoist**.
One night, a **divine figure** appeared in his dream and said:
*"If you seek the **Way of the Immortals**, choose a sacred mountain."*

Often lamenting the lack of a true teacher,
he would, in quiet nights, ascend the **altar**,
loose his hair, burn incense,
and take the **Heavenly Dao** as his master.

Later, hearing of **Huàyáng Máo Zōngshī’s** virtue,
he went to serve under him.

Residing in **Jīyín Shān’s** hermitage,
he often saw **five-colored clouds** forming palaces—
mortals marveled at this.
One day, **three羽士** arrived at his dwelling,
pointing to the **eastern corner of his hut** and saying:
*"Dwell here, embrace the **Spirit**, and guard the **Center**—
your **virtue/power** will bless others,
and you shall have no cause to shame your predecessors."*

They then gazed at his brow and asked:
*"This is a place of **non-doing**—
the **Dao** holds it sacred.
No blemish may remain."*
With their hands, they touched the mark—
and by morning, the scar vanished.

In **Yuán’yòu’s first year** (1086 CE),
Empress **Mèng** of the **Philosopher’s Son** (Zhèzōng) accidentally swallowed a needle,
and physicians could not remove it.
The officials, hearing of his **high virtue/power**, summoned him.
The Master administered a **talisman**—
she vomited up the needle, and the **inscription** appeared on the paper.

The court marveled at this, bestowing the title
**"Dòngyuán Tōngmiào Fashi" (Master of Penetrating Originality and Mysterious Perfection)**
and appointing him **Head of the Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace**.

In **Shàoshèng’s fourth year** (1097 CE),
the **Jiāngníng Prefecture** was renamed **Yuánsú Guān**,
with his **Qiánshén Ān** as its center.
He also established **Sān Máo Shān** in **Jùróng Xiàn**,
**Jīngpēng Zōngtán** in **Xìnzhōu’s Lónghǔ Shān**,
and **Hézào Shān** in **Línjiāng Jūn**—
**three peaks standing firm**, aiding the **imperial transformation**.

The **Huizōng Emperor** further honored him with:
the title **"Yuánsú Wànníng Gōng" (Palace of Originality and Universal Peace)**,
the **jade seal "Jiǔlǎo Xiāndū Jūn"** (Lord of the Nine Elders of the Immortal Realm),
the **jewel-encrusted "Jǐngzhèn Yángjù Dāo"** (Sword of Resounding Thunder),
and imperial **poetry, calligraphy, and paintings**.

Though he repeatedly submitted petitions on calamities,
the emperor, though moved, did not act upon them.
He was summoned to the capital repeatedly.

In **Dàguān’s second year** (1108 CE),
when called to court, he managed the **Lùzhē Dao** (Deer-Barrier Road).
The Master explained its meaning—
a deer struck the carriage and died at the road’s side.
Before this, his **tamed crane**, hearing the summons, flew away.
He said:
*"The crane departs, the deer dies—
I have no return."*

In the **fourth month**, he arrived in the capital,
where the **Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace** had newly built the **Yuánsú** branch temple.
That night, he dreamed of the **Celestial Sovereign’s** summons.

At dawn, the emperor visited the **Zhǐcáng Chúxiáng Palace** to see him,
and the Master presented the **ten volumes of the *Dàdòng Jīng*** he had recited.
On the **seventh day**, at noon,
he **ascended in transformation**, aged **seventy-two**.

The court dispatched officials to escort his remains back to the mountain,
where he was buried at **Diéyù Fēng**.
By imperial decree, the **Cángzhēn Guān** was built as his shrine.

---
The **eulogy** proclaims:
**Jade blossoms** drift on the void,
**golden flowers** scatter fragrant qi.
The **host of immortals** opens the **Celestial Gate**—
receiving the **Purple Sovereign’s** sacred contract.

In the **divine realm’s domain**, the **Way** is perfected.
**Inheriting truth**, **transmitting the Dao**—
**Heaven and Earth grow old together**.

---
**The Twenty-Sixth Generation Master:**
**Níngshén Diànshì Chéngjìng Chong-Hé Master**,
**Suffused with Concealment**—
Surname **Zhú**, given name **Mózhī**, also called **Zhìyuǎn**,
of **Jīnlíng** lineage.
His father, **Déyī**, loved the **Dao** and guarded its teachings,
and the villagers called him **"Dáfáng"** (the **Vessel of the Way**).

There was a **Du Daoist** from **Yúháng**,
who concealed his name,
and once studied under him.

a great snowfall, the **wood jasmine** bloomed suddenly before his abode—
the Master found this strange.
After a short while,
a **Daoist** named **Liú Hùnkāng** arrived from **Tāihé Guān** in **Chángzhōu**,
his sincerity moving the Master,
and the auspicious sign confirming his **virtue/power**—
thus, he imparted the **scriptures and methods** in that moment.

Not long after, he attained **corporeal dissolution**.
In **Chóngníng**’s first year (1102 CE),
he was posthumously honored with a title.

chunks.original_text: 熙宁元年，师将诞，父梦杜投其家，心异之。 师幼与掌儿戏，辄画地为道家像。 父拥之来山，刘先生见而奇之日：是子他日人天师也。 师喜跃，誓不复归，父亦欣然。 从之。 元佑问，与俱入朝，先生被旨住持上 志储祥宫，以师归，主元符宫事。 崇宁四年，赐法师号，兼领崇禧观，凡上恩兴建土木与夫山门之请乞，师备劳焉。 撰集科仪，营救贫乏，尤所致意。 政和三年七月三日，召门弟子日：吾今四十有六岁，昔先生尝授记以为过，叨朝廷厚恩，寿当不逾於此。 遂索笔书遗表，盥沐更衣，泊然而逝。 表闻，天子嗟悼，韶赠冲隐先生，爵及父母，葬藏真观之山。 入室弟子俞希隐、徐希和。 希和得旨嗣传印剑，希隐入青城山，今蜀人有闻洞法上道，俞公之行化也。 师美髯长身，丰骨异俗。 每入见，为上加赏云。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Sixth Year of Xīníng**, the Master was about to be born, when his father dreamed that the **Du Daoist** from **Yúháng** came to their home, and he took note of this wonder.

As a child, the Master often played with the Daoist’s young attendant, and whenever they did, he would draw patterns on the ground depicting **Daoist figures**. His father then took him to the mountain, where **Sīliú Mr.** saw him and marveled, saying: *"This child will one day become a **Human-Heaven Master**."* The Master leapt with joy, vowing never to return home again, and his father rejoiced as well. He followed the Daoist.

During the **Yuán-Yòu** period, the Master and his teacher together entered the imperial court, where **Mr.** was granted an edict to oversee the **Upper Residence of Auspicious Retention** (*Shàngzhǐ Chúxiáng Gōng*), and the Master was sent back to his home, to manage the affairs of the **Upper Residence of Original Symbols** (*Yuánfú Gōng*).

In the **Fourth Year of Chóngníng**, the Master was bestowed with the title of **Law Master**, and he was also entrusted with the **Chóngxì Guān**. For all matters of imperial favor—whether the construction of earthen and wooden structures or petitions for the **mountain gate’s** affairs—he diligently attended to them. He composed and gathered **ritual texts and procedures**, rescued the needy and impoverished, and especially devoted himself to such deeds.

On the **Third Day of the Seventh Month in the Third Year of Zhènghé**, he summoned his disciples and said: *"I am now forty-six years old. In the past, **Mr.** had instructed me that my lifespan would not exceed this age, and yet by the grace of the court, I have been granted such longevity. Thus, I have reached my limit."* He then took up his brush to write a farewell memorial, bathed and changed into fresh robes, and passed away peacefully.

When the memorial was heard, the **Son of Heaven** sighed and mourned, bestowing the title of **Suffused Concealment** (*Chónghé*) **Mr.** upon him, and conferring rank upon his parents. The Master was buried in the **mountain of the Concealed Truth** (*Cángzhēn Guān*).

His disciples included **Yú Xīyǐn** and **Xú Xīhé**. **Xú Xīhé**, upon receiving the imperial decree, succeeded him in holding the **seal and sword**. **Yú Xīyǐn** entered **Qīngchéng Mountain**, and today in **Shǔ** there are those who speak of the **Cavern Method** (*Dòngfǎ*) ascending the **Way**, for it is the **public transformation** (*xínghuà*) of **Yú Mr.**

The Master had a fine beard and a tall, sturdy frame, with a robust and uncommonly graceful build. Whenever he entered to pay his respects, the **Sovereign** would bestow special favors upon him.

chunks.original_text: 上志品篇 二十七代宗师：太中大夫凝神殿侍宸养素观妙先生，姓徐讳希和，字仲和，金陵溧水人。 祖父乐施与，笞一君尤为徐君所敬慕，命师以侍巾乌，尝从入朝。 上嘉其道才 志素，劲就陛前承恩为道士，冲隐解化，奉御笔嗣宗坛。 政和四年，召请阙，及秋还山，赐丹台郎，转太素大夫凝神殿校籍。 宣和三年，复被召内廷，建别绾处之。 四年，授前职，请归故山，勃有司礼送。 五年三月十八日，降御封香入山，有白鹤天灯之应。 每坐大静接降仙真，侍者窥之，唯闻其语。 师预知世，故常若隐忧。 靖康之初，闭靖不食。 一日集徒众日：吾仙期已迫，不得见圣人治世也。 以建炎元年七月二十五日若坐忘长往矣。 赞曰： 古先圣真，炼质返始。 往来无方，聚散无体。 我神甚真，故与之遇。 外户何人，欲闻其语。
chunks.translated_text:
**Volume XII: *Shàngzhì* (Ascending the Way) – Successor Master of the Tradition**

**The Twenty-Seventh Generation Master of the Tradition:**
**Revered Master of Mysterious Perfection and Concentrated Essence, the Honorable *Xiū Xīhé* (Surname Xu, given name Xīhé), courtesy name Zhònghé**, a native of Lìshuǐ, Jīnlíng (modern-day Nanjing). He held the title *Tàizhōng Dàfū* (Grand Minister of the Central Palace) and served as an attendant in the *Níngshén Diàn* (Hall of Concentrated Essence), nurturing the Celestial and refining the Marvelous.

His grandfather, *Lèshī Yǔ*, was a whip-bearer to a nobleman whom Master Xu held in profound reverence. Once, he accompanied his grandfather to court, where the emperor admired his Daoist talent and virtue. The emperor then granted him the title of *Dàoshì* (Daoist Immortal) and, upon his request, bestowed the *Zōngtán* (Altar of the Tradition) succession. In the fourth year of *Zhènghé* (1114), he was summoned to the capital but returned to the mountains in autumn, receiving the honorific *Dāntái Láng* (Officer of the Celestial Terrace) and promotion to *Tàisù Dàfū* (Grand Minister of Supreme Purity), overseeing the *Níngshén Diàn* registers.

In the third year of *Xuānhé* (1121), he was again summoned to the inner palace, where a separate residence was established for him. In the fourth year (1122), he was reinstated in his former rank and requested permission to return to his mountain retreat, where officials escorted him with ceremonial honors. On the eighteenth day of the third month of the fifth year (1123), the emperor bestowed a sacred seal upon him as he ascended the mountain, accompanied by the omen of a white crane and celestial lanterns.

Often, while seated in profound stillness, he would receive descending immortals. Attendants who spied upon him heard only his voice. The Master, foreseeing the world’s fate, often seemed burdened with hidden sorrow. At the onset of *Jìngkāng* (1126), he sealed himself in seclusion, refusing food. One day, he gathered his disciples and declared:
*"My term among the immortals is near—I shall not witness the Sage’s governance of the world."*

On the twenty-fifth day of the seventh month of the first year of *Jiàn’án* (1127), he departed in the state of *zuòwàng* (sitting-forgetfulness), ascending beyond.

**Eulogy:**
Ancient sages and true immortals,
Refine essence, return to origin.
Coming and going without bounds,
Gathering and dispersing without form.
My spirit is most true—
Thus I met with them.
Who stands at the outer gate?
Desires to hear their words.

The Twenty-Eighth Patriarch: Master Yuanguān, surnamed Jiang with the given name Jǐngchè, styled Tōnglǎo, of Jùróng in Jīnníng.

His brow and eyes were strikingly refined, his face marked with a celestial pattern. At eleven, he served Master Chōngyǐn Gōng. When he heard that Master Yú of the Three Caverns had entered Shu, he journeyed to see him at Éméi Mountain. Master Yú admired his devotion and deepened his teachings.

At parting, he told the Master: *"At the thirty-fifth generation, I shall return to the peaks of Fùjí Mountain and succeed as the grand master of the Dao."*

When the *Jiàn’án* rebellions arose, the *Yuánfú* Palace was destroyed, yet the Master alone preserved the sacred scrolls, the ritual seal, and the sword. Left Street Grand Coordinator Fú Xīliè reported this to the court, and Emperor Gāozōng granted gold to rebuild the temple. The Master then traveled north to the capital.

The night before his arrival, Prince Wáng Yáng Chúnzhōng and his wife, Lady Zhào, dreamed of the Celestial Worthy descending to their home. The next day, the Master visited the prince’s gate, who held him in great reverence and faith. The present temple’s mountain gate was built by the prince.

The Master often sighed: *"Because of my involvement in mundane construction, I have diminished my Daoist merit and cannot ascend in broad daylight."*

He possessed a secret white jade statue of the Celestial Worthy, which vanished at the moment of his dissolution. This occurred on the twenty-ninth day of the fourth month of the sixteenth year of *Shàoxīng* (1146).

Revered Virtue Master, surname **Lǐ**, given name **Jǐnghé**,
courtesy name **Língyùn**, native of **Jùróng**.

As a youth, he studied under Master Yuánguān,
mastering the scriptures with thorough precision.
After the Southern Migration, ritual platforms and ceremonial norms had decayed—
His refinements restored them.

One day, wandering **Léipíng Shān**, he found an ancient sword,
which he presented to Master Yuánguān.
Yuánguān replied: *"This is from the tomb of Taoist Lord Dàotóng.
Divine artifacts must not be revealed—return it to its original place."*
He indeed found the hidden tomb and placed the sword upright upon it.

A moment later, thunder and lightning struck with fierce winds, obscuring the sky.
The next day, he went to inspect—
the sword had vanished, and instead, two emerald-green **Lǐ** fruits appeared on the tomb.
Yuánguān heard of this and said: *"The sword departs, the fruits emerge—
I ought to step aside from the platform."*

He immediately honored the Master, who ascended the altar.
That day, tigers roared, deer howled,
and cranes and phoenix-like birds gathered in harmony.
The Master delighted in dispensing medicine—
whenever a person’s illness was eased,
he would cast a single coin into the **Yàojiàn Píng**.
The coins accumulated, filling the well,
and people named it the **Medicine-Money Well**.
The number of lives he saved can be inferred.

he passed away without illness,
and was buried in **Guīzhēn Shān**.

The sacred **Lǐ** fruits returned, accompanied by thunder and lightning.
Where did the green **Lǐ** come from?
They emerged as a sign of the Master’s divine resting place.

He dispensed medicine to ease suffering,
and the waters flowed, filling the groves.
With boundless generosity, he awaited those still in need.

Thirty generations of his disciples:
**Jìngzhēn** Master, surname **Jǐng**, given name **Yǐng**, courtesy name **Línghuī**,
younger brother of the **Chóngdé** Master.
He lost his father young, and with filial devotion served his mother.
At forty, he did not marry; when his mother passed,

The **Chóngdé** Master said:
*"In days past, I found two **Lǐ** fruits beneath Master Táo’s tomb—
now you have come to verify them."*

Thus, he built the **Two Lǐ Fruits Pavilion** by Bái Lǐ Stream.
The Master possessed a pure and tranquil nature,
cherishing **virtue** and frugality.
Once he entered **Great Stillness (Dàjìng)**,
he remained secluded for a month without emerging.

The **Emperor Gāozōng** repeatedly summoned him,
but he declined due to illness and never appeared.
The Emperor then bestowed upon him the title **Jìngzhēn Master** from his mountain retreat.

In the summer of the **Lóngxīng** era (1163), a drought struck,
and the **Lǐshǒu** (regional governor) visited the Master to pray for rain—
which fell abundantly, as the Master had foretold.
The **Lǐshǒu** heard of this and rejoiced.

Imperial envoys came twice more,
but the Master, feigning illness with utmost sincerity,
still refused to leave.

he discerned that **Qín** (Qin Gui) had struck **Dèng Dū** (Deng Zhi).
In the first month of the **Lóngxīng** era (1164),
he told his attendants:

until the sixth day at noon, when he **observed the Dao (guānhuà)**.

is fulfilled in its essence.

chunks.original_text: 而所福祸，则不敢私。 迷国当诛，犹冀冥报。 玄狱之警，亦辅名教。 三十一代宗师：保宁冲妙先生，姓徐讳守经，金陵溧水人。 母梦流星降其室而生，十岁不能言，有道人言自茅山来，服其丹，遂能言。 母乃令入山师事靖真。 守一抱道，不求人知。 隆兴二年，嗣主坛遗，朝廷累召，守靖真之教，确然不起。 每有桧禳，遣使即山修事，辄获嘉应。 及得江阴秦先生，手印剑付之，退藏於密。 庆元元年三月九日，辞众而逝。 赞日： 流星之光，下而为人。 敛精含辉，忘言绝尘。 神丹之来，道不苟授。 应物泊然，是善玄守。 三十二代宗师：明教先生，姓秦讳汝达，字通远，江阴人。 家贫苦学，常拾废纸遗笔学书，强记过人。 访道东南名山，保宁宗师辟绾西洞，以书致之。 先生来，与语通夕，明日以印剑奉先生登坛，众望见先生眉宇若神，皆服保宁公择贤之密、知人之明也。 绍熙二年，朝廷遣使封香营金录斋，有白鹤彩云之异，赐先生号。 庆元元年十月九日，句容簿沈来谒，比别，至山桥，闻钟声，人曰：秦宗师仙去。 沈大骇，还望先生，趺坐凝然，体犹温泽，因叹曰：相逢茶已罢，一笑便升仙。 入室弟子邢汝嘉时在京，为太一宫高士左街道录，是日还山，奉劫嗣教。 赞日： 仙学所能，非人问书。

His mother then sent him into the mountains

Then, upon meeting **Master Xīng of Jiāngyīn**,

On the **ninth day of the third month of the Qìngyuán era** (1195),

The **meteor’s** radiance, descending to become a man.

The **elixir’s** arrival, the **Dao/Way** not given lightly.
Responding to things with tranquil ease—
this is the **virtue/power** of the **Mysterious Prison’s** guardian.

surname **Qín**, given name **Rǔ Dá**,
courtesy name **Tōngyuǎn**,
a native of **Jiāngyīn**.

His family was poor, yet he endured hardship in his studies,

to the Master as he ascended the **altar**,
and the assembly saw the Master’s **brow and eye** as divine—
all marveled at the **Patriarch of Bǎoníng’s** discernment of talent
and his clarity of insight.

In the **Shàoxī** era (1191),
the court dispatched officials to offer **incense and wine**,
and to establish the **Golden Records Hall (Jīn Lù Zhāi)**,

the court then bestowed a title upon the Master.

When they parted,
at the **mountain bridge**,

**Shén** was greatly startled,

his **body** still sat upright, his **form** yet warm,

*"We met when the tea was already over,

**Thirty-Fifth Patriarch of the Lineage: Master Tónglíng Zhìdào,**
surname **Rén**, given name **Yuánfù**, courtesy name **Shānfǔ**,
a native of **Lìshuǐ**.

From youth, he bore an extraordinary nature,
discerning profound principles with penetrating insight,
his divine bearing transcending the mundane,
his bearing exuding an aura of the immortal.

**Master Xué**, the Patriarch, dreamed of a boy
raising his seat and declaring:
*"Master Yú is coming—you must yield your place."*
Yú was none other than **Yuán Guān**, the **Jiāng Lord of Éméi Mountain**,
who had spoken of the thirty-fifth Patriarch as **Rùfù**.
This was a prophecy from **Shǔ**, where the immortal had departed decades prior,
and **Xué** had once heard such words.

When the Master entered the mountains,

**Eulogy:**
One in a thousand preserves pure virtue,
One in ten billion reaches its utmost.
Pure to the extreme—he ascends as an immortal,
Humanity transformed—his passage complete.
His father did not take what was lost—
the Dao promised his son transcendence.

The Master said: *"The rain need not be conjured."*

The Emperor said: *"The drought is severe—what shall we do?"*
The Master replied: *"Your Majesty, I have heard that the people are the Emperor’s children. If Your Majesty cares for them thus, the rain will soon return. Though my conduct does not equal Heaven’s expectations, my heart knows Heaven’s will."*

The Emperor granted him a generous parting gift.

In the **Eleventh Year**, he submitted a petition to resign.

In **Bǎoyòu Six Year**, on the **third day of the first month**, he said to his disciples: *"Laughing into the boundless void—one*—thus I depart from the world with a single laugh."*

The disciples praised him:

*"The cap, sash, and robes—
these are the adornments of the outer self.
I measure my life by wandering,
returning to my true nature is no strange thing.
The worries of the **Sānglín** life
are cast aside with sweet simplicity.
Yet I do not deify myself—
the rain that nourishes is Heaven’s gift."*

Humans bear fire’s legacy,
while I return to the **True Extremity**.

The **43rd-generation Master of the Dao**:
**Master Zhenghe Xuanjing Zhenying**,
surname Xu, given name Daoji,
style name Zuyu, of Jùróng.
He was a descendant of **Master Shangzhi Xianhou**,
born in the **Song Ending Peace** era,
third year, **Bingshen** month, twenty-seventh day.

As a child, he served **Master Jiang Du**.
His teacher’s conduct was upright and resolute,
never lightly giving his word.

At the dawn of the **reign**,
after the wars had ceased,
a year of drought, famine, and plague struck,
worse in the Huai region than anywhere else.
At that time, the **Metropolitan Inspector’s office** was in **Weiyang**,
and officials gathered in the **Hall of Avoidance**,
begging the **Master** to come to **Tao**—
and when he did, the rains came,
the sickness abated.
Thus, they were granted **post stations and provisions**,
and escorted to the **court**.

The **Emperor Shizu**,
suffering from an arm ailment,
summoned him to the **Fragrant Hall of Dadu**,
commanding him to apply his **method**—
and he was cured.
Again, he was ordered to pray for snow and still the winds,
both requests met with **wondrous efficacy**.
The emperor bestowed a **jewel-encrusted crown** and **Daoist robes**,
and issued a **decree** to **greatly protect his teaching**.
With **insignia in hand**, he returned south,
and all **Sanmao Mountains** came under his governance.

In the **year twenty-eight of the Yuan era**,
on the third day of the second month,
he **subtly showed signs of illness**,
clasping his **insignia tightly**,
urgently calling **Wang Jun Daomeng**,
and passing on the **scriptures and methods** before departing,
his age **fifty-six**.

They praised him:

chunks.original_text: 仙曹署篇 华阳洞天三宫五府：日易迁宫、含真宫、萧闲宫，日太元府、定录府、保命府、童初府、灵虚府。 其太元、定录、保命，为三茅君所治。 易迁、含真，则女子成道者居之。 余官府皆男真也。 保命间用女宫。 束海青童君一年再游，校此诸宫观，见群辈 前司三官保命真人 郭四朝真人，燕国人也。 兄弟四人，秦时居伏龙之地，并得道。 四朝是长兄，真法，其司三官者六百年，无违坐#1超迁之。 四朝职满，上补九官左仙公，领玉台执。 盖郎中问久缺无人，后以茅小君代四朝耳。 定录府左右理中监 定录官僚有左、右理中监，准世长史、司马职。 又有北河司命主水官。 考些二职，常领#2九宫禁保侯职，主领应为种民者。 洞宫自二君而下，便次此三职为大矣。 左理中监，准大府长史。 昔用韩崇以居之，名不字长委，昊郡毗陵人。 少好道，林屋仙人王璋玄曾授之以流珠丹一法，崇奉而修之，大有验。 璋玄语之：子行此道，亦可以出身仕宦，无妨#3仙举也。 崇遂积仕至宛陵令，迁汝南太守，秩中二千石。 在郡积十四#4年，化政洽着，举天下最。 年七十四，璋玄乃授以隐解法，得去入大霍山，复受璋玄遁化泥丸紫户术，以度世来在洞中也。 《汉书有传》。 右理中监，准职如司马。

The **Record of the Celestial Registrar’s Bureau**—
The **Three Palaces and Five Offices of the Metropolis of Upper Clarity (Huayang Dongtian)** are: the **Palace of Easy Relocation (Yiqian Gong)**, the **Palace of Embracing Truth (HanZhen Gong)**, and the **Palace of Serene Leisure (Xiaoxian Gong**; the **Office of the Grand Primordial (Taiyuan Fu)**, the **Office of Recorded Decrees (Dinglu Fu)**, the **Office of Preserved Life (Baoming Fu)**, the **Office of Pure Beginnings (Tongchu Fu)**, and the **Office of Ethereal Emptiness (Lingxu Fu)**.

Among these, the **Offices of the Grand Primordial, Recorded Decrees, and Preserved Life** are governed by the **Three Elders of the Teachings (San Mao Jun)**. The **Palaces of Easy Relocation and Embracing Truth** are inhabited by **female disciples who have attained the Dao**. The remaining palaces and offices are staffed by **male Daoists**. The **Office of Preserved Life** sometimes employs a **female palace**.

The **Celestial Elder of the Azure Boy Who Binds the Seas (Shu Hai Qing Tong Jun)** visits the realm twice yearly, inspecting these palaces and observatories. Among the Daoist officials, the **Three Elders of the Teachings (San Mao Jun)** and **Elder of the Four Pure Ones (Gu Si Chao Jun)**, a native of **Yan State**, stand foremost. Four brothers, dwelling in **Fuyong** during the **Qin Dynasty**, all attained the Dao. **Si Chao** was the eldest. His **Daoist virtue** was such that he governed the **Three Elders of the Teachings** for **six hundred years**, never failing in his duties or being **transferred beyond rank**#1.

When his term concluded, he was **replaced in the Nine Palaces by the Left Celestial Lord of the Immortal Metropolis (Zi Xian Gong)**, who led the **Jade Platform Bureau**. It was said that the **Lingzhong (郎中)** had long been vacant, and later **Si Chao** was replaced by the **Junior Elder of the Teachings (Mao Xiao Jun)**.

The **Offices of Recorded Decrees** have **Left and Right Celestial Registrars (Zi You Li Zhong Jian)**, whose ranks correspond to those of **Worldly Longshis (Shichang Shi)** and **Celestial Masters (Sima)**. There is also the **Water Officer of the Northern River (Bei He Si Ming)**, who oversees aquatic affairs. These two offices **traditionally hold the rank of the Nine Palaces’ Celestial Guardians (Jin Bao Hou)**, and their duties are to **supervise those who should be nurtured as kindred souls**. Below the **Celestial Palaces**, these three ranks are the most exalted.

The **Left Celestial Registrar (Zi Li Zhong Jian)** corresponds to the **Longshi of the Grand Office (Da Fu Chang Shi)**. Formerly, **Han Chong** held this post, whose given name was **Buzhi Changwei**, a native of **Piling in Gaoyou**. In his youth, he took delight in the Dao. The **Forest Dwelling Immortal (Linwu Xianren)** **Wang Zhang** once **bestowed upon him the method of the Flowing Pearl Elixir (Liu Zhu Dan)**, which he reverently practiced, with great efficacy. **Zhang** spoke to him: *"If you follow this Dao, you may also attain secular office, without hindrance to your **Daoist election**#3."* Chong thus **accumulated merit and rose to the rank of Prefect of Ruanling**, later **transferred to the Governor of Runan**, with a salary of **two thousand bushels**. For **fourteen years**#4 in his office, his **administrative virtue** was profound and renowned, making him the **best under heaven**. At age **seventy-four**, **Zhang** then **bestowed upon him the method of the Hidden Resolution (Yin Jie Fa)**, enabling him to depart and enter **Mount Huo**. He further received **Zhang’s method of the Elusive Transformation (Dun Hua) Mud Pill (Ni Wan) and Purple House (Zi Hu) technique**, thus **crossing the mortal world and dwelling in the Metropolis**. (*His biography appears in the **Han Records***.)

The **Right Celestial Registrar (You Li Zhong Jian)** holds duties equivalent to those of a **Celestial Master (Sima)**.

「There was Liu Lan, whose courtesy name was **Zixiang** (later recorded in the *Han Records* as **Zixiang**#1). Lan was originally from **Yingchuan**, but in his youth he took delight in **Dao/Way and virtue**, often providing assistance without expecting gratitude, and saving the destitute—he was not a solitary figure in this. He was recommended for the **Upper Calculations** (Shang Ji) office and appointed as **Lan Zhong**, later transferred to **Governor of Chenliu**.

When he met **Master Ma Huang**, the latter told Lan: *"Your benevolence moves Heaven and Earth, and your hidden virtue is revered by gods and spirits. The **Most High** will surely commend your sincere devotion.* He has sent me to bestow upon you the **method of Longevity**. Lan knelt and struck his head in supplication, earnestly requesting to serve as an attendant. He then entered the **Tongwu Mountains** and was taught the **Eight Hidden Arts of the Earth** and the **Method of the Five Stars’ Splendor**, thus attaining the **degree of Eastern Hua**. He was then granted an office within the **Metropolis** (Dongzhong).#

The **North River Celestial Registrar (Bei He Sì Mìng)** had no incumbent, and in the past, **Yao Jun** was temporarily entrusted with the position. Jun was from **Qiantang**, having studied at the **Imperial Academy** (Taixue) and mastered the **Classics of Wei**. When calamities and omens occurred, he held the office of **Governor of Jiao**, but at the end of the **Han Dynasty**, he abandoned worldly affairs and entered **Zengcheng Mountain** to study the **Dao/Way**. He encountered **Shu Guo Youping**, a man from the **Qin era** who had long concealed himself in **Zengcheng Mountain**, a **Daoist adept** who taught Jun the **Nine Refining Qi Methods** and the **technique of aligning the stars within the heart**. After perfecting these methods, Jun came to the **Metropolis** and took charge of the **North River Celestial Registrar’s duties**, overseeing the **appraisal and punishment of water officials**. Though this position is officially registered in the **Fixed Records** (Ding Lu), in reality, it falls under the **command of the Bureau of the Purple Master (Zi Hua Guan)** in the **Celestial Metropolis** (Dongzhong). Yao Jun’s courtesy name was **Fang Zhong**.#

The *Records of the Hidden Residence* state: *"There is a tomb in Qiantang, near the **Linping** mound and altar, where the descendants of the **Miao** clan still linger in the vicinity. At times, the sound of drums and horns is heard, and outsiders dare not disturb it. It is commonly called the **Tomb of Registrar Yao**."*

Zhang Ji’s son, **Zhang Feng**, originally named **Ji Zi**, whose courtesy name was **Gongxian**, was from **Henan**. In his youth, he was called **Ji Zi**. He abandoned worldly affairs and entered **Ke Mountain**, where he met **Master Shantou**, who taught him the **Lian Yu Method**. After practicing it, he attained **Dao**. He then advanced to the **Purple Master’s Bureau**, where he was to serve as the **Celestial Marshal of the Supreme Pole (Tai Ji Xian Hou)**.»#

At times, he also held the office of **Nine Palaces Chancellor**, mirroring the **North River Marquis** in overseeing water governance. The *Record of the North River Celestial Registrar* states that he was also known as **Forbidden Preservation Marquis**, sharing the same duties by tradition. His governance was conducted within the **Celestial Metropolis**.

The **Record-Keeper’s Bureau** had its **Law Enforcer** **Chunyu Zhen**, styled **Shuxian**, who oversaw examinations of those who had attained the Dao. Zhen hailed from Shangyu in **Willow Grove**, having served as a county magistrate in **Xu Province** during Emperor Huan of Han. In his youth, he cultivated the Dao, mastered numerology and divination, and consumed **hempseed and rehmannia qi** elixirs. Later, he retreated into the **Hao Wu Target Mountain**, where he encountered the immortal **Huichezi**, who transmitted the *Rainbow Landscape Elixir Canon*. Through practice, he attained the Dao and took up his duties within the Metropolis.

The **Preservation of Life Bureau** had its **Bright Dawn Attendants**, with the **Office of Divine Mandate** overseeing the **Three Officials**—its staff numbered seven: four women and three men. The seven **Bright Dawn Attendants** held roles akin to modern **Censors-in-Chief**, all subordinate to the **Purple Master’s Domain**, with the **Preservation of Life Lord** overseeing them collectively.

**Zhou Yuanzhi** was the daughter of **Zhou Chang** (styled **Bochi**), the **River South Administrator** of Han. Chang, from **Ancheng in Ru South**, practiced hidden virtue, his deeds unnoticed yet profound. During the second year of **Yongchu**, a severe drought struck, and he collected and buried over ten thousand corpses of travelers who had died near Luoyang, erecting a righteous tomb and conducting funeral rites. The rains returned, and the harvests flourished—his deeds were many such. His hidden virtue reached the **Highest Sovereign**, who commanded Yuanzhi to receive transformation in the **Southern Palace** and ascend to the Metropolis. In her youth, Yuanzhi also cultivated the Dao, consuming **reed rhizome** for thirty years before encountering **Stone Longevity**, who taught her the **Method of Transformation and Evasion**—a form of **upper body ascension**. The *Hidden Residences* notes that Chang was Zhou Jia’s younger cousin, serving as **River South Administrator** during Emperor Chao’s reign and later as **Grand Officer of Light**. **Zhang Taozhi** was the mother of **Zhu Yu**, the **Secretary of the Capital Region** in Han. Zhu’s mother practiced hidden virtue, and though long rumored to have ascended, she was later appointed as an attendant. The *Hidden Residences* states that Zhu, from **Pei**, was among the **Eight Virtuous Ones** of the **Huan-Ling era**.

**Xia Fu**, styled **Zizhi**, of **Chenliu**, in his youth cultivated the Dao, consuming **wood-based elixirs** and mixing **mica**. Later, he entered **Hao Mountain**, where he studied the **Soul-Refining Method** under **Red-Bearded Master**, and later received the **Yellow Water Cloud Nectar Method** from **Tongxiang True Person**, attaining the Dao and ascending to the Metropolis. In his youth, Fu was summoned by a government office but departed by inscribing his resignation on a wall and hanging it from a mulberry tree—his lofty ambition thus displayed. The *Hidden Residences* and *Records of Later Han and High Virtue* state that Fu was a **Yù official** of **Chenliu**, recommended for his **upright speech** during Emperor Huan’s reign but declining the post. The *True Revelations* states that such attendants were selected based on **equanimity, rectitude, hidden virtue, and clarity of spirit**, without gender restriction. The remaining individuals cannot be enumerated here.

The **Preservation of Life Bureau** also had its **Forbidden Prohibitions Overseer**.

chunks.original_text: 张玄宾，定一襄人也。 魏武帝时举茂才，归乡里，师事西河蓟公，受服木饵，兼行洞房元白＃７之事。 后遇真人樊子明於少室，哑以遁变隐景之道。 昔在天柱山，后来华阳内，为理禁伯。 理禁伯者，主雨水官也，亦保命之监国也。 玄宾善谈空无，乃谈士，常论：无者，大有之宅，小有所以生焉。 积小有以养小无，见大有以本大无，有有亦无焉，无无亦有焉。 所以我目都不见物，物亦不见。 无寄有以成无，寄无以得无，於是无则无宅也，太空亦宅无矣。 我未生时，天下皆无无也。 自云昔曾诣蓬莱左公宋晨生，与其论无，厅得人意，桐梧诸真且不能折之。 过此以去，尚未能本有，安能本无耶？ 其高气秉理如此。 保命府丞
chunks.translated_text:
Zhang Xuanbin, a native of Dingyi in Shanyang. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei, he was recommended as a **Teacher of Virtue** (茂才). Returning to his hometown, he became a disciple of Ji Gong of Xīhé, learning to take **wooden decoctions** (服木饵) and practicing the **Dao of the Primordial Void** (洞房元白) within the **Cavern of the Mysterious** (元白之事).

Later, he encountered the **True Person** Fan Ziming at Shàoshì Mountain and was taught the **Dao of Evasion and Transformation** (遁变隐景之道). Once he resided at Tiānzhù Mountain, then moved to Huáyáng’s inner chambers, becoming the **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** (理禁伯).

The **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** was the official in charge of **meteorological rites** (主雨水官), also serving as the **Supervisor of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命之监国). Xuanbin excelled in discussing **emptiness and non-existence** (空无), being a **Daoist adept** (谈士), often expounding:

*"Non-existence* (无) *is the dwelling of the Great Existence* (大有), *and the lesser existence* (小有) *is where it arises. By accumulating lesser existence to nourish lesser non-existence* (积小有以养小无), *one perceives the Great Existence as the root of the Great Non-existence* (见大有以本大无). *Existence is also non-existence, and non-existence is also existence* (有有亦无焉，无无亦有焉). *Thus, my eyes see nothing, yet nothing hides from me. Non-existence depends on existence to achieve non-existence* (无寄有以成无), *and depends on non-existence to attain non-existence* (寄无以得无). *In this way, non-existence has no dwelling* (於是无则无宅也), *yet the Absolute Void also dwells in non-existence* (太空亦宅无矣).

*Before my birth, the world knew no non-existence* (我未生时，天下皆无无也). *I once visited* **Left Lord of Penglai**, **Song Chengsheng** (蓬莱左公宋晨生), *and discussed non-existence with him. His understanding surpassed others, and even the* **True Persons of Tongwu** (桐梧诸真) *could not refute him. Beyond this, I have yet to grasp the root of existence* (过此以去，尚未能本有)， *how could I grasp non-existence?* (安能本无耶) *Such was his lofty* **qi** (高气) *and profound Daoist principles* (秉理如此).

The **Deputy of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命府丞).

chunks.original_text: 赵威伯，束郡人也。 少受业于那鄹张先生，行抱日月之景，服九灵明镜之华。 晚在中岳受《玉佩金当经》於范丘林。 丘林，乃是汉楼船将军卫行道妇也。 《河图》云：昊楚多有人得见太平者。 常语人云：此言不虚，此验不久。 其所存明镜，非世问常法。 得道来在华阳内，为保命丞。 保命有四丞，赵主仙籍及主暴雨水，领五芝金玉草。 欲致洪雨者，可将词诣之也。 其一丞是咸阳乐长治，东卿司命君乡里人也。 为茅小君所举用汉桓帝中书侍郎。 晚从中岳李先生受步七元法，得仙。 长治主灾害。 其一丞是孟君入室弟子郑稚正也。 孟君所属用郑，主考注。 其一丞是西山唐公，房蜀人。 奉事李八伯者也。 唐主生死。 《周氏玄通记》：黄元平，东海人，年可三十许，白布垮褶。 平上绩执手版，版黑色，散在保命赵丞问，无位任。 河九李整，昔受守一法，井行洞房得道。 初在阳洛山，后来入华阳中，又主诸考祟民问之事。 整往尝为常道乡公傅，受道入山时，已年六十。 《隐居》云：整居四平山及大茅东，采石胜，服之得道。 今犹有采处。 周子良，字元稣，内讳太玄，字虚灵，永嘉人，隐居高第弟子也。 挺命降真以梁天监十四年十月二十七日白日尸解，时年二十。 隐居检集平日真降事边，类为四卷，进之武皇帝，即《周氏玄通记》也。 记中载二君选为保籍丞，此位乃始立以助领诸簿录。 其任数小而高清为美，后当度名束华，更奏上位，为保晨司，知天下神仙功夫之事、教学之方也。 保命府鬼帅 王延、傅晃、范强、徐卫，此四鬼帅，本亦道家之祭酒也。 得下解法，受书为鬼帅耳。 华阳洞玉童 《周氏玄通记》：华阳之天，司晨玉童姓景，名上期。 萧闲宫仙人 《周氏玄通记》：萧闲仙卿张子安，芙蓉冠，绛绣衣，侍者三人。 子安，名孝，荣阳架井人也。 童初府上帅 刘文饶，弘农刘宽也。
