Zhào Wēibó, a native of Shù Commandery, in his youth studied under Master Zhāng of Nàzōu. He carried the luminosity of the sun and moon and wore the radiant petals of the Nine Spirits’ Mirror. Later, at Zhōngyuè, he received the *Yùpèi Jīndāng Jīng* from Fàn Qiūlín. Qiūlín was the wife of Wèi Xíngdào, the Han *Lóuchuán* General. The *Hétú* states: *"Hàochǔ has many who have glimpsed the Great Peace."* He often told others: *"These words are not false—this proof will soon manifest."* The luminous mirror he preserved was not of the ordinary world’s craft. After attaining the Dao, he dwelled within Huáyáng, serving as Deputy of the Preservation of Life.

The Preservation of Life Bureau has four deputies: Zhào oversees the *xiānjiè* (仙籍, celestial registers) and violent storms, commanding the Five Sacred Herbs of gold and jade. Those seeking torrential rains may present petitions to him.

One deputy is Lè Chángzhì of Xiányáng, a native of Dōngqīng, where the Lord of *Sìmìng* resides. He was recommended by the *Máoxiǎo* Lady and appointed as Imperial Secretary during Emperor Huán’s reign. Later, he studied the *Bùqī Yuānfǎ* from Master Lǐ of Zhōngyuè and ascended as an immortal. Chángzhì oversees calamities.

Another deputy is Zhèng Zhìzhèng, a disciple of the Inner Chamber of Master Méng. Méng recommended him, and he oversees examinations and registries.

The fourth deputy is Master Táng of Xīshān, a native of Fáng Shǔ. He served Lǐ Bābó. Táng oversees life and death.

The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: Huáng Yuánpíng, of Dōnghǎi, was about thirty years old, dressed in white linen robes. Yuánpíng carried a black tablet, which he presented to Deputy Zhào of the Preservation of Life, though he held no official rank. Lǐ Zhěng of Héjiǔ once received the *Shǒuyī Fǎ*, practiced in a cavernous chamber, and attained the Dao. Initially at Yángluò Shān, he later entered Huáyáng, where he also oversaw examinations and rituals for the people. Zhěng had once served as a tutor for the Lord of Chángdào, receiving the Dao and entering the mountains at age sixty. The *Yǐnjū* states: *"Zhěng resided at Sìpíng Shān and Dàmáo’s eastern peak, where he gathered victory stones, consuming them to attain the Dao. The gathering site remains."*

Zhōu Zǐliáng, styled Yuánsù, with the inner taboo *Tàixuān* and the style *Xūlíng*, was a native of Yǒngjiā. As a hidden recluse, he was a disciple of Gāojì. On the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month in the fourteenth year of Liáng Tiānjiàn (515 CE), he underwent *báirì shījiě* (白日尸解, daytime dissolution of the corpse) at age twenty. The recluse compiled his daily records of true transformations, categorizing them into four volumes, which he presented to Emperor Wǔ of the Liang—this became the *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì*. The text records two officials appointed as deputies of the Preservation Bureau, a position newly established to assist in managing celestial registers. Though their duties were minor, their virtue and purity were esteemed. Later, they would ascend to *Bǎochén Sī* (保晨司), overseeing the Daoist practices of immortals across the world and the methods of instruction.

The ghostly marshals of the Preservation of Life Bureau—Wáng Yán, Fù Huǎng, Fàn Qiáng, and Xú Wèi—were originally Daoist *sàijiào* (祭酒, ritual toasts). Having mastered the *xiàjiě fǎ* (下解法, method of descending dissolution), they were appointed as ghostly marshals.

**Huáyáng’s Celestial Child of Jade**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: In the heavens of Huáyáng, the Marshal of Dawn, Jade Child, surnames Jǐng, named Shàngqī.

**The Recluse of Xiāoxián Palace**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: The Daoist official Zhāng Zǐ’ān of Xiāoxián, wearing a *fúróng guān* (芙蓉冠, hibiscus crown) and crimson embroidered robes, with three attendants. Zǐ’ān’s given name was Xiào, a native of Jiàjǐng in Róngyáng.

**Initial Marshal of the Bureau, Liú Wénráo**—Liú Kuān of Hóngnóng.

chunks.original_text: 年七十三，一旦遇青谷先生降之寝室，授其杖解法，将去入华山，行九息服气，又授以炉火丹方。 修之道成，后来洞中，主始学道者。 宽仕汉，位至司徒太尉，好行阴德，拯寒困，万民悦而附之如父母焉。 《汉书》有传。 童初府监 范幼冲，辽西人也。 受太素胎化易形之道，常旦日一存青、白、赤三气各如艇，从束方日下直入口中，抱之九十过，自饱便止，行之十年得道。 其法约，其事验，太素秘道也。 范监者，即其人也，昔为童初监，今在华阳中。 童初府仙人 童初府有王少道、范叔胜、李伯山，皆童初之标者。 少道，汉时人，王逐儿也。 运，汉时山阳太守。 范叔胜，北地人也。 魏文帝黄门郎。 李伯山，李冲父也。 冲，汉时为白马令，行阴德，或积世有道，仁行所锺。 此之仙人，皆一进再进，得入此府，未必尽径来也。 三官大理 范帅云：三官有狱官，不名廷尉，名大理。 李丰，今为大理都余一守缺，以拟王附子，不以与许虎也。 《隐居》云：李丰，字安国，改字宣国，冯斓人。 李义子，本寒微，有才 志，遂仕魏为尚书仆射。 大理即古之狱官，前汉洎魏时廷尉亦名大理。 此职是仙官也，王附子是王缺之小名，许虎即虎牙也。 地下主者 鲍说，字太玄，陈留人也。 仕晋，累征为黄门侍郎，出为南海太守。 洞监幽玄，学通经纬，人莫知之。
chunks.translated_text:
At seventy-three, one day he encountered Master Qīnggǔ in his chamber, who taught him the *zhàngjiě fǎ* (杖解法, staff dissolution method) and, as he prepared to depart for Huàshān, instructed him in the *jiǔxī fúqì* (九息服气, nine-breaths qi cultivation). He was also given the elixir furnace-fire formula. Having perfected his Dao, he later returned to the grotto, where he oversaw those who first sought the Way.

Kuān served the Han, rising to the rank of *Sītú Tàiyuè* (司徒太尉, Grand Tutor and Grand Marshal). He delighted in practicing *yīndé* (阴德, hidden virtue), rescuing the cold and destitute, and the common people rejoiced and clung to him as to parents. His biography appears in the *Hànshū*.

**Superintendent of the Bureau, Fàn Yòuchōng**—A native of Liáoxī.

He received the *Tàisù tāihuà yìxíng* (太素胎化易形, Supreme Primordial Embryonic Transformation and Metamorphosis) Dao. Daily, he would preserve the three *qì*—green, white, and red—each as a boat, drawing them from the *shùfāng* (束方, bound direction) as the sun descended, guiding them straight into his mouth. He would then embrace them ninety times before stopping once sated. Practicing this for ten years, he attained the Dao.

His method was concise, and its efficacy was proven—a secret transmission of the Supreme Primordial Dao. The "Superintendent Fàn" refers to this man, who once served as Superintendent of the Bureau and now resides in Huáyáng.

**Daoists of the Bureau:**
The Bureau of Jǔngchū includes Wáng Shàodào, Fàn Shūshèng, and Lǐ Bóshān—all its foremost figures.

**Wáng Shàodào**—A man of the Han era, surnamed Wáng, originally named Zhú’ér (逐儿). **Yùn**—a Han-era governor of Shānyáng.

**Fàn Shūshèng**—A native of Běidì, who served as *Huángmén Làng* (黄门郎, Imperial Attendant) under Wèi Wéndì.

**Lǐ Bóshān**—Father of Lǐ Chōng, who, in the Han, held the office of *Báimǎ Lìng* (白马令, White Horse Prefect). Chōng practiced *yīndé*, and it is said that either through accumulated merit over generations or innate virtue, his benevolence was profound. These Daoists all advanced step by step, gaining entry to this Bureau—not necessarily having come directly here.

**Grand Justiciar of the Three Officials:**
Fàn Shuài said: The Three Officials have a judicial officer, not called *Tíngwèi* (廷尉, Censorate), but *Dàlǐ* (大理, Grand Justiciar). Lǐ Fēng now serves as the *Shǒuhuò* (守缺, acting) Grand Justiciar of Dūyú, having been compared to Wáng Fùzǐ (王附子) but not to Xǔ Hǔ (许虎).

*The Hidden Residence* records: Lǐ Fēng, courtesy name Ānguó (安国), later changed to Xuānguó (宣国), was from Féngyàn. Lǐ Yì’s adopted son, originally of humble birth, possessed talent and ambition, and thus entered service under Wèi as *Shàngshū Fúshè* (尚书仆射, Minister of War).

The Grand Justiciar is the ancient judicial officer; during the Former Han and Wèi, the *Tíngwèi* was also called *Dàlǐ*. This is a Daoist office. Wáng Fùzǐ was the childhood name of Wáng Huò, and Xǔ Hǔ refers to *Hǔyá* (虎牙, Tiger Claw).

Bào Shuō, courtesy name Tàixuān (太玄), a native of Chénliú.

chunks.original_text: 仙曹署篇 易迁宫仙人 易迁馆、含真台皆官名也。 易迁中都有八十三人。 又有协辰夫人者，九宫之真女也。 太上往遣来教此辈法，皆以保命授书，协辰夫人主教领之也。 夫人，汉司空黄琼女黄景华也，师韩终，授以岷山丹，服之得仙。 赵素，台者，在易迁中己四百年，不肯徙，自谓天下无复乐於此处也。 素台是赵熙女。 汉时熙为幽州刺史，有济穷人功，河中救王惠等于#1族诛，行阴德数十事，故其身得诣朱陵，儿子并在洞天中。 熙怛出入定录府，素台数微服游行道巷，盼山泽以自足矣。 《玄通记》云：易迁领学仙妃赵夫人，字素台，年三十余，绿绣衣。 易迁中有高业而萧条者，有宝琼英、韩太华、刘春龙、王进贤、李奚子、郭叔香，此数人并天姿郁秀，清澄眇邈，才文拟胜，仪观骇众，此则主者之高辈仙官之奇才。 其次及得张姜子辈耳。 窦琼英者，窦武妹也。 其七世祖有名峙者，以藏枯骨为业，活死为事，故祚及英身。 韩太华者，韩安国子，汉二师将军李广利之妇也。 广利宿世有功德，今亦在南宫受化。 刘春龙，汉宗正刘奉先之女。 李奚子，李忠之祖母也。 忠，晋初东平太守，忠祖田舍人耳，而多阴德，遇大雪寒冻而不覆所积，尝露谷於园庭，惟恐乌雀饿死。 其用心如此。 王进贤，王衍女。
chunks.translated_text:
**Records of the Celestial Bureaucracy**

**Yì Qiān’s Immortal of the Transferred Palace**
The *Yìqiān Guǎn* (易迁馆) and the *Hántián Tái* (含真台) are both official titles. Within the *Yìqiān Zhōngdū* (易迁中都), there were eighty-three immortals.

There was also **Xié Chén Fūrén** (协辰夫人), the true maiden of the Nine Palaces. The *Tàishàng* (太上) once dispatched her to instruct this group in Dao, granting them the *Bǎomìng* (保命, Longevity Prescriptions) and scriptures. **Xié Chén Fūrén** oversaw their teachings.

The lady was **Huáng Jǐnghuá** (黄景华), daughter of the Han *Sīkōng* (司空, Grand Tutor) **Huáng Jūn**. She studied under **Hán Zhōng**, who taught her the *Mínshān Dān* (岷山丹, Mineral Elixir of Mount Mín). Upon ingesting it, she attained immortality.

**Zhào Sùtái** (赵素台), the *Tái* (台, Pavilion), had resided in *Yìqiān Zhōngdū* for four hundred years and refused to depart, claiming no place on Earth surpassed its joy. She was the daughter of **Zhào Xī** (赵熙).

During the Han, **Zhào Xī** served as *Yōuzhōu Cìshǐ* (幽州刺史, Prefect of Yōuzhōu) and performed deeds of mercy for the destitute. He rescued **Wáng Huì** (王惠) and others from execution in the **Hézhōng** (河中) region, accumulating over ten acts of hidden virtue. Thus, his spirit was summoned to **Zhūlíng** (朱陵), while his sons dwelled in the *Dòngtiān* (洞天, Cavernous Heavens).

**Zhào Xī** frequently entered the *Dìnglù Fǔ* (定录府, Bureau of Recorded Destiny), while **Sùtái** often wandered the Daoist paths in plain attire, content with the mountains and marshes.

The *Xuántōng Jì* (《玄通记》) states: Among the *Yìqiān* were the Daoist consorts, including **Zhào Fūrén** (赵夫人), styled **Sùtái**, aged over thirty, clad in emerald brocade.

Within *Yìqiān Zhōngdū*, there were those of high attainment yet humble demeanor: **Bǎo Qióngyīng** (宝琼英), **Hán Tàihuá** (韩太华), **Liú Chūnlóng** (刘春龙), **Wáng Jìnxián** (王进贤), **Lǐ Xīzǐ** (李奚子), and **Guō Shūxiāng** (郭叔香). These six possessed innate brilliance, serene and distant in bearing, surpassing in talent and eloquence, their presence striking all who beheld them—truly the elite among the Celestial Overseers and prodigies of the Dao. Below them stood figures like **Zhāng Jiāngzǐ** (张姜子) and his ilk.

**Dòu Qióngyīng** (窦琼英) was the sister of **Dòu Wǔ** (窦武). Her seventh-generation ancestor, **Dòu Zhì** (窦峙), practiced the art of reviving the dead through the preservation of skeletal remains, and thus his lineage’s virtue extended to **Qióngyīng**.

**Hán Tàihuá** was the daughter of **Hán Ānguó** (韩安国) and the wife of **Lǐ Guǎnglì** (李广利), the Han *Èrshī Jiāngjūn* (二师将军, General of the Two Armies). **Lǐ Guǎnglì** had accumulated merit in past lives and now resides in the *Nángōng* (南宫, Southern Celestial Bureau) receiving transformation.

**Liú Chūnlóng** was the daughter of **Liú Fèngxiān** (刘奉先), the Han *Zōngzhèng* (宗正, Minister of Ceremonial Rites).

**Lǐ Xīzǐ** was the grandmother of **Lǐ Zhōng** (李忠). **Lǐ Zhōng**, the Eastern Píng *Tàishǒu* (东平太守) of the early Jin, was once a humble *Tiánshèrén* (田舍人, rural commoner). Yet he harbored profound hidden virtue—during a severe winter, he refused to cover his stored grain, even exposing it in his courtyard for fear that sparrows might starve. Such was his compassion.

**Wáng Jìnxián** was the daughter of **Wáng Yǎn** (王衍).

chunks.original_text: 郭叔香者，王修母也。 又进贤有婢名六出，本姓田，渔阳人，浚仪令田讽之孙，年二十二三许，体貌亦整，善有心节，同在易迁。 易迁左嫔王夫人，改字太英，年二十许，紫衣。 易迁右嫔刘夫人，字玄微，年二十许，绿衣。 易迁都司学陶夫人，改名智安，年四十许，上绿下紫。 许缘母名科斗，改名，恐此即是。 易迁受学李飞华，淮阴人，来易迁中已九十四年，年可二十许，通青衣。 易迁中有柳妙姬孙芳华、阮惠香，此三子学有功夫，得度方诸第八朱台中受书，并为仙妃。 张姜子，西州人，张济妹也。 李惠姑，齐人，夏侯玄妇也。 施淑女，山阳人，施绩女也。 郑天生，邓芝母也。 此数女子，昔世有仁行令闻。 并得在洞中。 含真台仙人 含真台，是女子已得道者居之，隶太元束宫，近#2有二百人。 定录君喂言：含真台，洞天中皆有，非独此也。 此一台偏属太元府，隶司命耳。 其中有女真二人总之。 其一张微子，汉昭帝将作大匠张庆女。 微子好道，得尸解法，常服雾气，受其法於束海束华玉妃淳文期。 青童之妹也。 云雾是山泽水火之华，金石盈气，服之，能散形入空，与云雾合体。 其一传礼和，是汉桓帝外甥侍中傅建女也。 其家奉佛精进，女常旦夕洒扫佛前，勤勤祝誓，心愿仙化，神灵鉴其心，亦得来＇此，久处易迁，后始得为含真台主也。 常服五星气以得道，礼和善歌，歌则乌兽飞聚而听声焉。 茅山仙人 展上公，高辛时人。

「Guō Shūxiāng was the mother of **Yì Qiān** (王修).

Furthermore, **Yì Qiān**’s maid, known as **Liùchū** (六出), bore the surname **Tián** (田), hailed from **Yúyáng** (渔阳), and was the granddaughter of **Tián Fěng** (田讽), the Prefect of **Jùnyí** (浚仪). At around twenty-two or three, she possessed a graceful appearance and a noble character, demonstrating great virtue—she was also destined to attain transformation alongside **Yì Qiān**.

**Yì Qiān**’s left consort, **Wáng Fūren** (王夫人), adopted the courtesy name **Tàiyīng** (太英), was about twenty years old, and clad in crimson attire.

**Yì Qiān**’s right consort, **Liú Fūren** (刘夫人), with the courtesy name **Xuánwēi** (玄微), was also around twenty, dressed in emerald-green robes.

**Yì Qiān**’s *Dūshǐ* (都司学) **Táo Fūren** (陶夫人), renamed herself **Zhì’ān** (智安), was approximately forty years old, wearing garments of green above and purple below.

**Xǔyuán**’s mother, originally named **Kēdòu** (科斗), underwent a change of name—perhaps this refers to her transformation.

**Yì Qiān** studied under **Lǐ Fēihuá** (李飞华), a native of **Huáiyín** (淮阴), who had resided in **Yì Qiān**’s abode for ninety-four years. At around twenty years of age, he was skilled in the **Qīngyī** (青衣) Dao/Way.

In **Yì Qiān**’s abode, there were also **Liǔ Miàojī**’s grandson **Fāng Huá** (芳华) and **Ruǎn Huìxiāng** (阮惠香). These three individuals had cultivated profound Daoist/Wayist attainments and were granted passage into the **Bāzhōu Jūtái** (八洲朱台) of the eighth rank, where they received scriptures and became *Xiānfēi* (仙妃, Celestial Consorts).

**Zhāng Jiāngzǐ** (张姜子) was from **Xīzhōu** (西州), the younger sister of **Zhāng Jì** (张济).

**Lǐ Huìgū** (李惠姑) was from **Qí** (齐), the wife of **Xiàhòu Xuán** (夏侯玄).

**Shī Shūnǚ** (施淑女) was from **Shānyáng** (山阳), the daughter of **Shī Jì** (施绩).

**Zhèng Tiānshēng** (郑天生) was the mother of **Dèng Zhī** (邓芝).

These several women, in their past lives, had practiced benevolent conduct of great renown. They were all granted residence in the *Dòng* (洞, Caverns).

**Hánzhēntái’s** *Xiānrén* (仙人, Immortal)

The **Hánzhēntái** (含真台), where these women who have attained the Dao/Way reside, is under the jurisdiction of the **Tàiyuán Shùgōng** (太元束宫, Celestial Bureau of Grand Unity), housing nearly two hundred individuals.

**Dìnglùjūn** (定录君) remarked: The **Hánzhēntái** (含真台) exists within all *Dòngtiān* (洞天, Caverns of Heaven), not exclusively here. This particular **Hánzhēntái** (含真台) is uniquely affiliated with the **Tàiyuán Fǔ** (太元府, Grand Unity Bureau), and falls under the administration of the *Sīmìng* (司命, Bureau of Fate).

Within it, two **Nǚzhēn** (女真, True Women) oversee the affairs: One is **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子), the daughter of **Zhāng Qìng** (张庆), the Han *Zhāngdì* (昭帝, Emperor)’s *Jiāngzuò Dàjiàng* (将作大匠, Grand Master of Construction). **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子) was devoted to the Dao/Way, attaining the *Shījiěfǎ* (尸解法, Method of Corporeal Dissolution), and habitually ingested *Wùqì* (雾气, Mist Qi), receiving her teachings from **Shùhǎi Shùhuá Yùfēi Chúnwénqī** (束海束华玉妃淳文期), the younger sister of **Qīngtóng** (青童, Azure Boy).

The *Wùqì* (雾气) refers to the refined essences of mountains, marshes, rivers, lakes, and the five elements—metal and stone *Yíngqì* (盈气, Qi of Abundance). By consuming it, one can disperse one’s corporeal form into the void and merge with clouds and mist.

The other is **Chuányǐ Hé** (传礼和), the daughter of **Fù Jiàn** (傅建), the *Shìzhōng* (侍中, Attendant-in-Ordinary) and distant cousin of the Han *Huándì* (桓帝, Emperor). Her family ardently practiced the **Fó** (佛, Buddha) and made diligent progress. She would often sweep and clean before the **Fó** (佛) at dawn and dusk, fervently vowing and praying, her heart’s desire being to transform into a celestial being. The divine spirits recognized her sincerity, and she was thus granted passage to this place. After spending a long time in **Yì Qiān**’s abode, she eventually became the overseer of **Hánzhēntái** (含真台). She habitually consumed the *qì* (气) of the Five Stars to attain the Dao/Way, and **Hé** (和) was skilled in song, such that birds and beasts would fly and gather to listen to her voice.

chunks.original_text: 定录君喂言：展先生昔学道於伏龙，地植李，弥满所住之山。 先生今为九宫右保司，其尝向诸仙人云：昔在华阳下食白李，味异美，忆之未久，忽已三千年矣。 秦巴陵侯姜叔茂，得道于句曲山，种五果、五辛菜，货之以市丹砂。 叔茂曾作书与太极官僚云：昔学道於鬼谷，得道於少室，养翮於华阳，待举於逸域，时乘飕车宴于句曲。 悟言永叹代谢之速，物存人亡，我劳如何。 周太宾，有才艺，善鼓琴，昔教麋长生、孙广田即孙登也，独弦能弹而成八音，真奇事也。 杜契契，字广平，京兆杜陵人。 建安初，来渡江依孙策，后孙权用为立信校尉。 黄武二年，渐学道，遇介玫先生授以玄白卫，久久能隐形。 居中茅，后去，来良常山。 契与徐宗度、晏贤生三人俱在茅山之中，时得入洞耳。 或自采伐，贸易衣粮於墟曲，而人自不知耳。 徐宗度，晋陵人，作孙皓左典军，吕悌司马，受风谷先生气禁卫。 晏贤生，是步惊外甥，即宗度弟子也。 《隐居》云：契音薛，契字四画，契三画，分豪有异也。 契弟子二人。 其一人，孙贲孙女寒华也。 贲乃昊大帝权之同堂兄，为昊豫章太守。 父讳奚，封山阴王。 寒华先入建安。 晚来茅山，行玄白法，有少容。 其一弟子是陈世京。 世京，孙休时侍郎，少好道，数入佛寺中，与契乡里，故晚又授法。 此数子处茅山之外，非常在洞之客也。 亦时得入耳。
chunks.translated_text:
「The *Dìnglù* (定录) recorded the words of **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展上公): **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展先生) once studied the Dao/Way under **Fùlóng** (伏龙, Master Fu Long), where the mountain was planted with peach trees, filling every corner of his dwelling.

**Zhǎnshànggōng** (展先生) now serves as the **Yòubǎoshī** (右保司, Right Protector) of the Nine Palaces. He once said to the other Immortals: *"Long ago, in Huáyáng (华阳), I ate white peaches, whose flavor was extraordinary. I barely remembered the taste when suddenly—three thousand years had passed!"*

**Jiāngshūmǎo** (姜叔茂), the **Bālíng** (巴陵) Marquis of **Qín** (秦), attained the Dao/Way at **Jùqū Shān** (句曲山). He cultivated the Five Fruits and Five Pungent Herbs, selling them in exchange for cinnabar.

Shūmǎo (叔茂) once wrote to the officials of **Tàijí** (太极, the Supreme Ultimate): *"I once studied the Dao/Way in Guǐgǔ (鬼谷), attained it on Shàoshì (少室), nourished my wings in Huáyáng (华阳), and awaited my ascent in Yìyù (逸域). At that time, I rode in a gusting carriage and feasted at Jùqū (句曲)."* Reflecting on these words, he sighed deeply, lamenting the swift passage of time, the survival of things while people perish, and his own futile labor.

**Zhōu Tàibīn** (周太宾), endowed with talent and skill, excelled in playing the *qín* (琴, zither). Once, he taught **Mí Chángshēng** (麋长生) and **Sūn Guǎngdiàn** (孙广田, i.e., **Sūn Dēng** 孙登) the art of longevity. With a single string, he could play all eight tones—a truly remarkable feat.

**Dù Qì** (杜契), courtesy name **Guǎngpíng** (广平), was from **Dùlíng** (杜陵) in **Jīngzhào** (京兆). At the beginning of the **Jiàn’ān** (建安) era, he crossed the **Jiāng** (江, Yangtze River) and relied on **Sūn Cè** (孙策). Later, **Sūn Quán** (孙权) appointed him as the **Lìxìn Xiàowèi** (立信校尉). In the second year of **Huángwǔ** (黄武), he gradually began studying the Dao/Way. He encountered **Jièmiè** (介玫) Master, who taught him the **Xuánbái Wèi** (玄白卫, Mysterious White Protection) method, allowing him to eventually vanish his form.

He resided in **Zhōng Máo** (中茅), then departed and came to **Liángcháng Shān** (良常山). **Dù Qì** (杜契) and **Xú Zōngdù** (徐宗度), along with **Yàn Xiāngshēng** (晏贤生), were all in the **Máoshān** (茅山) region. At times, they could enter the **Dòng’ěr** (洞耳, Cave of Ears). Some would secretly gather and trade their clothing and food in the **Chóuqū** (墟曲) marketplace, yet no one would know of their presence.

**Xú Zōngdù** (徐宗度) was from **Jìnlíng** (晋陵), serving as **Sūn Huò** (孙皓)'s **Zuǒ Diǎnjūn** (左典军) and **Lǚ Dì** (吕悌)'s **Shìmǎ** (司马). He received the **Fēnggǔ** (风谷) Master's **Qì Jìn Wèi** (气禁卫, Qi-Protection) method.

**Yàn Xiāngshēng** (晏贤生) was the nephew of **Bùjīng** (步惊), the disciple of **Zōngdù** (宗度). The text *"Yǐnjū"* (隐居) states: *"Qì (契) sounds like 'Xuē' (薛), Qì (契) with four strokes is 'Guǎngpíng' (广平), and Qì (契) with three strokes is 'Zōngdù' (宗度). The distinction in strokes marks their difference in rank."* **Dù Qì** (杜契) had two disciples.

One was **Sūn Fèn** (孙贲)'s daughter, **Hánhuá** (寒华). **Sūn Fèn** (孙贲) was the younger brother of **Hàodà** (昊大) Emperor's **Quán** (权), serving as the **Yùzhāng Tàishǒu** (豫章太守). His father was posthumously named **Shānyīn Wáng** (山阴王), with the given name **Xí** (讳奚). **Hánhuá** (寒华) first entered **Jiàn’ān** (建安). Later, she came to **Máoshān** (茅山), practicing the **Xuánbái Fǎ** (玄白法, Mysterious White Method), and had a youthful appearance.

His other disciple was **Chén Shìjīng** (陈世京). **Shìjīng** (世京) was an official under **Sūn Xiū** (孙休) during his time as **Shìláng** (侍郎). Young, he took to the Dao/Way and frequently entered **Fó sì** (佛寺, Buddhist temples). Since he was from the same region as **Dù Qì** (杜契), he later received his teachings as well.

These disciples dwelled outside **Máoshān** (茅山), not as permanent residents within the caves. Yet, they too could sometimes enter the **Dòng’ěr** (洞耳).」

chunks.original_text: 世京服泽泻，寒汉无所服，并已三百余年，正玄白之力也。 左慈，字元放。 汉建安之中，斋戒登山，入洞虚造阴官，三茅君授以神芝，复就司命君乞玉门丹砂，得十二斤耳。 《隐居》云：元放当是为魏武所逼后仍来，所请丹砂合炉火九华丹也。 定录君哑言：左慈今在小括山，常行来，数在此下，寻更受职也。 慈颜色甚少，正得炉火九华之益。 又云。 慈初来，亦勤心礼拜灵山五年许，乃得深进东西宫耳。 即李仲甫弟子、葛玄之师。 蒲先生，失其名字，常乘白鹿采芝草於茅山。 许先生，名迈一，名瑛，字叔玄，丹阳句容人，上清真人长史穆之兄。 总角好道，从郭璞筮卦，遇泰，其上六爻发谓日，君元吉自天，宜学道。 初师鲍说，未忍违亲，谓余杭悬溜山近延陵之茅山，是洞庭西门，港通五岳，陈安世、茅季伟所尝游处，於是立精舍於悬溜，而往来茅岭之洞室，朔望时节还家定省而已。 父母既终，乃遣妇孙氏还家，改名玄，字远游。 永和二年，入居临安西山，与王右军父子周旋。 后移临海赤山，遇王世龙、赵道玄、傅太初，遂师世龙，受解束反行之道，服玉液朝脑精之法，临应得道。 三官都禁左郎遣典柄侯周纺、主非使者严白虎，出丹简罪簿各一通，诂瑛诸愆，如其无答，便当执之。 先生怖惧，强长啸叱咚而答日：大道无亲，唯善是与； 天地无私，随德乃矜，是以圾泉流血，无违龙髯之举； 三苗丹野涿鹿绛草，岂妨大圣灵化高通上达耶？ 吾七世祖许子阿者，积仁蕴德，阴加乌兽。 凶荒疫疠之年，人民百遗一口，子阿散财拯救，自营方＂药，垂死得济者四百八人。 德坠我等，应得登升者三人，度世者五人，录名太上，策简青官，岂是汝辈所可豫乎？ 言毕，会定录君遣中候李遵握火铃而至，纺等笑而走，即得度名东华，为地仙之中品。 复迁盖竹山中，故后与长史书日，恨吾遭良师之太晚，反滞性之不早，吾得道之状艰辛情事。 定录真君当已说之矣。 崇赖成覆救济之恩，天地不能脍也。 任真人，名敦、字尚朴，乐安博昌人。 少学道罗浮山，晋永嘉初游岱宗，后居华阳南洞，修步斗道及洞玄五符，能役鬼召神，隐身分形。 饮酒，服木黄精饵。 凿地入七尺，取赤坛土，状如赤石脂，日吞九丸时复出入人问。 手执经科，教示愚人，远近穆然从化。 永昌元年壬午岁，大雪盈丈，乌兽半死，施食山中，虎鹿数十同拿而游。 每出，掌虎垂耳弭尾从之。 一日，忽见一人身长丈许，着五彩玄黄衣，至前揖问日：卿是何鬼神？ 何为来此？ 其人称是和那老君使来，问信，公名已上丹简矣。 真人尝为洞天绾主，炼大丹成，语弟子日：吾当寻括苍、盖竹诸山去矣。 其故宅即今崇寿观。 《云岌七签》、《赤城志》俱有传。 桃源黄尊师，法录甚高，於茅山修天尊殿，讲说教化，日有数千人。 时讲筵初合，忽有一人排闯叫呼，人貌厅黑，言辞鄙陋，腰插骡鞭，如随商客骡驮者，骂曰：道士，奴正热时聚众作何物？ 不向深山学修道，还敢作漫语耶？ 黄尊师不测下讲筵逊词，众人悉惧，不敢抵捂。 良久，辞色稍和，日：岂不是修台殿，都用几钱？ 黄日：要得五千#3贯。 日：尽搬破铛釜及杂铁来。 约八九百斤，掘地为炉，以火销之，探怀中葫芦，泻两丸药，以物搅之。

Zhèngyīng (左慈), courtesy name Yuànfàng (元放), during the **Jiàn’ān** (建安) era of the **Hàn** (汉), observed strict fasting and ascetic practices before ascending **Máoshān** (茅山). He entered the **Dòngxū** (洞虚) to craft an **yīnguān** (阴官, shadowy official), where the **Sānmáo Jūn** (三茅君) bestowed upon him divine **shénzhī** (神芝, sacred fungi). He then sought **Yùmén Dānshā** (玉门丹砂, cinnabar) from the **Sīmìng Jūn** (司命君), obtaining twelve *jīn* (斤).

The *Yǐnjū* (《隐居》) states: Yuànfàng was likely driven by **Wèiwǔ** (魏武) before returning, and the cinnabar he requested was used to forge the **Lúhuǒ Jiǔhuá Dān** (炉火九华丹, Nine-Petal Furnace Elixir).

The **Dìnglù Jūn** (定录君) spoke in silence: *"Zhèngyīng now resides at Xiǎokuò Shān (小括山), frequently appearing here. He often comes below, soon to be granted an official post."* His countenance remained youthful, a testament to the benefits of the **Lúhuǒ Jiǔhuá** (炉火九华).

It was also said that Zhèngyīng initially devoted five years to fervent worship of the **Língshān** (灵山, Sacred Mountain) before gaining deeper access to the **Dōngxī Gōng** (东西宫, Eastern and Western Palaces).

He was the master of **Lǐ Zhòngfǔ** (李仲甫) and the teacher of **Gě Xuán** (葛玄).

**Pú Xiānsheng** (蒲先生), whose name is lost, often rode a white deer to gather **zhīcǎo** (芝草, fungi) on **Máoshān**.

**Xǔ Xiānsheng** (许先生), named **Mài** (迈) and **Yīng** (瑛), with the courtesy name **Shū Xuán** (叔玄), hailed from **Dānyáng Jùróng** (丹阳句容). As a youth, he took to the Dao/Way, consulting **Guō Pú** (郭璞) on divination. The *Tài* (泰) hexagram’s sixth line revealed: *"You shall attain supreme fortune from Heaven; it is fitting to study the Dao."*

Initially, he followed **Bào Shuō** (鲍说) but hesitated to abandon his parents. He settled near **Xuánliù Shān** (悬溜山) in **Yánháng**, close to **Yánlíng’s** (延陵) **Máoshān**, which he regarded as the western gate of **Dòngtíng** (洞庭). Its channels connected to the **Wǔyuè** (五岳), a place once frequented by **Chén Ānshì** (陈安世) and **Máo Jìwěi** (茅季伟). He established a **jīngshè** (精舍, hall of refinement) at Xuánliù, traveling between the **Máolíng** (茅岭) caves, returning home only on the **suòwàng** (朔望, new and full moons) to pay respects.

After his parents’ passing, he sent his wife, **Sūn Shì** (孙氏), back to her family, renaming himself **Xuán** (玄) with the courtesy name **Yuǎnyóu** (远游).

In **Yǒnghé Èrnián** (永和二年), he settled at **Lín’ān Xīshān** (临安西山), associating with **Wáng Yòujūn** (王右军) and his son. Later, he moved to **Línhǎi Chìshān** (临海赤山), where he encountered **Wáng Shìlóng** (王世龙), **Zhào Dàoxuán** (赵道玄), and **Fù Tàichū** (傅太初). He then became **Shìlóng’s** disciple, receiving the **jiěshù fǎnxíng** (解束反行, Unbinding and Reversal Technique) and the method of ingesting **yùyè cháo nǎojīng** (玉液朝脑精, Elixir of Jade Dew and Morning Brain Essence), achieving transcendence through timely responses.

The **Sānguān Dūjìn** (三官都禁) dispatched **Zuǒ Láng** (左郎) **Zhōu Fǎng** (周纺), bearing the **Dānjiǎn** (丹简, Elixir Register) and **Zuìbù** (罪簿, Crime Ledger), alongside **Zhǔfēi Shǐzhě** (主非使者) **Yán Báihǔ** (严白虎). They demanded an accounting of **Yīng’s** (瑛) transgressions, threatening arrest if unanswered.

Terrified, **Xuānsheng** (先生) forcefully exhaled and retorted:
*"The Dao/Way knows no favoritism—only virtue is embraced.
Heaven and Earth hold no bias—they reward virtue alone.
Thus, even if **Jīquán** (圾泉) flows with blood, it cannot hinder the **Lóngrán** (龙髯, Dragon-Beard) ascension.
The **Sānmiao** (三苗) of **Dānyě** (丹野), **Zhúlù** (涿鹿), and **Jiàngcǎo** (绛草)—how could they obstruct the **Dàshèng** (大圣) from attaining supreme enlightenment and transcendent reach?

My seventh-generation ancestor, **Xǔ Zǐ’ē** (许子阿), amassed virtue and power, his deeds unseen yet profound.
In years of famine and plague, when people barely survived, **Zǐ’ē** distributed wealth to rescue them, personally concocting remedies—reviving **sìbǎi bāshí** (四百八十) near-death individuals.
His virtue descended upon us, granting three ascensions and five salvations of the world, with names recorded by the **Tàishàng** (太上). How could such glory be yours to anticipate?"

As he spoke, **Dìnglù Jūn** (定录君) sent **Zhōnghòu Lǐ Zūn** (中候李遵), who arrived clutching a **huǒlíng** (火铃, fire bell). **Zhōu Fǎng** and his companions laughed and fled. **Xuānsheng** was then enrolled in **Dōnghuá** (东华), becoming a **Dìxiān** (地仙) of the middle rank.

Later, he relocated to **Gàizhú Shān** (盖竹山), lamenting in a letter to his **Chángshì** (长史):
*"I regret encountering my master too late, delaying my nature’s refinement. The arduous path to transcendence is fraught with hardship."*

The **Dìnglù Zhēn Jūn** (定录真君) had already revealed this.

*"The debt of gratitude to the **Chónglài Chéngfù Jiùjì** (崇赖成覆救济) is beyond what Heaven and Earth can repay."*

**Rèn Zhēnrén** (任真人), named **Dūn** (敦) with the courtesy name **Shàngpǔ** (尚朴), hailed from **Lè’ān Bóchāng** (乐安博昌). As a youth, he studied the Dao/Way on **Luófú Shān** (罗浮山). During the early **Yǒngjiā** (永嘉) era of the **Jìn** (晋), he traveled to **Dàizōng** (岱宗, Mount Tai), later residing in **Huáyáng Nándòng** (华阳南洞). He mastered the **Bùdǒu Dào** (步斗道, Step-and-Fight Technique) and **Dòngxuān Wǔfú** (洞玄五符, Five Talismans of the Mysterious Void), capable of summoning ghosts and gods, hiding his form, and splitting his shape.

He consumed alcohol and **mùhuángjīng** (木黄精, yellow horny goat weed) elixirs. Digging seven *chǐ* (尺) into the earth, he extracted **chítán tǔ** (赤坛土, red furnace soil), resembling **chìshízhī** (赤石脂, red stone fat). He ingested nine pills daily, entering and exiting the earth.

Holding **jīngkē** (经科, scriptural formulas), he taught the unenlightened, drawing followers from afar.

In **Yǒngchāng Yīnián** (永昌元年), during the **Rénwǔ** (壬午) year, a snowfall of over *zhǎng* (丈) killed half the **wūshòu** (乌兽, dark beasts). He fed them in the mountains, and **hǔlù** (虎鹿, tigers and deer) numbering in the tens gathered to eat from his hands.

Each time he ventured out, a tiger with drooping ears and curled tail followed him.

One day, a man of towering stature—over *zhǎng* (丈) tall—clad in **wǔcǎi xuánhuáng yī** (五彩玄黄衣, five-colored dark-yellow robes) approached, bowing and asking:
*"Who are you, ghost or god? What brings you here?"*

The man identified himself as a messenger of **Hénà Lǎojūn** (和那老君), inquiring about his credentials. The **Zhēnrén** replied that his name had already been recorded in the **Dānjiǎn**.

The **Zhēnrén** had once served as the **Dòngtiān Jiǎnzhǔ** (洞天绾主, Master of the Cavernous Heaven), refining the **Dàdān** (大丹, Great Elixir). To his disciples, he declared:
*"I shall soon depart for **Kuòchāng** (括苍) and **Gàizhú** (盖竹) Mountains."*

His former residence became the **Chóngshòu Guàn** (崇寿观).

The *Yúnjì Qīqiān* (《云岌七签_) and *Chìchéng Zhì* (《赤城志_) both record his biography.

**Táoyuán Huáng Zūnshī** (桃源黄尊师), with lofty **fǎlù** (法录, spiritual records), constructed the **Tiānzūn Diàn** (天尊殿) on **Máoshān**, delivering sermons that drew thousands daily.

As the lecture platform was being assembled, a man burst in, his face dark, his speech vulgar, a **luóbiān** (骡鞭, donkey whip) at his waist—like a merchant’s attendant. He sneered:
*"Daoists! Gathering crowds while the world burns—what foolishness! You dare speak idly instead of secluding yourselves in the mountains to cultivate?"*

**Huáng Zūnshī** (黄尊师), unperturbed, descended from the platform without reply. The crowd, terrified, dared not protest.

After some time, the man’s demeanor softened:
*"Aren’t you building a hall? How much will it cost?"*
**Huáng** replied: *"Five thousand *guàn* (贯)."*
*"Bring every broken pot, pan, and scrap of iron—eight or nine *jīn* (斤) worth. Dig a furnace, melt them down, then stir in two pills from my gourd."*

He reached into his robes and poured out the elixirs.

chunks.original_text: 少顷，出火已成上银。 日：此合得万余贯，修观计用有余，讲则所获无多，但罢之。 黄与徒众深相谢，问其所欲，笑出门去，不知所之。 后十余年，黄奉召来京，忽於长安街西遇插骡鞭者，肩一袱子，随骑驴老人行，全无茅山气色。 黄欲趋拜，乃拨手指骑驴者，复连 叩头，黄但遥磕礼而已。 老人发尽白， 视之十四五女子也。 事见逸史。 茅山志竟 #1于：原缺，据笪本增。 #2近：原文前有『中』，据笪本删。 #3千：原作『十』，据笪本改。 茅山志卷之十五 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造

After a short while, the fire had fully melted the silver. The man said:
*"This yields over ten thousand *guàn*—more than enough for the observatory’s construction. The lecture hall’s needs are modest; let it be abandoned."*

**Huáng** and his disciples bowed deeply in gratitude, asking what he desired. The man laughed and left through the gate, his destination unknown.

Ten years later, when **Huáng** was summoned to the capital, he suddenly encountered the man with the donkey whip on a street in Chang’an. The stranger carried a bundle over his shoulder, riding a donkey beside an elderly figure—no trace of his former Te Mountain aura remained. **Huáng** moved to kneel in reverence, but the man raised his hand and pointed at the donkey rider, who then bowed repeatedly. **Huáng** merely returned a distant obeisance from afar.

The old man’s hair was now entirely white, and his appearance resembled that of a fourteen- or fifteen-year-old girl. The account appears in the *Lost Histories*. The *Te Mountain Records* concludes here—originally incomplete, supplemented from the *Pí* edition.

chunks.original_text: 采真游篇 昊绰，神凤初采药华阳洞口，见一小儿子把大珠三颗，戏於松下，绰因前询谁氏之子，儿奔入洞中，绰恐为虎所伤，遂相从，连呼救之。 行不三十步，见儿化作龙形，一手握三珠填左耳中。 绰素刚胆，以药斧层之落左耳，而三珠已失所在，龙亦不见。 出不十余步，洞门闭矣。 宋宣和封绰为养素先生，事见《龙城录》。 薛彪之，晋陵人也。 少不狎俗，无羡荣秩。 齐建武二年，停束）lI，采访真秘，三年乃反，启劝於大茅山束岭洞天馆，行道松飧涧饮，弥历年岁也。 馆即晋任真人於此成道坛，鳌犹存，殊有灵验，先生是以访古求真而即地焉。 冯法先，字法远，晋陵曲阿人。 陈文帝天嘉元年，遣中庶虞荔诣法远，营大斋三日，中时行道，每礼一拜，锺辄□自呜，诵步虚尽契，亦复如此，莫不嗟异。 马枢，字要理，扶风那人也。 博极经史，尤善佛书及《周易》、《老子义》。 邵陵王纶为南徐州刺史，引为学士。 纶举兵援台，留书二万卷付枢。 枢肆志寻览。 殆褊，乃喟然叹日：吾闻贵爵位者以巢由为栓桔。 爱山林者以伊吕为莞库。 束名实则刍芥柱下之高，骯清虚则枇糠席上之说。 稽之笃论，亦各从其好也。 比求志之士望途而，岂天之不惠高尚，何山林之无闻甚？ 乃隐於茅山，有终焉之志。 陈天嘉元年，文帝征为度支尚书，辞不应命。 目精洞黄，能视间中物。 有燕双巢其庭树，驯狎阑应，时至几案，春来秋去几三十年。 大建十三年卒，撰《道觉论》行于世。 戴胜，字世荣，晋陵曲阿人。 少而出，家贫尽，为乡人刘表佣作。 表是将士，好畋猎，胜乃弃之，来入茅山也。 褚雅，字玄通，昊郡钱唐人。 梁末隐山中，重施轻财，拯物无厌。 营田若熟，以乞贫者与人共居。 常旦起洒扫。 取水，褊以周给觅樵薪乞人。 夏月种瓜，资人来取也。 桓法闻，字彦舒，束海丹徒人，陶隐居高第弟子也。 为梁南平王清远馆主，任事绿多绪，有废研修，乃於＃１郁冈山右别筑玄洲精舍。 周处士弘让题精舍壁云：李基遗故鼎，赵啸绝风云。 悠悠升载下，更复属夫君。 王僧辩使陆晃图闱及己形与周处士像於障面，又飞白写闻与僧辩，书於障背，仍以遗阅。 世有《指桓记》云：阅为隐居执爨者。 宋道士贾善翔集高道传，谬用其说。 《隐居》书闻入山诗及隐居墓碑，可表也矣。 孙文韬，一名韬，字文藏，会稽刻县人。 入山师隐居，参授真法，及见杨、许三真手书上经，稍学模写，遂大巧妙。 后学大王书，殊有深分，当时称之。 南洞九锡文碑、许长史旧馆坛碑，并韬之边也。 南洞碑阴云：文韬心柔容毅，边方智圆，既业不草物，故异简刊焉。 钱妙真，晋陵女子也。 辞家学道於隐居，普通年中，独处幽岩，诵《黄庭经》，时年十九，所居燕口洞，积三十年而仙。 将去，手裁书并诗七首与隐居别，一日佩白练隐形入洞，劫其地为燕洞宫。 至今女官奉祠。 上清道士丹阳葛景宣仙公之胤： 太中兰陵萧世显，解缨帝室，服道山林。 平昌幸修之，精进勤修，古宿所推。 兰陵邵元泰，道化弘远。 束海徐伯迁，德教惧洽。 菩提白塔行禅比丘会稽释智渊，业总五乘，义该两教。 陪真馆主、义兴蒋负刍，去来茅山，有志柄托。 齐元二年，劫请於宗阳馆行道练纳修备。

**Admonitions on the Perfected Way**

**Hàochuò** was gathering the *Zhen* when, in the early years of the divine *Fèng* era, he came to Huáyáng Cave and saw a young boy playing with three large pearls beneath a pine. Chuò approached and asked whose son he was. The boy fled into the cave, and fearing he might be harmed by a tiger, Chuò followed, calling out for help. After no more than thirty paces, the boy transformed into a dragon, clutching the three pearls to fill its left ear. Bold by nature, Chuò struck the dragon’s ear with his alchemical axe, causing the pearls to fall and vanish, and the dragon itself to disappear. Before he had taken ten more steps, the cave entrance sealed shut. During the Song dynasty’s *Xuānhé* era, Chuò was ennobled as *Yǎngsù* Master. The account appears in *The Dragon City Records*.

**Xuè Biāozhī**, a native of Jìnlíng, from youth shunned worldly affairs and held no desire for rank or wealth. In the second year of the *Jiànwǔ* era of the Qi dynasty, he suspended his worldly duties to seek the hidden and mysterious. After three years, he returned and reported to the *Shùlǐng* Hall of the Great Te Mountain, where he practiced the Dao, subsisting on pine shoots and spring water, passing the years in seclusion. The hall was where the *Rèn Zhēnrén* of Jin had once attained perfection, and the tortoise-shell tablet remained, its spiritual efficacy undiminished. Thus, the master sought the ancient and true, dwelling right there.

**Féng Fǎxiān**, styled *Fǎyuǎn*, was from Qǔ’ē in Jìnlíng. In the first year of the *Tiānjiā* era of the Chen emperor, the court dispatched the middle official *Yú Lì* to summon Fǎxiān, who was then conducting a three-day grand ritual. At each bow in the ceremony, the bell chimed on its own, and when he recited the *Bùxū* scripture, the same phenomenon occurred—all marveled at it.

**Mǎ Shū**, styled *Yàolǐ*, hailed from *Nà* in Fúfēng. He was well-versed in the classics and histories, particularly skilled in Buddhist texts, the *Zhōuyì*, and the *Lǎozǐ Yì*. When the Prince of Shàolíng, *Lún*, served as Prefect of Nánxú, he appointed Shū as his scholar-official. When Lún raised troops to aid the capital, he entrusted Shū with twenty thousand volumes of books. Shū devoted himself to their study, then sighed deeply, saying: *"I have heard that those who prize noble rank and office regard Confucius and Yan Hui as the highest treasures. Those who cherish mountains and forests revere Yi Yin and Lü Shang as their greatest wealth. To bind oneself to name and gain is like the lofty grass beneath the pillars of a hall, while to despise purity and emptiness is to speak of the worthless husks on a mat. Examining profound teachings, each follows their own inclination. Yet why do those who seek the Way gaze longingly at the path, as if Heaven does not favor the lofty and virtuous? Why is there no fame in the mountains and forests?"* He then retired to Te Mountain, resolved to remain there. In the first year of the *Tiānjiā* era of the Chen dynasty, the emperor summoned him to the post of *Dùzhī Shàngshū*, but he declined. His vision was keen, able to discern objects at a distance. Swallows nested in his courtyard trees, tame and familiar, perching on his desk and coming and going for nearly thirty years. He passed away in the thirteenth year of the *Dàjiàn* era, leaving behind his *Dao Jué Lùn*, which circulated in the world.

**Dài Shèng**, styled *Shìróng*, was from Qǔ’ē in Jìnlíng. At a young age, he left home, his family’s wealth exhausted, and became a laborer for the village elder *Liú Biǎo*, who was a military officer and fond of hunting. Shèng abandoned him and came to Te Mountain instead.

**Chǔ Yǎ**, styled *Xuántōng*, was from Jiānyún in Hào Commandery. In the late Liang dynasty, he lived in seclusion among the mountains, generously giving away wealth and aiding the needy without measure. When his fields were ready for harvest, he would share the produce with the poor, allowing them to dwell with him. He would rise early each morning to sweep and water, and when fetching water, he would ensure that those gathering firewood and begging for alms were also provided for. In summer, he would plant melons, offering them to those who came to take them.

**Huán Fǎwén**, styled *Yànshū*, was from Dāntú in Shùhǎi, a disciple of the *Táo Yǐnjū* Ertóu. He served as the *Guǎnzhǔ* for the Prince of Nánpíng, *Qīngyuǎn*, but finding his duties too burdensome and hindering his cultivation, he built a *Xuánzhōu Jīngshè* on the right side of *Yùgāng* Mountain. The recluse *Zhōu Chǔshì* inscribed on the wall of the hall:
*"Li Jī’s ancient tripod remains,
Zhào Xiào’s winds and clouds depart.
Lofty and boundless, ascending and descending,
Now entrusted to you, O Master."*

The Prince of Wáng Sēngbiàn commissioned *Lù Huáng* to paint portraits of himself and the recluse on a screen, and also had *Fēibái* script the inscription by Sēngbiàn on the reverse. There exists a *Zhǐ Huán Jì* stating that Huán was the recluse’s attendant. The Daoist *Jiā Shànxiáng* of the Song dynasty compiled the *Transmissions of High Masters*, mistakenly adopting this claim. The *Yǐnjū* book contains his poems upon entering the mountains and his tomb inscription, which suffice to clarify the matter.

**Sūn Wéntáo**, also named *Wéi*, styled *Wénzàng*, was from Kè County in Kuàijì. He entered the mountains to study under the recluse, receiving true teachings, and later saw the *Shàngjīng* handwritten by the Three True Ones, *Yáng* and *Xǔ*. He practiced copying them, becoming highly skilled. He then studied the script of the Great King, achieving profound mastery, and was praised by contemporaries. The *Jiǔxì* inscription of the Nán Dòng and the old *Guǎn* stele of *Xǔ Zhàngshì* were both his work. The reverse of the Nán Dòng stele reads:
*"Wéntáo’s heart was gentle yet resolute,
His wisdom vast and his insight profound.
Having mastered the arts, he left no trace—
Thus, his name was carved in stone."*

**Qián Miàozhēn**, a woman of Jìnlíng, left her family to study the Dao under the recluse. During the *Tōngguāng* era, she lived alone in a secluded cave, reciting the *Huángtíng Jīng* at age nineteen. Her dwelling, *Yànkǒu Dòng*, remained for thirty years before she ascended. As she departed, she left a handwritten letter and seven poems to bid farewell to the recluse. One day, she donned white silk, vanished into the cave, and seized the land to establish the *Yàn Dòng Palace*. To this day, female officials tend her shrine.

**The Lineage of the Upper Clarity Daoist Gě Jǐngxuān of Dānyáng:**

**Shuò Shìxiǎn** of Lánlíng, having severed ties with the imperial house, devoted himself to the Dao in the mountains. His diligence in cultivation was unmatched, earning praise from ancient masters.

**Shào Yuàntài** of Lánlíng, whose Daoist influence was vast and far-reaching.

**Xú Bóqiān** of Shùhǎi, whose virtue and teachings were profound and harmonious.

**The Venerable *Bìqí* Huìzhī** of Kuàijì, a monk who practiced *Pútí* meditation, mastering the Five Vehicles and encompassing both teachings.

**Jiǎng Fùchú**, the *Guǎnzhǔ* of Yìxìng, who frequently visited Te Mountain with the resolve to entrust his fate to it.

In the second year of the *Yuán* era of the Qi dynasty, he was invited to the *Zōngyáng Guǎn* to practice and refine his cultivation.

**Daoist Masters of Distinctive Spirit and Virtue:**

Unmatched in cultivation, surpassing the age of *méishòu* (a traditional measure of longevity, often 120 years), and refining their *qi* through ascetic practice, they were:

The *Huàyáng* **Guànzhǔ** (Master of the *Huàyáng* Hall), **Lù Yìzhòng** of Hào Commandery.

The *Huàyáng* Hall **Guànzhǔ**, **Wáng Fǎmíng** of Tàiyuān.

These two masters, both of lofty resolve, dwelled in seclusion, never settling among the common halls.

The *Chóngyuán* Hall **Guànzhǔ**, **Zhāng Yuánzhī** of Jiāxīng, who was appointed in the *Jiànwǔ* era. He also built a pavilion atop *Jūn* Mountain, where white cranes would alight, and thus named it **Hètái** (Crane Pavilion).

The **Jūyáng Hall Guànzhǔ**, the Daoist **Pān Yuánwén** of Shàngqīng, who lived in seclusion and revered the *Sānmáo Èrxǔ Jīngbǎo* (Scriptures of the Three Teachings of Máo and the Two Teachings of Xǔ). The hall was established in the 12th year of the *Tiānjiàn* era by his invitation.

The **Sìzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Xǔ Língzhēn** of Jǔróng in Dānyáng, the sixth-generation descendant of the *Xǔ Zhēnrén* (True Person of Xǔ) lineage of the Jìn dynasty. The hall was founded in the 3rd year of the *Tiānjiàn* era by his invitation.

The **Chóngxū Hall Guànzhǔ**, Daoist **Zhāng Yì** of Hào Commandery, originally the Daoist hall established by Sòng Míngdì in the *Cháogōu* (Tidal Gorge) to honor the great *Dàfǎshī* (Grand Master) **Lù Xiūjìng**. In the *Qi Yǒngmíng* era, it was relocated to **Jiānglíng** by **Yì** (Effort), and **Táo** (the Master) revived it once more.

The **Zōngzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Wú Xiànzé** of **Qū’ē** (Curve and Ease), whose Daoist practice was profound and whose virtue was esteemed.

chunks.original_text: 宗元逻主，昊郡陆僧回。 神州邑主，法身薄九真。 建真邑主，法身韩休明。 朝宦法身，延陵曹玄明。 治令法身，彭城郑休之。 治丞法身，山阴董道盖。 桐梧先生王轨，字洪范，一字道模，琅琊临沂人也。 曾祖筠，梁散骑常侍。 祖钴，简文太子洗马。 父瑜，陈着作佐郎。 先生年二十事王法主，为巾瓶弟子，积十六年。 从法主际遇隋唐二代。 初，大业十一年，奉诏河南二十四郡博访异人。 贞观问，奉劫改建华阳观。 乾封二年十一月朔#4旦顾谓门人日：吾昨梦三羽人执简，告日：华阳天宫用师为神仙万人主者，兼知校领省官，请当行矣。 吾昔在桐梧山，已感斯梦，须应此召。 至八日，沐浴易衣冠，九日，端简而化。

chunks.original_text: 年八十八，葬雷平山陶真人墓右。 王昱，有术解，居洛阳青萝山，乡里见之已数百岁，常有少容。 开元中，征至京师，玄宗见其童颜翼发，颇加恩礼。 时玄宗於茅山得杨、许众真及陶贞白所写上清诸经、真迹。 其经阙文十三纸，使昱责玺书信币诣紫阳观，玄静先生补书之。 若日：朕不欲命臣干冒於先生，委卿专往，必冀神仙手笔，今古相续耳。 昱到山之日，灵鹤翔呜，玄静书经之时，神人降其室，皆精诚所应也。 事见《仙传拾遗》。 昊筠，鲁中儒，入嵩山依宗师潘师正为道士，传上清之法，苦心钻仰，乃尽通其术？ 开元中，南游金陵，访道茅山，久之东，游天台。 尤善着述，玄宗闻其名，征之，与语甚悦，令待诏翰林。 未几，求还茅山，许之。 既而中原大乱，江淮多盗，乃束游会稽天台，与李白、孔巢父诗篇酬和，逍遥泉石，竟终於越中。 见《唐书本传》。 崔希真，客锺陵，舍于郡西，善鼓琴，工绘事兼好修炼之卫。
chunks.translated_text:
In his eighty-eighth year, he was buried beside the tomb of the Daoist Master Táozhēn on Léipíng Mountain.

Wáng Yù possessed Daoist arts and resided on Qīngluó Mountain in Luòyáng. The villagers, seeing him, already took him for several hundred years old, yet he always maintained a youthful appearance. During the **Kāiyuán** era, he was summoned to the capital, where Emperor Xuánzōng observed his childlike face and flowing hair, greatly honoring him.

At that time, Xuánzōng had obtained from **Máoshān** the many Daoist masters Yáng and Xǔ, as well as the original scriptures of the *Shàngqīng* Daoist canon and true writings by Táozhēn. Among these scriptures, thirteen sheets were missing, so he dispatched Wáng Yù with imperial seals, letters, and coins to visit **Zǐyáng Guàn**, where Xuánjìng Master (Xuánjìng xiānsheng) completed the missing text.

The emperor said: *"I do not wish to command my subjects to presume upon the Master’s favor. I entrust you alone to go—certainly, I hope for the hand of a Daoist immortal, to ensure the scriptures continue from antiquity to the present."*

On the day Wáng Yù arrived at the mountain, a spirit crane soared and cried. When Xuánjìng was writing the scriptures, a celestial being descended into his chamber. These were all responses to his sincere devotion. The details are recorded in *The Gathered Remnants of Daoist Transmissions*.

Hào Jūn was a Confucian scholar from **Lǔzhōng**, who entered **Sōngshān** and followed his teacher Pān Shìzhèng as a Daoist. He transmitted the **Shàngqīng** Dao, studying it with great diligence until he mastered its techniques. During the **Kāiyuán** era, he traveled south to **Jīnlíng**, sought Dao in **Máoshān**, and later journeyed east to **Tiāntái**. He was particularly skilled in writing, and Emperor Xuánzōng, upon hearing his name, summoned him. The emperor found his conversation delightful and appointed him as a *dàizhào* (imperial attendant) in the **Hánlín** Academy.

Soon after, he requested to return to **Máoshān**, and permission was granted. Later, when chaos spread across the central plains and bandits plagued **Jiānghuái**, he withdrew to **Kuàijī Tiāntái**, where he exchanged poems with Lǐ Bái and Kǒng Cháo Fǔ. He wandered freely among springs and rocks, ultimately dying in **Yuèzhōng**.

The account is found in *The Biography of the Tang Book*.

Cuī Xīzhēn, a guest of **Zhōnglíng**, dwelled in the western suburbs of the prefecture. He excelled in playing the *qín* (zither) and was skilled in painting, while also cultivating Daoist practices with fervor.

chunks.original_text: 大历二年十月朔，夜大雪，希真晨启门，见一老人衣蓑戴笠避雪门下，崔异之，延入，脱去蓑笠，神色、毛骨非常，益敬之，问日：家有大麦缅，聊以充饥，公能食乎？ 老父日：大麦受四时气，谷之善者也，沃以豉汁，弥佳。 崔命家人具，问又献松花酒，老父曰：花涩无，野人有物，能令其醇美。 乃探怀中丸药，色黄而坚，以石叩之，置少许酒中，甘香顿异，仍以余药遗希真。 崔入宅，隙窗窥之，见老父於帏喔前所侦画素，上如有所图，瞬息而罢。 崔出，已失老父，遂践雪迩逐之，数里至江，入芦洲中，见一大舫，舫中数人状貌皆奇。 其人顾笑曰：葛三乃见逼於伊人。 回谓崔曰：遵道严师之礼，不必然也。 崔拜而谢之，归视喔中，得图焉。 有三人、二树、一白鹿、一药岌。 其二人盖方外之状，手执玄芝，一似采药者。 二树似松相，皆幽岩为风雨所败枯朽之状，根相连属，非常意所及。 后拥图并丸药来山诣李舍光天师，天师日：此真人葛洪第三子所画也。 李君又日：写神人形状於朽木之下，意若得道者寿过松梧也，其药乃千岁松胶也。 事见《原化记》。 崔芋处士，隐居茅山。 贞元十二年，右谏议大夫韦渠牟荐之，德宗征至阙下，事见唐史。 龚道者，逸其名，居东海蓬莱观，服食十余年，唐咸通中，得入华阳洞，大有灵异。 茅山志卷之十五竟 #1於：原本无，据笪本增。
chunks.translated_text:
On the first day of the tenth month in the second year of the **Dàlì** era, a heavy snow fell at night. At dawn, **Xīzhēn** opened his door and saw an elderly man in a **suō** (straw raincoat) and **lì** (bamboo hat) taking shelter from the snow beneath his gate. **Xīzhēn** was struck by his unusual appearance and invited him in, whereupon the old man removed his raincoat and hat. His **shénsè** (divine countenance) and **máogǔ** (frame of bones and flesh) were extraordinary, and **Xīzhēn** revered him even more, asking:

"At home, I have some **dàmài miǎn** (large barley grains). I can offer them to ease your hunger. Would you care to eat?"

The old man replied:

"Barley absorbs the **qi** of all four seasons, making it the finest of grains. If it is seasoned with **zhǐ** (fermented soybean paste) broth, it would be even better."

**Xīzhēn** then ordered his household to prepare the barley, and when they did, they also presented **sōnghuā jiǔ** (pine-flower wine). The old man said:

"The flowers are too astringent—no. But the common folk have something that can refine it and make it truly **chún měi** (pure and exquisite)."

He reached into his bosom and withdrew a yellow, hard pill, striking it with a stone. After placing a small portion in the wine, its sweet fragrance became instantly distinct. He then gave the remaining pill to **Xīzhēn** as a parting gift.

**Xīzhēn** returned to his home and, peering through a crack in the window, saw the old man before a **wéi** (screen) drawing on white silk. He sketched as if guided by unseen visions, then paused in an instant. When **Xīzhēn** stepped outside, the old man had vanished. He followed the snow tracks and soon reached the river, where he entered a **lúzhōu** (reed marsh). There, he saw a grand **fǎng** (boat), inside which several men of strange and striking appearances were gathered.

One of them turned and laughed:

"Bo **Gěsān**—now you are pressed by this man!"

He then addressed **Xīzhēn**:

"Follow the **Dao** with strict discipline, and such encounters need not occur."

**Xīzhēn** bowed in gratitude and departed. Upon returning home, he found the silk drawing. It depicted three figures, two trees, one white deer, and one **yàojí** (medicinal plant). The two figures seemed to be **fāngwài** (those beyond worldly affairs), each holding **xuánzhī** (a type of immortal herb), as if they were gathering medicine. The two trees resembled pines but bore the appearance of ancient, decayed trunks ravaged by wind and rain, their roots intertwined in an unnatural way—beyond ordinary comprehension.

Later, **Xīzhēn** brought the drawing and the pill to **Shān** (Mountain) **Máoshān**, presenting them to **Lǐ Shèguāng**, the **Tiāntái** (Celestial Master). The master said:

"This is the work of the **Zhēnrén** (True Person) **Gē Hóng**, the third son of **Gěsān**."

**Lǐ Shèguāng** further remarked:

"To depict a **Shénrén** (Divine Person) beneath withered wood suggests that those who attain the **Dao** may live longer than pines and willows. And this pill is made from the **gāo** (resin) of a thousand-year-old pine."

The account is recorded in *The Original Transformation Record*.

**Cuī Xīzhēn**, the **Chǔshì** (Master of Retirement), lived in seclusion at **Máoshān**. In the twelfth year of the **Zhēnyuán** era, the **Yòu Jiànyì Dàfū** (Right Advisor of the Imperial Censorate) **Wéi Qúmóu** recommended him. Emperor **Dézōng** summoned him to the capital, as recorded in the **Tángshǐ** (Tang History).

**Gē**, the **Daoist practitioner** (whose full name is unknown), resided at the **Pénglái Guān** (Pénglái Observatory) in the **East Sea**. He practiced **fúshí** (nourishment and abstinence) for over a decade. During the **Xiàntōng** era of the **Táng**, he attained entry into the **Huáyáng Dòng** (Cave of the Flowered Sun), where many extraordinary **língyì** (supernatural phenomena) occurred.

This is recorded in the fifteenth volume of *The Records of Máoshān*. #1: "於" was originally absent; added according to the **Dì** (variant) text.

chunks.original_text: #2十二：笪本作『三』。 #3原本『人』后有『云』，据笪本删。 #4朔：原本无，据笪本增。 茅山志卷之十六 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 采真游篇 夏侯隐者，不知何许人。 唐大中末，来山，常拥布囊、竹杖而已，饮食同常，而独居一室，或露宿坛中、草问、树下。 人窥规之，但见云气蓊郁，不见其身。 每游三十、五十里，登山渡水而闭目美睡，同行者闻其鼻鼾之声，而步不蹉跌，足#1无蹶碍，至所止即觉，时号睡仙。 后不知所终见《仙传拾遗》。 周隐遥，字息元。 唐宝历崇元圣祖院在南洞者，即赞皇李公德裕供养先生之所。 又尝居洞庭苞山，不以昼夜更动息，不以寒暑易纤厚，不食而甚力，虽饮而无漏。 唐令狐楚为之记。 《仙传拾遗》亦有传。

**Xiàhóu**, the recluse (whose origins remain unknown), arrived at Máoshān during the late **Dàzhōng** era of the **Táng**. Each time he wandered thirty or fifty *lǐ*, ascending mountains or crossing waters while keeping his eyes closed in blissful slumber, his companions heard his breathing and snoring, yet never stumbled in their steps. His feet #1 encountered no obstruction, and upon reaching his destination, he would awaken—earning the name *Sleeping Immortal* at the time.

chunks.original_text: 张绍英，丹阳人。 自为道士，不入城府。 仁宗思接方外之论，先生与友朱自英观妙宗师也。 偕应韶，朱既治行，先生辞以疾。 明年，丞相丁谓、王钦若，同奏于上，再召。 后二年使车再至，俱称疾不起。 遣中贵人任珪责诰于山，赐号明真先生，仍劝所居庵为天圣观。 年七十五，一日清旦沐浴更衣，升坛拜 于四方、上下肩户而坐，弟子异之，启户已蜕化矣。 王荃，字子真，岐下平阳人。 父锡殿中丞，母司马氏，兄弟皆从科举，荃独学道。 因郊行，憩瓜圃问，有厘妇从乞瓜，视其乳齐於腹，异之，遗以瓜，妇食之，以其余啖荃。 荃食之，妇喜日：可教矣，吾萧三娘也，神仙海蟾子居此，发阁旦与俱见，遂授丹诀。 自尔奉三清尊像，朝夕礼谒，诵《黄庭经》，累月不出户。 后远游名山，西至成都，富郑公慕之，馆於门下八年。 丞相吕公尤敬之，近臣欲举种放故事，以谏议大夫起之，宰相以荃无为人意，乃止。 元丰中，复举于朝，赐号冲照处士。 族弟柄守台州，欲往台，未至而柄卒，因来山从刘先生受上清经录。 传度之夕，雷起中茅峰上，便门忽开，仙乐闻於空中。 一日昼寝，梦二天人引入便门，至洞官，见茅君告日：已劫汝司命府丞，赐以金尺。 乃觉，遂预言逝日，投山下道民葛冲家端坐而蜕，年六十一。 荃清修骨立，所食才如婴儿，通夕燕坐，冠带不去体，老更起居轻利。 张舜民调碑文，冠剑藏于凤翔。 汤用明，字晦之，锺陵道士也。 神锋凌迈，通经博物，专内炼坐忘之学。 元佑初，年方壮，闻刘先生之道，不远千里参受经法，与卢必强、汤道原、冯悦道、鲍炼师、王景山数人为友。 刘先生被召，欲师与道原偕行，俱辞不往。 结庵金菌山，高居洞之侧，不交外物，衣弊履穿，无愧人之色。 大观初，无疾化去。 冯太申，字悦道，池州人。 为道士，结友十人来居山，会连岁歉，九人去，独太申艺蕾不给，终守初志，居祠宇久，为道俗所归。 有卢先生者，建观璨山，未成，闻召而解去，其徒积道数千缙，不敢归，请太申主其观。 斋施所入，尽偿之，复还祠宇，旋化于山舍。 弟子邵次山、葛真一皆恬漠自守，人敬爱之。 陈希微，字彦真，姑苏人，先名伯雄。 父之才，朝奉郎监江宁府粮料院。 元佑中，伯雄得复连疾，已困，诣刘先生乞符水治之，疾良愈。 妻门下侍郎薛昂夫人之妹，会先卒，遂山居为道士，改名希微，筑室柳济泉上。 徽宗闻其名，累召不起，乃劝所居为抱元观，赐号洞微法师。 宣和中为人拜章，诘日一解去。 黄澄，毗陵人，隶业丹阳之仙台观。 崇宁初，有劝，改玉晨观为崇宁万寿宫，先生充住持。 未几，徽宗玺书召，赴阙，劫差住持金山神霄万寿宫。 累授太素大夫、冲素静一先生，领玉堂高士左右街都道录兼管教门公事，食实封一千二百户，赐紫金方符。 请老还山，告逝於玉晨所建束庵。 初，三山经录，龙虎、正一、阁皂、灵宝、茅山大洞，各嗣其本宗，先生请混一之。 今龙虎阁皂之传、上清毕法盖始於此。 杨希真，字元道。 世为仪真米商，积阴德。 元道生建中靖国元年，六岁始能言，稍长，知敬事四圣真君像。 一夕，梦神人告日：吾为北方天辅上帅，悯子葱志，一反子尸浊，期於华阳仙府，与子换骨，当授以神书。

**Zhāng Shào Yīng**, a native of Dānyáng, became a Daoist recluse and never entered the city gates. Emperor Rénzōng, seeking the wisdom of those outside the court, summoned him along with his friend **Zhū Zì Yīng** to meet the wondrous **Miào Zōng Shī**. They were both called to serve **Yìng Shào**, but **Zhū** declined due to illness. The following year, **Chéngxiàng Dīng Wèi** and **Wáng Qīn Ruò** jointly petitioned the throne, and **Zhāng Shào Yīng** was summoned again. Two years later, when an imperial carriage was sent a second time, both declined, citing illness.

The court dispatched a eunuch, **Rèn Guì**, to deliver a formal reprimand at the mountain. **Zhāng Shào Yīng** was granted the title *Míng Zhēn Xiānshēng*, and his dwelling was renamed **Tiān Shèng Guàn**. At seventy-five, one morning after bathing and changing his clothes, he ascended the altar, bowed to the four directions, and sat with his shoulders facing above and below. His disciples, astonished, opened the door and found him already transformed. **Wáng Qǎn**, courtesy name *Zǐ Zhēn*, from **Qíxià Píngyáng**, was a descendant of the **Sìdiàn Zhèngxiàng** and his mother was of the **Sīmǎ** clan. His brothers all pursued official careers through the imperial examinations, but he alone studied the Dao.

While traveling in the countryside, he rested beneath a melon patch and encountered a Daoist woman begging for melons. Observing her milk-like *qi* concentrated in her abdomen, he was struck by her presence and gave her melons. She ate them and offered the remainder to him. **Wáng Qǎn** consumed it, and the woman rejoiced, saying: "You may be taught! I am **Xiāo Sān Niáng**, and the Immortal **Hǎichán Zǐ** resides here. When you open your door at dawn, you will see him together with me." She then instructed him in the elixir's secrets. From that day on, he revered the statues of the **Sān Qīng** and paid homage morning and evening, reciting the *Huángtíng Jīng* for months without stepping outside.

Later, he journeyed to distant sacred mountains, reaching **Chéngdū** in the west. **Fù Zhèng Gōng**, admiring his virtues, hosted him for eight years. **Chéngxiàng Lǚ Gōng** held him in even greater esteem, and officials wished to elevate him by recommending him for office as a **Guānyì Dàfū**. However, the ministers deemed him unsuited to human affairs and the proposal was abandoned. During the **Yuánfēng** era, he was again summoned to court and granted the title *Chōng Zhào Chǔshì*.

His nephew **Bìng**, who governed **Táizhōu**, wished to invite him there, but **Bìng** died before the journey could be made. Instead, **Wáng Qǎn** came to the mountain and received the **Shàng Qīng Jīng** from **Liú Xiānshēng**. On the night of his transmission, thunder rolled over **Zhōngmáo Shān**, and the door suddenly opened, revealing celestial music in the air. One day, while napping, he dreamed of two heavenly beings leading him through the door to a cave, where he met **Máo Jūn**, who declared: "You have been assigned to oversee the **Sīmìng Fǔ** in the Northern Quarter. I grant you a golden ruler." Upon waking, he predicted his own death and, seated in the home of a mountain Daoist named **Gě Chōng**, ascended in transformation at age sixty-one.

**Wáng Qǎn** practiced austere refinement, consuming only enough food to sustain an infant. He remained seated through the night, never removing his cap and sash, and even in old age moved with ease. **Zhāng Shùn Mín** composed an epitaph for him, which was engraved at **Fèng Xiāng**.

**Tāng Yòng Míng**, courtesy name *Huì Zhī*, was a Daoist from **Zhōng Líng**. His spiritual prowess was extraordinary, and he mastered the classics while exploring profound knowledge. He specialized in the inner alchemy of the *Zuòwàng* method. At the beginning of the **Yuán Yòu** era, though still in his prime, he heard of **Liú Xiānshēng**’s teachings and traveled thousands of miles to receive them in person, befriending **Lú Bì Qiáng**, **Tāng Dào Yuán**, **Féng Yuè Dào**, **Bào Liàn Shī**, and **Wáng Jǐng Shān**.

When **Liú Xiānshēng** was summoned to court, **Tāng Yòng Míng** and **Tāng Dào Yuán** wished to accompany him, but both declined, refusing to go. They built a hermitage on **Jīn Jūn Shān**, dwelling in seclusion beside a cave, with no contact with the outside world. Their rags and worn sandals betrayed no shame. In the early **Dàguān** era, **Tāng Yòng Míng** departed without illness.

**Féng Tàishēn**, courtesy name *Yuè Dào*, of **Chízhōu**, became a Daoist and gathered ten companions to reside on the mountain. When famine struck for consecutive years, nine of them left, but only **Féng Tàishēn** remained, his *qi* refined and unyielding. He stayed long in the temple halls, revered by both Daoists and laymen. There was a **Lú Xiānshēng** who built a Daoist observatory on **Càn Shān**, but it was unfinished when he heard of the summons and abandoned the project. His disciples, numbering thousands, dared not return, so they begged **Féng Tàishēn** to lead them. He used all his offerings to repay them and returned to the temple, soon ascending in transformation at his mountain dwelling. His disciples, **Shào Cì Shān** and **Gě Zhēn Yī**, were both serene and self-disciplined, held in respect by all.

**Chén Xī Wēi**, courtesy name *Yàn Zhēn*, originally named **Bó Xióng**, was from **Gūsū**. His father, **Zhī Cái**, served as a **Cháofèng Láng** overseeing the grain supplies of **Jiāngníng Fǔ**. During the **Yuán Yòu** era, **Bó Xióng** fell gravely ill, and his wife, the younger sister of **Ménxià Shìláng Xuē Áng**, begged **Liú Xiānshēng** for a talisman and sacred water to cure him. His illness was swiftly healed. After his father’s death, he took up mountain life as a Daoist, changed his name to **Xī Wēi**, and built a dwelling above **Liǔ Jì Quán**.

Emperor **Huìzōng** heard his name and repeatedly summoned him, but **Chén Xī Wēi** declined each time. The court then encouraged him to establish a Daoist observatory, naming it **Bàoyuán Guàn**, and granted him the title *Dòngwēi Fǎshī*. During the **Xuānhé** era, he was invited to write petitions for others, but he resigned after just one day. **Huáng Chéng**, a native of **Pílíng**, was affiliated with **Dānyáng Xiāntái Guàn**. In the early **Chóngníng** era, he was persuaded to change the name of **Yùchén Guàn** to **Chóngníng Wànshòu Gōng**, and **Chéng** was appointed as its abbot.

Soon after, **Huìzōng** issued an imperial seal summoning him to the capital. When **Chéng** arrived, he was instead assigned to oversee **Shénxiāo Wànshòu Gōng** on **Jīn Shān**. He was repeatedly granted the titles *Tàisù Dàfū*, *Chōngsù Jìngyī Xiānshēng*, and *Lǐng Yùtáng Gāoshì Zuǒyòu Jiē Dōulù Jìngyī Gōngshì*, with a stipend of 1,200 households and a purple-gold talisman. He requested retirement and returned to the mountain, departing in his hermitage built at **Yùchén**. Initially, the **Sānyuán Jīnglù**—including **Lónghǔ**, **Zhèngyī**, **Gézào**, **Língbǎo**, and **Máoshān Dàdòng**—each followed their own traditions. **Chéng** petitioned to unify them, and from this point, the lineages of **Lónghǔ Gézào** and **Shàngqīng Bìfǎ** began.

**Yáng Xī Zhēn**, courtesy name *Yuán Dào*, was a descendant of the **Yízhēn Mǐshāng** family, accumulating hidden virtue. **Yuán Dào** was born in the first year of **Jiànzhōng Jìngguó** (1101), and at six he could speak. As he grew older, he knew to honor the statues of the **Sìshèng Zhēnjūn**. One night, he dreamed of a divine being who said: "I am the Northern Quarter’s **Tiānfú Shàngshuài**. Pitying your sincere devotion, I will reverse your impure physical form and meet you at the **Huáyáng Xiānfǔ**. I will grant you a new body and bestow upon you sacred scriptures."

chunks.original_text: 君自是数通冥感，若有心疾，狂走，失所在。 宣和二年庚子岁，入华阳洞不返。 明年自洞出，比还，乡邻皆讶之。 君日：我昔实非狂颠，为求法耳。 今得真哑童初大法，可以度世矣。 徽宗索异人，进上九灵玉婴神变等经及灵虚秘旨，劫黄冕校定录，付道藏，特授丹台郎、冲和妙一法师，视朝请大夫。 年二十四尸解，越三日，复起，手书辞谢门状，投笔坐逝，甲辰三月十七日也。 童初之法遂显于世，门人承务郎沈育作《杨真人传》。 沈若济，字子舟。 远祖当昊越钱氏时为谋主，遂为钱唐人，宗族盛大。 师年十许岁，便不乐尘埃中事，诣本郡元真观出家。 元佑庚午，试经为道士，年始十三。 取道藏书读，旁采外书，与其学之同者参焉，上下贯穿，无不该洽，尤长於医。 游山，客崇禧观。 政和末，延康殿学士。 王公汉之因论内外丹，有契，载与俱归。 公帅建康，乃茸山中洞阳馆以处，师俾炼大药，且广施药，以已四方疾者。 徽宗再召，强起馆於龙德宫，数月，赐号洞元大师，命之道官，辞以疾，赐金方符，送还山。 绍兴初，服丹尸解，年六十二。 汤友成，字道原，桐川人。 兄景仁，登进士第。 熙宁丙辰岁，与弟友直同试经为道士。 友成事徐神翁於泰州。 翁天机深妙，不与物接，唯时与友成语。 居岁余，因获二鼠，闭盎中，欲纵之，发视而鼠已死，翁咄咄有所尤，不复顾之，遂辞翁。 翁遣诣刘先生受经法，与友直修鹤庙居。 王公汉之邀治丹炉，又从王谪居濠梁，王得还，复归鹤庙。 宣和召索异人，友成兄弟晦边山庐，恒恐人知。 建炎盗起，友直逃入深岩不返，友成居山五十余载。 自濠建州还，不复出门。 绍兴癸亥，预言去世日，其年六月五日汲寒水沐浴，问日早晏，正午而逝，年八十四。 李珏，广陵江阳人。 贩耀自业，人有耀者，即授以升斗，俾自量，年八十余，不改其业。

「Later, the Master often communicated with the unseen and divine, and if he suffered from any physical ailment, he would rush about in a frenzy, losing all sense of direction. In the second year of **Xuānhé** (1120), in the year of **Gēngzǐ**, he entered the **Huáyáng Dòng** and did not return.

The following year, he emerged from the cave, and upon his return, his neighbors were astonished. The Master said: "I was not truly mad before; I sought only the Dao. Now I have obtained **Tóngchū**’s initial great method, which can save the world."

The **Huīzōng** Emperor sought out this extraordinary man and requested the **Jiǔ Líng Yùyīng Shénbiàn** scriptures, along with the **Língxū Mìzhǐ** and other sacred texts. He was ordered to refine and compile them into the **Jiéhuáng Jiàodìng Lù**, to be included in the **Dàozàng** (Daoist Canon). The Emperor specially bestowed upon him the titles **Dāntái Láng**, **Chōnghé Miào-Yī Fǎshī**, and **Shìcháo Qǐng Dàfū**.

At the age of twenty-four, his physical form dissolved (**shísèjiě**), but after three days, he revived. He wrote a farewell note to his disciples, placed it on the door, and then sat down and passed away—on the seventeenth day of the third month, in the year of **Jiǎchén**.

Thus, **Tóngchū**’s method became renowned in the world, and his disciple, **Ménrén** the **Wèiláng** (Assistant Minister) **Shěn Yù**, composed the *Biography of Master Yáng Zhēn*.

**Shěn Yù**, courtesy name *Zǐzhōu*, hailed from a distant lineage that, during the time of **Hàoyuè**’s **Qián Shì**, served as a strategist. They became **Qián Táng** (Hangzhou) people, and their clan flourished in grandeur. As a young man of about ten years, he took no pleasure in mundane affairs but sought out the **Yuánzhēn Guàn** in his native district and became an ascetic. In the year **Yuán Yòu Gēngwǔ** (1090), he passed the **shìjīng** (scripture examination) and became a Daoist priest at the age of thirteen.

He studied the **Dàozàng** meticulously and supplemented his learning with external texts, comparing and harmonizing them with his fellow scholars. His understanding was comprehensive and profound, especially in the art of medicine. While traveling in the mountains, he visited the **Chóngxī Guàn** and lodged there. In the latter years of **Zhènghé**, he was invited to the **Yánkāng Dìng** as a **Xuéshì** (scholar-official). **Wáng Gōng Hànzhī** sought his counsel on inner and outer alchemy (**nèidān wàidān**), and they found mutual accord. When **Wáng Gōng** led the retreat to **Jiànkāng**, he settled in the **Dòngyáng Guǎn** within the mountains, and the Master was tasked with refining the great elixir (**dàyào**) while also widely dispensing medicine to cure the sick from all directions.

The **Huīzōng** Emperor summoned him again, compelling him to take up residence in the **Lóngdé Gōng**. After several months, the Emperor granted him the title **Dòngyuán Dàshī** and appointed him to a Daoist office. He declined due to illness, and the Emperor bestowed upon him a **jīnfāng fú** (golden prescription talisman) before sending him back to the mountains.

At the beginning of the **Shàoxīng** era (1131), he consumed the elixir and his physical form dissolved (**shísèjiě**) at the age of sixty-two.

**Tāng Yǒuchéng**, courtesy name *Dàoyuán*, was from **Tóngchuān** (Tongchuan). His elder brother **Tāng Jǐngrén** passed the **Jìnshì** examination. In the year **Xīníng Bǐngchén** (1066), he and his younger brother **Yǒuzhí** both took the **shìjīng** examination and became Daoist priests together.

**Yǒuchéng** served under **Xú Shénwēng** in **Tàizhōu**. The Master’s understanding of the **Tiān jī** (heavenly mechanism) was profound and subtle; he rarely interacted with others, only speaking with **Yǒuchéng** at times. After residing there for over a year, he once caught two mice, sealed them in a jar, and intended to release them. But upon opening the jar, the mice were already dead. The Master scolded him sharply (**duōduō yǒu suǒ yóu**), then ignored him entirely, and **Yǒuchéng** thus left his service.

The Master then instructed him to go to **Liú Zhēnshī** to receive the scriptures and methods (**jīngfǎ**), and together they cultivated in the **Hèmiào** (Hall of Cranes). **Wáng Gōng** invited him to oversee the **dànlú** (elixir furnace), and he also followed **Wáng Gōng** into exile at **Háoliáng**. When **Wáng Gōng** returned, they once again retreated to the **Hèmiào**.

During the **Xuānhé** Emperor’s summons for extraordinary men (**yìrén**), **Yǒuchéng** and his brother hid in secluded mountain huts, always fearing discovery. In the **Jiàn Yán** era (1127), when bandits rose in rebellion, **Yǒuzhí** fled into a deep ravine and never returned, while **Yǒuchéng** lived in the mountains for over fifty years. Upon returning from **Háoliáng** to **Jiànzhōu**, he never left his home again.

In the year **Shàoxīng Guǐhài** (1143), he foretold his passing. On the fifth day of the sixth month of that year, he drank cold water and bathed, asking when the day would end. At noon, he departed (**shì**), at the age of eighty-four.

**Lǐ Jué**, a native of **Guǎnglíng Jiāngyáng** (Yangzhou), engaged in the trade of **yào** (medicinal herbs). If anyone sought his help, he would give them a measure of herbs (**shēngdǒu**) to weigh themselves, and he did not change his profession even at over eighty years of age.

Pitying your sincere devotion, I will reverse your impure physical form and meet you at the **Huáyáng Xiānfǔ**. I will grant you a new body and bestow upon you sacred scriptures."

chunks.original_text: 适李公#2珏，节制淮南，珏以同姓名，改名宽。 李珏下车数月，修道斋次，夜梦入洞府，见石壁金书李珏，字长尺余，珏#3视之极喜，自谓生於明代，又升宰辅，今洞府有名，我仙人也。 方喜之际，二青衣自石壁左右出，珏#4问：此何所也？ 日：华阳洞天，此姓名非相公也。 珏#5惊，复问：非珏何人也？ 青衣日：此相公江阳部民也。 珏#6晓，益自惊叹，乃令城府求访同姓□名者，得李宽旧名珏，迎置静室，拜为道兄。 宽素恬担，道貌秀异，须长尺余，皓然可爱。 年六十时，有道士教其．胎，息，亦久不食。 珏愈敬之，洎问道术，宽辞以愚民，不知所修，以贩耀对。 珏#7咨嗟日：此常人之难事，阴功不可及也。 宽百余岁，轻健异常，忽一夕卒，三日棺裂，视之如蝉蜕矣。 事见《续仙传》。 傅霄，字子昂，晋陵人。 博古明经，善书，尤精隶古，由儒入道，隶居常州天庆观。 高宗召主太一官祠，乞还茅山，赐号明真通微先生，领山门都道正，住持玉晨观，建雷平院，往来山中四十年，搜访真秘，拯救穷乏，利益甚探，重编隐居集，修茅山旧记着作，惜多无传。 绍兴二十九年己卯，正月立春日化。 杨任丁，字直甲，河北相州人，气貌雄伟。 绍兴三十年，弃官入山，筑庵飕输峰下，和王杨公存中遣兵士五百人为筑庵基。 庵成，先生日：吾平生未尝求信於人，惟求信於天，遂名庵日天信，先生精於变遁之道，盖真隐者也。 太宗淳化二年生，孝宗淳熙五年二月十五日卒，寿一百八十有四。 刘道怀，恩州人，时称蓑衣先生，齐云庵是其居也。 高宗御笔召先生留守，晁公谦之传上意，具书敦请，强延诣阙。 时金海陵炀王完颜亮兵临瓜洲，上惧，询以国事，先生直答云：没事没事，南北两家各换主耳。 俄海陵弒，高宗亦内禅。 先生年八十四，坐逝於齐云。 陶源静，曹州人，居山之南，同蓑衣先生被召，上表力辞还山，绍兴十八年也。 时号陶、刘二公。 陈槐，京口人，号靖真先生。 绍兴问任待制，勇庾辞禄，肥遁入林，筑八卦台于茅洞之东。 石室像遗存焉。
chunks.translated_text:
When **Li Gong**#2 **Jué** governed the **Huái Nán** region, **Jué**—sharing the same name as **Li Jué**—changed his name to **Kuān**.

Within months of **Li Jué**’s arrival, he established Daoist observances and fasts. One night, he dreamed of entering a **Dòngfǔ** (cave palace), where he saw a stone wall inscribed in gold with the name **Li Jué**, the characters spanning over a foot in length. **Jué**#3 gazed upon it with great delight, believing himself destined for the **Míng** dynasty, even to rise as a high minister. Now, he thought, his name was recorded in the **Dòngfǔ**, and he was surely a **xiānrén** (immortal).

As he rejoiced, two **qīngyī** (attendants in green robes) emerged from either side of the stone wall. **Jué**#4 asked: *"Where is this place?"*
They replied: *"Huáyáng Dòngtiān* (a celestial cave realm). This name does not belong to you, honored sir."

**Jué**#5 was startled and asked again: *"If not mine, then whose?"*
The attendants said: *"It belongs to a commoner named Li from your Jiangyáng district."*

**Jué**#6 awoke in shock, marveled, and ordered his officials to investigate for someone with the same surname and name. They found **Li Kuān**, whose former name was **Jué**, and brought him to a secluded chamber, bowing to him as a Daoist elder brother.

**Kuān** was naturally serene and possessed an extraordinary Daoist bearing, with a beard over a foot long, pure and radiant. At sixty years old, a Daoist instructed him in **tāixī** (embryonic breathing) and **xī** (suspended animation), and he abstained from food for long periods. **Jué** revered him even more, inquiring about his Daoist practices, but **Kuān** humbly declined, claiming he was merely a commoner who sold medicinal herbs. **Jué**#7 sighed: *"This is beyond the reach of ordinary mortals—his hidden virtue is unmatched."*

**Kuān** lived over a hundred years, remaining agile and vigorous until one night he suddenly passed away. After three days, his coffin split open, revealing his body as withered as a **chántuì** (cicada’s shed skin). The account appears in the *Xù Xiān Zhuàn* (Continuation of the Immortal Records).

**Fù Xiāo**, styled **Zǐ’áng**, hailed from **Jìnlíng**. Well-versed in antiquity and the classics, he excelled in calligraphy, particularly in **lì** and **gǔ** scripts. Entering Daoism from Confucianism, he resided at **Chángzhōu Tiānjìng Guàn**. Emperor **Gāozōng** summoned him to oversee the **Tàiyī** shrine, but he begged to return to **Máoshān**, receiving the title **Míngzhēn Tōngwēi Xiānsheng** and serving as **Shānmén Dùdàozhèng** at **Yùchén Guàn**, where he established the **Léipíng Yùan**. For forty years, he wandered the mountains, seeking hidden truths, rescuing the destitute, and benefiting many. He recompiled the *Yǐnjū Jí* and revised the *Máoshān Jiùjì*, though much of his work is now lost.

On the **Jìchǔ** day of the **Shàoxīng** era’s **29th year** (1159), on the first day of spring, he ascended.

**Yáng Rèn Dīng**, styled **Zhíjiǎ**, was from **Xiāngzhōu** in **Héběi**, with a commanding presence and imposing **qi**.

In the **30th year of Shàoxīng** (1160), he resigned his post and entered the mountains, building a hermitage beneath **Sōngshū Fēng**. **Wáng Yáng Gōng Cúnzhōng** dispatched five hundred soldiers to assist in constructing its foundation.

When the hermitage was complete, the master declared: *"I have never sought faith in mortals, only in Heaven."* Thus, he named it **Tiānxìn** (Heaven’s Faith). The master was adept in the **biàn dùn** (transformation and evasion) arts—truly a **zhēn yǐnzhě** (true recluse).

Born in the **Chúnhuà** era of **Tàizōng** (921), he passed away on the **15th day of the 2nd month of Chúnxī** (1178), at the age of **184**.

**Liú Dàohuái**, a native of **Ēnzhōu**, was known as the **Suōyī Xiānsheng** (Straw-Cape Master), residing at **Qíyún Yùan**. Emperor **Gāozōng**, in his own hand, summoned the master to serve as **Liúshǒu**, but **Cháo Gōng Qiānzhī** conveyed the imperial intent, urging him to accept. The master was forcibly escorted to the capital.

At the time, **Wán Yán Líng Yángwáng** **Wán Yán Líng** of **Jīn** (Emperor Yáng of Hǎiliáng), **Guānyán Ráng**, threatened **Guāzhōu**. The emperor, fearful, consulted him on state affairs. The master replied bluntly: *"No matter—no matter. The north and south will simply exchange rulers."*

Soon after, **Hǎiliáng** was assassinated, and **Gāozōng** abdicated in favor of **Xiàozōng**.

The master, aged **84**, died seated in **Qíyún**.

**Táo Yuánjìng**, from **Cáozhōu**, resided in the southern mountains. Like the **Suōyī Xiānsheng**, he was summoned, but he submitted a petition declining and returned to the mountains in the **18th year of Shàoxīng** (1148). At the time, they were known as the **Táo-Liú Érgōng** (Masters Táo and Liú).

**Chén Huái**, of **Jīngkǒu**, was styled **Jìngzhēn Xiānsheng**. During the **Shàoxīng** era, he served as **Dàizhì**, but declined office and retreated into the woods, constructing an **Bāguà Tái** in the east of **Máodòng**. A **shíshì** (stone chamber) with his likeness remains.

**Lǐ Jué**, a native of **Guǎnglíng Jiāngyáng** (Yangzhou), engaged in the trade of **yào** (medicinal herbs). If anyone sought his help, he would give them a measure of herbs (**shēngdǒu**) to weigh themselves, and he did not change his profession even at over eighty years of age.

chunks.original_text: 刘至孝，失其名，咸通里人也。 弱冠丧父母，愿终身麻衣，人呼为至孝。 住白鹤庙数年，修奉勤瘁。 一日修殿於海，石榴树下有物如桃。 以冬月非时，争擘之，且无核，人皆弃去，至孝取食，味异美。 是晚，复至前所，得物如拳，内绿外红。 明日得如掌者，色味皆如桃，尤珍美。 至孝自是不姻火食，远游名岳，不知所终。 岂纯孝之报耶？ 所遇皆芝英之类耶？ 见《道藏灵验记》。 刘商，彭城人居长安，擢第历台省为郎。 性耽道卫，每叹浮荣世宦於己何益？ 古贤皆填官以求道，多得度世。
chunks.translated_text:
**Liú Zhìxiào**, whose given name is lost, was a native of **Xiántōng Lǐ**. At the age of majority, he lost both parents and vowed to wear coarse hempen garments for life, earning the name *Zhìxiào* ("Most Filial"). He dwelled at the **Báiè Miào** for several years, devoting himself tirelessly to its upkeep.

One day, while repairing a hall by the sea, beneath a pomegranate tree he found an object resembling a peach. Though it was winter and out of season, he and others peeled and tasted it—it had no pit, and all discarded it. Only Zhìxiào kept some, finding its flavor exquisite. That evening, he returned to the same spot and found another object, the size of a fist, green within and red without. The next day, he discovered one the size of a palm, its color and taste like that of a peach, yet even more refined and precious. From then on, Zhìxiào abstained from all cooked food, wandering the sacred mountains until his fate was unknown. Was this not the reward of pure filial virtue? Or did he encounter only rare elixirs of the Dao? This account appears in the *Dàozàng Língyàn Jì*.

**Liú Shāng**, a man of **Péngchéng** who resided in **Cháng’ān**, rose through the imperial examinations and served in the central bureaucracy as a *láng* (official). By nature, he was devoted to Daoist cultivation, often sighing at the fleeting glories of worldly office—what use were they to him? The ancient sages had all abandoned officialdom to seek the Way, and many attained transcendence to save the world.

chunks.original_text: 幸毕婚嫁，不为俗累，岂劣於许远游哉？ 遂以病免官，道服束游，及广陵，遇一道士卖药，众中见商目之相异，乃罢药，据手登酒家楼，谈秦汉问事如目睹。 商师敬之，及暮，下楼，闪然不见。 明日，访诸城街，剧谈欢醉，出小药囊，赠商，戏吟日：无事到扬州，相担上酒楼。 药囊为赠别，千载复何求。 别后累求之不得，囊中得药九粒，依诀服之，顿觉神爽不饥，身轻醒然。 乃过江隐於‘山中，时往来胡父渚，樵者有遇之者，我刘郎中也，而不知其所止。 温德成，字韶叟，自称束蒙子，三山长乐人。 与晦庵象山诸先生游，住持玉晨观三十年，立道藏，初受度於昊兴计筹山之升元观。 喜泰问归主升元。
chunks.translated_text:
Fortunate that his marriage was complete and he was free from worldly entanglements, how could he be inferior to Xu Yuan’s wandering? Thus, he resigned from office on the pretext of illness, donned Daoist robes, and set out to travel. Arriving in Guangling, he encountered a Daoist selling medicines. Among the crowd, the man noticed Liu Shang’s unusual bearing and, abandoning his wares, took his hand and led him up to a winehouse pavilion. There, he conversed on the affairs of Qin and Han as if witnessing them firsthand.

Liu Shang revered him as a master. As evening fell, the man descended the stairs and vanished without a trace.

The next day, Liu Shang searched the city streets, engaging in lively discourse and drinking deeply. He then produced a small medicine pouch and presented it to Liu Shang, jesting with the verse:

*"Without purpose to Yangzhou I came,
Together we climbed the winehouse’s frame.
This pouch of medicine is my parting gift—
What more could one seek across the ages?"*

After their separation, Liu Shang repeatedly sought him in vain, but found nine pills within the pouch. Following the instructions, he ingested them and instantly felt his spirit brightened, his hunger vanished, and his body lightened with clarity.

He then crossed the river and secluded himself in the mountains, occasionally visiting the Hu Fu Zhu docks. Woodcutters who encountered him would say, *"There goes Master Liu the Official,"* yet none knew his dwelling place.

Wen Decheng, styled Shaoshou, who called himself Shumengzi, was a native of Changle in the Three Mountains. He associated with scholars like Huì’ān Xiàngshān, and for thirty years oversaw the Yùchén Guan, compiling the Daoist Canon. Initially, he received his ordination at the Shēngyuán Guan on Jìzhōu Mountain in Hào Xīng.

He delighted in the *Tàiqíng* and the *Guīzhǔ* sutras.

chunks.original_text: 嘉定丙子四月示化，年七十二，葬武康县蛟池之西。 复十五年庚寅岁，一日乘肩舆过山中八卦台，守庵见而疑，且曰：往束岳检校江东斋醮文籍，因经故山。 时有双鹤飞呜，若相迎导，索笔留诗而去。 明日，守庵持其诗质於崇禧管辖包守明。 包识为故人温讲师真迹，大相叹异。 升元令有《东蒙集》，所留诗刊附卷末云。 金元范，凝神庵道士，性朴野，未尝闻道法。 宝佑元年，浙江潮犯钱唐，不能禁。 元范梦茅君喂符诀，令治潮。 明日忘之，是夕再梦，如是三夕，乃诣阙自白，劫有司往试其法，比潮怒至，元范飞符厉声喝退潮势却立，自是水不为害。 命之道官，赐金帛，皆不顾，惟乞免庵田税租。 时相谢方叔有喝退江潮免税还之句。 送之还山，盖实录也，盛称金真人云。 杨志隐，字空静，鄂州人。 年数岁，不告其家随木筏至江束。 稍长，为道士於元符宫。 喜读书，貌甚怪。 遇异人哑召雷雨之术。 大元初，以其法事世祖皇帝。 每被顾问，奏对朴直，不避时忌，上优容之。
chunks.translated_text:
The *jì* of the *jìchuán* continues:

In the fourth month of the *jiǎdìng* year *bǐngzǐ* (1216), Master Wen Decheng entered *shìhuà*, having lived to seventy-two. He was interred west of the *Jiāochí* in Wǔkāng County.

Fifteen years later, in the year *gēngyín*, as he rode in a shoulder-litter through the mountains near the *Bāguà Tái*, the guardian of the hermitage saw him and was astonished, saying, *"I was sent to inspect the Daoist ritual texts of Jiangdong at Shùyùe, and now I pass through my old mountain."* At that moment, a pair of cranes flew with a mournful cry, as if guiding and welcoming him. He took up a brush to leave a poem before departing.

The next day, the guardian brought the poem to *Bāo Shǒumíng*, the magistrate under *Chóngxǐ* jurisdiction. Bāo recognized it as the genuine hand of his old friend, Master Wen the Lecturer, and marveled greatly. The preface to the *Dōngméng Jí* records that the poem was later published in its final volume.

As for *Jīnyuán Fàn*, a Daoist of the *Níngshén’ān*, his nature was simple and rustic, yet he had never studied Daoist teachings. In the first year of *Bǎoyòu* (1253), when the tides of Zhèjiāng surged against Jiāntáng, the officials were powerless to stop them. Fàn dreamed that the Immortal of the Teahouse gave him a talisman and incantation, commanding him to subdue the tide. The next morning, he forgot it, but that evening, he dreamed of it again—three nights in total. Finally, he went to the imperial court to confess, and the authorities tested his method. When the tide raged, Fàn hurled the talisman and shouted, and the tide immediately retreated. From then on, the waters caused no more harm. The court appointed him to the Daoist bureaucracy, bestowed gold and silk, which he refused, asking only for exemption from taxes on his hermitage’s fields. At the time, Chancellor Xiè Fāngzú composed the lines *"With a shout, the river tides retreat—taxes forgiven, returned to the mountain."* His return was indeed recorded in the *Shìlù*, and he was widely praised as the *Jīn Zhēnrén*.

Yang Zhìyǐn, styled *Kōngjìng*, was a native of Èzhōu. As a child of mere years, he left his family without warning and drifted downriver on a raft to Jiangdong. As he grew older, he became a Daoist at the *Yuánsù Gōng*. He delighted in reading, though his appearance was most unusual. He encountered a strange man who taught him the art of summoning thunder and rain. In the early years of the *Dàyuán*, he used his methods to serve the *Shìzǔ* Emperor. Whenever the emperor inquired of him, his responses were direct and unadorned, never avoiding taboos, and the emperor treated him with favor.
