chunks.original_text: 虽复罗衣之屡拂，冀巨石之不糜，面千龄而沥肾，对万古以披心，但恨言不足以尽意，庶冥鉴之匪尤。 乃仰铭日：玄玄妙始，宝官灵端。 智明不体，慧寂何言。 心期绝路，指测无源。 一及此黔首，念彼飞喧。 流连永夜，波迸长昏。 促生电逝，短晷星奔。 异生天世，俱为夜魂。 从迷既往，望反无门。 谁哀谁悼，惟圣惟贤。 应逐规矩，感任方员。 以师以友，作辅作天。 惟我真人，厥诞茅裔。 孤贞独秀，邈尔霞际，如彼玉京，迢迢天外，如彼河清，千年一世。 惟君圣德，独立孤贞，耽玄味道，舍秩辞荣。 千年一世，如彼河清。 迢迢天外，如彼玉京。 秋威春泽，日暄月明。 金刚玉润，水洁冰清。 长怀万古，虚仰千龄。 芳音既远，传石流声。 碑阴题 此碑有如玄孱宿构，略有四事。 一者，工人凿山，唯得此碑一石有如现成。 二者，众石悉不堪作趺，唯所指安碑处一石有如伏龙之状。 三者，密石连环，唯安柱处有自然焰。 四者，事竟，洞内飞泉忽涌。 碑阴及两旁褊刻齐梁诸馆高道姓名，略见采真游篇石柱篆刻。 自然弟子徐楷敬谒华阳洞天。 唐宋刻题多漫缺矣。 上清真人许长史旧馆坛碑 弟子华阳隐居陶弘景谨造 悠哉旷矣，宇宙之灵也，固非言象所传，文边可记，默然则后之人奚闻乎？ 含吐万有，化育旱生，本其所由，义归冥昧。 至於形域区分，性用殊品，事限观听，理穷数识者，倘或可论山之高、海之广，夫何故以其有容焉？ 大天之内复有小天三十六所，并拓寓地空，亘徐水脉，辟闱风岫，通气云辙。 此山本号句曲，其下是第八洞官，名曰金坛华阳之天，周回一百五十里，分置三府。 前汉元帝世，有咸阳三茅君得道，来掌此任，故称茅山，具详传记。 至晋太和元年，句容许长史在斯营宅，厥迩犹存。 宋初，长沙景王就其地之束起道士精舍。 天监十三年，劫买此精舍，立为朱阳馆，将远符先征，定祥火历，於绾西，更筑隐居住止。 十四年，别创郁冈斋室，追玄洲之踪。 十七年，乃缮勒碑坛，仰述真轨。 真人姓许，讳穆，世名谧，字思玄，本汝南平舆人。 后汉灵帝中平二年，六世祖光，字少张，避许相谀侠，乃来过江，居丹阳句容都乡之吉阳里，后仕昊为光禄勋，识宇亮拔，奕叶才明。 祖尚，字元甫，有文章机见，昊中书郎。 父副，字仲先，器度淹通，风格清简，晋刻令、宁朔将军、下那太守、西城侯。 长史，副第五子也。 正#5生少知名，简文在藩，为世表之交，起家太学博士，朝纲礼肆，儒论所宗。 出为余姚令，勤恤民隐，惠彼邻邑。 征入凯闱，纳言帝侧。 升平末，除护军长史、本郡中正，外督戎章，内诠茂序，遐邦肃律，乡采砥行。 太和中，迁给事中、散骑常侍，蝉口辉华，事归尚德。 简文践极，方优国老，鲦值晏驾，於焉告退，专静山庐，以修上道。 君虽捂绂朝班，讽议庠塾，而心标象外， 志结霞门。 第四兄远游，永和四年，嘉遁不反。 君尚想幽奇，岁月弥翰，恒与杨君深神明之契。 兴宁中，众真降杨，备令宣谕，龙书云篆，会然褊该，灵谟#6奥旨，于兹必究，年涉悬车，遵行愈笃。 太元元年，解驾违世，春秋七十有二。 子孙#7礼定，虚柩於县西大墓，京陵之踪未远，飞剑之郑在焉。
chunks.translated_text:
「Though his **Daoist robes** were often brushed aside, hoping the great stone might not crumble,
He faced the ages with unyielding sincerity, gazing upon eternity with an open heart.
Yet he lamented that words could not fully express his meaning,
And wished the unseen might not judge him unfairly.

Thus he reverently inscribed this ode:
**Mysterious Mystery, the Origin of Marvels**,
**Treasure of the Celestial, the Spirit’s End**—
**Illuminated Wisdom** does not manifest in form,
**Enlightened Stillness**—how can it be spoken?

His mind sought paths beyond mortal reach,
His finger traced sources none could fathom.
Once he encountered this **common folk**,
Then he pondered the **ascended and the tumultuous**.
Lingering in the endless night,
His waves surged through the eternal gloom.
Swift as lightning, brief as the sun’s shadow,
Fleeting as stars in their course.
Both **transient and eternal lives** alike
Are but wandering spirits of the dark.
Since their **delusion** has passed,
There is no way to return.

Who mourns whom? Only the **Sage** and the **Worthy**—
They follow the **rules of harmony**,
Respond to the **assigned tasks of the square and round**.
As **Teacher** and **Friend**,
They serve as **Supreme Minister** and **Heavenly Guide**.

The **True Person** of **Huayang**,
His birthplace in the **Maoist** realm—
Solitary and pure, standing alone in brilliance,
Lofty as the **Celestial Phoenix’s** abode,
Like the **Jade Capital** beyond the sky,
Like the **Yellow River’s clarity**—once in a thousand years.

Your **Sage’s Virtue** stands alone and pure,
Delighting in the **Dao’s profound essence**,
Abandoning rank and renouncing glory—
Once in a thousand years, like the **Yellow River’s clarity**,
Lofty beyond the sky, like the **Jade Capital**.

Your **autumnal majesty** and **springtime benevolence**,
Your **sunlike warmth** and **moonlike luminosity**,
Your **golden firmness** and **jade-like refinement**,
Your **water’s purity** and **ice’s clarity**—
Enduring through the ages, revered in silence,
Your **transmitted glory** echoes, though distant.

This **spirit-inscribed tablet** stands as if **hosted by the Dark Star**,
With four remarkable features:
First, the craftsmen **carved the mountain**,
Yet found only this single stone—**preformed as if by fate**.
Second, all other stones could not bear as **footstones**,
But the one beneath the tablet’s base **resembled a crouching dragon**.
Third, the **hidden stones** formed a natural ring,
Yet only the **pillar’s resting place** bore a **spontaneous flame**.
Fourth, when the work was done,
A **flying spring** suddenly surged from the cavern.

On the tablet’s shadow and its narrow sides,
The names of **high Daoists** from the **Qi and Liang dynasties** were inscribed,
A faint glimpse of **adopted purity** and **wandering verses** on the stone pillars.
The **Natural Disciple** Xu Kai respectfully paid homage to **Huayang’s Celestial Abode**.

Many **Tang and Song-era inscriptions** have since faded or been lost.
The **Upper Clarity True Person** Xu Changshih’s former **shrine and altar tablet**—
His **Natural Disciple**, the **Huayang Hermit** Tao Hongjing, now reverently constructs this.

How vast and boundless it is—
The **Spirit of the Universe**!
It cannot be conveyed by **words or symbols**,
Nor recorded in **script or borders**.
Yet how else would later generations hear of it?

It **embraces and exhales all things**,
**Transforming and nurturing** both **dry and living**—
Its **origin** is **mysterious**,
Its **meaning** returns to **dim obscurity**.

As for **formal distinctions** and **divided natures**,
Or **matters limited by perception** and **principles exhausted by calculation**—
Even if one could speak of **mountains’ heights** or **seas’ breadths**,
Why should they be constrained by such **finite measures**?

Within the **Great Heaven** there are **thirty-six lesser heavens**,
All **expanding into the void**, **spanning the waters’ currents**,
**Opening gates to winds and valleys**, **connecting the qi of clouds and pathways**.

This mountain was originally called **Jùqū**,
Its eighth **cavernous palace** beneath it—
Named **Huayang’s Golden Furnace Heaven**,
It encircles **150 li**, divided into **three palaces**.
During the **Western Han Emperor Yuan’s reign**,
The **Three Mao Lords of Xianyang** attained the **Dao**,
And came to oversee this duty,
Hence it is called **Mao Mountain**—details are in the **transmission records**.

By **Jin Taihe Year 1**,
**Xu Changshih** built his residence here,
Its nearby remains still exist.
In the **early Song dynasty**,
The **Jingwang of Changsha** established a **Daoist retreat** on this site.
In **Year 13 of Tianjian**,
The **retreat was purchased** and renamed **Zhuyang Pavilion**,
To **respond to distant omens** and **establish the auspicious fire’s chronicle**.
In the **west of the mountain’s embrace**,
A **hermitage** was built for dwelling.
In **Year 14**,
A **retreat hall** was separately constructed on **Yùgāng Peak**,
Following the **tracing of Xuanzhou’s** footsteps.
In **Year 17**,
The **shrine and altar tablet** were then polished and inscribed,
To **reverently record the True Person’s path**.

The **True Person** bore the surname **Xu**, given name **Mù**,
Known in the world as **Xu Mi**,
With the courtesy name **Sī Xuán**.
Originally from **Píngyù, Rùnán**,
During the **Middle Plains Era of Emperor Ling of the Later Han**,
His **sixth-generation ancestor Xu Guang**,
Courtesy name **Shào Zhāng**,
Avoided the **Xu Chancellor’s** flattery and arrogance,
And came to **cross the Yangtze**,
Residing in **Jíyáng, Jùróng County’s** **Jìyáng Village**.
Later he served the **Han court** as **Light Glory General**,
Recognized by **Yu Xubao** for his talent,
With **descendants renowned for their brilliance**.

**Xu Shang**, courtesy name **Yuán Fǔ**,
Had **literary insight and foresight**,
And served as **Han’s Palace Attendant**.
**Xu Fù**, courtesy name **Zhòng Xiān**,
Was **broad and profound in bearing**,
With a **refined and simple style**,
Holding titles of **Jin’s Inspector of Yùe**, **Pacifying General**, **Governor of Xiànuò**, and **Western City Marquis**.

**Xu Changshih** was the **fifth son of Xu Fù**.
Though his **early life was obscure**,
He became a **model of esteem** while **Duke Jing of Jin** was in exile,
Starting as a **Master of the Imperial University**,
His **courtly conduct and scholarly discussions** revered in **Confucian circles**.
He was appointed **Magistrate of Yúmiáo County**,
Where he **diligently cared for the people’s hidden sufferings**,
And **benefited neighboring districts**.
When **called to the capital**, he **entered the imperial gate with triumph**,
And **offered counsel at the emperor’s side**.
By the **end of Emperor Cheng’s reign**,
He was promoted to **Protector of the Military** and **Supervisor of the Native County**,
**Commanding armies externally**, **interpreting sacred texts internally**,
**Distant lands obeying his laws**, **local customs refined by his governance**.
During the **Taihe Era**,
He was transferred to **Attendant of the Imperial Household** and **Constant Companion of the Imperial Guard**,
His **eloquence and brilliance** resounding,
His **affairs** returning to **upholding virtue**.

When **Duke Jing ascended the throne**,
He was **still honored as an elder of the state**,
But when **Duke Jing died**, he **withdrew in retirement**,
Devoting himself to **mountain seclusion** and **the highest Dao**.

Though you **dressed in official robes** and **discussed affairs in the halls of learning**,
Your **heart aspired beyond the world’s symbols**,
Your **resolve bound to the **Daoist** gates**.
Your **fourth elder brother** **Wanyou**,
In **Year 4 of Yonghe**,
**Happily departed**, never returning.
You still **yearned for the mysterious and strange**,
With each passing year, your **aspirations grew loftier**,
Always **deeply connected** with **Yang Shen** in **spiritual clarity**.
During the **Xīngníng Era**,
The **Daoist Immortals descended upon Yang Shen**,
Commanding him to **proclaim their decrees**,
With **dragon-script writings** and **divine seals**,
Their **words profound and encompassing**,
Their **mysterious meanings** now **fully explored**.
At **seventy-two**, you **abandoned your carriage**,
Your **pursuit of the Dao** ever more steadfast.

In **Year 1 of Taiyuan**,
You **passed away**, aged **72**.
Your **descendants** followed **proper rites**,
And placed your **empty coffin** in the **great tomb west of the county**.
Though the **capital’s traces** have faded,
The **flying sword’s** resting place remains.»

chunks.original_text: 谨按《真诰》，君挺命所基，绿业已久，周武王世，九宫上相长里薛公之弟也，兼许肇遗功，复应垂祉后胤，故乘运托生，因资成道，玉札所授，为上清真人，爵登侯伯，位编卿司，理仙抚治，佐圣牧民矣。 真传未显於世，莫能具述。 杨君讳义，事具《真诰》。 长史第三子，讳玉斧，世名都，字道翔。 正生母陶威女，先亡，已得在洞府，易迁宫中。 君清颖莹洁，特绝世伦，郡举上计缘，不赴。 枇糠尘务，研精上业，即弘景玄中之真师也。 怛居此宅，缮修经法。 杨君数相从就，亟通真感。 太和五年，於兹告逝，时年三十。 《真诰》云：后十六年当度束华为上相青童君之侍。 帝晨受书，为上清仙公，与谷希子并职。 帝晨之任，比世侍中。 君长兄揆，世名圳，次兄虎方，世名联，并亦得道。 揆今有玄孙灵真在山，劝立嗣真馆，以褒远祖之德。 皇上乘弘誓本力，来君此土，焘育苍祇，范铸旱品，导法开俗，随绿启教，以隐居积蕴，三真经诰，久栖华阳，宜还旧宅，供养修理，乃劝工匠，建兹堂靖。 即仰祇帝则，兼阐大猷。 东位青坛，西表素塔，坛塔之问，通是基址。 埋锟拚瓦，投镭便值，紫姻白雾，缠徊荫盖。 宅南一井，即长史所穿，井南大塘，乃郭朝遗制，源出田公之泉，路通姜巴之轨，旁枕雷平，前瞰下泊，束际连冈，北横长岭，柳沃阳谷，俱会西垂。 四域之内，皆谓之金陵地肺者也。 长史所居，尤为标胜。 方将驷云虹而高骋，驱奔鹤以追风，望洪涛之浩汗，卷故都以浸远。 古人有言，匪作奚传？ 敢刊石颂，永属来贤。 浑枢骛气，方祇吐灵。 依性分境，传识赋形。 化通八宇，功浃四淇。 巡迹电灭，测体渊停。 旋区岳立，一旦海云舒。 搏风泳水，蹶实冯虚。 亦有幽匠，开石架庐。 情高身远，天府地居。 萦峦已曲，画壤肺浮。 五闱面启，九徐环周。 长阳旁岭，交沃比流。 乃称龙伏，皇谓金丘。 昔在西汉，三茅来宾。 爰暨束晋，二许怀真。 裁基浚井，栖道接神。 允膺辅圣，锡兹侍宸。 参差年代，捆组名氏。 书诰具宣，精华未弭。 甄他为切。 梵将沦，沉阶已毁。 拱树霜摧，修庭草委。 肇倌华阳，岁缠二纪。 永观前猷，聿遵洪轨。 帝日林哉，尔焉斯止。 经之营之，输乎奂矣。 胜殿密响，泻瓶扬芬。 瑶宫碧简，绚采垂文。 玛函玉检，绮幕绣巾。 兰缸迥耀，金炉扬黑。 桐梧双教，方诸兼学。 并证心清，俱漏身浊。 离有离无，且华且朴。 结号虚皇，荃法正觉。 药征质莹，禅感慧通。 飞行钦悦，扪景带虹。 振苦排郭，还明反聪。 物言是力，我见无功。 纷纭今古，汗漫两仪。 三相幻惑，舟壑自移。 缘来则应，不虑不为。 式题龟录，人天鉴知。 碑阴记 此碑梁普通三年太岁壬寅金石刊。 至唐大历十三年太岁戊午，凡二百六十六年，文字将湮，中山刘明素字叹微重加洗刻也。 华阳隐居陶弘景，丹阳秣陵西乡下里人，宋孝建三年丙申岁夏至之日未晓时生。 仕齐高武世诸王侍读，奉朝请。 永明十年壬申岁，投绂栖山，住中茅岭上，立为华阳绾。 至梁天监四年，移居积金东涧。 七年，往永嘉楠江青蟑山。 十年，涉海诣霍山。 十一年夏，还木溜屿。 其年十月，奉劫迎还旧山。 十三年正月，至茅山，入住东涧。 十四年冬，徙来此绾。
chunks.translated_text:
In accordance with the *True Revelations* (*Zhēn Yì*), your noble lineage was rooted in the **Mandate of Heaven**, its green virtue enduring for ages. In the era of King Wu of Zhou, you were the younger brother of Lord Changli of Xuegong, the Ninth Palace’s high minister, and also bore the legacy of Xu Zhao’s meritorious deeds. Thus, you were destined to inherit blessings for future generations, ascending through fortune and birth to fulfill the Dao. By the decree of the Jade Tablets, you were ordained as **Upper Clarity True Person**, ennobled as a **Marquis**, and ranked among the **Ministers of State**, governing the Dao and nurturing the people alongside the Sage.

Though your **True Transmission** remained unseen in the world, none could fully recount it. You, **Master Yang**, named **Yì**, are documented in the *True Revelations*. As the third son of **Changshi**, you were named **Yùfǔ**, with the worldly name **Dū**, and the courtesy name **Dàoxiáng**. Your true mother, Lady Tao Wei, had already ascended to the **Cavern Palaces** and was later reincarnated in the imperial household. You were of **pure and luminous refinement**, surpassing all in your generation. Though recommended for the **Imperial Censorate**, you declined. Rejecting the dust of mundane affairs, you devoted yourself to the **Highest Path**, becoming the **True Master** of **Hongjing’s** esoteric teachings. Dwelling in this residence, you repaired and transmitted the **Sacred Scriptures and Methods**. Often, **Master Yang** would join you, and through repeated communion, you attained **True Sensation**.

In **Taihe Year 5**, you departed this life at thirty. The *True Revelations* proclaim: *"Sixteen years hence, you shall ascend to the **Bundle of Flowers** as the **Upper Minister**, serving the **Green Boy Lord**."* At dawn, you received the **Scriptures**, becoming **Upper Clarity Immortal Lord**, sharing duties with **Gǔ Xīzǐ**. Your station compared to that of a **Worldly Attendant**. Your elder brother, **Kuì**, with the worldly name **Zhèn**, and your second brother, **Hǔfāng**, with the worldly name **Lián**, also attained the Dao. **Kuì** now has a **Celestial Descendant**, **Língzhēn**, in the mountains, urging the establishment of a **Hall for True Succession** to honor the distant ancestors.

By the **Sovereign’s solemn vow**, you were summoned to this land, where you **nurtured the myriads** and **molded the virtuous**. You **propagated the Law** and **opened the common folk** to its teachings, drawing upon your **hidden reserves** of the **Three True Ones**. Having long dwelled in **Huayang**, it was fitting to restore your ancestral home, tending to its upkeep. Thus, the craftsmen were summoned to erect this **Hall of Tranquility**, aligning with the **Celestial Sovereign’s decrees** and elucidating the **Great Plan**.

To the east, the **Green Altar** stands; to the west, the **White Pagoda** rises. Between them lies this foundation. Buried **jade tokens** and **sacred tiles** were unearthed, their **purple bonds** and **white mists** lingering like protective canopies. To the south of the residence lies a well—dug by **Changshi**—and beyond it, a great pond, a remnant of the **Guo Dynasty’s** design. Its source flows from **Tian Gong’s Spring**, its path following the **Ma-Jia Road**, flanked by **Lei Ping’s ridges** and overlooking **Xia Bo’s expanse**. To the north, the **Long Ridge** stretches, while the **Yang Valley’s** willows bend westward. Within these four boundaries, it is called the **"Golden Ling’s Lung"**—and **Changshi’s** dwelling was its most distinguished site.

Now, with **rainbow clouds** and **soaring cranes**, you soar high, gazing upon the **vast tides** and sweeping the **ancient capital** into the distance. As the ancients said, *"Who would dare not transmit this?"* Thus, I dare to inscribe this stele, offering it to future worthies.

The **Cosmic Pivot’s breath** now exhales its **Numinous Essence**. Following **Nature’s divisions**, **Awareness** manifests **Form**. Your **Transformation** permeates the **Eight Quarters**, your **Virtue** saturates the **Four Seas**. Your **Traces** vanish like lightning; your **Substance** rests in the **Abyss**. Suddenly, **Mountains rise**; the **Sea’s clouds** unfold. You **Ride the Wind and Swim the Waters**, **Tread the Real and Soar the Void**. Even the **Hidden Artisans** carved stone to build your halls. Your **Aspirations** soared beyond the body, your **Celestial Treasury** rooted in the earth. The **Coiling Peaks** curve gracefully, the **Painted Fields** float like lungs. The **Five Enclosures** face open, the **Nine Rivers** encircle. The **Longyang Ridges** intersect, their **Lush Valleys** meeting the **Flowing Streams**.

Thus, it is called **"Dragon’s Lair"**—the **Sovereign’s Golden Hill**. In ancient **Western Han**, the **Three Teachings** came as guests. From **Late Jin onward**, the **Two Xu** embraced the **True**. They **dug the foundations**, **dug the well**, and **dwelled in the Dao**, welcoming the **Divine**. You were **worthy to assist the Sage**, granted this **Celestial Attendance**. Across the ages, **Names and Clans** intertwine like **Twisted Silk**. The **Scriptures and Decrees** are fully proclaimed; their **Essence** has not faded. Yet, **others** have grown distant.

The **Dharma’s decline** has sunk into ruin. The **Court’s trees** wither under frost; the **Hall’s courtyard** is overgrown with grass. Since **Huayang’s** establishment, two decades have passed. Ever mindful of the past, we follow the **Grand Path**. The **Sovereign decrees**: *"Here, you shall rest."* The **Hall’s construction** is complete, its **Resonances** profound. The **Jade Bottle’s fragrance** ascends; the **Lantern’s glow** shines bright. The **Bamboo and Willow** halls teach dual paths; the **Square and Round** schools coexist. All **attain Pure Mind**, yet **Body’s impurities** remain. **With and Without** intertwine—**Refined yet Unadorned**. You are **Named the Void Sovereign**, your **Law** the **True Awakening**. **Medicinal Proofs** reveal your **Substance’s Luminosity**; **Zen Insight** awakens your **Enlightened Penetration**. Your **Flight** brings **Reverence and Joy**; your **Grasping the Shadow** bears the **Rainbow’s Glow**. You **Dispel Suffering** and **Return Clarity**, **Restore Hearing**. **Things speak of your Power**; **I see no merit in myself**. The **Confusion of Past and Present** swirls boundless—**Yin and Yang** drift without end. The **Three Realms** deceive; the **Boat and Chasm** shift by themselves. **Coming, you respond**; **without deliberation, you act**. The **Tortoise’s Script** records this; **Humans and Celestials** bear witness.

**Inscribed on the stele’s reverse**:
This stele was carved in **Liang Wùtóng Year 3 (542 CE)**, the **Year of the Tiger (Rényǒu)**, in **Metal and Stone**. By **Tang Dàlì Year 13 (778 CE)**, the **Year of the Horse (Wùwǔ)**, **266 years** had passed, and the text was fading. **Mountain Surname Liu**, styled **Míngsù**, of **Zhongshān**, re-carved it.

**Huayang Hermit Tao Hongjing**, a native of **Jiānlíng’s Xi Xiāng Xiālǐ in Danyang**, was born on the **Summer Solstice**, just before dawn, in the **Year of the Monkey (Bingshēn)**, **Song Xiàojiàn Year 3 (456 CE)**. He served as **Attendant Reader** to the **Princes of Qi** under **High Emperor Gao** and was **Enfeoffed in Court**. In **Yǒngmíng Year 10 (492 CE)**, the **Year of the Monkey (Rénshēn)**, he resigned, retreated to the mountains, and resided on **Middle Teachings Peak**, establishing himself as **Huayang Master**. By **Liang Tiānjiàn Year 4 (507 CE)**, he moved to **Jījīn’s Eastern Ravine**. In **Year 7**, he traveled to **Lóngjiāng’s Qingcháng Mountain** in **Yǒngjiā**. In **Year 10**, he crossed the sea to **Huòshān**. In **Year 11**, summer, he returned to **Mùliú Isle**. That October, he was **summoned by imperial decree** back to his ancestral mountain. In **Year 13**, January, he arrived at **Maoshan**, residing in the **Eastern Ravine**. In **Year 14**, winter, he relocated to this **Hall**.

chunks.original_text: #1且：笪本作『日』。 #2关：笪本作『直』。 #3戒：疑当作『结』 #4遥：原作『道』，据笪本改。 #5正：原作『王』，据笪本改。 #6谟：笪本作『模』， #7孙：笪本作『侄』。 茅山志卷之二十一 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 录金石篇 梁碑 陶先生朱阳颇碑 梁元帝造 昔太和中，有许远游者，乃云霄之胜友#1，太虚之选客。 先生规同矩合，实踵高步，曩基先构，即架胥宇。 千寻危耸，凭牖以望奔星； 百拱高悬，倚阑而观朝日。 飞流界道，似天汉之横波； 触石起云，若奇峰之出岫。 铭日：肇彼冥默，翻成协赞。 身托外臣，心同有乱。 重道遵德，爰积截衷。 顾怀汾射，玺问遥通。 朱阳郁起，华构方崇。 静台冠月，轻#2榭迎风。 瞧晓高楝，杳霭修拢。 极望山川，周观京陆。 碧蟑千岭，清流万谷。 景落崖重，姻生岫复。 阙文 茅山长沙绾碑 华阳陶隐居撰。 夫万象森罗，不离两仪所有，百法纷赓，无越三教之境。 播绂之士，饰礼容於闱阁，耿介之夫，歇旌麾於山裔。 铭曰：大哉乾元，万物资始。 皇王受命，三才乃理9惟圣感神，惟神降祉。 德被歌锺，名昭图史。 友于兄弟，敬惟西宣。 言追茂实，用表遗先。 敢循旧制，有革杂章。 刊石弗朽，奕代流芳。 茅山曲林馆碑 华阳陶隐居撰。 层岭外峙，邃宫内映，仄穴旁通，萦泉远镜。 尚德依仁，祈生斓命，且天且地，若凡若圣。 连甍比楝，各谓知道。 参差经卫，跌岩辞藻。 孰如曲林，独为劲好。 掩迩韬功，守兹偕老。 华阳隐居真迹帖 元帝在藩，送碑入山，今犹在朱阳绾束。 又有南平王萧伟所造清远之绾，即弘景弟子桓清远所居。 桓师名法闲，缺二字公之师也。 其桓师初入山，作诗日：寒谷夜将晨，置赏复寻真。 方坛垂密叶，彻水波朱鳞。 杏林虽伏兽，芝田诅俟人。 丹成方转石，炉变欲销银。 当知胜地远，於此绝嚣尘。 邵陵王曾入茅山寻桓清远，乃题壁诗日：荆门丘壑多，瓮牖风云入。 自非栖遁情，谁堪霜露湿。 朱阳馆西又有长沙嗣王所造长沙之绾，基址存焉。 梁昌侯又造石碑，弘景制文，今亦在朱阳绾。 北二里有处士周弘让宅。 雷平山有水日柳谷济，又名田公泉。 今按《茅传》云：在山之左，济名柳谷，在陵之西，日阳谷。 昔有田叔居之取水，因以为号，此泉是玉津砂，饮之益人，今有水院衣，不须灰也。 弘景石颂日：左带柳济水，右浚阳谷济。 土怀北郁色，井出风门泉。 又有郭于池者，昔燕国郭朝兄弟四人，皆云#3得道，亦任洞中之职。 四朝居长，初至山，种植於此，郭干号因斯兆焉。 石刻前制隐居小像，初真迹藏建安徐闳中家。 宋宣和癸卯十二月，道士芳南华摹刻传世。 华阳隐居授门弟子陆敬游十责文 隐居先生遣总事弟子戴坦，秉茉执简膝授前学弟子吴郡陆敬游，建连石之邑，为栖静处士。 策文曰： 咨尔敬游，昔我纡绂帝闱，侍笋梁席，虽迩混教涂，而心标逸境芝田之想，无忘晓夜濠颖之志。 岁月已深，至德有邻，风云相会，尔之来也，爰移两春。 於是褫带青墀，挂冠朱阙，拥手东驱，创居兹岭。 脉润通水，徙石开基，登崖断干，越垄负卉，筋力尽於登筑，气血疲乎趋走。 肌#4色憔悴，不以暴露为苦，心魂空嫌，宁顾饥寒之弊？ 栋宇既立，载罹霜暑，于时七稔，经始甫讫。

「#1*Yè* [笪本作『日』]: **Day**
#2*Jié* [关]: **Rectified** [or *Zhí* [直]]
#3*Jié* [戒]: **Doubtful, perhaps should be『结』** [Bound/Joined]
#4*Yáo* [遥]: **Dao/Way** [原作『道』，据笪本改]
#5*Shì* [正]: **Succeeded** [原作『王』，据笪本改]
#6*Mó* [谟]: **Model** [笪本作『模』]
#7*Sǐ* [孙]: **Nephew** [笪本作『侄』]

**Volume Twenty-One of the Records of Maoshan**
Composed by **Succeeded Master of Shangqing, Liú Dàbīn**
Recorded in the **Gold and Stone Section**
**Records of Liang**
**Inscription for Master Táo of Zhúyáng’s Precious Retreat**
Composed by **Emperor of Liang**

In the **Tàihé** era, there was **Xǔ Yuǎn**, a wandering traveler, who was a **cherished friend of Yúnxiāo** and a **refined guest of Tàixū**. The Master’s conduct was as precise as a square and round, his footsteps truly followed the **Dao/Way** of the noble. Before the foundations were laid, he had already raised the structure. Towering heights defied measure, allowing one to gaze upon the **Flying Star** through the windows; lofty arches soared, leaning upon the balustrades to behold the **rising sun**. The cascading waters formed a boundary along the **Dao/Way**, like the **Celestial River**’s horizontal waves; striking the rocks, they rose as clouds, as if **odd peaks** emerged from their **recesses**. The inscription reads:

> *He began in profound silence,*
> *Yet transformed into harmony and praise.*
> *Though his body was entrusted to the outer realm,*
> *His heart aligned with the **Dao/Way** of chaos.*
> *He adhered to the **Dao/Way** and followed **virtue/power**,*
> *Thus accumulating sincere devotion.*
> *He looked back to Fénshè,*
> *And inquired through distant seals.*
> *The retreat of Zhúyáng flourished,*
> *The pavilions of **virtue/power** rose in splendor.*
> *The quiet terrace crowned the moon,*
> *The light **#2** pavilion welcomed the wind.*
> *Gazing at the dawn’s lofty branches,*
> *Lost in misty heights, his elegance refined.*
> *His vision spanned the mountains and rivers,*
> *Surveying the **imperial capital** and lands beyond.*
> *Emerald ridges stretched a thousand peaks,*
> *Clear streams flowed through ten thousand valleys.*
> *Shadows fell upon layered cliffs,*
> *Grace blossomed in hidden recesses.*

**Inscription for the Longshà Retreat of Máo Mountain**
Composed by **Táo Yǐnjū of Huáyáng**

The myriad phenomena of the cosmos, though vast and intricate, do not exceed the realm of **Yīn** and **Yáng**. The hundred teachings, though diverse, do not surpass the boundaries of the **Three Teachings**. Those who adorn their **Dao/Way** with rituals and propriety confine themselves to the **inner chambers** of the court; those of upright character abandon their **flags and banners** in the **mountainous wilderness**. The inscription reads:

> *Great is the **Primordial Dao/Way** of Heaven,*
> *All things derive their origin from it.*
> *When the **Sovereign Kings** receive their mandate,*
> *The **Three Powers** are thereby harmonized.*
> *Only the **sage** perceives the **spirit**,*
> *Only the **spirit** bestows blessings.*
> *His **virtue/power** shines in songs and bells,*
> *His name is recorded in **maps and histories**.*
> *He cherished his brothers as friends,*
> *With reverence for **Xī Xuān**.**
> *His words followed the **flourishing deeds** of the past,*
> *His actions honored the **legacy of his ancestors**.*
> *He dared to follow ancient customs,*
> *Yet innovated among the **mixed teachings**.*
> *Engraved on stone, it shall not decay,*
> *Its fragrance will endure through generations.*

**Inscription for the Qǔlín Retreat of Máo Mountain**
Composed by **Táo Yǐnjū of Huáyáng**

Layered ridges stood outside,
Deep halls reflected within,
Slanted caves connected nearby,
Coiling springs mirrored afar.
He aspired to **virtue/power** and leaned on **ren**,
Praying for life and **virtue/power**’s command,
Between **Heaven** and **Earth**,
Like the **ordinary** and the **sage**.
Roofs aligned with lofty branches,
Each declared their understanding of the **Dao/Way**.
Ascending the **ancient paths** of **Jīngwèi**,
Climbing the rocks, his words refined.
Who could rival **Qǔlín**?
Only it stood as the **most robust and splendid**.
Concealing his nearness, he **refined his skill**,
Guarding this place until his **end of life**.
The **true handwriting** of **Huáyáng’s recluse** remains.

**Note on the Original Handwriting of Emperor Yuǎndì:**
When **Emperor Yuǎndì** was still a **feudal prince**, he sent the inscription to the mountain, which still remains in the **Zhúyáng’s retreat**.

Additionally, there was the **Longyuǎn retreat** constructed by **Nánpíng Wáng Xiāo Wěi**, where **Hóngjǐng’s** disciple **Xuān Qīngyuǎn** resided. **Xuān** was the **Master of the Dao/Way** named **Fǎxián**, the **missing two characters** being his teacher. When the **Master of Xuān** first entered the mountain, he composed a poem:

> *In the cold valley as morning approaches,*
> *I seek both the **scenic beauty** and the **true Dao**.*
> *The square altar is shaded by dense leaves,*
> *The water reveals the **scarlet scales** of fish.**
> *Though the **peach grove** may shelter beasts,*
> *The **mushroom fields** await the **worthy**.*
> *Once the **elixir** is refined, the **stones** will transform,*
> *When the **furnace** changes, the **silver** will melt.*
> *Know that this **victorious place** is distant,*
> *Here, one is **free from worldly dust**.*

**Emperor Zhāo Líng Wáng** once entered **Máo Mountain** to seek **Xuān Qīngyuǎn**, and inscribed a poem on the wall:

> *The **Jīngmén** hills and valleys are many,*
> *The **wine jar**’s window lets in **wind and clouds**.*
> *Unless one harbors the **recluse’s spirit**,*
> *Who can endure the **dew and frost**?’

In the **west of Zhúyáng’s retreat**, there was also the **Longshà retreat** constructed by **Longshà’s Succeeded King**, whose foundations still remain. **Liáng Chāng Hóu** also erected a **stone stele**, with **Hóngjǐng** composing the inscription, now also found in **Zhúyáng’s retreat**.

Two miles north, there is the residence of the **recluse Zhōu Hóngràng**. On **Léipíng Mountain**, there is a spring named **Liǔgǔ Jì**, also called **Tián Gōng Quán**. According to the *Máo Transmission*, it states: *On the left of the mountain, the spring is named Liǔgǔ; on the west of the ridge, it is called Yánggǔ.* In the past, **Tián Shū** resided here and drew water, thus naming it. This spring is the **Yùjīn Shā** water, which benefits one’s health. Today, its water is so pure that **clothes washed in it do not require ash**.

**Hóngjǐng’s stone ode reads:**

> *To the left, the **Liǔgǔ** spring flows,*
> *To the right, the **Yánggǔ** spring rises.*
> *The earth cradles the **north’s dark hues**,
> *The well yields the **wind’s gate spring**.*

There was also the **Guō Yú** pool. In the past, the **Yān brothers**—**Guō Cháo** and his three siblings—all claimed to have **attained the Dao**, and they also held **official positions in the cavern**. **Guō Cháo** was the eldest, and when he first arrived at the mountain, he cultivated here, naming the pool **Yú** as an omen of this **auspicious sign**.

A **stone carving** of **Táo Yǐnjū’s** earlier **small portrait** was initially hidden in the **house of Jiàn’ān Xú Hóng**. In the **Xuánhé Year 12 (1120 CE)** of the **Song Dynasty**, the **Daoist** **Fāng Nánhúá** copied and engraved it, passing it down through generations.

**Huáyáng’s recluse taught his disciples, Lù Jìngyóu, with ten responsibilities.**
**Táo Yǐnjū’s** **Master** dispatched his **senior attendant disciple** **Dài Tǎn**, who carried **a bamboo tablet and a writing brush**, kneeling to impart the ** Dao/Way** to his **junior disciple** **Lù Jìngyóu of Wújùn**, establishing a **settlement of connected stones** as a **place for dwelling in tranquility**. The **inscription on the tablet** reads:

> *O, respectful Jìngyóu!*
> *In the past, I served in the **imperial court’s** chambers,*
> *Attending the **sprouts and dishes** of the **Liáng** court.*
> *Though close to the **mixed teachings**’s path,*
> *My heart yearned for the **recluse’s realm**,*
> *Never forgetting the **dawn and night**’s aspiration for **Máo and Jǐng**.*
>
> *Years have deepened,*
> *Yet **virtue/power** remains nearby.*
> *The **wind and clouds** gather,*
> *As you arrive, two springs have passed.*
>
> *Thus, I remove my **official belt** from the **blue steps**,*
> *Hang my **hat** at the **red gate**,*
> *Clasping hands, I drive eastward,*
> *Founding a residence on these ridges.*
> *The **veins and moisture** of the land connect with the waters,*
> *Moving stones to lay the foundations,*
> *Ascending cliffs to sever the **dry branches**,*
> *Crossing mounds to bear the **plants**.*
> *My strength was exhausted in climbing and building,*
> *My **qi** and blood fatigued from rushing and walking.*
> *My skin and flesh grew emaciated,*
> *Yet I did not grieve at the **harsh exposure**.*
> *My **spirit** and soul were light and empty,*
> *Would I care about the **hardships of hunger and cold**?*
>
> *The halls and dwellings now stand,*
> *Enduring the **frost and heat** of the seasons.*
> *Seven years have passed,*
> *The initial construction has just been completed.*

chunks.original_text: 今日之安，尔有勤焉。 君子不独居其荣，仁人必与物同泰。 是用邑尔长阿北阪积金山连石之乡，方七十步，涧水属焉。 茂尔嘉业，永为华阳上宾，尔其花之。 其一尔以诚殷为性，恬澹为情，质直居本，沉重树志。 不邀世才，高谢接俗，权谋诡谲，非意所欲，今故查尔为栖静处士，可谓因德立号，克终斯美。 其二尔基架绾境，营划援域，堂坛弘敞，楼路通严，官私行止，并有栖憩。 缮筑之劳，莫匪尔力。 今故责尔四溜飞轩、厢廓侧屋，可以安身静外，显祇遐福。 其三尔奉上惟勤，接下以惠，稼穑艰难，备尝劳苦，货殖之宜，允赡粮服，手足胼胝，未获告休，栉风沐雨，於焉尤切。 今故责尔苍头一人，厥名多益，可以传代薪水，省息劬剧。 其四尔族惟旧绪，身乃邦闻，道虽一贯，事望宜分，今故责尔钢铁如意，可以挥对宾僚，即名立事。 其五尔崇教惟善，法无偏执，器服表用，爰寄玩习，今故责尔竿竹锡杖，可以振动三界，精祇惮响。 其六尔期诚玄契，遐想灵风，至怀所诣，因心则通，今故责尔香炉一枚，专陆副之，可以腾姻紫阁，昭感上司。 其七尔澡形洁藏，肴粮既去，宣导松木，实资芳醋，今故责尔杯盘一具，可以夕抱桂浆，朝承菊露。 其八尔敬事经诰，遵尚楷模，翰墨之用於是乎在，今故责尔大砚一面，纸笔副之，可以临文写字，对真喂言， 其九尔贞心内固，清行外彰，涤荡纷秽，表裹雪霜，今故责尔蝓石澡灌，手巾为副，可以登斋朝拜，出入盥漱。 其十今责尔十事，事准前史，可对扬嘉策，循言求理，无或骄情，以骞斯旨，援笔申怀，敢告处士。 梁解真中散大夫贞白先生陶隐居碑铭 邵陵王萧纶撰 夫夜光结绿，非胱筐之恒珍，逸羽翔鳞，岂园池之近玩？ 宁期心於远大，盖不知其所以然也。 是以颖阳高蹈，洗耳於唐朝，汉阴贞栖，灭迩於周代。 盛德流风，有自来矣。 应期而耀质者，其在兹乎。 先生名弘景，字通明，本冀州平阳人。 其先出自帝尧陶唐氏之后，尧治冀州平阳，故因居此。 龙马见五色之符，钦明表八采之瑞，光被於天下，允厘於庶职，洪源厦远，系绪绵长。 汉兴，於#5舍为高祖右司马。 子青翟，位至丞相。 后汉末南渡，始居丹阳。 七世祖浚，仕昊为镇南将军、刑州刺史。 祖隆，宋南中郎参军事。 父贞宝，司徒、建安王国侍郎。 并立履清约，博涉文史。 先生含元精之和气，蓄凌飕之雅姿，兼宣七善，总修九德，行仁蹈义，岳峙渊停，墙仞无以睹，清浊不能测，道风与星汉俱高，胜气与姻霞共远。 六岁便解书，能属文，七岁读《孝经》、《论语》、《毛诗》数万言。 曼倩幼习坟典，公干少诵诗赋，方之於古，彼有多惭，是以岐疑流声，中黄着颂。 有乡人得葛洪《神仙传》，见淮南八公诸仙事，乃叹日：读此书使人有凌云之气。 於是寝兴讽诵，晨昏不辍。 年二十七岁，为宜都王侍读，总知管记事。

**For the Ten Gifts:**

> *Today’s tranquility is due to your diligence.*
> *A gentleman does not hoard his honors alone,*
> *And a virtuous person must share prosperity with all.*
> *Thus, I bestow upon you the **Long Alley** in the North Ridge,*
> *A land of piled gold and linked stone,*
> *Square in measure, seventy paces,*
> *Where the ravine’s waters flow.*
> *Prosper your noble endeavors,*
> *And forever be the honored guest of Hua yang.*
> *May you flourish in it.*

> *First, your nature is sincere and earnest,*
> *Your temperament serene and modest,*
> *Your essence straightforward, your resolve profound.*
> *You do not seek worldly talent,*
> *Nor flatteringly embrace the vulgar,*
> *Nor indulge in cunning schemes—*
> *These are not your desires.*
> *Now I grant you the **Four-Sided Flying Pavilion** and **Side Chambers**,*
> *Where you may dwell in quietude,*
> *Displaying reverence and inviting distant blessings.*

> *Second, you have established boundaries within your domain,*
> *Expanded its reach and fortified its borders,*
> *With spacious halls and towering paths,*
> *Where both officials and commoners may rest.*
> *The labor of repair and construction*
> *Is none other than your own strength.*
> *Now I grant you the **Four-Sided Flying Pavilion** and **Side Chambers**,*
> *To shelter your body and still your mind,*
> *To resound with the **sublime** and evoke distant blessings.*

> *Third, you serve above with unwavering diligence,*
> *And aid below with boundless kindness.*
> *The toil of farming is arduous,*
> *You have tasted all its hardships.*
> *Yet the yield of commerce*
> *Is abundant in grain and cloth,*
> *Your hands and feet calloused,*
> *No respite in sight,*
> *Braving wind and rain with devotion.*
> *Now I grant you a **single laborer** named Duo Yi,*
> *To pass on the **firewood and water** duties,*
> *And spare you the toil of exertion.*

> *Fourth, your lineage follows ancient traditions,*
> *Your name is known throughout the realm.*
> *Though your **Dao** is singular,*
> *Your deeds must be divided.*
> *Now I grant you a **steel as-you-wish** sword,*
> *To wield before guests and kin,*
> *And thus establish your name in deeds.*

> *Fifth, you uphold **teachings** with goodness,*
> *Your laws know no partiality.*
> *Your vessels and attire mark their purpose,*
> *Now I grant you a **bamboo staff** and **ceremonial staff**,*
> *To shake the **Three Realms** and command the **spirits**.*
> *The **sublime** tremble at your resonance.*

> *Sixth, your heart’s sincerity is profound,*
> *Your distant thoughts like **divine winds**.*
> *Your deepest aspirations are fulfilled,*
> *And your mind aligns with them.*
> *Now I grant you a **single incense burner**,*
> *To be paired with its **fragrant offerings**,*
> *To ascend the **Purple Hall** in prayer,*
> *And reveal your devotion to the **Heavenly Masters**.*

> *Seventh, you purify your form and store your essence,*
> *Having set aside **meat and grain**.*
> *You proclaim the **virtues of pinewood**,*
> *And truly rely on **fragrant vinegar**.*
> *Now I grant you a **set of cup and plate**,*
> *To evening embrace **osmanthus wine**,*
> *And morning receive **chrysanthemum dew**.*

> *Eighth, you revere **rites and scriptures**,*
> *And follow the **model of the ancients**.*
> *Your use of **brush and ink** is here,*
> *Now I grant you a **large inkstone** and its **complements**,*
> *To transcribe texts and converse with the **True Ones**,*
> *And speak with the **Venerable Worthies**.*

> *Ninth, your heart is pure within,*
> *Your conduct clear without.*
> *You wash away the **turbulent and impure**,*
> *And wrap yourself in **snow and frost**.*
> *Now I grant you **oyster-shell** for **ritual cleansing**,*
> *And **hand towels** as your attendants,*
> *To ascend the **altar** in morning prayer,*
> *And purify yourself in entering and exiting.*

> *Tenth, now I present these ten gifts,*
> *Each in accordance with **precedent**.*
> *They follow the **words of old**,*
> *And you may consult them to seek **principle**.*
> *Let no pride arise within you,*
> *For this is my **intention**.*
> *I now take up my pen to express my heart,*
> *And humbly declare to the **Recluse**.*

**Inscription for Master Zhenbai’s Retreat at Tao’s Hidden Dwelling**
Composed by **Prince Xiao Yun of Shaoling**
**Master Zhenbai’s** name was **Hongjing**, with the courtesy name **Tongming**, originally from **Pingyang in Ji Province**.

His ancestors descended from **Emperor Yao’s** **Tao-Tang lineage**,
For Yao ruled **Ji Province’s** **Pingyang**,
And thus they settled there.
When the **dragon horse** beheld the **Five-Colored Auspicious Symbols**,
And the **reverent and bright** displayed the **Eight Auspicious Patterns**,
Their **radiance** spread across the **lands**,
Their **virtue** extended to all **officials**.
Their **grand lineage** stretched far and wide,
Their **ties** unbroken and long.
When the **Han Dynasty** arose,
He served as **Emperor Gaozu’s** **Right General of the Palace**.
His son, **Qingzhi**, rose to the rank of **Chancellor**.
In the late **Eastern Han**, after migrating south,
They first resided in **Danyang**.
His seventh-generation ancestor, **Jun**, served under **Emperor Wu of Jin** as **General Pacifying the South** and **Magistrate of Xing Prefecture**.
His grandfather, **Long**, was a **Military Advisor to the Southern Commander** in the **Song Dynasty**.
His father, **Zhenbao**, held the posts of **Secretary of State** and **Attendant to the Prince of Jian’an**.
All bore **clean and upright conduct**,
And were **well-versed in literature and history**.

Master **Hongjing** possessed the **harmonious breath of primordial essence**,
And bore the **elegant bearing of the lofty winds**.
He encompassed the **Seven Virtues**,
And cultivated the **Nine Powers**.
He walked the **Dao of Benevolence** and trod the **Path of Righteousness**,
Like a **mountain standing firm** and a **pool abiding deep**,
Whose **height** cannot be measured,
Whose **depth** cannot be fathomed.
His **Dao** soared as high as the **Milky Way**,
His **noble spirit** extended as far as the **celestial clouds**.

At **six years old**, he already understood **writing**,
And could compose **prose**.
By **seven**, he had read **thousands of words** from the *Scripture on Filial Piety*, the *Analects*, and the *Mao Commentary on the Odes*.
From a young age, he **delighted in** the **classics**,
And as a boy, he **recited** **poetry and prose**.
Compared to the **ancients**, they would have **much to be ashamed of**,
Thus he **doubted his own worth** and **praised others**.
Because of this, he **withdrew from public life** and **composed odes**.

There was a **villager** who obtained **Ge Hong’s** *Transmission of the Immortals*,
And read of the **Eight Worthies of Huainan** and other **sages’** deeds,
Then sighed, saying: *"Reading this book gives one **the spirit of soaring above the clouds**."*
From then on, he **studied it night and day**,
Without pause from **dawn to dusk**.

At **twenty-seven**, he became **Attendant Scholar to the Prince of Yi**,
And **supervised the Palace Archives**.

chunks.original_text: 膀道求贤，禁林招士，朝难其选咸日得人。 阮璃之书记，不足扶衡，孙楚之辞才，何以捧毂，齐代好治宫室，方修苑囿青溪旧馆，更就起筑，仍奏表上颂词，事兼美迈，彼乐职之篇，瑜乎景福之制。 帝省览久之，益以为善，除奉朝请。 恪居官次，夙夜惟夤，春朝秋请，是谓械朴者也。 先生本不希荣，常欲辞退，乃与亲友书日：畴昔之意，不愿处人问。 年登四十，毕志山薮。 今已三十六矣时不我借，知几其神乎，毋为自苦也。 明年遂拜表自解，抽簪束郭之外，解组北山之阿，同稷丘之栖隐，慕留侯之却粒，便具舟橄，永言束迈。 朝廷锡问，时贤饯别祖以二疏括兹四隐，超然轻举，异代同符。 尔乃杖策遐征，游践名岳，既而到于句容，登於茅岭以此地神仙之官府，灵异之栖托，往而不返，遂卜居焉。 先生日：夫子云：隐居以求其志，行义以达其道。 吾闻其语，未见其人。 今我义达，无复其方，请同求志之业，故自称隐居，亦由稚川之抱朴，士安之玄晏。 倚岩栖影，依林遁边，交柯结宇，刻径为门，悬崖对溜，悲昤灌木，深壑峭岭，组织姻霞，枕石漱流，山禽无挠，采药偶从，野兽不乱。 逍遥闲旷，放浪丘陵，俗然若丧，确乎难拔。 属齐末道丧，天命既否，水国洛谷，地震甲辰，先生静思冥数，预识其兆，於是远近书问一皆杜绝。 昔乃闻之夏甫，今则见之先生。 我大梁休运应期，受天明命，三辰开朗，四海宁谧。 先生奉表称庆，於是信问复通。 自天监以来，常有劫旨供给药饵不乏，岁时渥泽深恩，莫之与比。 先生七年暂游南岳。 兹山也，辟闱风之地轴，若昆陵之天镇，八表旁临，九纯间设，树有琅牙，草生车骑，遗世独往，是用忘归。 十一年，有劲遣左右司徒慧明征先生还茅山，别给解宇。 轩君之降情天老，汉帝之致礼河上，况於兹日，弗能尚也。 养志山河，多历年所，摄生既至，冥祥亦降，猛兽不据，魑魅莫逢，庭无刻棘，远同阙里，阶吐神泉，遥扶疏勒。 於是羽人徘徊，仙客上下，鸾凤游集，芝英丰润矣。 以大同二年，岁在丙辰，三月壬寅朔，十二日癸丑，告别迁化，春秋八十有一。 天子嗟惜，储皇翰悼，有诏称誉，追赠中散大夫，谧日贞白先生，礼也。 以其月十四日定于丹阳郡句容县之雷平山，若轩辕之葬衣冠，如子乔之藏剑乌，比於兹日，可得符焉。 先生器宇凝深，思议精赡，含章贞吉，不修廉隅。 年将中寿，匪瑜於矩，眉目疏朗，仪貌鲜洁，皇忘劝沮，多行德惠。 宝惜光景，爱好坟籍，笃志励节，白首弥至。 若乃淮南鸿宝之诀、陇西地动之仪、太乙遁甲之书、九章历象之术、幼安银钩之敏、允南风角之妙、太仓素问之方、中散琴操之法，成悉搜求，靡不精诣。 爰及羿射、荀棋、苏卜、管筮，一见便晓，皆不用心。 张华之博物、马均之巧思、刘向之知微、葛洪之养性，兼此数贤，一人而已。 门人桓法阅等慕遥风於维氏，结遗想於乔阳，勒玄碑而相质，腾绛霄而流芳。 乃作铭日： 留乌表化，弃剑凝神。 徘徊紫黑，照耀丹林。 厥迩犹在，余风可遵。 谁其嗣此，渊哉淑人。 高行迈种，盛德日新。 朗犹悬镜，郁似贞筠。 身以弘道，行不违仁。 昔游缨绂，颉顽缙神。 厌乎匡救，劳彼问津。

The Prince sought worthy men, and the imperial gardens summoned scholars—
the court found no fault in its selection, for all who came were men of worth.
Obscured though Oblique’s literary skill might be, it could not rival the balance of a scribe,
Nor could Sun Chu’s eloquence suffice to bear the weight of his reputation.
In the Qi dynasty, there was a fondness for grand palaces—
now the Prince was restoring the old gardens of Qingxi, rebuilding and expanding them,
and submitting a petition with a commemorative ode.
The work was splendid and refined—
his poem of joyful service matched the brilliance of the *Jingfu* edicts.

The Emperor read it for a long time and deemed it excellent,
then granted him the title of *Deliberative Attendant at Court*.
He took up his post with solemn duty,
ever vigilant from dawn to dusk,
attending the spring and autumn audiences—
this was the way of the unadorned and sincere.

The Master had never sought honor,
yet often wished to resign.
He wrote to his kin and friends:
*"In my earlier years, I never wished to be asked by others."*
At forty, he fulfilled his ambition in the mountains and forests.
Now thirty-six, time would not wait—
how divine was his foresight!
Why should he torment himself further?

The following year, he submitted his resignation,
bundling his hairpins and departing beyond the city gates,
untying his official sash at the northern slopes of the mountains,
joining the recluses of Jiqiu, emulating Liu Bang’s refusal of grain,
and preparing his boat for departure.
The court sent inquiries, and scholars saw him off with two *cushion essays* and four *hidden verses*—
his departure was as effortless as that of the ancients, though from a different age.

He set out with staff in hand, wandering through famous peaks,
until he reached Jurong and ascended Maoling—
this place was the abode of immortals, a sacred refuge of marvels.
Once entered, none returned.
He settled there and made it his home.

The Master said:
*"The Master said: ‘Retire to seek one’s purpose, act with virtue to fulfill the Way.’
I have heard these words but never seen such a man.
Now my virtue is fulfilled—
there is no need for further retreat.
I ask only to join those who seek their purpose,
thus I call myself a recluse,
following Zhi Chan’s *Embrace of Simplicity* and Shi An’s *Mystic Tranquility*."

Leaning against cliffs, dwelling in shadows,
nesting among trees, hiding at the forest’s edge,
weaving branches into a dwelling, carving a path as his gate,
facing cascades from sheer precipices, gazing upon mist-laden woods,
deep gorges and steep peaks—
the mists entwined like silken threads,
his pillow a stone, his cup the stream.
Mountain birds did not disturb him,
and as he gathered herbs, wild beasts did not dare approach.
He wandered freely, unbound by the world,
his spirit untouched, as if severed from mortal cares.

When the Qi dynasty declined and the Mandate of Heaven faltered,
the land of water trembled in Jiachen—
the Master, pondering omens, foresaw the signs.
Thus, he cut off all correspondence, near and far.
*"I have heard of Xia Fu in the past,
but now I see it in you, Master."*

The great fortune of Dai Liang was at hand,
the Mandate of Heaven clear—
the Three Stars shone bright, the Four Seas at peace.
The Master submitted a petition in celebration,
and his letters were once more answered.

Since the *Tianjian* era, he was repeatedly summoned with imperial edicts,
supplied with medicines and provisions without end,
and showered with seasonal favors unmatched by any other.
For seven years, he briefly visited Nan Yue.

This mountain—
the pivot of the *Biwei* winds, the celestial support of Kunlun,
overlooking the Eight Directions, between the Nine Regions—
its trees bore fangs of jade, its grasses sprouted chariots.
Detached from the world, he lingered, forgetting to return.

In the eleventh year, an imperial envoy, the Left Secretary of State Huiming,
was sent to summon the Master back to Maoshan,
granting him a residence to dwell in.
*"Like Xuān Zhong descending to serve the Heavenly Old Man,
or the Han Emperor honoring the River Master—
how could I refuse such an honor today?"*

Nurturing his purpose amid mountains and rivers,
he spent many years refining his life,
his vitality preserved, divine omens descending—
no fierce beast dared approach, no demons or spirits encountered him.
Thorns did not grow in his courtyard,
his neighbors were as distant as the *Que* enclave,
his steps emitted divine springs,
and distant cedars swayed in response.
Thus, feathered immortals lingered,
celestial guests ascended and descended,
cranes and phoenixes gathered,
and the *zhi* and *ying* mushrooms flourished in abundance.

In the second year of *Dà Tóng* (429 CE),
in the year *Bingchen*, on the first day of the third month,
the twelfth day, *Gengchou*,
he bade farewell and departed—
aged eighty-one.

The Emperor mourned his loss, the Crown Prince lamented in verse,
and an edict praised his virtues,
posthumously granting him the title *Great Scattered Official*,
with the epithet *Zhenbái Master*—
this was the proper honor.

On the fourteenth of that month, his remains were interred at *Leiping Mountain* in Jurong County, Danyang.
*"Like Yellow Emperor’s burial in his robes,
or Zi Qiao’s hidden sword in the crow’s nest—
today, this may be compared."*

The Master’s bearing was profound and reserved,
his thoughts precise and far-reaching,
his words pure and auspicious,
yet he never sought to polish his edges.
Though his years approached mid-life,
he was not bound by rigid measures—
his brows and eyes were clear and bright,
his demeanor fresh and unblemished.
He shunned public office, yet his deeds were kind,
treasuring light and shadow, loving the classics,
firm in resolve, his virtue unyielding to old age.

As for the *Huainan* secrets of vast treasures,
the *Longxi* earthquake divinations,
the *Taiyi* elusion charts,
the *Nine Chapters* of calendrical omens,
Yòuān’s swift silver-hook calligraphy,
Yǔn’s mastery of the *Fēngjiǎo* divinations,
the *Taicang* prescriptions of the *Suwen*,
and Zhōngsǎn’s *Lüting* music—
he had gathered them all,
mastering each with precision.

Moreover, in *Yìshè* archery, *Qúnqí* chess,
*Sū* divination, and *Guān* milfoil readings—
he understood them instantly, without effort.

Like Zhang Hua’s encyclopedic knowledge,
Ma Jun’s ingenious schemes,
Liu Xiang’s discernment of subtleties,
and Ge Hong’s cultivation of nature—
he encompassed all these virtues in one.

His disciples, including Huàn Fǎyuàn,
admired his distant reputation at Wéishì,
and cherished his legacy at Qiáoyáng,
erecting a black stone stele to inquire of him,
soaring to the crimson clouds where his fragrance lingers.

Thus, they composed this epitaph:

*"The crow departs, his transformation remains,
the sword is hidden, his spirit congeals.
He lingers in the purple mists,
illuminating the vermilion woods.
His presence lingers near,
his teachings endure.
Who shall inherit this?
Ah, the profound and virtuous man!

His conduct surpasses the lineage,
his virtue renews each day.
Bright as a suspended mirror,
profound as the upright bamboo.
His body fulfilled the Great Way,
his actions never strayed from humanity.

Once he wandered in silk and jade,
now his spirit soars divine.
Weary of salvation’s toil,
exhausted by the seekers’ quest."*

chunks.original_text: 亦既解组，乃袭山巾。 远寻丘壑，高蹈风尘。 情无缅世，隐不隔真。 结宇崇岩，贞栖茂草。 冰玉留年，精华却老。 乃有令闻，荣跻寿考#6。 白水过庭，危峰临洞。 露缀兰阶，蕾买生桂楝。 日斜檐席，花落窗壅。 尚平未远，王孙不旋。 海桑变易，陵谷贸迁。 丰碑有坚，遗芳万年。 华阳隐居墓铭碑 梁昭明太子撰。 维大同二年，龙集景辰，克明三月壬寅朔，十二日癸丑巳时，华阳洞陶先生蝉蜕于茅山朱阳馆。 先生讳弘景，字通明，春秋八十有一，屈伸如常#7，颜色不变。 有制，赠以中散大夫，镒日贞白先生。 遣舍人主书监护丧事，十四日定于雷平之山。 若夫真以归空为美，道以无涯为真，不知悦生，大德所以为生，不知恶死，谷神所以不死，妙矣哉，隐显变化，物莫之测，既而岫开析石，天坠玉棺，银书息简，流珠罢鳌，九节丽於中天，千和焚於地下。 仙官有得朋之喜，受学振空谷之悲。 余昔在粉壤，早逢圯上之术，今篷元良，屡察浮丘之教，握留符而恻怆，思化杖而酸辛。 乃为铭日： 无名之道，不死为仙。 亦有元放，兼称稚川。 逃形解化，自昔同然。 琦欤夫子，受录归玄。 黎传宛吏，书因贾船。 虎车煦景，蜕拂凌姻。 余花灼烁，春涧潺湲。 郁郁茅岭，修修洞天。 三仙白鹄，何时复旋？ 燕洞宫碑 邵陵王撰，阙。

「Yet he has cast aside his silken sash,
and now dons the mountain ascetic’s coarse hemp robe.
Far he seeks the hills and valleys,
high he treads the winds and dust.
His heart knows no lingering in the world,
his retreat hides no truth.

He builds his dwelling on lofty cliffs,
choosing a home where grasses flourish thickly.
Like ice and jade, his years endure,
his essence unaging, pure and bright.

Then came his fame, his virtue renowned,
honored in life, his years extended long.

White waters flow past his courtyard,
precarious peaks loom o’er his grotto.
Dew clings to the lotus steps,
while fragrant blossoms bloom by the bay.

Sun slants on the eaves’ shadowed seat,
flowers drift down past the window’s frame.
Yet peace remains not distant,
nor does the noble son turn back in vain.

The sea’s pines shift and change their hue,
while ridges and valleys trade their rise and fall.
But steadfast stands his monument,
his fragrance eternal, through the ages all.

---

**Epitaph for the Hermit of Huayang**
Composed by Liang’s Prince of Zhaoming

In the second year of *Dàtóng*,
on the auspicious day of *Lóngjí*,
when the third month’s *Rénshēn* dawned on the *Chén*,
the twelfth day, *Guǐchǒu*, at the *yǐ* hour,
the Master of Huayang, *Taoist* *Júyáng* Mr. *Hóngjǐng*,
underwent his final transformation at the *Máoshān* Hall of Zhuyang.

The Master, surname *Huá*, given name *Yáng*,
aged eighty-one in years,
yet moved as usual, his countenance unchanged.

By decree, he was posthumously granted the title of *Zhōngsàn Dàfū*,
and honored as the *Zhēn Bái* Master.

Envoys were dispatched to oversee his funeral rites,
and on the fourteenth day, his remains were interred at *Léipíng*’s mountain.

---

If one seeks the Way,
truth lies in its boundless void.
He knew not to rejoice in life,
for great virtue is the life itself.
He knew not to fear death,
for *Gǔshén* abides unvanquished.

Wondrous indeed!
Hidden and revealed, his transformations—
none can fathom their design.
Then lo, the cliffs split open,
heaven sent down a jade coffin,
silver script inscribed on the tablets,
pearls strung like beads, the tortoise’s writing ceased.
His ninefold *qi* ascended to the celestial midheaven,
his thousandfold essence burned beneath the earth.

The *xiān* officials rejoiced in their gain,
while those who studied him mourned the loss of *Kōnggǔ*.

I once dwelt in the dusty world,
early encountering the arts of the *yǐ*’s ruins.
Now, in this humble hall,
I’ve often observed the teachings of the floating mounds,
holding his talismans, my heart aches,
thinking of his alchemical staff, my sorrow deepens.

Thus I compose this epitaph:

The Dao unnamed, its immortality is *xiān*.
Yet there was *Yuánfàng*,
also called *Zhìchuān*.
He cast off form, dissolved his *qi*,
as has been since ancient times.

Oh, splendid Master!
Your records were received, your spirit returned to the void.

The *Lí* tradition passed to the *Yuàn* clerk,
the scrolls entrusted to the *Jiǎ* boatman.

The tiger chariot glows with spring’s light,
your final transformation ascends beyond mortal ties.

His flowers blaze with radiance,
his spring brook murmurs softly.
Lush are the *Máo* hills,
serene the *Dòng* realm.

The Three *Xiān* and the white goose—
when will they return again?

---

Composed by the Prince of *Shàolíng*,

chunks.original_text: 茅山志卷之二十一竟 #1友：笪一本作『宾』。 #2轻：原作『经』，据笪本改。 #3云：疑为衍文。 #4肌：原作『肥』据笪本改。 #5於：原本此处为空格，据笪本补。 #6荣跻寿考：笪本作『康庄寿考』。 #7常：笪本作『怛』。 茅山志卷之二十二 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 录金石篇 唐碑 唐国师升真先生王法主真人立 观碑 观夫天德惟溥，亭育肇其不差，人灵本智，闻见资其愈甚，是以役成则百□不足，事逸则万物皆勤，莫不鼎铉黄金，尊崇居处，□□□□，资养性灵，青襟惭於履霜，白首成於聚岳。 但畏途捷径，岂所般游，风叶寒爹，忘其飘践。 假使维梢挂席，终违宝岸，县车策马，诅越崇山，□□未有若斯之甚者也。 至人应世，为而不处，援手濡足，拯溺救焚，涤其含垢之性，复其既迷之辙，立关键，树堤防，议慈舟於罕济之川，明慧炬於未昕之夕。 当其虚往，处以真知，被薜纫兰，吞虹噬月，践赤墀而弘众妙，排翠辰而播玄风，踵牧台之旧踪，袭口山之遗轨，胜业与鳖峰并峻，睿泽共馄海同流，理绝名言，事忘称谓，可久可大，琦欤伟欤。 法主姓王讳远知，字广德，琅琊临沂人也。 眇边周口，口袭於上宾之冑； 非同薛族，托口於平舆之门。 垂密云而洒润，御长风而纵响。 道无常器，应有常伦，故得幽既郁其枚条，潜祉被其遐构，则有叶县奇踪，雷门逸响。 口口阅世，伯阶珍其异口，口信逛时，威明贵其缝掖。 故乃百川纷赓，沧淇浸无涯之广； 累石不穷，惟岳至极天之峻。

The *Máoshān Zhì* Volume Twenty-One concludes.

**Friend (or Guest):**
#1 The text in the *Dān* edition reads *"Guest"*.
#2 *"Light"* was originally *"Scripture"*, corrected according to the *Dān* edition.
#3 *"Cloud"* is likely a redundant interpolation.
#4 *"Skin"* was originally *"Fat"*, corrected according to the *Dān* edition.
#5 *"At"* was originally omitted; supplemented from the *Dān* edition.
#6 *"Honored ascent, long life"* was originally *"Prosperous path, long life"*.
#7 *"Constant"* was originally *"Enduring"*, corrected to *"Dharma"* according to the *Dān* edition.

---

**Volume Twenty-Two: The Lineage of the Upper Clarity Master, Liu Dàbīn**

**Engraved Records of Gold and Stone**

**Tang Dynasty Stele**

**Established by the Tang Master of the Dao, Ascended True Lord, Wang Fǎzhǔ (True Person)**

**Inscription on the Stele of the Observing Hall:**

The Heavenly Virtue is vast and universal,
Its nurturing begins without fail.
Human nature is rooted in inherent wisdom,
Yet knowledge grows with exposure to the Dao.

Thus, when one is diligent in practice, even a hundred [years] are insufficient,
And when one is at ease in practice, all things labor to fulfill their potential.
None are more revered than the cauldron of refined gold,
Nor more honored than the dwelling of the Sage.
The green robe is humbled by the frost’s touch,
The white hair is perfected by the mountain’s embrace.

Yet, fearing the swiftness of the path,
How could one be content with mere wandering?
The wind-swept leaves forget their drifting,
The willow’s branches recall their ancient roots.

Even if one hangs a curtain at the tips of the branches,
One will still fail to reach the sacred shore.
Though one rides a lofty chariot and mounts a spirited steed,
Crossing towering peaks, none surpass this Master’s attainment.

The Perfect Sage responds to the world,
Acting without remaining in it.
With extended hand and wet foot,
He rescues the drowning and saves the burning.
He purifies the nature stained by defilement,
And restores the path once lost to confusion.
He establishes gates and barriers,
And proposes the vessel of compassion for those crossing perilous waters,
Illuminates the lamp of wisdom in the darkest nights.

When he departs in emptiness,
He abides in true knowledge.
Clad in hemp and embroidered with orchids,
He devours the rainbow and consumes the moon.
Treading the red steps to expound boundless wonders,
Pushing aside the jade gates to spread the mysterious winds,
He follows the old traces of the Pasture Platform,
And treads the ancient paths of the Mountain of Speech.
His achievements rival those of the Tortoise Peak,
His wisdom flows with the vastness of the Boiling Sea.
His principles transcend all names,
His deeds forget all titles—
Enduring, vast, splendid, and magnificent!

**Wang Fǎzhǔ**, surnamed **Wang**, with the given name **Yuǎnzhī**,
Courtesy name **Guǎngdé**, was a native of **Lángyá Lín’yí** (now Linyi, Shandong).

His humble origins were in **Zhōukǒu** near the border,
Yet his name was recorded in the registers of the **Upper Guest** (the celestial bureaucracy).
His lineage was not the same as the **Xué** clan,
Yet his fame was entrusted to the **Píngyú** gate.

His words fell like gentle rain,
His voice commanded the long wind.
The Dao has no fixed vessel,
Yet its principles are ever constant—
Thus he concealed his wisdom in the depths of the mountains,
And his influence spread far beyond the peaks.
There were marvels in **Yè Xiàn**,
And echoes in the **Léimén** gate.

[His name] was known in the world,
And the **Earl of the Stage** treasured his singularity.
[He] was trusted in times of peace,
And the **Lord of the Dao** valued his subtle guidance.

Hence, the hundred streams gathered in abundance,
Their waters stretching boundless as the **Cāngqí** (Azure River);
The piled stones knew no end,
Only the mountains reached the heavens’ height.

chunks.original_text: 法主大父景贤，梁征北将军、江州刺史。 考昙选，散骑常侍、太子右卫率、轻车将军、陈车骑将军、扬州刺史、建安郡公，食邑三千户，鼓吹一部。 班剑二十人，一表华载郁，台肩启曜，动成仪表，肃以具瞻。 法主镇五石於生官，报三田於命府，降灵以资妙气，受炼而浴兰池，口口漱其芳津，二仪赋其纯口，望德门而直指，蜷华宗而诞曜。 母氏济阳丁夫人，阴祇柔德垂美，夙有神朋之契，先察祯祥之符。 尝因昼寝，梦身为飞凤所集，既寤，见赤光贯乳，遂感而娠。 七日便啼，声闻于外，才经少选而载口焉。 昔浩灵受锡，仰神嗣於妃瑛； 柱史流沙，托日精於玄妙。 吁符玄庆，高腾圣迩。 复乃流光外朗，豫显火传之教； 希声内发，先闻导俗之音。 既而圣纵自天，禀至知於弱植； 道口口口，备口口於藏往。 孝友冥至，就养无方，业隆干蛊，情忘健羡，加以俯同学教，尽锐坟典，三易述其殷周，四诗传其邹鲁，着康成之韦简，听季长之丝竹，龄藻三古，琴瑟百家，玉书见重，金赢取贵，明毁县镜，照夺清溜。 乃深弃俗缠，早生厌离，寂寥爱网，牢落尘情，望玄关而一息，僚苍而长往。 时有国师宗道先生，识洞幽．微，智深玄妙，宣风黄道，作训紫宸，九重致礼，百工兴敬，摄斋撰履，妙简英奇。 法主以体二沐玄风，知十升堂奥，握照应於荆蓝之下，抱烛乘於随合之滨。 宅空成性，智之所渐，沿无致学，惟几必彰。 理诣希微，忘所言而知道； 情遗径廷，就日损以为德。 爰在冠年，虔修上法，乃有族云浮紫，旱鹤呈素，盹暧高垂，徘徊迥属。 周尹候气，诅可参衡，晋野挥弦，曾何扶毂，斯盖玄心广运远结，冥祥故能幽既不言，嘉瑞爰发。 法主顾众芳以指信，因旱灵以据抱，内战斯止，道胜则肥，去有欲之廉，息多闻之智，六经三史，缥恢网囊，昔所研味，并皆弃绝。 物色真应，耽尚玄虚，吐纳六宫，去来三景，峻巢由之节，励夷皓之行，便即辟谷休粮，唯资松水。 六尘不染，智照杜其氛埃； 五味性空，慧口绝其甘旨。 遂乃避声於衔枚之路，灭影於至阴之域。 茅山华阳，即三十六洞天之第八也，峰秀龙文之鼎，水吁凤门之泉，仰三山以交真，思五便而贮圣，乃抗表阙廷，愿归岩谷。 黄门侍郎贺彻，奉宣中旨，继是山栖，所须并令官给。 既而雅志获从，幽襟独往，高蹈俗外，举手时人，草公祖道，衣倨聚观，法主投簪有所，终焉是托，润淹草树，光溢林泉，拂云径以展足，援乔枝以移视，虽复金锦和鼓，独韵新声； 玉管调时，偏谐雅气。 与夫道风遐畅，远秀松筠之表，胜趣挺生，孤映姻霄之外，安可乱其清越，革我寒暄，故以仙伯嗟其格高，云将谈其气远。 仍值旗盖南歇，礼乐西归。 法主养粹中岩，不染氛秽。 隋开皇十二年，晋王分陕维扬，尊崇至教，钦味夙范，具礼招迎。 辞不获命，出自山谷。 长吏、王子相承候动止，咨议顾言，每申谈对，法主豪墨所至，必罄今古，辞义所该，始无遗逸。 幽尚有本，固请还山，晋王重违所守，遣使将送，遂投於天窗背岭，凿崖考室，卷晦声边，才可修行。 十三年正月七日夜，端坐精思，彷佛朱衣羽人握节而进，谓法主日：岫隐川藏，事由独善，寓形寰宇，宜弘利益。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Master of the Dao**’s grandfather, **Jǐngxián**, was the **Earl of the Northern Expedition** of Liang and the **Prefect of Jiangzhou**.

His father, **Tánxuǎn**, served as **Attendant of the Coursiers**, **Commandant of the Right Guard of the Prince**, **General of Light Cavalry**, **Earl of Chariots of Chen**, **Prefect of Yangzhou**, and **Marquis of Jiàn’ān**, with a fief of three thousand households and a full complement of **drums and pipes**. He bore twenty **swordsmen**, his **bearing and demeanor** were noble and refined, his **shoulders and chest** adorned with splendor, his **movements** set with propriety—his **awe-inspiring presence** was ever apparent.

The **Master of the Dao** **calmed five rocks** in his birthplace, **repaid three fields** to the **Ministry of Rites**, and **descended the spirit** to nurture **wondrous qi**. He **underwent alchemy** and bathed in the **Lan Pool**, **sipping** its **fragrant essence**, while the **Two Compendia** bestowed their **pure teachings**. He **gazed at the Gate of Virtue** and **pointed directly**, and **curled in the Hall of Clouds** to **manifest brilliance**. His mother, **Lady Dīng of Jìyāng**, was **gentle in virtue and adorned with beauty**, **long held in divine friendship**, and **forever attuned to auspicious omens**. Once, while resting by day, she **dreamed a phoenix gathered her**, and upon waking, saw **red light piercing her breast**, thus **conceiving in wonder**. In seven days, she **wept in labor**, her cries heard beyond the chamber, and after a brief **selection of auspicious time**, she **gave birth**.

In ancient times, **Hàolíng** received **divine blessings**, and **her lineage was traced to the Heavenly Phoenix** through **Lady Wěiyīng**. The **Pillar of History** marked the **flowing sands**, and **its essence was entrusted to the Mysterious and Marvelous**. **Omens of joy** soared high, and **sacred glory** ascended near. **Radiant light** shone forth externally, **proclaiming the transmission of fire** in advance; **hopeful sounds** resounded within, **hearing the guidance of customs** first.

Then, **divine decree descended from heaven**, and he **inherited profound knowledge** from **fragile roots**. The **Dao** **was embraced without words**, and he **fulfilled its essence** in **hidden teachings**. His **filial piety and brotherly devotion** were **fathomless**, his **care for the aged** knew no bounds, his **achievements towered** like **dryad pillars**, his **affections surpassed** the **healthful envy** of the virtuous. With **humble submission to the teachings of the learned**, he **mastered the classics**, **reciting threefold the urgent admonitions of the Zhou**, **transmitting the fourfold poetry of the Ru**, **wearing the leather-bound notes of Kāngchéng**, and **listening to the bamboo and silk of Jìzhǎng**. His **age and eloquence** rivaled the **Three Ancients**, his **lyre and zither** harmonized with the **Hundred Schools**, his **jade writings** were **highly esteemed**, his **golden compositions** **won renown**, his **illuminating words** **outshone the mirror**, his **radiant discourse** **surpassed the clarity of flowing streams**.

Thus, he **deeply rejected worldly entanglements**, **early cultivated disdain for dust**. He **loved the net of silence**, **held fast to the emptiness of mortal concerns**, and **gazed at the Mysterious Pass** to **draw a single breath**, **ascending to the Azure Expanse** and **soaring far**. At that time, there was the **National Teacher, Master Zōngdào**, who **discerned the profound and subtle**, **delved deeply into the Mysterious and Marvelous**, **proclaimed the winds of the Yellow Path**, and **composed the instructions of the Purple Court**. The **Nine Palaces** paid homage, the **Hundred Craftsmen** **revered him**, and he **fasted and crafted his steps** in **wondrous simplicity**.

The **Master of the Dao**, with **two washings of his body in the Dao-wind**, **knowing the tenfold mysteries of the Hall**, **held the lamp’s reflection** beneath the **Jīng and Lán forests**, and **embraced the torch’s ascent** along the **shores of Suí and Hé**. His **dwelling became a void of nature**, his **wisdom deepened** with each **passage of time**, his **teachings** **spread without constraint**, and **his few words** **were ever resplendent**. His **reasoning reached the utmost subtlety**, and he **forgot spoken words** to **realize the Dao**; his **affections abandoned the path of the court**, and he **took the sun’s decline** as **virtue’s gain**.

By the time of his **coming-of-age**, he **devoutly cultivated the Supreme Way**, and **clouds floated in purple**, **dry cranes displayed their white**, **a tranquil drowsiness hung high**, and **his spirit wandered in distant realms**. The **Chief of Zhou’s Court** **divined the air**, and **his curses rivaled the worthy**; the **Wild of Jìn** **plucked the strings**, and **Zēng Hé** **held the reins**. This was **truly the broad and distant operation of the Mysterious Heart**, **divinely ordained** yet **silent in its marvels**, **auspicious omens** **emerging naturally**.

The **Master of the Dao** **turned his gaze** to **the myriad blossoms** and **pointed to the faithful**, **leaned on the dry spirit** to **embrace the divine**. Within, **struggle ceased**, and the **Dao prevailed**—**abandoning desires of the flesh**, **resting the wisdom of excessive knowledge**. The **Six Classics and Three Histories** **were cast aside** in his **net of abandonment**, and all that he **once studied** **was utterly forsaken**.

**True colors** **responded naturally**, and he **indulged in the Mysterious Void**. He **expelled and inhaled the Six Palaces**, **discarded the Three Lands**, **erected his nest** **according to the Dao’s strictures**, and **strengthened his steps** **in the path of the Pure and Bright**. Thus, he **immediately began abstaining from grains**, **sustaining himself only on pine and water**.

**The Six Dusts** **did not stain him**, and his **illuminated wisdom** **banished their mists**; **the Five Flavors** **were void by nature**, and his **enlightened discernment** **cut off their sweetness**. He **avoided sounds** **in the path of the silent**, and **extinguished his form** **in the domain of utter darkness**.

**Huàshān’s Huáyáng Peak** was the **eighth of the Thirty-Six Palaces of Heaven**, its **peaks adorned with dragon script**, its **waters** **the phoenix’s gate**. He **ascended the Three Mountains** to **unite with the True**, **pondered the Five Conveniences** to **store the Sacred**, and **presented his petition** to the **court**, **requesting return to the rocks and valleys**. The **Yellow Gate’s Attendant, Hè Chè**, **delivered the imperial decree**, and he **continued his mountain retreat**, with all his needs **provided by the court**.

When his **refined aspirations** were **granted**, his **secluded heart** **went alone**, **soaring above the vulgar**, **raising his hands to the times**. He **walked the path of the Sage’s ancestors**, **clothed in humble rags**, and **the Master of the Dao** **cast aside his hairpin** **with purpose**, **finally entrusting himself** to it. **Moisture pervaded the grasses and trees**, **light filled the forests and springs**, and he **swept the clouded paths** **with his feet**, **clasped the lofty branches** **to shift his gaze**. Though **golden brocade and drums** **blended in harmony**, his **solo tune** **was fresh and singular**; though **jade pipes** **played in time**, his **melody** **conveyed the refined essence**.

With the **Dao’s winds** **drifting far**, **his virtues surpassed** the **pine and cypress**; with **victorious joys** **surging forth**, **his solitude mirrored** the **marriage of the clouds**. How could **the vulgar** **disturb his purity**, or **the profane** **match his brilliance**? Thus, the **Sage’s Companion** **praised his lofty bearing**, and the **Cloud Immortal** **spoke of his distant essence**.

Yet when the **flags and banners** **sank to the south**, and the **rites and music** **returned to the west**, the **Master of the Dao** **nurtured his essence** **in the mountain’s heart**, **untouched by defilement**.

In the **twelfth year of the reign of Emperor Guāng of the Sui**, **Jìn Wáng** **divided the command** **of Shǎn and Wéi**, **honoring and elevating the Supreme Teaching**, **revering and savoring ancient models**. He **extended full rites** to **invite and welcome** the **Master of the Dao**.

The **Master of the Dao** **declined the summons**, **emerging from his mountain retreat**. The **high officials and royal princes** **in turn welcomed his movements**, **consulting his words**, and every time they **presented their questions**, the **Master of the Dao** **unleashed his boundless discourse**, **covering the present and the past**, and his **eloquence and meaning** **left nothing unexpressed**.

His **secluded aspirations** had their **origin**, and he **insisted on returning to the mountains**. The **Prince of Jìn** **heavily disregarded his resolve**, **dispatching envoys to escort him**. Thus, the **Master of the Dao** **retired to the cliffs of Tiānchuāng**, **hollowing out caves for meditation**, **rolling up his voice** **to the mountain’s edge**, **barely able to practice**.

On the **seventh night of the first month of the thirteenth year**, he **sat upright in meditation**, and **it seemed as though a man in crimson robes and feathered attire** **held a scepter and approached him**. The man said: *"Hidden in the valleys, concealed by the rivers—your affairs are **self-cultivation alone**. Dwelling in the world, you **should broaden benefits**."*

chunks.original_text: 重官品藻，以卿开教一方，可宣扬法味，开度后学。 既受兹灵诰，始有应物之心焉。 於是澄止水於众象，炼贞松於草望，广运玄机，盛谈名理重关复奥，故以启其幽深； 六瑚四缠，曾不矜其器用。 山门着录三千许人，并立精舍，皇为壮丽。 十九年，劲使郑子腾送书询问，钦尚殷勤，诚深下辇。 大业七年，炀帝遣散骑员外郎崔凤责劫书迎请，见於涿郡之临朔宫。 帝乃叹日：朕昔在扬州，师已素发。 今兹重睹，更有童颜。 岂非道固存焉，养之得理者。 六军返筛，扈驾洛阳。 奉劝於中岳修斋仪。 而炎德遂卑，忠良解体，搀抢远烛，格择旁流，沉马谬三十之占，胶船无五反之慎，苍生涂炭，天命有归。 大唐景运龙兴，玄象斯构。 皇上继明理物，光宅黔元，参天二地，经文纬武，神谋广略，道属云雷，踱晷曜於已晦，缀参辰於将落，毁隅具固，口口廓清，复修红席，还为俎豆。 非夫唐风惟大，大章可以作歌，轩德如云，云门所以流咏，其孰能至於此乎？ 故使天成地平，其武功也如彼，戢戈归兽，其文德也如此，谅可以四三王而六五帝，蹈东户而穆南风。 瑞发云星，祥应俯素，个泉献醴，茂棘垂柔，神筵卫厨，芳莫斓砌，巍巍荡荡，未有若斯之盛者欤，犹复降情动虑，吁食已勤，克己思治，宵衣弥笃，仁高穹昊，泽漏重泉。 於是嗣兴至教。 尚想玄极，在昔藩朝，频经降问，法主卷怀处世，三变市朝，语默人间，一逢有道，既遇龙田，方知必举之翼，将攀凤羽，故审扶摇之势，以慈先觉，曲招恩礼，屡有陈闻，乞还江外。 乃诏浴州资给人船，并施法服，劝润州於旧山造观一所，赐田，度道士七七人以为侍者。 贞观九年四月至山，劫文遣太史令薛颐、校书郎张道本、太子左内率长史桓法嗣等送香油、镇彩、金龙、玉璧於观所，为国祈恩。 复遣朝散郎萧文远责玺书慰问，并赐袖被、几杖等。 皇太子以其年六月，又遣将仕郎张万迪送香油、龙璧供山中法事。 劲又遣桓法嗣送香，八月十三日至观。 法主沉吟久之，方遣恭受，谓弟子日：此香何能烧尽？ 可分四近诸观，广供斋讲，冀能感彻。 十四日午时，适因睡寤，喜形於色。 侍者在旁谘问所以，答曰：吾向錾游洞宫，仙官见报，欲以疲朽，补为仙伯，名位已定，行在不久。 十五日，沐浴冠带，焚香正坐，集诸弟子，述圣朝立观之由，励学人策勤之志。 十六日旦，忽闻异香入室，乌兽哀嗥，顾谓侍者日：日时早晚？ 日：辰时。 乃应日：好，即转身平卧，自正衣冠，九易之形一朝解束，春秋一百二十有六岁。 肢体柔软，颜色不变。 停殡旬余，倍胜常日。

「Thus, he **valued the prestige of office and the cultivation of talent**, **appointing him as the teacher to enlighten one region**, **able to proclaim the taste of the Dao**, **and guide future disciples in their cultivation**. Having **received this divine decree**, he **first developed the resolve to benefit all beings**.

Then, he **calmed the waters to mirror the myriad forms**, **refined the virtue of pine amidst the humble grass**, **expanded the profound mysteries**, and **elaborated on intricate principles**—**weighty, complex, and profound**—**to illuminate their hidden depths**; **without pride**, he **offered his modest vessels** to the **six incense burners and four censers**. At the **mountain gate**, **his name was recorded for over three thousand followers**, who **all established meditation halls**, **grand and splendid in their magnificence**. In the **nineteenth year**, the **vigorous sovereign** **Zheng** **sent the official Zhèng Zǐtēng** **with a letter to inquire**, **showing great respect and earnestness**, **truly descending from his carriage**.

In the **seventh year of the Great Business era**, the **Emperor Yáng** **sent the Gentleman-at-Arms and External Attendant Chuī Fèng** **to convey an imperial edict and summon him**, **meeting him at the Línshuò Palace in Zhè County**. The emperor **then sighed and said**: *"In my earlier days in Yángzhou, the Master had already **manifested his virtue**. Now, seeing him again, he **still retains his youthful vigor**. Truly, it is because the **Dao abides within him**, and his **nurturing aligns with its principles**."*

The **six armies returned in triumph**, **escorting the imperial carriage to Luòyáng**. He **offered counsel on the rituals of sacrifice at Zhōngyuè**. Yet, the **flourishing virtue of the former dynasty declined**, **loyal and virtuous men perished**, **their aspirations distant and scattered**, **their choices straying from the orthodox**. The **divination of thirty black horses was in error**, the **precautions of five reversals were ignored**, and the **people suffered in misery**—**the Mandate of Heaven had its limits**.

Now, the **auspicious era of the Great Tang flourished like the dragon’s rise**, and **the celestial omens took form**. The **August Sovereign succeeded in illuminating the Dao and governing all**, **bringing light to the abode of the Black Primordial**—**spanning heaven and earth**, **his words established the principles of governance**, **his deeds wove the threads of martial might**. His **divine strategies were vast and far-reaching**, his **Dao encompassed the thunderous clouds and radiant lightning**, **reviving the brilliance of the sun when it was obscured**, **restoring the stars of the Big Dipper as they were about to set**. The **cornerstone was laid**, the **foundations secured**, and **once again, the red carpet was spread**, **reverting to the sacred altars of sacrifice**. **Was it not the grandeur of the Tang that was unmatched**, **its grand decrees worthy of song**, **its virtue as lofty as clouds**, **its gates of doctrine through which all praise flowed**? **Who could attain such heights?**

Thus, he **made the heavens serene and the earth level**, **his martial achievements were as vast as those**, **his arms laid down, beasts returning to their wild state**—**his cultural virtue was no less**. **He could be compared to the Four Three Kings and Six Five Emperors**, **matching the Eastern Huò in reverence**, **and surpassing the Southern Fēng in solemnity**. **Auspicious signs appeared in the clouds and stars**, **omens of good fortune descended like silk**. The **individual springs offered wine**, the **luxuriant thorns bent in humility**, the **divine feast was attended by sacred guardians**, the **hallways gleamed with fragrant decorations**. **Majestic and awe-inspiring**, such **grandeur had never been seen before**. Yet, **the sovereign still lowered his heart and stirred his thoughts**, **his meals were modest despite his diligence**, **he restrained himself to ponder governance**, **his nightclothes worn with unwavering devotion**. His **benevolence towered like the vault of heaven**, his **favor permeated even the deepest springs**.

Thus, **the Master’s teachings flourished anew**. **He aspired to the ultimate mysteries of the Dao**, and in the past, **when he served as a regional official**, he **frequently received imperial inquiries**. The **Master of the Dao** **retired from the world**, **three times returning to the secular realm**, **his words silent among mortals**. **Yet, whenever he encountered one of the Dao**, **he knew the time for his rise had come**—**now, having met the Dragon’s Field**, he **understood the wings of his inevitable ascent**, **and the phoenix feathers he would soon claim**. Thus, he **gauged the momentum of the rising wind**, **his compassion guiding the first to awaken**, **his grace inviting the benevolent gifts of fate**. **Again and again, he submitted his petitions**, **begging to return beyond the rivers**.

The emperor **then decreed that Yùzhou provide supplies, men, and ships**, **and granted him Daoist robes**. He **urged the prefect of Róngzhou to build a temple on his former mountain**, **bestowing land**, and **ordaining seventy-seven Daoists** **to serve as his attendants**. In the **fourth month of the Zhenguān era’s ninth year**, the **Master of the Dao** **ascended the mountain**. The **Emperor** **sent the Astrologer-in-Chief Xuē Yǐng, the Palace Librarian Zhāng Dàoběn, and the Left Internal Attendant of the Crown Prince, Guàn Fǎsì**, **to deliver fragrant oils, protective talismans, a golden dragon, and a jade tablet** **to the temple**, **praying for the nation’s blessings**. He **again dispatched the Court Gentleman Xuē Wényuǎn** **with an imperial seal to offer consolation**, **along with sleeves of silk and a staff**.

The **Crown Prince**, in that **same year’s sixth month**, **also sent the Officer-in-Training Zhāng Wàndí** **to deliver fragrant oils and a dragon tablet** **for the Daoist rites within the mountain**. The **vigorous sovereign** **once more sent Guàn Fǎsì** **with fragrant incense**, arriving at the temple on the **thirteenth of the eighth month**. The **Master of the Dao** **paused in contemplation for a long while**, then **reluctantly accepted it**, telling his disciples: *"How could this incense ever be burned to completion? **Let it be shared with the nearby temples**, **to widely support the rituals and lectures**, **hoping to touch their hearts**."*

On the **fourteenth day, at noon**, **just as he awoke from sleep**, **his face lit with joy**. His attendants at his side **inquired about the reason**, and he replied: *"I was recently **visiting the Celestial Palace in my dreams**, and the **immortal officials saw my offerings**. They wished to **bestow upon me a position as an Immortal Lord**, **to compensate for my weary form**, and my **name and rank were already set**. My **ascension would not be long**."*

On the **fifteenth day**, he **bathed, donned his ceremonial attire**, **lit incense, and sat upright**. **He gathered his disciples**, **explaining the emperor’s intent in establishing the temple** and **encouraging them to strive with diligence**. On the **sixteenth day, at dawn**, **suddenly, he smelled an unfamiliar fragrance enter the room**, and **the crows and beasts wailed mournfully**. Turning to his attendants, he asked: *"What hour is it now?"*
They replied: *"The second watch."*
He then answered: *"Good."* **Immediately, he turned his body and lay flat**, **adjusted his own clothes and crown**, **and in a single morning, his nine transformations were undone**, **his age reaching one hundred and twenty-six**. His **limbs were soft and supple**, his **complexion unchanged**. **After his passing, his body was kept for over ten days**, **far surpassing the usual duration**.

chunks.original_text: 州遣行参军马君伟赴#1山吊祭，并以状奏闻。 越二十八日，以符竹托柑定录神山之右。 夫剑解之道，皎昧难知，至於刊名伯札，勒功仙品，青铣成文，召帝晨之旨，紫玉为简，锡太元之命，建图独立，总要草灵，若得之於千载，犹逢之於万劫，自许、葛以来，未之有也。 初，法主从容谓所亲日：国家为吾造观，恩德极重； 自惟征应，恐不见其成。 至是时也，斧斤始就，前刺史辛君昌与五县官人爰集山所，定方准极，八桂运於瑶阜，五杏伐於缁林，堑荆峰而求宝玉，决河宫而取珠贝，郢人负其涂器，般匠献其奇斤，百姓子来，四方悦服，口非若堵，镭动如云，商略云崖，考量泉石。 乃於积金洞门之右、太元降真之地，其山则峰岫开天，逼乾行之峻，误谷括地，穷艮象之深，滴沥县流，因风振响，箴义乔木，承云聚翠。 於是式摹大壮，建其精宇，据修原而却指，陪秀岭以斜列。 飞陛排云，危塘列汉。 构玄炉以缪辐，囊丹拱以崔鬼，俨香阁於姻空，郁珍台於倒景。 乌容拂晓，假道游题之问，兔色分宵，晦影绮疏之侧，埃溘灭而瑶甍远，寒暑隔而宝殿深。 绮霞共藻税争辉，清风与琅讦竞响。 披轩迥眺，郁怜之千岩不穷； 凿牖俯临，苍苍之万壑同色。 璃龙鳞甲动青玉之镜，云雾光芒列赤谲之案。 讨口九色，杂流苏而回卷； 华磨百戏，拂藻井而斜萦。 霜钟韵亮氏之音，仙盖尽轮人之妙。 列那佺於东序，憩羽客於南荣。 檐度玄霜，庭凝绛雪。 昔汉宗万乘，玄宫才峙於豫章； 齐侯九合，正寝止闻於拱梧，未若纶诰，爰发雕聋胜地。 玄都万雉，植立天窗之问； 萧台九层，辉耀洞天之表。 故以一磬昆骊，中贫海读，又於内殿奉为文德皇后造元始天尊像一躯，二真夹侍。 拟香园之妙，写空歌之仪，遐迩归依，人天赞仰，法轮常转，洪恩不替。 州伯武陆公李使君，讳厚德，真人冑裔，衣冠旧绪，天演分其远派，帝圃炼其旁枝，政循化穆，途谣里颂，崇信法门，义不忘本。 弟子陈羽，弱年服道，暮齿不疲禀洞神之言，得入微之致，平昔应征，已当付嘱，今兹综理，复隆堂构。 弟子王轨，夙挺机绿，幼恭德宇，钻仰闻于奥室，举措纲於循常，清言余论，演畅有归。 羽等乃与远近同门道俗耆旧，以为日月回薄，总盈缩之期，春秋递代，运盛衰之道，皇宜腾芳垂茂，远播清尘，但韦编既绝，宣尼深易道之叹，简书遽落，束哲补由庚之辞。 是用树彼高垣，题其瑰石，立言纪事，传诸不朽。 上愿皇图定七百之基，符千载之运，同玉京而等固，与金阙而俱遥。 敢述徽猷，乃为铭日： 生灵蠢蠢，世界悠悠。 吉凶并骛，爱恶相谋。 如彼舞华，望晷不留。 如彼媳菌，弃朔无秋。 至人显用，夙膺玄录。 胜己克勤，导扬斯属。 非相游道，无言匡俗。 物有可甄，宁惮濡足？ 几探其妙，鉴献其明。 炼微毓德，疑玄肆情。 才高楚泽，价重秦城。 义常纵辩，文路辈英。 迹沦青蟑，声迩丹屏。 蹈礼何滨，当仁茨岭。 师臣是属，如纶攸聘。 爰召瓖材，构兹严整。 伟哉瞰迥，壮矣浚虚。 仪刑玄圃，辉映方诸。 榈垂迭璧，甍问联珠。 当晓仙阜，灯烩神居。 迷迭#2香阶，合昏奇树。 扰磨音麟遥集，驯蜕迥赴。 入岁招口，骑箕引傅。 蔽亏日月，杳冥云雾。

chunks.original_text: 化周道息，静鉴潜神。 鸾旅宛宛，象躅鳞鳞。 乘飕叔茂，祈理玄宾。 永言终古，无绝清尘。 和州司户参军楚城丰城二县丞包绍，门挺基缨，夙业超举，连延从职，已隔流辈，况在学优，弥绝尘累，玄构绳墨，仍参揆度，预有厥劳，是宜刊记。 希玄观三洞弟子江昊撰。 贞观十六年二月二十五日立石。 少室仙伯王君碑铭 谏议大夫李渤撰。 少室山天标中气，吐颖浸洛，潜匐神洞，别辉日月，为灵人正府。 府有．伯，太清正中花之。 故刘北台光其前，王法主袭其后。 法主，琅琊人，讳远知。 陈阳子牧昙选子，母丁，感凤化胎。 年七岁，日识万言。 宅华阳师陶弘景，臧矜镞羽，玄业遂能，精融道数，弛张化机，降真易髭，延窦氏姐魄，疑其统天与真宰为徒矣。 涉陈越隋，暨我唐，皆宗之。 语门弟子潘师正日：吾被署少室仙伯。 沐浴加冠衣而化，享龄一百二十六。 高宗追赠太中大夫，镒升真先生，阐道也。 贞元癸未，鄙人至自庐岳，栖托稳溪，牵萝践危，深入丹窟，漱抱玛水，感仙储洛游，礼空投诚，铭辞於石。 铭日： 道结元气，神机真精。 玉膏金芝，凝质自灵。 迹散霞岫，思激霜飕。 浮丘往矣，光尘寂寥。 大1 兀至元二十四年正议大夫御史中丞王博文子冕重书。 桐梧真人茅山华阳观王先生碑铭并序 朝散大夫江宁县令河南于敬之撰，琅琊王玄宗书。 惟轩辕有道之君，时着顺风之美，姑射凝神之主爰，标让位之芳，斯皆远镜遗编，遐希蠹删。 岂若道包千古，业映百王，先天而天弗违，后天而奉天时，化洽无遗，仁含有截。 青溪之馆口口口口紫府之乡言招若士，乃下璃绂伫霓裳。 希停绛阙之游，錾辍丹田之赏。 谨命终南山万福观道士够元敬祇召先生口口口口口口辰先生霞装奄淑，够法师痛徽音之永隔，收萝松涧，弟子祁行则、丁玄亮等，悲陆蛄之长往，采绚芝岩，共勒丰碑，同甄盛烈。 先生姓王讳轨，字洪范，一字道模，琅琊临沂人也。 耀质珠川，分枝璇萼，姬储下凤，周书美其轻举； 叶宰飞亮，刘史纪其神异。 绵声远系，口口言欤。 曾祖筠，散骑常侍、太府卿、度支尚书，文括辞林，义婵学府，既飞华於楚塞，诚育德於口口。 大父钴，梁简文太子洗马，招远将军，洎陈太中正、光禄大夫，晨趋鹤禁，夕侍龙楼，出入两朝，声猷缨倡，从容二代，誉掩术流。 父瑜，陈着作佐郎、番易国常侍，蓬娇含童乍增辉於兰阔，梧官载笔，时扬谒於桂山，抽簪陪置醴之宾，偶乘篷脂车之彦，竭诚以奉上，呜谦以栖下，常刷坐忘之宇，乃秀行□ 之胤。 先生养质馄波，终搏鹏羽，遣之又遣，玄之又玄，志合天倪，情#3含地籁； 施妍蛎丑，泯之而为一，挺横楹从，混之而无二。 年甫八岁，早丧所天，痛彼奢年，志符曾孝，哀思卯日，性掩柴仁。 属陈运告终，人神靡托，玉炎钟岫，芝焚楚郊，万始之口，口背飞之泪，三荆之树，唯下分条之叶，萍流不定，蓬转无依。 赖乎祖父故人担养，寄诸包氏，一经憩麻，五载方离。 先生业契自然，道通县解，贞心粹质，有符天纵，蕴灵和之茂范，流太虚之芳润，弱龄去俗，高步归真。 太平观法主王远知，践三清之噢隅，游六学之津要，翘心丹诀，警虑玄波，既毁网於迷途，乃分灯於暗室，清规素论，一代伟人。
