The **Dao/Way** of the Zhou **fades into repose**, the **stillness** reflects the **hidden Sage**.

The **phoenix** lingers in **graceful flight**, the **elephant** treads in **scaled steps**.

He **rides the zephyrs** of **Master Shū**, **prays for harmony** with the **mysterious Guest**.

His **words** endure through **eternal ages**, his **virtue/power** clears **pure dust** without end.

**Pāo Xiāo**, the **Prefect of Hēzhou** and **Count of Bōchēng**, **Fēngchéng**, with **lofty lineage** and **unbroken service**, though **separated by generations**, much more so in **scholarly excellence**, far **above mortal burdens**, his **Dao/Way**-crafted **lines and measures** refined, his **judgment** yet **consulted**, his **labors** already **recorded**—thus it is **proper** to **inscribe** this **account**.

**Jiāng Hào**, a **disciple of the Three Caverns**, composed this **eulogy**. Established on stone in the **second month, twenty-fifth day**, of the **16th year of Zhēnguān (642 CE)**.

**Inscription for the Daoist Sage of Xiāoshì Shān, Master Wáng Jūn**:
**Wáng Jūn**, the **Sage of Xiāoshì Shān**, **Master of the Celestial Standard**, **emits** his **radiance** to **drench the Luo**, **conceals** his **form** in **divine caverns**, **distinguishes** his **glow** from **sun and moon**—a **true abode** for the **souls of the worthy**.

Thus, **Sage** **Liú Běitái** **illuminated** his **forebear**, and **Master Wáng** **inherited** his **legacy**. **Master Wáng**, a **man of Lángyá**, named **Yuǎnzhī**. His **father**, **Sāngyáng**, was **guided by the phoenix** in **conception**; his **mother**, **Dīng**, **transformed** under the **wind’s influence**. At **seven years old**, he **knew ten thousand words**. His **home** was the **Héyuáng** **Master’s**, where **Táo Hóngjǐng** **dwelled**. There, he **held the needle** with **precision**, **mastered the Dao/Way**-craft**, **relaxed the body’s transformations**, **descended the True** to **replace the coarse**—even **summoning the Window sisters**, one **suspected** him to be the **disciple of the Celestial Sovereign** himself.

Through the **dynasties of Chén, Yuè, and Sūi**, and into our **Táng**, all **revered** him.
His **disciple**, **Pān Shīzhèng**, once **declared**: *"I am **appointed** as the **Sage of Xiāoshì Shān**."* After **bathing and donning ritual robes**, he **ascended**, **enjoying life** to **126 years**. The **Emperor Gāozōng** **posthumously conferred** him as **Great Middle Marshal**, **Mr. Zhēn of the True Dao**, **expounding the Way**.

In **Zhēnyuán’s 10th year (814 CE)**, the **humble one** **arrived from Lúyù**, **lodging** at **Wěnxī**. **Climbing vines**, he **ventured into perilous depths**, **penetrating the crimson chambers**, **rinsing with jade waters**, **echoing the Sage’s wanderings in the Luo**. **Offering sincerity to the void**, he **inscribed** this **eulogy** upon the stone.

**Eulogy**:
The **Dao/Way** **binds** the **original qi**, the **divine mechanism** the **true essence**.
**Jade nectar** and **golden sprouts**, **congealed** in **self-illuminating substance**.
His **traces** **dissipate** like **clouds over misty peaks**, his **thoughts** **stir** the **frost-laden zephyrs**.
The **floating isle** has **passed**, its **radiance** now **still and remote**.

In **24th year of Dàyì (819 CE)**, **Wáng Bówén**, **Grand Marshal** and **Censor-in-Chief**, **reinscribed** this **account**.

**Inscription for the Daoist Sage, Mr. Wáng of the Húángshān Tàipíngguān, and his Preface**:
**Yú Jìngzhī**, **Count of Jiāngníng**, **from Hénán**, composed this; **Wáng Xuánzōng of Lángyá** **inscribed** it.

**Alone**, the **Sovereign of the Yellow Emperor** **possessed the Dao/Way**, **marking the beauty of the顺风**—the **Master of Gūshè** **congealed his spirit**, **setting the example for abdication**—these are **distant reflections** of **ancient texts**, **faint hopes** of **preserved words**.

**How much** does the **Dao/Way** **encompass the ages**, its **virtue/power** **illuminating a hundred kings**! **Before Heaven**, Heaven **does not resist**; **after Heaven**, he **follows Heaven’s timing**. His **transformations** **permeate all**, his **virtue/power** **embraces the utmost**. **Jade waters** of **Qīngxī’s hall**, **purple palaces** of the **Celestial Treasury**—his **summons** **gathered** the **worthy scholars**, who **descended** in **refined robes**, **waiting in ethereal attire**.

He **ceased his journey** at the **vermilion gates**, **abandoned his pleasures** in the **crimson fields**.
**Carefully**, he **entrusted** the **Daoist of Zhōngnánshān**, **Wànfúguān**, **Zhōu Yuánjìng**, to **invite the Sage**. On the **day of the Sage’s ascension**, **clad in misty robes**, he **descended in grace**. **Master Wáng** **lamented** the **eternal separation** of **Master Fǎ’s voice**, **gathered vines** from **Sōngjiàn’s ravine**, and his **disciples**—**Qí Xíngzé**, **Dīng Xuánliàng**, and others—**grieved** for the **departed Sage**, **plucking colored herbs** from **Ránshù’s rocks**, **erecting this grand stele**, **together honoring** his **exalted deeds**.

The **Sage**, **Mr. Wáng**, named **Gǔn**, with the **style** **Hóngfàn**, also called **Dàomó**, was from **Lángyá Lín’í**. His **nature** **gleamed** like **pearls from Zhūchuān**, his **branches** **divided** like **jewel-like petals**; his **clan** **nurtured** the **phoenix’s offspring**, the **Zhōu Book** **praised his lightness of bearing**.

His **leaf** **soared** in **brightness**, the **Líu Histories** **recorded his divine strangeness**.
His **voice** **echoed far**, his **words** **resonated**—
**Ancestor Yún**, **Attendant of the Scattered Cavalry**, **Chief of the Treasury**, **Minister of Revenue**, **his words** **adorned the literary forests**, his **virtue/power** **embellished the halls of learning**; he **soared in splendor** to **Chǔ’s frontiers**, **truly nurturing virtue**—
**Grandfather Guǐ**, **Chancellor of Lǐng Jiǎnwén’s retinue**, **General of the Distant**, **Minister of the Grand Secretariat** in **Chén**, **Grandee of the Light**—he **morning by morning** **hurried to the phoenix court**, **evening by evening** **attended the dragon hall**, **serving two dynasties**, his **reputation** **rivaling the scholars**, his **grace** **overshadowing the arts**—
**Father Yú**, **Assistant of the Literary Bureau** in **Chén**, **Constant Attendant of Fányì**—his **childhood** **radiated** like **lanterns in orchids**, his **official career** **bore the brush**; he **often visited** **Guìshān**, **removing his cap** to **join the guests of the wine feast**, **sometimes riding** in the **pavilion-carriage of the scholars**, **devoting his sincerity** to **serve above**, **humbling himself** to **rest below**, **ever practicing** the **forgotten seat**—thus, he was the **progenitor of noble conduct**.

The **Sage** **nurtured his nature** in the **boiling waves**, **ultimately soaring** on **penguin’s wings**.
**He departed**, yet **returned**; **mysterious**, yet **more mysterious**—his **aspirations** **aligned** with **Heaven’s vastness**, his **affections** **harmonized** with **Earth’s resonance**.
**At eight years old**, he **lost his parents**, **grieving** their **early demise**, his **heart** **echoed** **Zēngxiào’s devotion**, his **sorrow** **matched** **Chái Rén’s kindness**.
When the **Chén dynasty** **ended**, **mortals and deities** **had no refuge**; **jade flames** **consumed the peaks**, **herbal fires** **burned the Chǔ wilds**. In the **beginning of all things**, **the leaves** **alone divided**—**floating reeds** **drifted without root**, **wandering grass** **turned without support**.
**Fortunately**, his **ancestors’ old friends** **sustained him**, **entrusting him** to the **Pāo clan**. After **one rest in the bamboo grove**, **five years** **passed** before he **departed**.

The **Sage’s studies** **contrasted with nature**, his **Dao/Way** **unified the county’s insights**. His **pure heart** **refined his essence**, **in harmony** with **Heaven’s decree**. **Rich** in **the Sage’s harmonious virtue**, **flowing** with **the Supreme Void’s fragrance**, **in youth** he **left the world**, **in later years** he **returned to the True**.

**Master Wáng of the Tàipíngguān**, **Sage of the Three Purity**, **traversed the six doctrines’ crossroads**, **elevating his heart** to **crimson secrets**, **reflecting on profound waves**. He **destroyed the net** in **the path of delusion**, **lit the lamp** in **the chamber of darkness**. His **clear rules** and **unadorned theories** made him a **great man of his age**.

chunks.original_text: 先生顿辔玄门，思弘妙旨，仍随法主卜居茅谷，为香鉼弟子一十六年，夜寝夙兴，劬劳匪懈。 晨供沆淦，夕进流霞，服义忘疲，依仁无教。 想朱宫而思圣，怀紫素以寻真，浪情泉石，披襟兰杜，抗巢由而狎乌，榈庄惠以观鱼。 每至风说春山，月华秋水，猿啼危娇，虎啸幽溪，未尝不警思绿情，抽毫写虑。 先生爰及冠年，虔受经法。 养谷神於玄牝，游浩气於黄庭。 初在法主座下听《老子》《西升》《灵宝》《南华真人论》，退席之际，即为人讲说。 五行俱览，一字无遗，辩若建领，词同炙棵胡瓦切。 。 法主叹而言日：吾道东矣，何独康成。 洎隋氏握图，物色岩穴，旁求俊异，旌贲英翘王法主美孕三仙，芳瑜七圣，爰降丝涣，追赴束都。 先生此辰从游京洛，朝陪琐阖，夕侍铜池，出入两宫，声华四部。 若匪体符真智，志吁虚舟，岂可应彼弓旌，允兹纶召。 当时奉劝，玉清玄坛行道，登厨厚膳，既撰玉而浆金，供帐芳华，亦铺霞而藉锦。 隋后主薄伐玄兔，先生扈从黄龙，车驾凯旋，陪还洛邑。 大业十一年，有诏特委先生於河南二十四郡博访缁素，有道卫、异能、杂技、德行、讲说灼然、堪供养者，及精通道法之徒，并具状追送驾所。 以兹御命，言归旧庐。 俄而炎运道消，苍灵失驭，黄巾、赤眉之倡，皑聚挺妖，绿林、青犊之俦，蠢辈肆姜，关河路绝，因即避乱名山，遂历天台、赤城、四明、桐相、金庭、蔡噢、缙云、若耶。 悟一息之难追，知百年之易往乃随时石室，或逆旅曲枝，折桂纫兰，漱流自乐。 日月居诸，复淹十载，而黔黎涂炭，县命有归。 我大唐凤举晋阳，龙兴渭泪，扫搀抢以居南面，除楔瑜以正北辰，御极紫微，负图黄屋，静稽天之大浸，灭炎昆之燎火，包日月以为肩牖，苑淇渤以作池隍，列珪璧於长安，大礼仪天地之轨，陈算诚于清庙，大乐节天地之音。 先生既属文明，遂动思归之引，整此驭，振蜕裳，背天台，还地肺，入报辕而迎法驾，游郊廓而谒真人。 太宗文皇帝游心寥廓之津，开玉京於碧落，凝神杳冥之境，敞金阙於绛宫。 截哲於是照临，至圣以之绵邈，而亭毒之私弘远，然随迎之道未臻，遇崆山之顺风，仰濑乡之微旨。 于时法主尚承思梓泽，夫果言之柳沃，故遣法师，先以还修茸许陶遗址。 此观，梁武皇帝於许真人旧宅为陶隐居建立，号日□朱阳。 皇明启运，更以华阳为目。 按《真诰》云：华阳，第八洞天之名也。 其山则崇岩隐天，入云逵而上炼； 盘基括地，带风溪而旁属。

The Master then halted his steed at the Mysterious Gate,
pondering how to expound the wondrous intent.
He still followed the Sage as his abode in the thatched valley,
serving as a disciple of the Fragrant Master for sixteen years,
rising early and retiring late,
laboring without ceasing.

At dawn, he offered the turbid brew,
at dusk, he partook the flowing nectar,
fulfilling his duty without weariness,
relying on virtue without instruction.

He contemplated the Vermilion Palace and sought the Sage,
held the Purple Robe in mind to find the True.
His emotions wandered with spring waters and stones,
his sleeves unfurled for orchids and cassia.
He raised the nest of Master You to tame the crows,
extended the palm of Master Zhuang to observe the fish.

When the wind spoke in spring’s mountains,
when moonlight shimmered on autumn’s waters,
when the monkeys cried in perilous heights,
when the tigers roared in secluded streams,
he never failed to awaken his thoughts in verdant reverie,
and dip his brush to record his reflections.

By the time the Master reached maturity,
he devoutly received the scriptures and teachings.
He nurtured the Valley Spirit in the Mysterious Feminine,
and roamed the Boundless Qi in the Yellow Palace.

At first, he sat beneath the Sage’s seat,
listening to *The Laozi*, *The Western Ascension*,
*The Soul’s Treasure*, and *The True Person of the South’s Discourse*.
Upon leaving, he immediately expounded them for others,
covering all Five Phases without omission,
every word preserved—
his arguments towered like the Pillars of Heaven,
his phrases aligned as sharp as the cleaving of Huo’s blade.

The Sage sighed and said:
*"My Dao has turned eastward—
why single out Kang Cheng alone?"*

When the Sui Dynasty seized the map,
scouting rocks and caves for omens,
seeking the gifted and extraordinary,
the Sage proclaimed the Three Fragrant Masters and Seven Holy Ones—
then descended in silk mist,
hurrying to the Bundled Capital.

At this juncture, the Master joined their journey to the Jing-Luo region,
morning by morning attending the humble court,
evening by evening serving the bronze pool,
entering and exiting the twin palaces,
his fame resounding through the Four Departments.

Had he not embodied True Wisdom,
had his resolve not been as vast as the Empty Boat,
how could he answer the archers’ banners,
or accept the summons of the silk edict?

At the time, he was urged to perform
the Dao of the Jade Pure and Mysterious Hall,
preparing thick sacrificial meals,
carving jade for the broth and gilding the rice,
decorating the altar with fragrant offerings,
spreading clouds as a quilt and brocade as a bed.

When the Sui ruler’s expedition returned victorious,
the Master accompanied him in the Yellow Dragon procession,
the chariots triumphant in their homeward march to Luoyang.

In the eleventh year of the Great Business era,
there came an edict commissioning the Master
to the twenty-four counties of Henan,
to broadly seek out black-robed monks—
those with genuine virtue, extraordinary abilities,
diverse skills, praiseworthy conduct,
or who could elucidate teachings with clarity,
and those who mastered the Dao’s methods—
and report their names to the imperial court.

With this imperial command,
he returned to his former dwelling.

Soon after, the fiery destiny waned,
the Celestial Sovereign lost control,
as the Yellow Scarves and Red Eyebrows
gathered in rebellion, their malice rising.
The Green Forests and Blue Calves
followed in their disorderly ranks,
their insolence unchecked.
The passes were severed, and so he fled to sacred mountains,
traversing Tian Tai, Chìchéng, Sìmíng,
Tóngxiāng, Jīntíng, Cài Yōu,
Jǐnyún, and Ruòyě.

Realizing that life is fleeting as a breath,
knowing that a hundred years pass swiftly,
he adapted to the times—
sometimes resting in stone chambers,
sometimes lodging in humble inns with crooked branches,
plucking osmanthus and orchids,
sipping flowing waters in self-contentment.

The sun and moon lingered in his presence,
and he immersed himself for another ten years,
yet the black-haired folk suffered in flames,
and the county magistrates had perished.

Then, the Great Tang’s phoenix arose from Jinyang,
its dragon ascended from Weishui,
sweeping away the chaotic and rebellious,
restoring order to the southern lands,
removing the wedge and correcting the northern pole,
holding the Purple Axis in reverence,
bearing the Yellow Map in triumph,
calmly contemplating Heaven’s vast inundation,
extinguishing the fiery Kun’s blazing flames,
enclosing the sun and moon as shoulder windows,
cultivating the Qí and Bó as a moat and pond,
ranking the jade tablets and bi discs in Chang’an,
establishing grand rites to align with Heaven and Earth,
proclaiming sincerity in the pure temple,
and composing grand music to harmonize with the sounds of Heaven and Earth.

The Master, having witnessed this flourishing civilization,
was moved to return by the call of his homeland.
He readied his carriage,
adjusted his worn robes,
left Tian Tai behind,
and entered the Earth’s Lung.
He entered the reporting gate to welcome the Sage’s procession,
and wandered the outer precincts to pay homage to the True Person.

The Emperor Taizong, the Wénhuáng,
wandered in spirit through the Boundless Pass,
opening the Jade Capital in the Verdant Reaches,
concentrating his mind in the Faint and Obscure Realm,
expanding the Golden Gate in the Crimson Palace.

The Sage now shone his wisdom,
the Most Holy extended his boundless compassion,
while the venom of private teachings spread far.
Yet the Master’s path of welcome was still incomplete,
and he encountered the favorable wind of Mount Kāng.
He ascended to the subtle teachings of the Lìxié Village.

At that time, the Sage still held the legacy of the Zǐzé Forest,
his words as lush as the willow’s shade.
Thus, he dispatched disciples,
first to restore the Master’s abode at the Er Tao’s former site.

This temple was built in the residence of the Xu Sage,
where the True Person once dwelled,
and was named □Zhūyáng.
In the Ming Dynasty’s reign,
it was renamed Huáyáng.
According to *The True Announcement*, Huáyáng
is the name of the eighth of the Celestial Caverns.

Its mountain rises in towering rocks,
hidden from the sky,
with paths ascending into the clouds—
where the refining takes place.
Its base encircles the earth,
its winding streams carry the wind,
and its peaks extend far beyond.

「With his dwelling bound by sacred groves,
he soared through the Nine Transformations to wander among the immortals;
to the south, he controlled the Luo Fu,
opening Five Passes to receive the Sage.
To the west, he connected with E Yao,
extending far to the Xi Jin.
To the north, he shook the Tai Zong,
flipping his crane-driving carriage to the hidden abode of the Spirit Sovereign.
Truly, he was one whom the feathered guests lingered to visit.

Yet his former foundations lay in ruins,
his nearby halls overgrown with weeds,
so the Master himself cleared the thorny fields and opened the grounds anew,
commencing this grand construction.
With reverence, he built the main hall,
three eaves and two bays,
including lecture halls, ritual platforms, chambers, and gateways.
He planted fragrant osmanthus and cassia along the winding paths,
so that their shadows darkened like clouds,
and raised plum beams upon the celestial roads,
so that their splendor blazed like morning mist.
The eaves extended like a duck’s flight, their calls ringing clear,
the phoenix-tiled roof stood solitary and lofty,
the joyful magpies ascended in pairs—
how much more than mere butterfly wings stirring the breeze,
or the mortals’ refined appearances from their alchemy!

Yet the sacred light was easily accessible,
why was the fulfillment of blessings so difficult?
Again, within the inner hall,
he reverently enshrined a statue of the Primordial Sovereign of Heaven,
eight feet in height,
with two Celestial Masters flanking him in attendance.
The divine bearing was solemn and dignified,
the sacred form subtle and refined—
its countenance mirrored the moon’s luminous purity,
its spirit captured the sun’s radiant brilliance.
The pillars gleamed with double hues,
displaying the *Golden Scripture of Auspiciousness*,
the palms emitted tenfold light,
the *Jade Tablets of Good Fortune* shone like crystal.
Thus, the celestial nymphs of divine splendor
came in procession from the *Hall of the Radiant Fungus*,
and the *Spiritual Deities of the Clouds*
gathered at the *Fragrant Tower of the Morning Mist*,
their attendance ceasing only with the day’s end.

The Master then arranged the emerald throne
and fanned the mysterious winds,
walking the red steps
to proclaim the myriad wonders.
He maneuvered the boat of compassion
to rescue those in need,
and raised the torch of wisdom
to illuminate the unenlightened.
His benevolent influence matched the depths of the whale’s abyss,
his achievements surpassed the Five Tortoises of the *Kui Peak* in grandeur—
Oh, how vast and beautiful they were!
Indeed, they were beyond praise.

The disciples traveled to renowned mountains and blessed lands,
encountering true scriptures by chance.
Later, they resided at the Hua Yang Cavern,
where they meticulously copied the sacred diagrams and secret treasures
of the Supreme Daoist Schools—
the *Dongxuan Sacred Patterns* and the *Dongxuan Divine Symbols*—
and with utmost devotion,
they transcribed the *Zhongwei Models* and exhausted the *Ban Chui Regulations*.
Sealed within a quiet chamber,
they eternally safeguarded the mountain’s gateways.

From youth to old age,
the Master always savored the scent of pine and wood.
In his lifetime, he conducted lectures and teachings,
and all his offerings and charities
were recorded as merits and virtues.
He never failed to rescue the poor.

In the second year of the Qian Feng era,
the year of the Ding Mao,
on the first day of the eleventh month,
after completing his morning rites,
he turned to his disciples and said:
*"Last night, during the fifth watch,
I seemed to be in a dream,
and saw three men in feathered robes,
their attire impeccable,
holding tablets and scrolls,
entering my chambers.
They declared that the Hua Yang Celestial Palace
had long evaluated my worth,
and now appointed me as the Immortal Sovereign for Ten Thousand People,
also entrusting me with the oversight of the Celestial Officials.

Moreover, your virtue and talent are pure and lofty,
fit for this station.
Now, we bear the heavy command to invite and welcome you—
you must depart without delay.
I once dwelled in the Tong Wu Mountains,
and already felt this calling in my dreams.
Though I declined, I could not escape,
and now must answer this summons.*
Thus, he admonished his disciples,
instructing them on the essentials of cultivating the Dao,
the scriptures and their practices,
each receiving his final charge.

On the eighth day of the month,
he repeatedly asked for fragrant baths and purification,
changing his headgear and sash,
and donning new robes.
At dawn on the ninth day,
strange incense filled the chamber,
his body upright and serene,
then suddenly dissolved into the void—
in the age of eighty-eight.

On the seventeenth day,
in the hour of Gui You,
he entrusted his spirit-tablet to a tree
at the Hua Yang Temple,
on the western slope of Lei Ping Mountain
and to the right of the tomb of Tao Zheng.
Alas!

The Master’s virtue was as boundless as the Two Principles,
his emotions encompassed the Six Qi.
From birth, he was a source of doubt and wonder,
yet in his growth, he embodied the Rectitude of the Dao.
His center was yellow and harmonious,
his elixir-fields concentrated in form.
The White Phoenix soared in his spirit,
and his discussions of Daoist texts in the *Hanlin Academy*
were as brilliant as the Spotted Bird’s flights in debate.
He analyzed profound truths in his lectures.

His body was one with the divine,
his nature aligned with the Dao.
He purified his heart along the Pine Path,
and practiced austerity in the Cloud Roads.
Truly, he was of the *Pengtiao* and *Qizhou* lineage,
united with the *Pengxian* in purpose.
The Five-Colored Mountains of the West
witnessed only the phantom of a child of the Dao,
and the Eight Immortals of the Huai Nan
were but echoes of his great deeds.

His disciples—Dai Huigong, Bao Fangguang,
Hao Dewen, Wang Yuanyao—
and over a thousand others,
all of extraordinary talent and virtue,
their voices rising above the *Qi Jian*,
inheriting the teachings from the *Que Li*,
devoted to the Dao in the *Zi Wei*,
grieved as if their beams were shattered,
mourned beyond the depths of *Lin Gu*—
they gathered the *Golden Hua* to bid farewell,
and sought the *Jade Shu* to reaffirm their resolve.
Time has passed like the sun and moon,
yet his lofty teachings remain.
When they saw his inscribed works,
they composed this elegy:

**First Ode:**
The Perfect One needs no aid,
the Supreme Virtue is nameless.
His heart concentrated as the Vermilion Tortoise,
his spirit wandering in the Jade Purity.
He battled winds with the wings of the Peng,
and struck water to cross the *Ying*.
The Green Stream bore his essence,
the Blue Sky echoed his fame.

**Second Ode:**
The Mystic Pearl was already attained,
the White Clouds could be commanded.
The cow-eyed were left unharmed,
the *Harmful Moths* departed.
The Yellow Court held his #4 virtue,
the Purple Court honored his reputation.
He then turned the *Huan Xi* seal,
and soon mourned the *Zhi Xu*’s dissipation.

**Third Ode:**
He shone like snow upon the Kāng peaks,
congealed like frost at Gu She.
The *Peony* was bought with scattered rainbows,
the *Lotus* moved with shifting thunder.
At first, he seemed to bury his sword—
then the *Ling Wu* left its mark.
His words spread far and wide,
yet his teachings were profound and vast.

**Fifth Ode:**
The fragrant mists were doubled,
the beauty of success was renewed.
Calamity stretched to the Vermilion Gate,
flames scoured the Azure Palace.
He cleared the brambles of the *Luo* grass,
and his foundation endured forevermore.
The Rainbow Disk and the Phoenix’s breath—
truly like the workings of the gods.

**Sixth Ode:**
In the *Liu* Valley, he sought the potter’s art,
in the *Zhi* Field, he greeted the sage.
He listened in secret to the Four Dynasties,
and conversed in revelry with the Three *Mao*.
Wild melodies filled the *Xia* Pavilion,
mountain sentiments rose with the moon’s ascent.
His pavilion faced the frost’s delicate charm,
his pool linked with the wind’s refined grace.

**Seventh Ode:**
He leaned on the *Yi* Law’s teachings,
his voice spreading profound and vast.
The realm of wisdom was not yet exhausted,
yet the *Sheng* Cause fell first.
He neared the *Lin* Altar’s ambition,
but his labor was undone like overturned earth.
The *Zhi* Standard marked the True Sovereign,
would he ever seek vain adornment?

**Eighth Ode:**
**Inscription for the Stele of Master Zhenbai of Mount Mao**
**A Brief Account by Master Dao-yin of the White Cloud Monastery, Recorded and Written by the River-intern Sima Dao-weizi**

Great indeed was Dao-yuan,
the source of ten thousand essences’ birth.
His presence was as fleeting as a passing breath,
yet his creation was as manifest as the mingling of *yin* and *yang*.
If one follows the Dao’s teachings,
refines the mind through profound insight,
harmonizes and circulates the elixir’s flow,
and transmutes both form and spirit—
to merge with the One and ascend the Three *Qing*,
to attain the ancient secrets yet few have reached perfection.

Only Master Zhenbai gathered them all,
discerned them with clarity,
dwelled in stillness and mastered them,
diligently practiced and fulfilled them.
Truly, he was born of the *Ling* Qi.
In his womb, he saw the Dragon’s ascent in dreams,
his towering virtue mirrored the *Hé* Sage’s form,
his bones recorded the *Bai* Immortal’s bearing.
His heart was like a bright mirror,
penetrating all without remainder,
his vessel like a great bell,
emptiness ensured its response.

Thus, the Dao’s true transmission was complete at the *Zhao* Platform,
its subtle meanings revealed in the *Ling* Treasury.
He compiled the scattered texts into coherent records,
expanded the *Jin* Script’s phoenix seals,
added the *Lang* Case’s dragon chapters,
unveiling ancient mysteries and guiding later disciples.
Like the lesser teachings of the Immortals,
he became the renowned master of ages.

Beholding Master Zhenbai’s likeness,
one sees the Dao preserved in his gaze.
Reading his writings,
one finds his spirit in the flowing words—
even after a thousand years, one may grasp his essence in a single morning.

As for the mysteries of his profound thoughts,
the subtleties of his form’s transmuted grace,
I know not how to fully describe them,
though logic strains to explain.

With reverence, I refine my own virtues and deeds,
receive the Dao’s full teachings,
and follow the *Ke* methods—
indeed surpassing the True Stages.
My fate diverges from his path,
my words differ in silence and revelation.
I follow his enlightenment’s shadow,
not his dawn’s ascent.
In darkness, I rise to the Upper *Qing*,
beyond mortal measure or recognition.

Yet though his form dissolved into clouds,
his empty chamber still remains,
his sword has not yet flown,
his grave mound remains unopened.
The Dao is honored, virtue esteemed—
eternally unchanged through the ages.
His writings reveal his essence,
yet today none may see it.

Dynasties have passed in succession,
mountain ages have turned cold.
None cherish the Immortal’s resolve,
long have I felt profound sorrow.

Now that Dao-weizi returns to the *Heng* Mountains,
resting at Mount Mao’s slopes,
he gathers with the *Fa* Masters to carve this stone.
The *Shao* Ling composed the text,
perfect in its time.
Now I record it with ink,
preserving his #5 past deeds.
With clumsy brush in hand,
I humbly recount his true teachings,
inscribing them beneath the stele
to illuminate the ages.

Written on the 13th day of the 9th month,
in the year *Jiazi* of the *Kaiyuan* era,
on the day *Gisi* (己巳).

In the year *Yihai* of the *Kaiyuan* era,
on the 4th month’s *Renzhi* day (壬子),
Master White Cloud was at Mount *Wangwu*,
when his nephew, the *Yanling* County magistrate’s clerk,
received his command to personally oversee the carving.

**Record of Gold and Stone: The Stele of Master Xuanjing of Purple Yang Observatory, Mao Mountain, in the Tang Dynasty**

Inscribed by **Gengshi** (secretary) Liu Shizhi of Hedong (河东柳识), written by **Zhì** (assistant justice) Zhang Congshen of the **Hao** Commandery (昊郡张从申), with the seal script on the preface by Li Yangbing (李阳冰).

The **Dao** Gate of **Hua**yang (華陽), also the **Confucian** Gate of **Mò**si (沬泗), is where the **Xuan** (玄) transformation resonates. At dawn beneath the golden light, there were the **Mao** brothers of the Western Han; in secluded shadows and hidden **Dao** withdrawal, there was the **Shu** family of the **Jin** dynasty (束晉許氏一門). Following their **Ming** (明) and **Chong** (沖) lineage, to elucidate the **Dao**’s wind, there were **Master Zhengbai** of the Liang (梁貞白先生) and **Master Xuanjing** of the Tang (唐玄靜先生).

During the **Kaiyuan** era, the **Xuan**zong (玄宗) honored the **Master** (尊師) and inquired about **li**hua (理化). He replied: *"The Daodejing* is the **Master**’s guide for rulers. In ancient times, Emperor Wen of Han practiced its teachings, and thus the **Ren**shou (仁壽) era brought prosperity to all under heaven."

The emperor then asked about **Jin**ding (金鼎). He replied: *"The **Dao**’s virtue/power is like the wind—if one raises it too hastily, it disperses. If one clings to its private aspects, they lose sight of the whole. The **Sage** (聖人) preserves the teachings, yet does not cling to life or indulge in desires, lest it appear as though striking the wind."*

The emperor was pleased and thus bestowed upon him the title **Xuanjing** (玄靜).

Not long after, he declined due to illness and returned eastward to **Jùqū** (句曲).

chunks.original_text: 先生讳含光，本姓弘，则天讳弘，改为李氏。 考孝威，州里号贞#1隐先生，家本醇儒，晋陵人也。 夫性与道妙，则真有运无。 古之学者，离有得有，不外叹驰景而内观驰心，不远思#2化金而近思化欲。 今之学者，多见反是，若乃行於真理，官然观妙，先示正性，发明宗元，则玄静其人也。 年十三，辞家奉道，端视清受，慈向蠢动，间室之中，如对君亲，时人见之，情性皆敛。 幼工篆隶，或称过父，一闻此议，终身不书。 所撰《仙学传记》阙遗备载，又论三玄异同，着《真经》及《本草音义》，而皆精详袂惑，穷理於学，如钟蕴声。 其后师事华盖峰司马君，云篆宝书，倾囊传授，既而目之曰：真玉清之客。 抱虚无而行功者，与道不穷，托幽阜而灭边者，於德亦浅。 承之自远，宜且救人。 於是引后学升堂禀玄训也。 先生元气不散，瑶图虚映，达灵已久，晦曜为常，动非用开，静非默闭，当吹万之会，若得一之初，应迩可名，常道不可名也，草蒙求我，岂劳言说，孕育至化，虚融一心，心一变至於学，学一变至於道，同淑气自来，得之不见，所以枢衣而进，无有远迩，仰范元和，茂资全性者，若秋芳之依层嗽，夏潦之会通川也。 先生忘情於身，而慈於人，祯祥屡应，视同众象，士庶咨询，色授其意。 常令章坛闭#3院，醮火择薪，精微诚敬，率皆此类。 曩者天书继至，务欲尊崇，公卿祈请，信无虚月，卒使玄门之中，转见真璞，持慈俭之宝，归羲黄之风。 至矣哉，我师教也。 大历四年冬十一月，顾谓入室弟子韦景昭、孟湛然日：吾将顺化。 神气恬然，若坐忘长往，时年八十七。 灵云降室，执简如生。 据真经，斯乃秉化自由，仙阶深妙者也。 门人等以为醴泉之味，饮者始知，我师之道，学久方见，愿叔真宗，以示於后。 泰曾游道，敢述玄风。 铭日： 古有强名，元精希夷，黄帝遗之，先生得之。 纵心而往，与一相随。 真性所容，太无同规。

「The **Master** (先生), whose personal name was **Hán Guāng** (含光), originally bore the surname **Hóng** (弘), but since the **Empress Zétiān** (則天) also bore that surname, he changed it to **Lǐ** (李). His father, **Xiào Wēi** (孝威), was renowned in his locality as **Zhēn#1yǐn** (贞#1隐). The **Master**’s family was one of **chún** **rú** (醇儒) from **Jìnlíng** (晉陵).

For nature and the **Dao** (道) are subtle, yet true **qi** (元氣) flows without end.

The ancient scholars sought **li**hua (理化) by discerning the **yǒu** (有) within the **wú** (無), neither straying beyond the sighing of the wind nor the fading of light, nor wandering far in thought of **huà** (化) as gold but staying close to the **Dao** (道) of desires. If one today practices true **li**hua (理化), naturally observes the subtle, first demonstrates upright **xìng** (性), and elucidates the fundamental **zōngyuán** (宗元), then such a one is **Xuanjing** (玄靜).

At thirteen, he left his home to devote himself to the **Dao** (道), maintaining a serene and pure gaze, offering kindness to even the most base of movements. In his dwelling, he treated others as if they were sovereigns or kin; those who saw him were all moved, their emotions and dispositions subdued.

In his youth, he mastered **zhuànlì** (篆隶) script, yet when someone praised him as surpassing his father, he never again wrote a single character.

His compositions, including *The Records of Daoist Learning* (《仙學傳記_), filled in gaps and preserved what was lost. He also discussed the differences and similarities among the *Three Daos* (三玄), compiling *The True Scripture* (《真經》) and *The Phonetic Meanings of the Fundamental Herbs* (《本草音義》), all of which were meticulously detailed, without confusion, and exhausted the principles of learning—like a bell holding its resonance.

Later, he studied under **Sìmǎ Jūn** (司馬君) of **Huágàifēng** (華蓋峰), who possessed **zhuàn** (篆) script treasures and imparted them generously. Afterward, he was addressed as *"The Guest of the True Pure and Clear"* (真玉清之客).

Those who embraced **xūwú** (虛無) yet neglected practice were no different from the **Dao** (道) itself; those who relied on secluded mountains yet abandoned their boundaries were shallow in **virtue/power** (德). To receive the **Dao** (道) from afar, one ought to save others first.

Thus, he guided his disciples to ascend his hall and receive his profound teachings.

The **Master**’s **qi** (元氣) was unscattered, his **yáo tú** (瑶圖) empty yet luminous. His **ling** **hun** (靈魂) had long been enlightened, his brilliance ever concealed. His actions did not reveal their purpose, nor did his stillness imply closure; at the assembly of the ten thousand, he was as if at the gathering of the one, and the **Dao** (道) that could be named was not the **Dao** (道) itself. When the grassy **Móng** (蒙) sought him, he did not labor over words. He nurtured the **Dao** (道) of ultimate transformation, blending the **xūróng** (虛融) into a single mind. The mind, once transformed, reaches **learning** (學); learning, once transformed, attains the **Dao** (道). This harmony of virtuous **qi** (氣) has always been present, but only those who seek it truly see it. Therefore, he wore his **shū** **yī** (枢衣) and advanced without distinction of near or far, taking **Yuán Hé** (元和) as his model and cultivating the fullness of his **xìng** (性)—like autumn flowers leaning on layered cliffs or summer floods converging in rivers.

The **Master** forgot his own body yet showed kindness to all; auspicious omens often appeared, as if he were a common sight. Commoners and scholars alike consulted him, and he conveyed his meaning through expression alone.

He often ordered the **zhāng tán** (章坛) to close its **bìyuàn** (閉#3院), to select incense wood for ritual offerings, and to perform rites with utmost sincerity—all in this manner.

Once, celestial scriptures arrived in succession, and he was earnestly requested to honor them. The ministers and officials prayed for his blessings, and indeed, there was no month without their petitions. Eventually, the **Dao** (道) community saw him as the *True Uncarved Jade* (真璞), holding the treasure of benevolent frugality and returning to the **Dao** (道) of the **Xī** (羲) and **Huáng** (黃).

Truly, my teacher’s teachings have reached their peak!

In the winter of the fourth year of **Dàlì** (大歷), he said to his disciples **Wéi Jǐngzhāo** (韋景昭) and **Mèng Zhǎnrán** (孟湛然): *"I shall now follow the **Dao** (道) of transformation."* His **shén qì** (神氣) was tranquil, as if in the state of **zuòwàng** (坐忘). He was then eighty-seven years old.

As his **líng yún** (靈雲) descended upon the hall, he held his tablet as if alive. According to *The True Scripture* (《真經》), this was the mark of one who grasped the freedom of transformation and the profound mysteries of the Daoist path.

His disciples said: *"The taste of the **Lìquán** (醴泉) is known only to those who drink it; the **Dao** (道) of our teacher is seen only by those who study it long. We wish to uphold the True Doctrine and demonstrate it to future generations."*

**Tài** (泰) once wandered in the **Dao** (道), now dares to recount its profound winds.

This inscription reads:

*"In ancient times, there were those who bore strong names, their **yuánjīng** (元精) rare and refined. The **Yellow Emperor** (黃帝) left them behind; the **Master** (先生) obtained them. He wandered freely, yet always in harmony with the One. The true **xìng** (性) contained within him followed the same rule as **Tàiwú** (太無).*

chunks.original_text: 日行仙路，不语到时。 人言万灵，我见常姿。 玄宗仰止，征就京师。 紫极徒贵，白云不知。 遐方后学，来往怡怡。 空有多门，真精自持。 委顺而去，人焉能窥。 玄科秘诀，本有冥期。 大历七年八月＋四日建。 茅山玄静先生广陵李君碑铭并序 金紫光禄大夫行湖州刺史上柱国鲁郡开国公颜真卿撰并书。 先生姓李，讳含光，广陵江都人。 本姓弘，以孝敬皇帝庙讳改焉。 二十一代祖宏#4，江夏太守，避王莽，徙居晋陵，遂为郡人。 高祖文疑，陈桂阳王国侍郎。 曾祖荣，皇朝雷州司马。 祖师宠#5，隐居以求其 志，徙居江都。 父孝威，博学好古，雅修彭、聘之道，与天台司马炼师子微为方外友，尤以笃慎着于州里，考行议，谧日正#6隐先生。 母琅琊王氏，贤明有德行。 先生孩提则有殊异，眸日独取《孝经》如捧读焉。 髻卯好静处，习诵坟、典。 年十八， 志求道妙，遂师事同邑李先生，游艺数年。 神龙初，以清行度为道士，居龙兴观，尤精《老》、《庄》、《周易》之深趣。 执丧过哀，口不尝甘旨之味，食惟积麦而已。 封植膳羞，皆出其手，号毁骨立，亲族莫不伤之。 开元十七年，从司马炼师於王屋山，传授大法灵文金记，一览无遗，综窍古今，该明奥旨。 玄宗知先生偏得子微之道，乃诏先生居王屋山阳台观以继之。 岁余，请归茅山，纂修经法。 频征，皆谢病不出。 天宝四载冬，乃命中官责玺书征之。 既至，延入禁中，每欲谘禀，必先斋沐。 他日请传道法，先生辞以足疾不任科仪者数焉，玄宗知不可强而止。 先生尝以茅山灵迹前焉将坠，真经秘录亦多散落，请归修茸。 乃特诏於杨、许旧居紫阳以宅之，仍赐绢二百疋、法衣两副、香炉一具、御制诗及叔以饯之。 又禁於山侧采捕渔猎，食荤血者不得辄入，公私祈梼，咸绝牲牢。 先生以六载秋到山，是岁韶书三至，渥泽频繁，辉映崖谷。 初，山中有上清真人许长史、杨君、陶隐居自写经法，历代传宝，时遭丧乱，散逸无遗。 先生奉韶搜求，悉备其迹而进上之。 先时，玄宗将求大法，请先生为师，竟执谦冲，辞疾而退。 洎七载春，玄宗又欲受《三洞真经》，以其春之三月，中官责玺书云：其月十八日，克受经诰。 是日於大同殿洁修其事，遂遥礼先生为度师，并赐衣一袭以申师资之礼，因以玄静为先生之嘉号焉。 仍诏刻石华阳洞宫以 志之。 是岁夏五月，隐居合丹之所，有芝草八十一茎散生松石之问，韶俾先生与中官启告灵仙，缄封表进。 夏，又诏以紫阳观侧近二百户，太平、崇元两观各一、百户，并免其官榣，以供香火。 秋七月，又征先生。 既至，请居道观以养疾。 九载春，辞归旧山。 其年夏六月，前生芝灵之所又产三百余茎，煌煌秀异，人所莫睹。 先生又图而奏之。 是岁冬，又征先生，於紫阳别院馆之。 十载秋，先生又恳辞告老，御制序诗以饯之。 十有一载，先生奉诏与门人韦景昭等於紫阳之束讲冈山别建斋院，立心诚肃。 是夜仙坛林问褊生甘露，因以上闻，特诏嘉异。 初，隐居先生以《三洞真经》传升玄先生，升玄付体玄先生，体玄付正一先生，正一付先生。 自先生距于隐居凡五叶矣，皆总袭妙门大正真法，所以茅山为天下学道之所宗矣。

「He walked the Daoist path daily, yet spoke not when the time arrived.
Men say all beings are wondrous, but I see only the common form.
The **Emperor Xuānzōng** (玄宗) revered him and summoned him to the capital.
The **Purple Peak** (紫极) was but honored in name, while the **White Cloud** (白云) remained unaware.

Later disciples from distant lands came and went in joyful harmony.
Though many schools of thought existed, his true **qi** (精) was self-sustained.
He entrusted himself to the Dao and departed, leaving none to fathom his essence.
The secret teachings of the mystic arts had their destined time—he knew it well.

In the seventh year of **Dàlì** (大历), on the fourth day of the eighth month, this inscription was established.

**Inscription for Master Lǐ Containing-Light of Mount Máo (茅山玄静先生) from Guānglíng (广陵)**
By **Jīnzǐ Guānglù Dàfū** (金紫光禄大夫) **Yán Zhēnqìng** (颜真卿), who held the titles of **Lake State Prefect** (行湖州刺史) and **Grandee of the Realm** (上柱国), and was the **Count of Lǔ** (鲁郡) and **First Duke of Kāiguó** (开国公).

The Master was surnamed **Lǐ** (李), given the name **Hán-Guāng** (含光), and hailed from **Jiāngdū** (江都) in **Guānglíng** (广陵).
Originally, his family bore the surname **Hóng** (弘), but it was changed to avoid the taboo of the **Temple Name of the Emperor Xiàojìng** (孝敬皇帝庙讳).

His **fourth ancestral grandfather** (二十一代祖), **Hóng** (宏), was the **Prefect of Jiāngxià** (江夏太守). To avoid the **usurpation of Wang Máng** (王莽), he relocated to **Jìnlíng** (晋陵), thus becoming a native of the county.
His **great-grandfather** (高祖), **Wéndú** (文疑), served as **Attendant Officer of the State of Guì** (陈桂阳王国侍郎).
His **great-grandfather** (曾祖), **Róng** (荣), held the post of **Master of Ráizhōu** (皇朝雷州司马).
His **grandfather** (祖师), **Chǒng** (宠), retired in seclusion to pursue his aspirations, later settling in **Jiāngdū** (江都).
His father, **Xiàowēi** (孝威), was a scholar of ancient lore, refining the **Dao of Páng** (彭) and **Lǐng** (聘). He befriended **Zǐwéi Sīmǎ Liànshī** (天台司马炼师子微) as a layman, and his reputation for earnestness and prudence earned him the title **Mr. Zhèngyǐn** (正隐先生) among the people. His mother, **Wáng from Lángyè** (琅琊王氏), was virtuous and of noble character.

As a child, the Master exhibited extraordinary traits. His eyes alone sought out the *Classic of Filial Piety* (《孝经》), as if cradling it in his hands.
From a young age, he favored quietude, studying and reciting the *Analects* (坟) and *Classics* (典).
At eighteen, he resolved to seek the profound mysteries of the Dao, and thus became a disciple of his fellow-county Daoist Master **Lǐ** (李), devoting years to his arts.

In the first year of **Shéndòng** (神龙), he was ordained as a Daoist priest for his virtuous conduct, residing at **Lóngxīng Guān** (龙兴观). He mastered the profound essences of the *Laozi* (《老》), *Zhuāngzi* (《庄》), and *Zhōuyǐ* (《周易》).

When attending to funeral rites, he did not taste sweet flavors, and his diet consisted solely of accumulated barley.
The offerings of food and drink for the deceased were all prepared by his own hands, earning him the epithet *"Destroying the bones, standing firm"* (毁骨立). His kin could not help but mourn his asceticism.

In the seventeenth year of **Kāiyuán** (开元), he accompanied **Sīmǎ Liànshī Zǐwéi** (司马炼师子微) to **Wángwū Shān** (王屋山), where he received the **Sacred Scriptures of the Great Dao** (大法灵文金记), comprehending them in a single glance. He synthesized the keys of antiquity and modernity, elucidating their profound meanings.

**Emperor Xuānzōng** (玄宗) recognized that the Master had uniquely inherited **Zǐwéi’s** Dao, and thus decreed that he reside at **Yángtái Guān** (阳台观) in **Wángwū Shān** (王屋山) to continue its teachings.

After a year, the Master requested to return to **Mount Máo** (茅山) to compile and refine the Daoist scriptures.
Repeated summons were all declined on account of his feigned illness.

In the winter of the fourth year of **Tiānbǎo** (天宝), the Emperor commanded imperial officials to deliver a sealed decree summoning him.
Upon arrival, he was granted an audience in the **Forbidden City** (禁中), and whenever the Emperor sought counsel, he first underwent purification rites.

Later, when the Emperor requested transmission of the Daoist teachings, the Master demurred, citing his foot ailment as an impediment to proper ritual observance, many times over. The Emperor, recognizing he could not be compelled, desisted.

The Master had once observed that the **Sacred Scriptures of Mount Máo** (茅山灵迹) were on the verge of collapse, and their secret records had largely scattered. He thus sought to return and restore them.

The Emperor specially granted him the former residences of **Yáng** (杨) and **Xǔ** (许) near **Zǐyáng** (紫阳), along with two hundred bolts of silk, two sets of Daoist robes, a censer, and imperial poetry. He also bestowed the title **Chú** (叔) upon him as a farewell gift.

Furthermore, the Emperor prohibited hunting and fishing near the mountain, forbidding those who consumed meat or blood from entering without prior purification. Both public and private sacrificial rites were henceforth conducted without slaughtered offerings.

The Master arrived at the mountain in the autumn of the sixth year. That year, the **auspicious winds** (韶书) descended three times, bringing abundant moisture and luminous reflections across the cliffs and valleys.

Initially, the mountain housed the **True Person of the Upper Clarity** (上清真人) **Xǔ Chángshǐ** (许长史), **Yáng Jūn** (杨君), and **Táo Yǐnjū** (陶隐居), who had personally inscribed their Daoist teachings. These sacred texts were passed down through generations, but during the chaos of war and upheaval, they were lost and scattered.

The Master, entrusted with the **auspicious winds** (韶), searched diligently and recovered their traces, presenting them to the Emperor.

Previously, when the Emperor sought the **Great Dao** (大法), he requested the Master as his teacher. The Master, however, remained modest and declined, citing illness.

In the spring of the seventh year, the Emperor again desired to receive the *Three Caverns True Scriptures* (《三洞真经》). In the third month of that spring, imperial officials delivered a sealed decree stating:
*"On the eighteenth day of this month, I shall humbly accept the scriptures."*

On that day, within the **Great Harmony Hall** (大同殿), he purified himself and prepared for the ritual. He then paid homage to the Master from afar as his **Degree Teacher** (度师), and the Emperor bestowed a single robe upon him to honor their teacher-student relationship. The title **Guāngjìng** (玄静) was bestowed upon the Master as a mark of distinction.

The Emperor further decreed that the **Scriptures of Mount Huáyáng** (华阳洞宫) be engraved upon stone as a memorial.

That summer, in the secluded place where he had previously cultivated the **Sacred Fungus** (芝), eighty-one stalks of **Lingzhí** (灵芝) emerged between pine and stone, their growth bountiful and strange. The Master, along with imperial officials, informed the **Immortal Sage** (灵仙) of this marvel, and the report was sealed and presented to the Emperor.

In the summer of that year, the Emperor also granted the Master two hundred households near **Zǐyáng Guān** (紫阳观), along with one hundred households each for **Tàipíng Guān** (太平观) and **Chóngyuán Guān** (崇元观). All were exempted from taxation to support the Master’s Daoist rites.

In the seventh month of that autumn, the Master was again summoned.
Upon arrival, he requested residence in a Daoist temple to tend to his illness.
In the spring of the ninth year, he declined the summons and returned to his old mountain.

That summer, in the sixth month, the place where the **Sacred Fungus** (芝) had previously sprouted again produced over three hundred stalks, resplendent and extraordinary—visible to none but him.
The Master documented this phenomenon and reported it to the Emperor.

That winter, the Master was summoned once more and housed in a separate hall at **Zǐyáng Guān** (紫阳观).
In the autumn of the tenth year, the Master again humbly declined, requesting retirement. The Emperor composed a farewell poem to honor him.

In the eleventh year of **Dàlì** (大历), the Master, at the Emperor’s decree, gathered with his disciples—including **Wéi Jǐngzhāo** (韦景昭)—at the **Zǐyáng Guān** (紫阳观) to establish a **fasting hall** (斋院) on **Gāng Shān** (冈山), a separate mountain. His resolve was sincere and solemn.

That night, a **sweet dew** (甘露) descended upon the **Daoist altar** (仙坛) and the surrounding forest. The Master reported this to the Emperor, who specially praised the marvel.

Initially, **Mr. Yǐnjū** (隐居先生) transmitted the *Three Caverns True Scriptures* (《三洞真经》) to **Master Shēngxiān** (升玄先生), who in turn passed them to **Master Tǐxiān** (体玄先生). **Master Tǐxiān** then entrusted them to **Master Zhèngyī** (正一先生), who finally transmitted them to the Master.

The Master was thus five generations removed from **Mr. Yǐnjū** (隐居先生), yet he fully inherited the **Great Dao’s True Teachings** (大正真法). Therefore, **Mount Máo** (茅山) became the ultimate source of Daoist learning for all under heaven.»

**Tài** (泰) once wandered in the **Dao** (道), now dares to recount its profound winds.

chunks.original_text: 於戏，是非可齐也，物我均焉，生死可忘也，觉梦同焉。 如此者，何域心於变化之际哉？ 先生以大历己酉岁冬十一月十有四日，遁化于紫阳之别院，春秋八十有七。 其十二月八日，门人赴丧而至者凡数千人，号奉冠乌，迁定于雷平山之西陲。 遗命以松棺、竹杖、木几、水瓶、香奁、香炉置於藏内。 门弟子等仰奉嘉猷，克遵俭德。 先生识思真淳，业行高古，道穷性命之本，学冠天人之际，所以优游句曲，郁为王者之师出入明庭，特宠肩舆之贵，是以顺风而问，昔称於黄帝，望山而请，今见於玄宗矣。 又博览草书，长於撰着。 尝以《本草》之#7书，精明药物，事关性命，难用因循，着《音义》两卷。 又以老庄《周易》为洁静之书，着《学记》、《义略》各三篇、《内学记》二篇，以续仙家之遗事，皆名实无遗，词旨该博。 初，先生幼年颇工篆籀，而隶书尤妙，客或赏之云：贤於其父。 因投笔不书。 玄宗诏山人王映强请先生楷书上经一十三纸，以补杨、许之阙。 先生能於阴阳术数之道，而不以艺业为能，极於转炼服食之事，而不以寿养为极，但冥怀素朴、妙味玄津，非夫博大之至人，孰能尽於此？ 真卿乾元二年，以升州刺史充浙江西节度，钦承至德，结慕玄微，遂专使致书茅山以抒诚恳。 先生特令韦炼师景昭复书，真卿恩眷绸缪，足励超然之 志。 然宗师可仰，望紫府而非遥，王事不遑，寄白云而攸远。 洎大历六年，真卿罢刺临川，旋舟建业，将宅心小岭，长庇高踪，而转刺昊兴，事乖夙愿。 徘徊郡邑，空怀尊道之心，瞻望林峦，永负借山之托。 而景昭洎郭闳等，以先生茂烈芳猷，愿铭金石，乃邀道士刘明素求托斯文。 真卿与先生门人中林子殷淑、遗名子韦渠牟尝接采真之游，绪闻含一之德，敢强名於巷党，曷足辩於鸿蒙。 其词日： 抱一混茫，人之纪纲。 先生以之，气王神强。 乃启玄旨，玄门以彰。 乃为帝师，帝道惟康。 甘露呈瑞，灵芝发祥。 上士云感，高风载扬。 鹤返仙庙，云辞帝乡。 退归而老，妙识行藏。 德本无累，道心有常。 皇日形解，孰与坐忘。 伐石表墓，勒名传芳。 谷变陵迁，厥迩弥光。 大历十二年夏五月建，渤海昊崇休镌。 华阳三洞景昭大法师碑 碑首篆题，旁刻萧史弄玉像。 朝识大夫检校国子司业兼御史中丞昊郡开国男陆长源撰。 朝议大夫检校尚书兵部郎中兼侍御史上柱国窦众书并篆额。 夫载宇宙，悬日月，提万象而首出者，其惟道乎。 夫通圣神、该品汇、冠百灵而独立者，其惟人乎。 道所以包浑元，经始万象者也，人所以禀纯粹，司会百灵者也。 故人因道而集祉，道因人而垂休，不宰之功，兆乎造物，无言之德，洽乎生民，萧散乎汗漫之问，冲融乎希夷之表，与天籁而吹万，并谷神而长存者矣。 紫阳真人大法师，讳景昭，字怀宝，本丹阳延陵人也。 其先系自颛顼大彭之后，在虞为陶唐氏，在夏为御龙氏，在商为豕韦氏，因国命氏。 芬馥蔓延，以至于裔孙孟。 孟为楚太傅，贤为汉丞相，昭入吴为侍中，昭兄慎为司空，法师即司空十六代孙也。 司空薨，葬于延陵，子孙因而家焉。 祖道会，父思戏，皆丘园养素，道高迹隐，载于列仙之籍。 留师方娠禀异，自幼表奇，孕元和之粹灵，体太玄之妙质，初以素书发迹，配度于延陵之寻仙观，后以丹台着称，隶居于长安之肃明观。

Ah, how the distinctions of right and wrong may be reconciled! The self and the world are one, and life and death may be forgotten—awake and dreaming are as one.

Thus, how could the mind be confined to the realm of change?

In the winter of the tenth month, on the fourteenth day of the *Jiǎyǒu* year of the *Dàlì* era (775 CE), the Master departed in seclusion at the separate retreat of Zìyáng (紫阳). He was eighty-seven years of age.

On the eighth day of the twelfth month, thousands of disciples arrived for his funeral, their mourning cries echoing like the *fèngguān* (奉冠乌) birds. His remains were interred at the western edge of Léipíng Shān (雷平山).

By his final decree, a pine coffin, bamboo staff, wooden table, water bottle, incense box, and incense burner were placed within the tomb. His disciples, revering his noble intentions, faithfully upheld his frugal virtue.

The Master’s thoughts were pure and sincere, his conduct ancient and refined. He penetrated the essence of life and vitality, his learning surpassing both humanity and the cosmos. Thus, he wandered freely in the Dao, esteemed as a sage by kings, honored with the privilege of riding in a palanquin, and summoned by imperial decree—once as the teacher of the Yellow Emperor, now as the guide of the Emperor Xuánzōng. He also mastered cursive script and excelled in composition, once remarking on the *Běn Cǎo* (本草) that its principles were vital to life and death, too profound for mere tradition, and thus compiled *Yīnyì* (音义) in two volumes.

He regarded the *Lǎozǐ*, *Zhuāngzǐ*, and *Zhōuyì* (周易) as texts of purity and stillness, writing *Xuéjì* (学记) and *Yìlüè* (义略), each in three sections, and *Nèixuéjì* (内学记) in two, continuing the legacy of the Daoist sages. His words were precise, his meaning vast.

In his youth, the Master was skilled in seal and clerical scripts, but his cursive was especially exquisite. A guest once praised it, saying, *"He surpasses his father."* Thereupon, he cast aside his brush and wrote no more.

Emperor Xuánzōng commanded the recluse Wáng Yìng to urgently request the Master’s calligraphic rendering of the *Thirteen Classics*, to fill the gaps left by Yáng and Xǔ.

Though the Master was adept in *yīnyáng* (阴阳) divination and alchemy, he did not consider these his greatest achievements. Though he mastered elixir refinement and longevity practices, he did not seek them as ultimate ends. Instead, he embraced the simplicity of the uncarved block (*sùpǔ*), savoring the subtleties of the Dao’s depths. Who but the most boundless sage could fully grasp this?

In the second year of *Jiānyuán* (760 CE), Zhèng Qīng (真卿), as Prefect of Shèngzhou and Military Governor of Zhejiang’s western circuit, revered the Emperor’s virtue and aspired to the mysteries of the Dao. He sent a special envoy to Máo Shān with a letter expressing his sincerity.

The Master had Wéi Liànshī (韦炼师) Jǐngzhāo (景昭) reply. Zhèng Qīng’s devotion was profound, inspiring his lofty aspirations. Yet though the Master was his revered teacher, the distance to the Celestial Bureaus was vast, and imperial duties kept him from lingering. He could only entrust his longing to the white clouds.

In the sixth year of *Dàlì* (771 CE), Zhèng Qīng was transferred from Línchuān to Hào Xīng, his hopes of retiring to Xiǎolǐng and honoring the Master’s legacy thwarted. Wandering through the prefectures, he carried only his reverence for the Dao, gazing at the forests in vain, forever bound by his unfulfilled vow.

Then, Jǐngzhāo and Guō Hóng (郭闳), moved by the Master’s virtuous legacy, sought to inscribe his deeds on stone. They invited the Daoist Liú Míngsù (刘明素) to draft the text.

Zhèng Qīng, who had once exchanged visits with the Master’s disciples—Zhōng Lín Zǐyīn (中林子殷淑) and Wéi Qú Móu (韦渠牟)—and heard of his transcendent virtue, dared not presume to rank himself among the common folk, let alone the primordial chaos. His inscription reads:

*"Embracing the One, boundless and mysterious—
The foundation of humanity.
The Master wielded *qi* like a king, his spirit unyielding.
He unveiled the Dao’s profound truths,
Illuminating the Gate of Mysteries.
Thus he became the Emperor’s teacher,
And the Dao flourished in peace.
Sweet dew descended as an omen,
Spiritual mushrooms sprouted as portents.
The noble respond in awe,
His lofty virtue spreads far.
The crane returns to the Celestial Hall,
The clouds depart from the Imperial City.
In retreat, he grows old,
His wisdom in action and stillness.
Virtue knows no burden,
The Dao’s heart is ever constant.
When the sun sets on the body,
Who compares to seated forgetfulness?
Carved stones mark his tomb,
His name forever fragrant.
Though valleys shift and mounds decay,
His light endures ever brighter."*

This stele was erected in the summer of the fifth month of *Dàlì*’s twelfth year (777 CE), inscribed by the *Bóhǎi* (渤海) master Hào Chóngxiū (昊崇休).

At its head, the seal inscription reads: *"Three Caverns of Zìyáng, Grand Master Jǐngzhāo’s Stele."* Flanking it are carvings of *Xiāo Shǐ* (萧史) and *Nòng Yù* (弄玉).

The inscription was composed by Lù Chángyuán (陆长源), then *Dàfū* (大夫), *Jiǎnshā* (检校) *Guózǐ Shìyè* (国子司业), and *Yùshì Zhōngchéng* (御史中丞), an *Kāiguó Nán* (开国男) of Hào Commandery (昊郡).

The calligraphy and seal were executed by Dòu Zhòng (窦众), then *Cháo Yì Dàfū* (朝议大夫), *Jiǎnshā Shàngshū Bīngbù Lángzhōng* (检校尚书兵部郎中), and *Shì Yù Zhōnggǔn* (侍御史上柱国).

*"He who governs the cosmos,
Suspends the sun and moon,
And first guides the myriad transformations—
This is none other than the Dao.

He who unites the sacred and divine,
Encompasses all categories,
And stands alone among the hundred spirits—
This is none other than humanity.

The Dao encompasses the undifferentiated origin,
Nurturing the myriad transformations.
Humanity embodies purity and completeness,
Harmonizing the hundred spirits.

Thus, humanity gathers blessings through the Dao,
And the Dao attains fulfillment through humanity.
The unspeakable function manifests in creation,
The silent virtue permeates all life.
Dissolving in boundless spontaneity,
Transcending the subtle and mysterious—
He blends with the celestial resonance,
Enduring alongside the valley’s spirit."*

**Zìyáng Zhēnrén Dàfāshī** (紫阳真人大法师), named **Jǐngzhāo** (景昭), with the courtesy name **Huáibǎo** (怀宝), was originally from Yánlíng (延陵), Dānyáng (丹阳).

His lineage traced back to **Zhuānxū Dà Pēng** (颛顼大彭), a descendant of the **Yú** dynasty as **Táotáng Shì** (陶唐氏), of the **Xià** as **Yùlóng Shì** (御龙氏), and of the **Shāng** as **Shǐwéi Shì** (豕韦氏), adopting the clan name from the state.

His virtuous lineage extended to his descendant **Mèng** (孟), who served as **Chǔ’s Grand Tutor** (楚太傅). His descendant **Xián** (贤) became **Han’s Chancellor** (汉丞相), and **Zhāo** (昭) entered **Wú** as **Shìzhōng** (侍中). His brother **Shèn** (慎) held the office of **Sīkōng** (司空). The Master was the sixteenth descendant of Sīkōng.

When Sīkōng passed away, he was buried in Yánlíng, and his descendants settled there. His ancestor **Dàohuì** (道会) and father **Sīxì** (思戏) both cultivated simplicity in seclusion, their virtue and reclusiveness recorded among the immortals.

The Master’s mother, **Liú Shīfāng** (留师方娠), conceived under auspicious signs. From infancy, he displayed extraordinary talent, embodying the essence of *yuánhé* (元和) and the subtlety of *tàixuān* (太玄). Initially, he gained recognition through his mastery of *sùshū* (素书), aligning with the *Xúnxiān Guàn* (寻仙观) in Yánlíng. Later, he became known as *Dāntái* (丹台), residing at the *Sùmíng Guàn* (肃明观) in Cháng’ān.

chunks.original_text: 属玄宗、广成问道，姑射颐神，放心於凝寂之场，垂拱於穆清之上，法师因得羽仪金录，颉顽玉绳，籍籍京师，垂二十载。 爰辞上国，思还故乡，重隶茅山之太平观。 天宝中，兴玄静先生奉诏修功德，造紫阳观，因而居焉。 遂於炼丹院传黄素之方，修斋醮之法，翔云瑞鹤，飞舞於坛场，甘露神芝，降生於庭院。 初，法师师事大法师包士荣，荣师事崇玄观道士包法整，整师事上士包方广，广师事华阳观道士王轨，轨师事升玄先生王远知，远知师事华阳隐居陶弘景。 自道源锡派，玄教传宗，玉堂银阙之人、羽盖毛旌之客，府无虚籍，代有其徒。 法师至行稽乎#8玄化，通识合于灵造，与其有也，万物不得而不有，与其无也，万物不得而不无。 得丧以春秋为死生，盈虚以天地为旦暮，云外虎头之佩，雪中鹤氅之裘，孩季通而抚子玄，师仇公而祖黄太，教戒示乎传授，服饵见乎延长，侍杖屦者，迩褊於江湖，传经录者，事同乎沬泗。 一居山观，三纪于兹，还神契乎时来，寂魄同乎物故，以贞元元年癸卯，委蜕于紫阳之道场，颜色怡悦，屈伸如常，春秋九十有二。 以其月己酉，迁神于雷平山之西原玄静先生寿宫之左。 传授苏州龙兴观道士皋洞虚，得冲虚之妙用，蹑上真之玄踪，梁市之客胥来，华阳之人问出矣。 道士韦崇询，主修斋醮祭，俯仰节度。 道士朱惠明，掌法录经书，修真秘诀。 法师上编仙录，旁契道枢，神含混元，德与纯粹，诱进草动，感通众灵，邈然非寰宇之问，超然在风尘之表。 至如身缠世故，迹混俗尘，发忠孝以饬躬，演信义而旌行，盖随时而不器，岂常道之可师与！ .浙江束西节度支度判官、检校尚书兵部郎中兼侍御史扶风窦公日：泉布武区中，栖心象外，与法师声同道濑，理契德源，追往想琴高之祠，传神着务光之传，见征副墨，用琢他山。 其词日： 惟道之大，提功混茫。

The Master, under the reign of **Xuánzōng** (玄宗) and **Guǎngchéng** (广成), sought the **Dao/Way** (道), savoring the **Divine Vitality** (神) of **Gūshè** (姑射). He let his mind rest in the realm of **congealed stillness** (凝寂), and his body repose beneath the **serene and pure heavens** (穆清). Thus, the Master attained the **feathered insignia and golden records** (羽仪金录), the **jade belt of the Precious Ones** (颉顽玉绳), and was renowned throughout the capital for two decades.

Then, he declined the imperial court, yearning to return to his native lands, and once more affiliated with the **Tàipíng Guàn** (太平观) of **Máoshān** (茅山). During the **Tiān Bǎo** (天宝) era, **Xīng Xuánjìng** (兴玄静) received an imperial decree to perform meritorious deeds, constructing the **Zǐyáng Guàn** (紫阳观), where the Master resided.

Thereafter, in the **Alchemy Hall** (炼丹院), he transmitted the **Yellow and White Elixir** (黄素) techniques and perfected the **fasting and sacrificial rites** (斋醮). Divine clouds and auspicious cranes soared above the altar, while **ambrosial dew and sacred fungi** (甘露神芝) descended into his courtyard.

Initially, the Master studied under the **Grand Master** (大法师) **Bāo Shìróng** (包士荣), who in turn had learned from **Bāo Fǎzhěng** (包法整), a **Daoist** (道士) of the **Chónghuán Guàn** (崇玄观). **Bāo Fǎzhěng** had been taught by **Bāo Fǎngguǎng** (包方广), a **Superior Adept** (上士), who had followed **Wáng Guǐ** (王轨), a **Daoist** of the **Huáyáng Guàn** (华阳观). **Wáng Guǐ** had been instructed by **Shēng Xuán** (升玄) **Wáng Yuǎnzhī** (王远知), and **Wáng Yuǎnzhī** in turn by the **Huáyáng Hermit** (华阳隐居) **Táo Hóngjǐng** (陶弘景).

From the **Source of the Dao** (道源), descending through successive generations, the **Wayist teachings** (玄教) flourished. Those of the **Jade Chamber** (玉堂) and **Silver Enclosure** (银阙), as well as disciples under **feathered banners and hairy insignia** (羽盖毛旌), left no vacancy in their ranks, each era producing its own successors.

The Master’s conduct was in harmony with the **transcendent transformations** (玄化), and his wisdom aligned with the **divine creation** (灵造). What he possessed, all things could not fail to possess; what he lacked, all things could not fail to lack. Life and death were measured by the seasons, while fullness and emptiness were observed like the dawn and dusk of the cosmos. His **cloud-pearl belt** (云外虎头之佩) and **snow-lotus crane-feather robe** (雪中鹤氅之裘) marked his refinement, while he nurtured his children with **Daoist simplicity** (玄) even as an infant. His lineage traced back to **Comrade Yú** (仇公) and **Ancestor Huáng Tài** (黄太), his teachings passed down through **transmission and instruction** (传授), and his **elixirs and prescriptions** (服饵) extended his lifespan.

Those who served him with **attendant staff and sandals** (侍杖屦) were drawn from the nearby **secluded regions of the Jiang-Hu** (江湖). Those who recorded his **scriptures and teachings** (经录) were akin to the **sages of the Mò Sì** (沬泗) era.

For three generations, he dwelled in the mountain halls. His **return to the divine** (还神) coincided with the passage of time, and his **silent spirit** (寂魄) mirrored the **cessation of all phenomena** (物故). In the **Chéngyuán** (贞元) year one, on the **Gǔmào** (癸卯) day, he **shed his mortal form** (委蜕) at the **Zǐyáng Daoist precinct** (紫阳之道场), his visage serene and his movements natural, at the age of ninety-two.

On the **Jǐyǒu** (己酉) day of that month, his **divine essence** (神) was relocated to the **left of the Mortuary Temple of Xuánjìng** (玄静先生寿宫) on the **western slope of Léipíngshān** (雷平山).

He transmitted his **Daoist arts** (道术) to **Sūzhōu** (苏州) **Lóngxīng Guàn** (龙兴观) **Daoist** **Gāo Dòngxū** (皋洞虚), who mastered the **marvelous techniques of Chōngxū** (冲虚) and followed the **mystical traces of Shàngzhēn** (上真). Thus, the **Way** spread among the **marketplaces of Liang** (梁市) and the **Huáyáng** (华阳) region.

The **Daoist** **Wéi Chóngxún** (韦崇询) oversaw the **fasting and sacrificial rites** (斋醮), maintaining strict **postures and rhythms** (俯仰节度).

The **Daoist** **Zhū Huìmíng** (朱惠明) managed the **scriptures and secret precepts** (法录经书), refining the **Daoist mysteries** (修真秘诀).

The Master compiled the **Register of the Immortals** (仙录), aligning with the **pivotal Daoist principles** (道枢). His **divine essence encompassed the Primordial Void** (神含混元), and his **virtue/power harmonized with the Pure and Undefiled** (德与纯粹). He **guided the uninitiated and communicated with spirits** (诱进草动，感通众灵), transcending the bounds of the world and rising above the **profane dust of life** (风尘).

Yet when he engaged with worldly affairs, his **Daoist essence mingled with the commonplace** (迹混俗尘), he **uphold loyalty and filial piety** (忠孝) to govern himself, and **demonstrated trustworthiness and righteousness** (信义) in his actions. His ways adapted to the times without conforming to any fixed **Daoist vessel** (器), for who could emulate his **constant Dao** (常道)?

**Zhèjiāng** (浙江) **Shùxī** (束西) **Nóngdù** (节度) **Zhǐdù** (支度) **Pàn Guān** (判官), **Chéngxiào** (检校) **Shàngshū** (尚书) **Bīngbù** (兵部) **Lángzhōng** (郎中) and **attendant censor** (兼侍御史) **Fǔfēng Dòu Gōng** (扶风窦公) remarked:

*"The Master’s **Daoist essence** (道) was vast, his **meritorious deeds** (功) blending with the **boundless void** (混茫). His **Daoist resonance** (声) harmonized with the **Daoist currents** (道濑), and his **principles** (理) aligned with the **Source of Virtue** (德源). We **honor the shrine of Qín Gāo** (琴高) and **preserve the transmission of Wù Guāng** (务光), his **words** like **sagely inscribed calligraphy** (征副墨), his **actions** refining **other mountains’ teachings** (用琢他山).*

His **words** were thus:

*"The Dao is supreme, its **meritorious deeds** (功) vast and boundless."*

The Master’s mother, **Liú Shīfāng** (留师方娠), conceived under auspicious signs. From infancy, he displayed extraordinary talent, embodying the essence of *yuánhé* (元和) and the subtlety of *tàixuān* (太玄). Initially, he gained recognition through his mastery of *sùshū* (素书), aligning with the *Xúnxiān Guàn* (寻仙观) in Yánlíng. Later, he became known as *Dāntái* (丹台), residing at the *Sùmíng Guàn* (肃明观) in Cháng’ān.

chunks.original_text: 惟人殆庶，与道回翔。 素韵凝寂，玄功灵长。 肇形无边，启迪逾光。 娇娇法师，锡羡华阳。 本族命世，在虞系唐。 御龙事夏，豕韦居商。 疑然灵表，自幼而彰。 理冠容成，质俾夏黄。 寻仙发迹，肃明始扬。 宵礼金殿，晨朝玉皇。 丹台道倡，白云帝乡。 楚山万里，故国丹阳，醮宫呜磬，斋室焚香。 芝生庭院，鹤舞坛场。 茅君秘洞，葛氏真方。 来时去顺，齐彭洎殇。 化鳞风袁，委蜕云酿。 峰峦逦逦，松桂苍苍。 尘生杖屦，苔染巾箱。 龙衔彩咤，虎缀盘囊。 闱风玄圃，瑶轩玉堂。 追存如在，颂德不忘。 孤石归然，万古连冈。 贞元三年，献春正月上元之辰建造。 太平观道士徐元沼、许长久、徐则，内行克修，外通儒学，许则宿推公干，虔奉真宗。 忠本元圣祖院碑贾练文 唐宝历二年，岁直丙午，浙右连帅、御史大夫赞皇公新建圣祖院于大茅峰下、崇元观之前，上直天华阳洞之南门，集草仙之灵庆，资圣寿於亿万。 本其经始，实感周先生出应昌运，为唐广成，荐瑞表祥，式旌不朽，於是恩锡院额，号日宝历崇元圣祖院。 玄门之盛，辉动岩谷。 时唐兴二百有九载，天子以神圣武文，惟新景命，德合乎五千文之玄训，明继乎十二圣之丕业，以清静源化理，以仁寿域生灵，陶之以太和，跻之於至顺。 故自临御大宝，则诏百辟，旁延万邦，推诚备礼、征访治道，寤寐孜孜，如恐不及。 夫明天子勤求于上，必贤邦伯感致于下，君臣一德，而道德可兴。 乃其年秋七月，公以天子之命，斋戒虔恳，果得周先生日：息元皇元精之全德，大道之宗师也。 先生葆真抱一，涵光吹万，天下聆其风者久矣。 而遐襟旷边，冥寄希夷，显晦自我，人莫能识。 夫玄珠非吃诟可索，至道惟精诚是致，故累圣所不能起，而一朝感契洪化，需然来思，且谓公曰：昔广成对理身之问，鸿蒙启养心之说，二者皇上大本也。 今息元亦将以斯道上报吾君。 公於是澄心清神，思所以庆皇休而赞景福，遂与先生图议，选置玄宇。 相彼形胜，莫灵此峰，昔梁朝福乡太子置道馆二，古坛废井，遗址犹在。 乃铲荒夷险，讲起层构，散俸钱以资其费，择干吏以董其役，单飞矢直，不日而成。 像设崇严，殿宇沉邃。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master’s **Dao** is nearly universal, yet he soars in harmony with the **Way**.

His **subtle resonance** (素韵) congeals in stillness, his **mysterious power** (玄功) eternally refined.
He **originates formless** (肇形) beyond all bounds, his **enlightenment** (启迪) surpassing even radiance.

The **venerable** (娇娇) Master of **Law** (法师), graced with **blessings** (锡羡) from **Huangyang** (华阳).
His **clan’s lineage** (本族) commands the age, tracing back to **Yu** (虞) and the **Tang** (唐).
He **tamed dragons** (御龙) for the **Xia** (夏), **dwelled among the Boar and the Wei** (豕韦居商).

His **divine aura** (疑然灵表) shone bright from youth.
His **principles** (理) surpassed **Rongcheng** (容成), his **nature** (质) matched **Xi Huang** (夏黄).

In **pursuit of immortals** (寻仙), his **trace** (发迹) began with **austerity** (肃明), then flourished.
He **paid homage at night** (宵礼) to the **Golden Hall** (金殿), **offered morning worship** (晨朝) to the **Jade Emperor** (玉皇).
His **Daoist gatherings** (丹台道倡) echoed in the **White Cloud Imperial Domain** (白云帝乡).

**Chu Mountain** (楚山) spans ten thousand **li**, his **native land** (故国) **Danyang** (丹阳).
The **temple bells** (醮宫呜磬) and **incense chambers** (斋室焚香) resound with sacred rites.
**Jade sprouts** (芝) in the courtyard, **cranes dance** (鹤舞) upon the **altars** (坛场).

The **Tea God’s hidden grotto** (茅君秘洞), **Bo’s authentic prescriptions** (葛氏真方).
His **coming and going** (来时去顺) follow **Peng and Zao** (齐彭洎殇).
He **transforms scales** (化鳞) in **Yuan’s wind** (风袁), **sheds his husk** (委蜕) in **Yan’s clouds** (云酿).

The **peaks stretch endlessly** (峰峦逦逦), **pines and cassia** (松桂) stand **ancient and verdant** (苍苍).
**Dust clings** (尘生) to his **staff and sandals** (杖屦), **moss stains** (苔染) his **hat and box** (巾箱).
**Dragons bear** (龙衔) his **auspicious banner** (彩咤), **tigers clasp** (虎缀) his **sacred pouch** (盘囊).

His **secluded halls** (闱风玄圃) and **jade-pillared pavilions** (瑶轩玉堂) hold eternal reverence.
We **cherish his memory as if he were still present** (追存如在), **ceaselessly extol his virtue** (颂德不忘).

A **lonely peak returns** (孤石归然), its **millions of layers** (万古连冈) standing firm.

In the **third year of Zhengyuan** (贞元三年), on the **first day of the first month** (正月上元之辰), its construction began.

The **Taipingguan Daoists** (太平观道士): **Xu Yuanze** (徐元沼), **Xu Ze** (徐则), and **Xu Changjiu** (许长久),
**Xu Ze** (许则) particularly renowned for his **public service** (公干),
all **devotedly upholding the True Dao** (虔奉真宗).
Their **words of loyalty** (忠本) were inscribed by **Jia Lianwen** (贾练文) on the **stele of the Saintly Ancestor’s Hall** (元圣祖院碑).

In the **second year of Baoli** (宝历二年), the **year of Bingwu** (丙午), the **linked commanders of the Zhe Right** (浙右连帅) and **Grand Censor** (御史大夫) **Zanhuang Gong** (赞皇公) rebuilt the **Saintly Ancestor’s Hall** (圣祖院) below **Damao Peak** (大茅峰),
before **Chongyuan Temple** (崇元观), and to the **south of Huangyang’s Celestial Cave** (天华阳洞之南门).
They **gathered the spirits of grass immortals** (集草仙之灵庆), **bestowing eternal blessings** (资圣寿於亿万).

The **foundation’s origin** (本其经始) was truly inspired by **Master Zhou** (周先生), who **responded to Changyun** (昌运) and became **Tang Guangcheng** (唐广成).
He **recommended the divine signs** (荐瑞表祥), **permanently honoring the immortal** (式旌不朽).
Thus, the **enlightened decree** (恩锡) bestowed the **hall’s name** (院额), calling it **Baoli Chongyuan Saintly Ancestor’s Hall** (宝历崇元圣祖院).

The **Daoist gates flourished** (玄门之盛), their **glory illuminating cliffs and valleys** (辉动岩谷).
At that time, the **Tang Dynasty** (唐) had **prospered for two hundred and nine years** (兴二百有九载).
The **Son of Heaven** (天子), with **divine might** (神圣) and **martial virtue** (武文),
**bestowed the new title** (新景命) upon him.
His **virtue aligned** (德合) with the **mysterious teachings** (玄训) of the **Five Thousand Characters** (五千文),
his **enlightenment continued** (明继) the **grand achievements** (丕业) of the **Twelve Saints** (十二圣).
He **drew from the Dao’s source** (清静源化理), **bestowed benevolent longevity** (仁寿域生灵),
**nurturing them in harmony** (陶之以太和), **elevating them to ultimate order** (跻之於至顺).

Thus, when he **ascended the throne** (临御大宝), he **commanded all officials** (诏百辟),
**extending his sincerity to all lands** (旁延万邦), **seeking the Dao of governance** (征访治道).
Day and night, he **diligently pursued virtue** (寤寐孜孜), as if **afraid of failing** (如恐不及).

For the **Son of Heaven** (明天子) to **strive for the Dao** (勤求于上),
the **worthy feudal lords** (贤邦伯) must **respond in kind** (感致于下).
When **sovereign and ministers share the same virtue** (君臣一德), then **Dao and virtue flourish** (而道德可兴).

That very year, in the **seventh month** (秋七月), the **Grand Censor** (公), following the **Son of Heaven’s command** (天子之命),
**fasted and purified himself** (斋戒虔恳), and **succeeded in receiving Master Zhou’s guidance** (果得周先生日):
*"The **息元皇** (息元皇) is the **completeness of the True Dao** (元精之全德), the **supreme teacher of the Dao** (大道之宗师).*
The **Master** (先生) **preserved his True Nature** (葆真抱一), **contained his radiance** (涵光吹万).
For ages, the **world has listened to his Daoist winds** (天下聆其风者久矣).
Yet his **spirit soared far** (遐襟旷边), **hidden in the boundless void** (冥寄希夷),
**revealing or concealing itself** (显晦自我), **none could truly recognize him** (人莫能识).

The **Dao’s mysteries** (玄珠) cannot be **grasped by vulgar words** (吃诟可索),
the **highest truth** (至道) can only be **attained through sincere devotion** (精诚是致).
Thus, even **successive sages** (累圣) could not **awaken him** (不能起),
yet in **one moment**, the **Son of Heaven’s harmony** (洪化) **inspired his resonance** (感契),
and he **came to ponder** (需然来思), saying to the **Grand Censor** (公):
*"In the past, **Guangcheng** (广成) **responded to the Dao’s principles** (对理身之问),
**Hongmeng** (鸿蒙) **opened the teachings of cultivation** (启养心之说).
Both are the **Son of Heaven’s supreme origins** (皇上大本).
Now, **息元** (息元) will also **ascend with this Dao** (以斯道上报吾君)."*

The **Grand Censor** (公) then **cleared his heart and refined his spirit** (澄心清神),
**pondering how to celebrate the **Son of Heaven’s blessings** (皇休) and **promote his prosperity** (赞景福).
He **consulted with Master Zhou** (遂与先生图议), **selecting a site for the Daoist hall** (选置玄宇).
Comparing **landscapes**, none surpassed this **peak’s divine essence** (形胜).
In **ancient Liang** (梁朝), the **Prince of Fuxiang** (福乡太子) established **two Daoist halls** (道馆二),
but the **old altar** (古坛) and **wells** (废井) remain, their **ruins still visible** (遗址犹在).

Thus, they **cleared wild growth and leveled rough terrain** (铲荒夷险),
**constructed tiered halls** (讲起层构),
**distributed their salaries** (散俸钱) to fund the work,
**selected capable officials** (择干吏) to oversee the labor,
**and completed it swiftly** (单飞矢直), **without delay** (不日而成).

The **images and altars** (像设) were **grand and solemn** (崇严),
the **halls and pavilions** (殿宇) **deep and majestic** (沉邃).

chunks.original_text: 神仙仪卫，左右森列。 并按旧史氏，得仲尼问礼，关尹请着书之象，咸备于前。 盖将会通仙而肃百灵，以永为国家斋醮之胜选也。 况三茅精气、二许馨烈，古来得道者，代有其人。 考传验图，若可攀揖。 而缭垣之内，有流泉嘉木，滋饰幽润，地灵境秀，触类增益，懋此成绩，与山无穷。 仰惟圣祖育德乎太极之前，显仁於未形之表，当是时也，合散消息，莫可名象，明而为日月，动而为风雷，播育而不测，运行而不殆，君得之豕韦，以挈天地，臣得之傅说，以相武丁，吾何为哉。 道本一贯，及夫神化挺生，含章炳灵，象帝之先，资我强名，将寄言以显玄枢，锡羡以兴皇业。 犹龙既见，万物方睹，是宜夫垂休储祉，长发其祥，亿万斯庆，集于宝历，此崇元新院所以得时而启也。 初，公以上方崇向道德之士，可以当是大选者，唯周先生一人而已。 故其招致之忠尽，访求之精实，则先生不得不出，而公之诚节不得不伸。 既而圣情感惬，万国瞻贺，其逢迎之优异，礼貌之严显，自古尊师重道之盛，无以加也。 则真宗玄极，至道之精，不得不洞契乎上心，播宣於至术，俾风流泽浸，广被八区，此先生所以出而不疑，亦所以示天下之不可不致如己者。 当吾君之至理，适吾道之可行，千载一期，起乃时耳。 蚓公以济代全材，合乎休明，树风南藩，绩最天下。 前岁兴建儒学，而天降膏露，显于庙庭，俗变风移，遂至於道。 今之辉崇真馆，阐奉玄化，上感睿旨，下孚元元，仁声顺气，流溢四境。 推是为政，大而伸之，则致君经国之用可见矣。 又况封部之内、融汰之下，褊识玄元之教，俱为煨场之人，顾难乎哉？ 炼谬列属城，获详事实，又尝以春秋属辞为学，故承命旧笔，直而不文。 其铭日： 圣运光启，山川效灵。 黄帝为君，起乃广成。 崆峒至言，今复行兮。 明明天子，以道致理。 方伯虔诚，先生戾止。 累圣莫致，今兹起兮。 玄感既宣，化流溥天。 公拜稽首，天子万年。 何以荐神，御玄元兮。 阙宇崇崇，圣祖尊容。 神而明之，神应丰隆。 华阳仙洞，大茅峰兮。 金榜瑶坛，仙卫真官。 羽节凌风，珠佩珊珊。 是醮是斋，百福延兮。 名从天锡，境占地久。 下荐臣忠，上资圣寿。 灵山万岁，绩不朽兮。 三圣记碑 有唐宝历二年，岁次丙午，八月庚戌，上清玄都大洞三景弟子、正议大夫、使持节润州诸军事、润州刺史、兼御史大夫、充浙西道都团练观察处置等使、上柱国、赞皇县开国男、食邑三百户、赐紫金鱼袋李德裕，上为九庙圣主，次为七世先灵，下为一切含识，於茅山崇元观南敬造老君殿院，及造老君、孔子、尹真人像三躯。 皆按史籍遗文，庶垂不朽。 谨记。

The **Daoist rituals and ceremonial guards** (神仙仪卫) stood in solemn array (左右森列).
They followed the **ancient rites of the Historians** (旧史氏),
retrieving **Confucius’ inquiries on ritual** (仲尼问礼) and the **symbols of Master Guan’s request for scripture** (关尹请着书之象),
all duly prepared before them (咸备于前).

They sought to **unify the Dao with the numinous** (会通仙) and **solemnly order the myriad spirits** (肃百灵),
thus **eternally establishing this site as the finest for state rituals and Daoist observances** (斋醮之胜选).
Moreover, the **refined qi of the Three Teachings** (三茅精气) and the **fragrant might of the Two Xu** (二许馨烈),
from antiquity to the present, have **yielded their Dao to worthy seekers** (得道者).
Upon examining the **ancient records and verified maps** (传验图),
one could **ascend to greet them** (攀揖).

Within the **enclosed courtyards** (缭垣之内),
there were **flowing springs and fine trees** (流泉嘉木),
**nurturing the land’s hidden luster and refined elegance** (滋饰幽润).
The **earth’s numinous essence and scenery’s grace** (地灵境秀),
when touched upon, **inspired ever-greater virtues** (触类增益).
Thus, they **labored to perfect this achievement** (懋此成绩),
**matching the mountain’s boundless splendor** (与山无穷).

In reverence, they **contemplate the Sage Ancestor** (圣祖),
who **nurtured virtue before the Great Ultimate** (育德乎太极之前),
and **manifested benevolence beyond form** (显仁於未形之表).
At that time, **unification and dispersion, concealment and revelation** (合散消息),
were **beyond mortal comprehension** (莫可名象).
Yet, **clarity became the sun and moon** (明而为日月),
**movement the winds and thunder** (动而为风雷).
**Propagation was limitless** (播育而不测),
**operation without cessation** (运行而不殆).
The **Lord obtained this as the Boar’s hide** (豕韦),
**to govern the heavens and earth** (挈天地),
while the **subject gained it as the sage Fu’s counsel** (傅说),
**to aid the King Wu Ding** (相武丁).
What then is my role? (吾何为哉)

The **Dao is a singular thread** (道本一贯),
yet when **spiritual transformations rise** (神化挺生),
**it contains the luminous chapters** (含章炳灵),
**mirroring the Emperor’s primal essence** (象帝之先).
Thus, they **lend me the name of strength** (资我强名),
**to proclaim the Dao’s hidden pivot** (寄言以显玄枢),
and **bestow blessings upon the Imperial lineage** (锡羡以兴皇业).

Like the **dragon appearing first** (龙既见),
**all things then take form** (万物方睹).
Hence, it is fitting that **rest and blessings descend** (垂休储祉),
**prolonging auspicious signs** (长发其祥).
**Ten thousand blessings converge** (亿万斯庆),
**gathered at this hall of宝历** (集于宝历),
**so this new hall of崇元 is opened in due time** (所以得时而启也).

Initially, the **Lord sought Daoist masters** (上方) who **revered the Way and its teachings** (崇向道德之士),
**worthy of this grand selection** (可以当是大选者).
Only **Master Zhou** (周先生) was deemed fit.
Thus, the **Lord’s sincerity and devotion** (忠尽) in summoning him,
and the **meticulous verification** (精实) in seeking the right teacher,
**compelled Master Zhou to emerge** (则先生不得不出),
while the **Lord’s integrity and solemnity shone forth** (公之诚节不得不伸).

When the **Imperial favor was met and satisfied** (圣情感惬),
**all nations gazed in celebration** (万国瞻贺),
the **Lord’s attentive reception** (逢迎之优异) and **grave reverence** (礼貌之严显)
exceeded even the **ancient traditions of honoring teachers and the Dao** (尊师重道之盛).
Thus, the **True Dao’s profound essence** (真宗玄极) and the **ultimate Way’s refined core** (至道之精)
**must resonate with the Lord’s highest intentions** (洞契乎上心),
**and be proclaimed through the most sacred arts** (播宣於至术),
so that **its influence permeates far and wide** (风流泽浸),
**benefiting all eight regions** (广被八区).
This is why **Master Zhou emerged without hesitation** (先生出而不疑),
**and why the world must emulate the Lord’s devotion** (亦所以示天下之不可不致如己者).

At this **juncture of the Lord’s ultimate wisdom** (至理),
**aligning with the Dao’s practicable path** (可行),
**a thousand-year opportunity arises** (千载一期),
**fulfilled in this very moment** (起乃时耳).

**The Lord, with his talents as vast as the Yellow River** (蚓公以济代全材),
**harmonizing with the bright and auspicious** (合乎休明),
**established the Way in the southern realm** (树风南藩),
**his deeds surpassing all under heaven** (绩最天下).
Last year, when **he undertook the construction of the Confucian school** (兴建儒学),
**the heavens showered blessings** (天降膏露),
**manifested in the temple courtyard** (显于庙庭).
**Customs transformed and winds shifted** (俗变风移),
**thus leading to the Dao’s flourishing** (遂至於道).

Now, **the hall’s splendor and the Dao’s revelation** (辉崇真馆, 阐奉玄化)
**resonate with the Lord’s enlightened decrees** (上感睿旨),
**and win the trust of all people** (下孚元元).
**Benevolence harmonizes with the flow of qi** (仁声顺气),
**spreading abundantly across the four boundaries** (流溢四境).

If **this governance is expanded and upheld** (推是为政),
**then the Lord’s use of the Dao to rule the land and nation becomes evident** (致君经国之用可见矣).
Again, **within the sealed domain** (封部之内) and **beneath the harmonious purges** (融汰之下),
**those with narrow understanding of the Dao’s origins** (褊识玄元之教)
are **all mere mortals** (煨场之人).
What then is the difficulty? (顾难乎哉)

**The Lord’s meticulous records of the city’s attributes** (炼谬列属城),
**gained through careful investigation** (获详事实),
**and his study of the Dao through the Spring and Autumn Annals’ style** (又尝以春秋属辞为学),
**thus, when assuming this charge, he wrote plainly yet profoundly** (故承命旧笔, 直而不文).

His **inscription reads**:

*"The Sage’s auspicious reign now shines** (圣运光启),
**mountains and rivers respond with numinous grace** (山川效灵).
**The Yellow Emperor as sovereign** (黄帝为君),
**gave rise to the Broad Success** (起乃广成).
**The sacred words of崆峒** (崆峒至言),
**now once more take form** (今复行兮).
**The bright and wise Son of Heaven** (明明天子),
**governs through the Dao’s harmony** (以道致理).
**The regional lord in pious sincerity** (方伯虔诚),
**Master Zhou stands firm** (先生戾止).
**Though past sages could not achieve this** (累圣莫致),
**now it rises anew** (今兹起兮).
**The Dao’s sacred influence is proclaimed** (玄感既宣),
**its transformations flow across the heavens** (化流溥天).
**The Lord bows in reverence** (公拜稽首),
**the Son of Heaven reigns eternally** (天子万年).

**How shall we offer this to the gods** (何以荐神),
**to honor the Dao’s primal essence** (御玄元兮)?
**The hall’s towering grandeur** (阙宇崇崇),
**the Sage Ancestor’s exalted presence** (圣祖尊容).
**Spiritual and luminous** (神而明之),
**the gods respond with abundant blessings** (神应丰隆).
**The Daoist grotto of华阳** (华阳仙洞),
**the Great Teachings’ peak of大茅** (大茅峰兮).
**The golden tablets and jade altars** (金榜瑶坛),
**the Dao’s true ceremonial guards** (仙卫真官).
**Feathers and jade adornments flutter in the wind** (羽节凌风, 珠佩珊珊).
**These are the rituals and fasts** (是醮是斋),
**invoking a hundred blessings** (百福延兮).
**Names are bestowed from heaven** (名从天锡),
**the site chosen by the earth’s enduring will** (境占地久).
**Below, the loyal subjects offer their reverence** (下荐臣忠),
**above, they bless the Sage’s eternal life** (上资圣寿).
**The numinous mountain endures for ten thousand years** (灵山万岁),
**its deeds never fade** (绩不朽兮).

**Inscription for the Three Sage Statues**:
In the **Tang era’s宝历 second year** (宝历二年), the **year of丙午** (岁次丙午),
on the **eighth month’s庚戌 day** (八月庚戌),
the **three disciples of the Upper Clarity Daoist Hall** (上清玄都大洞三景弟子),
**the Just and Proper Grand Officer** (正议大夫),
**the Commissioner with Military Authority over Runzhou** (使持节润州诸军事),
**the Governor of Runzhou** (润州刺史),
**the Grand Inspector, concurrently** (兼御史大夫),
**the Commissioner for the Defense and Inspection of the Zhexi Circuit** (充浙西道都团练观察处置等使),
**the Grand Duke** (上柱国),
**the Founding Male of赞皇 County** (赞皇县开国男),
**with an estate of three hundred households** (食邑三百户),
**and granted the Purple Gold Fish Bag** (赐紫金鱼袋) **Li Deyu** (李德裕),
**erected this hall in honor of the Daoist Sage Lao** (於茅山崇元观南敬造老君殿院),
**and carved statues of Lao, Confucius, and the True Person Master Yin** (及造老君、孔子、尹真人像三躯).
All were **modeled after ancient texts and preserved traditions** (皆按史籍遗文),
**to ensure their enduring legacy** (庶垂不朽).
**This inscription is recorded in reverence** (谨记).

Thus, they **cleared wild growth and leveled rough terrain** (铲荒夷险),
**constructed tiered halls** (讲起层构),
**distributed their salaries** (散俸钱) to fund the work,
