chunks.original_text: 孔子，按《史记》，孔子适周，将问礼於老子，老子日：子所言者，其人与骨皆已朽矣，独其言在耳。 且夫君子得时则驾，不得时则蓬累而行。 吾闻之，良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德容貌若愚。 去子之骄气与淫神，是皆无益於子之身。 吾所告子若是已。 孔子去，谓弟子日：乌，吾知其能飞； 鱼，吾知其能游； 兽，吾知其能走。 走者可为网，游者可为纶，飞者可为增。 至於龙，吾不知其乘风云而上天，吾今日见老子，其犹龙耶。 尹真人，按《史记》，老子居周久之，见周之衰，乃遁去至关。 关令尹喜日：子将隐矣，强为我着书。 於是老子乃着上下篇，言道德之意五千余言而去。 《列仙传》曰：关令尹喜者，周大夫也，善内学。 服星宿精华，隐德行仁，时人莫知也。 老子西游，喜先见其气，知真人过，物色而迎之，果得老子。 老子亦知其奇，为着书。 与老子俱之流沙之西，服巨胜实，莫知其所终。 唐石灯记 功德主崇元观上清三洞道士贺思宝，敬造长明灯台於宝殿内，永充供养。 宝历三年，岁直丁未，二月十五日丁未，奉记助造灯台三洞道士陈惠瑁记大匠乐安、蒋浑、男清磷镌。 齐建元劫立崇元馆，唐贞观劫号崇元观，宋大中祥符劝改崇寿观。 太元殿长明石灯，宝历三年丁未岁造，当是文宗太和元年，积四百九十八年。 是为大元泰定甲子上清弟子崇寿观主昊郡张嗣真重为刻治，着铭于石。 铭日： 华阳之天，流金之庭。

「Confucius, according to the *Records of the Grand Historian* (《史记》),
went to the Zhou capital and intended to ask about rites from Laozi.
Laozi said: "What you speak of, its person and bones are both already decayed,
only their words remain in the ears.
Moreover, a gentleman, when his time comes, rides in a carriage;
when his time does not come, he walks in rags.
I have heard that a skilled merchant conceals his goods as if they were nonexistent,
and a gentleman of great virtue and noble bearing appears as if he were foolish.
Abandon your proud *qi* and your licentious spirit—
these bring no benefit to your body.
What I have told you is this."

Confucius departed and said to his disciples:
"Ah, I know the crow can fly;
the fish, I know can swim;
the beast, I know can run.
The running can be ensnared in nets,
the swimming can be caught with lines,
the flying can be trapped with snares.
But as for the dragon,
I do not know if it rides the wind and clouds to ascend to heaven—
today, I have seen Laozi,
his *qi* is like that of a dragon, is it not?"

**Master Yin the True Person** (尹真人),
according to the *Records of the Grand Historian* (《史记》),
Laozi dwelled long in Zhou,
and seeing its decline, retreated to the Pass of Guanzhong.
The Governor of the Pass, Yin Xi (尹喜),
said: "Master, you are about to depart in seclusion,
yet you are strong—please write a book for me."
Thus Laozi wrote the *Dao De Jing* (《道德经》),
its upper and lower chapters,
with over five thousand words on the Way and virtue,
and then departed.

The *Biographies of Immortals* (《列仙传》) states:
Yin Xi, the Governor of the Pass,
was a Zhou Grand Officer (大夫),
skilled in internal learning (内学).
He consumed the essence of the starry hosts,
concealed his virtue and practiced benevolence,
so that people of his time knew nothing of him.
When Laozi journeyed westward,
Yin Xi first perceived his *qi*,
knew the True Person was passing by,
and sought him out, meeting him in person.
Laozi also recognized his singularity,
and wrote the book for him.
Together they went to the west of Liu Sha (流沙),
where Yin Xi consumed the *giant victory fruit* (巨胜实),
and none knew his ultimate fate.

In the Tang dynasty, the *Stone Lamp Record* (《石灯记》)
lists **Acupuncturist and Daoist Sage Hè Sībǎo** (贺思宝)
as the merit-maker (功德主)
who, in reverence, constructed the **Eternal Brightness Lamp Tower** (长明灯台)
within the **Treasure Hall** (宝殿),
to provide perpetual offerings.

In the **Baolì Era, Year Dingwù** (宝历三年丁未岁),
on the **15th day of the 2nd month, Dingwù** (二月十五日丁未),
the Daoist disciples of the **Upper Clarity Three Caverns** (上清三洞)
—**Chen Huìméi** (陈惠瑁)—
recorded the inscription,
and the artisans **Lè An** (乐安),
**Jiǎng Hún** (蒋浑),
and **Male Qīnglín** (男清磷) carved it.

In the **Qí Era** (齐建元劫),
the **Chóngyuán Pavilion** (崇元馆) was established;
in the **Zhēnguān Era** (唐贞观劫),
it was renamed the **Chóngyuán Hall** (崇元观);
in the **Song Era, Great Zhōngxiángfú** (宋大中祥符劫),
it was encouraged to change its name to the **Chóngshòu Hall** (崇寿观).

The **Eternal Brightness Stone Lamp** (长明石灯)
of the **Tàiyuán Hall** (太元殿)
was constructed in the **Baolì Era, Year Dingwù** (宝历三年丁未岁).
This corresponds to the **Tàihé Era of Emperor Wénzōng** (文宗太和元年),
a span of **four hundred ninety-eight years**.

In the **Great Yuan Era, Year Jiǎzǐ** (大元泰定甲子),
the **Chóngshòu Hall Master** (崇寿观主),
**Zhāng Suìzhēn of Hào Commandery** (昊郡张嗣真),
had this lamp restored and inscribed.

The inscription reads:

*"The Heaven of Huáyáng* (华阳之天),
*the Court of Flowing Gold* (流金之庭)."

chunks.original_text: 阴辉日精，昼夜洞明。 神灯灿灿，二景是法。 树此南便，板世小劫。 稽首司命，朝彻重玄。 度人度仙，若火之传。 茅山志卷之二十三竟 #1贞：后文作『正』，参见#6。 #2远思：笪本作『远望』。 #3闭：笪本作『闲（闲）』。 #4宏：原本作『弘』，据笪本改。 #5师仑：原本此处为空格，据竺本补。 #6正：前文作『贞』，参见#1。 #7之：原缺，据笪本补。 #8乎：原本作『於』，据笪本改。 茅山志卷之二十四 上清嗣宗师刘大彬造 录金石篇 唐碑

The radiance of yin shines bright as the sun’s essence,
illuminating day and night with boundless clarity.

The divine lamp gleams resplendent—
two luminous wonders, the law of light.

Planted here to the south, it stands eternal,
a beacon through the eons of the lesser kalpa.

With reverence, I bow to the Lord of Destiny,
piercing the depths of the Supreme Mysteries.

Guiding mortals and immortals alike,
its flame spreads like fire passed from hand to hand.

---
*Teachán Zhì* (茅山志), Volume Twenty-Three, concludes.

---
*Táng* stele recording the **Upper Clarity Successor Sect Master Liú Dàbīn** (上清嗣宗师刘大彬) construction,
from the *Record of Gold and Stone* (录金石篇).

Brightness Stone Lamp** (长明石灯)
of the **Tàiyuán Hall** (太元殿)
was constructed in the **Baolì Era, Year Dingwù** (宝历三年丁未岁).
This corresponds to the **Tàihé Era of Emperor Wénzōng** (文宗太和元年),
a span of **four hundred ninety-eight years**.

In the **Great Yuan Era, Year Jiǎzǐ** (大元泰定甲子),

The inscription reads:

*"The Heaven of Huáyáng* (华阳之天),
*the Court of Flowing Gold* (流金之庭)."

chunks.original_text: 唐道门威仪玄博大师贞素先生王君碑 朝议郎、守尚书祠部郎中、知制诰武骑尉、赐紫金鱼袋徐铉撰并篆额。 原夫至道之先，邈哉希矣，书契以降，可得而云。 黄帝、尧、舜澄其源，故垂衣恭己，在宥天下。 伯阳、仲尼道其用，故建言立德，宪，章无穷。 赤松、羡门神而明之，故轻举上宾，留侯、商皓变而通之，故解景灭迩。 顺是而下，莫不由之。 故有缙绅端委，利万物於庙堂之上； 葛巾蕙带，全阴功於尘埃之外。 隐显殊志，趣舍同归。 其人有终，其魄不死。 闱风玄圃，草帝之密都； 赤城华阳，仙圣之治所。 光灵肝蛮，若在左右，仁人君子，往往至焉，见之於贞素先生矣。 君讳栖霞，字玄隐，华宗继世，积德所钟。 生於齐，得泱泱之风； 长於鲁，习徇徇之教。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Stele of Master Wáng Jūn Chénsù, the Pure and Virtuous Sage of the Grand Daoist Tradition of the Táng**

Composed and inscribed by **Xú Xiāo** (徐铉), *Chéngyì Láng* (朝议郎), Overseer of the *Shàngshū Yìbù Lángzhōng* (守尚书祠部郎中), Keeper of the *Zhī Zhìguì* (知制诰), *Wǔqí Wèiwèi* (武骑尉), and granted the *Zìyǔ Jīndài* (紫金鱼袋).

---

The **Supreme Dao** (至道) first emerged—
how vast and rare it is! Since the invention of writing,
its traces may be discerned.

The **Yellow Emperor**, **Yáo**, and **Shùn** clarified its origins,
thus they wore simple robes and behaved with reverence,
governing the world in gentle harmony.

**Bóyáng** (伯阳) and **Zhòngní** (仲尼) expounded its applications,
thus they established teachings and cultivated **virtue/power** (德),
endless in their statutes and precepts.

**Chìsōng** (赤松) and **Xiànmén** (羡门) divinely illuminated its mysteries,
thus they ascended lightly as honored guests.
**Liú Lǐhòu** (留侯) and **Shāng Hào** (商皓) transformed and harmonized its ways,
thus they dispelled omens and extinguished near calamities.

Following this Dao downward through the ages,
none fail to adhere to it.

Thus there are **scholars and officials** (缙绅) of upright bearing,
benefiting all under the **regal halls** (庙堂).
And there are those in **rough hemp garments** (葛巾) and **fragrant sashes** (蕙带),
preserving **yin virtue/power** (阴功) beyond the dust of mortal life.

Though their aims differ—hidden or revealed—
their aspirations converge in the same end.

When their bodies perish,
their **qi-spirits** (魄) remain undying.
The **Enclosure of Winds** (闱风) and the **Mysterious Grove** (玄圃)
are the **secret cities** (密都) of the **Grass Sovereign** (草帝);
**Red City** (赤城) and **Hua Mountain** (华阳)
are the abodes of the **Immortal Saints** (仙圣).

The **radiant soul** (光灵) and **liver-snakes** (肝蛮) appear as if at their side—
**Noble Persons** (仁人) and **Principled Gentlemen** (君子)
often arrive there. In **Master Wáng Chénsù** (贞素先生),
we see this realized.

His given name was **Qīxiá** (栖霞), his courtesy name **Xuányǐn** (玄隐).
He inherited the **Hua Sect** (华宗), a gift of accumulated **virtue/power** (德).
Born in **Qí** (齐), he received its **vast and noble winds** (泱泱之风);
raised in **Lǔ** (鲁), he learned its **refined and harmonious teachings** (徇徇之教).

chunks.original_text: 七岁神童及第，十五博综经史，闽党童子，靡敢并行，束方诸侯，为之前席。 而仙才灵气禀於自然，尘缨世网，不可拘系。 每名山独往，神契感通，奇怪恍惚，众莫能测。 天佑丁卯岁，避乱南渡，至于寿春，感四海之分崩，想八公之遗迹，於是解巾名路，委质玄门。 问政先生聂君见而奇之，授以法线。 是日有彩云皓鹤，翔舞久之。 既而穷若士之遨游，得束卿之胜境。 道无不在，善岂常师，又从威仪邓君启遐受《大洞真经》，玄科秘旨，动以谘询。 福地仙源，因而栖托，诛茅穿径，枕石漱流。 身既隐而名愈彰，道己寂而节弥苦。 桑田自改，桂树长留。 烈祖孝高皇帝方在宾门，实来作镇。 紫黑表真人之应，青云符好道之占。 君鹄书被征，褐衣来见，谈天人之际，讲道德之源，靡劳牧马之迷，自契顺风之请。 因从敦礼，来止建康。 有玄真观者，陈宣帝为藏矜先生之所作也。 殿堂岑寂，水木清华，游焉息焉，以遂其好。 每竹宫望拜，玉牒秘词，叩寂求真，必君是赖，嘉祥灵应，世莫得闻。 圣历中一兴，恩礼殊重，赐金印紫绶，号玄博大师。 烈祖尝从容谓君日：吾不贪四海之富，惟以苍生为忧。 君对日：夫古圣人，修其身而后及天下，天下得一人安而后安。 今天子动劳万机，忘寝与食，身且不能自治，岂能治苍生哉？ 帝善其言，以百金为之寿。 其识度亮直，又如此焉。 今上嗣清静之基，尊玄默之化，谘课宾敬，有瑜於前，而君茅岭夙心，老而弥笃。 比年抗表，请归旧山，优诏惜之，又加贞素先生之号。 既而玉棺有命，紫素告期，葛洪见留，不成大药，少君舍去，先梦绣衣。 保大壬子岁夏四月甲寅，隐化于玄真观，春秋六十有二。 恩旨痛惜，赙钱二十万，道俗嗟慕，会葬数百人。 初，君之及茅山也，即良常洞之前，相雷平山之下，披榛蓊秽，面壑临流，除地为坛，表朝真之位，因丘设隧，卜安神之室。 至是归葬，符夙愿焉。 六月丙申，发自京师，沂淮而上。 时畿内久旱，川涂可揭，是日大雨洪注，腾波却流。 蓦长堤，瑜重堰，飘然利涉，人不知劳。 昔周君有乐水之朝，宣尼有泗水之应，校灵比德，其殆庶乎？ 君传法度人，数逾累百。 有若玄真观主朱怀德，名先入室，道极严师。 首座孙仲之，章表，大德刘德光，参受经法，预闻玄秘。 永怀在三之义，愿垂不朽之风。 威仪王可德、首座陈希声，并仰高山，共刊贞石。 铉也不佞，夙承教义，虽复仙凡异迩，静躁殊途，而诚以所感，素交斯在，徘徊祠宇，邈若山河，敬书岘首之悲，以伺辽城之叹。 其词日： 於铄子晋，上宾于天。 亦有胤孙，穷神体玄。 昔我来斯，世称其贤。 今我往矣，人谓之仙。 至道希夷，熟知其然？ 华阳洞府，句曲风姻。 林芳橘叶，地即芝田。 披文相质，亿万斯年。 文林郎守拾遗充集贤院直学士徐楷书。 银青光禄大夫行右千牛卫兵曹参军兼监察御史上柱国王文秉刻字。 茅山紫阳观碑铭并序 朝议郎守太子右谕德武骑射赐紫金鱼袋臣徐铉奉制撰，朝议郎守尚书虞部郎中武骑尉赐紫金鱼袋臣杨元鼎奉制书并篆额。 臣闻太初之气，其生也无始； 众妙之门，其本也无名。
chunks.translated_text:
「At seven years old, he was a prodigious child who passed the imperial examinations;
by fifteen, he mastered the breadth of Confucian and historical texts.
Among the Min scholars’ disciples and the young of the realm,
none dared walk beside him, and all bowed before his wisdom.
Even the feudal lords of the **Enclosure of Winds** (闱风)
yielded to his virtue and took their seats behind him.

Yet his **Daoist talent** (仙才) and **luminous qi** (灵气)
were bestowed by nature itself—
the entanglements of worldly affairs and the bonds of mortal existence
could not restrain him.

He often journeyed alone to the sacred mountains,
where his spirit resonated in harmony with the divine.
Strange and fleeting phenomena unfolded before him—
none could fathom their meaning.

In the year **Dīngmǎo** (丁卯), when Heaven’s favor was upon him,
he fled the chaos of war and crossed southward,
reaching **Shòuchūn** (寿春).
Witnessing the **fragmentation of the Four Seas** (四海之分崩),
he reflected upon the **Legacy of the Eight Immortals** (八公之遗迹),
and thus removed his scholar’s cap, took the name **Lù** (路),
and surrendered himself to the **Mysterious Dao** (玄门).

**Master Wénzhèng** (问政先生) **Plěi Jūn** (聂君)
beheld him and marveled at his presence,
bestowing upon him the **Law of the Thread** (法线).
On that very day, **rainbow clouds** (彩云) and **radiant cranes** (皓鹤)
hovered and danced in the sky for a long time.

Later, he explored the **wandering realm of the recluse** (若士之遨游)
and attained the **victorious domain of the Master of Bundles** (束卿之胜境).
The **Dao/Way** (道) is everywhere—
who would not seek its guidance?
He then followed **Master Wēiyí Dèng Jūn** (威仪邓君),
who opened his heart to distant teachings,
and received the *Great Cavern True Scripture* (《大洞真经》).
Its **profound and secret principles** (玄科秘旨)
were ever his source of consultation.

He took refuge in the **blessed Daoist land** (福地仙源),
clearing brush and hacking paths to dwell there,
resting on stones and washing with streams.
Though his body was hidden, his name grew ever more renowned;
though his **Dao/Way** (道) was silent, his conduct became all the more resolute.
The **mulberry fields** (桑田) changed, yet the **cinnamon trees** (桂树) endured.

His **fierce ancestor**, **Emperor Xiàogāo** (孝高皇帝),
still lingered in the **Guest Hall of the Spirits** (宾门),
truly arriving to preside over his legacy.

The **purple-black markings** (紫黑) signified the **True Person’s** (真人) response,
while the **blue-green clouds** (青云) bore the **auspicious omens** (占) of his devotion to the **Dao/Way** (道).

When the summons came in **Lù’s** (路) **scroll of jade** (鹄书),
he arrived in **humble attire** (褐衣),
discussing the **boundaries between Heaven and Man** (天人之际)
and expounding the **origins of virtue/power** (道德之源).
He rejected the **confusion of the herdsman’s labyrinth** (牧马之迷),
yet naturally aligned with the **request of the wind** (顺风之请).

He then followed **Dūnlǐ** (敦礼),
and settled in **Jiànkāng** (建康).
There was the **Play of the Mysterious and True** (玄真观),
built by **Emperor Xuānyǐn** (宣帝) of the **Chén** (陈) dynasty
for **Master Zhēnshèng** (矜先生).
Its halls stood solemn and still,
the waters and woods pure and refined.
He wandered there, found rest there,
and fulfilled his passion.

Each time he visited the **Bamboo Palace** (竹宫),
he sought the **secret words of jade** (玉牒秘词),
knocking at the silent gates to seek truth,
and always found his reliance in this **Master** (君).
The **auspicious signs of good fortune** (嘉祥灵应)
were heard by none but him.

During the reign of **Emperor Shènglì** (圣历),
his favor and respect were uniquely profound.
He was granted a **gold seal and purple ribbon** (金印紫绶),
and named **Grandmaster Xuánbó** (玄博大师).
The **fierce ancestor** (烈祖) once spoke to him leisurely,
saying: *"I do not covet the wealth of the Four Seas,
but only worry for the common people."*

He replied: *"The ancient **Saints** (圣人),
first cultivated their own **virtue/power** (德),
and then extended their care to the world.
When the world finds one **Virtuous Person** (得一人),
it is then at peace.

Today, the **Son of Heaven** (今天子) toils over myriad affairs,
forgetting sleep and food,
yet cannot even govern his own body—
how could he govern the common people?"*

The **Emperor** (帝) praised his words,
and offered him a hundred **jīn** (金) as a gift.
His wisdom and discernment were as bright and direct as this.

The present **Emperor** (今上) inherited the foundation of **tranquility and stillness** (清静之基),
and honored the **transformation of the Mysterious and Silent** (玄默之化).
He consulted and revered his guests,
and **Master Lù** (路) in his **Tea Mountain** (茅岭) heart
grew only more steadfast with age.

In recent years, he submitted petitions,
requesting to return to his ancestral mountain.
The **Emperor’s** gracious edict lamented his departure,
and further bestowed upon him the title **Master Zhēnsù** (贞素先生).

Yet when his **jade coffin** (玉棺) was decreed,
and the **purple and white robes** (紫素) announced their time,
**Master Géhóng** (葛洪) came to bid farewell,
but could not prepare the **Great Elixir** (大药).
**Young Master Shǎo** (少君) left him,
having first dreamed of a **silk-clad figure** (绣衣).

On the **fourth month**, **jǐnyǐzǐ** (壬子) year,
**summer’s** **jǐyīn** (甲寅) day,
he ascended to **hidden transformation** (隐化) at the **Play of the Mysterious and True** (玄真观),
having lived to the age of sixty-two.

The **Emperor’s** decrees lamented his loss,
granting him **twenty thousand in funeral funds** (赙钱二十万).
Both **Daoists** (道) and **laymen** (俗) mourned his passing,
with hundreds gathering for his funeral rites.

Initially, when he came to **Tea Mountain** (茅山),
he stood before **Goodly Constant Cavern** (良常洞),
beneath **Rǎipíng Hill** (雷平山).
He cleared the thickets and wild growth,
facing the ravines and standing by the streams,
clearing the ground to build an altar,
and marking the **position of the Celestial Worthies** (朝真之位).
He shaped the hill into a **tunnel** (隧),
and divined the **chamber for the spirit’s repose** (安神之室).

Now, in his return to burial,
his wishes were fulfilled.

On the **sixth month**, **wǔshēn** (丙申) day,
his remains departed from the capital,
ascending along the **Zī and Huái rivers** (沂淮).
At that time, the **central lands** (畿内) suffered from prolonged drought,
the riverbeds exposed and dry.
Yet on that very day, **great rains poured down** (大雨洪注),
waves surging back toward their source.
The **long embankments** (长堤) were submerged,
the **heavy dams** (重堰) overflowed,
and he crossed effortlessly,
as if borne by the wind—
no one knew of his labor.

In ancient times, **Zhōu Jūn** (周君) had the **auspicious water of his reign** (乐水之朝),
and **Prophet Xiān** (宣尼) the **responses of the Sī River** (泗水之应).
Comparing their **spirits** (灵) to his **virtue/power** (德),
their cases were perhaps similar?

**Master Lù** (路) transmitted the **Daoist precepts** (法度) to many,
numbering over a hundred.

Among them was **Jū Huáidé** (朱怀德), the **Master of the Play of the Mysterious and True** (玄真观主),
who was the first to enter his **inner chamber** (室),
his **Dao/Way** (道) taught with the utmost severity.

**Chief Disciple Sūn Zhòngzhī** (首座孙仲之),
**Chapter Master Zhāngbiǎo** (章表),
and **Great Virtue Master Liú Déguāng** (大德刘德光)
all received the **scriptures and precepts** (经法),
and participated in the **hearing of profound secrets** (预闻玄秘).

They cherished the **Threefold Harmony** (三之义),
and wished to perpetuate his **unfading influence** (垂不朽之风).

**Master Wēiyí** (威仪) **Wáng Kědé** (王可德)
and **Chief Disciple Chén Xīshēng** (首座陈希声)
both looked up to the **high peaks** (高山),
and together carved the **chaste stone** (贞石).

Though I am unworthy,
I have long upheld his teachings.
Though **Daoists** (仙) and **mortals** (凡) differ in their paths,
and **stillness** (静) and **agitation** (躁) diverge in their ways,
yet my sincere devotion to what I have witnessed
and our **lifelong bond** (素交) remain unchanged.
I linger at his shrine,
as vast as the mountains and rivers,
respectfully recording my sorrow at the **cliff’s edge** (岘首),
to await the lament of **Liáochéng** (辽城).

My words declare:
*"In the reign of **Zǐjìn** (铄子),
I was a guest of Heaven.
I also had descendants,
who exhausted the **mysteries of the spirit** (穷神体玄).

When I first came here,
the world called me **Virtuous** (贤).
Now that I depart,
they name me **Immortal** (仙).

The **Supreme Dao/Way** (至道) is rare and lofty—
who truly understands its nature?
The **Hua Sect’s** **Cavern Abode** (华阳洞府),
where the **sentient winds of Jǔqū** (句曲风姻) gather,
the **fragrant groves of Tea Mountain** (林芳橘叶),
the **land of jade-like herbs** (地即芝田).

I have **discarded worldly texts** (披文) and **returned to essential truth** (相质),
for countless ages.
**Lǎng Wénlín** (文林郎) **Xú Kuài** (徐楷),
**Scholar of Lost Treasures** (守拾遗),
**Senior Scholar at the Palace of Accomplished Worthies** (充集贤院直学士),
and **Kèguì** (刻字) **Wáng Wénbǐng** (王文秉),
**Count of the Right Division of the Royal Guards** (行右千牛卫兵曹参军),
**Censor-in-Chief** (兼监察御史),
**King of the Upper Pillar** (上柱国王),
both inscribed the **stele of Tea Mountain’s Purple Yang Palace** (茅山紫阳观碑铭并序).

**Xú Kuàng** (徐铉),
**Counselor of State** (朝议郎),
**Attendant of the Prince’s Right** (守太子右谕),
**Master of Rites and Archery** (武骑射),
**Holder of the Purple Fish Bag** (赐紫金鱼袋),
and **Yáng Yuāndīng** (杨元鼎),
**Counselor of State** (朝议郎),
**Attendant of the Prince’s Right** (守尚书虞部郎中),
**Master of Rites and Archery** (武骑尉),
**Holder of the Purple Fish Bag** (赐紫金鱼袋),
both inscribed and engraved the **stele’s title** (并序并篆额).

I have heard that the **primordial qi** (太初之气)
has no beginning in its generation;
the **gateway to myriad marvels** (众妙之门)
has no name in its origin.»

returns hearing to silence,

「The **Lingzhi in Dragon’s Clay** was reverently presented in succession—commoners and nobles alike, how could they do less than honor the **Count of Bright Clarity**, the **forbidden groves of Firewood and Mulberry**, or the **Tomb of the Willow’s Shadow**? Since then, each age has seen its reverence renewed: eminent scholars and sages, ever casting off their old selves. **Cloud Pavilions and Feathered Canopies** often descended with divine grace, their deeds inscribed on **gold and stone**, their legends passed through song and verse.

Alas! The four ages have cycled, as **Heaven’s Dao** fills and empties. Though the **Nine Breaths of Qi** endure eterniously, spanning **kalpas** to nourish their harmony, the **Three Stages of Manifestation** follow time’s shifts, revealing their brilliance or obscurity—this pattern will rise and fall with the **worldly fortunes**, ascending or descending alongside the **imperial destiny**.

When **Red Clarity** had yet to dawn, there lingered still the sorrow of **idle halls**; but now **White Water** flourishes, granting the blessings of **highborn prosperity**. The **Emperor Gaozong**, like a **dragon bearing virtue**, planted his **meritorious shade**—he responded to the **unusual omens of the pivoting realm**, mirroring **Zhongtian’s** wondrous signs.

At **Ganpan**, he cultivated harmony in the **first year of the sixty-second cycle**; the **cook-officials** were appointed, and their merit shone in the **third month of the ninth year**; the **guest-halls** received counselors, and great transformations arose in his time. His **crimson arrows and Lu bows** were justly revered by all under **Heaven**.

Thus, he followed the **Way of Yao’s Mandate**, revived the **Xia’s Middle Prosperity**, and mended the **unfulfilled regions of the West and North**, aligning with the **southern kingly Qi**. He presided over the **Bright Hall**, greeting the **Grass Sovereign**, and gathered the **auspicious jade**, meeting with the **feudal lords**.

Having achieved stability and success, he grew ever more profound in his concerns. He rode in **chariots of the swift and the decayed**, not deeming the **yellow-roofed halls** as supreme; he ate lightly and wore coarse garments, his thoughts ever for the **people’s welfare**. He knew the **effortless perfection** of the **Dao** without failure, embodying the **highest virtue’s** non-virtue—his spirit focused on **Gushu Island**, upright and serene, his governance flowing naturally, his actions responding as needed. He cherished the people and upheld the law, revering roots and instructing farmers.

He laid aside arms and disbanded soldiers, heeding the warning that **good defense must guard against the dangers of war**; he kept his palace humble and his meals simple, fearing reproach for indulging in **popular desires**. Thus, he earned the **effects of myriad treasures**, the **three celestial luminaries** offering blessings—his influence reached far, his peace near. His achievements surpassed those of **King Shao Kang’s** radiant might, and his **true vision** outshone **Emperor Kaizong’s** founding deeds.

Now the **current sovereign**, inheriting the **accumulated virtue** of his ancestors, follows the **natural Way**—to embody **effortless transformation** is **sainthood**, to wield **might without slaughter** is **benevolence**. He delves into **profound and subtle teachings**, upholding **modest brilliance** while embracing **unfathomable application**; he reveals the **hidden and obscure**, embodying **great capacity** to encompass the **boundless**.

When he acts, he shields the people; he does not boast of deeds but values **wisdom**; in stillness, he refines governance, ever practicing **frugality** to encourage **sharing**. He hears of good as if struck by fear, always scrutinizing the **finest details of autumn hairs**; his **radiant bearing** shines forth, yet he never deviates from the **tiniest of righteous paths**. His **transformations permeate**, as **winds follow**, and his **harmony spreads**, enriching the **customs of the age**.」

The realm is the **mightiest ancestor’s** domain, its **constitutional model** the **ascendant’s** edicts.
Enduring blessings stretch without end, boundless reverence forever held—
**Ancestral halls** and **clan temples** cannot fully express devotion,
**Sacrificial music** and **ritual song** fall short of true homage.

In **heavenly splendor**, we trace the **Celestial Chariot’s** path,
And in **severe inquiry**, we seek the **Palace of the Dao**.
There we meet the **Immortal of Chang’an’s** lofty grace,
Where **Dragon’s Well** stirs sacred inspiration—
We chant the **people’s hymns of birth**,
And ponder the **great work of pacifying chaos**,
Then turn to **Spirit Rock’s** sacred heights,
And issue **radiant decrees** to proclaim:
*"Summon the **Pei-Heng officials**,
Gather the **craftsmen of Ban’er**,
Let **artisans race with swift steeds**,
And **refined materials** reach their peak."*

From **Su-yuan’s granaries**, let **Gong-duan’s** tribute be supplied,
And from **Northern Yu’s** earth, **Qiu-man’s** labor be drawn.

Then the **Secret Hall** was renewed—
Its grandeur vast, its **misty vapors** dark,
Its **domed ceilings** towering, its **mutual beams** interlaced with **crystal brilliance**,
While **pearl nets** weave in **dim recesses**,
**Thunderous echoes** drip like rain,
And **rainbow hues** glide along the **eaves’ curves**.
Sudden shadows yield to light,
And fleeting **crimson clouds** swirl with **billowing mists**.

Majestic as the **Celestial Sovereign’s** presence,
Serene as the **Supreme Uncarved’s** bearing—
It seems the **Dao-qi ascends** in boundless flight,
And **lofty clouds** dissolve into distant gaze.

Then the **High Gate** was erected—
Its **gatehouse grand**, its **golden thresholds** gleaming,
**Dragon motifs** and **wind-inscribed seals** inscribed upon its beams,
**Rainbow banners** and **crimson flags** marking its comings and goings.

Two **processional halls** were built, their **layers deep and winding**,
And **tiered pavilions** rose, their **heights vast and open**—
Stretching north to **Guo-Gan’s** paths,
And south to **Jiang-Ba’s** thoroughfares.
**Resplendent light** illuminates the **earth’s expanse**,
And **vibrant hues** adorn the **wilds**.

Swift as **divine motion**, wondrous as **transformative craft**—
When the sun nears the **stars’ return** and the year draws near its close,
When **paeony blossoms** drift upon the **pond’s surface**,
And **spring’s warmth** begins to rise,
When **Red City’s** cranes take flight at dawn,
And **White Geese** gather for morning court—
The **capital’s folk**, men and women alike,
Raise their sleeves as **curtains of mist**,
And share in the **sacred wind’s** harmony,
Gazing upward at the **cloud-built halls**,
Only then do they grasp the **Sovereign’s might**.

How could it be merely a **century’s awe**?
Only **Yellow Emperor’s** terrace compares—
**Three lifespans** as companions,
Enduring **Jiang-Suo’s** temple’s silence,
Oh, **grandeur supreme**—words fail to name it!

**Mystery’s root** is **utter void**, yet **renown endures immortal**—
It **transcends divine insight**, revealing **hidden, luminous truths**,
And **establishes the Dao’s worth**, restoring **primordial simplicity**.
Its blessings bring **wealth and longevity** to the people,
Its **music** becomes **harmonious verse**,
Its **records** enter the **histories’ annals**,
Its **inscriptions** grace **monumental stones**—
Its **radiant virtue** shines eternal, here and now.

Thus the **lowly subject** was commanded:
*"With reverence, record the **august virtue**."*

The words proclaim:
*"Lofty is the **Dao’s path**, vast the **mystic gate**—
Empty yet ever-present, like threads without end.
From it arise **clarity and turbidity**,
And **heaven and earth** take form.
It gives birth to the **people**, and **kings arise**.
**Virtue’s splendor** shines as **imperial**,
**Achievements** soar to **divine** heights.
At **Kongtong’s peaks**, the **Dao** is sought,
And from **Red Waters**, the **pearls** are drawn.
Some say it **exists**, others call it **ultimate truth**.
The **Three Calendars** cycle anew,
And **grand designs** begin anew.
Ah, the **foundation’s mandate**—
**Resplendent is the **Tang’s** glory!
**Rebirth’s work** is launched, **heaven’s blessings** descend in abundance.
**Mysterious virtue** ascends to **heaven’s ear**,
And **longevity’s** **radiance** shines eternal.
Riding **white clouds**, he reaches the **imperial realm**,
Where **serene successors** reign,
And **mighty warriors** stand below.
**Rites match heaven’s grandeur**,
**Teachings honor the ancestors**.
**Clarified wisdom** reveals all thoughts,
**Bright as day**, as if seen.
With **reverence**, we await the **Immortal’s** return,
And **solemnly** prepare the **court’s halls**.

Where lie these **halls**? On **Jiu-Jin’s** ridge—
**Crimson clouds** glow at dusk,
**White mists** gather at dawn.
**Four-tiered roofs** rise in splendor,
**Nine-layered towers** pierce the sky.
**Clouds** swirl in **hidden valleys**,
**Sunlight** gleams on **jagged peaks**.
**Three peaks** shade the **paths**,
**Five ridges** divide the **trails**.
**Cinnabar sands** flow like liquid,
**Dark isles** stand firm.
**Willow groves** weave their bonds,
And **Thunder Pools** spill their mirrors.
Like **Nine Hua’s** phantom peaks,
Or **Seven Echoes’** faint traces—
**Sincerity moves mountains**,
And **responses come swift**.
**True men** ascend in **pure grace**,
**Leisurely and refined**,
Their **wheels** turn in fleeting haste,
Their **morning canopies** drift in **wandering flight**.
**Common folk** gaze upward in awe,
While **scholars** ponder the **lofty halls**.

In days of old, **sages spoke**,
And **laid down their teachings**—
**Compassion saved all things**,
**Filial piety** honored the **ancestors**.
With **reverence**, they followed the **True Contract**,
And **heard the Great Dao’s** voice.
They **manifested mystery** in **words and symbols**,
And **stirred the pure wind** among the **ten thousand households**.
They **offered unadulterated silk** to the **boundless**,
And **looked upward** to the **Sovereign’s** **grand designs**.

**Established in the twelfth month, the year Jiwei (60th year of the cycle).**

**Reinstating the Mountain’s Taboo**
**Xu Xian’s** inscription:

**Hua-Yang’s** **Cavernous Dao-Heaven**, **Jinling’s** **auspicious earth**—
Where **drought-alleviating immortals** gather,
And **auspicious blessings** take root—
Thus its **altars and halls** surpass all,
Its **offerings** are most **sacred and frequent**,
And its **forbidden groves** shield the **mountain’s purity**—
All this has stood since ancient times.

In the **Sacred History’s** decline,
**Officials neglected their duties**,
And the **places of worship** fell into **wild disarray**.
When **true spirits** hover and **divine feasts** are held,
**Restoration** must come through **uncommon men**.

In the **year Ding-Chou**, **Master Zheng-Su Wang Xi** of **Qing-Xia**
First came to this mountain,
**Reverently** upholding the **ancestral laws**,
**Pacing the sacred grounds**,
**Resting at Zhu-Yang’s** slopes,
**Ever mindful** of the **old ways**,
**Determined** to restore them.

The **Master’s** **hidden virtue** shone within,
And his **auspicious signs** harmonized without—
**Scholars and sages** aligned with him,
Their **Dao-resonance** in **silent accord**.
All **white silk offerings** and **sincere tributes**
Were dedicated to the **mountain’s gate**,
To fulfill his **long-held vow**.

Thus, from **Liang-Chang’s** **Cave** to **Lei-Ping’s** **Mountain**—
Ten *li* distant—
All **common folk** enslaved there were **redeemed**.
**Firewood and grass** could not be **plucked at will**,
And **graves and villages** were **separated**.
**Artisans’ trees** shaded the **wilds**,
**Pine groves** marked the **entrances**,
**Rivers and bridges** were **cleared**,
And **briers and weeds** were **pruned away**.

A **square altar** was built atop **Lei-Ping’s** peak,
And a **high pavilion** constructed before **Liang-Chang’s** **Cave**—
For **morning rites** of **sincere devotion**,
And **leisurely stays** where **chariots** are **taxed**.

**Jiang-Ba’s** **ancient paths** and **Qin-Wang’s** **old seals**
Now stand **solemn and bright**,
Restored to the **glory of Kaiyuan and Tianbao’s** days.

chunks.original_text: 先是紫阳之右有灵宝院焉，真台故基，鞠为茂草。 先生婵罄资用，克构殿堂，有开必先，无远弗届。 都督武陵康王奉钱百万，梁王造殿一区，向道之徒，咸助厥事，曾未周岁，惟新旧宫，皆先生之力也。 昔大限致襄城之驾、庚桑化喂场之人，是知道心唯微，其应如响。 时则有若道士经若虚，协规同志，是摄是赞，干事以恪，感物以诚，绩用不愆，斯实尤赖。 先生以保大壬子岁夏四月，悉书夫屋室之数、疆畔所经，请命于京师，申禁于郡县，以授茅山都监邓君栖一。 能事既毕，数日而化。 期命玄应，昧者不知。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Wuzhuang Temple** stood to the right of **Zisun**,
Its ancient foundations lost beneath thick grass.
The Master, though impoverished, gathered his resources,
And built halls and chambers—
Wherever there was need, he reached first,
No distance too great to span.

The **Duke of Wuling**, **Kang Wang**, offered a million coins,
And **Liang Wang** constructed a pavilion block.
All who followed the **Dao** contributed their efforts,
And before a year had passed,
Both the old and new halls—
All were the Master’s work.

In days of old, **Da Xian** summoned the **Shuangcheng** carriage,
And **Gengsang** transformed the **Weichang** folk—
This was because the **Dao** resides in the mind,
Its response swift as an echo.

Then there was **Daoshi Jing Xu**, who aligned his plans with the Master’s intent,
Assisting and supporting him in all matters,
Diligent in his duties, sincere in his responses,
His contributions never lacking—
This was truly his greatest merit.

In the summer of the **Baodà** era’s **Renzi year** (fourth month),
The Master recorded the number of halls and chambers,
The boundaries and paths they traversed,
And petitioned the capital,
Issuing decrees to the prefectures and counties,
Entrusting the task to **Deng Qiyong**, the **Du Inspector of Maoshan**.

When all was complete,
He ascended in just a few days.
His **mandate** fulfilled, his **response** divine—
The unenlightened knew not of it.

chunks.original_text: 夫仙阶感召，一讽非一揆，若乃神清气灵，骨录标映，受之於天也； 心虚器冲，玄德充蔚，基之於性也； 昭真垂教，启焕灵迩，行之於勤也。 故策名紫素，飞步黄庭，流功储庆，必相参合。 然则先生之道，其殆庶乎？ 虽飕驾不留，冥升日远，而高风可述，遗范在人，进而纪之，翰墨之职也。 邓君企慕前躅，见托直书。 己未岁秋八月日记。 上清真人许长史丹井铭碑 徐铉文并书。 长史含道，栖神、九天，人非邑改，丹井存焉。 射兹谷驸，洌彼寒泉。 分甘玉液，流润芝田。 我来自西，寻真紫阳，若爱召#13树，如升鲁堂。 敬刊翠谈，永识银床，噫嗟后学，抱此余光。 灵宝院记 赐紫道士王栖霞撰，昊诸道副都统镇海军节度使检校太尉守中书令东海徐公重建。 粤灵宝者，空洞赤书之秘号也。 讲勃自然，生天地先，运无为德，被有为作，是以太上立德，其次立功。 德者乾坤之大生，功者生三中利益也。 苟德以润身，功能济物，即示轻举，如蹑归径，革喧嚣於蜕脱耳。 且校籍所载，真迹所存，有非常人，立非常功，遂历古今，芳猷不绝。 茅束卿棣萼，以直道仕，恺悌立身。 周物者智，乐静者仁，云党咸阳，初依恒岳，寻栖此山，介然掩躁，克奉玄寂，陶然若朴，惟德动天。 遽绣衣持九锡之丈，芝盖导三清之路，玄鹄下盘，感应无昧，斯积业夙习之感哉。 缅惟异代同途，继踵美迹者，谅我公矣。 公以践履德业，游泳忠信； 松高韵远，玉真芒寒； 景钟麟史，堂构袭迹； 风池龙节，马序分宠； 致君一匡，锡我所履； 威临铁审，贵拥朱输，智发未萌，道了得一，蒲鞭举而过改，桑附谣而政遐。 谓我无欲民朴，我无为民化，法黄老而熙帝载，考始制而弘象教，乃顾名都，更植世福。 灵宝院者，梁天监岁贞白陶先生弘景所创也，始本昭真其号焉。 紫阳观，即长史宅，界于束小茅岭雷平山，列于南钟山西朝焉、良常北彻焉。 其余胜盘草阜，若众星之环拱，不可婵论。 先是，迥台层汉，攸阁匝云，秘三洞谲文，集丹丘羽客，门人周仙君子良勤修於是，崇习玄风，炼金石身，腾姻霞辙。 时移代厦，瓦木之功寝泯。 及唐太和中，太尉赞皇李公每胆遗躅，屡构遐绿，门师道士孙智清复讨前址，再建是院，寻诸旧号，额日灵宝。 尔后既偶兵焰，灵致煨烬，刑棘相森，凡材围长，狐兔往焉，刍莞往焉，弗芟弗萝，历五十载矣。 栖霞冑叨素业，幼专不息，虽童卯获名，而屡厄兵难，迹不遑处，遗构殆空，断梗杳泊，自北祖南，幸托玄化，遐钦兹境。 聿谐所适，乃励畚钟，忘錾劳，砌坛植松，结茅庇拙，纫兰饵木#14，愿言终遁。 俄奉先齐王旨，□ 命出居会府，齿朝修事，沐浴恩遇，扬历馆，仞甄道，衔表命服，再管再钥，是涎是镕。 洎我公移镇是邦，自以风痹，厥躬告从，谷隐公遂舍俸钱一百万，俾於旧基，别崇利有。 禀命之际，赛昼勉励，夙夜匪懈，思竭克勤，冀荷恩教。 噫，事难谋始，智寡周防，且虎视非一雀之图，而雀终噪，蟾盈非片云可同，而云或掩。 时哉？ 理非契也，非台曜览幽，几止终废。

The path to transcendence is not a single call but many—
One who is spiritually refined, his *qi* luminous,
His bones and markings divine—
This is bestowed by Heaven.

One whose heart is empty, his nature pure,
His virtue profound and vast—
This is rooted in his essence.

One who reveals truth and imparts teachings,
Illuminating the near and distant—
This is achieved through diligence.

Thus, though his name be inscribed in purple and white,
And his steps ascend the Yellow Court,
His deeds flow on, his blessings stored—
These must harmonize in unity.

Then, the Master’s Dao—
Was it not thus?

Though his carriage departed without pause,
And his ascent vanished with the sun,
Yet his lofty virtue may be recounted,
His enduring model remains among men.
To record it is the duty of the brush.

Deng Jun, in reverence, now commits this to script.
In the eighth month of autumn, the year *Jìwèi*,
Recorded by Xu Xian, the *Shangqing* True Person,
Chancellor and Calligrapher of Danjing.

The Chancellor, steeped in Dao,
Dwelling in spirit, ascending to the Nine Heavens—
Though men may change, the Dan Well endures.
Here, the valley’s prince is shot,
Cold springs gush forth.
Dividing the sweet nectar,
They nourish the fields of immortality.

From the west I came,
Seeking the True of Purple Yang,
As if loving the #13 Charm Tree,
Ascending to the Lu Hall.
With reverence, I carve the Green Talks,
Forever to remember the Silver Bed.
Alas, for later scholars,
To hold this lingering light.

**Record of the Lingbao Academy**
Composed by Wang Qixia, the Purple-Garbed Daoist,
And rebuilt by Xu Gong, the Celestial Master,
Vice Commander of the Daoist Army,
Governor of the Zhenhai Military Circuit,
Holding the rank of Inspector-General,
Guardian of the Secretariat,
Lord of Donghai.

Now, the Lingbao—
A secret name from the Empty Cavern’s Red Scriptures.
It expounds the natural order,
Born before Heaven and Earth.
Its virtue is effortless, yet it nurtures all deeds.
Thus, the Most High establishes virtue,
The next establishes deeds.

Virtue is the great origin of Heaven and Earth,
Deeds bring benefit to the three realms.
If virtue nourishes the self,
And deeds aid others,
Then even slight actions,
Like returning home,
Transform the clamor of the world into quiet retreat.

Moreover, the records and traces that remain—
There are extraordinary men,
Who achieve extraordinary deeds,
Thus spanning ancient and modern times,
Their noble intentions unbroken.

Teachings bound like brocade,
With upright Dao in service,
Kind and gentle in conduct.
Understanding the world is wisdom,
Finding joy in stillness is benevolence.
He once dwelled in Chang’an’s clouds,
Initially relying on Heng Mountain,
Then taking refuge here,
Calmly suppressing agitation,
Devoted to the Mysterious and Silent,
Simple as uncarved wood—
His virtue moved Heaven itself.

Suddenly, clad in embroidered robes,
He received the Nine Tributes,
Guided by the Three Pure Ones’ path,
The phoenix descended in response,
His blessings unerring—
This was the accumulation of past merit.

Now, those of later ages who follow the same path,
Surely, it is our Lord.

Our Lord, with his footsteps in virtue,
Swimming in loyalty and sincerity,
His lofty virtue far-reaching,
His purity like jade’s chill—
His fame resounds like the *Ling* and *Shi*,
His halls echoing ancient traces,
His authority like the Dragon’s Pool,
His honors as vast as the Red Gates.
He righted the ruler with one counsel,
Bestowed upon us his path,
His judgments stern as iron,
His wealth as rich as cinnabar.
His wisdom arose before its time,
His Dao attained in a single moment—
With a bamboo whip, he transformed all,
And with the *Sangfu* hymns, his governance spread far.

He said:
*"I have no desires, yet the people are simple,
I act without doing, yet the people are transformed.
Following Huang-Lao’s teachings, the Emperor’s reign flourished,
Examining the origins, the Sacred Instruction was expanded.
Thus, he turned to the named capital,
And planted blessings for the world."*

The Lingbao Academy was established by Tao Hongjing,
Master of *Zhenbai*, in the *Tianjian* era of the Liang.
Originally, it was called *Zhaozhen*.

The Purple Yang Observatory,
Once the Chancellor’s residence,
Lies between the Small Mao Ridge and Leiping Mountain,
Facing South Zhong Mountain’s *Zhaochang*,
And extending north to Liangchang.

The remaining peaks and valleys,
Like stars encircling the pole,
Cannot be fully described.

Before this, the towering halls,
Layered like the Milky Way,
Housed the Three Caverns’ arcane texts,
Gathering the feathered guests of Danqiu.
The disciples—Zhou Xianjun and Zichang—
Diligently cultivated here,
Cherishing the Dao’s winds,
Refining their bodies with gold and stone,
Ascending on clouds.

Yet time passed, and the halls decayed,
Their wooden frames crumbling to dust.

In the *Taihe* era of the Tang,
Li Gong, Marquis of Zanhuang and Grandee,
Often visited, rebuilding the distant greenery.
The Daoist Master Sun Zhicheng,
His disciple, investigated the old site,
And rebuilt the academy,
Renaming it *Lingbao* as before.

Later, war’s flames consumed its blessings,
Reducing it to ashes.
Thorns and brambles grew thick,
Long grass and weeds overran it,
Foxes and rabbits dwelled there,
Reeds and sedges choked the paths—
Untrimmed for fifty years.

Qixia, though burdened by past merits,
From youth onward, never ceased his devotion.
Though he gained fame early,
He endured repeated wars,
His traces scattered,
His structures nearly lost—
The broken branches vanished into the void,
From north to south.
Fortunate to rely on Dao’s transformation,
He revered this sacred ground.

Thus, he aligned his path,
And with zeal, he labored—
Forgetting weariness,
Building altars, planting pines,
Weaving thatch for shelter,
Binding orchids to wood,
Wishing only to retreat forever.

Soon, he received the decree from the Prince of Qi,
[Command to reside in] the Imperial Academy,
Serving in the court,
Bathing in imperial favor,
Elevated in rank,
His Dao refined,
Wearing the ceremonial robes,
Twice entrusted with keys—
Both honored and refined.

When our Lord took governorship here,
Though afflicted by illness,
He humbly resigned.
Lord Guyin then donated a million in salary,
To rebuild on the old foundation,
Creating new blessings.

At the time of receiving the command,
He strove day and night without rest,
Ever diligent, hoping to fulfill his duty.
Alas, planning is difficult,
Wisdom lacks foresight—
Though a tiger’s gaze is not for a single sparrow,
Yet the sparrow still chirps.
Though the moon’s fullness is not for a single cloud,
Yet the cloud may obscure it.

Ah, the times!
Logic does not always prevail—
Unless the Platform illuminates the hidden,
Nearly all would be lost.

The county’s governance was measured and meticulous,
Months and days marked its progress,
Wisely soliciting judgments,
Matching talents to tasks—
Mud walls and thatch roofs were reinforced,
Plans for sprawl were firmly set,
Leveling earth and stones to equal heights,
Dispelling wolves and cutting wild grass.
Ten thousand laborers toiled endlessly,
Years passed without respite,
Their craft refined to perfection,
Their pigments and glazes exquisitely blended.
Three halls were constructed for the main palace,
With the Celestial Venerable of Precious Treasure enshrined within,
And the Sacred Followers arrayed.
Three-tiered altars were built,
Three gates and three halls,
Sixteen surrounding corridors,
All decaying structures repaired and restored.
The Hall of Descending Truth was extended inward,
The pond’s foundation was renewed,
And the walls rebuilt.

At the northern corner,
Bound by the loyal and righteous Duke of Loyalty and Righteousness’ younger brother,
A hall of auspicious visions was erected on the old platform’s foundation,
Three halls housing the Three Manifestations of the Venerable Lord of Yangjiao Mountain.
To the southwest,
The Hall of the Three Officials Facing the Sun was built—
Two halls, their statues towering and majestic,
Their golden and azure adornments resplendent,
Their reflections dazzling.
Tiled roofs stacked like mandarin ducks in flight,
Ridge beams curling like phoenixes’ tails.
Though the rituals were fragmented as if calcified,
The guards who gazed upon them were struck with awe.
Banners fluttered like clouds,
While cranes and tortoises glided as if plowing fields.
Opposite stood towering figures,
As if miraculously risen—
Doubtful wonders, as if flown from afar.
Had it not been for our Lord’s unwavering resolve,
Had the teachings not been moved by devotion,
How could this desolate land witness such splendor?
Enough to spread eternal virtue,
To perpetuate divine influence,
To align with Heaven and Earth in longevity,
To gather the blessings of mountains and rivers—
Grand and mighty, enduring and vast.

Tomorrow’s Clouds’ wisdom was beyond compare,
His talents unmatched in composition.
Yet he received his Dao at its beginning,
And his mandate here.
With utmost sincerity and diligence,
This work was completed.
Now recorded in plain prose,
Presented to the Platform for inspection,
To be inscribed for future generations.

In the year *Dàhé Sānnián* of Rebuilt Unity,
The ninth month, on the *yǐyǒu* day of the first,
The ninth day, *gǔsǐ*,
This was respectfully recorded.

Silver Green Light Honorable Grandee,
Acting Left Scattered Cavalry Attendant,
Sentenced to govern Rùchéng County and oversee the affairs,
Huáng Huánqián,
In fulfillment of the Platform’s decree of virtuous completion.

Supervising Daoists:
Jīng Ruòxū, Zhū Huáidé,
Cloud-and-Water Daoist Lǚ Zǐyuán,
Who inscribed the inscriptions.
The Orthodox Unity Disciple Shěn Déqián assisted wholeheartedly.
Master Pán Zūnshī’s epitaph was composed by
Right Assistant Historian Chén Zǐ’áng.

Master Pán’s teachings were profound and esoteric,
His devotion to the *sè* serene and deep,
His heart aligned with Heaven, his treasures few.
Abandoning the Sage’s ways, discarding wisdom,
He did not flaunt his light,
Thus the True was moved by hidden destiny,
His sacred diagrams and secret arts
Beyond mortal comprehension.

Yet his lofty aspirations stretched to distant horizons,
His distant thoughts soaring—
His will reaching for the Azure Clouds,
His gaze fixed upon the Purple Gates.
The High Ancestor often descended in person,
Visiting his humble abode,
Yet Master Pán never left his hall,
Only extending his hands in greeting.
He sighed, saying:
*“A true man’s pursuit of the Dao
Should cast his body into the heavens,
Erase his shadow in the forests,
Yet here I weary myself in these mountains,
Bothering the sovereign—
This is my fault!”*
He then wished to seek Penglai,
Sailing the fox-boat into the sea.
But the Heavenly Sovereign’s reverence for this Dao was profound,
His entreaties ever deeper,
And so he lingered at the mountain’s edge,
His journey never undertaken.

Then the celestial decree arrived,
And his reins were bound to this realm.
Alas! In ancient times,
The Immortal of Gūshè existed—
Emperor Yáo valued the world so lightly;

chunks.original_text: 崆峒有至道，轩屈顺风，玄真高踪，万古同德，何其盛哉1 ．尊师有弟子十人，并仙阶之秀，然鸾姿凤骨、眇爱云松者，唯颖川韩法昭、河内司马子微，皆禀命瑶庭，密受琼室，专太清之业，遗下仙之俦，谷汲芝耕，服勤於我，盖历岁纪也。 始尊师受录於茅山，升玄王君，王君受道於华阳隐居陶公，陶公至子微，二百岁矣，而玄标仙骨，雅似华阳。 夫阶真蹈冥，炼景游化者，其心必有类乎。 昭等永惟尊师灵边洞业，高深迈古，而弃世往矣，其若之何！ ．乃断石幽山，申颂玄德。 颂日： 观元化兮，求古之列仙，得瑶图与金鼎，信元符之自然，神与道而为一。 天与人兮相连，苟精守以专密，必驾景而凌姻。 丹丘不死兮羡门子，黄宫度世兮吾体玄。 休#15玄至德兮洵淑美。 冲心养和保元始，初学茅山济江水，乃入华阳洞天裹。 道逢真人升玄子，授以宝书青台旨，令守嵩阳玉女峰，云栖穷林今五纪。 圣人以万机为贵，而我以天下为累，圣人以大宝为尊，而我以天下为烦，是以冥居於喂蝙，寄遗边於轩辕。 有唐高宗兮，天子之光，好道乐仙兮，思彼云乡。 千旌万骑兮翠凤凰，遨游汝海兮箕山阳。 朝拜白茅夕紫房，斋心洁意缅相望。 祈问玉真及玉皇，何以得之受天昌。 黄庭中人在子身，窈窈冥冥精甚真，去汝骄气与淫神，勤能思之道自亲。 遂解形而遗世，乘白云而上宾。 弟子不知其所往也，乃刻石以思真。 唐汉东紫阳先生碑铭 陇西李白撰 呜呼，紫阳竟天，其志以默化，不昭然白日而升九天乎？ 或将潜宾皇王，非世所测，缺十一字挺列仙明拔之英姿，明堂平白，长耳广颗，挥手振骨，百关有声，殊毛秀采，居然逸异，缺十字而直达，何龟鹤早世，媳蛄延秋！ ．元命乎！ ．遭命乎？

At **Kōngtóng**, the Dao reached its zenith—
Its lofty path bent with the wind’s grace,
Its mysterious traces soaring high,
Its virtue enduring through ten thousand ages—
How magnificent it was!

The Master had ten disciples,
All gems of the Immortal ranks,
Yet those with the bearing of cranes and phoenixes,
Whose love for clouds and pines was profound—
Only **Yǐngchuān’s Hàn Fǎzhāo** and **Héinà’s Sīmǎ Zīwéi**
Had received their mandates from the Jade Court,
Secretly instructed in the Pearl Chambers,
Devoted solely to the **Tàiqīng** arts,
Leaving behind the company of mortal men.
They drew water from the valleys, tilled the fields for elixirs,
Serving me with diligence—
For years upon years.

At first, the Master was recorded at **Máoshān**,
Ascending as **Xuánwáng Jūn**.
**Xuánwáng Jūn** received the Dao from **Huàyáng’s** recluse, **Táo Gōng**,
And **Táo Gōng** traced his lineage back to **Zīwéi**—
Two hundred years had passed,
Yet the Master’s lofty frame and immortal bones
Resembled **Huàyáng** in every way.

Those who tread the True Path, refining essence and transcending form,
Their hearts must share a kindred essence.

**Fǎzhāo** and the others forever cherished the Master’s profound and recondite teachings—
His virtue soaring beyond the ancients—
Yet he abandoned the world and departed.
What could we do but—

Carve this inscription upon the silent stone of the deep mountain,
To proclaim his transcendent virtue.

**Ode:**

Behold the primal transformation,
Seeking the ancient ranks of the Immortals,
Obtaining the Jade Diagram and Golden Cauldron—
Truly the natural fulfillment of the primal signs,
As the spirit merges with the Dao.

Heaven and man are bound as one—
If one guards the essence with unwavering devotion,
One shall ride the clouds and ascend the celestial marriage.

At **Dānqiū**, the **Ménzi** never dies,
Within the **Huánggōng**, the world is transcended—
My body now embraces the **Xuán**.

Restoring the **Xuán’s** most noble virtue,
Truly refined and beautiful.
Nurturing harmony within the heart,
Preserving the primal origin—
First learning at **Máoshān** to cross the **Jiāng**,
Then entering **Huàyáng’s** **Dòngtiān** enclosure.
There met the True Person, **Xuánzǐ**,
Who gave the **Bǎoshū** of **Qīngtái’s** decree,
Commanding him to guard **Sōngyáng’s** **Yùnǚ Fēng**,
Where now, for five cycles, he dwells in secluded forests.

The Sage is burdened by ten thousand affairs,
Yet I consider the world a hindrance;
The Sage treasures the Great Treasure,
Yet I find the world a distraction—
Thus I dwell in obscurity at **Fèifán**,
Leaving my legacy to **Xuānyuán**.

Oh, **Emperor Gāozōng of Táng**—
The radiant Son of Heaven,
Loving the Dao, delighting in the Immortals,
Yearning for the celestial abodes.
With ten thousand banners and a thousand steeds,
A train of **Cǐfènghuáng**,
Roving the **Rǔ Sea**, basking in **Jīshān’s** glow.
Morning visits to the **Báimáo**, evening at the **Zǐfáng**,
Purifying the heart, refining the will—
Ever in reverent anticipation.
He inquired of **Yùzhēn** and the **Yùhuáng**,
How to attain the Heaven’s favor.
Within the **Huángtíng**, the True Person resides—
Mysterious, profound, his essence most pure,
Banishing arrogance and lasciviousness,
Diligently cultivating the Dao, drawing ever closer.

Thus he cast off his form and left the world,
Riding the white clouds to the celestial guests.
His disciples knew not his destination,
And so carved this stone in longing for the True.

**Inscription for the Eastern Purple Yang Master of Táng and Hàn**
Composed by **Lǐ Bái of Lǒngxī**
Alas! **Zǐyáng** ascended to Heaven—
His will subtly transformed,
Not ascending in plain sight to the Nine Heavens?
Perhaps he now consorts with the **Huángdì** in secret,
Beyond mortal comprehension—

*[Fragment: eleven characters missing]*
The peerless brilliance of the **Lìxiān**—
His **Míngtáng** clear and unblemished,
Long ears, broad forehead,
His gestures bold, his bones resonant—
A hundred joints harmonious,
His fur and feathers extraordinary,
Truly one of singular grace.

*[Fragment: ten characters missing]*
Ah! **Yuánmìng**—
Or was it **Zāomìng**?

chunks.original_text: 余长息三日，懵於变化之理。 先生姓胡氏，缺六字族也。 代业黄老，门清儒素，皆龙脱世网，鸿冥高云，但贵天爵，何征阀阅？ 始八岁，经仙城山，缺十一字有清都紫微之遐想。 九岁出家，十二休粮，二十游衡山，云寻洞府，水涉瞑壑。 神王缺八字召为威仪及天下采经使。 因遇诸真人，哑赤丹阳精、石景水母，故常吸飞根，吞日魂，密而修之，缺六字所居苦竹院，置飧霞之楼，手植双桂，栖迟其下，闻金陵之墟，道始盛於三茅，波乎四许。 华阳缺七字陶隐居传升玄子，升玄子传体玄，体玄传贞一先生，贞一先生传天师李含光，李含光合契乎紫阳、缺五字於神农之里，南抵朱陵，北越白水，禀训门下者，三千余人。 邻境牧守，移风问道，忽遇先生之宴坐，缺五字隐机鸦行而前，为时见重，多此类也。 天宝初，威仪元丹丘，道门龙凤，厚礼致屈，传录于嵩山束京大唐缺二字宫、三请固辞，偃外未几而诏书下责，不得已而行。 入宫一革轨仪，大变都邑。 然海乌愁臧文之享，谖狙裂周公之衣，志往迩留，称疾辞帝，克期离阙。 临别自祭，其文日：神将献余，余非驮世。 乃顾命侄道士胡齐物，具平肩舆，归骨旧土。 王公卿士送及龙门，入叶县#16。 次王乔之祠，目若有睹，泊然而化。 天香引道，尸轻空衣。 及本郡太守裴公以幡华郊迎，举郭雷动缺四字开颜如生，观者日万，草议骇俗。 至其年十月二十三日，葬于郭束之新松山，春秋六十有二。 先生含弘光大，不修小节； 书不尽妙，讲有崩云之势，文非夙工，时动雕龙之作。 存也宇宙而无光，殁也浪化而蝉蜕。 岂缺八字乎！ ．有乡僧贞倩，雅仗才气，请余为铭。 余与紫阳神交，饱飧素论，十得其九。 弟子元丹丘等咸思鸾凤之仪羽，想珠玉之云气，洒扫松月，载扬仙风，篆石颂德，与兹山不朽。 词日： 贤哉仙士，六十而化。 光光紫阳，善与时而为龙蛇，固亦以生死为昼夜。 有力者挈之而趋劫运，颓落终归於无。 惟元神不灭，湛然清都，延陵既殁，仲尼呜呼。 青青松梧，离离山隅。 篆石颂德，名扬八区。

「I lingered in sorrow for three days, bewildered by the subtleties of transformation.
The Master bore the surname **Hú**—
*[Fragment: six characters missing]*
His lineage traced back to **Huánglǎo**’s teachings,
His household upheld **Rú**’s refined traditions,
Both transcending worldly bonds like dragons shedding their nets,
Soaring beyond mortal clouds—
Yet they prized only the **Heavenly Merit**,
Why seek earthly fame or official rank?

From age eight, he wandered the **Xiancheng** mountain,
*[Fragment: eleven characters missing]*
His thoughts already stretched toward the **Qingdu** and **Zǐwēi**’s distant splendor.
At nine, he left the home,
At twelve, he ceased taking grain.
At twenty, he visited **Héngshān**, seeking the hidden halls,
Wading through waters where darkness swallows the valleys.

The **Divine Sovereign** *[Fragment: eight characters missing]*
Summoned him to serve as **威仪** and to gather scriptures across the land.
Encountering the **True Ones**, he absorbed **Dānyáng**’s elixir essence,
And **Shíjǐng**’s water-mother secret—
Thus he constantly drew upon the **flying roots** of immortality,
And swallowed the **soul of the sun**, practicing in secrecy.
*[Fragment: six characters missing]*
His dwelling was the **Kǔzhú** Grove,
Where he built the **Fēixiá** pavilion,
Planted twin **guì** trees beneath it,
And rested there, listening to the distant echoes of **Jīnlíng**’s ruins.
The **Dao** flourished in the **Sānmiáo** grove,
And rippled through the **Sìxǔ** regions.

From **Huáyáng** *[Fragment: seven characters missing]*
**Táo Yǐnjī** passed the **Shēngxiān** tradition,
**Shēngxiān** transmitted to **Tǐxiān**,
**Tǐxiān** passed to **Zhēnyī** Master,
**Zhēnyī** Master taught **Liánhuáng**,
And **Liánhuáng** finally merged with **Zǐyáng**—
*[Fragment: five characters missing]*
Reaching from **Shénnóng**’s village,
South to **Zhūlíng**, north beyond **Báishuǐ**,
Instructing over three thousand souls in his halls.

Nearby officials and governors,
Transformed by his teachings, sought his counsel—
Yet suddenly they found him reclining in meditation,
*[Fragment: five characters missing]*
Hidden like a crow in flight, approaching without warning,
Held in high esteem by the age,
Many such tales existed.

At the start of the **Tiān Bǎo** era,
He was summoned by **Dānyáng** to the **Liúfèng** halls,
With lavish gifts to bend **Qū**’s will,
And to record the transmission at **Sōngshān**’s **Shùjīng**—
The **Great Tang** *[Fragment: two characters missing]* Palace.
Three entreaties were made, yet he firmly declined,
Refusing to leave his retreat.
But soon the imperial edict arrived, commanding his presence—
Reluctantly, he obeyed.

Upon entering the palace, he altered the **ritual norms**,
Greatly transforming the capital’s customs.
Yet like the **Hǎiwū** feasting on **Zāng Wén**,
Or the **Yuánzhū** tearing at **Zhōugōng**’s robes,
His heart yearned for departure while his body lingered—
He feigned illness to bid the Emperor farewell,
And fixed a date to leave the court.

As he prepared to depart, he composed his own elegy:
*"The gods now summon me, yet I am no worldly burden."*

He entrusted his disciple **Hú Qìwù**,
Who carried him on a **píngjiān** palanquin,
Returning his remains to the ancestral soil.
Nobles and ministers saw him off to **Lóngmén**,
And into **Yèxiàn**’s precinct #16.

At **Wáng Qiáo**’s temple,
His gaze seemed to linger—
Then peacefully, he ascended.

The **heavenly fragrance** guided his **Dao**,
His body light as air, his robes empty.
When the **Tàishōu** of this prefecture,
**Kāi** by the **fānhuá** at the suburban shrine,
The heavens trembled, the earth roared—
*[Fragment: four characters missing]*
His face radiant as life,
Ten thousand daily witnesses,
All stunned by the spectacle.

On the twenty-third day of the tenth month of that year,
He was buried at **Xīnsōngshān** within the **Guōshù** walls,
His age sixty-two.

The Master held vast **prong** and brilliant **light**—
He did not concern himself with trifling matters;
His writings were never fully exquisite,
Yet his teachings carried the force of **crashing clouds**,
His compositions were not the work of long practice,
Yet they stirred even **dragon-carved** masterpieces.

In life, he illuminated the **cosmos** without a trace,
In death, he dissolved into the **void** like a cicada’s molt.
Was it not *[Fragment: eight characters missing]*

There was a local monk, **Zhēnqiàn**,
Who admired his talent and **virtue**,
And asked me to compose this **inscription**.
I, having exchanged **Dao** with **Zǐyáng**,
Filled with discussions of **substance and emptiness**,
Understood nine-tenths of his essence.

His disciples, **Yuándānqiū** and others,
All longed for his **luanfèng**’s noble bearing,
And imagined his **zhūyù**’s luminous presence—
Sweeping away the dust of mortal months,
Praising his **Dao**’s immortal winds,
Engraving this stone to immortalize his **virtue**,
So that with this mountain, his name shall endure.

The words are as follows:

**Yánlíng** has passed, **Zhòngní** sighs in lament.
Green the **sōng** and **wú**,

Engrave this stone to praise his **virtue**,
Let his name resound through the **Eight Regions**."*

**Records of Gold and Stone: Song Stele #1 *Imperial Composition of the Ode to the Dragon with Preface***

The *Mao Mountain Records* [茅山志] states:
*"The Thunderous Pool of the Fire Hall, the Imperial Pool of the Fire Hall—
within them dwells a small black dragon, now rarely seen.
There is also the Pool of Master Guo [郭真人池], where such dragons are always present.
These spirit-beings shift and transform, their abodes not fixed—
men sometimes capture them and bring them down from the mountain,
yet even when sealed in vessels, they vanish without trace."*

Recently, the court dispatched the imperial envoy **Ren Wencai** [任文庆] to perform **rites of exorcism and prayer** [醮祭] at the sacred peaks,
seeking blessings for the people.

**Ren Wencai** [文庆] procured one dragon and presented it,
then carried two dragons with him as he journeyed.
Midway, winds and rains arose—
indeed, one dragon was lost.

Holding the remaining dragon at the imperial gate,
he closely examined its form—
truly remarkable, so I composed this ode to record it.

**The Ode:**

*The foremost of the Four Spirits is this dragon,
whose transformations are fixed and hard to match.
The Three Teaches’ blessed land, the abode of the Dry Immortals [旱仙宅],
where spirit-forms gather in this sacred pool.

The immortals of the pool tamed it with their Dao,
yet to this day, its hidden and revealed nature remains unmeasured.

Riding the clouds, it moves alone with wondrous grace,
bringing rain and nurturing life, all through its virtue/power.
Common folk seize it, yet it flees their grasp—
once out of the mountain, where can it be found?

The imperial envoy sought it with earnest intent,
wishing to present it to the court and proclaim its auspicious signs.

At first, he carried one dragon to the **Wei Gate** [魏阙],
then, by chance, held two as he left their cavernous home.
Human hearts and dragon hearts, if in harmony, are like matching seals—
one departs, one remains—what spirit is more strange?

I beheld the true dragon and was not alarmed,
for sincere devotion pleases the dragon’s ears.
I only hope winds and rains will follow year after year,
so that granaries may overflow in every place.

In the third year of **Great Harmony and Auspicious Symbols** [大中祥符], sixth month.

chunks.original_text: 宋天圣皇太后受上清录记 上清大洞宗师赐紫臣朱自英撰，御书院祇候臣孟应之奉圣旨书并篆额。 皇宋应运之四叶，圣君在宥之三年，圣母皇太后刘氏九灵分粹，三元毓神，流光开泰之期，握符圣明之化，内以肃雍九族，外以缉熙庶政。 万机之暇，宅心虚无之表，凝神太漠之乡，金妃拂筵于琳碧之堂，玉华散馨於虚白之室，而又澄神澹思，诵《黄庭二景经》，志意内修，晨夕忘倦，岂独拘魂制魄，上符高圣之言，盖亦务本还淳，下荫普天之众。 于以观三素，思九真，揖仪璘，玩当佩。 南真依稀而密盼。 西母彷佛以宴观。 胖蜜之应，继日而昭，积累之功，卜年而进。 信乎，仙可学而道不虚行矣。 仍念研精尚鲜，未臻道源，闻南岳紫虚元君魏夫人，昔以东晋兴宁甲子岁先农日，以小有天王清虚真人所授上清大洞宝文，下教于茅山东华真人杨君，洎上清仙侯许长史。 迄后，灵源真系，接武华阳，道叶仙枝，流芳寰海，县是乃诏玉清昭应官冲妙大师皇甫希及寻绩王、魏之文，研杨、许之边，得上清三品神经、玉清隐书、九清众秘、与金神二虎八景玉录、上皇玉讳元始谱录，流金火铃，回车毕道、三元玉检，九凤灵章、紫文白带，太微黄书，谲宫灵飞等录凡十卷，金仙玉马等一十五券。 依科备办金龙、玉鱼、金羊、银鸦、青丝金钮，云锦凤文，碧霞拂尘之罗，绛章落尸之帛，四规明镜，景震灵剑，五色彩缯上清法服，盟文礼物，莫不周悉。 先遣中使责密词诣南岳，致告于紫虚元君，默允冥旨。 续命入内内侍省西头供奉官臣康从政、入内内侍省内侍殿头勾当御药院臣江德用，并韶右街副道录、知玉清昭应宫事、同管勾左右街教门公事、冲真大师赐紫臣李知损、左街都监寿宁观住持明真大师臣石知章、玉清昭应宫副直岁宣教大师赐紫臣周遂良、玉清昭应宫住持冲妙大师赐紫臣皇甫希及、玉清昭应宫同住持冲秘大师赐紫臣薛清和等，同责青词黄素，一行礼信，就江宁府茅山崇禧观开建上清黄坛，预启玉录道场七昼夜，散日设醮三百六十分位，依科传度讫，别设谢恩道场三昼夜，设阖山道士女冠大斋一中，投送金龙玉简、金环玉鱼于华阳洞、燕洞、金山水府，于以告盟七圣，于以致诚九清，伸授受之仪，罄师资之礼。 始以输轩至日，灵鹤低迎於羽葆，当建斋之夕，商云远布於层霄，宿露真文以祈感，预陈精梼以伸款，兰膏晃尔，璧月集然。 百神受厘以效祥，五岳卫灵而荐祉，中夜灵风飒至，嘉雨需然，须臾之顷，银汉森列，星斗烂如。 咸云风伯扫坛，雨师洒席，观其所以，不亦宜乎。 及启传之旦，九霞流光之辉，照烁而凝照； 三素飞烟之气，缥缈以浮空，飕钦萃焉，霓旌焕焉，习仪恍焉，万灵肃然q 当分金列契之际，皓鹤复翔于坛上，绛霞纷绕於山中，蕙风袭人，灵芬郁野。 蚓夫众妙多门而学则有序，至神无方而感则无待，斯以见我后用心之精诚也。 符健顺服，人神降灵，仙契冥奥，非浩劫累崇之德，积生致尚之果，其孰能臻於此焉？ 是知令乎善始则美克有终，谋之以道，何患不臧，若然者，八景飞霞之辈，主元流云之宴，九色凤脑之僎、十精徊水之浆，靡日而致之矣。 恭惟圣念，奉若秘文，盖欲昭事昊穹，保宁真主，固宗枋於亿载，福民庶之三登，永戢干戈，同承富寿者也。

The **Empress Dowager of the Song Dynasty, Heavenly Saintly and Pure**, received the *Upper Clarity Record of the Great Cavern Dao Master*, inscribed by the Purple-Granted Subject Zhu Ziying and calligraphed by the Palace Academy Attendant Meng Yingzhi under imperial decree.

In the fourth generation of the Song Dynasty’s auspicious mandate, during the third year of the Sage’s benevolent reign, the Holy Mother Empress Dowager Liu—refined essence of the Nine Spirits, nurtured by the Three Primordials—ushered in an era of radiant prosperity. With the talisman of sagely virtue in hand, she harmonized the inner realm, reverently ordering the nine clans, and extended her enlightened governance outward, refining the affairs of the people.

In moments of respite from statecraft, her mind dwelled in the void’s boundless expanse, her spirit soaring in the boundless realm. At the jade-paved hall, she brushed away the golden incense’s smoke; in the chamber of pure whiteness, she scattered fragrant blossoms. She further purified her mind and stilled her thoughts, reciting the *Huangting Erjing Sutra*, her resolve inwardly cultivated, tireless in morning and evening. Was it merely to subdue spirit and soul, aligning with the lofty words of the Sage? Or was it also to return to the roots, to nurture the virtue/power that would shelter all under heaven?

Thus, she contemplated the Three Pure Ones, mused upon the Nine Immortals, bowed to the adorned jade scepter, and admired the pendant of the Dao. The Southern Immortal appeared faintly yet with eager anticipation. The Western Mother seemed to manifest in leisurely observation. The responses of the *Pangmi* [膏沐] were revealed day by day, and the accumulated merit progressed year by year. Truly, the Dao can be learned, and the Way is not an empty pursuit.

Yet, still mindful of her own incomplete refinement, she had not yet reached the source of the Way. She heard that the **Wuzhu Yuanjun, Wei the Lady of Southern Peak**, in the year *Xingning Jiazi* of the Eastern Jin (349 CE), on the *Xiaoyou* [小有] day of the *Qingxu True Person*’s teaching by the *Xiaohao Tianwang*, received the *Upper Clarity Great Cavern Treasure Scripture* and passed it down to the *Donghua True Person* Yang Jun of Mount Mao, and later to the *Upper Clarity Dao Marshal* Xu Changshi.

Since then, the sacred lineage of the source continued, inheriting the traditions of Huayang, extending the branches of the Dao, and spreading its fragrance across the world. Now, by imperial decree, the *Zhaoying Official of the Jade Clarity* Suong Miao Dasheng Huangfu Xiji and the officials Wang, Wei, and Wen were commissioned to study the margins of Yang and Xu’s teachings. They obtained the *Upper Clarity Three-Grade Divine Scripture*, the *Jade Clarity Hidden Writings*, the *Nine Clarities’ Secrets*, the *Golden God’s Two Tigers and Eight Scenes Jade Record*, the *Imperial Ancestor’s Jade Taboo and Yuan Shi Genealogy*, the *Flowing Gold Fire Bell*, the *Returning Chariot’s Complete Dao*, the *Three Primordials’ Jade Inspection*, the *Nine Phoenix Sacred Scriptures*, the *Purple Text and White Belt*, the *Taixi Yellow Scripture*, the *Guile Palace’s Lingfei Record*—ten volumes in total—and fifteen *Golden Immortal Jade Horse Certificates*.

According to the prescribed rites, they prepared the *Golden Dragon*, *Jade Fish*, *Golden Ram*, *Silver Crow*, *Green Silk Golden Button*, *Cloud Brocade Phoenix Pattern*, *Bixia Waving Dust Silk*, *Red Seal Mortuary Silk*, the *Four Rectangular Clear Mirrors*, the *Jingzhen Sacred Sword*, the *Five-Colored Silk Upper Clarity Daoist Robes*, and all ceremonial offerings—none were omitted.

First, envoys were dispatched with secret petitions to Southern Peak, conveying the message to the Wuzhu Yuanjun. In silence, she assented to the divine intent.

Next, the **Inner Palace Attendants** Kang Congzheng and Jiang Deyong of the *Western Palace Supply Office*, along with the *Right Street Vice Dao Master* Li Zhishun—who oversaw the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple* and managed the *Left and Right Street Teaching Gates*—the *Suongzhen Dasheng* Shi Zhizhang, the *Left Street Overseer* and *Shouning Guan Abbot* Mingzhen Dasheng, the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple Vice Director* and *Xuanjiao Dasheng* Zhou Suiliang, the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple Abbot* Suongmiao Dasheng Huangfu Xiji, and the *Co-Abbot* Suongmi Dasheng Xue Qinghe—were commissioned to present the *Blue-Worded Petition on Yellow Silk* and perform the rites in person.

At the **Chongxi Observatory of Mount Mao in Jiangning**, they constructed the *Upper Clarity Yellow Altar*, presided over the *Jade Record Dao Ritual* for seven days and nights, and conducted *360 sessions of the Great Fast* during the day. Following the rites, they held a *Three-Day Thanksgiving Dao Ritual* and a *Grand Fast for All Mountain Daoists and Female Immortals*. They also cast the *Golden Dragon Jade Tablet* and *Golden Ring Jade Fish* into the *Huayang Cave*, *Yan Cave*, and *Jinshan Water Palace*, thereby paying homage to the Seven Saints and expressing sincerity to the Nine Clarities. Thus, the rites of transmission and reception were fulfilled, and the rituals of master and disciple were complete.

On the day of the ritual’s commencement, the sacred crane descended to greet beneath the feathered canopy. As the altar was erected, the clouds gathered afar in the layered heavens. The morning dew inscribed the true scriptures, and the offerings were presented with reverent sincerity. The orchid incense burned brightly, and the jade moon gathered its light.

The hundred spirits, ordered and refined, manifested auspicious signs. The Five Peaks’ guardians stood vigilant, offering blessings. At midnight, a sacred wind swept through, and auspicious rain fell. In an instant, the Milky Way shimmered, and the stars blazed like scattered jewels. It was said that the Wind Lord swept the altar, and the Rain Master sprinkled the feast—how could it be otherwise?

When the day of transmission arrived, the radiance of the *Nine Xias* flowed like light, dazzling and concentrated. The *Three Pure Ones’* misty qi drifted ethereally in the sky. The wind gathered in awe, the rainbow banners gleamed, and the ritual movements seemed to float. All spirits stood in solemn reverence.

At the moment of dividing the golden contracts, a white crane circled above the altar, and crimson clouds swirled in the mountains. The osmanthus wind enveloped all, and the sacred fragrance permeated the wilds.

Though the myriad wonders of the Dao have many paths, learning follows an order; though the most sublime mysteries have no fixed method, responses require no delay. This demonstrates the Empress Dowager’s profound sincerity.

The talismans were reverently received, the spirits and humans aligned in harmony, and the Dao’s mysteries were fulfilled. Without the accumulated virtue of countless eons and the fruit of lifelong aspiration, who could attain this?

It is known that a good beginning ensures a beautiful end. If one plans with the Dao, what need is there for concern? Thus, the *Eight Scenes of Flying Xias* will gather in celestial feasts, the *Nine-Colored Phoenix’s Brain* and the *Ten Refined Waters* will be offered daily without end.

In reverence for the Holy Thought, the sacred texts were treated as if they were the most confidential of secrets. This was to glorify the Celestial Sovereign, to safeguard the True Master, to firmly establish the ancestral Dao for ten thousand generations, to bestow triple blessings upon the people, and to forever quell warfare, so that all might share in prosperity and longevity.

chunks.original_text: 惟道家者流，有清静冲虚之说，归真复朴之教，后代悦其风者，触类而长，於是乎幽经秘诀之敷演，清都洞台之照临，三云八景之炼修、童初广寒之游集，上自后辟，迄于臣民，用资化源，着在彝典，初，真宗皇帝既偃武节，聿修文事，封泰山，款后土，谒仙里，建灵宫，务辑一王之仪，邈追前代之盛。 公於是时，都将相之重，极风云之遇，与一二元老、鸿儒硕生，内则栩赞宸猷，外则讨论经礼，用□削药之□，密荷沃心之赏，借前着而谋定，申巽风而令行。 至如检玉介丘、座缯睢壤、近甸巡豫、嘉坛裒对，咸遵秘录，聿彰勤任，用三洞之科式，先八銮而启行，公则参仪卫之职焉。 寅受天瑞，钦崇祖烈，五岳升号，灵泉效祉，并敞真宇，茂昭元既，公又历置使之任焉。 总集髦侍，纷披载籍，撷百世之龟鉴，述方来之矩擭，复诏公典领焉。 公又以混元之法，有助亨会，函岌所蕴，源流皇繁，欣逢盛明，用得论次，乃复选通达其学者，校俨而辨正焉。 名山洞室之藏，金简玉文之萃，多所刊定，讫无调谬。 本至性之冲漠，益圣朝之参会，徜徉乎丛霄太霞之境，讽咏乎广韶曲素之篇，寤寐赤松之游，沉酣金匕之药，间接真士，高谈妙枢，由是偷然有乘云縿扬、离人拔俗之想。 每出沐休暇、元辰令吉，特屏世事，虔修挣醮。 坛宇严邃，旌婶飒俪，杳尘寰之不接，疑景象之有闻，绵袄寝久，积精忘疲。 乾兴壬戌岁，分符秣陵，眷言兹山，实迩郊次。 俄奉中诏，即伸嘉荐，注慕灵壤，徘徊诤域，道肃自得，澹乎忘归。 隐士朱自英者，肥逛中岩，载更年所，公乐其素约，宛若石友，还朝秉钧之再岁，以其名闻。 召至都下，宴语细绎，异於常伦。 及其还山，又约他日卜邻洞府，音旨隆密，朱#3君异之。 后数月而公捐馆舍，且有遗语，卜兹缔构，前后所费私帑凡百五十万，官给不预焉。 续诏朱自英往来临莅之，皆从公之素志也。 按《真诰》言，句曲地肺，土良水清，谓之华阳洞天，可以度世种民，是处三灾不干。 又言，至忠至孝之人，皆先受灵职，次为列仙，岁登降其幽明，如人问之考绩。 则公之结思崇岫，归诚妙象，岂徒然哉？ 蚓夫出应贤运，越登极位，佐时勋大，用物精多，非持受灵气，厦瑜群品，曷以协昌辰之伟任，非默契仙录，往阶真格，曷以显太和之挺生。 质於前闻，其有冥合。 呜嘻，乘时奋庸，握文武之柄，尊主庇物，罄其蕴怀，执方持衡，不疚风议，垣赫辉耀，以功名自终，然后脱遗世氛，与羡门雇佺之徒，相期於烟霭之际，不其盛与？ 惟夫人恪奉治命，无忘适追，其嗣子、殿中丞寅亮，瞿瞿协心，克终胜筑，足播徽范，永光图史。 谓殊夙以文翰游公馆宇，见托撰述，着之金石，是用拜礼命之辱，而忘其陋芜。 公姓王氏，讳钦若，字定国，夫人姓李氏。 公之邑里世系，历官差次，上载史牒，下刊碑志，此得略而不书。 庆历二年，岁次壬午，十月乙卯记。 山门道判兼管观事赐紫孟子宣、雷平胡恢书丹，将仕郎守句容县尉陆绛勾当立石。 茅山第二十三代上清大洞国师乾元观妙先生幽光显扬之碑 云阳南郭陈辅造，七闽西山蔡仍书并题额。 先生姓朱氏，讳自英，字隐芝，句曲朱阳里人也。

In the realm of the Daoist tradition, there are teachings of purity, tranquility, and boundless void, and doctrines of returning to the True and embracing simplicity. Later generations who took delight in its ways expanded upon these themes, thus arose the dissemination of esoteric scriptures and hidden precepts, the illumination of the Celestial Capital and Sacred Isles, the cultivation of the Three Clouds and Eight Sceneries, and the gatherings of the youthful immortals and the Broad Cold. From the august sovereigns to the humble subjects, all drew upon its transformative power, as recorded in the *Yi Zhuan*. Initially, Emperor **True宗** (Zhenzong), having laid down arms and embraced peace, devoted himself to literary and cultural pursuits, ascending Mount Tai, offering tribute to the Earthly Sovereign, visiting the Celestial Precincts, and erecting the Sacred Hall, striving to unify the imperial rites and emulate the grandeur of former dynasties.

At this time, the Master held the weighty office of **Grand Marshal and Chancellor**, enjoying the highest favor of the winds and clouds. Alongside a few senior statesmen and eminent scholars, he both adorned the imperial designs within and deliberated on scriptures and rites without. Employing the **elixir of refinement** and the **award of inner nourishment**, he relied on precedent to establish his course and aligned with the humility of the Dao to ensure his decrees were carried out.

When it came to inspecting the jade tokens of the sacred mounds, sitting upon the tapestry mats of the **Sui** (Zui) region, patrolling the nearby prefectures, and presiding over the grand altars for ritual offerings, all adhered to the secret records, and his diligence shone forth. He led the **Three Caverns** rites before the Eight Palanquins set out, and also took part in the ceremonial escort.

In the year of the **Tiger (丙寅)**, he received celestial blessings, revering and honoring ancestral achievements. The Five Sacred Mountains were elevated in title, the numinous springs bore their fruits, and the sacred precincts were expanded in splendor, the hallowed legacy made manifest. The Master was again entrusted with the role of **Imperial Envoy**.

He gathered the **Sacred Hair** (Hao) attendants and the **abundant scriptures**, selecting the **mirror of ages** from the past and the **rectangular measure** of the future, and was once more commissioned to oversee them.

With the **mysterious and primordial laws** of Dao, he contributed to the harmonious gatherings, encompassing the essence of lofty peaks and the flow of imperial prosperity. Encountering the flourishing era of the **Sacred Reign**, he obtained the sequence of discussions, and thus selected those scholars who were well-versed in its teachings, examining and rectifying them with meticulous care. The treasures hidden in the **Sacred Mountains and Caverns**, the **golden tablets and jade scriptures**, were all subject to his revisions, concluding without error or discrepancy.

Endowed with innate purity, he furthered the **Sacred Court’s** harmonious assemblies, wandering in the realm of **clustered mists and grand effulgence**, reciting the **melodic verses of Broad Cold**. In dreams, he roamed with **Red Pine**, and in waking moments, he indulged in the **elixir of golden ladle**. Occasionally, he met with the **True Worthies**, engaging in profound discourse on the **wondrous pivots** of the Dao. Thus, he secretly aspired to ascend on clouds, transcending the mundane and departing from the common folk.

Whenever he emerged during moments of rest or on auspicious days, he would screen out worldly affairs and diligently perform the **ritual of exorcism and purification** (挣醮). The altars were solemnly constructed, the **silken banners** fluttered in the breeze, the **dust of the world** did not dare intrude, and the **sacred visions** seemed to resonate in the air. Wrapped in fine wool, he rested for long hours, accumulating his **qi** and forgetting weariness.

In the year of **Renxi (壬戌)**, he was assigned the **imperial seal** of **Miling** (秣陵), and his heart yearned for this sacred mountain, which lay close to the capital. Soon after, he received an imperial decree, extending his commendation, and was directed to visit the **numinous soil** of the mountain, lingering in its **auspicious domain**. His spirit was at ease, and he drifted in forgetfulness of return.

A recluse named **Juzhi** (朱自英) dwelled in the fertile caves of the mountain, his abode changing with the years. The Master took pleasure in his simple and unadorned ways, as if they were a **kindred spirit of stone**. In the second year of his return to court, the recluse’s reputation had spread.

He was summoned to the capital, where the Master hosted a grand banquet and engaged him in intimate conversation, far beyond the ordinary. When the recluse returned to the mountain, the Master again made arrangements for a future visit to his **cave-dwelling abode**, their correspondence marked by deep reverence and mystery. **Juzhi** (朱自英) was astonished by this.

A few months later, the Master passed away, leaving behind words that echoed his intent: to build this **sacred structure** here. The total expenditure from his private funds amounted to **150,000**, with no additional contributions from the state.

Subsequent imperial decrees allowed **Juzhi** (朱自英) to come and go as he pleased, all in accordance with the Master’s original intentions.

According to the *Zhenzhuang* (《真诰》), the **Sententious** (句曲) land is the **Lung of the Earth**, with fertile soil and pure waters, known as the **Hua Yang Sacred Cavern** (华阳洞天), capable of **transcending the world and nurturing the people**, untouched by the **Three Calamities**. It further states that those of **utter loyalty and filial piety** would first receive **sacred commissions**, then ascend to the ranks of the **Celestial Worthies**, with their **ascensions and descents** recorded in the **registers of the dark and luminous**, akin to the **appraisal of human merit**.

Thus, the Master’s devotion to this **lofty peak** and his reverence for its **wondrous symbols** were not in vain.

Indeed, he emerged during the **Age of the Virtuous Sage** (应贤运), ascended to the **highest echelons of power**, and rendered great service to his time. His **virtue and power** were profound, and his **achievements and influence** vast. Without **embracing the numinous qi**, how could he have **aligned with the august worthies** and fulfilled his **grand mission**? Without **harmonizing with the sacred records**, ascending to the **true stages of immortality**, how could he have **manifested the vigor of the Great Peace**?

His character matched these earlier accounts, and their **mysterious resonance** was confirmed.

Ah! To **ride the winds of time**, **striving in both martial and literary pursuits**, **holding the reins of governance**, **revering the sovereign and sheltering the people**, **exhausting his wisdom and virtue**, **upholding the balance of the Dao**, **unshaken by the controversies of the age**, **radiant and awe-inspiring**, and to **end his days in glory**—then, to **shed the mundane and ascend**, joining the **Xianmen** (仙门) and **Yueye** (雇佺) **adepts**, meeting them at the **boundaries of mist and vapor**, was this not a grand and splendid fate?

Indeed, his wife **faithfully upheld the imperial mandate**, never forgetting to **pursue and honor** him. His son, **Yanliang** (寅亮), **Chancellor of the Palace**, **wholeheartedly assisted** in completing the **victorious construction**, ensuring his **exemplary legacy** would endure and forever shine in history.

It is said that **Chen Fu** (陈辅), a **disciple of the early years** who frequented the Master’s **abode of literary pursuits**, was entrusted with **commissions for writing**, and his works were inscribed upon **gold and stone**. Thus, he accepted the **honor of the imperial appointment**, though he was unworthy of such grandeur.

The Master bore the surname **Wang**, given name **Qinruo**, and courtesy name **Dingguo**. His wife bore the surname **Li**.

The lineage and official records of the Master’s **native village and clan**, along with the **sequence of his ancestral offices**, are inscribed in the **historic annals** above and **engraved in stone** below—these details are known and thus omitted here.

This inscription was made in the **second year of Regency** (庆历二年), the year of the **Tiger and Horse** (壬午), on the **twentieth day of the tenth month** (乙卯).

**Mengzi Xuan** (孟子宣), **Judge of the Daoist Temple** at **Buzheng** (句曲) and **Superintendent of the Observatories**, granted the **purple robe**, and **Leiping Hu** (雷平胡恢), **Superintendent of the Daoist Temple**, inscribed the **stele** with their brushes. **Lugong** (陆绛), a **Junior Official** and **Guardian of the Juren County** (句容县尉), was responsible for **overseeing the construction and erection** of the stone.

**Stele of the 23rd Generation Grand Master of Upper Clarity, Master of the Great Cavern, Miao Xiansheng** (幽光显扬) **of Jianyuan Temple** (乾元观妙先生) **at Mount Mao** (茅山).

**Chen Fu** (陈辅) of **Cloudyang’s Southern Suburbs** (云阳南郭) **crafted** the stele, while **Cai Reng** (蔡仍), **Scholar of the Western Mountains of the Seven Prefectures** (七闽西山), **wrote and inscribed** the epitaph.

The Master bore the surname **Juzhi** (朱氏), given name **Ziying** (自英), and courtesy name **Yinzhi** (隐芝), hailing from **Juyang** (朱阳里) in **Juqiu** (句曲).

chunks.original_text: 生八九岁，牧牛郭干村，儿曹卷芦吹茄，鞭角驰牛，陆降为戏，先生辞不能，牧儿哈焉，先生笑日：尔骑牛曷若我骑鹤？ 徐徐出笛袖问，裂竹而鹤舞空下，先生跨背，鹤腾辄坠，牧儿骇呼。 自是从牧，时能致鹤。 或谓不祥，父母遂弃之入道，师玉晨观道士朱文吉。 训笃隶业。 先生过目掩卷日：熟矣。 师盖未能，奇也。 十有一岁，度为道士，仙标玉骨，固已棱棱迥出风尘外。 先生幼生村野，未始目吾儒经史与夫道家仙籍，问焚香诵六经、百子、三乘三十六部，一表衰不绝口，四远老人夙学，愿见眉宇。 先生坐一室，闭目温绎，听者按无一字遗。 及长，把笔为文章，混然天成，尤精风雅，句句警策，发药契经，如空洞之音焉。 金陵牧马公亮遣吏持书，置而弗问，其师恐，告以未善，先生日：不然，劳我矣。 自尔，偕明真张炼师绍英，扪萝上积金峰，密天市坛宠火院而栖。 二人却谷，以至骨立，餐沆尘，奔三景，修仪璘当佩之法，以速轻举。 居无何，户外之屦满，顾谓张日：如何，比期绝边而蹑我众，不泰多事乎。 张日：子勿膻，人将掷子之不暇，如其膻天下，断有不嗅者，何必行。 先生日．．一住一行，亦各其志，奚必同。 於是旦迭坛而夕渡江，将拜混元於毫社，礼天师於青城。 方其历关而西抵剑门，道逢一叟，修臂鹤发，方目犊瞳，踞坐咄曰：少冠奚自？ 日：自华阳。 复而日：奚适？
