chunks.original_text: 然念帝王奉道，乃与臣庶不同，一言一动，上合天心，则万方蒙福。 幸毋以华丽荡真，以亏圣典。 太上五千言以去奢、去泰、慈俭为先，乃陛下之师宝、致道之津梁也。 伏愿陛下清心寡欲以保圣躬，节财俭用以固邦本，听纳忠良以广言路，天下幸甚。 如臣下愚，固不当冒死#11陈词，实念先师付托之重，尝令臣以尽忠报国为先。 当今之际，不进一言以裨圣德，则臣违天负师、抱恨泉#12壤矣。 臣传宗法录、真经玉印、及陛下前后所赐书画，并已付本宫徒弟俞希隐收掌讫，更愿陛下重念先师扶教宣道之心，曲垂恩佑，终始无替於宗门，则臣虽不获再瞻#13天颜，死#14无憾矣。 操笔陈情，伏增感怆，臣诤之再言押。 冲隐先生墓志铭 检校少保、镇东军节度使、开府仪同三司中、太一官使兼侍读修国史臣蔡卞奉劫撰并书。 先生氏竺，名净之，字清远#15，金陵人。 父得一，少不事事，晚好道术，乡里号笞一翁。 余杭有杜道士者，自匿其名，常从翁游。 先生方在娠，一□ 日，翁夙兴见杜道士入其门，俄失所在，心异之，有顷先生诞焉。 先生生而淳澹，识度深远，幼不．茹荤，六七岁，日诵书数百言，从草儿嬉，辄画地为道家像。 父携之游茅山，时静一先生刘混康结茅积金峰，一见称之日：是子他日人天师也。 示之以轻举之法，先生跃而大喜，愿留师事，誓不复归，父亦欣然许之。 服勤左右累年。 王安石闲居金陵，闻静一高行，遣书致礼邀之。 先生奉杖屦以从，试与之语，率皆造理，屡称善焉。 元佑中，臣守宣城，静一遣先生持书过之，馆之后园西室，前有华果。 林木迭蟑楼台之胜，近俯城市，远望百里问，而先生终日静坐，未尝出门，心窃奇之，乃出缙钱度为道士。 先生志益精笃，静一悉以三洞经界之。 书符呎水以弥疾除邪，率多验。 盖累年之问，尽得静一之道，深居山林之幽，而声名暴着一时。 哲宗皇帝在宥天下，搜求道卫之士，首召静一来朝京师。 从师入见，顾其貌，异焉，锡师名以宠之。 元符初，赐所庐为观，号元符。 今天子躬体妙道，以临万邦，命守臣敦遣静一造朝，勿听其有所辞。 先生与之俱来，礼遇尤至，劫有司大新厥字，亲书宫名以赐，更号守静法师，领住持事。 又明年，复召入朝，暨进见，弟子从行者皆有恩数及之。 久之，得请还山，又加号凝和，赐御书画以宠其行。 大观四年，复至自茅山，天子命即所馆建坛席，俾倡其教以示学者，遣中使责之，缙绅士大夫多从听受，复固辞还山。 上更以御书及画静一遗像付之。 先是，九幽黄录久废，世罕道者，先生发明之，二科仪式方大显於时。 凡深山绝娇，学者栖处其问，时或淫雨积雪，径路阻绝，先生必亟往饷之。 岁稍不登，辄令臧田租之入，以麋粥食饥者，不幸俘婵，衣袅座之。 居数年，一日召其徒，谓之日：吾今年四十有六，昔吾先师记吾之数不逾於此，吾将化矣。 荷国重恩，不得面见天子，乃索笔自草遗表以闻。 翌日，具汤沐，易衣冠而逝，时政和三年七月三日也。 表闻，天子嗟悼，诏赠冲隐先生，责之缙钱。 以其年十一月封穷于大茅峰之阳华盖峰下，受业弟子数十人，其上首日傅希列、徐希和#16。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet reflecting upon the Dao of emperors and rulers—
it differs from that of common subjects.
Every word and deed, if aligned with Heaven’s will,
brings blessings to all under the heavens.

May Your Majesty not be swayed by superficial splendor,
lest it undermine the sacred traditions.
The *Tai Shang Kan Ying Ping* of five thousand words
prioritizes frugality, simplicity, and benevolence—
a guiding treasure and the bridge to attaining the Dao.
I humbly pray Your Majesty may preserve Your sacred person
by purifying the heart and curbing desires,
strengthen the nation’s foundation through moderation in wealth,
and broaden the path of counsel by heeding loyal ministers.
The realm would be most fortunate.

Though my wisdom is meager, I dare not presume to risk my life
in offering these words.
Yet I recall my master’s solemn charge,
who bade me prioritize loyalty and service to the state.
At this critical juncture, if I fail to speak even a word
to aid Your Majesty’s virtue,
I would betray Heaven, betray my master,
and carry my regret to the grave.

I have already entrusted the *Zongfa Luju* scrolls,
the *True Scripture* seals, and Your Majesty’s
previous and later gifts of calligraphy and paintings
to my disciple, Yu Xiyin, for safekeeping.
I further pray Your Majesty, in remembrance of my master’s
devotion to teaching and propagating the Dao,
may extend Your grace and protection to our lineage,
so that even if I never again behold Your face,
my death will be without regret.

As I pen these words, my sorrow deepens.
I, a loyal subject, have spoken again—
**Eulogy for Master Chongyin**
Composed and inscribed by the humble servant Cai Bian,
*Jianjia Shaobo, Zhengdong Jun Jiedu Shi, Kaifu Yitong Sansi,
Taiyi Guan Shi* concurrently serving as *Shiren Xiuguo Shi*.

Master Chongyin’s given name was Jingzhi,
with the courtesy name Qingyuan,
a native of Jining.

His father, Deyi, was a man of idle youth
who later took to Daoist arts,
earning the nickname *Chi Yi* Old Man among his neighbors.
A Daoist from Yuhang, who concealed his true name,
often visited him.

When Master Chongyin was still in the womb,
one day, his father rose early and saw the Daoist enter their home,
only to vanish moments later—
a strange occurrence that filled him with wonder.
Soon after, Master Chongyin was born.

From birth, he was pure and unadorned,
with profound insight and discernment.
As a child, he abstained from meat,
and by age six or seven, recited hundreds of words daily.
While playing with grasshoppers, he would sketch Daoist figures on the ground.

His father took him to Mount Mao.
At the time, Master Jingyi Liu Hunkang had secluded himself on Jijin Peak,
and upon seeing him, declared:
*“This child will one day become a Celestial Master.”*
He taught him the *Qingju* methods,
and Master Chongyin leapt with joy, vowing to stay as his disciple
and never return home—
his father, delighted, agreed.

He served diligently at his master’s side for years.
When Wang Anshi resided in Jining,
he heard of Master Jingyi’s virtuous conduct,
sent a letter with gifts to invite him.
Master Chongyin carried his staff and sandals to meet him,
and in their conversation, his words always struck the essence.
Wang Anshi repeatedly praised him.

During the Yuanyou era,
when I governed Xuancheng,
Master Jingyi sent Master Chongyin with a letter.
I lodged him in the western chamber of my rear garden,
where fragrant fruits hung before him.
Though the garden boasted layered pavilions and towering trees,
overlooking the city and stretching for a hundred *li*,
Master Chongyin sat in silence all day, never leaving his room—
I marveled at this, and so I initiated him into Daoist ranks.

His resolve grew ever deeper,
and Master Jingyi entrusted him with the *San Dong* scriptures.
He inscribed talismans to heal ailments and dispel malevolence,
and his methods were often verified.

Over the years, he mastered his teacher’s entire Dao,
retiring to the secluded mountains,
yet his reputation spread swiftly in his time.

When Emperor Zhezong ruled with benevolence,
seeking Daoist sages to protect the realm,
he first summoned Master Jingyi to the capital.
When Master Chongyin entered the court with him,
the emperor studied his appearance with interest
and bestowed upon him the title of *Shi* as an honor.

At the start of the Yuanshu era,
he was granted his residence as an observatory,
named *Yuanshu Guan*.
When the present emperor personally embodied the Dao
to govern the lands,
he commanded me to urgently invite Master Jingyi to court,
forbidding any refusal.

Master Chongyin accompanied him,
and the honors bestowed upon him were extraordinary.
The officials were ordered to enlarge his nameplate,
and the emperor himself inscribed his title as a gift,
further bestowing upon him the title *Guardian of the Dao* (*Shoujing Fashi*)
and appointing him as the abbot.

The following year, he was summoned again to court,
and when he presented himself, his disciples who accompanied him
were also granted favors.

After some time, he requested permission to return to the mountains,
and was further honored with the title *Ninghe*,
along with imperial calligraphy and paintings as parting gifts.

In the fourth year of the *Daguan* era,
he returned from Mount Mao,
and the emperor commanded that an altar be erected at his lodging,
so he might expound his teachings to the scholars.
A court official was dispatched to oversee the matter,
and many officials and scholars attended to receive his instruction.
He again firmly declined and returned to the mountains.
The emperor then gave him imperial calligraphy and a painted portrait of Master Jingyi.

Previously, the *Jiuyou Huanglu* had long been neglected,
and few practiced the Dao.
Master Chongyin revived it,
and the rituals of the two *Ke* systems flourished in his time.

Whenever disciples resided in remote, inaccessible mountains,
if heavy rains or snow blocked the paths,
Master Chongyin would urgently bring them supplies.
In years of famine, he would divert the taxes from his fields
to feed the hungry with millet gruel.
If a captive or prisoner passed by, he would clothe and feed them.

After several years, one day he gathered his disciples
and said:
*“I am now forty-six years old.
My master once recorded that my lifespan would not exceed this.
I am departing.”*
Though he bore the nation’s heavy gratitude,
he could not face the emperor in person,
so he took up his brush to draft a farewell memorial.

The next day, he bathed, donned his robes,
and passed away—
on the third day of the seventh month, *Zhonghe* era.

When the memorial reached the emperor,
he mourned deeply and posthumously bestowed upon him
the title *Chongyin Master*,
granting him official honors.

In the eleventh month of that year,
his remains were interred beneath Huagai Peak,
on the southern slope of the Great Mao Peak.
His disciples numbered over forty,
with Fu Xilie and Xu Xihe as the foremost.

until I reached Master Cheng.

Truly, it is Master Yang.*

offered him a title of merit,
and summoned me to speak before him.

*Though his form has passed,
his spirit ever ascends—
the remaining threads of his teachings,
are recorded in this very epitaph."*

*Mount Jiuqu, the sacred domain of the Three Teachings,*
*its divine halls and towering structures,*
*soaring and resplendent,*
*outshine all of Jiangzuo’s thousands of leagues.*

The **Fusion-of-Spirit Hall** lies within,
its groves and caves concealed,
its **qi** profound and steady—
a fitting abode for lofty recluses and free-spirited sages.

In the *Genghai* year of the *Shaoxing* era,
the temple’s officiant, Daoist Zhang Zhen of the *Mao* Peak,
with his disciples, dwelt beneath the central peak,
built a hermitage on Mount Mao,
casting aside worldly distractions,
nurturing the spirit and preserving its radiance,

his refined essence stood firm as the mountain,
his spiritual prowess rose pure as jade.
Gazing upon him,

chunks.original_text: 既见，上顾劳甚宠，解御服以赐，且命图形於神仙阁，固请还山。 先生起草莱，受知圣明，前后六至阙下，壬午视师，亦赐对于行在所，每见加厚。 初，太上皇欲易庵为观，先生辞以有观额则事烦，非幽居之宜，故止赐今名，实乙亥六月也。 庚辰岁，建三清殿，像设供具，皆上方所制。 其后以行宫赐银建天祥阁，奉藏宸翰，又为层屋，置内府赐钟。 云汉在上，光被草木，宝器所镇，神鬼守护。 凡二纪责锡，悉充栋宇费，斋库庖淄，位置不渎，於是丰约中度，规制具体矣。 乾道壬辰，赐田三百三十亩有畸，仍命漕浙除其税，德至渥也。 居之高下，皆因其山之势，妥帖邃密，不晦不露，白云峰拥其左，小峰拱其右，面抱赤山，大罗源平远当胸，而升元顶亦逐逐在目也。 紫翠环绕，四山如屏，晨光陆离，篆影浚乱。 宵籁闲寂，琴声清圆，恍若与尘世隔。 匹夫而能动冕旎之高听，享山林之至乐，其必有以也夫。 噫，老佛之教，与孔氏鼎立，后世纷纷，矛盾异同，真人御辩，融三为一，恭己正南面，而儒术行於天下，刑政修，礼乐兴，二家翼之，使民心一於为善。 熏陶渐渍，风俗淳厚，兵寝刑措，日跻仁寿之域，庸非助乎！ ．先生访对之际，言不得闻，若夫方士诬虚之说，治道清静之要，将奚择焉？ 天实闻之矣。 其能动高听，享至乐，宜哉。 先生，常州晋陵人。 少为人也，名行义，字达道，度为道士，改今名，而世先以其字行。 既殁之．九年，住庵弟子茅见独以仆畴昔与先生有一日之雅，而与其兄王见志从游荆溪之上垂四十年，属为之记，故独取其庵之颠末，系於兴创者，识之。 其被遇两宫、荣宠光显，当有纪录，以侈眷异，兹不具载云。 淳熙十年九月朔，朝散大夫新权发遣处州军州事、赞皇李处全记并书。

The emperor, upon seeing him, bestowed great favor and labored to honor him, removing his own imperial robes to bestow them, and further commanding that his likeness be painted in the **Divine Immortal Hall**. Yet Zhang Zhen firmly requested to return to the mountain.

The master, rising from obscurity, gained recognition from the sage-emperor. Over six times he came to the imperial court—once in the *Rénwǔ* year to inspect the troops, and again summoned to the traveling palace for an audience, each time receiving ever-greater honors.

Initially, the **Empress Dowager** wished to transform his hermitage into a grand observatory, but Zhang Zhen declined, stating that such a title would bring official burdens, unsuited to his secluded life. Thus, only the current name was bestowed in the sixth month of the *Yǐhài* year.

In the *Gēngchén* year, the **Three Pure Ones Hall** was constructed, with statues and ritual furnishings all crafted by imperial artisans. Later, a silver-funded **Heavenly Auspicious Pavilion** was granted as a traveling palace, enshrining imperial calligraphy, and a tiered pavilion was built to house a bell from the inner treasury. Its radiance descended like clouds upon the earth, its sacred vessels warding off spirits, and celestial guardians standing watch. Over two decades of imperial bestowals, all funds were devoted to halls and shrines, granaries and kitchens—each in proper order, neither extravagant nor meager, their designs precise and harmonious.

In the *Buqian* year of the *Jiāndào* era, three hundred and thirty *mǔ* of land were granted, with the tax exemption for the *Hángzhōu* and *Zhè* regions—his virtue was indeed profound.

His dwellings, high and low, followed the mountain’s contours, fitting yet secluded, neither hidden nor exposed. The **White Cloud Peak** embraced his left, the **Small Peak** bowed to his right, while **Red Mountain** cradled him in front, the **Great Luo Spring** stretching far before him, and the **Ascension Peak** visible in the distance. Purple and emerald hues encircled him, the four mountains like screens, morning light dappled and shifting, while evening breezes carried the pure, round tones of the *qín*—as if severed from the world of dust.

A humble man yet able to move the emperor’s lofty ears, to enjoy the supreme delights of mountain and forest—truly, he must have possessed such virtue!

Ah! The teachings of the **Old Sage** and **Buddha** stand alongside Confucius, their doctrines clashing and converging in later ages. The **True Person** harmonizes the Three into One, governing with rectitude and facing south in authority, while Confucian learning spreads across the land, laws refined, music and rites flourishing. The two traditions support it, guiding the people’s hearts toward goodness. Through gradual cultivation, customs grow pure and thick, wars cease, punishments abandoned, and the realm ascends toward the domain of **Ren and Longevity**—how could this not be his contribution?

During their audiences, Zhang Zhen spoke little, yet his words on **Daoist adepts’ deceit** and the **principles of governance through stillness**—what choice did the emperor have but to heed them? Heaven itself must have listened.

That he could move the emperor’s ears and enjoy such bliss—how fitting!

The master hailed from **Jìnlíng**, **Chángzhōu**. In his youth, he bore the name **Yì** and the virtue-name **Dádào**, later taking the Daoist precept and adopting his present name, though the world still knew him by his virtue-name.

Nine years after his passing, the hermitage’s disciple **Máo Jiàn**—who once shared a day’s intimacy with the master and, with his brother **Wáng Jiànzhì**, wandered the **Jīngxī** streams for forty years—entrusted me to record this account. Thus, I have gathered only the hermitage’s latter days, linking them to its founding, and inscribed this.

His honors from the two palaces, his glory and favor, would warrant a full chronicle—yet to dwell on such singular grace, I omit it here.

Recorded and inscribed by **Lǐ Chǔquán**, *Cháosàn Dàfū*, newly commissioned to oversee **Chǔzhōu Military Prefecture**, on the first day of the ninth month, *Chúnxī* 10.

chunks.original_text: 嘉定皇后受录之记 皇帝妙毓至神、钻承大统，薄海内外，晏然无事。 皇后道合坤宁，光齐日耀，弥纶帝德，辅赞化原，而内助余闲，贵道清静，宅心虚白。 乃嘉定庚午午节，命左街监义臣上官德钦，缄封宝黑，肃将中旨，用章献明肃皇后故事，至华阳洞天上清宗坛，传受大洞毕法宝录、金龙玉璧、质信礼仪，罔不毕备。 上清经录宗师臣薛汝积实临坛度师。 臣汝积恭承教令，洁己斋心，驰诚南岳，结想上灵，建置玉录道场、罗天大醮，广修斋设，延供羽衣。 是夕，玉绳金波，昭回游汉，祥讽瑞霭，纷郁宫庭。 翼日，笙鹤翱翔，飞舞呈瑞，灵芝异草，迭产於林炯问。 四方来观，莫不敬叹，琦欤盛哉！ ．臣先觉曩以微贱遇孝宗皇帝，蒙恩放还山林，与臣汝积从游，目击盛事，欣喜踊跃。 窃考经录之自来，求流传之所在，巍巍至妙，荡荡难名，诚求道之津梁，登真之道路。 至於光显流衍，嘱付帝后，俾承天而行，与道合真，则我朝之盛，又非前代所及也。 气结九天，自然成文，火炼太空，皇人按笔，此宝录所由始也。 太平下教，小有天王，紫虚元君，流播人问，此宝录所由传也。 元君初降句曲，命杨羲以隶古定其文，传上清仙翕许剑宝岌琅函，凤罗金钮，割敌有仪，盟誓甚重，得之者，必名书金简，自在丹台，苟非其人，不在此族。 历代帝后，佩服崇尚，用以延洪祚，用以益永年，发祥啧祉，如鼓应杆，然足以知其教，不足以见其盛也。 自元君二十二传观妙先生朱自英，是为章献明肃皇后临坛之师。 两传而至冲和先生刘混康，时在宣和，徽宗皇帝命先生总括三洞四辅，为盟传之师，仍赐白玉印以续宗坛之系。 九传而至臣汝积，又复恭遇圣后，下屈崇尊，增贲经录，其道益以光显，其事益以流衍。 圣子神孙，奕叶相承，不忘道化，用跻世於仁寿，此千载一遇，万世之下，不可尚矣。 天降其祥，地不爱宝，未足见皇天之所以眷顾我圣后者，亿万斯年，与帝并尊，为天下母，此降精三境，流光十极，付嘱於#17我圣后者，其在兹乎！ 恭惟皇后殿下，聪明天禀，慈慧日隆j 百神敷佑，瑞气腾空，国家宝历过期，流芳亿兆之祥也。 臣不敢自默，敬为之记，姑录始末，不敢为文。 嘉定三年庚午岁，五月十有六日，右街道录凝神斋高士臣刘先觉拜手稽首恭记。 临坛保举师、太上灵宝无上洞玄法师、元符万宁宫知官、冲妙大师臣任元阜，监度师阀、临坛度师茅山经签三十四代嗣教宗师、上清三洞法师、管辖元符万宁官明一大师、赐紫臣薛汝积、承议郎、知建康府句容县事、兼管内劝农营田公事、臣朱拱臣建并书。 白云崇福观记 徽猷阁学士、正议大夫、提举佑神观、兼太子詹事、兼修国史、兼实录院修撰戴溪撰，朝奉郎、守起居郎、兼国史院编修官、兼实录院讨官、兼侍讲黄中书，正奉大夫、守吏部尚书、兼修国史、兼实禄院修撰、兼太子詹事曾映篆额。 句曲江左名山，洞天福地，以茅君隐而仙，是称茅山。 有积金峰当西一面，积金之支，右转而特起者，白云之峰也。 道俗相传，尝见其草木后凋J 烟霞在望，然束西两山，灵宫阀宇，各奠所宜，兹旷弗卜，顾有待耶？ 绍兴中，华阳道士王景温披榛棘，凿岩崖，室于峰之下。
chunks.translated_text:
**Record of the Transmission to Empress Jiādìng**

The Emperor, of wondrous and divine virtue, pierced the Great Dao and inherited the Mandate. Within the Four Seas, both near and far, all was tranquil and without strife.

The Empress harmonized with the **Kūn** (Earthly) Principle, her radiance rivaling the sun and moon. She wove the Emperor’s virtue, assisted in the transformation of the world, and as his inner helpmate, she remained in leisure, cherishing the Dao and cultivating stillness, her heart pure and white.

On the **Jīadìng Rénwǔ** (Regency) year of **Gēngwǔ** (1200), the Emperor commanded **Yìchén Shàngguān Déqīn**, Left Street Overseer, to seal a black jade tablet with imperial edict, solemnly conveying the decree to follow the precedent of **Chángxiàn Míngsù Empress**, and proceed to **Huáyáng Dòngtiān**, the **Shàngqīng Zōngtán** (Supreme Purity Altar), to receive the **Dàdòng Bìfǎ Bǎolù** (Great Cavern’s Secret Law Transmission Scroll), the **Jīnlóng Yùbì** (Golden Dragon Jade Tablet), and the **zhìxìn lǐyí** (sincere ritual observances)—all without omission.

The **Shàngqīng Jīnglù Zōngshī** (Supreme Purity Scripture Transmission Master), **Xué Rǔjǐ**, presided over the altar and transmitted the precepts.

I, **Rǔjǐ**, reverently obeyed the imperial command, purified my body and mind, and with sincere devotion, journeyed to **Nányuè** (Southern Peak), focusing my thoughts on the **Shànglíng** (Supreme Spirit). I established the **Yùlù Dàochǎng** (Jade Register Ritual Ground) and the **Luótiān Dàjiào** (Celestial Net Great Offering), broadly conducting fasts and sacrifices, summoning the **Yǔyī** (Feathered Robes).

That night, the **Yùguǒ Jīnbō** (Jade Strings and Golden Waves) shimmered, their luminous traces lingering like the Han dynasty’s celestial apparitions. Auspicious omens and sacred mists filled the palace courts in abundance.

The following day, **shēnghé** (mythical birds) soared and danced in celestial display, while **língzhī** (sacred mushrooms) and rare grasses sprouted in the bright groves. All who came from afar to witness were moved to reverence and awe—how splendid and resplendent!

I, **Xiānjué** (Prior Awakening), once of humble station, was graced by **Emperor Xiàozōng** with the favor of returning to the mountains. I wandered with **Rǔjǐ**, witnessing these grand events, my joy unbounded.

In examining the transmission of these scriptures from antiquity, seeking where their lineage persists, their grandeur is sublime and ineffable—truly the bridge to the Dao and the path to transcendence. As for their radiance and propagation, entrusted to emperors and empresses, that they might align with Heaven and embody the Dao, the splendor of our dynasty surpasses even the past.

The **qi** congealed in the Nine Heavens, forming naturally of its own accord; the **fire** refined the boundless void, and the imperial hand recorded it—thus did this **Bǎolù** (Precious Scroll) originate.

The **Tàipíng Xiàjiào** (Great Peace Edict) descended, bestowed by the **Xiǎoyǒu Tiānwáng** (Lesser Heavenly Sovereign), the **Zǐxū Yuánjūn** (Purple Void Primordial Lord), spreading among mortals—thus did this **Bǎolù** transmit.

When the **Yuánjūn** first descended to **Jùqū** (Sentence Bend), he commanded **Yáng Xí** to inscribe its text in ancient script. The **Shàngqīng Xiānxiū Xù Jiànbǎo** (Supreme Purity Immortal Xu’s Sword Treasure) was passed down in a **Lánghán** (Lantern Case) with **fèngluó jīnniǔ** (phoenix-woven golden buttons), its solemn oaths and covenants weighty. Those who received it inscribed their names on **jīnjiǎn** (golden tablets) from the **Zìzài Dāntái** (Self-Soaring Celestial Terrace). Unless one was destined, they would not belong to this lineage.

Across the dynasties, emperors and empresses revered and upheld it, using it to prolong the imperial lineage and extend their years. Its blessings were as certain as the drum responding to the rod—yet even this could not fully reveal its grandeur.

From the **Yuánjūn**, twenty-two generations passed to **Guānmiào Xiānshēng Zhū Zìyīng**, who became the **Chángxiàn Míngsù Empress’s** altar master.

Two more generations brought it to **Chōnghé Xiānshēng Liú Húnkāng**, during the **Xuānhé** era. Emperor **Huìzōng** commanded him to compile the **Sāndòng Sìfǔ** (Three Caverns and Four Auxiliaries), making him the **Mèngchuán** (Oath Transmission) Master, and bestowed a white jade seal to continue the **Zōngtán** (Altar Lineage).

Nine generations later, it reached me, **Rǔjǐ**, who once again was graced by the Holy Empress, humbly accepting her exalted trust. I augmented the **Jīnglù**, and thus the Dao grew ever more luminous, its propagation ever more vast.

The sacred lineage of imperial descendants, generation upon generation, never forgot the Dao’s transformation, ascending to **Rénshòu** (Human Longevity). This is a fortune encountered once in a thousand ages, unmatched beneath the heavens.

Heaven sent its omens, Earth did not hoard its treasures—yet this scarcely reveals how Heaven favored our Holy Empress, that for ten thousand years she might share the Emperor’s glory, becoming the Mother of All Under Heaven. This was the **Jiāngjīng Sānjìng** (Three Celestial Precincts’ descent), the **Liúguāng Shíjí** (Ten Extremes of Radiance), entrusted to her—was it not so?

In reverence for the Empress, Your Highness, whose wisdom and benevolence shine like Heaven’s decree, whose divine grace grows ever brighter—when the hundred spirits bestow their blessings and auspicious **qi** fills the sky, the nation’s sacred calendar has passed its term, and its fragrance endures for all generations.

I dare not remain silent and thus humbly record this, merely chronicling the beginning and end without presuming to compose.

**Jiādìng** **Sānnián** (1203), **Gēngwǔ** year, the sixteenth day of the fifth month. **Yòujiē Dàolù Níngshén Zhāi Gāoshì** (Right Street Daoist Registrar of Concentrated Spirit), **Liú Xiānjué**, with hands clasped and head bowed, respectfully records this.

**Líntán Bǎojiù Shī** (Altar Guardian and Recommender), **Tàishàng Língbǎo Wúshàng Dòngxuán Fǎshī** (Supreme Sacred Treasure of the Highest Cavern), **Yuánfú Wànníng Gōng Zhīguān** (Official of the Ten-Thousand-Nurturing Palace), **Chōngmiào Dàshī** (Master of Supreme Harmony), **Rén Yuánfù**, **Jiāndù Shī** (Degree Master), **Máo Shān Jīngqiān Sìshísì Dài Sìjiào Zōngshī** (Thirty-Fourth Generation Successor-Teacher of the Teachings from Máo Mountain Scripture Signet), **Shàngqīng Sāndòng Fǎshī** (Supreme Purity Three Caverns Master), **Guǎnxiá Yuánfú Wànníng Guān Míngyī Dàshī** (Master of the Ten-Thousand-Nurturing Palace), **Cìzǐ** (Purple Robe), **Xué Rǔjǐ**, **Chéngyì Láng** (Attendant of the Imperial Council), **Zhī Jiànkāng Fǔ Jùróng Xiànshì** (Magistrate of Jùróng County, Jiànkāng Prefecture), **Jiānguǎn Nèi Cuànnóng Yíngtián Gōngshì** (Overseeing Internal Encouragement of Agriculture and Farming), **Zhū Gǒng**, together inscribed this.

---
**Record of the White Cloud Chongfu Observatory**

**Huīyuán Gé Xuéshì** (Scholar of the Splendid Designs Hall), **Zhèngyì Dàfū** (Honorable Official of Correctness), **Tízhǔ Yòushén Guān** (Overseer of the Auspicious Spirit Observatory), concurrently **Tàizǐ Jiànshì** (Grand Tutor to the Heir Apparent), **Jiānguǎn Guóshǐ** (Overseeing National Histories), **Jiānguān Shílù Yuàn Xiūzhuàn** (Concurrent Compiler of the Veritable Records), **Dài Xī** (of the Dai Stream), composed this.

**Jùqū** (Sentence Bend), a renowned mountain on the **Jiāngnán** (Southern River) side, a **Dòngtiān Fúdì** (Celestial Cavern, Auspicious Land), where **Máo Jūn** (Master Máo) hid and ascended—thus it is called **Máoshān**.

There is the **Jījīnfēng** (Accumulated Gold Peak) facing west, and from its branch, a ridge rising particularly to the right—**BáiYúnfēng** (White Cloud Peak).

Folklore and Daoist tradition recount that its grasses and trees wither later than others, and its mists and clouds are ever visible. Yet between the two western mountains, the **línggōng** (sacred halls) and **yuèwū** (pavilions) stand where they ought—why has this place remained unmarked? Why awaits it still?

During the **Shàoxīng** era, the **Huáyáng Dàoshì Wáng Jǐngwēn** (Huáyáng Daoist Wang Jingwen) hacked through brambles, carved into the cliffs, and built a dwelling at the peak’s base.

chunks.original_text: 俄以行志修洁闻，乃即其居锡崇福观额，暨白金、庄田饶益之，俾展其成。 於是璧坛场、班像设，有门鼎峙，有亭晕飞，堂皇深密，廊应裹延，重楼杰阁，云层巍峨，前辟端逵，松杉行列，如盖如幢。 有赤山湖，轩豁面势，崇冈秀峦，左顾右揖，郁郁杳杳，映带清深，而居而游，如脱纷挈，如蹈仙墟。 中问方壶丈室，上亲洒翰，揭以虚静，与夫绍兴以来四朝锡予，宝镇泉石人问世事，待有大福德力作兴风云，会合殊胜，然后底乃绩。 今其徒居之，思有以称，亦反其初而已。 大林、丘山之善於人也，亦神者弗胜，然而道者托焉。 昔之为道术者，弃绝乎名势利欲，精专乎身心性命，唯恐入焉不深且密也。 待其行成，一朝蜕去，人方竞竞然持其所弃，边其所蜕，以饼蒙其隐约，鼓钟其沈潜，影响其清风素节，而冀得其人如初，乃亦甘心焉。 豢其养，尸其居，美其衣食寝处如世俗，转复为名势利欲所愚，而道术安在！ ．是山不特茅隐、二许、杨、陶之遗，地不改址，往往蓬户桑枢，霞飧梧食，托於人之所不堪顾，自有丹台绛宫、抱玉怀珠在，开白云者，必不专以外境遗子孙也。 溪之从子涎，往来山中，人境俱熟。 道士周观复，景温高弟，求记其师之功绪甚力，乃俾涎序次其见闻，因附见吾说。 观复持归，告语其徒，庶有警焉，以复其初。 嘉定四年九月望日记。 洞阳馆记
chunks.translated_text:
When Jingwen’s reputation for upright conduct and purity spread, he was granted the honor of inscribing the name *Chóngfú Guān* (Honored Blessing Hall) upon his dwelling, along with endowments of white gold and fertile fields to aid its completion. Thus, the altar platforms were erected, sacred images enshrined, and gateways raised like tripods, pavilions soaring like mist—grand and profound, corridors winding in layered embrace, multi-tiered halls and towering pavilions ascending in cloud-like majesty. A broad path was cleared before them, where pine and cypress marched in orderly ranks, like banners and canopies.

There was the **Chìshān Lake**, its expanse open and commanding, towering ridges and verdant peaks rising to either side—left and right, bowing in reverence, dense and boundless, their shadows weaving through the clear depths. To dwell or wander there was to escape the tumult, to tread upon the realm of the transcendent.

Within the **Fānghú Zhàngshì** (Square-Inch Chamber), he personally inscribed his brushstrokes, declaring the virtue of emptiness and stillness. Along with the imperial bestowals of the four dynasties since the Shàoxīng era—treasures, seals, and sacred stones bestowed upon mortals—he awaited one of great virtue and power to stir the winds and clouds, to gather the extraordinary, and thus fulfill his legacy.

Now, his disciples reside here, seeking to honor him, yet only by returning to his original intent.

The great forests and mountains benefit humanity, yet even the divine cannot overcome them. Still, the Daoists take refuge within them. Those who once practiced the Dao abandoned worldly fame, power, wealth, and desire, focusing solely on refining body, heart, nature, and life—ever fearful of not delving deeply enough. When their practice was complete, they shed their mortal forms in an instant. Yet mortals, clamoring after what was abandoned, clinging to what was cast off, plaster over their traces, ring bells at their hidden depths, and echo their pure and modest virtues, hoping to find such men as before—only to be content with this.

They feed them, shelter them, adorn their clothing, food, and dwellings as the world does, only to be ensnared once more by fame, power, wealth, and desire. Where then is the Dao?

This mountain is not merely the legacy of **Máo Yǐn, the Two Xǔs, Yáng Xióng, and Táo Yuánmíng**—its land unchanged, where thatched huts and rustic doors once stood, where meals of mist and bamboo shoots were shared in obscurity, beyond mortal notice. Yet within, the **Dāntái Gǒnggōng** (Dan Platform, Vermilion Palace) and those who embrace jade and pearls remain. Those who open the White Clouds do not confine their legacy to external trappings for their descendants.

**Xī Zhī**, a descendant of the same lineage, frequently traveled through these mountains, familiar with both the landscape and its people. The Daoist **Zhōu Guānfù**, a senior disciple of Jingwen, earnestly sought to record his master’s deeds. He thus commissioned Zhī to arrange his observations, appending his own reflections.

Guānfù returned with this account, sharing it with his disciples, hoping it might serve as a warning, a return to the original path.

Recorded on the **wǎn rì** (full moon) of the ninth month, **Jiādìng** **sìnián** (1211 CE).
**Dòngyáng Guān Jì** (Record of the Cavern of the East).

chunks.original_text: 宣和问，道士沈洞元炼大药，人知神其医而已。 侍郎王公汉之帅金陵，为人择地，乃之华阳之南、四平之北，修筑馆舍，仍旧号日洞阳，并祠其先世。 盖道书称洞阳为朱陵升度之馆，又以据洞府之阳而名焉。 思陵在御，岁遣使清真观建万道斋，斋时旱鹤翔集，盖三月十八日称鹤会始此。 淳熙初，洞元之徒皆远游，贰车王光国克承先志，为地择人。 道者王介叔草衣木食，主天市坛，遂#18邀至来洞阳。 介叔之徒日丁道存，相与刻志道业，招徕四方之士，而鹤会之盛，既无前代赐予，不在清真，而在洞阳矣。 三十四代宗师薛君汝积强以祠牒衣冠之，以表其容，众俾为善，日益不怠。 环陵推官汤乔年施田二#19顷，以续岁供，意亦以增冥福，为报本地。 其手泽付予，周防甚至。 未几，为汤后者肯获功亏，田不能久，而归洪氏。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Xuān Hé Emperor**, inquiring, learned that the Daoist **Shěn Dòngyuán** refined elixirs, and men knew him only as a divine physician.

When **Sìláng Wáng Hànzhī** led troops in **Jīnlíng**, he sought suitable land and went to the south of **Huáyáng**, north of **Sìpíng**, building halls and residences, retaining the old name **Dòngyáng**, and also enshrining his ancestors. For the Daoist scriptures speak of **Dòngyáng** as the **Jūlíng Shēngdù’s** retreat, and it takes its name from its position facing the **Dòngfǔ’s** southern aspect.

When **Sīlíng** (Emperor Gaozong) reigned, he annually sent envoys to **Qīngzhēn Guàn** to establish the **Wàn Dào Zhāi** (Ten-Thousand Dao Ritual), and during the fast, cranes would gather in flight—it was on the eighteenth day of the third month that the **Hèhuì** (Crane Assembly) first began here.

In the early **Chúnxī** era, Dòngyuán’s disciples all dispersed far and wide. **Èchē Wáng Guāngguó** alone upheld his master’s legacy, selecting both land and people. The Daoist **Wáng Jièshū**, clad in hemp and eating coarse grains, oversaw the **Tiānshì Tán** (Celestial Market Altar), and was thus invited to come to **Dòngyáng**. Jièshū’s disciple, **Dīng Dàocún**, together with him, inscribed their Daoist aspirations, attracting scholars from all quarters. Yet the splendor of the **Hèhuì**, lacking imperial favor as in past ages, was no longer held at **Qīngzhēn** but at **Dòngyáng**.

The **34th-generation patriarch, Xué Jūn Rǔjī**, strengthened the ancestral rites and ancestral tablets, preserving their dignity, and the assembly encouraged virtue without ceasing. The **Huánlíng** magistrate **Táng Qiáonián** donated two **#19** *mǔ* of land to ensure annual offerings, intending to augment his posthumous blessings and repay his native soil.

His descendants, however, proved unworthy of his merit—his land could not endure, and it was eventually transferred to the **Hóng** family.

chunks.original_text: 洪氏有名秉钧，长且贤，四中乡选，投笔高蹈，士类因以真隐称。 真隐知田之自，乃集子侄议举半入延庆饭僧，其百亩复施洞阳，若将使汤推官少偿夙愿於地下。 吁，汤君之施出於有心，而真隐未始容心，此岂周防思虑所及哉？ 洞阳既再入田，乃绍定庚寅，予偕诸侄成存道之志，为建斋寮，大隶题榜，并识始末，以传永久，且为贤不肖子孙之世鉴云。 嘉熙丁酉日南至，丹阳张提撰并书，朝奉大夫监行在左藏西库丁宗魏篆额。 宋罗天感应碑山人校遗文 元符万宁宫经藏记秦口撰
chunks.translated_text:
The **Hóng** family had a man of renown named **Bǐngjūn**, tall and virtuous, who was chosen from the four surrounding villages. He abandoned his official post to embrace the **Dao/Way** of true recluses, and thus the local scholars came to regard him as a genuine **hermit** (*zhēnyǐn*).

**Bǐngjūn** understood the origin of the land and so gathered his sons and nephews to propose dividing half of it to support the monks of **Yánqìng**, while the remaining **100 mǔ** he donated to **Dòngyáng**, as if to allow **Táng Qiáonián** to fulfill his long-standing aspirations in the underworld.

Ah! **Táng Qiáonián**’s generosity stemmed from his earnest intentions, yet **Bǐngjūn** acted without premeditation—could this have been the foresight of **Zhōufáng**?

When the land was again returned to **Dòngyáng**, it was in the year **Gēngyín** of the **Shàodìng** era, and together with his nephews, he fulfilled **Cángshén Dào**’s original aspirations, constructing an **altar hall** (*zhāiliáo*) and commissioning grand inscriptions upon the banners. He also recorded the entire history, ensuring its permanence, and thus made it a lesson for future generations—both virtuous and unworthy descendants.

In the **Jiāxī** era on **Dīngyòu** day, **Zhāng Tí** of **Nányáng** both composed and inscribed the text, while **Dàn’yáng** **Dīng Zōng Wèi** (a **Chief Librarian** of the **Left Treasury**) inscribed the seal.

The **Ròu** **Tiān’án** "Responsive to Heaven" **Stèle Master** (*Shānrén*) revised the lost text.
In the **Yuánfú** era, the **Qínkǒu** "Qin Mouth" **Scripture Librarian** (*Jīngcángjì*) recorded the inscription.

chunks.original_text: 录金石篇 元碑 华阳道院碑铭 翰林直学士、朝列大夫、知制诰同修国史元明善撰，翰林侍读学士、中顺大夫、知制诰同修国史赵孟俯书。 道家者流，有符录之法，谓能呼吸风雷，役召神鬼，或者疑焉。 天人一也，寒则体栗，暑则体燠，是形吾者天也，周吾形者无非天也。 故曰天人之际，感与应而已。 惟其人气之戾，始与天乖，愚夫愚妇，一念之烈，犹能有动，况高人德士，栖身孤厦，炼行精纯，志之所在，天必不违。 昔在世祖皇帝时，句曲许宗师来朝，有梼辄应，上异之，特诏主其诸官观，绍传符录。 许宗师将化，手印待今王君至而传之。 大德二年，淮南蝗，本道宣慰使礼请君至江都，醮而禳焉，俄而未羽者噎於雨，羽者，有惊蔽空而至，啄食之，食而复吐，吐之复啄，如是连日，蝗不为灾。 先是，早梼而雨，淮南人大骇悦，争持金帛拜而酵之，却之不退，送者填道。 归日：吾岂必夫景既哉？ 第竭吾诚以济吾法。 至於两获捷应，全活数郡者，实三茅君有相其往，且宝运方隆，不当有饿民耳。 其所酬金帛，苟蠹装之，是幸功也。 吾以别馆三君而祝厘於国，兼祀二亲以报其私，庶乎称也。 是年，遂营於元符万宁宫之束，仰抱枫轮，俯瞰金菌，山得所峙，永得所经。 限灵即秀，巧适地宜，俭不至陋，奢不瑜制，凡为屋五十余楹，象三茅君於主殿，依其考妣於翼室。 肇基讫工尽六年，号华阳道院。 至大三年夏，天子命玄教嗣师昊真人醮祀江南，始于句曲。 君出近京口，真人日：香币上所祝而手以授余，余将之无敢不恪。 暑雨方淫，请朝当抵元符，雨悼或沾，亦惟神羞。 君曰：敢敬诺。 翌日，雨垂不下，既奠香币，大雨行事，之日复止。 真人还朝，为余缕言王君如右，因为求铭华阳。 余闻王君简而章，庄而和，静方而动圆，盖有道君子也，故出言而灾弥，有梼而神彰，功成而不宰，德充而愈约。 由是制授养素通真明教真人。 夫句曲之为名山，旧矣。 高人德士，游息其问者，以其幽深隔世，嚣纷绝迩，驻灵光而资悟赏也。 既纪其事，仍系之辞，依仿步虚之声，写其闲远之思。 君名道孟，号牧斋，建康句容人，嗣四十四代宗师。 辞日： 句曲嵯峨窈昤茔，神仙所宅阀云肩。 霓旌羽盖博紫清，鲦来忽逝何杳冥。 通真真人炼元精，餐霞服气方瞳青。 栖迟阳谷吹玉笙，瑶装驻鹤昆仑庭。 镯灾弥变翼世平，扬休储庆奉天明。 远心绝物思蓬瀛，手持青芝对丹经。 琼都琳绾吾此营，大招真倡扪幽灵。 爰清爰静无劳形，无摇尔精可长生。 下观尘嚣百忧婴，醉生梦死悲短龄。 重阴无坛窥日星，有欲从之视此铭。 句曲山洞泉铭 泰定甲子岁玉虚子造。 茅山三山、罗络诸峰。 大魁小杓，象斗七宫。 上清有坛，高居其中。 山曲而容，水斯朝宗。 我修华池，内景合同。 在艮之止，塞兑之空。 丹井西注，石梁亘东。 玄师有作，兆兹灵综。 藏录玉浆，向用奚穷。 善利万物，道不言功。 福乡井铭 惟萧有台，曲水之滨，井梵不改，我思若人。 若人伊何，桐梧其俦。 禀教华阳，振迩丹丘。 百世之泽，式如金玉。 是谓正明，并受其福。 弘道坛铭 上清真人潘尊师体玄，建弘道坛于嵩之阳； 句曲外史，基石仪道，乃复古初，乃奉圣神，永作宪矩。

**Recorded in the *Mao Shan Zhi* (Teachings of the Twenty-Seventh Volume of the *Mao Shan Zhi*)**

**Upper Clarity Successor Master** Liu Dabin constructed [the temple].

---

**Record of the Golden and Stone Inscription**
*Yuan Dynasty Stele*
*Inscription of the Hua Yang Dao Yuan (Daoist Temple)*

The **Hanlin Direct Scholar, Court Official, and Keeper of the Imperial Edicts** Yuan Mingxian composed it, while the **Hanlin Attendant Scholar, Middle Order Official, and Keeper of the Imperial Edicts** Zhao Mengfu inscribed it.

The **Daoist adepts** follow the tradition of **符錄 (symbolic records)**, claiming they can summon the winds and thunders, command spirits and ghosts, and some may doubt this. **Dao/Way and humanity are one**; when cold, the body shivers; when hot, the body perspires. This is because **形 (form)** is what **天 (Heaven)** manifests, and what surrounds **形 (form)** is none other than **天 (Heaven)**. Thus, it is said that at the juncture of **Dao/Way and humanity**, there is only **感 (response)** and **應 (correspondence)**.

Only when a person’s **氣 (qi)** is perverse does it begin to diverge from **天 (Heaven)**. Even a foolish man or woman, with a single resolute thought, can stir movement. How much more so for **高人德士 (noble virtuous ones)**, dwelling in solitary halls, refining their practices with utmost purity, where their will is set—**天 (Heaven)** will never defy them.

In the time of the **World Ancestor Emperor (世祖皇帝)**, Master Xu of **Jouqu (句曲)** came to court. When he **梼 (invoked)** disaster, it **應 (responded)**. The Emperor was astonished and specially ordered him to oversee the temple rituals and continue the **符錄 (symbolic records)** tradition. As Master Xu was about to ascend, he pressed his seal upon the **待 (awaiting)** hands of the present Lord Wang until he arrived to receive it.

In the **second year of the Great Virtue (大德二年)**, locusts plagued **Huainan (淮南)**. The **宣慰使 (Commissioner of Pacification)** of this **道 (Daoist region)** respectfully invited Lord Wang to Jiangdu, where he performed **醮 (ritual exorcism)** to avert the calamity. Soon, the locusts that had not yet sprouted wings were choked by the rain, and those that had wings were struck by a sudden wind that darkened the sky. They pecked at the locusts, ate them, then spat them out—pecking and spitting in cycles over several days. The locusts did not become a disaster.

Before this, when the drought **梼 (invoked)** rain, the people of **Huainan (淮南)** were greatly alarmed and delighted. They competed to offer gold and silk, worshipping and kneading it in reverence, but he refused none, and those who escorted him filled the road. On his return, he said: *“Do I truly need the rain to cease?* My sincerity alone suffices to fulfill my **法 (Daoist method)**.”

When he **二 (twice)** achieved swift responses and saved countless lives across several prefectures, it was truly because **三茅君 (San Mao Jun, the Three Venerable Masters of Mao Shan)** had guided him. Moreover, the **宝运 (auspicious era)** was flourishing—how could there be starving people? The gold and silk he received, if stored in his coffers, would be a fortunate gain. I, in my separate dwelling, pray to the Three Venerable Masters on behalf of the nation, and also worship my two parents to repay their private blessings. This, perhaps, is fitting.

That year, he thus **遂 (completed)** the construction at the **束 (eastern side)** of the **Yuanfu (元符) Hall of Ten Thousand Tranquilities (万宁宫)**, gazing upward at the **枫轮 (crimson wheel, i.e., the sun)**, downward at the **金菌 (golden fungi, i.e., the moon)**. The mountain found its proper place, and the temple was forever established. The **限 (boundaries)** of the sacred site were refined into elegance, perfectly suited to the terrain. Neither frugality led to vulgarity nor excess to disorder. A total of over fifty halls were built, with **San Mao Jun** enshrined in the main hall and their **考妣 (ancestors)** in the side chambers.

From the laying of the foundation to the completion of the work, it took six years. The temple was named **Hua Yang Dao Yuan (華陽道院)**.

In the **third summer of the Great Virtue (至大三年)**, the Emperor commanded the **Upper Clarity Successor Master (上清嗣宗师)**, the **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)**, to perform **醮 (ritual exorcism)** in **Jiangnan (江南)**, beginning at **Jouqu (句曲)**. Lord Wang traveled near **Jingkou (京口)**, and the **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)** said: *“The incense and offerings you have prayed to in court, I will now receive with my hands. I dare not disrespect them.”* As the **暑雨 (summer rains)** were relentless, he requested that the next day’s rites would reach **Yuanfu (元符)**. If the rain persisted, even a drop would be a shame to the **神 (divine)**.

Lord Wang replied: *“I dare not fail to respect your words.”* The following day, the rain barely ceased. After the offerings were made, it poured heavily during the rites, then stopped again. The **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)** returned to court and, in detail, recounted Lord Wang’s deeds as above, and thus sought an inscription for **Hua Yang (華陽)**.

I heard that Lord Wang was **简 (modest)** yet **章 (illustrious)**, **庄 (serene)** yet **和 (harmonious)**, **静 (still)** yet **动 (active)** with perfect balance. He was truly a **道君子 (Daoist noble)**. Thus, when he **出言 (uttered words)**, calamities were averted; when he **有梼 (invoked disaster)**, the divine became manifest; when his **功 (deeds)** were complete, he did not claim credit; when his **德 (virtue/power)** was fulfilled, his humility only increased. Therefore, the Emperor granted him the title of **养素通真明教真人 (Nourishing Virtue, Penetrating Truth, Illuminating Daoist Master)**.

**Jouqu (句曲)** has long been a **名山 (famed mountain)**. The **高人德士 (noble virtuous ones)** who dwell there, because of its secluded depths and worldly isolation, its tumultuous distance from the near, halt their **灵光 (spiritual brilliance)** to cultivate enlightenment and appreciation. Having recorded his deeds, I further inscribed these words, echoing the **步虚 (Ascending the Void)** hymns and capturing his **闲远 (tranquil and distant)** thoughts.

Lord Wang’s name was **Dao Meng (道孟)**, with the sobriquet **Mu Zhai (牧斋)**. He was from **Juchong (句容)** in **Jiankang (建康)**, the **四十四代宗师 (forty-fourth generation successor master)**.

**Inscription:**
*The towering and dim Jouqu (句曲) mountain,*
*Where the gods and immortals dwell beneath clouds,*
*Its purple banners and feathered canopies unfurled,*
*The carp vanish suddenly—where do they flee?*

*The **通真真人 (Tong Zhen Zhenren)** refines the **元精 (original essence)**,*
*Feasting on mist and inhaling **氣 (qi)**—his complexion now clear.*
*He lingers in **Yanggu (陽谷)**, blowing the jade flute,*
*His **瑶装 (jade adornments)** and cranes in the **Kunlun (昆仑)** courtyard.*

*When disaster looms, he spreads his wings to transform the world,*
*When peace is restored, he stores blessings for the **天明 (Heavenly Clarity)**.*

*His distant heart seeks **Penglai (蓬瀛)**,*
*Handholding **青芝 (bluegrass, i.e., sacred herbs)** before the **丹经 (Cinnabar Scripture)**.*

*At the **琼都 (Jade Capital)**, I gather these words,*
*Greatly summoning the **真倡 (True Procession)** to touch the **幽灵 (profound spirits)**.*

*Here, clarity and tranquility require no exertion,*
*No disturbance—your **精 (essence)** can thus attain **長生 (longevity)**.*

*Below, the dusty world is plagued by a hundred woes,*
*Drunkenness and death in dreams—alas for short-lived suffering.*

*In the **重阴 (dense shadows)**, no altar gazes upon the sun and stars,*
*Yet those with desire may seek this inscription.*

**Inscription of the Jouqu Mountain Cave and Spring:**
*In the **泰定甲子 (Tai Ding Jia Zi, 1324)** year, the **玉虚子 (Yu Xu Zi, Jade Void Master)** constructed [this].

**Mao Shan’s Three Mountains and the Luo Luo Peaks.**
**The Great Dipper and Little Dipper**, mirroring the **七宫 (Seven Mansions)**.
**Upper Clarity has its altar**, high and central.
The mountain bends to contain, the waters flow to pay homage.

I cultivated the **華池 (Hua Pool)**, its inner landscape harmonizing.
At the **艮 (Kan, northwest)** it stands still,
Blocking the **兌 (Dui, southeast)** void.
The **丹井 (Cinnabar Well)** flows westward,
The **石梁 (Stone Beam)** stretches eastward.

The **玄師 (Mysterious Master)** had his works,
Omen of this **灵综 (profound convergence)**.
Storing the **玉浆 (jade nectar)**, once used by **奚穷 (Qi Qiong, a legendary immortal)**.
Benefiting all things, **Dao/Way** does not speak of merit.

**Inscription of the Blessing Village Well:**
*Only the **萧 (Xiao, a surname)** has a **台 (platform)**,*
*By **曲水 (bending waters)**,*
*The well’s **梵 (sacred)** essence unchanging,*
*My thoughts turn to **若人 (such a one)**.*

*Who is **若人 (such a one)**?*
*His peers are **桐梧 (Tong Wu, legendary immortals)**.*

*He received the **教 (Daoist teachings)** of **Hua Yang (華陽)**,*
*And spread blessings to the **近 (nearby)** **丹丘 (Dan Qiu, Cinnabar Mound)**.*

*His blessings endure for a hundred generations,*
*Like **金玉 (gold and jade)**.*

*This is called **正明 (True Clarity)**,*
*And all receive its blessings.*

**Inscription of the Great Dao Altar:**
The **Upper Clarity True Master (上清真人)**, **Pan Zunshen (潘尊师)**, embodied the **玄 (Mysterious)**, and built the **弘道坛 (Great Dao Altar)** at the **嵩 (Song) mountain’s** southern slope.

The **外史 (Outer Historian, i.e., Lord Wang)** of **Jouqu (句曲)**, with **基石 (foundation stones)** aligned to **Dao/Way**, restored the ancient ways and enshrined the **圣神 (Sacred Spirits)**. Forever, he set the **宪矩 (normative standards)**.

chunks.original_text: 上清宗师刘大彬作篆镇坛，大洞法师倪天奎协诚购石。 崇禧万寿宫记 从仕郎、镇江路录事、致仕王去疾为文，前翰林学士、承旨荣禄大夫，知制诰兼修国史赵孟俯书并篆题。 华阳洞天，自三茅君以神道设教，瑞人神士不可梯接者，代有其人。 历考其问，惟隐居陶真人立馆以处高弟，所以启佑其后人者为最盛。 今之崇禧观，隐居曲林馆也。 唐贞观问，太宗以升真王真人有港藩之旧，且尝师事隐居，遂建太平观以居之，赐田与山，赡其学者，飧钱铺粟用给，所辖宫观十有．二。 宋政和三年，始分田以给之，使自养其弟子，具载山志。 宋改太平观为崇禧，揭虔妥灵，有盛无教，式克至于今日，广殿修廊，弘弘辙辙，检题牖槐之饰，婶华香火之供，千余年问，其崇奉未有如此之盛者也。 於皇三君，威神在天，阴隐默相，华阳道振，如鲁沬泗。 世有升降，道无升降，时有显晦，道无显晦，陶真人之於三君也，神交沈寥之上。 王真人之於隐居也，心授问答之间。 绵绵延延，往过来续，千载如一日。 皇元肇兴，天兵南渡，神明所扶，坛宇如故。 心远邹君道元，若造物者，拟其人为时而出，叫闻阖於九天之上。 上方偃武修文，以清静为坛，以慈俭为宇，垂意玄教，命邹君道元掌教事，尽护诸山。 厥后束涧洪君宗源、复阳杨君元澈、碧泉蔡君德溥，继继承承，用保有累朝之宠命。 皇庆初元春，南呜陈君志新入觐，上观天光於清都. 紫微之问，承九重之殊渥，荷真人之美名，上赐金栏道衣以为身章。 延佑四年，南院君私窃自念：崇禧道场自昔总辖诸山，实为上帝垂休储祉之所，不有以表章之，何以名有尊？ 乞升崇禧为宫，白之集贤诸公，以其事闻于朝。 嗣岁陛辞还山，上复降香以荣其归。 延佑六年八月二十二日，玉音自天而下，赐号日崇禧万寿宫。 玄教大宗师上卿大真大张公、嗣师掌教真人昊公兴有功焉。 是日也，荣光异气，上烛层霄，崇山峻岭，咸有矜色，真人陈志新率羽士稽首再拜於道之左，对扬休命曰：明明天子，万寿万年。 实与太元司命君自混沌瞑津开关之始。 赤明龙汉浩劫之前，俱以愿力，裁成辅相，以左右民。 虽今昔殊时，幽显异迩，其受命於皇皇后帝，则异世而同符也，於摩休哉。 既而冠巾之众，如出一口而祝之日：陈真人自隐居陶真人立馆以来，既尝为太平观矣，又尝为崇禧观矣，上赐今额，甚盛举也。 他日秉国史之笔者，系年击月击日，大书之日：改观为宫，自真人陈志新始。 其皇恩如天，将何以报塞耶，惟我真人在帝左右，必敬必恭，蚤夜以思，弼成玄功，庶其有以答君师宠绥之造，而真人亦有无穷之闻。 真人日：三君之灵也，吾皇之赐也，臣何力之有焉？ 敢不敬恭以从祝规。 延佑七年夏四月，南坞君俾去疾纪其事，以传方来。 去疾谓必有山玄卿其人，而后为新宫铭，草野之文何足以纪盛事。 辞不获命，乃举前说为之记，而又黑沐系之以诗。 日： 自有宇宙有此山，开山者谁高辛氏。 耿耿祉哉太元君，天之辅相民估恃。 曲林旧馆陶真人，潜德幽光发千祀。 山图飞上天皇家，云汉分章来万里。 煌煌崇禧万寿官，巨扁鸾飞羲献字。 凤歌鹤舞锵钧韶，山川鬼神共欢喜。 物不疵疠年谷丰，乾坤清夷风日美。
chunks.translated_text:
**Inscription of the Great Daoist Master (刘大彬) and Record of the Revered Longevity Palace (崇禧万寿宫)**

The **Upper Clarity Daoist Master (上清宗师)**, **Liu Dabin (刘大彬)**, inscribed the **Zhen (True) Seal Altar (篆镇坛)**,
while the **Great Cavern Daoist Master (大洞法师)**, **Ni Tiankui (倪天奎)**, pledged sincerity and purchased the stones in cooperation.

**Record of the Revered Longevity Palace (崇禧万寿宫):**
The **Jouqu (句曲) Outer Historian (外史)**, **Wang Quji (王去疾)**, who had once served in officialdom and later retired, composed the text,
while **Zhao Mengfu (赵孟俯)**, the former **Hanlin Academician (前翰林学士)**, **Chengyi Grandee (承旨荣禄大夫)**, and **Master of Drafting Edicts (知制诰)** who also oversaw the compilation of **national history (国史)**, inscribed and titled it in **seal script (篆题)**.

**Hua Yang (華陽) Cavern of the Dao:**
Since **San Mao Jun (三茅君)** established the **Sacred Dao (神道)** and taught here,
those who received its blessings—**divine men (瑞人)** and **spiritual adepts (神士)**—could not be counted in succession.
Each generation had its own worthy inheritors.

Examining their lineage through history,
only **Tao Zhenren (陶真人)**, the recluse, established a **hall for high disciples (立馆以处高弟)**,
and his nurturing and protection of successors were most abundant.

The **Revered Longevity Pavilion (崇禧观)** today is the **Tao Zhenren’s hidden retreat (隐居曲林馆)**.

In the **Tang Dynasty’s Zhenguan (貞觀) era (年)**,
Emperor **Taizong (太宗)** recalled that **Shengzhen Wang Zhenren (升真王真人)** had once dwelled here,
and since he had formerly been a disciple of **Tao Zhenren (隐居)**,
he built the **Taiping Pavilion (太平观)** to house him,
granting him **fields and mountains (赐田与山)**,
and providing **scholars with stipends (赡其学者)**,
**allowing them to distribute grain and money (飧钱铺粟用给)**.
Under his jurisdiction were twelve **palaces and pavilions (宫观)**.

In the **Song Dynasty’s Zhenghe (政和) year 3 (三年)**,
the **fields were divided (分田)** to support the disciples,
so they could sustain themselves—details recorded in the **mountain annals (山志)**.

The **Song (宋)** renamed **Taiping Pavilion (太平观)** as **Chongxi Pavilion (崇禧观)**,
erecting **pious and solemn altars (揭虔妥灵)**.
Though lacking in teaching, its **splendor endured (有盛无教)**,
reaching today’s grandeur—**expansive halls and refined corridors (广殿修廊)**,
**magnificent Daoist paths (弘弘辙辙)**—
adorned with **ornaments of phoenix and cassia (检题牖槐之饰)**,
**fragrant incense and offerings (婶华香火之供)**.
For a thousand years, no such **reverence and devotion (崇奉)** had been seen.

The **Three Sovereigns (於皇三君)** of the **Dao (道)**,
their **mighty and sacred spirits (威神)** dwelling in heaven,
**subtly aiding and unseen (阴隐默相)**,
made the **Dao of Hua Yang flourish (华阳道振)**,
as did **Lu (鲁)**, **Mao (沬)**, and **Si (泗)**.

Though the world has **ascents and descents (世有升降)**,
the **Dao knows none (道无升降)**;
though time has **manifestations and obscurities (时有显晦)**,
the **Dao remains constant (道无显晦)**.
**Tao Zhenren’s (陶真人)** relation to the **Three Sovereigns (三君)** was one of **divine communion beyond measure (神交沈寥之上)**.
**Wang Zhenren’s (王真人)** connection to **Tao Zhenren (隐居)** was through **heart-to-heart transmission (心授问答之间)**.

Their **lineage stretched unbroken (绵绵延延)**,
**passing from ancient to modern (往过来续)**,
as if a single day endured for a thousand years.

When the **Ming Dynasty (皇元)** first arose,
the **heavenly armies (天兵)** crossed southward,
and the **divine and luminous (神明)** supported them,
**leaving the altars untouched (坛宇如故)**.

**Zou Jun Dao Yuan (邹君道元)**, whose **mind was distant as the Dao’s essence (心远)**,
was like the **Creator (造物者)**—
a man chosen by the **Dao/Way (拟其人)** for his time,
whose **voice resounded through the nine heavens (叫闻阖於九天之上)**.
The **Upper Realm (上方)** ceased its martial ways and turned to **cultivation of the Dao (修文)**,
establishing a **seal of purity and tranquility (以清静为坛)**,
and a **dwelling of benevolence and frugality (以慈俭为宇)**.
With **intentions toward the Mysterious Teachings (垂意玄教)**,
the **Dao/Way (道)** commanded **Zou Jun Dao Yuan (邹君道元)** to oversee its affairs,
**protecting all the mountains (尽护诸山)**.
His successors—**Hong Jun Zongyuan (洪君宗源)** of **Shu Jian (束涧)**,
**Yang Jun Yuanche (杨君元澈)** of **Fuyang (复阳)**,
and **Cai Jun Depu (蔡君德溥)** of **Bi Quan (碧泉)**—
**continued the lineage (继继承承)**,
and thus **preserved the favor of successive dynasties (用保有累朝之宠命)**.

At the **beginning of Spring (元春)** in the **Reign of Hongwu (皇庆)**,
**Chen Jun Zhixin (陈君志新)** of **Nan Wu (南呜)** paid homage in court.
The **Emperor (上)** observed the **celestial light (天光)** at **Qingdu (清都)**,
**Zi Wei (紫微)**, and **received special grace (承九重之殊渥)**,
**honored with the title of True Master (荷真人之美名)**,
and **granted a golden Daoist robe (赐金栏道衣)** as a mark of distinction.

In the **Yanyou (延佑) year 4 (四年)**,
**Chen Zhixin (陈志新)**, the **Southern Pavilion Master (南院君)**,
reflected privately:
*"The Chongxi Daoist Hall (崇禧道场) has long governed all these mountains,
truly a place where the **Supreme Deity (上帝)** rests and **bestows blessings (储祉)**.
If we do not **properly honor it (有以表章之)**,
how can its **name be held in esteem (名有尊)**?
I petition to **elevate Chongxi to the rank of a palace (宫)***,
and **presented this to the scholars of the Jixian Hall (集贤诸公)**,
**submitting the matter to the court (以其事闻于朝)**.

The **following year (嗣岁)**, upon his **return to the mountains (陛辞还山)**,
the **Emperor again bestowed incense (上复降香)** to honor his journey home.

On the **22nd day of the 8th month in the Yanyou year 6 (延佑六年八月二十二日)**,
a **jewel-toned decree (玉音)** descended from heaven,
**granting the name Chongxi Wanshou Palace (崇禧万寿宫)**.

**Zhang Gong (张公)**, the **Great Daoist Master (大宗师)**, **Grand Master (上卿)**, **Great True One (大真)**,
and **Hao Gongxing (昊公兴)**, the **Successor Master (嗣师)** who oversaw the **Daoist teachings (掌教真人)**,
were instrumental in this.

On that day,
**radiant and unusual qi (荣光异气)** ascended,
**illuminating the layered heavens (上烛层霄)**.
The **lofty mountains and steep peaks (崇山峻岭)** all bore a **reverential hue (矜色)**.
**Chen Zhixin (陈志新)**, the **True Master (真人)**, led his **Daoist disciples (羽士)** in **prostrations and double obeisances (稽首再拜)** at the **left of the Dao (道之左)**,
and **responded to the Emperor’s blessings (对扬休命)** with:
*"The **illustrious Heavenly Son (明明天子)**,
may his **longevity and rule endure forever (万寿万年)**.
This **truly aligns with the primordial decree of Taizong (太元司命君)**,
from the **opening of the cosmic gate (自混沌瞑津开关)** at the **beginning of time (之始)**.
Even before the **vast and boundless cycle (赤明龙汉浩劫)**,
they **joined in aspirations (俱以愿力)**,
**crafting their roles as helpers and protectors (裁成辅相)**,
to **govern the people (左右民)**.
Though **times and circumstances differ (虽今昔殊时)**,
and **their presence may be hidden or revealed (幽显异迩)**,
their **receiving the mandate from the august Sovereigns (受命於皇皇后帝)***
is **the same across ages (则异世而同符也)**.
**Thus, let all be at peace (於摩休哉)**."

Then, the **crowds in ceremonial dress (冠巾之众)**,
as one voice, **praised him (祝之)**:
*"Since **Chen Zhixin (陈志新)** succeeded **Tao Zhenren (隐居陶真人)** in establishing the hall,
he has **first been honored as the Taiping Pavilion (太平观)**,
then **as Chongxi Pavilion (崇禧观)**,
and now **the Emperor grants this new name (上赐今额)**—
a **most splendid achievement (甚盛举也)**.
Future **historians compiling national records (秉国史之笔者)**,
when they **chronicle the years and months (系年击月)** and **days (击日)**,
will **inscribe in bold (大书之)**:
*'The transformation of a pavilion into a palace began with **True Master Chen Zhixin (真人陈志新)**.*
**How can one repay such imperial grace (其皇恩如天)**?
Only by **serving the Emperor with utmost reverence (在帝左右)***,
**ever respectful and dutiful (必敬必恭)***,
**constantly pondering (蚤夜以思)***,
and **assisting in the Dao’s grand work (弼成玄功)***,
can one **hope to answer the favor of the Sovereign’s nurturing and protection (君师宠绥之造)***,
and **thus the True Master’s name will be immortal (真人亦有无穷之闻)**.*

The **True Master (真人)** replied:
*'The **sacred spirits of the Three Sovereigns (三君之灵)** are **manifest (也)**,
and the **Emperor’s grace (吾皇之赐)** is **bestowed (也)**.
What **power do I possess (臣何力)** to repay this?*
**I dare not fail in reverence (敢不敬恭)** and will **follow the ritual norms (以从祝规)**."*

In the **summer of the 4th month in the Yanyou year 7 (延佑七年夏四月)**,
**Wang Quji (去疾)**, the **Southern Buttress Master (南坞君)**,
recorded these events for **future Daoists (以传方来)**.
**Wang Quji** believed that **only a mountain Daoist of profound insight (必有山玄卿其人)***
could **craft an inscription worthy of the new palace (而后为新宫铭)**,
and that **my humble writings (草野之文)** were insufficient to **commemorate such grandeur (何足以纪盛事)***.
Yet **he could not decline the command (辞不获命)**,
so he **composed the record (乃举前说为之记)***
and **further adorned it with poetry (而又黑沐系之以诗)***.

*"Since the **mountains first emerged with the cosmos (自有宇宙有此山)***,
who **cleared them and established this place (开山者)**?
It was **Gaoxin (高辛氏)**.
**Taizong (太元君)**, the **noble and virtuous (耿耿祉哉)**,
was the **heavenly helper and protector (天之辅相)**,
**relying on whom the people prospered (民估恃)**.
**Tao Zhenren (曲林旧馆陶真人)**, in his **hidden virtue and luminous Dao (潜德幽光)***,
**shone for a thousand years (发千祀)**.
The **mountain’s map ascended to the heavenly court (山图飞上天皇家)***,
and **divine decrees were divided across ten thousand leagues (云汉分章来万里)**.

**Magnificent Chongxi Wanshou Palace (崇禧万寿官)***,
**its grand inscriptions penned by the ancient sage (巨扁鸾飞羲献字)***,
**where phoenix songs and crane dances resound with harmonious grace (凤歌鹤舞锵钧韶)***,
**and the mountains, rivers, spirits, and ghosts all rejoice (山川鬼神共欢喜)**.

**No pestilence afflicts the people (物不疵疠)**,
and **the harvests are abundant (年谷丰)**.
**The heavens and earth are purified (乾坤清夷)***,
and **the winds and days are beautiful (风日美)**."*

**Inscription of the Great Dao Altar:**
The **Upper Clarity True Master (上清真人)**, **Pan Zunshen (潘尊师)**, embodied the **玄 (Mysterious)**, and built the **弘道坛 (Great Dao Altar)** at the **嵩 (Song) mountain’s** southern slope.

The **外史 (Outer Historian, i.e., Lord Wang)** of **Jouqu (句曲)**, with **基石 (foundation stones)** aligned to **Dao/Way**, restored the ancient ways and enshrined the **圣神 (Sacred Spirits)**. Forever, he set the **宪矩 (normative standards)**.

chunks.original_text: 皇帝怡愉奉太皇，万年亿载自今始。 元至治元年正月十有五日建 崇寿观碑 承德郎国子司业蜀郡虞集撰并书丹题额。 大茅峰之下，当华阳南洞之便门，有崇寿观者，本晋洞天馆主任敦故宅，宋元嘉十一年路太后始建坛宇。 太始中，庐陵太守孔嗣之重立，以奉曲阿高士华文贤。 齐建元二年，劝句容王文清仍立而主之，名崇元馆，武帝以太子时至焉。 唐贞观初，劝改为崇元观。 有太极元年所树碑，石完而文泯、，可识者，左拾遗孙处玄文、杨幽经书数字而已。 天宝七年，李玄静先生奉劫重修，复民百家备修茸。 宝历三年，主者有贺思宝，则因器物铭识而考见者也。 宋大中祥符七年，劫赐今名。 大元至治二年，句曲外史张君嗣真始来主之。 顾瞻方台近对南面，左峰迭玉，右引大茅之支而回合焉。 定录君喂言：大茅山下有泉水，近水口处可立静舍。 陶隐居云，近南大洞口有好流水而多石，少出便平，比有王文清居之。 则此观是矣。 乃叹日：山中馆宇，自齐、梁、唐、宋至于今，代有增益。

The Emperor, in joyful reverence for the **Grand Ancestor** (太皇),
commenced this era of **ten thousand years and countless ages** from this day onward.

In the first year of **Yuan Zhi Zhi** (元至治), on the fifteenth day of the first month,
the **Chongshou Observatory Stele** (崇寿观碑) was erected.
**Chengde Lang** and **Guozi Siyu** from **Shu Commandery**, **Yu Ji** (虞集),
composed and inscribed the text, as well as carved the inscription on the tablet.

Beneath **Damao Peak** (大茅峰), at the **southern entrance of Huayang’s South Cave** (华阳南洞之便门),
stood **Chongshou Observatory** (崇寿观), originally the residence of **Dongtian Guan’s** (洞天馆) former overseer, **Ren Dun** (任敦).
In the **eleventh year of Song Yuanjia** (宋元嘉), **Lu Taihou** (路太后) first constructed the hall and altar.

During the **Taishi era** (太始中), **Luling Taishou Kong Sizi** (庐陵太守孔嗣之) rebuilt it
to honor **Qu’e’s lofty recluse, Hua Wenxian** (曲阿高士华文贤).
In the **second year of Qi Jianyuan** (齐建元), **Juan Jucong Wang Wencheng** (劝句容王文清)
reestablished and took charge, naming it **Chongyuan Guan** (崇元馆).
The **Emperor Wu** (武帝), as **Crown Prince**, often visited it.
At the beginning of **Tang Zhenguan** (唐贞观初), it was renamed **Chongyuan Observatory** (崇元观).

There exists a stele from the **Taiji era** (太极元年), though its stone remains intact while its inscription has faded—
only the names of **Zuoxieyi Sun Chuxuan** (左拾遗孙处玄) and **Yang Youjing** (杨幽经) can be discerned.

In the **seventh year of Tianbao** (天宝七年), **Master Li Xuanjing** (李玄静先生) undertook a grand restoration,
with contributions from **a hundred families of commoners** (民百家).
In the **third year of Baoli** (宝历三年), the overseer was **He Sibaobao** (贺思宝),
whose records were later confirmed through inscriptions on artifacts.

In the **seventh year of Song Dazhong Xiangfu** (宋大中祥符), the name was bestowed as it is today.
In the **second year of Yuan Zhi Zhi** (大元至治二年), **Zhang Jun Sizhen** (句曲外史张君嗣真) first arrived to oversee it.

Gazing upon the **square platform facing south** (方台近对南面),
to the left, **peaks stacked like jade** (左峰迭玉),
to the right, the **branches of Damao Mountain** (右引大茅之支) curve and converge here.

**Dinglu Jun** (定录君) remarked:
*"Beneath Damao Mountain lies a spring, where a quiet retreat may be established near the water’s mouth."*

**Tao Yinjü** (陶隐居) noted:
*"Near the entrance of the **Southern Great Cave** (南大洞口) flows clear water amid rocks,
and after a short ascent, the land levels out—here, **Wang Wencheng** once resided."*

Thus, this observatory is indeed the place.
He sighed and said:
*"The halls within these mountains, from the **Qi, Liang, Tang, and Song dynasties** down to today,
have been successively enlarged and augmented by each generation."*

chunks.original_text: 求诸晋人之旧，惟此与玉晨许长史宅耳。 而吾所治，乃倾废隘陋持甚，岂不在我耶，於是度材鸠工，更后堂为太元殿，以复旧规，象三茅君於中，东为任、华、王、李、贺五君祠，西为陶隐居祠。 充前殿基为弘道坛，自制铭其上。 坛束为玄武祠，西为广惠祠，后为文贤讲堂，而前为都门。 门外浚古玉津池，尽受大茅南面诸原之水。 循池西南，得昭明太子读书台。 台束有井日福乡井。 福乡者，因昭明道馆名也。 出诸榛莽，着文刻石，覆之以亭，而岩洞泉石之胜，近在百步内者，皆按图表之可以观览。 泰定元年，上清四十五代宗师刘君大彬朝京师，授予始末，俾为之次第焉。 张君，昊郡人，名天雨，内名嗣真，字伯雨，别号贞居。 年二十，弃家入道，褊游天台、括苍诸名山。 ，昊人周大静先为许宗师弟子，得杨、许遗书。 张君从而以为师，悉受其说，尝从开元王君寿衍入朝，被玺书赐驿传，显受教门擢任，非其志也，即自誓不希荣进，因从三茅之招，追奉任君而下五君，为文而告之，愿毕力兹宇，所着《外史山世集》三卷、《碧岩玄会录》二卷、又《寻山志》十五卷，考索极精博云。 呜呼，自任君始居此，余数百年，才五人传焉，其自致于久远者，果何托也，岂若后世各诱门人，系以私属、如家人父子者哉？ 故宁希阔而有待。 今张君无前代赐予之助，徒草衣木食以营此，而旷然思与四方之士共为千载之期，岂非豁落丈夫也哉，予故与君为方外友，奇其能先予远举也。 故击之诗，日： 大茅南垂元气积，阴关阖扉阳洞辟。 曲穴流泉保灵宅，任君来饵黄赤石。 天一召锡太元册，曲阿受养良有择。 构宫方严自王伯，清跸临止灵响格。 虚林森爽化赫奕，福乡帝子发甘液。 不食何年丧遗臂，白云映空玉清客。 开元全盛烦百役，持节旁午致熏璧。 尔来萧条世代隔，石镜刻文土漫画。 谁其启之规古昔，句曲外史美冠乌。 研书千卷视贞白，天真景随玄系绎。 玉室金堂万无教。 茅山志卷之二十七竟 茅山志卷之二十八

「In tracing the legacy of the Jin people, only this place and the residence of the Master of Xu, Master Yuchen, remain.

Yet what I have undertaken here is to restore and expand the neglected and humble structures—is this not my responsibility? Thus, I assessed the materials and gathered the workers, transforming the rear hall into the **Great Primordial Hall** (太元殿) to revive its former grandeur and enshrine the **Three Masters of Mao** (三茅君) within. To the east, I built the **Shrines of the Five Masters: Ren, Hua, Wang, Li, and He** (任、华、王、李、贺五君祠), and to the west, the **Shrine of Tao Yinjü** (陶隐居祠).

I filled the foundation of the front hall to create the **Grand Dao Platform** (弘道坛), and inscribed a eulogy upon it myself.

To the north of the platform, I established the **Shrine of the Dark Warrior** (玄武祠), to the west, the **Shrine of Broad Benevolence** (广惠祠), and behind it, the **Literary Virtue Lecture Hall** (文贤讲堂), while at the front stands the **Main Gate** (都门).

Beyond the gate, I dredged the ancient **Jade Spring Pool** (古玉津池), collecting all the waters from the southern slopes of Damao Mountain.

Following the pool’s southwestern edge, I discovered the **Reading Platform of Master Zhaoming** (昭明太子读书台).

Beside the platform lies a well called the **Well of Fukang** (福乡井)—Fukang, as it derives its name from the **Dao Retreat of Master Zhaoming** (昭明道馆).

Clearing the thickets and wild growth, I marked the site with inscriptions and stones, sheltering them under pavilions. All the scenic rock formations, caves, and springs within a hundred paces, I surveyed and recorded them as worthy of observation.

In the first year of **Taiding** (泰定), the **Master of Shangqing**, the forty-fifth generation **Master Liu Dabian** (刘君大彬), came to the capital, and I reported to him the details of my work, so that he might approve the sequence.

**Zhang Jun** (张君), a native of the **Hao Commandery** (昊郡), was named **Tianyu** (天雨), with his inner name **Zhizhen** (嗣真), courtesy name **Boyu** (伯雨), and alternate sobriquet **Zhengju** (贞居). At twenty, he abandoned his family to embrace the **Dao/Way** (道), wandering through the renowned mountains of **Tiantai** (天台) and **Kechang** (括苍).

A man from Hao, **Zhou Dajing** (周大静), was first a disciple of Master Xu and inherited the teachings of **Yang** (杨) and **Xu** (许). Zhang Jun followed him as a teacher, receiving all his doctrines. Once, he accompanied **Master Wang Shouyan of Kaiyuan** (开元王君寿衍) to the capital, where he was honored with imperial decrees and granted courier privileges. Though elevated by his teacher’s influence and appointed to office, this was not his true aspiration. He then swore never to seek advancement, and in response to the **Three Masters of Mao’s** (三茅) summons, he descended to serve the Five Masters—**Ren, Hua, Wang, Li, and He** (任、华、王、李、贺)—composing a declaration to that effect. He vowed to dedicate his full strength to this sanctuary, and his works include *The Outer Historian’s Mountain World Collection* (《外史山世集》) in three volumes, *The Record of Mystic Gatherings at Biyuan* (《碧岩玄会录》) in two volumes, and *The Chronicle of Mountain Seeking* (《寻山志》) in fifteen volumes, all marked by meticulous research and vast erudition.

Ah! Since Master Ren first resided here, spanning nearly five hundred years, only five individuals have succeeded in transmitting the legacy—what profound dedication to the distant future is this! How unlike later generations, who merely entice their disciples and bind them through personal ties, as if they were household servants or father-son relations!

Thus, I prefer to wait for those who share my vision of grandeur.

Now, Zhang Jun has no prior imperial assistance to rely upon; clad in coarse robes and subsisting on simple fare, he labors here alone. Yet his heart is vast, and he contemplates aligning with scholars across the land to establish a foundation for the ages—is this not the spirit of a noble and magnanimous man? Therefore, I consider him a **secular friend** (方外友), admiring his foresight in reaching beyond my own.

Hence, I composed this poem in his honor:

---
**Damao’s Southern Slope**, where **Primordial Qi** (元气) gathers,
**Yin Pass** (阴关) seals its gates, the **Yang Caverns** (阳洞) open wide.
**Twisting Caverns** (曲穴) hold flowing springs, safeguarding this **Spiritual Retreat** (灵宅).
Master **Ren** (任君) comes to taste the **Yellow and Red Stones** (黄赤石).

The **Mao Mountain Chronicle** concludes its **Upper Dao/Way Sect** lineage:
The Master Liu Dabian of **Succeeding Upper Clarity** crafted *Golden Carpets* and *Jade Weavings*,
The **Poems of the Northern and Southern Dynasties** and the **Fifteen Hundred Lines of Hua Yang Stone Eulogy**,
As well as **Tao Qian’s** *River Chapters* and the **Records of Past Renown**—all bearing **Confucius’** mark.

For three nights, the **Luminous Hosts** adorned the heavens,
Two **Golden Ones** stood as earthly emblems.
The **Right Pivot**—its dwelling shifts from non-existence to existence,
In existence, it returns to emptiness.
The **Spiritual Structure** needs no craftsman,
The **Void Form** achieves success on its own.

The **Right Essence and Manifestation**—the divine essence encompasses the **Three Palaces**,
The **Five Circuits** intermingle with the **Five Colors**.
The **Yin Luster** greets the night’s wisdom,
The **Morning Essence** gazes toward the dawn’s suspension.

The **Right Form and Position**—the **Southern Peak** displays the **Mystic Cauldron**,
The **Northern Ridge** spans the **Qin Seal**.
Its **outer boundaries** embrace the **Jade Sands’** crossing,
Its **inner wheel** veils the **Hidden Circuits**.

The **Left Belt** follows the **Grove of Willow and Samphire Waters**,
The **Right** clears the **Yang Valley’s** streams.
The **soil** cradles the **Northern Darkness’** hue,
The **wells** reflect the **Phoenix Gate’s** chill.

The **Right Traces and Marks**—the **Guo Dry Banks** stand in silent vigil,
The **Jiang and Ba Distant Paths** stretch endlessly.
The **Crane Temple** sometimes offers feasts,
The **Separate Dwelling** remains in constant reverence.

The **Right Category and Affiliation**—the **Celestial Residence** knows not the earth,
The **Yue Tomb** curses the **Hidden Migration**.
The **Tree Canopy** bends in vain beneath the shade,
The **Stone Tortoise** never tasted incense smoke.

The **Right Material Paths**—the **Fruit Grove** lingers in **Nai’s** shadow,
The **Vegetable Patch** sprawls with **Xin’s** vines.
The **Glowing Reishi** can light the night,
The **Field Springs** once stirred the dust.

The **Right Gatherings**—the **Descending Guest** of **Gui Mountain**,
The **Unbridled Chariot** of **Qing Hua’s** youth.
They dined in the **True Essence Hall**,
And convened in the **Lofty and Serene Palace**.

The **Right Talents**—their **Pure Songs** soared in the **Feathered Assembly**,
Their **Long Whistles** returned with the **Cloud’s** turn.
A **Single String** held its **Graceful Tune**,
Yet **Empty Talk** found no equal.

The **Right Learning and Aspiration**—the **Pathway to the Dao** already ascends,
The **Flying Flowers** now guide the heart.

The **Right Divine Aid and Fate**—the **Spirit’s Salvation** exists as it should,
Departure or stay follows its natural course.
Why seek **Manifestation** when the heart is near?
The **Dark Path** knows its own way.

The **Right Rectitude and Fulfillment**—in the **Four Corners**, the **Jade Blade** wanders,
In **Hua Yang**, the **Hidden Dweller** takes root.
The **Seven Elements** may yet support the **Buxu**,
If **Repeated Separation** should ever resemble.

The **Right Omen and Promise**—the **Hao Cycle** will soon be complete,
The **Hai Count** not yet ended in **Ding**.
When **Tang’s** era arrives, the **Guest** comes to the **Holy Court**.

The **Right Sincerity and Hope**—engraved on the **Mystic Window**,
Inscribed at the **Bent Stage’s** gate.

Not failing the **recommendation of virtue/power**.

chunks.original_text: 山中何所有？ 岭上多白云。 只可自怡悦，不堪持寄君。 告逝篇 性灵昔既肇，绿业久相因。 即化非冥灭，在理担悲欣。 冠剑空衣影，镳辔乃仙身。 去此昭轩倡，结彼瀛台宾。 倘能踵留辙，为子道玄津。 入山寻桓清远不遇　邵陵王萧纶 荆门丘壑多，瓮牖风云入。 自非栖遁情，谁堪霜露湿。 初入山作　　　　　　怛法阖 寒谷夜将晨，置赏复寻真。 方坛垂密叶，澈水度朱鳞。 杏林虽伏兽，芝田诅俟人。 丹成方转石，炉变欲销银。 当知胜地远，於此绝嚣尘。 酬华阳陶先生　　　　　　　沈约 三清未可毡，一气且空存，所愿回光景，拯难拔危魂。 若蒙九丹赠，岂惧六龙奔？ 还园宅奉酬华阳陶先生 早欲寻名山，期待婚嫁毕。 二事虽云已，此外复非一。 忽闻龙图至，仍睹荣光溢。 副朝首八元，开壤赋千室。 冠缨曾弗露，风雨未尝栉。 呜玉响洞门，金蝉映朝日。 惭无小人报，徒叨令尹秩。 岂忘平生怀，靡盐不遑恤。 华阳先生登楼不下赠呈 侧闻上士说，尺木乃腾霄。 蕾买饼不展地，仙居多丽谯。 卧待三芝秀，坐对百神朝。 衔书必青乌，嘉客信龙镳。 非止灵桃实，方见大桩凋。 奉华阳王外兵隐居别易氏号 餐玉驻年龄，吞霞返容质。 眇识青丘树，回见搏桑日。 烂慢蜃云舒，嵚釜山海出。 答句曲先生　　　　　　范云 终朝吐祥雾，薄晚孕奇烟。 迥涧生芝草，重崖出醴泉。 中有怀真士，被褐守冲玄。 石户栖十秘，金坛谒九仙。 乘鹌方履汉，辔鹤上腾天。 唐诗 酬茅山权器　　　　　皇甫冉

---

**Mountain Retreat**
What does the mountain hold?
White clouds abound on the ridges.
Only for oneself may it bring delight,
Unfit to send to you, my lord.

**On Departure**
The nature of mind was born of old,
Green virtue long sustained.
Though transformed, it does not vanish in obscurity—
In the Dao, joy and sorrow are borne.
Crown and sword cast empty shadows,
Reins and bridle mark the immortal form.
From this bright hall of revelry, I depart,
To join the guests of Penglai’s isle.
If you can follow in my footsteps,
I will guide you to the Dao’s hidden ford.

**Seeking Master Huan in the Mountains**
*By Xiao Yao of Shaoling*
Unyielding peaks and valleys stretch in Ucing,
Where wind and cloud enter the clay-walled cell.
Unless one harbors the spirit of retreat,
Who could endure frost and dew’s relentless chill?

**Entering the Mountains**
*By Dafa He*
Morning dawns in the cold valley’s embrace,
Seeking truth after setting down my gifts.
The sacred altar droops with dense leaves,
Clear waters teem with crimson scales.
Though the peach grove hides wild beasts,
The immortals’ fields await the worthy.
When the elixir’s craft is perfected,
The furnace’s silver begins to fade.
Know this place surpasses all others—
Here, the clamor of the world dissolves.

**In Reply to Master Tao of Huayang**
*By Shen Yue*
The Three Pure Ones are not yet veiled,
Yet one breath remains—still preserved.
I wish to reclaim the fading light,
To rescue souls from peril’s grasp.
If granted the Nine Elixirs’ gift,
What fear have I of the Six Dragons’ flight?

**Returning to My Garden in Reply to Master Tao of Huayang**
Long I wished to seek the sacred peaks,
Waiting till my marriage rites were done.
Though these two tasks are now complete,
Other matters still remain undone.
News of the Dragon Chart’s arrival came,
And honor’s glow now fills my hall.
As Vice-Premier of the Eight Directions,
I open lands and grant a thousand homes.
Though my cap and sash were never shown,
Wind and rain never touched my comb.
Jade chimes resound at the cavern’s gate,
Golden cicadas gleam in morning’s sun.
Ashamed I lack the humble’s gratitude,
Yet still I bear the Lord’s high rank.
How could I forget my lifelong vow—
To spare no salt in my care for all?

**Master Huayang Riding the Tower and Not Descending**
A sage once spoke of humble wood
Ascending to the clouds’ domain.
The lotus bud, though bought with coins,
Unfolds not on the earthly plain.
The immortal’s home is rich with towers bright,
Where I await the Three Rare Herbs’ bloom,
And watch the hundred deities in court.
The black tortoise bears the sacred scroll,
The noble guest arrives with dragon reins.
Not just the spirit peach bears fruit—
Now the great *zhuang* tree withers too.

**In Farewell to Lady Yi, Master Huayang’s Outer Soldier**
Feasting on jade prolongs the years,
Swallowing mist restores the form.
Faintly I recall the Green Mound’s trees,
And see again the sun at the Mulberry’s gate.
The mirage’s slow waves stretch wide,
Mountains rise from the boiling cauldron’s tide.

**In Reply to Master Qu from Jianqu**
All day, auspicious mists exhale,
By evening, strange vapors brew.
Lofty gorges nurture rare herbs,
Layered cliffs yield the wine of life.
Within dwell men of true refinement,
In coarse robes guarding the Dao’s depth.
Stone doors hide ten arcane secrets,
The golden altar summons the Nine Immortals.
Riding the *an* bird, they tread the Han,
With crane reins, they soar to heaven’s span.

**In Reply to Master Quan Qi of Maoshan**
*By Huangfu Yan*

chunks.original_text: 南望江南满山雪，此情惆怅将谁说。 徒随草吏不曾闲，顾与诸生为久别。 闻君静坐转耽书，种树茸茅还旧居。 终日白云还自足，明年芳草又何如。 人生有怀苦不展，出入公门犹未免。 回舟早晚待春风，先报华阳洞深浅。 送陆潜夫往茅山 游仙洞兮访真官，奠瑶席兮礼石坛。 忽髻絮兮云扰，杳阴深兮夏寒。 欲回头兮挥手，便辞家兮来否。 有婚嫁兮婴缠，待归来兮已久。 送张道士归茅山 向山独有一人行，近洞应逢只鹤迎。 唯以素书传弟子，还因白石号先生。 无穷杏树绿山种，几许芝田向月耕。 师事少君年岁久，欲随毛节往青城。 送郑员外入茅山 但见全家去，宁知几日还。 白云迎谷口，流水出人问。 冠冕情遗世，神仙事满山。 其中应有物，岂贵一身闲。 送郑二之茅山 水流绝涧，终日草长。 深山暮春，犬吠鹦呜。 几处条桑，种杳何人。 山居即事　　　　　　　顾况 下泊降茅仙，萧闲隐洞天。 杨君闲上法，司命驻流年。 崎合桃华水，窗分柳谷烟。 抱孙看种树，倚杖问耘田。 世事休相扰，浮名任一边。 由来谢安石，不解饮灵泉。 崎裹桃华 崎裹桃华逢女冠，林间杏叶落仙坛。 老人方授上清录，夜听步虚山月寒。 大茅岭束新居忆亡子从真 谷乌犹呼儿，山人夕沾襟。 怀哉隔生死，怅矣徒登临。 束门忧不入，西河遇#1亦深。 古来失中道，偶向经中寻。 大象无停输，倏忽成古今。 其夭非不幸，炼形由太阴。 凡欲攀云阶，譬如火铸金。 虚室留旧札，洞房掩闲琴。 泉源登方诸，上有空青林。 彷佛通寤寐，萧寥邈微音。 软草被汀洲，鲜云略浮沈。 赦景宣迭丽，钳波响飘淋。 石窟含云巢，迢迢耿南岑。 悲恨自兹断，情尘诅能侵。 真静一时变，坐起唯从合o 思归桃华崎二首 废弃忝残生，后来亦先夭。 诗人感风雨，长夜何时晓？ 去国宦情无，近乡归梦少，庇身绝中援，甘静忘外扰。 丽景变重阴，洞山空水表。 灵潮若有信，寄谢西飞乌。 朝与佳人期，碧树坐红萼。 暮与佳人期，飞雨洒青阁。 佳人官何许，中夜心寂寞。 始忆花正开，复惊叶初落。 行骑飞泉鹿，外听双海鹤。 嘉愿有所从，安得处其薄？ 题卢道士房 秋砧响落木，共坐茅君家。 唯见两童子，门外汲井花。 空坛静白日，神鼎飞丹砂。 尘尾拂霜草，金铃摇霁霞。 上章尘世隔，看奕桐阴斜。 稽首问仙要，黄精堪饵花。 忆山中 春还不得还，家在最深山。 蕙圃泉浇湿，松窗月映闲。 薄田临谷口，小职向人问。 去处但无事，重门深闭关。 送李道士归桃华崎 人境年虚掷，仙源日未斜。 羡君乘竹杖，辞我隐桃华。 乌去宁知路，云飞似忆家。 莫愁容发改，自有紫河车。 夜中望仙观 日暮衔花飞乌还，月明溪上见青山。 遥知玉女窗前树，不是仙人不许攀。 酬韦夏卿送归茅山兼景母正字 玉帝居金阙，灵山几处朝，简书犹有畏，神理诅能超。 鹤庙新家近，龙门旧国遥。 离魂结不断，洞府一吹箫。 送顾昆归茅山　　　　韦夏卿 圣代为迁客，虚皇作近臣。 法尊

**To Lu Qianfu on His Journey to Teahill Grotto**
Southward I gaze—Jiangnan’s peaks are snowbound,
This sorrow lingers, who shall bear its weight?
In vain I follow the grass-clad clerk, never idle,
While with the scholars I’ve been long parted.
Hearing you sit in quiet, lost in books,
Planting trees and thatching reeds at your old home.
All day the white clouds drift by—enough to content,
Next year’s fragrant grasses, what will they bring?
Life’s cares press heavy, unfulfilled,
Even public doors cannot fully spare.
When will the spring wind bear my boat home?
First tell me of Huayang’s cave—deep or shallow?

---

**Sending Zhang Daoist Back to Teahill Mountain**
Alone toward the mountain, one man walks,
Near the grotto, a crane greets him alone.
Only white letters pass to his disciples,
And white stones earn him the title *Master*.
Endless peach trees clothe the green hills,
Moonlit fields await the plow’s return.
Long he served the Lesser Lord,
Now he follows Mao’s node to Qingcheng’s peak.

---

**Sending Zheng the Outer Official to Teahill Mountain**
I see your whole family depart—
Who knows when you’ll return?
White clouds greet the valley’s mouth,
Flowing waters ask of those within.
Crowns and robes cast aside,
Divine affairs fill the mountain.
There must be treasures unseen,
Why value just a body’s ease?

---

**Sending Zheng the Second to Teahill Mountain**
The stream cuts through the ravine,
All day the grass grows long.
Deep in the mountain at spring’s end,
Dogs bark, cranes cry.
Where are the mulberry rows,
Planted by whom in vain?

---

**Mountain Residence—Miscellaneous Notes**
*(by Gu Kuang)*
The Teahill Immortal descends from his thatched hall,
Serene and secluded in the hidden realm.
Yang Jun’s leisurely law ascends,
The Lord of Fate halts the flowing years.
Peach blossoms gather at the water’s edge,
Window frames the willow valley’s mist.
Holding my grandson, I watch the trees grow,
Leaning on my staff, I ask of the plowed fields.
Let worldly affairs disturb no more,
Floating fame may fade to one side.
From old, like Xie Anshi,
He never sought the elixir’s spring.

---

**Peach Blossom Ravine**
At Peach Blossom Ravine, I meet a maiden’s veil,
Between the trees, apricot leaves fall on the altar.
An elder hands down the *Upper Purity Register*,
Night’s step on the Void Mountain—chill as moon.
*(Note: "Upper Purity" refers to Daoist scriptures of high attainment.)*

---

**New Dwelling on Great Teahill Mountain, Remembering My Lost Son Who Followed the Dao**
The valley raven still calls for my child,
The mountain man weeps at dusk.
Across life and death, my heart aches,
In vain I climb these heights.
The gate is barred with sorrow,
West River’s grief runs deep.
From ancient times, the Middle Way was lost,
Only in scriptures do we seek it now.
The Great Symbol never ceases,
Swiftly it shapes past and future.
His early death was no misfortune,
His body refined by the Dark Yin.
Who would dare climb the Cloud Stairs,
Like gold forged in fire?
The empty hall keeps his old notes,
The grotto’s room hides his idle lute.
Spring’s sources rise at Fangzhu’s peak,
Above, the empty green pines.
As if dreams and waking merge,
The faint, lonely sounds drift.
Soft grass covers the riverbank,
Fresh clouds hover, light as mist.
The sun’s farewell paints the scene anew,
Waves clasp the shore in rippling cries.
The stone cave cradles a cloud’s nest,
Far off, the southern peak stands lone.
Grief and regret now sever,
No dust can stain this stillness.
True quiet shifts in an instant,
Sitting or rising, all is one.

---

**Two Poems on Returning to Peach Blossom Ravine**
A wasted life, now broken,
Later years may fade as swiftly.
Poets lament the wind and rain,
When will the long night end?
No ties to the court’s affairs,
Few dreams of home’s return.
No aid in midlife’s struggles,
I choose stillness, forget the world’s noise.
Fair scenes turn to heavy shade,
The grotto’s mountain stands alone.
If the spirit tide bears word,
Send thanks to the west-flying crow.

---
**The First Poem:**
Morning, I meet my beloved beneath the green trees,
Seated where blossoms blush.
Evening, I wait for my beloved,
Rain flies, drenching the green pavilion.
Where is my beloved’s home?
Midnight’s heart is lonely.
I recall the flowers just opening,
Now shocked to see the leaves fall.
Riding through the deer’s spring stream,
Outside, the twin seas’ cranes call.
My wishes have their source,
How can I dwell in such thinness?

---
**The Second Poem:**
*(as above)*

---

**Inscribed on Lu Daoist’s Chamber**
Autumn’s pestle echoes on the fallen wood,
Sitting with the Teahill Master.
Only two boys stand outside,
Drawing water where the flowers bloom.
The empty altar basks in white daylight,
The divine tripod sends phoenix sand aloft.
Dust trails sweep the frost-kissed grass,
Golden bells chime in the clear, high sky.
The chapter above separates from the mundane,
I watch the chessboard’s shade slant.
Bowing, I ask of the Dao’s essence,
Yellowroot’s flower may be my feast.

---

**Recalling the Mountain**
Spring returns, yet I cannot return,
My home lies deepest in the hills.
The orchid garden’s spring is damp,
Moonlight maps the idle window’s pane.
My small fields border the valley’s mouth,
My humble duties I ask of others.
Where I go, there is no strife,
Heavy gates lock the secluded path.

---

**Sending Li Daoist Back to Peach Blossom Ravine**
Wasted years in the human realm,
The Dao’s source still waits.
Envy your bamboo staff,
As you leave, hidden in Peach Blossom’s shade.
The crow departs—does it know the way?
Clouds fly, as if they remember home.
Do not fret over changing hair,
The Purple River’s elixir remains.

---

**Midnight Gazing at the Immortal’s Observatory**
At dusk, the crow returns with flowers in its beak,
Under moonlight, the green mountains rise.
I know the jade maiden’s window trees,
Only immortals may climb.

---

**In Reply to Wei Xiaqing on His Return to Teahill Mountain, Also Commemorating Lady Jing’s Name**
The Jade Emperor dwells in the Golden Gate,
To which sacred peaks does he pay homage?
His edicts still strike fear,
Yet divine logic transcends even that.
The Crane Temple’s new home is near,
The Dragon Gate’s old land lies far.
My departing spirit lingers,
The grotto’s flute plays on.

---
**Sending Gu Kun Back to Teahill Mountain**
*(by Wei Xiaqing)*
In this sacred age, you are exiled,
The Void Sovereign makes you his minister.
The Law is revered,

chunks.original_text: 称大洞，着作已受上清毕法学浅忝初真。 夏卿初受正一鸾凤文章丽，烟霞翰墨新。 羡君寻句曲，白鹄是三神。 奉同　　　　　　　　泰母诚 谪宦闻尝赋，游仙便作诗。 白银双阙恋，青竹一龙骑。 先入茅君洞，旋过葛稚陂。 泠＃２然列御寇，五日有还期。 答赠木耳一名树鸡　　韩愈 软湿青红状可猜，欲烹还唤木盘回。 想君直入华阳洞，割取乖龙左耳来。 刻溪逢茅山道士　　　　张籍 茅山近别刻溪逢，玉节青毛十二重。 自说年年上天去，罗浮最近海边峰。 赠茅山杨判官 应得烟霞出俗心，茅山道士共追寻。 闲怜鹤貌偏能画，暗辩桐音自作琴。 长啸每来松下坐，新诗堪向雪中昤。 征南幕裹多宾客，君独相知最校深。 寄华阳孙炼师三首　　李德裕 何地最鲦然，华阳第八天。 松风清有露，萝月#3静无烟。 乍警瑶坛鹤，时嘶玉树蝉。 欲驰千里思，唯恋凤门泉。 石上溪荪发紫茸，碧山幽蔼水溶溶。 莒花定是无人见，春日唯应羽客逢。 独寻兰渚玩迟晖，闲倚松窗望翠微。 逼想春山明月曙，玉坛清声步虚归。 逼伤茅山孙尊师三首 蝉蜕遗虚白，蜕飞入上清。 同人悲剑解，旧友觉衣轻。 黄鹄遥将举，斑麟俨未行。 唯应鲍说室，终夜识琴声。 空宇留丹鳌，层霄被羽衣。 旧山闻鹤化，遗乌尚亮飞。 数日奇香在，何年白鹄归？ 想君游下泊，方叹里闻非。 金格期初至，飕轮去不停。 山摧武担石，天陨少微星。 弟子悲徐甲，门人泣蔡经。 空闻留玉乌，犹在阜乡亭。 尊师是桃源黄先生得法弟子，尝见尊师称先师灵迹，今重赋此诗，兼寄题黄先生旧馆 后学方成市，今茅山宫观道士并是先生弟子也。 吾师久上宾。 洞天应不夜，源树只知春。 此并迹桃源事。 暮客留童子，瞿仙童即先生弟子。 桃源得仙人暮子，载在传记内。 山精避直神。 先生初至茅山，童子误触法铙，有声，先生疑山神所为，以符召致之，灵异如比。 无因握石髓，分与养生人。 右四诗石刻唐会昌癸亥年暮春十八日，秘书郎、上柱国裴质方书。 溪芦 楚客重兰荪，遗芳今未歇。
